ACT I
SCENE I. London. The palace.
Enter KING HENRY
So shaken as we are
To be commenced in strands afar remote.
No more the thirsty entrance of this soil
Shall daub her lips with her own children's blood;
Nor more shall trenching war channel her fields
Of hostile paces: those opposed eyes
And furious close of civil butchery
Shall now
Against acquaintance
The edge of war
We are impressed and engaged to fight
Whose arms were moulded in their mothers' womb
To chase these pagans in those holy fields
Over whose acres walk'd those blessed feet
Which fourteen hundred years ago were nail'd
For our advantage on the bitter cross.
But this our purpose now is twelve month old
Therefore we meet not now. Then let me hear
Of you
In forwarding this dear expedience.
My liege
But yesternight: when all athwart there came
A post from Wales loaden with heavy news;
Whose worst was
Against the irregular and wild Glendower
Upon whose dead corpse there was such misuse
Without much shame retold or spoken of.
It seems then that the tidings of this broil
Brake off our business for the Holy Land.
This match'd with other did
For more uneven and unwelcome news
Came from the north and thus it did import:
On Holy-rood day
For he that brought them
And pride of their contention did take horse
Here is a dear
Stain'd with the variation of each soil
Betwixt that Holmedon and this seat of ours;
And he hath brought us smooth and welcome news.
The Earl of Douglas is discomfited:
Ten thousand bold Scots
On Holmedon's plains. Of prisoners
Mordake the Earl of Fife
To beaten Douglas; and the Earl of Athol
And is not this an honourable spoil?
A gallant prize? ha
In faith
Yea
In envy that my Lord Northumberland
Should be the father to so blest a son
Amongst a grove
Who is sweet Fortune's minion and her pride:
Whilst I
Of my young Harry. O that it could be proved
That some night-tripping fairy had exchanged
In cradle-clothes our children where they lay
Then would I have his Harry
But let him from my thoughts. What think you
This is his uncle's teaching; this is Worcester
Which makes him prune himself
The crest of youth against your dignity.
But I have sent for him to answer this;
And for this cause awhile we must neglect
Our holy purpose to Jerusalem.
Cousin
Will hold at Windsor; so inform the lords:
But come yourself with speed to us again;
For more is to be said and to be done
Than out of anger can be uttered.
I will
Exeunt
SCENE II. London. An apartment of the Prince's.
Enter the PRINCE OF WALES and FALSTAFF
Now
Thou art so fat-witted
and unbuttoning thee after supper and sleeping upon
benches after noon
demand that truly which thou wouldst truly know.
What a devil hast thou to do with the time of the
day? Unless hours were cups of sack and minutes
capons and clocks the tongues of bawds and dials the
signs of leaping-houses and the blessed sun himself
a fair hot wench in flame-coloured taffeta
reason why thou shouldst be so superfluous to demand
the time of the day.
Indeed
purses go by the moon and the seven stars
by Phoebus
save thy grace
thou wilt have none
What
No
prologue to an egg and butter.
Well
Marry
us that are squires of the night's body be called
thieves of the day's beauty: let us be Diana's
foresters
moon; and let men say we be men of good government
chaste mistress the moon
Thou sayest well
fortune of us that are the moon's men doth ebb and
flow like the sea
most resolutely snatched on Monday night and most
dissolutely spent on Tuesday morning; got with
swearing 'Lay by' and spent with crying 'Bring in;'
now in as low an ebb as the foot of the ladder
and by and by in as high a flow as the ridge of the gallows.
By the Lord
hostess of the tavern a most sweet wench?
As the honey of Hybla
is not a buff jerkin a most sweet robe of durance?
How now
thy quiddities? what a plague have I to do with a
buff jerkin?
Why
Well
time and oft.
Did I ever call for thee to pay thy part?
No; I'll give thee thy due
Yea
and where it would not
Yea
that thou art heir apparent--But
wag
thou art king? and resolution thus fobbed as it is
with the rusty curb of old father antic the law? Do
not thou
No; thou shalt.
Shall I? O rare! By the Lord
Thou judgest false already: I mean
the hanging of the thieves and so become a rare hangman.
Well
humour as well as waiting in the court
you.
For obtaining of suits?
Yea
hath no lean wardrobe. 'Sblood
as a gib cat or a lugged bear.
Or an old lion
Yea
What sayest thou to a hare
Moor-ditch?
Thou hast the most unsavoury similes and art indeed
the most comparative
prince. But
with vanity. I would to God thou and I knew where a
commodity of good names were to be bought. An old
lord of the council rated me the other day in the
street about you
he talked very wisely
yet he talked wisely
Thou didst well; for wisdom cries out in the
streets
O
to corrupt a saint. Thou hast done much harm upon
me
thee
should speak truly
wicked. I must give over this life
it over: by the Lord
I'll be damned for never a king's son in
Christendom.
Where shall we take a purse tomorrow
'Zounds
do not
I see a good amendment of life in thee; from praying
to purse-taking.
Why
man to labour in his vocation.
Enter POINS
Poins! Now shall we know if Gadshill have set a
match. O
hole in hell were hot enough for him? This is the
most omnipotent villain that ever cried 'Stand' to
a true man.
Good morrow
Good morrow
what says Sir John Sack and Sugar? Jack! how
agrees the devil and thee about thy soul
soldest him on Good-Friday last for a cup of Madeira
and a cold capon's leg?
Sir John stands to his word
his bargain; for he was never yet a breaker of
proverbs: he will give the devil his due.
Then art thou damned for keeping thy word with the devil.
Else he had been damned for cozening the devil.
But
o'clock
to Canterbury with rich offerings
riding to London with fat purses: I have vizards
for you all; you have horses for yourselves:
Gadshill lies to-night in Rochester: I have bespoke
supper to-morrow night in Eastcheap: we may do it
as secure as sleep. If you will go
your purses full of crowns; if you will not
at home and be hanged.
Hear ye
You will
Hal
Who
There's neither honesty
fellowship in thee
royal
Well then
Why
Well
By the Lord
I care not.
Sir John
I will lay him down such reasons for this adventure
that he shall go.
Well
the ears of profiting
move and what he hears may be believed
true prince may
thief; for the poor abuses of the time want
countenance. Farewell: you shall find me in Eastcheap.
Farewell
Exit Falstaff
Now
to-morrow: I have a jest to execute that I cannot
manage alone. Falstaff
shall rob those men that we have already waylaid:
yourself and I will not be there; and when they
have the booty
this head off from my shoulders.
How shall we part with them in setting forth?
Why
appoint them a place of meeting
our pleasure to fail
upon the exploit themselves; which they shall have
no sooner achieved
Yea
horses
appointment
Tut! our horses they shall not see: I'll tie them
in the wood; our vizards we will change after we
leave them: and
for the nonce
Yea
Well
true-bred cowards as ever turned back; and for the
third
forswear arms. The virtue of this jest will be
incomprehensible lies that this same fat rogue will
tell us when we meet at supper: how thirty
least
extremities he endured; and in the reproof of this
lies the jest.
Well
necessary and meet me to-morrow night in Eastcheap;
there I'll sup. Farewell.
Farewell
Exit Poins
I know you all
The unyoked humour of your idleness:
Yet herein will I imitate the sun
To smother up his beauty from the world
Of vapours that did seem to strangle him.
If all the year were playing holidays
But when they seldom come
So
And pay the debt I never promised
And like bright metal on a sullen ground
Than that which hath no foil to set it off.
I'll so offend
Redeeming time when men think least I will.
Exit
SCENE III. London. The palace.
Enter the KING
My blood hath been too cold and temperate
You tread upon my patience: but be sure
I will from henceforth rather be myself
Which hath been smooth as oil
Which the proud soul ne'er pays but to the proud.
Our house
The scourge of greatness to be used on it;
And that same greatness too which our own hands
Have holp to make so portly.
My lord.--
Worcester
Danger and disobedience in thine eye:
O
The moody frontier of a servant brow.
You have good leave to leave us: when we need
Your use and counsel
Exit Worcester
You were about to speak.
To North
Yea
Those prisoners in your highness' name demanded
As is deliver'd to your majesty:
Either envy
Is guilty of this fault and not my son.
My liege
But I remember
Show'd like a stubble-land at harvest-home;
He was perfumed like a milliner;
And 'twixt his finger and his thumb he held
A pouncet-box
He gave his nose and took't away again;
Who therewith angry
Betwixt the wind and his nobility.
With many holiday and lady terms
He question'd me; amongst the rest
My prisoners in your majesty's behalf.
I then
To see him shine so brisk and smell so sweet
And talk so like a waiting-gentlewoman
Of guns and drums and wounds
And telling me the sovereign'st thing on earth
Was parmaceti for an inward bruise;
And that it was great pity
Out of the bowels of the harmless earth
So cowardly; and but for these vile guns
This bald unjointed chat of his
And I beseech you
Come current for an accusation
Betwixt my love and your high majesty.
The circumstance consider'd
To such a person and in such a place
To do him wrong or any way impeach
What then he said
Why
His brother-in-law
Who
The lives of those that he did lead to fight
Against that great magician
Hath lately married. Shall our coffers
Shall we but treason? and indent with fears
No
For I shall never hold that man my friend
Whose tongue shall ask me for one penny cost
To ransom home revolted Mortimer.
Revolted Mortimer!
He never did fall off
Needs no more but one tongue for all those wounds
When on the gentle Severn's sedgy bank
In changing hardiment with great Glendower:
Three times they breathed and three times did
they drink
Who then
Never did base and rotten policy
Colour her working with such deadly wounds;
Nor could the noble Mortimer
Receive so many
Then let not him be slander'd with revolt.
Thou dost belie him
He never did encounter with Glendower:
I tell thee
As Owen Glendower for an enemy.
Art thou not ashamed? But
Let me not hear you speak of Mortimer:
Send me your prisoners with the speediest means
As will displease you. My Lord Northumberland
Send us your prisoners
Exeunt King Henry
An if the devil come and roar for them
And tell him so; for I will ease my heart
What
Here comes your uncle.
Re-enter WORCESTER
Speak of Mortimer!
'Zounds
Want mercy
Yea
As high in the air as this unthankful king
Brother
Who struck this heat up after I was gone?
He will
And when I urged the ransom once again
Of my wife's brother
I cannot blame him: was not he proclaim'd
By Richard that dead is the next of blood?
He was; I heard the proclamation:
And then it was when the unhappy king
Upon his Irish expedition;
From whence he intercepted did return
To be deposed and shortly murdered.
And for whose death we in the world's wide mouth
Live scandalized and foully spoken of.
But soft
Proclaim my brother Edmund Mortimer
Heir to the crown?
He did; myself did hear it.
Nay
But shall it be that you
Upon the head of this forgetful man
And for his sake wear the detested blot
Of murderous subornation
O
Wherein you range under this subtle king;
Shall it for shame be spoken in these days
Did gage them both in an unjust behalf
And shall it in more shame be further spoken
By him for whom these shames ye underwent?
No; yet time serves wherein you may redeem
Your banish'd honours and restore yourselves
Into the good thoughts of the world again
Of this proud king
To answer all the debt he owes to you
Even with the bloody payment of your deaths:
Therefore
Peace
And now I will unclasp a secret book
I'll read you matter deep and dangerous
As to o'er-walk a current roaring loud
On the unsteadfast footing of a spear.
If he fall in
Send danger from the east unto the west
To rouse a lion than to start a hare!
Imagination of some great exploit
Drives him beyond the bounds of patience.
By heaven
So he that doth redeem her thence might wear
Without corrival
But out upon this half-faced fellowship!
He apprehends a world of figures here
Good cousin
I cry you mercy.
Those same noble Scots
That are your prisoners
I'll keep them all;
By God
No
I'll keep them
You start away
And lend no ear unto my purposes.
Those prisoners you shall keep.
Nay
He said he would not ransom Mortimer;
Forbad my tongue to speak of Mortimer;
But I will find him when he lies asleep
Nay
Nothing but 'Mortimer
To keep his anger still in motion.
Hear you
All studies here I solemnly defy
And that same sword-and-buckler Prince of Wales
And would be glad he met with some mischance
Farewell
When you are better temper'd to attend.
Why
Art thou to break into this woman's mood
Why
Of this vile politician
In Richard's time
A plague upon it
'Twas where the madcap duke his uncle kept
Unto this king of smiles
'Sblood!--
When you and he came back from Ravenspurgh.
At Berkley castle.
You say true:
Why
This fawning greyhound then did proffer me!
Look
And 'gentle Harry Percy
O
Good uncle
Nay
We will stay your leisure.
I have done
Then once more to your Scottish prisoners.
Deliver them up without their ransom straight
For powers in Scotland; which
Which I shall send you written
Your son in Scotland being thus employ'd
Of that same noble prelate
Of York
True; who bears hard
His brother's death at Bristol
I speak not this in estimation
Is ruminated
Of that occasion that shall bring it on.
I smell it: upon my life
Before the game is afoot
Why
And then the power of Scotland and of York
And so they shall.
In faith
And 'tis no little reason bids us speed
For
And see already how he doth begin
To make us strangers to his looks of love.
He does
Cousin
Than I by letters shall direct your course.
When time is ripe
Where you and Douglas and our powers at once
Farewell
Uncle
Till fields and blows and groans applaud our sport!
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Rochester. An inn yard.
Enter a Carrier with a lantern in his hand
Heigh-ho! an it be not four by the day
hanged: Charles' wain is over the new chimney
yet our horse not packed. What
[Within]   Anon
I prithee
in the point; poor jade
of all cess.
Enter another Carrier
Peas and beans are as dank here as a dog
is the next way to give poor jades the bots: this
house is turned upside down since Robin Ostler died.
Poor fellow
rose; it was the death of him.
I think this be the most villanous house in all
London road for fleas: I am stung like a tench.
Like a tench! by the mass
christen could be better bit than I have been since
the first cock.
Why
leak in your chimney; and your chamber-lie breeds
fleas like a loach.
What
I have a gammon of bacon and two razors of ginger
God's body! the turkeys in my pannier are quite
starved. What
never an eye in thy head? canst not hear? An
'twere not as good deed as drink
on thee
hast thou no faith in thee?

Good morrow
I think it be two o'clock.
I pray thee lend me thy lantern
in the stable.
Nay
I pray thee
Ay

Sirrah carrier
Time enough to go to bed with a candle

Good morrow

company last night at supper; a kind of auditor; one
that hath abundance of charge too

No

Enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS

Poins! Poins

Where's Poins
He is walked up to the top of the hill: I'll go seek him.
I am accursed to rob in that thief's company: the
rascal hath removed my horse
not where. If I travel but four foot by the squier
further afoot
not but to die a fair death for all this

rogue's company. If the rascal hath not given me

could not be else: I have drunk medicines. Poins!

I'll starve ere I'll rob a foot further. An 'twere
not as good a deed as drink
leave these rogues
ever chewed with a tooth. Eight yards of uneven
ground is threescore and ten miles afoot with me;
and the stony-hearted villains know it well enough:
a plague upon it when thieves cannot be true one to another!
They whistle
Whew! A plague upon you all! Give me my horse
rogues; give me my horse
Peace

Villains!
As they are sharing
Got with much ease. Now merrily to horse:
The thieves are all scatter'd and possess'd with fear
So strongly that they dare not meet each other;
Each takes his fellow for an officer.
Away
Were 't not for laughing
How the rogue roar'd!

SCENE III. Warkworth castle
Enter HOTSPUR
'But for mine own part
contented to be there
your house.' He could be contented: why is he not
he shows in this
he loves our house. Let me see some more. 'The

certain: 'tis dangerous to take a cold

nettle

Enter LADY PERCY
How now
O
For what offence have I this fortnight been
A banish'd woman from my Harry's bed?
Tell me
Thy stomach
Why dost thou bend thine eyes upon the earth
Why hast thou lost the fresh blood in thy cheeks;
And given my treasures and my rights of thee
To thick-eyed musing and cursed melancholy?
In thy faint slumbers I by thee have watch'd
Speak terms of manage to thy bounding steed;
Cry 'Courage! to the field!' And thou hast talk'd
Of sallies and retires
Thy spirit within thee hath been so at war
And thus hath so bestirr'd thee in thy sleep
Like bubbles in a late-disturbed stream;
And in thy face strange motions have appear'd
On some great sudden hest. O
Some heavy business hath my lord in hand
What
Enter Servant
Is Gilliams with the packet gone?
He is

One horse

It is

Well

But hear you

Why
Out
A weasel hath not such a deal of spleen
As you are toss'd with. In faith
I fear my brother Mortimer doth stir
About his title
To line his enterprise: but if you go
So far afoot
Come

In faith

We must have bloody noses and crack'd crowns

in it. A villanous coward! Go thy ways

not forgot upon the face of the earth
shotten herring. There live not three good men

grows old: God help the while! a bad world
I would I were a weaver; I could sing psalms or any
thing. A plague of all cowards
How now

O villain! thy lips are scarce wiped since thou

ACT III
SCENE I. Bangor. The Archdeacon's house.
Enter HOTSPUR
These promises are fair
Lord Mortimer
And uncle Worcester: a plague upon it!
I have forgot the map.
No
Sit
Doth speak of you
A rising sigh he wisheth you in heaven.
And you in hell
I cannot blame him: at my nativity
The front of heaven was full of fiery shapes
The frame and huge foundation of the earth
Shaked like a coward.
Why
your mother's cat had but kittened
had never been born.
I say the earth did shake when I was born.
And I say the earth was not of my mind
The heavens were all on fire
O
Diseased nature oftentimes breaks forth
In strange eruptions; oft the teeming earth
Is with a kind of colic pinch'd and vex'd
By the imprisoning of unruly wind
Within her womb; which
Steeples and moss-grown towers. At your birth
Our grandam earth
Cousin
I do not bear these crossings. Give me leave
To tell you once again that at my birth
The front of heaven was full of fiery shapes
Were strangely clamorous to the frighted fields.
These signs have mark'd me extraordinary;
And all the courses of my life do show
I am not in the roll of common men.
Where is he living
That chides the banks of England
And bring him out that is but woman's son
Can trace me in the tedious ways of art
And hold me pace in deep experiments.
I think there's no man speaks better Welsh.
I'll to dinner.
Peace
I can call spirits from the vasty deep.
Why
But will they come when you do call for them?
Why
The devil.
And I can teach thee
By telling truth: tell truth and shame the devil.
If thou have power to raise him
O
Come
Three times hath Henry Bolingbroke made head
Against my power; thrice from the banks of Wye
And sandy-bottom'd Severn have I sent him
Bootless home and weather-beaten back.
Home without boots
How 'scapes he agues
Come
According to our threefold order ta'en?
The archdeacon hath divided it
Into three limits very equally:
England
All westward
The remnant northward
And our indentures tripartite are drawn;
Which being sealed interchangeably
And my good Lord of Worcester will set forth
To meet your father and the Scottish power
My father Glendower is not ready yet
Within that space you may have drawn together
Your tenants
A shorter time shall send me to you
And in my conduct shall your ladies come;
From whom you now must steal and take no leave
Upon the parting of your wives and you.
Methinks my moiety
See how this river comes me cranking in
A huge half-moon
I'll have the current in this place damm'd up;
And here the smug and silver Trent shall run
In a new channel
It shall not wind with such a deep indent
Not wind? it shall
Yea
Mark how he bears his course
With like advantage on the other side;
Gelding the opposed continent as much
As on the other side it takes from you.
Yea
And on this north side win this cape of land;
And then he runs straight and even.
I'll have it so: a little charge will do it.
I'll not have it alter'd.
Will not you?
No
Who shall say me nay?
Why
Let me not understand you
I can speak English
For I was train'd up in the English court;
Where
Many an English ditty lovely well
And gave the tongue a helpful ornament
Marry
I had rather be a kitten and cry mew
Than one of these same metre ballad-mongers;
I had rather hear a brazen canstick turn'd
And that would set my teeth nothing on edge
'Tis like the forced gait of a shuffling nag.
Come
I do not care: I'll give thrice so much land
To any well-deserving friend;
But in the way of bargain
Are the indentures drawn? shall we be gone?
The moon shines fair; you may away by night:
I'll haste the writer and withal
Break with your wives of your departure hence:
I am afraid my daughter will run mad
Exit GLENDOWER
Fie
I cannot choose: sometime he angers me
With telling me of the mouldwarp and the ant
As puts me from my faith. I tell you what;
He held me last night at least nine hours
In reckoning up the several devils' names
That were his lackeys: I cried 'hum
But mark'd him not a word. O
As a tired horse
Worse than a smoky house: I had rather live
With cheese and garlic in a windmill
In any summer-house in Christendom.
In faith
In strange concealments
And as wondrous affable and as bountiful
As mines of India. Shall I tell you
He holds your temper in a high respect
And curbs himself even of his natural scope
When you come 'cross his humour; faith
I warrant you
Might so have tempted him as you have done
But do not use it oft
In faith
And since your coming hither have done enough
To put him quite beside his patience.
You must needs learn
Though sometimes it show greatness
And that's the dearest grace it renders you
Yet oftentimes it doth present harsh rage
The least of which haunting a nobleman
Loseth men's hearts and leaves behind a stain
Upon the beauty of all parts besides
Well
Here come our wives
Re-enter GLENDOWER with the ladies
This is the deadly spite that angers me;
My wife can speak no English
My daughter weeps: she will not part with you;
She'll be a soldier too
Good father
Shall follow in your conduct speedily.
Glendower speaks to her in Welsh
She is desperate here; a peevish self-wind harlotry
The lady speaks in Welsh
I understand thy looks: that pretty Welsh
Which thou pour'st down from these swelling heavens
I am too perfect in; and
The lady speaks again in Welsh
I understand thy kisses and thou mine
But I will never be a truant
Makes Welsh as sweet as ditties highly penn'd
Nay
The lady speaks again in Welsh
O
She bids you on the wanton rushes lay you down
And rest your gentle head upon her lap
And on your eyelids crown the god of sleep.
Charming your blood with pleasing heaviness
As is the difference betwixt day and night
The hour before the heavenly-harness'd team
Begins his golden progress in the east.
With all my heart I'll sit and hear her sing:
By that time will our book
Do so;
And those musicians that shall play to you
Hang in the air a thousand leagues from hence
Come
Go
The music plays
Now I perceive the devil understands Welsh;
And 'tis no marvel he is so humorous.
By'r lady
Then should you be nothing but musical for you are
altogether governed by humours. Lie still
I had rather hear Lady
Wouldst thou have thy head broken?
No.
Then be still.
Neither;'tis a woman's fault.
Now God help thee!
To the Welsh lady's bed.
What's that?
Peace! she sings.
Here the lady sings a Welsh song
Come
Not mine
Not yours
comfit-maker's wife. 'Not you
'as true as I live

Swear me

'Tis the next way to turn tailor

Exit
Come
As hot Lord Percy is on fire to go.
By this our book is drawn; we'll but seal
With all my heart.
Exeunt
SCENE II. London. The palace.
Enter KING HENRY IV
Lords
Must have some private conference; but be near at hand
Exeunt Lords
I know not whether God will have it so
He'll breed revengement and a scourge for me;
But thou dost in thy passages of life
Make me believe that thou art only mark'd
For the hot vengeance and the rod of heaven
To punish my mistreadings. Tell me else
And hold their level with thy princely heart?
So please your majesty
Quit all offences with as clear excuse
As well as I am doubtless I can purge
Myself of many I am charged withal:
Yet such extenuation let me beg
Hath faulty wander'd and irregular
God pardon thee! yet let me wonder
Quite from the flight of all thy ancestors.
Thy place in council thou hast rudely lost.
Which by thy younger brother is supplied
Of all the court and princes of my blood:
The hope and expectation of thy time
Is ruin'd
Prophetically doth forethink thy fall.
Had I so lavish of my presence been
And left me in reputeless banishment
By being seldom seen
But like a comet I was wonder'd at;
That men would tell their children 'This is he;'
Others would say 'Where
And then I stole all courtesy from heaven
That I did pluck allegiance from men's hearts
Thus did I keep my person fresh and new;
My presence
And won by rareness such solemnity.
The skipping king
With shallow jesters and rash bavin wits
And gave his countenance
Of every beardless vain comparative
That
To loathe the taste of sweetness
More than a little is by much too much.
So when he had occasion to be seen
As
When it shines seldom in admiring eyes;
But rather drowzed and hung their eyelids down
As cloudy men use to their adversaries
And in that very line
For thou has lost thy princely privilege
With vile participation: not an eye
But is a-weary of thy common sight
Which now doth that I would not have it do
I shall hereafter
For all the world
As thou art to this hour was Richard then
When I from France set foot at Ravenspurgh
Now
Than thou the shadow of succession;
For of no right
To bloody battles and to bruising arms.
What never-dying honour hath he got
Against renowned Douglas! whose high deeds
Holds from all soldiers chief majority
And military title capital
Through all the kingdoms that acknowledge Christ:
Thrice hath this Hotspur
Discomfited great Douglas
And shake the peace and safety of our throne.
And what say you to this? Percy
But wherefore do I tell these news to thee?
Why
Thou that art like enough
To fight against me under Percy's pay
Do not think so; you shall not find it so:
And God forgive them that so much have sway'd
Your majesty's good thoughts away from me!
I will redeem all this on Percy's head
And in the closing of some glorious day
Be bold to tell you that I am your son;
When I will wear a garment all of blood
And stain my favours in a bloody mask
And that shall be the day
For every honour sitting on his helm
My shames redoubled! for the time will come
His glorious deeds for my indignities.
Percy is but my factor
And I will call him to so strict account
This
The which if He be pleased I shall perform
The long-grown wounds of my intemperance:
If not
And I will die a hundred thousand deaths
Ere break the smallest parcel of this vow.
A hundred thousand rebels die in this:
Thou shalt have charge and sovereign trust herein.
Enter BLUNT
How now
So hath the business that I come to speak of.
Lord Mortimer of Scotland hath sent word
That Douglas and the English rebels met
The eleventh of this month at Shrewsbury
A mighty and a fearful head they are
The Earl of Westmoreland set forth to-day;
With him my son
For this advertisement is five days old:
On Wednesday next
On Thursday we ourselves will march: our meeting
Is Bridgenorth: and
Through Gloucestershire; by which account
Our general forces at Bridgenorth shall meet.
Our hands are full of business: let's away;
Advantage feeds him fat
Exeunt

o'clock in the afternoon.
There shalt thou know thy charge; and there receive
Money and order for their furniture.
The land is burning; Percy stands on high;
And either we or they must lower lie.
Exit PRINCE HENRY
Rare words! brave world! Hostess
O
Exit
ACT IV
SCENE I. The rebel camp near Shrewsbury.
Enter HOTSPUR
Well said
In this fine age were not thought flattery
Should go so general current through the world.
By God
The tongues of soothers; but a braver place
In my heart's love hath no man than yourself:
Nay
Thou art the king of honour:
No man so potent breathes upon the ground
But I will beard him.
Do so
Enter a Messenger with letters
What letters hast thou there?--I can but thank you.
These letters come from your father.
Letters from him! why comes he not himself?
He cannot come
'Zounds! how has he the leisure to be sick
In such a rustling time? Who leads his power?
Under whose government come they along?
His letters bear his mind
I prithee
He did
And at the time of my departure thence
He was much fear'd by his physicians.
I would the state of time had first been whole
Ere he by sickness had been visited:
His health was never better worth than now.
Sick now! droop now! this sickness doth infect
The very life-blood of our enterprise;
'Tis catching hither
He writes me here
And that his friends by deputation could not
So soon be drawn
To lay so dangerous and dear a trust
On any soul removed but on his own.
Yet doth he give us bold advertisement
For
Because the king is certainly possess'd
Of all our purposes. What say you to it?
Your father's sickness is a maim to us.
A perilous gash
And yet
Seems more than we shall find it: were it good
To set the exact wealth of all our states
All at one cast? to set so rich a main
On the nice hazard of one doubtful hour?
It were not good; for therein should we read
The very bottom and the soul of hope
Of all our fortunes.
'Faith
Where now remains a sweet reversion:
We may boldly spend upon the hope of what
Is to come in:
A comfort of retirement lives in this.
A rendezvous
If that the devil and mischance look big
Upon the maidenhead of our affairs.
But yet I would your father had been here.
The quality and hair of our attempt
Brooks no division: it will be thought
By some
Of our proceedings kept the earl from hence:
And think how such an apprehension
May turn the tide of fearful faction
And breed a kind of question in our cause;
For well you know we of the offering side
Must keep aloof from strict arbitrement
The eye of reason may pry in upon us:
This absence of your father's draws a curtain
Before not dreamt of.
You strain too far.
I rather of his absence make this use:
It lends a lustre and more great opinion
To push against a kingdom
We shall o'erturn it topsy-turvy down.
Yet all goes well
As heart can think: there is not such a word
Spoke of in Scotland as this term of fear.
Enter SIR RICHARD VERNON
My cousin Vernon
Pray God my news be worth a welcome
The Earl of Westmoreland
No harm: what more?
And further
He shall be welcome too. Where is his son
All furnish'd
All plumed like estridges that with the wind
Baited like eagles having lately bathed;
Glittering in golden coats
As full of spirit as the month of May
Wanton as youthful goats
I saw young Harry
Rise from the ground like feather'd Mercury
And witch the world with noble horsemanship.
No more
They come like sacrifices in their trim
All hot and bleeding will we offer them:
The mailed Mars shall on his altar sit
Up to the ears in blood. I am on fire
To hear this rich reprisal is so nigh
And yet not ours. Come
Against the bosom of the Prince of Wales:
Harry to Harry shall
O that Glendower were come!
There is more news:
I learn'd in Worcester
That's the worst tidings that I hear of yet.
Ay
What may the king's whole battle reach unto?
To thirty thousand.
Forty let it be:
My father and Glendower being both away
Come
Doomsday is near; die all
Talk not of dying: I am out of fear
Of death or death's hand for this one-half year.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A public road near Coventry.
Enter FALSTAFF and BARDOLPH
Bardolph
bottle of sack: our soldiers shall march through;
we'll to Sutton Co'fil' tonight.
Will you give me money
Lay out
This bottle makes an angel.
An if it do
twenty
my lieutenant Peto meet me at town's end.
I will
Exit
If I be not ashamed of my soldiers
gurnet. I have misused the king's press damnably.
I have got
soldiers
none but good house-holders
me out contracted bachelors
twice on the banns; such a commodity of warm slaves
fear the report of a caliver worse than a struck
fowl or a hurt wild-duck. I pressed me none but such
toasts-and-butter
bigger than pins' heads
their services; and now my whole charge consists of
ancients
companies
painted cloth
sores; and such as indeed were never soldiers
discarded unjust serving-men
younger brothers
trade-fallen
long peace
an old faced ancient: and such have I
the rooms of them that have bought out their
services
and fifty tattered prodigals lately come from
swine-keeping
fellow met me on the way and told me I had unloaded
all the gibbets and pressed the dead bodies. No eye
hath seen such scarecrows. I'll not march through
Coventry with them
villains march wide betwixt the legs
gyves on; for indeed I had the most of them out of
prison. There's but a shirt and a half in all my
company; and the half shirt is two napkins tacked
together and thrown over the shoulders like an
herald's coat without sleeves; and the shirt
the truth
the red-nose innkeeper of Daventry. But that's all
one; they'll find linen enough on every hedge.
Enter the PRINCE and WESTMORELAND
How now
What
in Warwickshire? My good Lord of Westmoreland
cry you mercy: I thought your honour had already been
at Shrewsbury.
Faith
there
The king
away all night.
Tut
steal cream.
I think
already made thee butter. But tell me
fellows are these that come after?
Mine
I did never see such pitiful rascals.
Tut
for powder; they'll fill a pit as well as better:
tush
Ay
and bare
'Faith
that; and for their bareness
learned that of me.
No I'll be sworn; unless you call three fingers on
the ribs bare. But
already in the field.
What
He is
Well
Fits a dull fighter and a keen guest.
Exeunt
SCENE III. The rebel camp near Shrewsbury.
Enter HOTSPUR
We'll fight with him to-night.
It may not be.
You give him then the advantage.
Not a whit.
Why say you so? looks he not for supply?
So do we.
His is certain
Good cousin
Do not
You do not counsel well:
You speak it out of fear and cold heart.
Do me no slander
As you
Let it be seen to-morrow in the battle
Which of us fears.
Yea
Content.
To-night
Come
Drag back our expedition: certain horse
Of my cousin Vernon's are not yet come up:
Your uncle Worcester's horse came but today;
And now their pride and mettle is asleep
So are the horses of the enemy
In general
The better part of ours are full of rest.
The number of the king exceedeth ours:
For God's sake. cousin
The trumpet sounds a parley
Enter SIR WALTER BLUNT
I come with gracious offers from the king
Welcome
You were of our determination!
Some of us love you well; and even those some
Envy your great deservings and good name
And God defend but still I should stand so
You stand against anointed majesty.
But to my charge. The king hath sent to know
The nature of your griefs
You conjure from the breast of civil peace
Such bold hostility
Audacious cruelty. If that the king
Have any way your good deserts forgot
You shall have your desires with interest
And pardon absolute for yourself and these
Herein misled by your suggestion.
The king is kind; and well we know the king
Knows at what time to promise
My father and my uncle and myself
Did give him that same royalty he wears;
And when he was not six and twenty strong
And when he heard him swear and vow to God
He came but to be Duke of Lancaster
Now when the lords and barons of the realm
Perceived Northumberland did lean to him
Met him in boroughs
Even at the heels in golden multitudes.
He presently
Made to my father
And now
Some certain edicts and some strait decrees
That lie too heavy on the commonwealth
Over his country's wrongs; and by this face
The hearts of all that he did angle for;
Proceeded further; cut me off the heads
Of all the favourites that the absent king
In deputation left behind him here
Tut
Then to the point.
In short time after
Soon after that
And in the neck of that
To make that worse
Disgraced me in my happy victories
Rated mine uncle from the council-board;
In rage dismiss'd my father from the court;
Broke oath on oath
This head of safety; and withal to pry
Into his title
Too indirect for long continuance.
Shall I return this answer to the king?
Not so
Go to the king; and let there be impawn'd
Some surety for a safe return again
Bring him our purposes: and so farewell.
I would you would accept of grace and love.
And may be so we shall.
Pray God you do.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. York. The ARCHBISHOP'S palace.
Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK and SIR MICHAEL
Hie
With winged haste to the lord marshal;
This to my cousin Scroop
To whom they are directed. If you knew
How much they do to import
My good lord
Like enough you do.
To-morrow
Wherein the fortune of ten thousand men
Must bide the touch; for
Meets with Lord Harry: and
And comes not in
To wage an instant trial with the king.
Why
There is Douglas and Lord Mortimer.
No
But there is Mordake
Of gallant warriors
And so there is: but yet the king hath drawn
The special head of all the land together:
The Prince of Wales
And moe corrivals and dear men
Of estimation and command in arms.
Doubt not
I hope no less
And
For if Lord Percy thrive not
Dismiss his power
Therefore make haste. I must go write again
To other friends; and so farewell
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. KING HENRY IV's camp near Shrewsbury.
Enter KING HENRY
How bloodily the sun begins to peer
Above yon busky hill! the day looks pale
At his distemperature.
The southern wind
Doth play the trumpet to his purposes
Foretells a tempest and a blustering day.
Then with the losers let it sympathize
The trumpet sounds
Enter WORCESTER and VERNON
How now
That you and I should meet upon such terms
As now we meet. You have deceived our trust
This is not well
What say you to it? will you again unknit
This curlish knot of all-abhorred war?
And move in that obedient orb again
Where you did give a fair and natural light
Of broached mischief to the unborn times?
Hear me
For mine own part
To entertain the lag-end of my life
With quiet hours; for I do protest
You have not sought it! how comes it
Rebellion lay in his way
Peace
It pleased your majesty to turn your looks
Of favour from myself and all our house;
And yet I must remember you
For you my staff of office did I break
In Richard's time; and posted day and night
to meet you on the way
Nothing so strong and fortunate as I.
It was myself
The dangers of the time. You swore to us
Nor claim no further than your new-fall'n right
To this we swore our aid. But in short space
It rain'd down fortune showering on your head;
And such a flood of greatness fell on you
So long in his unlucky Irish wars
That all in England did repute him dead:
And from this swarm of fair advantages
You took occasion to be quickly woo'd
To gripe the general sway into your hand;
Forget your oath to us at Doncaster;
And being fed by us you used us so
As that ungentle hull
Grew by our feeding to so great a bulk
That even our love durst not come near your sight
For fear of swallowing; but with nimble wing
We were enforced
Out of sight and raise this present head;
Whereby we stand opposed by such means
As you yourself have forged against yourself
By unkind usage
Sworn to us in your younger enterprise.
These things indeed you have articulate
With some fine colour that may please the eye
Of fickle changelings and poor discontents
Of hurlyburly innovation:
And never yet did insurrection want
Such water-colours to impaint his cause;
Nor moody beggars
Of pellmell havoc and confusion.
In both your armies there is many a soul
Shall pay full dearly for this encounter
In praise of Henry Percy: by my hopes
To grace this latter age with noble deeds.
For my part
And so I hear he doth account me too;
Yet this before my father's majesty--
I am content that he shall take the odds
Of his great name and estimation
And
Do make against it. No
That are misled upon your cousin's part;
And
Shall be my friend again and I'll be his:
So tell your cousin
What he will do: but if he will not yield
And they shall do their office. So
We will not now be troubled with reply:
We offer fair; take it advisedly.
Exeunt WORCESTER and VERNON
It will not be accepted
The Douglas and the Hotspur both together
Are confident against the world in arms.
Hence
For
And God befriend us
Exeunt all but PRINCE HENRY and FALSTAFF
Hal
me
Nothing but a colossus can do thee that friendship.
Say thy prayers
I  would 'twere bed-time
Why
Exit PRINCE HENRY
'Tis not due yet; I would be loath to pay him before
his day. What need I be so forward with him that
calls not on me? Well
me on. Yea
come on? how then? Can honour set to a leg? no: or
an arm? no: or take away the grief of a wound? no.
Honour hath no skill in surgery
honour? a word. What is in that word honour? what
is that honour? air. A trim reckoning! Who hath it?
he that died o' Wednesday. Doth he feel it? no.
Doth he hear it? no. 'Tis insensible
no. Why? detraction will not suffer it. Therefore
I'll none of it. Honour is a mere scutcheon: and so
ends my catechism.
Exit
SCENE II. The rebel camp.
Enter WORCESTER and VERNON
O
'Twere best he did.
Then are we all undone.
It is not possible
He will suspect us still and find a time
To punish this offence in other faults:
Suspicion all our lives shall be stuck full of eyes;
For treason is but trusted like the fox
Look how we can
My nephew's trespass may be well forgot;
it hath the excuse of youth and heat of blood
All his offences live upon my head
And on his father's; we did train him on
Therefore
Deliver what you will; I'll say 'tis so.
Here comes your cousin.
Enter HOTSPUR and DOUGLAS
My uncle is return'd:
Deliver up my Lord of Westmoreland.
Uncle
The king will bid you battle presently.
Defy him by the Lord of Westmoreland.
Lord Douglas
Marry
Exit
There is no seeming mercy in the king.
Did you beg any? God forbid!
I told him gently of our grievances
He calls us rebels
With haughty arms this hateful name in us.
Re-enter the EARL OF DOUGLAS
Arm
A brave defiance in King Henry's teeth
Which cannot choose but bring him quickly on.
The Prince of Wales stepp'd forth before the king
O
But I and Harry Monmouth! Tell me
No
Did hear a challenge urged more modestly
To gentle exercise and proof of arms.
He gave you all the duties of a man;
Trimm'd up your praises with a princely tongue
By still dispraising praise valued in you;
And
And chid his truant youth with such a grace
As if he master'd there a double spirit.
Of teaching and of learning instantly.
There did he pause: but let me tell the world
Cousin
On his follies: never did I hear
Of any prince so wild a libertine.
But be he as he will
I will embrace him with a soldier's arm
Arm
Than I
Enter a Messenger
My lord
I cannot read them now.
O gentlemen
To spend that shortness basely were too long
An if we live
If die
Now
Enter another Messenger
My lord
I thank him
Let each man do his best: and here draw I
A sword
With the best blood that I can meet withal
In the adventure of this perilous day.
Now
Sound all the lofty instruments of war
For
A second time do such a courtesy.
The trumpets sound. They embrace
SCENE III. Plain between the camps.
KING HENRY enters with his power. Alarum to the battle. Then enter DOUGLAS and SIR WALTER BLUNT
What is thy name
Thou crossest me? what honour dost thou seek
Upon my head?
Know then
And I do haunt thee in the battle thus
Because some tell me that thou art a king.
They tell thee true.
The Lord of Stafford dear to-day hath bought
Thy likeness
I was not born a yielder
And thou shalt find a king that will revenge
Lord Stafford's death.
They fight. DOUGLAS kills SIR WALTER BLUNT. Enter HOTSPUR
O Douglas
All's done
Where?
Here.
This
A gallant knight he was
Semblably furnish'd like the king himself.
A fool go with thy soul
A borrow'd title hast thou bought too dear:
Why didst thou tell me that thou wert a king?
The king hath many marching in his coats.
Now
I'll murder all his wardrobe
Up
Our soldiers stand full fairly for the day.
Exeunt
Alarum. Enter FALSTAFF
Though I could 'scape shot-free at London
the shot here; here's no scoring but upon the pate.
Soft! who are you? Sir Walter Blunt: there's honour
for you! here's no vanity! I am as hot as moulten
lead
need no more weight than mine own bowels. I have
led my ragamuffins where they are peppered: there's
not three of my hundred and fifty left alive; and
they are for the town's end
But who comes here?
Enter PRINCE HENRY
What
Many a nobleman lies stark and stiff
Under the hoofs of vaunting enemies
O Hal
Turk Gregory never did such deeds in arms as I have
done this day. I have paid Percy
He is
Nay
not my sword; but take my pistol
Give it to me: what
Ay
PRINCE HENRY draws it out
What
He throws the bottle at him. Exit
Well
come in my way
willingly
not such grinning honour as Sir Walter hath: give me
life: which if I can save
unlooked for
Exit FALSTAFF
SCENE IV. Another part of the field.
Alarum. Excursions. Enter PRINCE HENRY
I prithee
Lord John of Lancaster
Not I
I beseech your majesty
I will do so.
My Lord of Westmoreland
Come
Lead me
And God forbid a shallow scratch should drive
The Prince of Wales from such a field as this
We breathe too long: come
Exeunt LANCASTER and WESTMORELAND
By God
I did not think thee lord of such a spirit:
Before
But now
I saw him hold Lord Percy at the point
With lustier maintenance than I did look for
Of such an ungrown warrior.
O
Lends mettle to us all!
Exit
Enter DOUGLAS
Another king! they grow like Hydra's heads:
I am the Douglas
That wear those colours on them: what art thou
The king himself; who
So many of his shadows thou hast met
And not the very king. I have two boys
Seek Percy and thyself about the field:
But
I fear thou art another counterfeit;
And yet
But mine I am sure thou art
They fight. KING HENRY being in danger
Hold up thy head
Never to hold it up again! the spirits
Of valiant Shirley
It is the Prince of Wales that threatens thee;
Who never promiseth but he means to pay.
They fight: DOUGLAS flies
Cheerly
Sir Nicholas Gawsey hath for succor sent
Stay
Thou hast redeem'd thy lost opinion
O God! they did me too much injury
That ever said I hearken'd for your death.
If it were so
The insulting hand of Douglas over you
As all the poisonous potions in the world
And saved the treacherous labour of your son.
Make up to Clifton: I'll to Sir Nicholas Gawsey.
Exit
Enter HOTSPUR
If I mistake not
Thou speak'st as if I would deny my name.
My name is Harry Percy.
Why
A very valiant rebel of the name.
I am the Prince of Wales; and think not
Two stars keep not their motion in one sphere;
Nor can one England brook a double reign
Nor shall it
To end the one of us; and would to God
Thy name in arms were now as great as mine!
I'll make it greater ere I part from thee;
And all the budding honours on thy crest
I'll crop
I can no longer brook thy vanities.
They fight
Enter FALSTAFF
Well said
boy's play here
Re-enter DOUGLAS; he fights with FALSTAFF
O
I better brook the loss of brittle life
Than those proud titles thou hast won of me;
They wound my thoughts worse than sword my flesh:
But thought's the slave of life
And time
Lies on my tongue: no
And food for--
Dies
For worms
Ill-weaved ambition
When that this body did contain a spirit
But now two paces of the vilest earth
Is room enough: this earth that bears thee dead
Bears not alive so stout a gentleman.
If thou wert sensible of courtesy
But let my favours hide thy mangled face;
And
For doing these fair rites of tenderness.
Adieu
Thy ignominy sleep with thee in the grave
He spieth FALSTAFF on the ground
What
Keep in a little life? Poor Jack
I could have better spared a better man:
O
Death hath not struck so fat a deer to-day
Embowell'd will I see thee by and by:
Till then in blood by noble Percy lie.
Exit PRINCE HENRY
[Rising up]  Embowelled! if thou embowel me to-day
to-morrow. 'Sblood
that hot termagant Scot had paid me scot and lot too.
Counterfeit? I lie
counterfeit of a man who hath not the life of a man:
but to counterfeit dying
liveth
perfect image of life indeed. The better part of
valour is discretion; in the which better part I
have saved my life.'Zounds
gunpowder Percy
should counterfeit too and rise? by my faith
afraid he would prove the better counterfeit.
Therefore I'll make him sure; yea
killed him. Why may not he rise as well as I?
Nothing confutes me but eyes
Therefore
with a new wound in your thigh
Takes up HOTSPUR on his back
Re-enter PRINCE HENRY and LORD JOHN OF LANCASTER
Come
Thy maiden sword.
But
Did you not tell me this fat man was dead?
I did; I saw him dead
thou alive?
Or is it fantasy that plays upon our eyesight?
I prithee
Without our ears: thou art not what thou seem'st.
No
be not Jack Falstaff
Throwing the body down
if your father will do me any honour
him kill the next Percy himself. I look to be either
earl or duke
Why
Didst thou? Lord
lying! I grant you I was down and out of breath;
and so was he: but we rose both at an instant and
fought a long hour by Shrewsbury clock. If I may be
believed
valour bear the sin upon their own heads. I'll take
it upon my death
thigh: if the man were alive and would deny it
This is the strangest tale that ever I heard.
This is the strangest fellow
Come
For my part
A retreat is sounded
The trumpet sounds retreat; the day is ours.
Come
Exeunt PRINCE HENRY and LANCASTER
I'll follow
rewards me
live cleanly as a nobleman should do.
Exit
SCENE V. Another part of the field.
The trumpets sound. Enter KING HENRY IV
Thus ever did rebellion find rebuke.
Ill-spirited Worcester! did not we send grace
And wouldst thou turn our offers contrary?
Misuse the tenor of thy kinsman's trust?
Three knights upon our party slain to-day
Had been alive this hour
Betwixt our armies true intelligence.
What I have done my safety urged me to;
And I embrace this fortune patiently
Bear Worcester to the death and Vernon too:
Other offenders we will pause upon.
Exeunt WORCESTER and VERNON
How goes the field?
The noble Scot
The fortune of the day quite turn'd from him
Upon the foot of fear
And falling from a hill
That the pursuers took him. At my tent
The Douglas is; and I beseech your grace
I may dispose of him.
With all my heart.
Then
This honourable bounty shall belong:
Go to the Douglas
Up to his pleasure
His valour shown upon our crests to-day
Hath taught us how to cherish such high deeds
Even in the bosom of our adversaries.
I thank your grace for this high courtesy
Then this remains
You
Towards York shall bend you with your dearest speed
Myself and you
Rebellion in this land shall lose his sway
And since this business so fair is done
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. Westminster Abbey.
Dead March. Enter the Funeral of KING HENRY the  Fifth
Hung be the heavens with black
Comets
That have consented unto Henry's death!
King Henry the Fifth
England ne'er lost a king of so much worth.
England ne'er had a king until his time.
Virtue he had
His brandish'd sword did blind men with his beams:
His arms spread wider than a dragon's wings;
His sparking eyes
Than mid-day sun fierce bent against their faces.
What should I say? his deeds exceed all speech:
He ne'er lift up his hand but conquered.
We mourn in black: why mourn we not in blood?
Henry is dead and never shall revive:
Upon a wooden coffin we attend
We with our stately presence glorify
What! shall we curse the planets of mishap
That plotted thus our glory's overthrow?
Or shall we think the subtle-witted French
Conjurers and sorcerers
By magic verses have contrived his end?
BISHOP
He was a king bless'd of the King of kings.
Unto the French the dreadful judgement-day
So dreadful will not be as was his sight.
The battles of the Lord of hosts he fought:
The church's prayers made him so prosperous.
The church! where is it? Had not churchmen pray'd
None do you like but an effeminate prince
BISHOP
Gloucester
And lookest to command the prince and realm.
Thy wife is proud; she holdeth thee in awe
Name not religion
Except it be to pray against thy foes.
Cease
Let's to the altar: heralds
Instead of gold
Since arms avail not now that Henry's dead.
Posterity
Henry the Fifth
Prosper this realm
A far more glorious star thy soul will make
Than Julius Caesar or bright--
Enter a Messenger
My honourable lords
Sad tidings bring I to you out of France
Guienne
What say'st thou
Speak softly
Will make him burst his lead and rise from death.
Is Paris lost? is Rouen yielded up?
If Henry were recall'd to life again
How were they lost? what treachery was used?
No treachery; but want of men and money.
Amongst the soldiers this is muttered
One would have lingering wars with little cost;
Another would fly swift
A third thinks
Awake
Let not sloth dim your horrors new-begot:
Cropp'd are the flower-de-luces in your arms;
Of England's coat one half is cut away.
Were our tears wanting to this funeral
Me they concern; Regent I am of France.
Give me my steeled coat. I'll fight for France.
Away with these disgraceful wailing robes!
Wounds will I lend the French instead of eyes
Enter to them another Messenger
Lords
France is revolted from the English quite
The Dauphin Charles is crowned king of Rheims;
The Bastard of Orleans with him is join'd;
Reignier
The Duke of Alencon flieth to his side.
The Dauphin crowned king! all fly to him!
O
We will not fly
Bedford
Gloucester
An army have I muster'd in my thoughts
Enter another Messenger
My gracious lords
Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French.
BISHOP
What! wherein Talbot overcame? is't so?
O
The circumstance I'll tell you more at large.
The tenth of August last this dreadful lord
By three and twenty thousand of the French
Was round encompassed and set upon.
No leisure had he to enrank his men;
He wanted pikes to set before his archers;
Instead whereof sharp stakes pluck'd out of hedges
They pitched in the ground confusedly
More than three hours the fight continued;
Where valiant Talbot above human thought
Enacted wonders with his sword and lance:
Hundreds he sent to hell
Here
The French exclaim'd
All the whole army stood agazed on him:
His soldiers spying his undaunted spirit
A Talbot! a Talbot! cried out amain
And rush'd into the bowels of the battle.
Here had the conquest fully been seal'd up
He
With purpose to relieve and follow them
Hence grew the general wreck and massacre;
Enclosed were they with their enemies:
A base Walloon
Durst not presume to look once in the face.
Is Talbot slain? then I will slay myself
O no
Most of the rest slaughter'd or took likewise.
His ransom there is none but I shall pay:
I'll hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne:
His crown shall be the ransom of my friend;
Four of their lords I'll change for one of ours.
Farewell
Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make
Ten thousand soldiers with me I will take
So you had need; for Orleans is besieged;
The English army is grown weak and faint:
The Earl of Salisbury craveth supply
Remember
I do remember it; and here take my leave
Exit
I'll to the Tower with all the haste I can
And then I will proclaim young Henry king.
Exit
To Eltham will I
Exit
BISHOP
Each hath his place and function to attend:
I am left out; for me nothing remains.
But long I will not be Jack out of office:
The king from Eltham I intend to steal
And sit at chiefest stern of public weal.
Exeunt
SCENE II. France. Before Orleans.
Sound a flourish. Enter CHARLES
Mars his true moving
So in the earth
Late did he shine upon the English side;
Now we are victors; upon us he smiles.
What towns of any moment but we have?
At pleasure here we lie near Orleans;
Otherwhiles the famish'd English
They want their porridge and their fat bull-beeves:
Either they must be dieted like mules
And have their provender tied to their mouths
Or piteous they will look
Let's raise the siege: why live we idly here?
Talbot is taken
Remaineth none but mad-brain'd Salisbury;
And he may well in fretting spend his gall
Sound
Now for the honour of the forlorn French!
Him I forgive my death that killeth me
When he sees me go back one foot or fly.
Exeunt
Here alarum; they are beaten back by the English with great loss. Re-enter CHARLES
Who ever saw the like? what men have I!
Dogs! cowards! dastards! I would ne'er have fled
Salisbury is a desperate homicide;
He fighteth as one weary of his life.
The other lords
Froissart
More truly now may this be verified;
For none but Samsons and Goliases
It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten!
Lean
They had such courage and audacity?
Let's leave this town; for they are hare-brain'd slaves
Of old I know them; rather with their teeth
The walls they'll tear down than forsake the siege.
I think
Their arms are set like clocks
Else ne'er could they hold out so as they do.
By my consent
Be it so.
Enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS
Where's the Prince Dauphin? I have news for him.
Bastard of Orleans
Methinks your looks are sad
Hath the late overthrow wrought this offence?
Be not dismay'd
A holy maid hither with me I bring
Ordained is to raise this tedious siege
And drive the English forth the bounds of France.
The spirit of deep prophecy she hath
What's past and what's to come she can descry.
Speak
Go
Exit BASTARD OF ORLEANS
But first
Question her proudly; let thy looks be stern:
By this means shall we sound what skill she hath.
Re-enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS
Fair maid
Reignier
Where is the Dauphin? Come
I know thee well
Be not amazed
In private will I talk with thee apart.
Stand back
She takes upon her bravely at first dash.
Dauphin
Heaven and our Lady gracious hath it pleased
To shine on my contemptible estate:
Lo
And in a vision full of majesty
Will'd me to leave my base vocation
And free my country from calamity:
Her aid she promised and assured success:
In complete glory she reveal'd herself;
And
That beauty am I bless'd with which you see.
Ask me what question thou canst possible
My courage try by combat
Resolve on this
Thou hast astonish'd me with thy high terms:
Only this proof I'll of thy valour make
Otherwise I renounce all confidence.
I am prepared: here is my keen-edged sword
The which at Touraine
churchyard
Then come
And while I live
Here they fight
Stay
And fightest with the sword of Deborah.
Christ's mother helps me
Whoe'er helps thee
Impatiently I burn with thy desire;
My heart and hands thou hast at once subdued.
Excellent Pucelle
'Tis the French Dauphin sueth to thee thus.
I must not yield to any rites of love
When I have chased all thy foes from hence
Meantime look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.
My lord
Doubtless he shrives this woman to her smock;
Else ne'er could he so long protract his speech.
Shall we disturb him
He may mean more than we poor men do know:
These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues.
My lord
Shall we give over Orleans
Why
Fight till the last gasp; I will be your guard.
What she says I'll confirm: we'll fight it out.
Assign'd am I to be the English scourge.
This night the siege assuredly I'll raise:
Expect Saint Martin's summer
Glory is like a circle in the water
Till by broad spreading it disperse to nought.
With Henry's death the English circle ends;
Dispersed are the glories it included.
Now am I like that proud insulting ship
Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.
Was Mahomet inspired with a dove?
Thou with an eagle art inspired then.
Helen
Bright star of Venus
Leave off delays
Woman
Drive them from Orleans and be immortalized.
Presently we'll try: come
No prophet will I trust
Exeunt
SCENE III. London. Before the Tower.
Enter GLOUCESTER
I am come to survey the Tower this day:
Since Henry's death
Where be these warders
Open the gates; 'tis Gloucester that calls.
[Within]  Who's there that knocks so imperiously?
"First Serving-Man	It is the noble Duke of Gloucester."
[Within]  Whoe'er he be
"First Serving-Man	Villains"
[Within]  The Lord protect him! so we answer him:
We do no otherwise than we are will'd.
Who willed you? or whose will stands but mine?
There's none protector of the realm but I.
Break up the gates
Shall I be flouted thus by dunghill grooms?
Gloucester's men rush at the Tower Gates
What noise is this? what traitors have we here?
Lieutenant
Open the gates; here's Gloucester that would enter.
Have patience
The Cardinal of Winchester forbids:
From him I have express commandment
That thou nor none of thine shall be let in.
Faint-hearted Woodvile
Arrogant Winchester
Thou art no friend to God or to the king:
Open the gates
"Serving-Men	Open the gates unto the lord protector"
Enter to the Protector at the Tower Gates BISHOP OF WINCHESTER and his men in tawny coats
BISHOP
How now
Peel'd priest
BISHOP
I do
Stand back
Thou that givest whores indulgences to sin:
I'll canvass thee in thy broad cardinal's hat
BISHOP
Nay
This be Damascus
I will not slay thee
Thy scarlet robes as a child's bearing-cloth
I'll use to carry thee out of this place.
BISHOP
Do what thou darest; I beard thee to thy face.
What! am I dared and bearded to my face?
Draw
Blue coats to tawny coats. Priest
Under my feet I stamp thy cardinal's hat:
In spite of pope or dignities of church
BISHOP
Gloucester
Winchester goose
Now beat them hence; why do you let them stay?
Thee I'll chase hence
Out
Here GLOUCESTER's men beat out BISHOP OF  WINCHESTER's men
Fie
Peace
Here's Beaufort
BISHOP
Here's Gloucester
I will not answer thee with words
Here they skirmish again
Naught rests for me in this tumultuous strife
But to make open proclamation:
Come
All manner of men assembled here in arms this day
against God's peace and the king's
command you
your several dwelling-places; and not to wear
Cardinal
But we shall meet
BISHOP
Gloucester
Thy heart-blood I will have for this day's work.
I'll call for clubs
This cardinal's more haughty than the devil.
Mayor
BISHOP
Abominable Gloucester
For I intend to have it ere long.
Exeunt
See the coast clear'd
Good God
I myself fight not once in forty year.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Orleans.
Enter
"Master-Gunner	Sirrah"
Father
"Master-Gunner	But now thou shalt not. Be thou ruled by me:"
Chief master-gunner am I of this town;
Something I must do to procure me grace.
The prince's espials have informed me
How the English
In yonder tower
They may vex us with shot
To intercept this inconvenience
And even these three days have I watch'd
Now do thou watch
If thou spy'st any
And thou shalt find me at the governor's.
Exit
Father
I'll never trouble you
Exit
Enter
Talbot
How wert thou handled being prisoner?
Or by what means got'st thou to be released?
Discourse
The Duke of Bedford had a prisoner
Call'd the brave Lord Ponton de Santrailles;
For him was I exchanged and ransomed.
But with a baser man of arms by far
Once in contempt they would have barter'd me:
Which I
In fine
But
Yet tell'st thou not how thou wert entertain'd.
With scoffs and scorns and contumelious taunts.
In open market-place produced they me
Here
Then broke I from the officers that led me
My grisly countenance made others fly;
None durst come near for fear of sudden death.
In iron walls they deem'd me not secure;
So great fear of my name 'mongst them was spread
Wherefore a guard of chosen shot I had
And if I did but stir out of my bed
Enter the Boy with a linstock
I grieve to hear what torments you endured
Now it is supper-time in Orleans:
Here
and view the Frenchmen how they fortify:
Let us look in; the sight will much delight thee.
Sir Thomas Gargrave
Where is best place to make our battery next.
I think
And I
For aught I see
Here they shoot. SALISBURY and GARGRAVE fall
O Lord
O Lord
What chance is this that suddenly hath cross'd us?
Speak
How farest thou
One of thy eyes and thy cheek's side struck off!
Accursed tower! accursed fatal hand
That hath contrived this woful tragedy!
In thirteen battles Salisbury o'ercame;
Henry the Fifth he first train'd to the wars;
Whilst any trump did sound
Yet livest thou
The sun with one eye vieweth all the world.
Heaven
Bear hence his body; I will help to bury it.
Sir Thomas Gargrave
Speak unto Talbot; nay
Salisbury
Thou shalt not die whiles--
He beckons with his hand and smiles on me.
As who should say 'When I am dead and gone
Plantagenet
Wretched shall France be only in my name.
Here an alarum
What stir is this? what tumult's in the heavens?
Whence cometh this alarum and the noise?
Enter a Messenger
My lord
The Dauphin
Here SALISBURY lifteth himself up and groans
Hear
It irks his heart he cannot be revenged.
Frenchmen
Pucelle or puzzel
Convey me Salisbury into his tent
Alarum. Exeunt
SCENE V. The same.
Here an alarum again: and TALBOT pursueth the  DAUPHIN
Where is my strength
Our English troops retire
A woman clad in armour chaseth them.
Re-enter JOAN LA PUCELLE
Here
Devil or devil's dam
Blood will I draw on thee
Come
Here they fight
Heavens
My breast I'll burst with straining of my courage
And from my shoulders crack my arms asunder.
But I will chastise this high-minded strumpet.
They fight again
Talbot
I must go victual Orleans forthwith.
A short alarum; then enter the town with soldiers
O'ertake me
Go
Help Salisbury to make his testament:
This day is ours
Exit
My thoughts are whirled like a potter's wheel;
I know not where I am
A witch
So bees with smoke and doves with noisome stench
Are from their hives and houses driven away.
They call'd us for our fierceness English dogs;
Now
A short alarum
Hark
Renounce your soil
Sheep run not half so treacherous from the wolf
Alarum. Here another skirmish
It will not be: retire into your trenches:
You all consented unto Salisbury's death
Pucelle is enter'd into Orleans
O
The shame hereof will make me hide my head.
Exit TALBOT. Alarum; retreat; flourish
SCENE VI. The same.
Enter
Advance our waving colours on the walls;
Rescued is Orleans from the English
Thus Joan la Pucelle hath perform'd her word.
Divinest creature
Thy promises are like Adonis' gardens
That one day bloom'd and fruitful were the next.
France
Recover'd is the town of Orleans:
More blessed hap did ne'er befall our state.
Why ring not out the bells aloud throughout the town?
Dauphin
And feast and banquet in the open streets
All France will be replete with mirth and joy
'Tis Joan
For which I will divide my crown with her
Shall in procession sing her endless praise.
A statelier pyramis to her I'll rear
Than Rhodope's or Memphis' ever was:
In memory of her when she is dead
Than the rich-jewel'd of Darius
Before the kings and queens of France.
No longer on Saint Denis will we cry
Come in
Flourish. Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Before Orleans.
Enter a Sergeant of a band with two Sentinels
Sirs
If any noise or soldier you perceive
Near to the walls
Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.
Sergeant
Exit Sergeant
Thus are poor servitors
Enter TALBOT
Lord Regent
Embrace we then this opportunity
As fitting best to quittance their deceit
Contrived by art and baleful sorcery.
Coward of France! how much he wrongs his fame
Traitors have never other company.
But what's that Pucelle whom they term so pure?
A maid
A maid! and be so martial!
Pray God she prove not masculine ere long
She carry armour as she hath begun.
Well
God is our fortress
Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.
Ascend
Not all together: better far
That
Agreed: I'll to yond corner.
And I to this.
And here will Talbot mount
Now
Of English Henry
How much in duty I am bound to both.
Arm! arm! the enemy doth make assault!
Cry: 'St. George
The French leap over the walls in their shirts.  Enter
How now
Unready! ay
'Twas time
Of all exploits since first I follow'd arms
More venturous or desperate than this.
I think this Talbot be a fiend of hell.
If not of hell
Here cometh Charles: I marvel how he sped.
Tut
Enter CHARLES and JOAN LA PUCELLE
Is this thy cunning
Didst thou at first
Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend!
At all times will you have my power alike?
Sleeping or waking must I still prevail
Improvident soldiers! had your watch been good
Duke of Alencon
Had all your quarters been as safely kept
As that whereof I had the government
Mine was secure.
And so was mine
And
I was employ'd in passing to and fro
Then how or which way should they first break in?
Question
But weakly guarded
And now there rests no other shift but this;
To gather our soldiers
Alarum. Enter an English Soldier
I'll be so bold to take what they have left.
The cry of Talbot serves me for a sword;
For I have loaden me with many spoils
Exit
SCENE II. Orleans. Within the town.
Enter TALBOT
The day begins to break
Here sound retreat
Retreat sounded
Bring forth the body of old Salisbury
Now have I paid my vow unto his soul;
For every drop of blood was drawn from him
And that hereafter ages may behold
What ruin happen'd in revenge of him
A tomb
Upon the which
And what a terror he had been to France.
But
'Tis thought
Leap o'er the walls for refuge in the field.
Myself
For smoke and dusky vapours of the night
That could not live asunder day or night.
After that things are set in order here
Enter a Messenger
All hail
Call ye the warlike Talbot
So much applauded through the realm of France?
Here is the Talbot: who would speak with him?
The virtuous lady
To visit her poor castle where she lies
Whose glory fills the world with loud report.
Is it even so? Nay
Will turn unto a peaceful comic sport
You may not
Ne'er trust me then; for when a world of men
Could not prevail with all their oratory
And therefore tell her I return great thanks
Will not your honours bear me company?
No
And I have heard it said
Are often welcomest when they are gone.
Well then
Come hither
Whispers
You perceive my mind?
I do
Exeunt
SCENE III. Auvergne. The COUNTESS's castle.
Enter the COUNTESS and her Porter
COUNTESS
Porter
And when you have done so
Madam
Exit
COUNTESS
The plot is laid: if all things fall out right
As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus' death.
Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight
Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears
Enter Messenger and TALBOT
Madam
COUNTESS
And he is welcome. What! is this the man?
Madam
COUNTESS
Is this the scourge of France?
Is this the Talbot
That with his name the mothers still their babes?
I see report is fabulous and false:
I thought I should have seen some Hercules
Alas
It cannot be this weak and writhled shrimp
Should strike such terror to his enemies.
Madam
But since your ladyship is not at leisure
COUNTESS
What means he now? Go ask him whither he goes.
Stay
To know the cause of your abrupt departure.
Marry
Re-enter Porter with keys
COUNTESS
If thou be he
Prisoner! to whom?
COUNTESS
To me
And for that cause I trained thee to my house.
Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me
But now the substance shall endure the like
Wasted our country
And sent our sons and husbands captivate.
Ha
COUNTESS
Laughest thou
I laugh to see your ladyship so fond
To think that you have aught but Talbot's shadow
Whereon to practise your severity.
COUNTESS
Why
I am indeed.
COUNTESS
Then have I substance too.
No
You are deceived
For what you see is but the smallest part
And least proportion of humanity:
I tell you
COUNTESS
This is a riddling merchant for the nonce;
He will be here
How can these contrarieties agree?
That will I show you presently.
Winds his horn. Drums strike up: a peal of ordnance. Enter soldiers
How say you
That Talbot is but shadow of himself?
These are his substance
And in a moment makes them desolate.
COUNTESS
Victorious Talbot! pardon my abuse:
I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited
And more than may be gather'd by thy shape.
Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath;
For I am sorry that with reverence
I did not entertain thee as thou art.
Be not dismay'd
The mind of Talbot
The outward composition of his body.
What you have done hath not offended me;
Nor other satisfaction do I crave
Taste of your wine and see what cates you have;
For soldiers' stomachs always serve them well.
COUNTESS
With all my heart
To feast so great a warrior in my house.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. London. The Temple-garden.
Enter the Earls of SOMERSET
RICHARD
Great lords and gentlemen
Dare no man answer in a case of truth?
Within the Temple-hall we were too loud;
The garden here is more convenient.
RICHARD
Then say at once if I maintain'd the truth;
Or else was wrangling Somerset in the error?
Faith
And therefore frame the law unto my will.
Judge you
Between two hawks
Between two dogs
Between two blades
Between two horses
Between two girls
I have perhaps some shallow spirit of judgement;
But in these nice sharp quillets of the law
RICHARD
Tut
The truth appears so naked on my side
That any purblind eye may find it out.
And on my side it is so well apparell'd
That it will glimmer through a blind man's eye.
RICHARD
Since you are tongue-tied and so loath to speak
Let him that is a true-born gentleman
And stands upon the honour of his birth
Let him that is no coward nor no flatterer
I love no colours
Of base insinuating flattery
I pluck this white rose with Plantagenet.
I pluck this red rose with young Somerset
And say withal I think he held the right.
Stay
The fewest roses are cropp'd from the tree
Shall yield the other in the right opinion.
Good Master Vernon
If I have fewest
RICHARD
And I.
Then for the truth and plainness of the case.
I pluck this pale and maiden blossom here
Prick not your finger as you pluck it off
And fall on my side so
If I my lord
And keep me on the side where still I am.
Well
Unless my study and my books be false
To SOMERSET
In sign whereof I pluck a white rose too.
RICHARD
Now
Here in my scabbard
Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red.
RICHARD
Meantime your cheeks do counterfeit our roses;
For pale they look with fear
The truth on our side.
No
Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses
RICHARD
Hath not thy rose a canker
Hath not thy rose a thorn
RICHARD
Ay
Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.
Well
RICHARD
Now
Turn not thy scorns this way
RICHARD
Proud Pole
I'll turn my part thereof into thy throat.
Away
We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.
Now
His grandfather was Lionel Duke of Clarence
Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root?
RICHARD
He bears him on the place's privilege
By him that made me
On any plot of ground in Christendom.
Was not thy father
And
His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood;
And
RICHARD
My father was attached
And that I'll prove on better men than Somerset
For your partaker Pole and you yourself
Look to it well and say you are well warn'd.
Ah
And know us by these colours for thy foes
RICHARD
And
Or flourish to the height of my degree.
Go forward and be choked with thy ambition!
And so farewell until I meet thee next.
Exit
Have with thee
Exit
RICHARD
How I am braved and must perforce endure it!
This blot that they object against your house
Shall be wiped out in the next parliament
Call'd for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester;
And if thou be not then created York
Meantime
And here I prophesy: this brawl to-day
A thousand souls to death and deadly night.
RICHARD
Good Master Vernon
In your behalf still will I wear the same.
And so will I.
RICHARD
Thanks
Come
This quarrel will drink blood another day.
Exeunt
SCENE V. The Tower of London.
Enter MORTIMER
Kind keepers of my weak decaying age
Even like a man new haled from the rack
And these grey locks
These eyes
Weak shoulders
That droops his sapless branches to the ground;
Yet are these feet
But tell me
Richard Plantagenet
We sent unto the Temple
And answer was return'd that he will come.
Enough: my soul shall then be satisfied.
Poor gentleman! his wrong doth equal mine.
Since Henry Monmouth first began to reign
And even since then hath Richard been obscured
But now the arbitrator of despairs
I would his troubles likewise were expired
Enter RICHARD PLANTAGENET
My lord
Richard Plantagenet
RICHARD
Ay
Direct mine arms I may embrace his neck
O
And now declare
RICHARD
First
And
This day
Among which terms he used his lavish tongue
And did upbraid me with my father's death:
Which obloquy set bars before my tongue
Therefore
And for alliance sake
My father
That cause
And hath detain'd me all my flowering youth
Within a loathsome dungeon
RICHARD
Discover more at large what cause that was
I will
And death approach not ere my tale be done.
Henry the Fourth
During whose reign the Percies of the north
The reason moved these warlike lords to this
Was
I was the next by birth and parentage;
For by my mother I derived am
From Lionel Duke of Clarence
To King Edward the Third; whereas he
From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigree
But mark: as in this haughty attempt
They laboured to plant the rightful heir
Long after this
From famous Edmund Langley
Levied an army
And have install'd me in the diadem:
But
And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers
RICHARD
Of which
True; and thou seest that I no issue have
And that my fainting words do warrant death;
Thou art my heir; the rest I wish thee gather:
But yet be wary in thy studious care.
RICHARD
Thy grave admonishments prevail with me:
But yet
Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.
With silence
Strong-fixed is the house of Lancaster
But now thy uncle is removing hence:
As princes do their courts
With long continuance in a settled place.
RICHARD
O
Might but redeem the passage of your age!
Thou dost then wrong me
Which giveth many wounds when one will kill.
Mourn not
Only give order for my funeral:
And so farewell
And prosperous be thy life in peace and war!
Dies
RICHARD
And peace
In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage
And like a hermit overpass'd thy days.
Well
And what I do imagine let that rest.
Keepers
Will see his burial better than his life.
Exeunt Gaolers
Here dies the dusky torch of Mortimer
And for those wrongs
I doubt not but with honour to redress;
And therefore haste I to the parliament
Exit
ACT III
SCENE I. London. The Parliament-house.
Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI
BISHOP
Comest thou with deep premeditated lines
As I with sudden and extemporal speech
Purpose to answer what thou canst object.
Presumptuous priest! this place commands my patience
Think not
The manner of thy vile outrageous crimes
Verbatim to rehearse the method of my pen:
No
Thou art a most pernicious usurer
Lascivious
A man of thy profession and degree;
And for thy treachery
In that thou laid'st a trap to take my life
Beside
From envious malice of thy swelling heart.
BISHOP
Gloucester
To give me hearing what I shall reply.
If I were covetous
Or how haps it I seek not to advance
Or raise myself
And for dissension
More than I do?--except I be provoked.
No
It is not that that hath incensed the duke:
It is
No one but he should be about the king;
And that engenders thunder in his breast
And makes him roar these accusations forth.
But he shall know I am as good--
As good!
Thou bastard of my grandfather!
BISHOP
Ay
Am I not protector
BISHOP
And am not I a prelate of the church?
Yes
And useth it to patronage his theft.
BISHOP
Unreverent Gloster!
Thou art reverent
Touching thy spiritual function
BISHOP
Rome shall remedy this.
Roam thither
My lord
Ay
Methinks my lord should be religious
And know the office that belongs to such.
Methinks his lordship should be humbler;
it fitteth not a prelate so to plead.
Yes
State holy or unhallow'd
Is not his grace protector to the king?
RICHARD
[Aside]  Plantagenet
Must your bold verdict enter talk with lords?'
Else would I have a fling at Winchester.
Uncles of Gloucester and of Winchester
O
Believe me
Civil dissension is a viperous worm
That gnaws the bowels of the commonwealth.
A noise within
What tumult's this?
An uproar
A noise again
O
