The bishop and the Duke of Gloucester's men
And banding themselves in contrary parts
Do pelt so fast at one another's pate
That many have their giddy brains knock'd out:
Our windows are broke down in every street
And we for fear compell'd to shut our shops.
Enter Serving-men
We charge you
Pray
"First Serving-man	Nay"
"Second Serving-man	Do what ye dare"
Skirmish again
You of my household
And set this unaccustom'd fight aside.
"Third Serving-man	My lord"
Just and upright; and
And ere that we will suffer such a prince
And have our bodies slaughtered by thy foes.
"First Serving-man	Ay"
Shall pitch a field when we are dead.
Begin again
Stay
And if you love me
O
Can you
My sighs and tears and will not once relent?
Who should be pitiful
Or who should study to prefer a peace.
If holy churchmen take delight in broils?
Yield
Except you mean with obstinate repulse
To slay your sovereign and destroy the realm.
You see what mischief and what murder too
Hath been enacted through your enmity;
Then be at peace except ye thirst for blood.
BISHOP
He shall submit
Compassion on the king commands me stoop;
Or I would see his heart out
Should ever get that privilege of me.
Behold
Hath banish'd moody discontented fury
Why look you still so stern and tragical?
Here
Fie
That malice was a great and grievous sin;
And will not you maintain the thing you teach
Sweet king! the bishop hath a kindly gird.
For shame
What
BISHOP
Well
Love for thy love and hand for hand I give.
[Aside]  Ay
See here
Betwixt ourselves and all our followers:
So help me God
BISHOP
[Aside]  So help me God
O
Away
But join in friendship
"First Serving-man	Content: I'll to the surgeon's."
"Second Serving-man	And so will I."
"Third Serving-man	And I will see what physic the tavern affords."
Exeunt Serving-men
Accept this scroll
We do exhibit to your majesty.
Well urged
Especially for those occasions
At Eltham Place I told your majesty.
And those occasions
Therefore
That Richard be restored to his blood.
Let Richard be restored to his blood;
So shall his father's wrongs be recompensed.
BISHOP
As will the rest
If Richard will be true
But all the whole inheritance I give
That doth belong unto the house of York
RICHARD
Thy humble servant vows obedience
And humble service till the point of death.
Stoop then and set your knee against my foot;
And
Rise Richard
RICHARD
And so thrive Richard as thy foes may fall!
And as my duty springs
That grudge one thought against your majesty!
Welcome
[Aside]  Perish
Now will it best avail your majesty
To cross the seas and to be crown'd in France:
The presence of a king engenders love
Amongst his subjects and his loyal friends
When Gloucester says the word
For friendly counsel cuts off many foes.
Your ships already are in readiness.
Sennet. Flourish. Exeunt all but EXETER
Ay
This late dissension grown betwixt the peers
Burns under feigned ashes of forged love
And will at last break out into a flame:
As fester'd members rot but by degree
And now I fear that fatal prophecy
Which in the time of Henry named the Fifth
Was in the mouth of every sucking babe;
That Henry born at Monmouth should win all
And Henry born at Windsor lose all:
Which is so plain that Exeter doth wish
His days may finish ere that hapless time.
Exit
SCENE II. France. Before Rouen.
Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE disguised
These are the city gates
Take heed
Talk like the vulgar sort of market men
That come to gather money for their corn.
If we have entrance
Our sacks shall be a mean to sack the city
Therefore we'll knock.
Knocks
[Within]  Qui est la?
Paysans
Poor market folks that come to sell their corn.
Enter
Now
Exeunt
Enter CHARLES
Saint Denis bless this happy stratagem!
And once again we'll sleep secure in Rouen.
Here enter'd Pucelle and her practisants;
Now she is there
Where is the best and safest passage in?
By thrusting out a torch from yonder tower;
Which
Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE on the top
Behold
That joineth Rouen unto her countrymen
Exit
See
The burning torch in yonder turret stands.
Now shine it like a comet of revenge
Defer no time
Enter
Alarum. Exeunt
An alarum. Enter TALBOT in an excursion
France
Pucelle
Exit
An alarum: excursions. BEDFORD
Good morrow
I think the Duke of Burgundy will fast
Before he'll buy again at such a rate:
'Twas full of darnel; do you like the taste?
Scoff on
I trust ere long to choke thee with thine own
And make thee curse the harvest of that corn.
Your grace may starve perhaps before that time.
O
What will you do
Foul fiend of France
Becomes it thee to taunt his valiant age
And twit with cowardice a man half dead?
Damsel
Are ye so hot
If Talbot do but thunder
The English whisper together in council
God speed the parliament! who shall be the speaker?
Dare ye come forth and meet us in the field?
Belike your lordship takes us then for fools
I speak not to that railing Hecate
Will ye
Signior
Signior
Like peasant foot-boys do they keep the walls
And dare not take up arms like gentlemen.
Away
For Talbot means no goodness by his looks.
God be wi' you
That we are here.
Exeunt from the walls
And there will we be too
Vow
And I
And as his father here was conqueror
Great Coeur-de-lion's heart was buried
My vows are equal partners with thy vows.
But
Lord Talbot
Here will I sit before the walls of Rouen
And will be partner of your weal or woe.
Courageous Bedford
Not to be gone from hence; for once I read
That stout Pendragon in his litter sick
Came to the field and vanquished his foes:
Methinks I should revive the soldiers' hearts
Undaunted spirit in a dying breast!
Then be it so: heavens keep old Bedford safe!
And now no more ado
And set upon our boasting enemy.
Exeunt all but BEDFORD and Attendants
An alarum: excursions. Enter FASTOLFE and a Captain
Whither away
Whither away! to save myself by flight:
We are like to have the overthrow again.
What! will you fly
Ay
Exit
Cowardly knight! ill fortune follow thee!
Exit
Retreat: excursions. JOAN LA PUCELLE
Now
What is the trust or strength of foolish man?
They that of late were daring with their scoffs
Are glad and fain by flight to save themselves.
BEDFORD dies
An alarum. Re-enter TALBOT
Lost
This is a double honour
Yet heavens have glory for this victory!
Warlike and martial Talbot
Enshrines thee in his heart and there erects
Thy noble deeds as valour's monuments.
Thanks
I think her old familiar is asleep:
Now where's the Bastard's braves
What
That such a valiant company are fled.
Now will we take some order in the town
What wills Lord Talbot pleaseth Burgundy.
But yet
The noble Duke of Bedford late deceased
A braver soldier never couched lance
But kings and mightiest potentates must die
Exeunt
SCENE III. The plains near Rouen.
Enter CHARLES
Dismay not
Care is no cure
Let frantic Talbot triumph for a while
And like a peacock sweep along his tail;
We'll pull his plumes and take away his train
We have been guided by thee hitherto
One sudden foil shall never breed distrust.
Search out thy wit for secret policies
We'll set thy statue in some holy place
Employ thee then
Then thus it must be; this doth Joan devise:
By fair persuasions mix'd with sugar'd words
We will entice the Duke of Burgundy
To leave the Talbot and to follow us.
Ay
Nor should that nation boast it so with us
For ever should they be expulsed from France
And not have title of an earldom here.
Your honours shall perceive how I will work
To bring this matter to the wished end.
Drum sounds afar off
Hark! by the sound of drum you may perceive
Their powers are marching unto Paris-ward.
Here sound an English march. Enter
There goes the Talbot
French march. Enter BURGUNDY and forces
Now in the rearward comes the duke and his:
Fortune in favour makes him lag behind.
Summon a parley; we will talk with him.
Trumpets sound a parley
A parley with the Duke of Burgundy!
Who craves a parley with the Burgundy?
The princely Charles of France
What say'st thou
Speak
Brave Burgundy
Stay
Speak on; but be not over-tedious.
Look on thy country
By wasting ruin of the cruel foe.
As looks the mother on her lowly babe
When death doth close his tender dying eyes
Behold the wounds
O
Strike those that hurt
One drop of blood drawn from thy country's bosom
Should grieve thee more than streams of foreign gore:
Return thee therefore with a flood of tears
Either she hath bewitch'd me with her words
Besides
Who joint'st thou with but with a lordly nation
That will not trust thee but for profit's sake?
When Talbot hath set footing once in France
And fashion'd thee that instrument of ill
And thou be thrust out like a fugitive?
Call we to mind
And was he not in England prisoner?
But when they heard he was thine enemy
See
And joint'st with them will be thy slaughtermen.
Come
Charles and the rest will take thee in their arms.
I am vanquished; these haughty words of hers
Have batter'd me like roaring cannon-shot
Forgive me
My forces and my power of men are yours:
So farewell
[Aside]  Done like a Frenchman: turn
Welcome
And doth beget new courage in our breasts.
Pucelle hath bravely play'd her part in this
Now let us on
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Paris. The palace.
Enter KING HENRY VI
My gracious prince
In sign
To your obedience fifty fortresses
Ascribes the glory of his conquest got
First to my God and next unto your grace.
Kneels
Is this the Lord Talbot
Yes
Welcome
When I was young
A stouter champion never handled sword.
Long since we were resolved of your truth
Yet never have you tasted our reward
Therefore
And in our coronation take your place.
Sennet. Flourish. Exeunt all but VERNON and BASSET
Now
In honour of my noble Lord of York:
Darest thou maintain the former words thou spakest?
Yes
The envious barking of your saucy tongue
Against my lord the Duke of Somerset.
Sirrah
Why
Hark ye; not so: in witness
Strikes him
Villain
That whoso draws a sword
But I'll unto his majesty
I may have liberty to venge this wrong;
When thou shalt see I'll meet thee to thy cost.
Well
And
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Paris. A hall of state.
Enter KING HENRY VI
Lord bishop
BISHOP
God save King Henry
Now
Esteem none friends but such as are his friends
Malicious practises against his state:
This shall ye do
Enter FASTOLFE
My gracious sovereign
Shame to the Duke of Burgundy and thee!
I vow'd
Which I have done
Thou wast installed in that high degree.
Pardon me
This dastard
And that the French were almost ten to one
In which assault we lost twelve hundred men;
Myself and divers gentlemen beside
Were there surprised and taken prisoners.
Then judge
Or whether that such cowards ought to wear
This ornament of knighthood
To say the truth
And ill beseeming any common man
When first this order was ordain'd
Not fearing death
He then that is not furnish'd in this sort
Doth but usurp the sacred name of knight
That doth presume to boast of gentle blood.
Stain to thy countrymen
Be packing
Henceforth we banish thee
Exit FASTOLFE
And now
Sent from our uncle Duke of Burgundy.
What means his grace
No more but
Hath he forgot he is his sovereign?
Or doth this churlish superscription
Pretend some alteration in good will?
What's here?
Reads
'I have
Of such as your oppression feeds upon
And join'd with Charles
O monstrous treachery! can this be so
What! doth my uncle Burgundy revolt?
He doth
Is that the worst this letter doth contain?
It is the worst
Why
And give him chastisement for this abuse.
How say you
Content
Then gather strength and march unto him straight:
Let him perceive how ill we brook his treason
And what offence it is to flout his friends.
I go
You may behold confusion of your foes.
Exit
Enter VERNON and BASSET
Grant me the combat
And me
This is my servant: hear him
And this is mine: sweet Henry
Be patient
Say
And wherefore crave you combat? or with whom?
With him
And I with him; for he hath done me wrong.
What is that wrong whereof you both complain?
First let me know
Crossing the sea from England into France
Saying
Did represent my master's blushing cheeks
About a certain question in the law
Argued betwixt the Duke of York and him;
With other vile and ignominious terms:
In confutation of which rude reproach
And in defence of my lord's worthiness
And that is my petition
For though he seem with forged quaint conceit
To set a gloss upon his bold intent
And he first took exceptions at this badge
Bewray'd the faintness of my master's heart.
Will not this malice
Your private grudge
Good Lord
Such factious emulations shall arise!
Good cousins both
Let this dissension first be tried by fight
The quarrel toucheth none but us alone;
Betwixt ourselves let us decide it then.
There is my pledge; accept it
Nay
Confirm it so
Confirm it so! Confounded be your strife!
And perish ye
Presumptuous vassals
With this immodest clamorous outrage
To trouble and disturb the king and us?
And you
To bear with their perverse objections;
Much less to take occasion from their mouths
To raise a mutiny betwixt yourselves:
Let me persuade you take a better course.
It grieves his highness: good my lords
Come hither
Henceforth I charge you
And you
If they perceive dissension in our looks
And that within ourselves we disagree
To wilful disobedience
Beside
That for a toy
Destroy'd themselves
O
That for a trifle that was bought with blood
Let me be umpire in this doubtful strife.
I see no reason
That any one should therefore be suspicious
I more incline to Somerset than York:
Both are my kinsmen
As well they may upbraid me with my crown
But your discretions better can persuade
Than I am able to instruct or teach:
And therefore
Cousin of York
To be our regent in these parts of France:
And
Your troops of horsemen with his bands of foot;
And
Your angry choler on your enemies.
Ourself
After some respite will return to Calais;
From thence to England; where I hope ere long
To be presented
Flourish. Exeunt all but YORK
My Lord of York
Prettily
And so he did; but yet I like it not
Tush
I dare presume
An if I wist he did
Other affairs must now be managed.
Exeunt all but EXETER
Well didst thou
For
More rancorous spite
But howsoe'er
This jarring discord of nobility
'Tis much when sceptres are in children's hands;
But more when envy breeds unkind division;
There comes the rain
Exit
SCENE II. Before Bourdeaux.
Enter TALBOT
Go to the gates of Bourdeaux
Summon their general unto the wall.
Trumpet sounds. Enter General and others
English John Talbot
And thus he would: Open your city gates;
Be humble to us; call my sovereign yours
And I'll withdraw me and my bloody power:
But
Who in a moment even with the earth
Shall lay your stately and air-braving towers
Thou ominous and fearful owl of death
The period of thy tyranny approacheth.
On us thou canst not enter but by death;
For
And strong enough to issue out and fight:
If thou retire
On either hand thee there are squadrons pitch'd
And no way canst thou turn thee for redress
And pale destruction meets thee in the face.
Ten thousand French have ta'en the sacrament
To rive their dangerous artillery
Upon no Christian soul but English Talbot.
Lo
This is the latest glory of thy praise
That I
For ere the glass
Drum afar off
Hark! hark! the Dauphin's drum
And mine shall ring thy dire departure out.
Exeunt General
He fables not; I hear the enemy:
Out
O
How are we park'd and bounded in a pale
If we be English deer
Not rascal-like
And make the cowards stand aloof at bay:
Sell every man his life as dear as mine
God and Saint George
Exeunt
SCENE III. Plains in Gascony.
Enter a Messenger that meets YORK. Enter YORK with trumpet and many Soldiers
Are not the speedy scouts return'd again
They are return'd
That he is march'd to Bourdeaux with his power
Two mightier troops than that the Dauphin led
A plague upon that villain Somerset
Of horsemen
Renowned Talbot doth expect my aid
And cannot help the noble chevalier:
God comfort him in this necessity!
If he miscarry
Enter Sir William LUCY
Thou princely leader of our English strength
And hemm'd about with grim destruction:
To Bourdeaux
Else
O God
Doth stop my cornets
So should we save a valiant gentleman
By forfeiting a traitor and a coward.
Mad ire and wrathful fury makes me weep
O
He dies
We mourn
All 'long of this vile traitor Somerset.
Then God take mercy on brave Talbot's soul;
And on his son young John
I met in travel toward his warlike father!
This seven years did not Talbot see his son;
And now they meet where both their lives are done.
Alas
To bid his young son welcome to his grave?
Away! vexation almost stops my breath
Lucy
Maine
Exit
Thus
Feeds in the bosom of such great commanders
The conquest of our scarce cold conqueror
Exit
SCENE IV. Other plains in Gascony.
Enter SOMERSET
It is too late; I cannot send them now:
This expedition was by York and Talbot
Too rashly plotted: all our general force
Might with a sally of the very town
Be buckled with: the over-daring Talbot
Hath sullied all his gloss of former honour
By this unheedful
York set him on to fight and die in shame
Here is Sir William Lucy
Set from our o'ermatch'd forces forth for aid.
Enter Sir William LUCY
How now
Whither
Who
And whiles the honourable captain there
Drops bloody sweat from his war-wearied limbs
Let not your private discord keep away
The levied succors that should lend him aid
Orleans the Bastard
York set him on; York should have sent him aid.
And York as fast upon your grace exclaims;
Swearing that you withhold his levied host
York lies; he might have sent and had the horse;
I owe him little duty
And take foul scorn to fawn on him by sending.
The fraud of England
Never to England shall he bear his life;
But dies
Come
Within six hours they will be at his aid.
Too late comes rescue: he is ta'en or slain;
For fly he could not
And fly would Talbot never
If he be dead
His fame lives in the world
Exeunt
SCENE V. The English camp near Bourdeaux.
Enter TALBOT and JOHN his son
O young John Talbot! I did send for thee
To tutor thee in stratagems of war
When sapless age and weak unable limbs
Should bring thy father to his drooping chair.
But
Now thou art come unto a feast of death
Therefore
And I'll direct thee how thou shalt escape
By sudden flight: come
Is my name Talbot? and am I your son?
And shall I fly? O if you love my mother
The world will say
Fly
He that flies so will ne'er return again.
If we both stay
Then let me stay; and
Your loss is great
My worth unknown
Upon my death the French can little boast;
In yours they will
Flight cannot stain the honour you have won;
But mine it will
You fled for vantage
But
There is no hope that ever I will stay
Here on my knee I beg mortality
Shall all thy mother's hopes lie in one tomb?
Ay
Upon my blessing
To fight I will
Part of thy father may be saved in thee.
No part of him but will be shame in me.
Thou never hadst renown
Yes
Thy father's charge shall clear thee from that stain.
You cannot witness for me
If death be so apparent
And leave my followers here to fight and die?
My age was never tainted with such shame.
And shall my youth be guilty of such blame?
No more can I be sever'd from your side
Stay
For live I will not
Then here I take my leave of thee
Come
And soul with soul from France to heaven fly.
Exeunt
SCENE VI. A field of battle.
Alarum: excursions
Saint George and victory! fight
The regent hath with Talbot broke his word
And left us to the rage of France his sword.
Where is John Talbot? Pause
I gave thee life and rescued thee from death.
O
The life thou gavest me first was lost and done
When from the Dauphin's crest thy sword struck fire
Of bold-faced victory. Then leaden age
The ireful bastard Orleans
From thee
Of thy first fight
Some of his bastard blood; and in disgrace
Bespoke him thus; 'Contaminated
And misbegotten blood I spill of thine
Which thou didst force from Talbot
Here
Wilt thou yet leave the battle
Fly
The help of one stands me in little stead.
O
If I to-day die not with Frenchmen's rage
By me they nothing gain an if I stay;
'Tis but the shortening of my life one day:
In thee thy mother dies
All these and more we hazard by thy stay;
All these are saved if thou wilt fly away.
The sword of Orleans hath not made me smart;
These words of yours draw life-blood from my heart:
On that advantage
And like me to the peasant boys of France
Surely
Then talk no more of flight
If son to Talbot
Then follow thou thy desperate sire of Crete
If thou wilt fight
And
Exeunt
SCENE VII. Another part of the field.
Alarum: excursions. Enter TALBOT led by a Servant
Where is my other life? mine own is gone;
O
Triumphant death
When he perceived me shrink and on my knee
Rough deeds of rage and stern impatience;
But when my angry guardant stood alone
Suddenly made him from my side to start
Into the clustering battle of the French;
And in that sea of blood my boy did drench
His over-mounting spirit
O
Enter Soldiers
Thou antic death
O
Brave death by speaking
Imagine him a Frenchman and thy foe.
Poor boy! he smiles
Come
My spirit can no longer bear these harms.
Soldiers
Dies
Enter CHARLES
Had York and Somerset brought rescue in
How the young whelp of Talbot's
Once I encounter'd him
'Thou maiden youth
But
To be the pillage of a giglot wench:'
So
Doubtless he would have made a noble knight;
See
Of the most bloody nurser of his harms!
Hew them to pieces
Whose life was England's glory
O
During the life
Enter Sir William LUCY
Herald
On what submissive message art thou sent?
Submission
We English warriors wot not what it means.
I come to know what prisoners thou hast ta'en
And to survey the bodies of the dead.
For prisoners ask'st thou? hell our prison is.
But tell me whom thou seek'st.
But where's the great Alcides of the field
Lord Talbot of Goodrig and Urchinfield
Knight of the noble order of Saint George
Great marshal to Henry the Sixth
Of all his wars within the realm of France?
Here is a silly stately style indeed!
The Turk
Him that thou magnifiest with all these titles
Stinking and fly-blown lies here at our feet.
Is Talbot slain
O
O
It were enough to fright the realm of France:
Were but his picture left amongst you here
Give me their bodies
And give them burial as beseems their worth.
I think this upstart is old Talbot's ghost
For God's sake let him have 'em; to keep them here
Go
I'll bear them hence; but from their ashes shall be rear'd
A phoenix that shall make all France afeard.
So we be rid of them
And now to Paris
All will be ours
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. London. The palace.
Sennet. Enter KING HENRY VI
Have you perused the letters from the pope
I have
They humbly sue unto your excellence
To have a godly peace concluded of
Between the realms of England and of France.
How doth your grace affect their motion?
Well
To stop effusion of our Christian blood
And 'stablish quietness on every side.
Ay
It was both impious and unnatural
That such immanity and bloody strife
Should reign among professors of one faith.
Beside
And surer bind this knot of amity
In marriage
Marriage
And fitter is my study and my books
Than wanton dalliance with a paramour.
Yet call the ambassador; and
I shall be well content with any choice
Tends to God's glory and my country's weal.
Enter CARDINAL OF WINCHESTER in Cardinal's habit
What! is my Lord of Winchester install'd
Then I perceive that will be verified
Henry the Fifth did sometime prophesy
My lords ambassadors
Have been consider'd and debated on.
And therefore are we certainly resolved
To draw conditions of a friendly peace;
Which by my Lord of Winchester we mean
Shall be transported presently to France.
And for the proffer of my lord your master
As liking of the lady's virtuous gifts
In argument and proof of which contract
And so
And safely brought to Dover; where inshipp'd
Commit them to the fortune of the sea.
Exeunt all but CARDINAL OF WINCHESTER and Legate
CARDINAL
Stay
The sum of money which I promised
Should be deliver'd to his holiness
For clothing me in these grave ornaments.
I will attend upon your lordship's leisure.
CARDINAL
[Aside]  Now Winchester will not submit
Humphrey of Gloucester
That
I'll either make thee stoop and bend thy knee
Exeunt
SCENE II. France. Plains in Anjou.
Enter CHARLES
These news
'Tis said the stout Parisians do revolt
And turn again unto the warlike French.
Then march to Paris
Peace be amongst them
Else
Enter Scout
Success unto our valiant general
What tidings send our scouts? I prithee
The English army
Into two parties
Somewhat too sudden
But we will presently provide for them.
I trust the ghost of Talbot is not there:
Now he is gone
Of all base passions
Command the conquest
Then on
Exeunt
SCENE III. Before Angiers.
Alarum. Excursions. Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE
The regent conquers
Now help
And ye choice spirits that admonish me
And give me signs of future accidents.
Thunder
You speedy helpers
Under the lordly monarch of the north
Enter Fiends
This speedy and quick appearance argues proof
Of your accustom'd diligence to me.
Now
Out of the powerful regions under earth
They walk
O
Where I was wont to feed you with my blood
In earnest of further benefit
They hang their heads
No hope to have redress? My body shall
Pay recompense
They shake their heads
Cannot my body nor blood-sacrifice
Entreat you to your wonted furtherance?
Then take my soul
They depart
See
That France must vail her lofty-plumed crest
And let her head fall into England's lap.
My ancient incantations are too weak
Now
Exit
Excursions. Re-enter JOAN LA PUCELLE fighting hand  to hand with YORK. JOAN LA PUCELLE is taken. The French fly.
Damsel of France
Unchain your spirits now with spelling charms
And try if they can gain your liberty.
A goodly prize
See
Changed to a worser shape thou canst not be.
O
No shape but his can please your dainty eye.
A plaguing mischief light on Charles and thee!
And may ye both be suddenly surprised
By bloody hands
Fell banning hag
I prithee
Curse
Exeunt
Alarum. Enter SUFFOLK with MARGARET in his hand
Be what thou wilt
Gazes on her
O fairest beauty
For I will touch thee but with reverent hands;
I kiss these fingers for eternal peace
Who art thou? say
Margaret my name
An earl I am
Be not offended
So doth the swan her downy cygnets save
Yet
Go
She is going
O
My hand would free her
As plays the sun upon the glassy streams
Fain would I woo her
I'll call for pen and ink
Fie
Hast not a tongue? is she not here?
Wilt thou be daunted at a woman's sight?
Ay
Say
What ransom must I pay before I pass?
For I perceive I am thy prisoner.
How canst thou tell she will deny thy suit
Why speak'st thou not? what ransom must I pay?
She's beautiful
She is a woman
Wilt thou accept of ransom? yea
Fond man
Then how can Margaret be thy paramour?
I were best to leave him
There all is marr'd; there lies a cooling card.
He talks at random; sure
And yet a dispensation may be had.
And yet I would that you would answer me.
I'll win this Lady Margaret. For whom?
Why
He talks of wood: it is some carpenter.
Yet so my fancy may be satisfied
But there remains a scruple in that too;
For though her father be the King of Naples
Hear ye
It shall be so
Henry is youthful and will quickly yield.
Madam
What though I be enthrall'd? he seems a knight
Lady
Perhaps I shall be rescued by the French;
And then I need not crave his courtesy.
Sweet madam
Tush
Lady
I cry you mercy
Say
Your bondage happy
To be a queen in bondage is more vile
Than is a slave in base servility;
For princes should be free.
And so shall you
Why
I'll undertake to make thee Henry's queen
And set a precious crown upon thy head
What?
His love.
I am unworthy to be Henry's wife.
No
To woo so fair a dame to be his wife
How say you
An if my father please
Then call our captains and our colours forth.
And
We'll crave a parley
A parley sounded. Enter REIGNIER on the walls
See
To whom?
To me.
Suffolk
I am a soldier
Yes
Consent
Whom I with pain have woo'd and won thereto;
And this her easy-held imprisonment
Hath gained thy daughter princely liberty.
Speaks Suffolk as he thinks?
Fair Margaret knows
That Suffolk doth not flatter
Upon thy princely warrant
To give thee answer of thy just demand.
Exit from the walls
And here I will expect thy coming.
Trumpets sound. Enter REIGNIER
Welcome
Command in Anjou what your honour pleases.
Thanks
What answer makes your grace unto my suit?
Since thou dost deign to woo her little worth
To be the princely bride of such a lord;
Upon condition I may quietly
Enjoy mine own
That is her ransom; I deliver her;
And those two counties I will undertake
Your grace shall well and quietly enjoy.
And I again
Reignier of France
Aside
And yet
To be mine own attorney in this case.
I'll over then to England with this news
So farewell
In golden palaces
I do embrace thee
The Christian prince
Farewell
Shall Suffolk ever have of Margaret.
Going
Farewell
No princely commendations to my king?
Such commendations as becomes a maid
Words sweetly placed and modestly directed.
But madam
No loving token to his majesty?
Yes
And this withal.
Kisses her
That for thyself: I will not so presume
To send such peevish tokens to a king.
Exeunt REIGNIER and MARGARET
O
Thou mayst not wander in that labyrinth;
There Minotaurs and ugly treasons lurk.
Solicit Henry with her wondrous praise:
Bethink thee on her virtues that surmount
Repeat their semblance often on the seas
Exit
SCENE IV. Camp of the YORK in Anjou.
Enter YORK
Bring forth that sorceress condemn'd to burn.
Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE
Ah
Have I sought every country far and near
Ah
Decrepit miser! base ignoble wretch!
I am descended of a gentler blood:
Thou art no father nor no friend of mine.
Out
I did beget her
Her mother liveth yet
She was the first fruit of my bachelorship.
Graceless! wilt thou deny thy parentage?
This argues what her kind of life hath been
Fie
God knows thou art a collop of my flesh;
And for thy sake have I shed many a tear:
Deny me not
Peasant
'Tis true
The morn that I was wedded to her mother.
Kneel down and take my blessing
Wilt thou not stoop? Now cursed be the time
Of thy nativity! I would the milk
Thy mother gave thee when thou suck'dst her breast
Or else
Dost thou deny thy father
O
Exit
Take her away; for she hath lived too long
First
Not me begotten of a shepherd swain
Virtuous and holy; chosen from above
I never had to do with wicked spirits:
But you
To compass wonders but by help of devils.
No
A virgin from her tender infancy
Whose maiden blood
Ay
And hark ye
Place barrels of pitch upon the fatal stake
Will nothing turn your unrelenting hearts?
Then
I am with child
Murder not then the fruit within my womb
Now heaven forfend! the holy maid with child!
The greatest miracle that e'er ye wrought:
Is all your strict preciseness come to this?
She and the Dauphin have been juggling:
I did imagine what would be her refuge.
Well
Especially since Charles must father it.
You are deceived; my child is none of his:
It was Alencon that enjoy'd my love.
Alencon! that notorious Machiavel!
It dies
O
'Twas neither Charles nor yet the duke I named
A married man! that's most intolerable.
Why
It's sign she hath been liberal and free.
And yet
Strumpet
Use no entreaty
Then lead me hence; with whom I leave my curse:
May never glorious sun reflex his beams
Upon the country where you make abode;
But darkness and the gloomy shade of death
Environ you
Drive you to break your necks or hang yourselves!
Exit
Break thou in pieces and consume to ashes
Enter CARDINAL OF WINCHESTER
CARDINAL
Lord regent
With letters of commission from the king.
For know
Betwixt our nation and the aspiring French;
And here at hand the Dauphin and his train
Approacheth
Is all our travail turn'd to this effect?
After the slaughter of so many peers
And sold their bodies for their country's benefit
Have we not lost most part of all the towns
O Warwick
The utter loss of all the realm of France.
Be patient
As little shall the Frenchmen gain thereby.
Enter CHARLES
Since
That peaceful truce shall be proclaim'd in France
What the conditions of that league must be.
Speak
The hollow passage of my poison'd voice
CARDINAL
Charles
That
And Charles
To pay him tribute
Must he be then as shadow of himself?
Adorn his temples with a coronet
This proffer is absurd and reasonless.
'Tis known already that I am possess'd
With more than half the Gallian territories
Shall I
No
That which I have than
Insulting Charles! hast thou by secret means
Used intercession to obtain a league
Either accept the title thou usurp'st
And not of any challenge of desert
My lord
To cavil in the course of this contract:
If once it be neglected
We shall not find like opportunity.
To say the truth
To save your subjects from such massacre
And ruthless slaughters as are daily seen
By our proceeding in hostility;
And therefore take this compact of a truce
How say'st thou
It shall;
Only reserved
In any of our towns of garrison.
Then swear allegiance to his majesty
Nor be rebellious to the crown of England
So
Hang up your ensign
Exeunt
SCENE V. London. The palace.
Enter SUFFOLK in conference with KING HENRY VI
Your wondrous rare description
Her virtues graced with external gifts
Do breed love's settled passions in my heart:
And like as rigor of tempestuous gusts
Provokes the mightiest hulk against the tide
Either to suffer shipwreck or arrive
Where I may have fruition of her love.
Tush
Is but a preface of her worthy praise;
The chief perfections of that lovely dame
Had I sufficient skill to utter them
And
She is content to be at your command;
Command
And otherwise will Henry ne'er presume.
Therefore
That Margaret may be England's royal queen.
So should I give consent to flatter sin.
You know
Unto another lady of esteem:
How shall we then dispense with that contract
As doth a ruler with unlawful oaths;
Or one that
To try his strength
By reason of his adversary's odds:
A poor earl's daughter is unequal odds
Why
Her father is no better than an earl
Yes
And of such great authority in France
As his alliance will confirm our peace
And keep the Frenchmen in allegiance.
And so the Earl of Armagnac may do
Beside
A dower
Henry is able to enrich his queen
And not seek a queen to make him rich:
So worthless peasants bargain for their wives
Marriage is a matter of more worth
Than to be dealt in by attorneyship;
Not whom we will
And therefore
For what is wedlock forced but a hell
Whereas the contrary bringeth bliss
Whom should we match with Henry
Her peerless feature
Her valiant courage and undaunted spirit
For Henry
As is fair Margaret he be link'd in love.
Then yield
That Margaret shall be queen
Whether it be through force of your report
My tender youth was never yet attaint
With any passion of inflaming love
Take
Agree to any covenants
That Lady Margaret do vouchsafe to come
To cross the seas to England and be crown'd
King Henry's faithful and anointed queen:
For your expenses and sufficient charge
Be gone
And you
If you do censure me by what you were
This sudden execution of my will.
And so
Exit
Ay
Exeunt GLOUCESTER and EXETER
Thus Suffolk hath prevail'd; and thus he goes
Margaret shall now be queen
But I will rule both her
Exit
ACT I
SCENE I. London. The palace.
Flourish of trumpets: then hautboys. Enter KING  HENRY VI
As by your high imperial majesty
I had in charge at my depart for France
And humbly now upon my bended knee
To your most gracious hands
Of that great shadow I did represent;
The happiest gift that ever marquess gave
Suffolk
I can express no kinder sign of love
Than this kind kiss. O Lord
For thou hast given me in this beauteous face
A world of earthly blessings to my soul
Great King of England and my gracious lord
With ruder terms
And over-joy of heart doth minister.
Her sight did ravish; but her grace in speech
Such is the fulness of my heart's content.
Lords
[Kneeling]  Long live Queen Margaret
happiness!
We thank you all.
Flourish
My lord protector
Between our sovereign and the French king Charles
[Reads]  'Imprimis
king Charles
Suffolk
the said Henry shall espouse the Lady Margaret
Jerusalem
thirtieth of May next ensuing. Item
of Anjou and the county of Maine shall be released
and delivered to the king her father'--
Lets the paper fall
Uncle
Pardon me
Some sudden qualm hath struck me at the heart
And dimm'd mine eyes
Uncle of Winchester
[Reads]  'Item
released and delivered over to the king her father
proper cost and charges
They please us well. Lord marquess
We here create thee the first duke of Suffolk
I' the parts of France
Be full expired. Thanks
We thank you all for the great favour done
Come
To see her coronation be perform'd.
Exeunt KING HENRY VI
Brave peers of England
What! did my brother Henry spend his youth
Did he so often lodge in open field
And did my brother Bedford toil his wits
Have you yourselves
Or hath mine uncle Beaufort and myself
Early and late
How France and Frenchmen might be kept in awe
Crowned in Paris in despite of foes?
And shall these labours and these honours die?
Shall Henry's conquest
O peers of England
Fatal this marriage
Nephew
For France
Ay
But now it is impossible we should:
Suffolk
Unto the poor King Reignier
Agrees not with the leanness of his purse.
Now
But wherefore weeps Warwick
For grief that they are past recovery:
For
Anjou and Maine! myself did win them both;
Those provinces these arms of mine did conquer:
And are the cities
Mort Dieu!
For Suffolk's duke
France should have torn and rent my very heart
I never read but England's kings have had
Large sums of gold and dowries with their wives:
And our King Henry gives away his own
A proper jest
For costs and charges in transporting her!
She should have stayed in France and starved
in France
My Lord of Gloucester
It was the pleasure of my lord the King.
My Lord of Winchester
'Tis not my speeches that you do mislike
Rancour will out: proud prelate
I see thy fury: if I longer stay
Lordings
Exit
So
'Tis known to you he is mine enemy
Consider
Had Henry got an empire by his marriage
Look to it
Bewitch your hearts; be wise and circumspect.
What though the common people favour him
Gloucester
Clapping their hands
With 'God preserve the good Duke Humphrey!'
I fear me
Why should he
Cousin of Somerset
This weighty business will not brook delay:
I'll to the Duke of Suffolk presently.
Exit
Cousin of Buckingham
And greatness of his place be grief to us
His insolence is more intolerable
Than all the princes in the land beside:
If Gloucester be displaced
Or thou or I
Exeunt BUCKINGHAM and SOMERSET
Pride went before
While these do labour for their own preferment
I never saw but Humphrey Duke of Gloucester
Did bear him like a noble gentleman.
Oft have I seen the haughty cardinal
Unlike the ruler of a commonweal.
Warwick
And
Join we together
The pride of Suffolk and the cardinal
And
So God help Warwick
[Aside]  And so says York
Then let's make haste away
Unto the main! O father
That Maine which by main force Warwick did win
Main chance
Anjou and Maine are given to the French;
Paris is lost; the state of Normandy
Stands on a tickle point
Suffolk concluded on the articles
To change two dukedoms for a duke's fair daughter.
I cannot blame them all: what is't to them?
'Tis thine they give away
Pirates may make cheap pennyworths of their pillage
And purchase friends and give to courtezans
While as the silly owner of the goods
Weeps over them and wrings his hapless hands
And shakes his head and trembling stands aloof
So York must sit and fret and bite his tongue
Methinks the realms of England
Bear that proportion to my flesh and blood
As did the fatal brand Althaea burn'd
Unto the prince's heart of Calydon.
Anjou and Maine both given unto the French!
Cold news for me
A day will come when York shall claim his own;
And therefore I will take the Nevils' parts
And make a show of love to proud Duke Humphrey
Nor shall proud Lancaster usurp my right
Then
Watch thou and wake when others be asleep
Till Henry
Then will I raise aloft the milk-white rose
And in my standard bear the arms of York
To grapple with the house of Lancaster;
And
Exit
SCENE II. GLOUCESTER'S house.
Enter GLOUCESTER and his DUCHESS
Why droops my lord
Why doth the great Duke Humphrey knit his brows
Why are thine eyes fixed to the sullen earth
What seest thou there? King Henry's diadem
If so
Put forth thy hand
What
And
As to vouchsafe one glance unto the ground.
O Nell
And may that thought
Against my king and nephew
My troublous dream this night doth make me sad.
What dream'd my lord? tell me
With sweet rehearsal of my morning's dream.
Methought this staff
And on the pieces of the broken wand
Were placed the heads of Edmund Duke of Somerset
This was my dream: what it doth bode
Tut
That he that breaks a stick of Gloucester's grove
Shall lose his head for his presumption.
But list to me
Methought I sat in seat of majesty
In the cathedral church of Westminster
Where Henry and dame Margaret kneel'd to me
And on my head did set the diadem.
Nay
Presumptuous dame
Hast thou not worldly pleasure at command
And wilt thou still be hammering treachery
From top of honour to disgrace's feet?
Away from me
What
With Eleanor
Next time I'll keep my dreams unto myself
Nay
Enter Messenger
My lord protector
You do prepare to ride unto Saint Alban's
I go. Come
Yes
Exeunt GLOUCESTER and Messenger
Follow I must; I cannot go before
Were I a man
And smooth my way upon their headless necks;
And
To play my part in Fortune's pageant.
Where are you there? Sir John! nay
Enter HUME
Jesus preserve your royal majesty!
What say'st thou? majesty! I am but grace.
But
What say'st thou
With Margery Jourdain
And will they undertake to do me good?
This they have promised
A spirit raised from depth of under-ground
As by your grace shall be propounded him.
It is enough; I'll think upon the questions:
When from St. Alban's we do make return
Here
Exit
Hume must make merry with the duchess' gold;
Marry
Seal up your lips
The business asketh silent secrecy.
Dame Eleanor gives gold to bring the witch:
Gold cannot come amiss
Yet have I gold flies from another coast;
I dare not say
And from the great and new-made Duke of Suffolk
And buz these conjurations in her brain.
They say 'A crafty knave does need no broker;'
Yet am I Suffolk and the cardinal's broker.
Hume
To call them both a pair of crafty knaves.
Well
Hume's knavery will be the duchess' wreck
Sort how it will
Exit

will come this way by and by

protector.

My Lord of Suffolk
Is this the government of Britain's isle
What shall King Henry be a pupil still
Under the surly Gloucester's governance?
Am I a queen in title and in style
I tell thee
Thou ran'st a tilt in honour of my love
And stolest away the ladies' hearts of France
In courage
But all his mind is bent to holiness
His champions are the prophets and apostles
Are brazen images of canonized saints.
I would the college of the cardinals
Would choose him pope
That were a state fit for his holiness.
Madam
Your highness came to England
In England work your grace's full content.
Beside the haughty protector
But can do more in England than the king.
And he of these that can do most of all
Cannot do more in England than the Nevils:
Salisbury and Warwick are no simple peers.
Not all these lords do vex me half so much
As that proud dame
She sweeps it through the court with troops of ladies
Strangers in court do take her for the queen:
She bears a duke's revenues on her back
Shall I not live to be avenged on her?
Contemptuous base-born callet as she is
Was better worth than all my father's lands
Madam
So
For I am bold to counsel you in this.
Although we fancy not the cardinal
As for the Duke of York
Will make but little for his benefit.
So
Sound a sennet. Enter KING HENRY VI
For my part
Or Somerset or York
If York have ill demean'd himself in France
If Somerset be unworthy of the place
Whether your grace be worthy
Ambitious Warwick
The cardinal's not my better in the field.
All in this presence are thy betters
Warwick may live to be the best of all.
Peace
Because the king
Madam
To give his censure: these are no women's matters.
If he be old enough
To be protector of his excellence?
Madam
And
Resign it then and leave thine insolence.
Since thou wert king--as who is king but thou?--
The commonwealth hath daily run to wreck;
The Dauphin hath prevail'd beyond the seas;
And all the peers and nobles of the realm
Have been as bondmen to thy sovereignty.
The commons hast thou rack'd; the clergy's bags
Are lank and lean with thy extortions.
Thy sumptuous buildings and thy wife's attire
Have cost a mass of public treasury.
Thy cruelty in execution
Upon offenders
They sale of offices and towns in France
Exit GLOUCESTER. QUEEN MARGARET drops her fan
Give me my fan: what
She gives the DUCHESS a box on the ear
I cry you mercy
Was't I! yea
Could I come near your beauty with my nails
Sweet aunt
Against her will! good king
She'll hamper thee
Though in this place most master wear no breeches
Exit
Lord cardinal
She's tickled now; her fume needs no spurs
Exit

Now
With walking once about the quadrangle
As for your spiteful false objections
But God in mercy so deal with my soul
But
I say
To be your regent in the realm of France.
Before we make election
To show some reason
I'll tell thee
First
Next
Last time
Till Paris was besieged
That can I witness; and a fouler fact
Did never traitor in the land commit.
Peace
Image of pride

Doth any one accuse York for a traitor?
What mean'st thou
Please it your majesty
That doth accuse his master of high treason:
His words were these: that Richard
And that your majesty was a usurper.
Say

thought any such matter: God is my witness

Lord of York's armour.
Base dunghill villain and mechanical

Uncle
This doom

This is the law

my case. The spite of man prevaileth against me. O

As the Spirit speaks

Let him shun castles;

Than where castles mounted stand.

ACT II
SCENE I. Saint Alban's.
Enter KING HENRY VI
Believe me
Yet
And
But what a point
To see how God in all his creatures works!
Yea
No marvel
They know their master loves to be aloft
My lord
That mounts no higher than a bird can soar.
I thought as much; he would be above the clouds.
Ay
Were it not good your grace could fly to heaven?
The treasury of everlasting joy.
Thy heaven is on earth; thine eyes and thoughts
Beat on a crown
Pernicious protector
What
Tantaene animis coelestibus irae?
Churchmen so hot? good uncle
With such holiness can you do it?
No malice
So good a quarrel and so bad a peer.
As who
Why
Why
And thy ambition
I prithee
For blessed are the peacemakers on earth.

Protector
The winds grow high; so do your stomachs
How irksome is this music to my heart!
When such strings jar
I pray

What means this noise?
Fellow
A miracle! a miracle!
Come to the king and tell him what miracle.
Forsooth
A man that ne'er saw in his life before.
Now
Gives light in darkness

His wife

better told.

At Berwick in the north

A hundred times and oftener
Most true

A fall off of a tree.

Born so

Saint Alban.

What's his name?
I know not.
Nor his?
No
What's thine own name?
Saunder Simpcox
Then
Christendom. If thou hadst been born blind
mightest as well have known all our names as thus to
name the several colours we do wear. Sight may
distinguish of colours
all
hath done a miracle; and would ye not think his
cunning to be great
to his legs again?
O master
My masters of Saint Alban's
your town
Yes
Then send for one presently.
Sirrah
Exit an Attendant
Now fetch me a stool hither by and by. Now
over this stool and run away.
Alas
You go about to torture me in vain.
Enter a Beadle with whips
Well
beadle
I will
doublet quickly.
Alas
After the Beadle hath hit him once
O God
It made me laugh to see the villain run.
Follow the knave; and take this drab away.
Alas
Let them be whipped through every market-town
they come to Berwick
Exeunt Wife
Duke Humphrey has done a miracle to-day.
True; made the lame to leap and fly away.
But you have done more miracles than I;
You made in a day
Enter BUCKINGHAM
What tidings with our cousin Buckingham?
Such as my heart doth tremble to unfold.
A sort of naughty persons
Of Lady Eleanor
Whom we have apprehended in the fact;
Raising up wicked spirits from under ground
As more at large your grace shall understand.
[Aside to GLOUCESTER]  And so
Your lady is forthcoming yet at London.
This news
'Tis like
Ambitious churchman
Sorrow and grief have vanquish'd all my powers;
And
O God
Gloucester
And look thyself be faultless
Madam
And
Sorry I am to hear what I have heard:
Noble she is
Honour and virtue and conversed with such
As
And give her as a prey to law and shame
Well
To-morrow toward London back again
And call these foul offenders to their answers
And poise the cause in justice' equal scales
Flourish. Exeunt
SCENE II. London. YORK'S garden.
Enter YORK
Now
In this close walk to satisfy myself
My lord
Sweet York
Then thus:
Edward the Third
The first
The second
Was John of Gaunt
The fifth was Edmund Langley
The sixth was Thomas of Woodstock
William of Windsor was the seventh and last.
Edward the Black Prince died before his father
And left behind him Richard
Till Henry Bolingbroke
Father
Thus got the house of Lancaster the crown.
Which now they hold by force and not by right;
For Richard
But William of Hatfield died without an heir.
The third son
I claimed the crown
Edmund had issue
Roger had issue
This Edmund
And
But to the rest.
His eldest sister
Married Richard Earl of Cambridge; who was son
To Edmund Langley
By her I claim the kingdom: she was heir
To Roger Earl of March
Of Edmund Mortimer
So
Succeed before the younger
What plain proceeding is more plain than this?
Henry doth claim the crown from John of Gaunt
Till Lionel's issue fails
It fails not yet
And in thy sons
Then
And in this private plot be we the first
That shall salute our rightful sovereign
With honour of his birthright to the crown.
Long live our sovereign Richard
We thank you
Till I be crown'd and that my sword be stain'd
With heart-blood of the house of Lancaster;
And that's not suddenly to be perform'd
Do you as I do in these dangerous days:
Wink at the Duke of Suffolk's insolence
'Tis that they seek
Shall find their deaths
My lord
My heart assures me that the Earl of Warwick
Shall one day make the Duke of York a king.
And
Richard shall live to make the Earl of Warwick
The greatest man in England but the king.
Exeunt
SCENE III. A hall of justice.
Sound trumpets. Enter KING HENRY VI
Stand forth
In sight of God and us
Receive the sentence of the law for sins
Such as by God's book are adjudged to death.
You four
From thence unto the place of execution:
The witch in Smithfield shall be burn'd to ashes
You
Welcome is banishment; welcome were my death.
Eleanor
I cannot justify whom the law condemns.
Exeunt DUCHESS and other prisoners
Mine eyes are full of tears
Ah
Will bring thy head with sorrow to the ground!
I beseech your majesty
Sorrow would solace and mine age would ease.
Stay
Protector be; and God shall be my hope
And go in peace
Than when thou wert protector to thy King.
I see no reason why a king of years
Should be to be protected like a child.
God and King Henry govern England's realm.
Give up your staff
My staff? here
As willingly do I the same resign
As e'er thy father Henry made it mine;
And even as willingly at thy feet I leave it
As others would ambitiously receive it.
Farewell
Exit
Why
And Humphrey Duke of Gloucester scarce himself
His lady banish'd
This staff of honour raught
Where it best fits to be
Thus droops this lofty pine and hangs his sprays;
Thus Eleanor's pride dies in her youngest days.
Lords
And ready are the appellant and defendant
Ay
Left I the court
O God's name
Here let them end it; and God defend the right!
I never saw a fellow worse bested
Enter at one door
Here
sack: and fear not
And here

SCENE IV. A street.
Enter GLOUCESTER and his Servingmen
Thus sometimes hath the brightest day a cloud;
And after summer evermore succeeds
Barren winter
So cares and joys abound
Sirs
Ten
Ten is the hour that was appointed me
To watch the coming of my punish'd duchess:
Uneath may she endure the flinty streets
Sweet Nell
The abject people gazing on thy face
When thou didst ride in triumph through the streets.
But
My tear-stain'd eyes to see her miseries.
Enter the DUCHESS in a white sheet
So please your grace
No
Come you
Now thou dost penance too. Look how they gaze!
See how the giddy multitude do point
Ah
Be patient
Ah
For whilst I think I am thy married wife
And thou a prince
To see my tears and hear my deep-fet groans.
The ruthless flint doth cut my tender feet
And bid me be advised how I tread.
Ah
Trow'st thou that e'er I'll look upon the world
No; dark shall be my light and night my day;
To think upon my pomp shall be my hell.
Sometime I'll say
Yet so he ruled and such a prince he was
As he stood by whilst I
To every idle rascal follower.
But be thou mild and blush not at my shame
Hang over thee
For Suffolk
With her that hateth thee and hates us all
But fear not thou
Ah
I must offend before I be attainted;
And had I twenty times so many foes
Wouldst have me rescue thee from this reproach?
Why
But I in danger for the breach of law.
Thy greatest help is quiet
I pray thee
These few days' wonder will be quickly worn.
Enter a Herald
I summon your grace to his majesty's parliament
And my consent ne'er ask'd herein before!
This is close dealing. Well
Exit Herald
My Nell
An't please your grace
To take her with him to the Isle of Man.
Must you
So am I given in charge
Entreat her not the worse in that I pray
You use her well: the world may laugh again;
And I may live to do you kindness if
You do it her: and so
What
Witness my tears
Exeunt GLOUCESTER and Servingmen
Art thou gone too? all comfort go with thee!
For none abides with me: my joy is death;
Death
Stanley
I care not whither
Why
There to be used according to your state.
That's bad enough
And shall I then be used reproachfully?
Like to a duchess
According to that state you shall be used.
Sheriff
It is my office; and
Ay
Come
Madam
My shame will not be shifted with my sheet:
No
And show itself
Go
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. The Abbey at Bury St. Edmund's.
Sound a sennet. Enter KING HENRY VI
I muse my Lord of Gloucester is not come:
'Tis not his wont to be the hindmost man
Can you not see? or will ye not observe
The strangeness of his alter'd countenance?
With what a majesty he bears himself
We know the time since he was mild and affable
But meet him now
Small curs are not regarded when they grin;
But great men tremble when the lion roars;
And Humphrey is no little man in England.
First note that he is near you in descent
Me seemeth then it is no policy
And his advantage following your decease
Or be admitted to your highness' council.
By flattery hath he won the commons' hearts
Now 'tis the spring
Suffer them now
And choke the herbs for want of husbandry.
The reverent care I bear unto my lord
Made me collect these dangers in the duke.
If it be fond
Which fear if better reasons can supplant
My Lord of Suffolk
Or else conclude my words effectual.
Well hath your highness seen into this duke;
And
The duchess
Or
By wicked means to frame our sovereign's fall.
Smooth runs the water where the brook is deep;
And in his simple show he harbours treason.
The fox barks not when he would steal the lamb.
No
Unsounded yet and full of deep deceit.
Did he not
And did he not
For soldiers' pay in France
By means whereof the towns each day revolted.
Tut
Which time will bring to light in smooth
Duke Humphrey.
My lords
From meaning treason to our royal person
As is the sucking lamb or harmless dove:
The duke is virtuous
To dream on evil or to work my downfall.
Ah
Seems he a dove? his feathers are but borrowed
Is he a lamb? his skin is surely lent him
Who cannot steal a shape that means deceit?
Take heed
Hangs on the cutting short that fraudful man.
Enter SOMERSET
All health unto my gracious sovereign!
Welcome
That all your interest in those territories
Is utterly bereft you; all is lost.
Cold news
[Aside]  Cold news for me; for I had hope of France
As firmly as I hope for fertile England.
Thus are my blossoms blasted in the bud
And caterpillars eat my leaves away;
But I will remedy this gear ere long
Enter GLOUCESTER
All happiness unto my lord the king!
Pardon
Nay
I do arrest thee of high treason here.
Well
Nor change my countenance for this arrest:
A heart unspotted is not easily daunted.
The purest spring is not so free from mud
As I am clear from treason to my sovereign:
Who can accuse me? wherein am I guilty?
'Tis thought
By means whereof his highness hath lost France.
Is it but thought so? what are they that think it?
I never robb'd the soldiers of their pay
So help me God
No; many a pound of mine own proper store
It serves you well
I say no more than truth
In your protectorship you did devise
Strange tortures for offenders never heard of
Why
protector
For I should melt at an offender's tears
Unless it were a bloody murderer
Murder indeed
Above the felon or what trespass else.
My lord
But mightier crimes are laid unto your charge
I do arrest you in his highness' name;
And here commit you to my lord cardinal
To keep
My lord of Gloucester
That you will clear yourself from all suspect:
My conscience tells me you are innocent.
Ah
Virtue is choked with foul ambition
And charity chased hence by rancour's hand;
Foul subornation is predominant
And equity exiled your highness' land.
I know their complot is to have my life
But mine is made the prologue to their play;
For thousands more
Beaufort's red sparkling eyes blab his heart's malice
Sharp Buckingham unburthens with his tongue
The envious load that lies upon his heart;
And dogged York
And you
My liefest liege to be mine enemy:
Ay
Myself had notice of your conventicles--
And all to make away my guiltless life.
I shall not want false witness to condemn me
The ancient proverb will be well effected:
'A staff is quickly found to beat a dog.'
My liege
If those that care to keep your royal person
From treason's secret knife and traitors' rage
Be thus upbraided
Hath he not twit our sovereign lady here
With ignominious words
False allegations to o'erthrow his state?
But I can give the loser leave to chide.
Far truer spoke than meant: I lose
Beshrew the winners
And well such losers may have leave to speak.
He'll wrest the sense and hold us here all day:
Lord cardinal
Sirs
Ah! thus King Henry throws away his crutch
Before his legs be firm to bear his body.
Thus is the shepherd beaten from thy side
Ah
For
Exit
My lords
What
Ay
Ah
The map of honour
And yet
That e'er I proved thee false or fear'd thy faith.
What louring star now envies thy estate
Do seek subversion of thy harmless life?
Thou never didst them wrong
And as the butcher takes away the calf
And binds the wretch
And as the dam runs lowing up and down
With sad unhelpful tears
Look after him and cannot do him good
His fortunes I will weep; and
Say 'Who's a traitor? Gloucester he is none.'
Exeunt all but QUEEN MARGARET
Free lords
Henry my lord is cold in great affairs
Beguiles him as the mournful crocodile
With sorrow snares relenting passengers
That for the beauty thinks it excellent.
Believe me
And yet herein I judge mine own wit good--
This Gloucester should be quickly rid the world
That he should die is worthy policy;
But yet we want a colour for his death:
'Tis meet he be condemn'd by course of law.
But
The king will labour still to save his life
And yet we have but trivial argument
So that
Ah
'Tis York that hath more reason for his death.
But
To guard the chicken from a hungry kite
So the poor chicken should be sure of death.
Madam
Who being accused a crafty murderer
No; let him die
And do not stand on quillets how to slay him:
Be it by gins
Which mates him first that first intends deceit.
Thrice-noble Suffolk
Not resolute
For things are often spoke and seldom meant:
But that my heart accordeth with my tongue
But I would have him dead
Say you consent and censure well the deed
Here is my hand
And so say I.
And I    and now we three have spoke it
Enter a Post
Great lords
And put the Englishmen unto the sword:
Send succors
For
A breach that craves a quick expedient stop!
What counsel give you in this weighty cause?
That Somerset be sent as regent thither:
'Tis meet that lucky ruler be employ'd;
Witness the fortune he hath had in France.
If York
No
I rather would have lost my life betimes
Than bring a burthen of dishonour home
By staying there so long till all were lost.
Show me one scar character'd on thy skin:
Men's flesh preserved so whole do seldom win.
Nay
No more
Thy fortune
What
And
My Lord of York
The uncivil kerns of Ireland are in arms
And temper clay with blood of Englishmen:
To Ireland will you lead a band of men
I will
Why
Then
I am content: provide me soldiers
A charge
But now return we to the false Duke Humphrey.
No more of him; for I will deal with him
That henceforth he shall trouble us no more.
And so break off; the day is almost spent:
Lord Suffolk
My Lord of Suffolk
At Bristol I expect my soldiers;
For there I'll ship them all for Ireland.
I'll see it truly done
Exeunt all but YORK
Now
Be that thou hopest to be
Resign to death; it is not worth the enjoying:
Let pale-faced fear keep with the mean-born man
Faster than spring-time showers comes thought
on thought
My brain more busy than the labouring spider
Weaves tedious snares to trap mine enemies.
Well
I fear me you but warm the starved snake
your hearts.
'Twas men I lack'd and you will give them me:
I take it kindly; and yet be well assured
You put sharp weapons in a madman's hands.
Whiles I in Ireland nourish a mighty band
Shall blow ten thousand souls to heaven or hell;
And this fell tempest shall not cease to rage
Until the golden circuit on my head
And
In Ireland have I seen this stubborn Cade
Oppose himself against a troop of kerns
Were almost like a sharp-quill'd porpentine;
And
Him caper upright like a wild Morisco
Full often
And given me notice of their villanies.
This devil here shall be my substitute;
For that John Mortimer
By this I shall perceive the commons' mind
Say he be taken
Will make him say I moved him to those arms.
Say that he thrive
And reap the harvest which that rascal sow'd;
For Humphrey being dead
Exit
SCENE II. Bury St. Edmund's. A room of state.
Enter certain Murderers
Run to my Lord of Suffolk; let him know
We have dispatch'd the duke
O that it were to do! What have we done?
Didst ever hear a man so penitent?
Enter SUFFOLK
Here comes my lord.
Now
Ay
Why
I will reward you for this venturous deed.
The king and all the peers are here at hand.
Have you laid fair the bed? Is all things well
'Tis
Away! be gone.
Exeunt Murderers
Sound trumpets. Enter KING HENRY VI
Go
Say we intend to try his grace to-day.
If he be guilty
I'll call him presently
Exit
Lords
Than from true evidence of good esteem
He be approved in practise culpable.
God forbid any malice should prevail
Pray God he may acquit him of suspicion!
I thank thee
Re-enter SUFFOLK
How now! why look'st thou pale? why tremblest thou?
Where is our uncle? what's the matter
Dead in his bed
Marry
God's secret judgment: I did dream to-night
The duke was dumb and could not speak a word.
KING HENRY VI swoons
How fares my lord? Help
Rear up his body; wring him by the nose.
Run
He doth revive again: madam
O heavenly God!
How fares my gracious lord?
Comfort
What
Came he right now to sing a raven's note
And thinks he that the chirping of a wren
Hide not thy poison with such sugar'd words;
Lay not thy hands on me; forbear
Their touch affrights me as a serpent's sting.
Thou baleful messenger
Upon thy eye-balls murderous tyranny
Sits in grim majesty
Look not upon me
Yet do not go away: come
For in the shade of death I shall find joy;
In life but double death
Why do you rate my Lord of Suffolk thus?
Although the duke was enemy to him
And for myself
Or blood-consuming sighs recall his life
What know I how the world may deem of me?
For it is known we were but hollow friends:
It may be judged I made the duke away;
So shall my name with slander's tongue be wounded
This get I by his death: ay me
To be a queen
Ah
Be woe for me
What
I am no loathsome leper; look on me.
What! art thou
Be poisonous too and kill thy forlorn queen.
Is all thy comfort shut in Gloucester's tomb?
Why
Erect his statue and worship it
Was I for this nigh wreck'd upon the sea
And twice by awkward wind from England's bank
Drove back again unto my native clime?
What boded this
Did seem to say 'Seek not a scorpion's nest
What did I then
And he that loosed them forth their brazen caves:
And bid them blow towards England's blessed shore
Yet AEolus would not be a murderer
The pretty-vaulting sea refused to drown me
The splitting rocks cower'd in the sinking sands
And would not dash me with their ragged sides
As far as I could ken thy chalky cliffs
My earnest-gaping sight of thy land's view
And even with this I lost fair England's view
And bid mine eyes be packing with my heart
And call'd them blind and dusky spectacles
How often have I tempted Suffolk's tongue
When he to madding Dido would unfold
His father's acts commenced in burning Troy!
Am I not witch'd like her? or thou not false like him?
Ay me
For Henry weeps that thou dost live so long.
Noise within. Enter WARWICK
It is reported
By Suffolk and the Cardinal Beaufort's means.
The commons
That want their leader
And care not who they sting in his revenge.
Myself have calm'd their spleenful mutiny
That he is dead
But how he died God knows
Enter his chamber
That shall I do
Exit
O Thou that judgest all things
Some violent hands were laid on Humphrey's life!
If my suspect be false
Fain would I go to chafe his paly lips
With twenty thousand kisses
Upon his face an ocean of salt tears
But all in vain are these mean obsequies;
And to survey his dead and earthly image
Re-enter WARWICK and others
Come hither
That is to see how deep my grave is made;
For with his soul fled all my worldly solace
As surely as my soul intends to live
With that dread King that took our state upon him
To free us from his father's wrathful curse
Upon the life of this thrice-famed duke.
A dreadful oath
What instance gives Lord Warwick for his vow?
See how the blood is settled in his face.
Oft have I seen a timely-parted ghost
Who
Which with the heart there cools and ne'er returneth
To blush and beautify the cheek again.
But see
His hair uprear'd
His hands abroad display'd
And tugg'd for life and was by strength subdued:
Look
His well-proportion'd beard made rough and rugged
It cannot be but he was murder'd here;
The least of all these signs were probable.
Why
Myself and Beaufort had him in protection;
And we
But both of you were vow'd Duke Humphrey's foes
'Tis like you would not feast him like a friend;
And 'tis well seen he found an enemy.
Then you
As guilty of Duke Humphrey's timeless death.
Who finds the heifer dead and bleeding fresh
And sees fast by a butcher with an axe
Who finds the partridge in the puttock's nest
Even so suspicious is this tragedy.
Are you the butcher
Is Beaufort term'd a kite? Where are his talons?
I wear no knife to slaughter sleeping men;
But here's a vengeful sword
That slanders me with murder's crimson badge.
Say
Exeunt CARDINAL
What dares not Warwick
He dares not calm his contumelious spirit
Nor cease to be an arrogant controller
Madam
For every word you speak in his behalf
Is slander to your royal dignity.
Blunt-witted lord
If ever lady wrong'd her lord so much
Some stern untutor'd churl
Was graft with crab-tree slip; whose fruit thou art
But that the guilt of murder bucklers thee
And I should rob the deathsman of his fee
Make thee beg pardon for thy passed speech
That thou thyself was born in bastardy;
And after all this fearful homage done
Thou shall be waking well I shed thy blood
Away even now
Unworthy though thou art
And do some service to Duke Humphrey's ghost.
Exeunt SUFFOLK and WARWICK
What stronger breastplate than a heart untainted!
Thrice is he armed that hath his quarrel just
Whose conscience with injustice is corrupted.
A noise within
What noise is this?
Re-enter SUFFOLK and WARWICK
Why
Here in our presence! dare you be so bold?
Why
The traitorous Warwick with the men of Bury
Set all upon me
[To the Commons
the king shall know your mind.
Dread lord
And torture him with grievous lingering death.
They say
They say
And mere instinct of love and loyalty
They say
And charge that no man should disturb your rest
In pain of your dislike or pain of death
And therefore do they cry
[Within]  An answer from the king
Lord of Salisbury!
'Tis like the commons
But you
But all the honour Salisbury hath won
Is
Sent from a sort of tinkers to the king.
[Within]  An answer from the king
Go
I thank them for their tender loving care;
And had I not been cited so by them
For
Mischance unto my state by Suffolk's means:
And therefore
But three days longer
Exit SALISBURY
O Henry
Ungentle queen
No more
Had I but said
If
On any ground that I am ruler of
Come
I have great matters to impart to thee.
Exeunt all but QUEEN MARGARET and SUFFOLK
Mischance and sorrow go along with you!
Heart's discontent and sour affliction
Be playfellows to keep you company!
There's two of you; the devil make a third!
And threefold vengeance tend upon your steps!
Cease
Fie
Hast thou not spirit to curse thine enemy?
A plague upon them! wherefore should I curse them?
Would curses kill
My tongue should stumble in mine earnest words;
Mine eyes should sparkle like the beaten flint;
Mine hair be fixed on end
Ay
And even now my burthen'd heart would break
Gall
Their sweetest shade a grove of cypress trees!
Their chiefest prospect murdering basilisks!
Their softest touch as smart as lizards' sting!
Their music frightful as the serpent's hiss
All the foul terrors in dark-seated hell--
Enough
And these dread curses
You bade me ban
Now
O
Nor let the rain of heaven wet this place
O
So
'Tis but surmised whiles thou art standing by
I will repeal thee
And banished I am
Go; speak not to me; even now be gone.
O
Embrace and kiss and take ten thousand leaves
Yet now farewell; and farewell life with thee!
Thus is poor Suffolk ten times banished;
Once by the king
'Tis not the land I care for
A wilderness is populous enough
For where thou art
I can no more: live thou to joy thy life;
Myself no joy in nought but that thou livest.
Enter VAUX
Wither goes Vaux so fast? what news
To signify unto his majesty
That Cardinal Beaufort is at point of death;
For suddenly a grievous sickness took him
Sometimes he talks as if Duke Humphrey's ghost
Were by his side; sometime he calls the king
And I am sent to tell his majesty
That even now he cries aloud for him.
Go tell this heavy message to the king.
Exit VAUX
Ay me! what is this world! what news are these!
But wherefore grieve I at an hour's poor loss
Why only
Now get thee hence: the king
If thou be found by me
If I depart from thee
And in thy sight to die
But like a pleasant slumber in thy lap?
Here could I breathe my soul into the air
Dying with mother's dug between its lips:
Where
So shouldst thou either turn my flying soul
To die by thee were but to die in jest;
From thee to die were torture more than death:
O
Away! though parting be a fretful corrosive
To France
For wheresoe'er thou art in this world's globe
I go.
And take my heart with thee.
A jewel
That ever did contain a thing of worth.
Even as a splitted bark
This way fall I to death.
This way for me.
Exeunt severally
SCENE III. A bedchamber.
Enter the KING
How fares my lord? speak
thy sovereign.
If thou be'st death
Ah
Beaufort
Bring me unto my trial when you will.
Died he not in his bed? where should he die?
Can I make men live
O
Alive again? then show me where he is:
I'll give a thousand pound to look upon him.
He hath no eyes
Comb down his hair; look
Give me some drink; and bid the apothecary
Bring the strong poison that I bought of him.
O thou eternal Mover of the heavens.
Look with a gentle eye upon this wretch!
O
That lays strong siege unto this wretch's soul.
And from his bosom purge this black despair!
See
Disturb him not; let him pass peaceably.
Peace to his soul
Lord cardinal
He dies
So bad a death argues a monstrous life.
Forbear to judge
Close up his eyes and draw the curtain close;
And let us all to meditation.
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. The coast of Kent.
Alarum. Fight at sea. Ordnance goes off. Enter a  Captain
The gaudy
Is crept into the bosom of the sea;
And now loud-howling wolves arouse the jades
That drag the tragic melancholy night;
Who
Breathe foul contagious darkness in the air.
Therefore bring forth the soldiers of our prize;
For
Master
And thou that art his mate
The other
What is my ransom
A thousand crowns
"Master's-Mate	And so much shall you give"
What
Cut both the villains' throats; for die you shall:
The lives of those which we have lost in fight
Be counterpoised with such a petty sum!
I'll give it
And so will I and write home for it straight.
I lost mine eye in laying the prize aboard
To SUFFOLK
And so should these
Be not so rash; take ransom
Look on my George; I am a gentleman:
Rate me at what thou wilt
And so am I; my name is Walter Whitmore.
How now! why start'st thou? what
death affright?
Thy name affrights me
A cunning man did calculate my birth
And told me that by water I should die:
Yet let not this make thee be bloody-minded;
Thy name is Gaultier
Gaultier or Walter
Never yet did base dishonour blur our name
Therefore
Stay
The Duke of Suffolk muffled up in rags!
Ay
Jove sometimes went disguised
But Jove was never slain
Obscure and lowly swain
Hast thou not kiss'd thy hand and held my stirrup?
Bare-headed plodded by my foot-cloth mule
And thought thee happy when I shook my head?
How often hast thou waited at my cup
When I have feasted with Queen Margaret?
Remember it and let it make thee crest-fall'n
How in our voiding lobby hast thou stood
And duly waited for my coming forth?
This hand of mine hath writ in thy behalf
Speak
First let my words stab him
Base slave
Convey him hence and on our longboat's side
Strike off his head.
Thou darest not
Yes
Pole!
Pool! Sir Pool! lord!
Ay
Troubles the silver spring where England drinks.
Now will I dam up this thy yawning mouth
For swallowing the treasure of the realm:
Thy lips that kiss'd the queen shall sweep the ground;
And thou that smiledst at good Duke Humphrey's death
And wedded be thou to the hags of hell
Unto the daughter of a worthless king
By devilish policy art thou grown great
With gobbets of thy mother's bleeding heart.
By thee Anjou and Maine were sold to France
Disdain to call us lord
Hath slain their governors
The princely Warwick
And now the house of York
By shameful murder of a guiltless king
And lofty proud encroaching tyranny
Advance our half-faced sun
The commons here in Kent are up in arms:
And
Is crept into the palace of our king.
And all by thee. Away! convey him hence.
O that I were a god
Upon these paltry
Small things make base men proud: this villain here
Than Bargulus the strong Illyrian pirate.
Drones suck not eagles' blood but rob beehives:
It is impossible that I should die
By such a lowly vassal as thyself.
Thy words move rage and not remorse in me:
I go of message from the queen to France;
I charge thee waft me safely cross the Channel.
Walter
Come
Gelidus timor occupat artus it is thee I fear.
Thou shalt have cause to fear before I leave thee.
What
My gracious lord
Suffolk's imperial tongue is stern and rough
Far be it we should honour such as these
With humble suit: no
Stoop to the block than these knees bow to any
Save to the God of heaven and to my king;
And sooner dance upon a bloody pole
Than stand uncover'd to the vulgar groom.
True nobility is exempt from fear:
More can I bear than you dare execute.
Hale him away
Come
Great men oft die by vile bezonians:
A Roman sworder and banditto slave
Murder'd sweet Tully; Brutus' bastard hand
Stabb'd Julius Caesar; savage islanders
Pompey the Great; and Suffolk dies by pirates.
Exeunt Whitmore and others with Suffolk
And as for these whose ransom we have set
Therefore come you with us and let him go.
Exeunt all but the First Gentleman
Re-enter WHITMORE with SUFFOLK's body
There let his head and lifeless body lie
Exit
O barbarous and bloody spectacle!
His body will I bear unto the king:
If he revenge it not
So will the queen
Exit with the body

Enter GEORGE BEVIS and JOHN HOLLAND
Come
they have been up these two days.
They have the more need to sleep now
I tell thee
the commonwealth
So he had need
was never merry world in England since gentlemen came up.
O miserable age! virtue is not regarded in handicrafts-men.
The nobility think scorn to go in leather aprons.
Nay

which is as much to say as
labouring men; and therefore should we be
magistrates.

We John Cade

[Aside]  Ay

Valiant I am.
[Aside]  A' must needs; for beggary is valiant.
I am able to endure much.
[Aside]  No question of that; for I have seen him
whipped three market-days together.
I fear neither sword nor fire.
[Aside]  He need not fear the sword; for his coat is of proof.
[Aside]  But methinks he should stand in fear of

Be brave
reformation. There shall be in England seven

common; and in Cheapside shall my palfrey go to
grass: and when I am king
God save your majesty!
I thank you

SCENE IV. London. The palace.
Enter KING HENRY VI with a supplication
Oft have I heard that grief softens the mind
Think therefore on revenge and cease to weep.
But who can cease to weep and look on this?
Here may his head lie on my throbbing breast:
But where's the body that I should embrace?
What answer makes your grace to the rebels'
supplication?
I'll send some holy bishop to entreat;
For God forbid so many simple souls
Should perish by the sword! And I myself
But stay
Ah
Ruled
Lord Say
Ay

Still lamenting and mourning for Suffolk's death?

Enter a Messenger
How now! what news? why comest thou in such haste?
The rebels are in Southwark; fly
Jack Cade proclaims himself Lord Mortimer
And vows to crown himself in Westminster.
His army is a ragged multitude
Of hinds and peasants
Sir Humphrey Stafford and h is brother's death
Hath given them heart and courage to proceed:
All scholars
O graceless men! they know not what they do.
My gracious lord
Ah
Lord Say
Therefore away with us to Killingworth.
So might your grace's person be in danger.
The sight of me is odious in their eyes;
And therefore in this city will I stay
And live alone as secret as I may.
Enter another Messenger
Jack Cade hath gotten London bridge:
The citizens fly and forsake their houses:
The rascal people
To spoil the city and your royal court.
Then linger not
Come
My hope is gone
Farewell
Trust nobody
The trust I have is in mine innocence

The people liberal

I sold not Maine
Justice with favour have I always done;
Prayers and tears have moved me
When have I aught exacted at your hands
Large gifts have I bestow'd on learned clerks
This tongue hath parley'd unto foreign kings
For your behoof
Tut
Great men have reaching hands: oft have I struck
Those that I never saw and struck them dead.
O monstrous coward! what
These cheeks are pale for watching for your good.

Long sitting to determine poor men's causes

Ye shall have a hempen caudle
Why dost thou quiver

with you: I'll see if his head will stand steadier

Ay
Know
Unto the commons whom thou hast misled;
And here pronounce free pardon to them all
That will forsake thee and go home in peace.
What say ye
Or let a rebel lead you to your deaths?
Who loves the king and will embrace his pardon
Who hateth him and honours not his father

you

To France

Henry hath money

SCENE IX. Kenilworth Castle.
Sound Trumpets. Enter KING HENRY VI
Was ever king that joy'd an earthly throne
No sooner was I crept out of my cradle
But I was made a king
Was never subject long'd to be a king
As I do long and wish to be a subject.

Why
Or is he but retired to make him strong?

He is fled
And humbly thus
Then
Soldiers

Please it your grace to be advertised

Of gallowglasses and stout kerns
Is marching hitherward in proud array
The Duke of Somerset
Thus stands my state
Like to a ship that
But now is Cade driven back

My lord
In any case
For he is fierce and cannot brook hard language.
I will
As all things shall redound unto your good.
Come
For yet may England curse my wretched reign.
