SCENE X. Kent. IDEN's garden.
Enter CADE
Fie on ambition! fie on myself
hid me in these woods and durst not peep out
all the country is laid for me; but now am I so
hungry that if I might have a lease of my life for a
thousand years I could stay no longer. Wherefore
see if I can eat grass
while
this hot weather. And I think this word 'sallet'
was born to do me good: for many a time
sallet
bill; and many a time
bravely marching
quart pot to drink in; and now the word 'sallet'
must serve me to feed on.
Enter IDEN
Lord
This small inheritance my father left me
Contenteth me
I seek not to wax great by others' waning
Sufficeth that I have maintains my state
And sends the poor well pleased from my gate.
Here's the lord of the soil come to seize me for a
stray
Ah
crowns of the king carrying my head to him: but

as a doornail

ACT V
SCENE I. Fields between Dartford and Blackheath.

From Ireland thus comes York to claim his right
Ring
Ah! sancta majestas
Let them obey that know not how to rule;
This hand was made to handle naught but gold.
I cannot give due action to my words
A sceptre shall it have

Whom have we here? Buckingham
The king hath sent him
York

O

My mind was troubled with deep melancholy.
The cause why I have brought this army hither
Is to remove proud Somerset from the king
That is too much presumption on thy part:
But if thy arms be to no other end
The Duke of Somerset is in the Tower.
Upon thine honour
Upon mine honour
Then

How now! is Somerset at liberty?
Then

False king! why hast thou broken faith with me
King did I call thee? no
That head of thine doth not become a crown;
Thy hand is made to grasp a palmer's staff
That gold must round engirt these brows of mine
Here is a hand to hold a sceptre up
And with the same to act controlling laws.
Give place: by heaven
O'er him whom heaven created for thy ruler.
O monstrous traitor! I arrest thee

I know

O blood-besotted Neapolitan
The sons of York
That for my surety will refuse the boys!
Enter EDWARD and RICHARD
See where they come: I'll warrant they'll
make it good.

And here comes Clifford to deny their bail.
Health and all happiness to my lord the king!
Kneels
I thank thee
Nay
We are thy sovereign
For thy mistaking so
This is my king
But thou mistakest me much to think I do:
To Bedlam with him! is the man grown mad?
Ay
Makes him oppose himself against his king.
He is a traitor; let him to the Tower
He is arrested
His sons
Will you not
Ay
And if words will not
Why
Look in a glass
I am thy king
Call hither to the stake my two brave bears
They may astonish these fell-lurking curs:
Bid Salisbury and Warwick come to me.
Enter the WARWICK and SALISBURY
Are these thy bears? we'll bait thy bears to death.
And manacle the bear-ward in their chains
Oft have I seen a hot o'erweening cur
Run back and bite
Who
And such a piece of service will you do
Hence
Nay
Take heed
Why
Old Salisbury
What
O
If it be banish'd from the frosty head
Wilt thou go dig a grave to find out war
Why art thou old
Or wherefore dost abuse it
For shame! in duty bend thy knee to me
That bows unto the grave with mickle age.
My lord
The title of this most renowned duke;
And in my conscience do repute his grace
The rightful heir to England's royal seat.
Hast thou not sworn allegiance unto me?
I have.
Canst thou dispense with heaven for such an oath?
It is great sin to swear unto a sin
Who can be bound by any solemn vow
To do a murderous deed
But that he was bound by a solemn oath?
A subtle traitor needs no sophister.
Call Buckingham
Call Buckingham
The first I warrant thee
You were best to go to bed and dream again
I am resolved to bear a greater storm
Than any thou canst conjure up to-day;
And that I'll write upon thy burgonet
Now
That keeps his leaves in spite of any storm
And from thy burgonet I'll rend thy bear
And tread it under foot with all contempt
And so to arms
Fie! charity
Foul stigmatic
If not in heaven
Exeunt severally
SCENE II. Saint Alban's.
Alarums to the battle. Enter WARWICK
Clifford of Cumberland
And if thou dost not hide thee from the bear
And dead men's cries do fill the empty air
Proud northern lord
Enter YORK
How now
The deadly-handed Clifford slew my steed
And made a prey for carrion kites and crows
Even of the bonny beast he loved so well.
Enter CLIFFORD
Of one or both of us the time is come.
Hold
Then
As I intend
Exit
What seest thou in me
With thy brave bearing should I be in love
Nor should thy prowess want praise and esteem
So let it help me now against thy sword
As I in justice and true right express it.
My soul and body on the action both!
A dreadful lay! Address thee instantly.
They fight
La fin couronne les oeuvres.
Dies
Thus war hath given thee peace
Peace with his soul
Exit
Enter YOUNG CLIFFORD
Shame and confusion! all is on the rout;
Fear frames disorder
Where it should guard. O war
Throw in the frozen bosoms of our part
Hot coals of vengeance! Let no soldier fly.
He that is truly dedicate to war
Hath no self-love
Hath not essentially but by circumstance
The name of valour.
Seeing his dead father
O
Knit earth and heaven together!
Now let the general trumpet blow his blast
To cease! Wast thou ordain'd
The silver livery of advised age
To die in ruffian battle? Even at this sight
My heart is turn'd to stone: and while 'tis mine
No more will I their babes: tears virginal
Shall be to me even as the dew to fire
Shall to my flaming wrath be oil and flax.
Henceforth I will not have to do with pity:
Meet I an infant of the house of York
As wild Medea young Absyrtus did:
In cruelty will I seek out my fame.
Come
As did AEneas old Anchises bear
But then AEneas bare a living load
Exit
Enter RICHARD and SOMERSET to fight. SOMERSET is killed
So
For underneath an alehouse' paltry sign
Hath made the wizard famous in his death.
Sword
Priests pray for enemies
Exit
Fight: excursions. Enter KING HENRY VI
Away
Can we outrun the heavens? good Margaret
What are you made of? you'll nor fight nor fly:
Now is it manhood
By what we can
Alarum afar off
If you be ta'en
Of all our fortunes: but if we haply scape
And where this breach now in our fortunes made
May readily be stopp'd.
Re-enter YOUNG CLIFFORD
But that my heart's on future mischief set
But fly you must; uncurable discomfit
Reigns in the hearts of all our present parts.
Away
To see their day and them our fortune give:
Away
Exeunt
SCENE III. Fields near St. Alban's.
Alarum. Retreat. Enter YORK
Of Salisbury
Aged contusions and all brush of time
Is not itself
My noble father
But still
And like rich hangings in a homely house
But
Enter SALISBURY
Now
By the mass
God knows how long it is I have to live;
And it hath pleased him that three times to-day
You have defended me from imminent death.
Well
'Tis not enough our foes are this time fled
I know our safety is to follow them;
For
Let us pursue him ere the writs go forth.
What says Lord Warwick? shall we after them?
After them! nay
Now
Saint Alban's battle won by famous York
Shall be eternized in all age to come.
Sound drums and trumpets
And more such days as these to us befall!
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. London. The Parliament-house.
Alarum. Enter YORK
I wonder how the king escaped our hands.
While we pursued the horsemen of the north
Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland
Were by the swords of common soldiers slain.
Lord Stafford's father
I cleft his beaver with a downright blow:
That this is true
And
Speak thou for me and tell them what I did.
Throwing down SOMERSET's head
Richard hath best deserved of all my sons.
But is your grace dead
Such hope have all the line of John of Gaunt!
Thus do I hope to shake King Henry's head.
And so do I. Victorious Prince of York
Which now the house of Lancaster usurps
This is the palace of the fearful king
For this is thine and not King Henry's heirs'
Assist me
For hither we have broken in by force.
We'll all assist you; he that flies shall die.
Thanks
And
They go up
And when the king comes
The queen this day here holds her parliament
By words or blows here let us win our right.
Arm'd as we are
The bloody parliament shall this be call'd
Hath made us by-words to our enemies.
Then leave me not
I mean to take possession of my right.
Neither the king
I'll plant Plantagenet
Resolve thee
Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI
My lords
Earl of Northumberland
And thine
On him
If I be not
The hope thereof makes Clifford mourn in steel.
What
My heart for anger burns; I cannot brook it.
Be patient
Patience is for poltroons
He durst not sit there
My gracious lord
Let us assail the family of York.
Well hast thou spoken
Ah
But when the duke is slain
Far be the thought of this from Henry's heart
Cousin of Exeter
Shall be the war that Henry means to use.
Thou factious Duke of York
I am thy sovereign.
I am thine.
For shame
'Twas my inheritance
Thy father was a traitor to the crown.
Exeter
In following this usurping Henry.
Whom should he follow but his natural king?
TRUE
And shall I stand
It must and shall be so: content thyself.
Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be king.
He is both king and Duke of Lancaster;
And that the Lord of Westmoreland shall maintain.
And Warwick shall disprove it. You forget
That we are those which chased you from the field
And slew your fathers
March'd through the city to the palace gates.
Yes
And
Plantagenet
Than drops of blood were in my father's veins.
Urge it no more; lest that
As shall revenge his death before I stir.
Poor Clifford! how I scorn his worthless threats!
Will you we show our title to the crown?
If not
What title hast thou
Thy father was
Thy grandfather
I am the son of Henry the Fifth
And seized upon their towns and provinces.
Talk not of France
The lord protector lost it
When I was crown'd I was but nine months old.
You are old enough now
Father
Sweet father
Good brother
Sound drums and trumpets
Sons
Peace
Plantagenet shall speak first: hear him
And be you silent and attentive too
Think'st thou that I will leave my kingly throne
No: first shall war unpeople this my realm;
Ay
My title's good
Prove it
Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown.
'Twas by rebellion against his king.
[Aside]  I know not what to say; my title's weak.--
Tell me
What then?
An if he may
For Richard
He rose against him
Suppose
No; for he could not so resign his crown
But that the next heir should succeed and reign.
Art thou against us
His is the right
Why whisper you
My conscience tells me he is lawful king.
[Aside]  All will revolt from me
Plantagenet
Deposed he shall be
Thou art deceived: 'tis not thy southern power
King Henry
May that ground gape and swallow me alive
O Clifford
Henry of Lancaster
What mutter you
Do right unto this princely Duke of York
He stamps with his foot and the soldiers show themselves
My Lord of Warwick
Let me for this my life-time reign as king.
Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs
I am content: Richard Plantagenet
What wrong is this unto the prince your son!
What good is this to England and himself!
Base
How hast thou injured both thyself and us!
I cannot stay to hear these articles.
Nor I.
Come
Farewell
Be thou a prey unto the house of York
In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome
Exeunt NORTHUMBERLAND
Turn this way
They seek revenge and therefore will not yield.
Ah
Why should you sigh
Not for myself
But be it as it may: I here entail
The crown to thee and to thine heirs for ever;
Conditionally
To cease this civil war
To seek to put me down and reign thyself.
This oath I willingly take and will perform.
Long live King Henry! Plantagenet embrace him.
And long live thou and these thy forward sons!
Now York and Lancaster are reconciled.
Accursed be he that seeks to make them foes!
Sennet. Here they come down
Farewell
And I'll keep London with my soldiers.
And I to Norfolk with my followers.
And I unto the sea from whence I came.
Exeunt YORK
And I
Enter QUEEN MARGARET and PRINCE EDWARD
Here comes the queen
I'll steal away.
Exeter
Nay
Be patient
Who can be patient in such extremes?
Ah
And never seen thee
Hath he deserved to lose his birthright thus?
Hadst thou but loved him half so well as I
And disinherited thine only son.
Father
If you be king
Pardon me
The Earl of Warwick and the duke enforced me.
Enforced thee! art thou king
I shame to hear thee speak. Ah
Thou hast undone thyself
And given unto the house of York such head
As thou shalt reign but by their sufferance.
To entail him and his heirs unto the crown
And creep into it far before thy time?
Warwick is chancellor and the lord of Calais;
Stern Falconbridge commands the narrow seas;
The duke is made protector of the realm;
And yet shalt thou be safe? such safety finds
The trembling lamb environed with wolves.
Had I been there
Before I would have granted to that act.
But thou preferr'st thy life before thine honour:
And seeing thou dost
Both from thy table
Whereby my son is disinherited.
The northern lords that have forsworn thy colours
Will follow mine
And spread they shall be
And utter ruin of the house of York.
Thus do I leave thee. Come
Our army is ready; come
Stay
Thou hast spoke too much already: get thee gone.
Gentle son Edward
Ay
When I return with victory from the field
I'll see your grace: till then I'll follow her.
Come
Exeunt QUEEN MARGARET and PRINCE EDWARD
Poor queen! how love to me and to her son
Hath made her break out into terms of rage!
Revenged may she be on that hateful duke
Tire on the flesh of me and of my son!
The loss of those three lords torments my heart:
I'll write unto them and entreat them fair.
Come
And I
Exeunt
SCENE II. Sandal Castle.
Enter RICHARD
Brother
No
But I have reasons strong and forcible.
Enter YORK
Why
What is your quarrel? how began it first?
No quarrel
About what?
About that which concerns your grace and us;
The crown of England
Mine boy? not till King Henry be dead.
Your right depends not on his life or death.
Now you are heir
By giving the house of Lancaster leave to breathe
I took an oath that he should quietly reign.
But for a kingdom any oath may be broken:
I would break a thousand oaths to reign one year.
No; God forbid your grace should be forsworn.
I shall be
I'll prove the contrary
Thou canst not
An oath is of no moment
Before a true and lawful magistrate
Henry had none
Then
Therefore
How sweet a thing it is to wear a crown;
Within whose circuit is Elysium
And all that poets feign of bliss and joy.
Why do we finger thus? I cannot rest
Until the white rose that I wear be dyed
Even in the lukewarm blood of Henry's heart.
Richard
Brother
Thou
You Edward
In them I trust; for they are soldiers
While you are thus employ'd
Enter a Messenger
But
The queen with all the northern earls and lords
Intend here to besiege you in your castle:
She is hard by with twenty thousand men;
And therefore fortify your hold
Ay
Edward and Richard
My brother Montague shall post to London:
Let noble Warwick
Brother
And thus most humbly I do take my leave.
Exit
Enter JOHN MORTIMER and HUGH MORTIMER
Sir John and Sir Hugh Mortimer
The army of the queen mean to besiege us.
She shall not need; we'll meet her in the field.
What
Ay
A woman's general; what should we fear?
A march afar off
I hear their drums: let's set our men in order
Five men to twenty! though the odds be great
Many a battle have I won in France
Why should I not now have the like success?
Alarum. Exeunt
SCENE III. Field of battle betwixt Sandal Castle and Wakefield.
Alarums. Enter RUTLAND and his Tutor
Ah
Ah
Enter CLIFFORD and Soldiers
Chaplain
As for the brat of this accursed duke
And I
Soldiers
Ah
Exit
How now! is he dead already? or is it fear
That makes him close his eyes? I'll open them.
So looks the pent-up lion o'er the wretch
That trembles under his devouring paws;
And so he walks
Ah
Sweet Clifford
I am too mean a subject for thy wrath:
Be thou revenged on men
In vain thou speak'st
Hath stopp'd the passage where thy words should enter.
Then let my father's blood open it again:
He is a man
Had thy brethren here
Were not revenge sufficient for me;
No
And hung their rotten coffins up in chains
The sight of any of the house of York
Is as a fury to torment my soul;
And till I root out their accursed line
And leave not one alive
Therefore--
Lifting his hand
O
To thee I pray; sweet Clifford
Such pity as my rapier's point affords.
I never did thee harm: why wilt thou slay me?
Thy father hath.
But 'twas ere I was born.
Thou hast one son; for his sake pity me
Ah
And when I give occasion of offence
No cause!
Thy father slew my father; therefore
Stabs him
Di faciant laudis summa sit ista tuae!
Dies
Plantagenet! I come
And this thy son's blood cleaving to my blade
Shall rust upon my weapon
Exit
SCENE IV. Another part of the field.
Alarum. Enter YORK
The army of the queen hath got the field:
My uncles both are slain in rescuing me;
And all my followers to the eager foe
Turn back and fly
Or lambs pursued by hunger-starved wolves.
My sons
But this I know
Like men born to renown by life or death.
Three times did Richard make a lane to me.
And thrice cried 'Courage
And full as oft came Edward to my side
In blood of those that had encounter'd him:
And when the hardiest warriors did retire
And cried 'A crown
A sceptre
With this
We bodged again; as I have seen a swan
With bootless labour swim against the tide
And spend her strength with over-matching waves.
A short alarum within
Ah
And I am faint and cannot fly their fury:
And were I strong
The sands are number'd that make up my life;
Here must I stay
Enter QUEEN MARGARET
Come
I am your butt
Yield to our mercy
Ay
Now Phaethon hath tumbled from his car
My ashes
A bird that will revenge upon you all:
And in that hope I throw mine eyes to heaven
Why come you not? what! multitudes
So cowards fight when they can fly no further;
So doves do peck the falcon's piercing talons;
So desperate thieves
O Clifford
And
Whose frown hath made thee faint and fly ere this!
I will not bandy with thee word for word
Hold
I would prolong awhile the traitor's life.
Wrath makes him deaf: speak thou
Hold
To prick thy finger
What valour were it
It is war's prize to take all vantages;
And ten to one is no impeach of valour.
They lay hands on YORK
Ay
So doth the cony struggle in the net.
So triumph thieves upon their conquer'd booty;
So true men yield
What would your grace have done unto him now?
Brave warriors
What! was it you that would be England's king?
Was't you that revell'd in our parliament
Where are your mess of sons to back you now?
The wanton Edward
And where's that valiant crook-back prodigy
Was wont to cheer his dad in mutinies?
Or
Look
That valiant Clifford
And if thine eyes can water for his death
Alas poor York! but that I hate thee deadly
I prithee
What
That not a tear can fall for Rutland's death?
Why art thou patient
And I
Stamp
Thou wouldst be fee'd
York cannot speak
A crown for York! and
Hold you his hands
Putting a paper crown on his head
Ay
Ay
But how is it that great Plantagenet
Is crown'd so soon
As I bethink me
Till our King Henry had shook hands with death.
And will you pale your head in Henry's glory
O
Off with the crown
And
That is my office
Nay
She-wolf of France
How ill-beseeming is it in thy sex
To triumph
But that thy face is
To tell thee whence thou camest
Thy father bears the type of King of Naples
Hath that poor monarch taught thee to insult?
It needs not
'Tis beauty that doth oft make women proud;
But
'Tis virtue that doth make them most admired;
The contrary doth make thee wonder'd at:
'Tis government that makes them seem divine;
The want thereof makes thee abominable:
Thou art as opposite to every good
As the Antipodes are unto us
O tiger's heart wrapt in a woman's hide!
How couldst thou drain the life-blood of the child
Women are soft
Thou stern
Bids't thou me rage? why
Wouldst have me weep? why
For raging wind blows up incessant showers
These tears are my sweet Rutland's obsequies:
And every drop cries vengeance for his death
Frenchwoman.
Beshrew me
That hardly can I cheque my eyes from tears.
That face of his the hungry cannibals
Would not have touch'd
But you are more inhuman
See
This cloth thou dip'dst in blood of my sweet boy
Keep thou the napkin
And if thou tell'st the heavy story right
Yea even my foes will shed fast-falling tears
There
And in thy need such comfort come to thee
As now I reap at thy too cruel hand!
Hard-hearted Clifford
My soul to heaven
Had he been slaughter-man to all my kin
To see how inly sorrow gripes his soul.
What
Think but upon the wrong he did us all
Here's for my oath
Stabbing him
And here's to right our gentle-hearted king.
Stabbing him
Open Thy gate of mercy
My soul flies through these wounds to seek out Thee.
Dies
Off with his head
So York may overlook the town of York.
Flourish. Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. A plain near Mortimer's Cross in Herefordshire.
A march. Enter EDWARD
I wonder how our princely father 'scaped
From Clifford's and Northumberland's pursuit:
Had he been ta'en
Had he been slain
Or had he 'scaped
The happy tidings of his good escape.
How fares my brother? why is he so sad?
I cannot joy
Where our right valiant father is become.
I saw him in the battle range about;
And watch'd him how he singled Clifford forth.
Methought he bore him in the thickest troop
As doth a lion in a herd of neat;
Or as a bear
So fared our father with his enemies;
So fled his enemies my warlike father:
Methinks
See how the morning opes her golden gates
How well resembles it the prime of youth
Dazzle mine eyes
Three glorious suns
Not separated with the racking clouds
See
Now are they but one lamp
In this the heaven figures some event.
'Tis wondrous strange
I think it cites us
And over-shine the earth as this the world.
Whate'er it bodes
Upon my target three fair-shining suns.
Nay
Enter a Messenger
But what art thou
Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue?
Ah
When as the noble Duke of York was slain
O
Say how he died
Environed he was with many foes
Against the Greeks that would have enter'd Troy.
But Hercules himself must yield to odds;
And many strokes
By many hands your father was subdued;
But only slaughter'd by the ireful arm
Of unrelenting Clifford and the queen
A napkin steeped in the harmless blood
Of sweet young Rutland
And after many scorns
They set the same; and there it doth remain
Sweet Duke of York
O Clifford
The flower of Europe for his chivalry;
And treacherously hast thou vanquish'd him
Now my soul's palace is become a prison:
Ah
Might in the ground be closed up in rest!
For never henceforth shall I joy again
I cannot weep; for all my body's moisture
Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart:
Nor can my tongue unload my heart's great burthen;
For selfsame wind that I should speak withal
Is kindling coals that fires all my breast
To weep is to make less the depth of grief:
Tears then for babes; blows and revenge for me
Richard
His name that valiant duke hath left with thee;
His dukedom and his chair with me is left.
Nay
For chair and dukedom
Either that is thine
March. Enter WARWICK
How now
Great Lord of Warwick
Our baleful news
Stab poniards in our flesh till all were told
O valiant lord
O Warwick
Ten days ago I drown'd these news in tears;
And now
After the bloody fray at Wakefield fought
I
For by my scouts I was advertised
That she was coming with a full intent
To dash our late decree in parliament
Touching King Henry's oath and your succession.
Short tale to make
Our battles join'd
But whether 'twas the coldness of the king
Or whether 'twas report of her success;
Or more than common fear of Clifford's rigour
Our soldiers'
I cheer'd them up with justice of our cause
But all in vain; they had no heart to fight
So that we fled; the king unto the queen;
Lord George your brother
For in the marches here we heard you were
Where is the Duke of Norfolk
And when came George from Burgundy to England?
Some six miles off the duke is with the soldiers;
And for your brother
From your kind aunt
'Twas odds
Oft have I heard his praises in pursuit
Nor now my scandal
For thou shalt know this strong right hand of mine
Can pluck the diadem from faint Henry's head
As he is famed for mildness
I know it well
'Tis love I bear thy glories makes me speak.
But in this troublous time what's to be done?
Shall we go throw away our coats of steel
Or shall we on the helmets of our foes
Tell our devotion with revengeful arms?
If for the last
Why
And therefore comes my brother Montague.
Attend me
He swore consent to your succession
And now to London all the crew are gone
May make against the house of Lancaster.
Their power
Now
But never once again turn back and fly.
Ay
Ne'er may he live to see a sunshine day
Lord Warwick
And when thou fail'st--as God forbid the hour!--
Must Edward fall
No longer Earl of March
The next degree is England's royal throne;
For King of England shalt thou be proclaim'd
In every borough as we pass along;
And he that throws not up his cap for joy
Shall for the fault make forfeit of his head.
King Edward
Then
Then strike up drums: God and Saint George for us!
Enter a Messenger
How now! what news?
The Duke of Norfolk sends you word by me
And craves your company for speedy counsel.
Why then it sorts
Exeunt
SCENE II. Before York.
Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI
Welcome
Yonder's the head of that arch-enemy
That sought to be encompass'd with your crown:
Doth not the object cheer your heart
Ay
To see this sight
Withhold revenge
My gracious liege
And harmful pity must be laid aside.
To whom do lions cast their gentle looks?
Not to the beast that would usurp their den.
Whose hand is that the forest bear doth lick?
Not his that spoils her young before her face.
Who 'scapes the lurking serpent's mortal sting?
Not he that sets his foot upon her back.
The smallest worm will turn being trodden on
Ambitious York doth level at thy crown
He
Thou
Unreasonable creatures feed their young;
And though man's face be fearful to their eyes
Which sometime they have used with fearful flight
For shame
Were it not pity that this goodly boy
Should lose his birthright by his father's fault
My careless father fondly gave away'?
Ah
And let his manly face
Successful fortune
To hold thine own and leave thine own with him.
Full well hath Clifford play'd the orator
But
That things ill-got had ever bad success?
And happy always was it for that son
Whose father for his hoarding went to hell?
I'll leave my son my virtuous deeds behind;
And would my father had left me no more!
For all the rest is held at such a rate
As brings a thousand-fold more care to keep
Than in possession and jot of pleasure.
Ah
How it doth grieve me that thy head is here!
My lord
You promised knighthood to our forward son:
Unsheathe your sword
Edward
Edward Plantagenet
And learn this lesson
My gracious father
Why
Enter a Messenger
Royal commanders
For with a band of thirty thousand men
Comes Warwick
And in the towns
Darraign your battle
I would your highness would depart the field:
The queen hath best success when you are absent.
Ay
Why
Be it with resolution then to fight.
My royal father
And hearten those that fight in your defence:
Unsheathe your sword
March. Enter EDWARD
Now
Or bide the mortal fortune of the field?
Go
Becomes it thee to be thus bold in terms
Before thy sovereign and thy lawful king?
I am his king
I was adopted heir by his consent:
Since when
And reason too:
Who should succeed the father but the son?
Are you there
Ay
'Twas you that kill'd young Rutland
Ay
For God's sake
What say'st thou
Why
When you and I met at Saint Alban's last
Then 'twas my turn to fly
You said so much before
'Twas not your valour
No
Northumberland
Break off the parley; for scarce I can refrain
The execution of my big-swoln heart
Upon that Clifford
I slew thy father
Ay
But ere sunset I'll make thee curse the deed.
Have done with words
Defy them then
I prithee
I am a king
My liege
Cannot be cured by words; therefore be still.
Then
By him that made us all
that Clifford's manhood lies upon his tongue.
Say
A thousand men have broke their fasts to-day
If thou deny
For York in justice puts his armour on.
If that be right which Warwick says is right
Whoever got thee
For
But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam;
But like a foul mis-shapen stigmatic
Iron of Naples hid with English gilt
As if a channel should be call'd the sea
Shamest thou not
A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns
Helen of Greece was fairer far than thou
And ne'er was Agamemnon's brother wrong'd
By that false woman
His father revell'd in the heart of France
And had he match'd according to his state
But when he took a beggar to his bed
For what hath broach'd this tumult but thy pride?
Hadst thou been meek
And we
But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring
And though the edge hath something hit ourselves
And
Not willing any longer conference
Sound trumpets! let our bloody colours wave!
And either victory
Stay
No
These words will cost ten thousand lives this day.
Exeunt
SCENE III. A field of battle between Towton and Saxton
Yorkshire.
Alarum. Excursions. Enter WARWICK
Forspent with toil
For strokes received
Enter EDWARD
Smile
For this world frowns
How now
Enter GEORGE
Our hap is loss
Our ranks are broke
What counsel give you? whither shall we fly?
Bootless is flight
And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.
Enter RICHARD
Ah
Thy brother's blood the thirsty earth hath drunk
And in the very pangs of death he cried
So
Then let the earth be drunken with our blood:
I'll kill my horse
Why stand we like soft-hearted women here
And look upon
Were play'd in jest by counterfeiting actors?
Here on my knee I vow to God above
Or fortune given me measure of revenge.
O Warwick
And in this vow do chain my soul to thine!
And
That to my foes this body must be prey
Now
Brother
I
That winter should cut off our spring-time so.
Away
Yet let us all together to our troops
And call them pillars that will stand to us;
And
As victors wear at the Olympian games:
This may plant courage in their quailing breasts;
For yet is hope of life and victory.
Forslow no longer
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Another part of the field.
Excursions. Enter RICHARD and CLIFFORD
Now
Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York
Now
This is the hand that stabb'd thy father York;
And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland;
And here's the heart that triumphs in their death
And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother
To execute the like upon thyself;
And so
They fight. WARWICK comes; CLIFFORD flies
Nay Warwick
For I myself will hunt this wolf to death.
Exeunt
SCENE V. Another part of the field.
Alarum. Enter KING HENRY VI alone
This battle fares like to the morning's war
Now sways it this way
Forced by the tide to combat with the wind;
Now sways it that way
Forced to retire by fury of the wind:
Sometime the flood prevails
Now one the better
Both tugging to be victors
So is the equal of this fell war.
Here on this molehill will I sit me down.
To whom God will
For Margaret my queen
They prosper best of all when I am thence.
Would I were dead! if God's good will were so;
For what is in this world but grief and woe?
O God! methinks it were a happy life
To sit upon a hill
How many hours bring about the day;
How many days will finish up the year;
How many years a mortal man may live.
When this is known
So many hours must I tend my flock;
So many hours must I take my rest;
So many hours must I contemplate;
So many hours must I sport myself;
So many days my ewes have been with young;
So many weeks ere the poor fools will ean:
So many years ere I shall shear the fleece:
So minutes
Ah
Gives not the hawthorn-bush a sweeter shade
To shepherds looking on their silly sheep
To kings that fear their subjects' treachery?
O
And to conclude
His wonted sleep under a fresh tree's shade
Alarum. Enter a Son that has killed his father
Ill blows the wind that profits nobody.
This man
And I
To some man else
Who's this? O God! it is my father's face
O heavy times
From London by the king was I press'd forth;
My father
And I
Have by my hands of life bereaved him.
Pardon me
And pardon
My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks;
And no more words till they have flow'd their fill.
O piteous spectacle! O bloody times!
Whiles lions war and battle for their dens
Weep
And let our hearts and eyes
Enter a Father that has killed his son
Thou that so stoutly hast resisted me
For I have bought it with an hundred blows.
But let me see: is this our foeman's face?
Ah
Ah
O
What stratagems
O boy
Woe above woe! grief more than common grief!
O that my death would stay these ruthful deeds!
O pity
The red rose and the white are on his face
The one his purple blood right well resembles;
The other his pale cheeks
Wither one rose
If you contend
How will my mother for a father's death
Take on with me and ne'er be satisfied!
How will my wife for slaughter of my son
Shed seas of tears and ne'er be satisfied!
How will the country for these woful chances
Misthink the king and not be satisfied!
Was ever son so rued a father's death?
Was ever father so bemoan'd his son?
Was ever king so grieved for subjects' woe?
Much is your sorrow; mine ten times so much.
I'll bear thee hence
Exit with the body
These arms of mine shall be thy winding-sheet;
My heart
My sighing breast shall be thy funeral bell;
And so obsequious will thy father be
I'll bear thee hence; and let them fight that will
Exit with the body
Sad-hearted men
Alarums: excursions. Enter QUEEN MARGARET
Fly
Away! for death doth hold us in pursuit.
Mount you
Edward and Richard
Having the fearful flying hare in sight
Away! for vengeance comes along with them:
Nay
Or else come after: I'll away before.
Nay
Not that I fear to stay
Whither the queen intends. Forward; away!
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Another part of the field.
A loud alarum. Enter CLIFFORD
Here burns my candle out; ay
O Lancaster
More than my body's parting with my soul!
My love and fear glued many friends to thee;
And
Impairing Henry
And whither fly the gnats but to the sun?
And who shines now but Henry's enemies?
O Phoebus
That Phaethon should cheque thy fiery steeds
And
I and ten thousand in this luckless realm
Had left no mourning widows for our death;
And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in peace.
For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air?
And what makes robbers bold but too much lenity?
Bootless are plaints
No way to fly
The foe is merciless
For at their hands I have deserved no pity.
The air hath got into my deadly wounds
Come
I stabb'd your fathers' bosoms
He faints
Alarum and retreat. Enter EDWARD
Now breathe we
Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen
But think you
No
Your brother Richard mark'd him for the grave:
And wheresoe'er he is
CLIFFORD groans
Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?
A deadly groan
See who it is: and
Revoke that doom of mercy
Who not contented that he lopp'd the branch
In hewing Rutland when his leaves put forth
From whence that tender spray did sweetly spring
From off the gates of York fetch down the head
Instead whereof let this supply the room:
Measure for measure must be answered.
Bring forth that fatal screech-owl to our house
Now death shall stop his dismal threatening sound
I think his understanding is bereft.
Speak
Dark cloudy death o'ershades his beams of life
O
'Tis but his policy to counterfeit
Which in the time of death he gave our father.
If so thou think'st
Clifford
Clifford
Clifford
While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.
Thou didst love York
Thou pitied'st Rutland; I will pity thee.
Where's Captain Margaret
They mock thee
What
When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath.
I know by that he's dead; and
issuing blood
Stifle the villain whose unstanched thirst
York and young Rutland could not satisfy.
Ay
And now to London with triumphant march
From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France
So shalt thou sinew both these lands together;
And
The scatter'd foe that hopes to rise again;
For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt
First will I see the coronation;
And then to Brittany I'll cross the sea
Even as thou wilt
For in thy shoulder do I build my seat
Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.
Richard
Let me be Duke of Clarence
For Gloucester's dukedom is too ominous.
Tut
Richard
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. A forest in the north of England.
Enter two Keepers
Under this thick-grown brake we'll shroud ourselves;
For through this laund anon the deer will come;
And in this covert will we make our stand
I'll stay above the hill
That cannot be; the noise of thy cross-bow
Will scare the herd
Here stand we both
And
In this self-place where now we mean to stand.
Here comes a man; let's stay till he be past.
Enter KING HENRY VI
From Scotland am I stol'n
No
Thy place is fill'd
No bending knee will call thee Caesar now
For how can I help them
Ay
This is the quondam king; let's seize upon him.
Let me embrace thee
Why linger we? let us lay hands upon him.
Forbear awhile; we'll hear a little more.
My queen and son are gone to France for aid;
And
Is thither gone
To wife for Edward: if this news be true
For Warwick is a subtle orator
By this account then Margaret may win him;
For she's a woman to be pitied much:
Her sighs will make a battery in his breast;
Her tears will pierce into a marble heart;
The tiger will be mild whiles she doth mourn;
And Nero will be tainted with remorse
Ay
She
She weeps
He smiles
That she
Whiles Warwick tells his title
O Margaret
Say
More than I seem
A man at least
And men may talk of kings
Ay
Why
But
My crown is in my heart
Not decked with diamonds and Indian stones
A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy.
Well
To go along with us; for as we think
And we his subjects sworn in all allegiance
Will apprehend you as his enemy.
But did you never swear
No
Where did you dwell when I was King of England?
Here in this country
I was anointed king at nine months old;
My father and my grandfather were kings
And tell me
No;
For we were subjects but while you were king.
Why
Ah
Look
Such is the lightness of you common men.
But do not break your oaths; for of that sin
My mild entreaty shall not make you guilty.
Go where you will
And be you kings
We are true subjects to the king
So would you be again to Henry
We charge you
In God's name
And what God will
And what he will
Exeunt
SCENE II. London. The palace.
Enter KING EDWARD IV
Brother of Gloucester
This lady's husband
Her suit is now to repossess those lands;
Which we in justice cannot well deny
The worthy gentleman did lose his life.
Your highness shall do well to grant her suit;
It were dishonour to deny it her.
It were no less; but yet I'll make a pause.
[Aside to CLARENCE]  Yea
I see the lady hath a thing to grant
[Aside to GLOUCESTER]  He knows the game: how true
he keeps the wind!
[Aside to CLARENCE]  Silence!
Widow
And come some other time to know our mind.
Right gracious lord
May it please your highness to resolve me now;
And what your pleasure is
[Aside to CLARENCE]  Ay
you all your lands
Fight closer
[Aside to GLOUCESTER]  I fear her not
chance to fall.
[Aside to CLARENCE] God forbid that! for he'll
take vantages.
How many children hast thou
[Aside to GLOUCESTER]  I think he means to beg a
child of her.
[Aside to CLARENCE]  Nay
give her two.
Three
[Aside to CLARENCE]  You shall have four
be ruled by him.
'Twere pity they should lose their father's lands.
Be pitiful
Lords
[Aside to CLARENCE]  Ay
you will have leave
GLOUCESTER and CLARENCE retire
Now tell me
Ay
And would you not do much to do them good?
To do them good
Then get your husband's lands
Therefore I came unto your majesty.
I'll tell you how these lands are to be got.
So shall you bind me to your highness' service.
What service wilt thou do me
What you command
But you will take exceptions to my boon.
No
Ay
Why
[Aside to CLARENCE]  He plies her hard; and much rain
wears the marble.
[Aside to GLOUCESTER]  As red as fire! nay
her wax must melt.
Why stops my lord
An easy task; 'tis but to love a king.
That's soon perform'd
Why
I take my leave with many thousand thanks.
[Aside to CLARENCE]  The match is made; she seals it
with a curtsy.
But stay thee
The fruits of love I mean
Ay
What love
My love till death
That love which virtue begs and virtue grants.
No
Why
But now you partly may perceive my mind.
My mind will never grant what I perceive
Your highness aims at
To tell thee plain
To tell you plain
Why
Why
For by that loss I will not purchase them.
Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily.
Herein your highness wrongs both them and me.
But
Accords not with the sadness of my suit:
Please you dismiss me either with 'ay' or 'no.'
Ay
No if thou dost say 'no' to my demand.
Then
[Aside to CLARENCE]  The widow likes him not
knits her brows.
[Aside to GLOUCESTER]  He is the bluntest wooer in
Christendom.
[Aside]  Her looks do argue her replete with modesty;
Her words do show her wit incomparable;
All her perfections challenge sovereignty:
One way or other
And she shall be my love
Say that King Edward take thee for his queen?
'Tis better said than done
I am a subject fit to jest withal
Sweet widow
I speak no more than what my soul intends;
And that is
And that is more than I will yield unto:
I know I am too mean to be your queen
You cavil
'Twill grieve your grace my sons should call you father.
No more than when my daughters call thee mother.
Thou art a widow
And
To be the father unto many sons.
Answer no more
[Aside to CLARENCE]  The ghostly father now hath done
his shrift.
[Aside to GLOUCESTER]  When he was made a shriver
Brothers
The widow likes it not
You'll think it strange if I should marry her.
To whom
Why
That would be ten days' wonder at the least.
That's a day longer than a wonder lasts.
By so much is the wonder in extremes.
Well
Her suit is granted for her husband's lands.
Enter a Nobleman
My gracious lord
See that he be convey'd unto the Tower:
And go we
Widow
Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER
Ay
Would he were wasted
And yet
The lustful Edward's title buried--
Is Clarence
A cold premeditation for my purpose!
Why
Like one that stands upon a promontory
So do I wish the crown
And so I chide the means that keeps me from it;
And so I say
My eye's too quick
Well
What other pleasure can the world afford?
I'll make my heaven in a lady's lap
O miserable thought! and more unlikely
Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns!
Why
And
To make an envious mountain on my back
To shape my legs of an unequal size;
To disproportion me in every part
That carries no impression like the dam.
And am I then a man to be beloved?
O monstrous fault
Then
As are of better person than myself
Be round impaled with a glorious crown.
And yet I know not how to get the crown
And I
Not knowing how to find the open air
Torment myself to catch the English crown:
And from that torment I will free myself
Why
I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall;
I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk;
I'll play the orator as well as Nestor
I can add colours to the chameleon
Can I do this
Tut
Exit
SCENE III. France. KING LEWIS XI's palace.
Flourish. Enter KING LEWIS XI
Fair Queen of England
And birth
No
Must strike her sail and learn awhile to serve
Where kings command. I was
But now mischance hath trod my title down
Where I must take like seat unto my fortune
Why
From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears
And stops my tongue
Whate'er it be
Seats her by him
Yield not thy neck
To fortune's yoke
Still ride in triumph over all mischance.
Be plain
It shall be eased
Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts
And give my tongue-tied sorrows leave to speak.
Now
While proud ambitious Edward Duke of York
Usurps the regal title and the seat
Of England's true-anointed lawful king.
This is the cause that I
And if thou fail us
Scotland hath will to help
Our people and our peers are both misled
Renowned queen
The more we stay
The more I stay
O
And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow!
Enter WARWICK
What's he approacheth boldly to our presence?
Our Earl of Warwick
Welcome
He descends. She ariseth
Ay
For this is he that moves both wind and tide.
From worthy Edward
And then to crave a league of amity;
And lastly
With a nuptial knot
That virtuous Lady Bona
[Aside]  If that go forward
[To BONA]  And
To tell the passion of my sovereign's heart;
Where fame
King Lewis and Lady Bona
Springs not from Edward's well-meant honest love
For how can tyrants safely govern home
To prove him tyrant this reason may suffice
Look
Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour;
For though usurpers sway the rule awhile
Injurious Margaret!
And why not queen?
Because thy father Henry did usurp;
And thou no more are prince than she is queen.
Then Warwick disannuls great John of Gaunt
And
And
From these our Henry lineally descends.
Oxford
All that which Henry Fifth had gotten?
Methinks these peers of France should smile at that.
But for the rest
Of threescore and two years; a silly time
To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.
Why
Can Oxford
For shame! leave Henry
Call him my king by whose injurious doom
My elder brother
No
And I the house of York.
Queen Margaret
They stand aloof
Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not!
Now Warwick
To link with him that were not lawful chosen.
Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.
But is he gracious in the people's eye?
The more that Henry was unfortunate.
Then further
Unto our sister Bona.
Such it seems
As may beseem a monarch like himself.
Myself have often heard him say and swear
That this his love was an eternal plant
Now
Your grant
To WARWICK
Yet I confess that often ere this day
Then
And now forthwith shall articles be drawn
Touching the jointure that your king must make
Draw near
That Bona shall be wife to the English king.
To Edward
Deceitful Warwick! it was thy device
By this alliance to make void my suit:
Before thy coming Lewis was Henry's friend.
And still is friend to him and Margaret:
But if your title to the crown be weak
From giving aid which late I promised.
Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand
That your estate requires and mine can yield.
Henry now lives in Scotland at his ease
And as for you yourself
And better 'twere you troubled him than France.
Peace
I will not hence
Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love;
For both of you are birds of selfsame feather.
Post blows a horn within
Warwick
Enter a Post
[To WARWICK]  My lord ambassador
To KING LEWIS XI
These from our king unto your majesty:
To QUEEN MARGARET
And
They all read their letters
I like it well that our fair queen and mistress
Smiles at her news
Nay
I hope all's for the best.
Warwick
Mine
Mine
What! has your king married the Lady Grey!
And now
Is this the alliance that he seeks with France?
Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner?
I told your majesty as much before:
This proveth Edward's love and Warwick's honesty.
King Lewis
Did I forget that by the house of York
My father came untimely to his death?
Did I let pass the abuse done to my niece?
Did I impale him with the regal crown?
Did I put Henry from his native right?
And am I guerdon'd at the last with shame?
Shame on himself! for my desert is honour:
And to repair my honour lost for him
My noble queen
I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona
Warwick
And I forgive and quite forget old faults
So much his friend
With some few bands of chosen soldiers
And force the tyrant from his seat by war.
'Tis not his new-made bride shall succor him:
And as for Clarence
Dear brother
But by thy help to this distressed queen?
Renowned prince
My quarrel and this English queen's are one.
And mine
And mine with hers
Therefore at last I firmly am resolved
You shall have aid.
Let me give humble thanks for all at once.
Then
To revel it with him and his new bride:
Thou seest what's past
Tell him
Tell him
Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong
There's thy reward: be gone.
Exit Post
But
And
And prince shall follow with a fresh supply.
Yet
This shall assure my constant loyalty
To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.
Yes
Son Edward
And
Yes
And here
He gives his hand to WARWICK
Why stay we now? These soldiers shall be levied
I long till Edward fall by war's mischance
Exeunt all but WARWICK
I came from Edward as ambassador
Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me
Had he none else to make a stale but me?
Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow.
I was the chief that raised him to the crown
Not that I pity Henry's misery
Exit
ACT IV
SCENE I. London. The palace.
Enter GLOUCESTER
Now tell me
Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey?
Hath not our brother made a worthy choice?
Alas
How could he stay till Warwick made return?
My lords
And his well-chosen bride.
I mind to tell him plainly what I think.
Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV
Now
As well as Lewis of France
That they'll take no offence at our abuse.
Suppose they take offence without a cause
And shall have your will
Yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well.
Yea
Not I:
No
Whom God hath join'd together; ay
To sunder them that yoke so well together.
Setting your scorns and your mislike aside
Should not become my wife and England's queen.
And you too
Then this is mine opinion: that King Lewis
Becomes your enemy
About the marriage of the Lady Bona.
And Warwick
What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeased
By such invention as I can devise?
Yet
Would more have strengthen'd this our commonwealth
'Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred marriage.
Why
England is safe
But the safer when 'tis back'd with France.
'Tis better using France than trusting France:
Let us be back'd with God and with the seas
Which He hath given for fence impregnable
In them and in ourselves our safety lies.
For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves
To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.
Ay
And for this once my will shall stand for law.
And yet methinks your grace hath not done well
Unto the brother of your loving bride;
She better would have fitted me or Clarence:
But in your bride you bury brotherhood.
Or else you would not have bestow'd the heir
Of the Lord Bonville on your new wife's son
Alas
That thou art malcontent? I will provide thee.
In choosing for yourself
To play the broker in mine own behalf;
And to that end I shortly mind to leave you.
Leave me
My lords
To raise my state to title of a queen
That I was not ignoble of descent;
And meaner than myself have had like fortune.
But as this title honours me and mine
My love
What danger or what sorrow can befall thee
Nay
Which if they do
[Aside]  I hear
Enter a Post
Now
From France?
My sovereign liege
Go to
What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters?
At my depart
'Go tell false Edward
To revel it with him and his new bride.'
Is Lewis so brave? belike he thinks me Henry.
But what said Lady Bona to my marriage?
These were her words
'Tell him
I blame not her
She had the wrong. But what said Henry's queen?
For I have heard that she was there in place.
'Tell him
Belike she minds to play the Amazon.
But what said Warwick to these injuries?
He
Than all the rest
'Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong
Ha! durst the traitor breathe out so proud words?
Well I will arm me
They shall have wars and pay for their presumption.
But say
Ay
friendship
That young Prince Edward marries Warwick's daughter.
Belike the elder; Clarence will have the younger.
Now
That
I may not prove inferior to yourself.
You that love me and Warwick
Exit CLARENCE
[Aside]  Not I:
My thoughts aim at a further matter; I
Stay not for the love of Edward
Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick!
Yet am I arm'd against the worst can happen;
And haste is needful in this desperate case.
Pembroke and Stafford
Go levy men
They are already
Myself in person will straight follow you.
Exeunt PEMBROKE and STAFFORD
But
Tell me if you love Warwick more than me?
If it be so
I rather wish you foes than hollow friends:
But if you mind to hold your true obedience
So God help Montague as he proves true!
And Hastings as he favours Edward's cause!
Now
Ay
Why
Now therefore let us hence; and lose no hour
Exeunt
SCENE II. A plain in Warwickshire.
Enter WARWICK and OXFORD
Trust me
The common people by numbers swarm to us.
Enter CLARENCE and SOMERSET
But see where Somerset and Clarence come!
Speak suddenly
Fear not that
Then
And welcome
To rest mistrustful where a noble heart
Hath pawn'd an open hand in sign of love;
Else might I think that Clarence
But welcome
And now what rests but
Our scouts have found the adventure very easy:
That as Ulysses and stout Diomede
With sleight and manhood stole to Rhesus' tents
And seize himself; I say not
You that will follow me to this attempt
They all cry
Why
For Warwick and his friends
Exeunt
SCENE III. Edward's camp
Enter three Watchmen
Come on
The king by this is set him down to sleep.
What
Why
Never to lie and take his natural rest
Till Warwick or himself be quite suppress'd.
To-morrow then belike shall be the day
But say
That with the king here resteth in his tent?
'Tis the Lord Hastings
O
That his chief followers lodge in towns about him
'Tis the more honour
Ay
I like it better than a dangerous honour.
If Warwick knew in what estate he stands
Unless our halberds did shut up his passage.
Ay
Enter WARWICK
This is his tent; and see where stand his guard.
Courage
But follow me
Who goes there?
Stay
WARWICK and the rest cry all
The drum playing and trumpet sounding
What are they that fly there?
Richard and Hastings: let them go; here is The duke.
The duke! Why
Ay
When you disgraced me in my embassade
Alas! how should you govern any kingdom
Yea
Nay
Yet
Though fortune's malice overthrow my state
Then
Takes off his crown
But Henry now shall wear the English crown
My Lord of Somerset
Unto my brother
When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows
Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him.
Now
They lead him out forcibly
What fates impose
It boots not to resist both wind and tide.
Exit
What now remains
But march to London with our soldiers?
Ay
To free King Henry from imprisonment
And see him seated in the regal throne.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. London. The palace.
Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH and RIVERS
Madam
Why brother Rivers
What late misfortune is befall'n King Edward?
What! loss of some pitch'd battle against Warwick?
No
Then is my sovereign slain?
Ay
Or by his foe surprised at unawares:
And
These news I must confess are full of grief;
Yet
Warwick may lose
Till then fair hope must hinder life's decay.
And I the rather wean me from despair
For love of Edward's offspring in my womb:
This is it that makes me bridle passion
And bear with mildness my misfortune's cross;
Ay
And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs
King Edward's fruit
But
I am inform'd that he comes towards London
Guess thou the rest; King Edward's friends must down
For trust not him that hath once broken faith
I'll hence forthwith unto the sanctuary
There shall I rest secure from force and fraud.
Come
If Warwick take us we are sure to die.
Exeunt
SCENE V. A park near Middleham Castle In Yorkshire.
Enter GLOUCESTER
Now
Thus stands the case: you know our king
He hath good usage and great liberty
I have advertised him by secret means
That if about this hour he make his way
Under the colour of his usual game
To set him free from his captivity.
Enter KING EDWARD IV and a Huntsman with him
This way
Nay
Now
Brother
Your horse stands ready at the park-corner.
But whither shall we then?
To Lynn
Well guess'd
Stanley
But wherefore stay we? 'tis no time to talk.
Huntsman
Better do so than tarry and be hang'd.
Come then
Bishop
And pray that I may repossess the crown.
Exeunt
SCENE VI. London. The Tower.
Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI
Master lieutenant
Have shaken Edward from the regal seat
Subjects may challenge nothing of their sovereigns;
But if an humble prayer may prevail
For what
Nay
Ay
Conceive when after many moody thoughts
At last by notes of household harmony
They quite forget their loss of liberty.
But
He was the author
Therefore
By living low
May not be punish'd with my thwarting stars
Your grace hath still been famed for virtuous;
And now may seem as wise as virtuous
Yet in this one thing let me blame your grace
No
Adjudged an olive branch and laurel crown
And therefore I yield thee my free consent.
And I choose Clarence only for protector.
Warwick and Clarence give me both your hands:
Now join your hands
I make you both protectors of this land
And in devotion spend my latter days
What answers Clarence to his sovereign's will?
That he consents
For on thy fortune I repose myself.
Why
We'll yoke together
To Henry's body
I mean
And
Forthwith that Edward be pronounced a traitor
What else? and that succession be determined.
Ay
But
Be sent for
For
My joy of liberty is half eclipsed.
It shall be done
My Lord of Somerset
My liege
Come hither
Lays his hand on his head
If secret powers
Suggest but truth to my divining thoughts
His looks are full of peaceful majesty
Likely in time to bless a regal throne.
Make much of him
Must help you more than you are hurt by me.
Enter a Post
What news
That Edward is escaped from your brother
Unsavoury news! but how made he escape?
He was convey'd by Richard Duke of Gloucester
And the Lord Hastings
In secret ambush on the forest side
And from the bishop's huntsmen rescued him;
For hunting was his daily exercise.
My brother was too careless of his charge.
But let us hence
A salve for any sore that may betide.
Exeunt all but SOMERSET
My lord
For doubtless Burgundy will yield him help
As Henry's late presaging prophecy
Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond
What may befall him
Therefore
Ay
It shall be so; he shall to Brittany.
Come
Exeunt
SCENE VII. Before York.
Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV
Now
My waned state for Henry's regal crown.
Well have we pass'd and now repass'd the seas
And brought desired help from Burgundy:
What then remains
From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York
The gates made fast! Brother
For many men that stumble at the threshold
Are well foretold that danger lurks within.
Tush
By fair or foul means we must enter in
My liege
Enter
My lords
For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.
But
TRUE
Why
[Aside]  But when the fox hath once got in his nose
Why
Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends.
Ay
They descend
A wise stout captain
The good old man would fain that all were well
Both him and all his brothers unto reason.
Enter the Mayor and two Aldermen
So
But in the night or in the time of war.
What! fear not
Takes his keys
For Edward will defend the town and thee
March. Enter MONTGOMERY
Brother
Welcome
To help King Edward in his time of storm
Thanks
Our title to the crown and only claim
Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.
Then fare you well
I came to serve a king and not a duke.
Drummer
The drum begins to march
Nay
By what safe means the crown may be recover'd.
What talk you of debating? in few words
To keep them back that come to succor you:
Why shall we fight
Why
When we grow stronger
Till then
Away with scrupulous wit! now arms must rule.
And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns.
Brother
The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.
Then be it as you will; for 'tis my right
Ay
And now will I be Edward's champion.
Sound trumpet; Edward shall be here proclaim'd:
Come
Flourish
Edward the Fourth
England and France
And whosoe'er gainsays King Edward's right
Throws down his gauntlet
Long live Edward the Fourth!
Thanks
If fortune serve me
Now
And when the morning sun shall raise his car
Above the border of this horizon
For well I wot that Henry is no soldier.
Ah
To flatter Henry and forsake thy brother!
Yet
Come on
Exeunt
SCENE VIII. London. The palace.
Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI
What counsel
And many giddy people flock to him.
Let's levy men
A little fire is quickly trodden out;
Which
In Warwickshire I have true-hearted friends
Those will I muster up: and thou
Thou
Men well inclined to hear what thou command'st:
And thou
My sovereign
Fair lords
Farewell
Farewell
In sign of truth
Well-minded Clarence
Comfort
And thus I seal my truth
Sweet Oxford
Farewell
Exeunt all but KING HENRY VI and EXETER
Here at the palace I will rest awhile.
Cousin of Exeter
Methinks the power that Edward hath in field
Should not be able to encounter mine.
The doubt is that he will seduce the rest.
That's not my fear; my meed hath got me fame:
I have not stopp'd mine ears to their demands
My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds
I have not been desirous of their wealth
Nor forward of revenge
Then why should they love Edward more than me?
No
And when the lion fawns upon the lamb
Shout within. 'A Lancaster! A Lancaster!'
Hark
Enter KING EDWARD IV
Seize on the shame-faced Henry
And once again proclaim us King of England.
You are the fount that makes small brooks to flow:
Now stops thy spring; my sea sha$l suck them dry
Hence with him to the Tower; let him not speak.
Exeunt some with KING HENRY VI
And
Where peremptory Warwick now remains:
The sun shines hot; and
Away betimes
Brave warriors
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. Coventry.

Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford?
How far hence is thy lord
By this at Dunsmore
How far off is our brother Montague?
Where is the post that came from Montague?
By this at Daintry

Say

At Southam I did leave him with his forces

Then Clarence is at hand
It is not his

Who should that be? belike
They are at hand

Go
See how the surly Warwick mans the wall!
O unbid spite! is sportful Edward come?
Where slept our scouts
Now
And he shall pardon thee these outrages.
Nay

I thought

Is not a dukedom
Ay

Why then 'tis mine
Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight:

Come
Nay

Oxford
He and his forces enter the city
The gates are open
So other foes may set upon our backs.

If not
O

Montague
He and his forces enter the city

The harder match'd
My mind presageth happy gain and conquest.

He and his forces enter the city
Two of thy name

And lo
With whom an upright zeal to right prevails
More than the nature of a brother's love!
Come
Father of Warwick
Taking his red rose out of his hat
Look here
I will not ruinate my father's house
Against his brother and his lawful king?
Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath:
To keep that oath were more impiety
Than Jephthah's
I am so sorry for my trespass made
That
As I will meet thee
To plague thee for thy foul misleading me.
And so

And

So
For Warwick was a bug that fear'd us all.

Ah

That I must yield my body to the earth
And
Thus yields the cedar to the axe's edge
And kept low shrubs from winter's powerful wind.
These eyes
The wrinkles in my brows
For who lived king

SCENE III. Another part of the field.
Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV in triumph; with GLOUCESTER
Thus far our fortune keeps an upward course
But
I mean
Hath raised in Gallia have arrived our coast
And
A little gale will soon disperse that cloud
And blow it to the source from whence it came:
The very beams will dry those vapours up
The queen is valued thirty thousand strong
If she have time to breathe be well assured
Her faction will be full as strong as ours.
We are advertised by our loving friends
That they do hold their course toward Tewksbury:
We
And
In every county as we go along.
Strike up the drum; cry 'Courage!' and away.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Plains near Tewksbury.
March. Enter QUEEN MARGARET
Great lords
What though the mast be now blown overboard
Yet lives our pilot still. Is't meet that he
Should leave the helm and like a fearful lad
With tearful eyes add water to the sea
And give more strength to that which hath too much
Ah
Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that?
And Montague our topmost; what of him?
Our slaughter'd friends the tackles; what of these?
Why
And Somerset another goodly mast?
The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings?
And
For once allow'd the skilful pilot's charge?
We will not from the helm to sit and weep
As good to chide the waves as speak them fair.
And what is Edward but ruthless sea?
What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit?
And Richard but a ragged fatal rock?
All these the enemies to our poor bark.
Say you can swim; alas
Tread on the sand; why
Bestride the rock; the tide will wash you off
This speak I
More than with ruthless waves
Why
'Twere childish weakness to lament or fear.
Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit
Should
And make him
I speak not this as doubting any here
For did I but suspect a fearful man
He should have leave to go away betimes
And make him of like spirit to himself.
If any such be here--as God forbid!--
Let him depart before we need his help.
Women and children of so high a courage
O brave young prince! thy famous grandfather
Doth live again in thee: long mayst thou live
To bear his image and renew his glories!
And he that will not fight for such a hope.
Go home to bed
Thanks
And take his thanks that yet hath nothing else.
Enter a Messenger
Prepare you
Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.
I thought no less: it is his policy
To haste thus fast
But he's deceived; we are in readiness.
This cheers my heart
Here pitch our battle; hence we will not budge.
Flourish and march. Enter KING EDWARD IV
Brave followers
I need not add more fuel to your fire
Give signal to the fight
Lords
My tears gainsay; for every word I speak
Therefore
And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil.
You fight in justice: then

Ay

Exit Lieutenant
So flies the reckless shepherd from the wolf;
So first the harmless sheep doth yield his fleece
And next his throat unto the butcher's knife.
What scene of death hath Roscius now to act?
Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind;
The thief doth fear each bush an officer.
The bird that hath been limed in a bush
And I
Where my poor young was limed
Why
An yet
I
Thy father
The sun that sear'd the wings of my sweet boy
Thy brother Edward
Whose envious gulf did swallow up his life.
Ah
My breast can better brook thy dagger's point
Than can my ears that tragic history.
But wherefore dost thou come? is't for my life?
Think'st thou I am an executioner?
A persecutor
If murdering innocents be executing
Thy son I kill'd for his presumption.
Hadst thou been kill'd when first thou didst presume
And thus I prophesy
Men for their sons
Shall rue the hour that ever thou wast born.
The owl shriek'd at thy birth
The night-crow cried
Dogs howl'd
The raven rook'd her on the chimney's top
Thy mother felt more than a mother's pain
Teeth hadst thou in thy head when thou wast born
And

For this amongst the rest
Ay

Dies
What

O
From those that wish the downfall of our house!
If any spark of life be yet remaining
Stabs him again
I
Indeed
For I have often heard my mother say
I came into the world with my legs forward:
Had I not reason
The midwife wonder'd and the women cried
'O
And so I was; which plainly signified
That I should snarl and bite and play the dog.
Then
I have no brother
And this word 'love
And not in me: I am myself alone.
Clarence
But I will sort a pitchy day for thee;
For I will buz abroad such prophecies
That Edward shall be fearful of his life
King Henry and the prince his son are gone:
Clarence
I'll throw thy body in another room
And triumph

SCENE VII. London. The palace.
Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV
Once more we sit in England's royal throne
What valiant foemen
Three Dukes of Somerset
For hardy and undoubted champions;
Two Cliffords
Ne'er spurr'd their coursers at the trumpet's sound;
With them
And made the forest tremble when they roar'd.
Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat
And made our footstool of security.
Come hither
Young Ned
Have in our armours watch'd the winter's night
And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.

For yet I am not look'd on in the world.
This shoulder was ordain'd so thick to heave;
And heave it shall some weight
Work thou the way

And cried 'all hail!' when as he meant all harm.

Reignier
Hath pawn'd the Sicils and Jerusalem

And now what rests but that we spend the time
With stately triumphs

For here

ACT I
SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

In delivering my son from me
And I in going
anew: but I must attend his majesty's command
whom I am now in ward
You shall find of the king a husband
good must of necessity hold his virtue to you; whose
worthiness would stir it up where it wanted rather
than lack it where there is such abundance.
What hope is there of his majesty's amendment?
He hath abandoned his physicians
practises he hath persecuted time with hope
finds no other advantage in the process but only the

This young gentlewoman had a father

far

the death of the king's disease.

his great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon.

A fistula
I heard not of it before.
I would it were not notorious. Was this gentlewoman

His sole child
overlooking. I have those hopes of her good that
her education promises; her dispositions she
inherits
an unclean mind carries virtuous qualities
commendations go with pity; they are virtues and
traitors too; in her they are the better for their

Your commendations
'Tis the best brine a maiden can season her praise
in. The remembrance of her father never approaches
her heart but the tyranny of her sorrows takes all
livelihood from her cheek. No more of this
go to
a sorrow than have it.
I do affect a sorrow indeed
Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead
If the living be enemy to the grief
makes it soon mortal.
Madam
How understand we that?
Be thou blest
In manners
Contend for empire in thee
Share with thy birthright! Love all
Rather in power than use
Under thy own life's key: be cheque'd for silence
'Tis an unseason'd courtier; good my lord
He cannot want the best
That shall attend his love.

O
And these great tears grace his remembrance more
Than those I shed for him. What was he like?
I have forgot him: my imagination
Carries no favour in't but Bertram's.
I am undone: there is no living
That I should love a bright particular star
And think to wed it
In his bright radiance and collateral light
Must I be comforted
The ambition in my love thus plagues itself:
The hind that would be mated by the lion
Must die for love. 'Twas pretty
His arched brows
Of every line and trick of his sweet favour:
But now he's gone
Must sanctify his reliques. Who comes here?
Enter PAROLLES
Aside
One that goes with him: I love him for his sake;
And yet I know him a notorious liar
Yet these fixed evils sit so fit in him
Look bleak i' the cold wind: withal
Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.
Save you
And you
No.
And no.
Are you meditating on virginity?
Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you: let me
ask you a question. Man is enemy to virginity; how
may we barricado it against him?
Keep him out.
But he assails; and our virginity
warlike resistance.
There is none: man
undermine you and blow you up.
Bless our poor virginity from underminers and
blowers up! Is there no military policy
virgins might blow up men?
Virginity being blown down
blown up: marry
the breach yourselves made
is not politic in the commonwealth of nature to
preserve virginity. Loss of virginity is rational
increase and there was never virgin got till
virginity was first lost. That you were made of is
metal to make virgins. Virginity by being once lost
may be ten times found; by being ever kept
ever lost: 'tis too cold a companion; away with 't!
I will stand for 't a little
There's little can be said in 't; 'tis against the
rule of nature. To speak on the part of virginity
disobedience. He that hangs himself is a virgin:
virginity murders itself and should be buried in
highways out of all sanctified limit
offendress against nature. Virginity breeds mites
paring
Besides
self-love
canon. Keep it not; you cannot choose but loose

itself ten
principal itself not much the worse: away with 't!
How might one do

likes. 'Tis a commodity will lose the gloss with

The court's a learning place

When he was predominant.

You go so much backward when you fight.

Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie
Gives us free scope
Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull.
What power is it which mounts my love so high
The mightiest space in fortune nature brings
To join like likes and kiss like native things.
Impossible be strange attempts to those
That weigh their pains in sense and do suppose
What hath been cannot be: who ever strove
So show her merit
The king's disease--my project may deceive me
Exit
SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING of France
The Florentines and Senoys are by the ears;
Have fought with equal fortune and continue
A braving war.
So 'tis reported
Nay
A certainty
For speedy aid; wherein our dearest friend
Prejudicates the business and would seem
To have us make denial.
His love and wisdom
For amplest credence.
He hath arm'd our answer
Yet
The Tuscan service
To stand on either part.
It well may serve
A nursery to our gentry
For breathing and exploit.
What's he comes here?
Enter BERTRAM
It is the Count Rousillon
Youth
Frank nature
Mayst thou inherit too! Welcome to Paris.
My thanks and duty are your majesty's.
I would I had that corporal soundness now
First tried our soldiership! He did look far
Into the service of the time and was
Discipled of the bravest: he lasted long;
But on us both did haggish age steal on
And wore us out of act. It much repairs me
To talk of your good father. In his youth
He had the wit which I can well observe
To-day in our young lords; but they may jest
Till their own scorn return to them unnoted
Ere they can hide their levity in honour;
So like a courtier
Were in his pride or sharpness; if they were
Exception bid him speak
His tongue obey'd his hand: who were below him
He used as creatures of another place
And bow'd his eminent top to their low ranks
Might be a copy to these younger times;
Which
But goers backward.
His good remembrance
So in approof lives not his epitaph
As in your royal speech.
Would I were with him! He would always say--
Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words
He scatter'd not in ears
This his good melancholy oft began
Of younger spirits
All but new things disdain; whose judgments are
Mere fathers of their garments; whose constancies
Expire before their fashions.' This he wish'd;
I after him do after him wish too
You are loved
They that least lend it you shall lack you first.
I fill a place
He was much famed.
Some six months since
If he were living
Lend me an arm; the rest have worn me out
With several applications; nature and sickness
Debate it at their leisure. Welcome
My son's no dearer.
Thank your majesty.
Exeunt. Flourish
SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
Enter COUNTESS
I will now hear; what say you of this gentlewoman?
Madam
wish might be found in the calendar of my past
endeavours; for then we wound our modesty and make
foul the clearness of our deservings
ourselves we publish them.
What does this knave here? Get you gone
the complaints I have heard of you I do not all
believe: 'tis my slowness that I do not; for I know
you lack not folly to commit them
enough to make such knaveries yours.
'Tis not unknown to you
Well
No
many of the rich are damned: but
your ladyship's good will to go to the world
the woman and I will do as we may.
Wilt thou needs be a beggar?
I do beg your good will in this case.
In what case?
In Isbel's case and mine own. Service is no
heritage: and I think I shall never have the
blessing of God till I have issue o' my body; for
they say barnes are blessings.
Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry.
My poor body
by the flesh; and he must needs go that the devil drives.
Is this all your worship's reason?
Faith
are.
May the world know them?
I have been
all flesh and blood are; and
that I may repent.
Thy marriage
I am out o' friends
friends for my wife's sake.
Such friends are thine enemies
You're shallow
knaves come to do that for me which I am aweary of.
He that ears my land spares my team and gives me
leave to in the crop; if I be his cuckold
drudge: he that comforts my wife is the cherisher
of my flesh and blood; he that cherishes my flesh
and blood loves my flesh and blood; he that loves my
flesh and blood is my friend: ergo
my wife is my friend. If men could be contented to
be what they are
for young Charbon the Puritan and old Poysam the
Papist
religion
horns together
Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouthed and calumnious knave?
A prophet I
way:
For I the ballad will repeat
Your marriage comes by destiny
Get you gone
May it please you
you: of her I am to speak.

Helen
Was this fair face the cause
Fond done
With that she sighed as she stood
Among nine bad if one be good
What

o' the song: would God would serve the world so all
