Well
I know
Faith
she herself
make title to as much love as she finds: there is
more owing her than is paid; and more shall be paid
her than she'll demand.
Madam
she wished me: alone she was
to herself her own words to her own ears; she
thought
stranger sense. Her matter was
Fortune
such difference betwixt their two estates; Love no
god
qualities were level; Dian no queen of virgins
would suffer her poor knight surprised
rescue in the first assault or ransom afterward.
This she delivered in the most bitter touch of
sorrow that e'er I heard virgin exclaim in: which I
held my duty speedily to acquaint you withal;
sithence
you something to know it.
You have discharged this honestly; keep it to
yourself: many likelihoods informed me of this
before
I could neither believe nor misdoubt. Pray you
for your honest care: I will speak with you further anon.
Exit Steward
Enter HELENA
Even so it was with me when I was young:
If ever we are nature's
Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong;
Our blood to us
It is the show and seal of nature's truth
By our remembrances of days foregone
Her eye is sick on't: I observe her now.
What is your pleasure
You know
Mine honourable mistress.
Nay
Why not a mother? When I said 'a mother
Methought you saw a serpent: what's in 'mother
That you start at it? I say
And put you in the catalogue of those
That were enwombed mine: 'tis often seen
Adoption strives with nature and choice breeds
A native slip to us from foreign seeds:
You ne'er oppress'd me with a mother's groan
God's mercy
To say I am thy mother? What's the matter
Why? that you are my daughter?
That I am not.
I say
Pardon
The Count Rousillon cannot be my brother:
I am from humble
No note upon my parents
My master
His servant live
He must not be my brother.
Nor I your mother?
You are my mother
So that my lord your son were not my brother
Indeed my mother! or were you both our mothers
Yes
God shield you mean it not! daughter and mother
So strive upon your pulse. What
My fear hath catch'd your fondness: now I see
The mystery of your loneliness
Your salt tears' head: now to all sense 'tis gross
You love my son; invention is ashamed
But tell me then
Confess it
See it so grossly shown in thy behaviors
That in their kind they speak it: only sin
And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue
If it be so
If it be not
Good madam
Do you love my son?
Your pardon
Love you my son?
Do not you love him
Go not about; my love hath in't a bond
The state of your affection; for your passions
Have to the full appeach'd.
Then
My friends were poor
Be not offended; for it hurts not him
That he is loved of me: I follow him not
By any token of presumptuous suit;
Nor would I have him till I do deserve him;
Yet never know how that desert should be.
I know I love in vain
Yet in this captious and intenible sieve
I still pour in the waters of my love
And lack not to lose still: thus
The sun
For loving where you do: but if yourself
Wish chastely and love dearly
Was both herself and love: O
To her
But lend and give where she is sure to lose;
That seeks not to find that her search implies
Had you not lately an intent
To go to Paris?
Madam
Wherefore? tell true.
I will tell truth; by grace itself I swear.
You know my father left me some prescriptions
Of rare and proved effects
And manifest experience had collected
For general sovereignty; and that he will'd me
In heedfull'st reservation to bestow them
More than they were in note: amongst the rest
The king is render'd lost.
This was your motive
For Paris
My lord your son made me to think of this;
Else Paris and the medicine and the king
Had from the conversation of my thoughts
Haply been absent then.
But think you
Are of a mind; he
A poor unlearned virgin
The danger to itself?
There's something in't
Of his profession
Shall for my legacy be sanctified
By the luckiest stars in heaven: and
But give me leave to try success
The well-lost life of mine on his grace's cure
By such a day and hour.
Dost thou believe't?
Ay
Why
To those of mine in court: I'll stay at home
And pray God's blessing into thy attempt:
Be gone to-morrow; and be sure of this
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING
Farewell
Do not throw from you: and you
Share the advice betwixt you; if both gain
The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis received
'Tis our hope
And find your grace in health.
No
Will not confess he owes the malady
That doth my life besiege. Farewell
Whether I live or die
Of worthy Frenchmen: let higher Italy
Those bated that inherit but the fall
Of the last monarchy
Not to woo honour
The bravest questant shrinks
Health
Those girls of Italy
They say
Our hearts receive your warnings.
Farewell. Come hither to me.
Exit
O
'Tis not his fault
O
Most admirable: I have seen those wars.
I am commanded here
'Too young' and 'the next year' and ''tis too early.'
An thy mind stand to't
I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock
But one to dance with! By heaven
There's honour in the theft.
Commit it
I am your accessary; and so
I grow to you
Farewell
Sweet Monsieur Parolles!

sparks and lustrous

[To BERTRAM]  Use a more spacious ceremony to the

time

and though the devil lead the measure

And I will do so.
Worthy fellows; and like to prove most sinewy sword-men.

[Kneeling]  Pardon
I'll fee thee to stand up.
Then here's a man stands
I would you had kneel'd
I would I had; so I had broke thy pate
Good faith
Will you be cured of your infirmity?
No.
O
Yes
My royal fox could reach them: I have seen a medicine
That's able to breathe life into a stone
With spritely fire and motion; whose simple touch
What 'her' is this?
Why
In this my light deliverance
With one that
Than I dare blame my weakness: will you see her
For that is her demand
That done
Now

By wondering how thou took'st it.

Thus he his special nothing ever prologues.
Re-enter LAFEU
Nay
This haste hath wings indeed.
Nay
This is his majesty; say your mind to him:
A traitor you do look like; but such traitors

Exit
Now
Ay
Gerard de Narbon was my father;
In what he did profess
I knew him.
The rather will I spare my praises towards him:
Knowing him is enough. On's bed of death
Many receipts he gave me: chiefly one.
Which
And hearing your high majesty is touch'd
With that malignant cause wherein the honour
Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power
With all bound humbleness.
We thank you
But may not be so credulous of cure
The congregated college have concluded
That labouring art can never ransom nature
From her inaidible estate; I say we must not
So stain our judgment
To empirics
Our great self and our credit
A senseless help when help past sense we deem.
My duty then shall pay me for my pains:
I will no more enforce mine office on you.
Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts
A modest one
I cannot give thee less
Thou thought'st to help me; and such thanks I give
As one near death to those that wish him live:
But what at full I know
What I can do can do no hurt to try
He that of greatest works is finisher
Oft does them by the weakest minister:
So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown
From simple sources
When miracles have by the greatest been denied.
Oft expectation fails and most oft there
Where most it promises
Where hope is coldest and despair most fits.
I must not hear thee; fare thee well
Thy pains not used must by thyself be paid:
Proffers not took reap thanks for their reward.
Inspired merit so by breath is barr'd:
It is not so with Him that all things knows
As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows;
But most it is presumption in us when
The help of heaven we count the act of men.
Dear sir
Of heaven
I am not an impostor that proclaim
Myself against the level of mine aim;
But know I think and think I know most sure
My art is not past power nor you past cure.
Are thou so confident? within what space
Hopest thou my cure?
The great'st grace lending grace
Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring
Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring
Moist Hesperus hath quench'd his sleepy lamp
Hath told the thievish minutes how they pass
Upon thy certainty and confidence
What darest thou venture?
Tax of impudence
Traduced by odious ballads: my maiden's name
Sear'd otherwise; nay
With vilest torture let my life be ended.
Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak
His powerful sound within an organ weak:
And what impossibility would slay
In common sense
Thy life is dear; for all that life can rate
Worth name of life in thee hath estimate
That happiness and prime can happy call:
Thou this to hazard needs must intimate
Skill infinite or monstrous desperate.
Sweet practiser
If I break time
Of what I spoke
But
Make thy demand.
But will you make it even?
Ay
Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand
What husband in thy power I will command:
Exempted be from me the arrogance
To choose from forth the royal blood of France
With any branch or image of thy state;
But such a one
Is free for me to ask
Here is my hand; the premises observed
So make the choice of thy own time
More should I question thee
Unquestion'd welcome and undoubted blest.
Give me some help here
As high as word
Flourish. Exeunt

But follows it
Must answer for your raising? I know her well:

A poor physician's daughter my wife! Disdain

'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her
I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods
In differences so mighty. If she be
All that is virtuous
Of virtue for the name: but do not so:
From lowest place when virtuous things proceed
Where great additions swell's
Is good without a name. Vileness is so:
The property by what it is should go
In these to nature she's immediate heir
And is not like the sire: honours thrive
Than our foregoers: the mere word's a slave
Debosh'd on every tomb
A lying trophy
Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb
Of honour'd bones indeed. What should be said?
If thou canst like this creature as a maid

I cannot love her
Thou wrong'st thyself
That you are well restored
Let the rest go.
My honour's at the stake; which to defeat

My love and her desert; that canst not dream
We please to have it grow. Cheque thy contempt:
Obey our will
Believe not thy disdain

Into the staggers and the careless lapse
Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate
Loosing upon thee
Pardon
My fancy to your eyes: when I consider

Was in my nobler thoughts most base
The praised of the king; who
Take her by the hand
A counterpoise
A balance more replete.
I take her hand.

You must not marvel
The ministration and required office
On my particular. Prepared I was not
For such a business; therefore am I found
So much unsettled: this drives me to entreat you
That presently you take our way for home;
And rather muse than ask why I entreat you
And my appointments have in them a need
Greater than shows itself at the first view

Sir

ACT III
SCENE I. Florence. The DUKE's palace.
Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence attended; the two Frenchmen
So that from point to point now have you heard
The fundamental reasons of this war
And more thirsts after.
Holy seems the quarrel
Upon your grace's part; black and fearful
On the opposer.
Therefore we marvel much our cousin France
Would in so just a business shut his bosom
Against our borrowing prayers.
Good my lord
By self-unable motion: therefore dare not
Say what I think of it
Myself in my incertain grounds to fail
As often as I guess'd.
Be it his pleasure.
But I am sure the younger of our nature
Come here for physic.
Welcome shall they be;
And all the honours that can fly from us
Shall on them settle. You know your places well;
When better fall
To-morrow to the field.
Flourish. Exeunt
SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
Enter COUNTESS and Clown
It hath happened all as I would have had it
that he comes not along with her.
By my troth
melancholy man.
By what observance
Why
ruff and sing; ask questions and sing; pick his
teeth and sing. I know a man that had this trick of
melancholy sold a goodly manor for a song.
Let me see what he writes
Opening a letter
I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court: our
old ling and our Isbels o' the country are nothing
like your old ling and your Isbels o' the court:
the brains of my Cupid's knocked out
love
What have we here?
E'en that you have there.

her

in the world
"to you.	Your unfortunate son"
This is not well
To fly the favours of so good a king;
To pluck his indignation on thy head
By the misprising of a maid too virtuous
For the contempt of empire.

soldiers and my young lady!

Save you
Madam

I will entreat you
The honour that he loses: more I'll entreat you
Written to bear along.
We serve you
Not so
Will you draw near!
Exeunt COUNTESS and Gentlemen
'Till I have no wife
Nothing in France
Thou shalt have none
Then hast thou all again. Poor lord! is't I
That chase thee from thy country and expose
Those tender limbs of thine to the event
Of the none-sparing war? and is it I
That drive thee from the sportive court
Wast shot at with fair eyes
Of smoky muskets? O you leaden messengers
Whoever shoots at him
Whoever charges on his forward breast
And
His death was so effected: better 'twere
I met the ravin lion when he roar'd
With sharp constraint of hunger; better 'twere
That all the miseries which nature owes
Were mine at once. No
My being here it is that holds thee hence:
Shall I stay here to do't?  no
The air of paradise did fan the house
And angels officed all: I will be gone
For with the dark
Exit
SCENE III. Florence. Before the DUKE's palace.
Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence
The general of our horse thou art; and we
Upon thy promising fortune.
Sir
A charge too heavy for my strength
We'll strive to bear it for your worthy sake
To the extreme edge of hazard.
Then go thou forth;
And fortune play upon thy prosperous helm
This very day
Make me but like my thoughts
A lover of thy drum
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
Enter COUNTESS and Steward
Alas! and would you take the letter of her?
Might you not know she would do as she has done
[Reads]
I am Saint Jaques' pilgrim
Ambitious love hath so in me offended
Write
My dearest master
Bless him at home in peace
His name with zealous fervor sanctify:
His taken labours bid him me forgive;
I
From courtly friends
He is too good and fair for death and me:
Whom I myself embrace
Ah
Rinaldo
Pardon me
If I had given you this at over-night
What angel shall
Bless this unworthy husband? he cannot thrive
And loves to grant
Of greatest justice. Write
Let every word weigh heavy of her worth
That he does weigh too light: my greatest grief.
Though little he do feel it
Dispatch the most convenient messenger:
When haply he shall hear that she is gone
Is dearest to me. I have no skill in sense
To make distinction: provide this messenger:
My heart is heavy and mine age is weak;
Grief would have tears
Exeunt
SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
Enter an old Widow of Florence
Nay
shall lose all the sight.
They say the French count has done most honourable service.
It is reported that he has taken their greatest
commander; and that with his own hand he slew the
duke's brother.
Tucket
We have lost our labour; they are gone a contrary
way: hark! you may know by their trumpets.
Come
the report of it. Well
French earl: the honour of a maid is her name; and
no legacy is so rich as honesty.
I have told my neighbour how you have been solicited

You shall not need to fear me.

my house; thither they send one another: I'll

To Saint Jaques le Grand.
Where do the palmers lodge
At the Saint Francis here beside the port.

Ay

As ample as myself.

I did so.

That has done worthy service.
His name
The Count Rousillon: know you such a one?
But by the ear
His face I know not.
Whatsome'er he is
Against his liking: think you it is so?
Ay
There is a gentleman that serves the count
Reports but coarsely of her.
What's his name?
Monsieur Parolles.
O
Of the great count himself
To have her name repeated: all her deserving
Is a reserved honesty
I have not heard examined.
Alas
'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife
Of a detesting lord.
I warrant
A shrewd turn
How do you mean?
May be the amorous count solicits her
In the unlawful purpose.
He does indeed;
And brokes with all that can in such a suit
Corrupt the tender honour of a maid:
But she is arm'd for him and keeps her guard
In honestest defence.
The gods forbid else!
So
Drum and Colours

That
Which is the Frenchman?
He;
That with the plume: 'tis a most gallant fellow.
I would he loved his wife: if he were honester
He were much goodlier: is't not a handsome gentleman?
I like him well.
'Tis pity he is not honest: yond's that same knave
That leads him to these places: were I his lady
Which is he?
That jack-an-apes with scarfs: why is he melancholy?
Perchance he's hurt i' the battle.
Lose our drum! well.
He's shrewdly vexed at something: look

Worthy the note.

SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
Enter HELENA and Widow
If you misdoubt me that I am not she
Though my estate be fallen
And would not put my reputation now
In any staining act.
Nor would I wish you.
First
Is so from word to word; and then you cannot
I should believe you:
For you have show'd me that which well approves
You're great in fortune.
Take this purse of gold
When I have found it. The count he wooes your daughter
Now his important blood will nought deny
That she'll demand: a ring the county wears
From son to son
Since the first father wore it: this ring he holds
In most rich choice; yet in his idle fire
Now I see
The bottom of your purpose.
You see it lawful
In fine
To what is passed already.
I have yielded:
Instruct my daughter how she shall persever
May prove coherent. Every night he comes
With musics of all sorts and songs composed
To her unworthiness: it nothing steads us
To chide him from our eaves; for he persists
As if his life lay on't.
Why then to-night
Let us assay our plot; which
And lawful meaning in a lawful act
But let's about it.
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
Enter Second French Lord
He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner.
When you sally upon him
language you will: though you understand it not
yourselves
understand him
must produce for an interpreter.
Good captain
Art not acquainted with him? knows he not thy voice?
No
But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us again?
E'en such as you speak to me.
He must think us some band of strangers i' the
adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack of
all neighbouring languages; therefore we must every
one be a man of his own fancy
speak one to another; so we seem to know

Enter PAROLLES
Ten o'clock: within these three hours 'twill be
time enough to go home. What shall I say I have
done? It must be a very plausive invention that
carries it: they begin to smoke me; and disgraces
have of late knocked too often at my door. I find
my tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath the
fear of Mars before it and of his creatures
daring the reports of my tongue.
This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue
was guilty of.
What the devil should move me to undertake the
recovery of this drum
impossibility
must give myself some hurts

will say

Is it possible he should know what he is
that he is?
I would the cutting of my garments would serve the
turn
We cannot afford you so.

'Twould not do.
Or to drown my clothes
Hardly serve.
Though I swore I leaped from the window of the citadel.
How deep?
Thirty fathom.

I recovered it.

Go
Till we do hear from them.
Captain
A' will betray us all unto ourselves:

SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
Enter BERTRAM and DIANA
They told me that your name was Fontibell.
No
Titled goddess;
And worth it
If quick fire of youth light not your mind
When you are dead
As you are now
And now you should be as your mother was
When your sweet self was got.
She then was honest.
So should you be.
No:
My mother did but duty; such
No more o' that;
I prithee
I was compell'd to her; but I love thee
By love's own sweet constraint
Do thee all rights of service.
Ay
Till we serve you; but when you have our roses
And mock us with our bareness.
How have I sworn!
'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth
What is not holy
Are words and poor conditions
Change it
Be not so holy-cruel: love is holy;
And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts
That you do charge men with. Stand no more off
My love as it begins shall so persever.
I see that men make ropes in such a scarre
That we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.
I'll lend it thee
To give it from me.
Will you not
It is an honour 'longing to our house
Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world
In me to lose.
Mine honour's such a ring:
My chastity's the jewel of our house
Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world
In me to lose: thus your own proper wisdom
Brings in the champion Honour on my part
Here
My house
When midnight comes
I'll order take my mother shall not hear.
Now will I charge you in the band of truth
My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them
When back again this ring shall be deliver'd:
And on your finger in the night I'll put
Another ring
May token to the future our past deeds.
Adieu
A wife of me
A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.
Exit
For which live long to thank both heaven and me!
You may so in the end.
My mother told me just how he would woo
Have the like oaths: he had sworn to marry me
When his wife's dead; therefore I'll lie with him
When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid
Only in this disguise I think't no sin
To cozen him that would unjustly win.
Exit
SCENE III. The Florentine camp.

You have not given him his mother's letter?
I have delivered it an hour since: there is

SCENE IV. Florence. The Widow's house.
Enter HELENA
That you may well perceive I have not wrong'd you
Shall be my surety; 'fore whose throne 'tis needful

His grace is at Marseilles; to which place
We have convenient convoy. You must know

Gentle madam

Nor you
To recompense your love: doubt not but heaven
Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower
And helper to a husband. But
That can such sweet use make of what they hate
Defiles the pitchy night: so lust doth play
With what it loathes for that which is away.
But more of this hereafter. You
Something in my behalf.
Let death and honesty

Yet

Our wagon is prepared
All's well that ends well; still the fine's the crown;
Whate'er the course

ACT V
SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.

But this exceeding posting day and night
Must wear your spirits low; we cannot help it:

As nothing can unroot you. In happy time;

SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
Flourish. Enter KING
We lost a jewel of her; and our esteem
Was made much poorer by it: but your son
Her estimation home.
'Tis past
And I beseech your majesty to make it
Natural rebellion
When oil and fire
My honour'd lady
Though my revenges were high bent upon him
This I must say
Did to his majesty
Offence of mighty note; but to himself
The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife
Whose beauty did astonish the survey
Of richest eyes
Humbly call'd mistress.
Praising what is lost
Makes the remembrance dear. Well
We are reconciled
All repetition: let him not ask our pardon;
The nature of his great offence is dead
The incensing relics of it: let him approach
So 'tis our will he should.
I shall
Exit
What says he to your daughter? have you spoke?
All that he is hath reference to your highness.
Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent me
That set him high in fame.
Enter BERTRAM
He looks well on't.
I am not a day of season
In me at once: but to the brightest beams
Distracted clouds give way; so stand thou forth;
The time is fair again.
My high-repented blames
All is whole;
Not one word more of the consumed time.
Let's take the instant by the forward top;
For we are old
The inaudible and noiseless foot of Time
Steals ere we can effect them. You remember
The daughter of this lord?
Admiringly
I stuck my choice upon her
Durst make too bold a herald of my tongue
Where the impression of mine eye infixing
Scorn'd a fair colour
Extended or contracted all proportions
To a most hideous object: thence it came
That she whom all men praised and whom myself
The dust that did offend it.
Well excused:
That thou didst love her
From the great compt: but love that comes too late
Make trivial price of serious things we have
Oft our displeasures
Our own love waking cries to see what's done
Be this sweet Helen's knell
Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin:
The main consents are had; and here we'll stay
To see our widower's second marriage-day.
Which better than the first
Or

ACT I

If with myself I hold intelligence
Or have acquaintance with mine own desires
As I do trust I am not--then
Did I offend your highness.
Thus do all traitors:
If their purgation did consist in words
Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not.
Yet your mistrust cannot make me a traitor:
Tell me whereon the likelihood depends.
Thou art thy father's daughter; there's enough.
So was I when your highness took his dukedom;
So was I when your highness banish'd him:
Treason is not inherited
Or
Then
To think my poverty is treacherous.
Dear sovereign
Ay
I did not then entreat to have her stay;

I was too young that time to value her;

Speak to the people
Thou art a fool: she robs thee of thy name;
And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous
When she is gone. Then open not thy lips:
Firm and irrevocable is my doom
Which I have pass'd upon her; she is banish'd.
Pronounce that sentence then on me
I cannot live out of her company.
You are a fool. You
If you outstay the time
Exeunt DUKE FREDERICK and Lords
O my poor Rosalind
Wilt thou change fathers? I will give thee mine.
I charge thee
I have more cause.
Thou hast not
Prithee be cheerful: know'st thou not
Hath banish'd me
That he hath not.
No
Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one:
Shall we be sunder'd? shall we part
No: let my father seek another heir.
Therefore devise with me how we may fly
And do not seek to take your change upon you
For
Why
To seek my uncle in the forest of Arden.
Alas
Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.
I'll put myself in poor and mean attire
And with a kind of umber smirch my face;
The like do you: so shall we pass along
And never stir assailants.
Were it not better
A gallant curtle-axe upon my thigh
Lie there what hidden woman's fear there will--
We'll have a swashing and a martial outside
That do outface it with their semblances.
What shall I call thee when thou art a man?
I'll have no worse a name than Jove's own page;
And therefore look you call me Ganymede.
But what will you be call'd?
Something that hath a reference to my state
No longer Celia
But
The clownish fool out of your father's court?
Would he not be a comfort to our travel?
He'll go along o'er the wide world with me;
Leave me alone to woo him. Let's away
To hide us from pursuit that will be made
After my flight. Now go we in content
To liberty and not to banishment.
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. The Forest of Arden.
Enter DUKE SENIOR
Now
Than that of painted pomp? Are not these woods
More free from peril than the envious court?
Here feel we but the penalty of Adam
And churlish chiding of the winter's wind
'This is no flattery: these are counsellors
That feelingly persuade me what I am.'
Sweet are the uses of adversity
And this our life exempt from public haunt
Finds tongues in trees
I would not change it.
Happy is your grace
Into so quiet and so sweet a style.
Come
And yet it irks me the poor dappled fools
Have their round haunches gored.
Indeed
Than doth your brother that hath banish'd you.
To-day my Lord of Amiens and myself
Did steal behind him as he lay along
Under an oak whose antique root peeps out
Upon the brook that brawls along this wood:
To the which place a poor sequester'd stag
That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat
Almost to bursting
Coursed one another down his innocent nose
In piteous chase; and thus the hairy fool
Much marked of the melancholy Jaques
But what said Jaques?
Did he not moralize this spectacle?
O
First
'Poor deer
As worldlings do
To that which had too much:' then
The flux of company:' anon a careless herd
And never stays to greet him; 'Ay' quoth Jaques
'Tis just the fashion: wherefore do you look
Upon that poor and broken bankrupt there?'
Thus most invectively he pierceth through
The body of the country
Are mere usurpers
In their assign'd and native dwelling-place.
And did you leave him in this contemplation?
We did
Upon the sobbing deer.
Show me the place:
I love to cope him in these sullen fits
I'll bring you to him straight.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A room in the palace.
Enter DUKE FREDERICK
Can it be possible that no man saw them?
It cannot be: some villains of my court
Are of consent and sufferance in this.
I cannot hear of any that did see her.
The ladies
They found the bed untreasured of their mistress.
My lord
Your grace was wont to laugh
Hisperia
Your daughter and her cousin much commend
The parts and graces of the wrestler
That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles;
And she believes
Send to his brother; fetch that gallant hither;
If he be absent
I'll make him find him: do this suddenly
To bring again these foolish runaways.
Exeunt
SCENE III. Before OLIVER'S house.
Enter ORLANDO and ADAM
Who's there?
What
O my sweet master! O you memory
Of old Sir Rowland! why
Why are you virtuous? why do people love you?
And wherefore are you gentle
Why would you be so fond to overcome
The bonny priser of the humorous duke?
Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.
Know you not
Their graces serve them but as enemies?
No more do yours: your virtues
O
Envenoms him that bears it!
Why
O unhappy youth!
Come not within these doors; within this roof
The enemy of all your graces lives:
Your brother--no
Yet not the son
Of him I was about to call his father--
Hath heard your praises
To burn the lodging where you use to lie
And you within it: if he fail of that
I overheard him and his practises.
This is no place; this house is but a butchery:
Abhor it
Why
No matter whither
What
Or with a base and boisterous sword enforce
A thievish living on the common road?
This I must do
Yet this I will not do
I rather will subject me to the malice
Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.
But do not so. I have five hundred crowns
When service should in my old limbs lie lame
And unregarded age in corners thrown:
Take that
And all this I give you. Let me be your servant:
Though I look old
For in my youth I never did apply
Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood
The means of weakness and debility;
Therefore my age is as a lusty winter
I'll do the service of a younger man
In all your business and necessities.
O good old man
The constant service of the antique world
Thou art not for the fashion of these times
Even with the having: it is not so with thee.
But
In lieu of all thy pains and husbandry
But come thy ways; well go along together
Master
From seventeen years till now almost fourscore
Here lived I
At seventeen years many their fortunes seek;
But at fourscore it is too late a week:
Yet fortune cannot recompense me better
Than to die well and not my master's debtor.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The Forest of Arden.
Enter ROSALIND for Ganymede
O Jupiter
I care not for my spirits
I could find in my heart to disgrace my man's
apparel and to cry like a woman; but I must comfort
the weaker vessel
itself courageous to petticoat: therefore courage
I pray you
For my part
you; yet I should bear no cross if I did bear you
Well
Ay
at home
must be content.
Ay
Enter CORIN and SILVIUS
Look you
solemn talk.
That is the way to make her scorn you still.
O Corin
I partly guess; for I have loved ere now.
No
As ever sigh'd upon a midnight pillow:
But if thy love were ever like to mine--
As sure I think did never man love so--
How many actions most ridiculous
Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?
Into a thousand that I have forgotten.
O
If thou remember'st not the slightest folly
That ever love did make thee run into
Or if thou hast not sat as I do now
Or if thou hast not broke from company
Abruptly
O Phebe
Exit
Alas
And I mine. I remember
my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for

pretty chopt hands had milked; and I remember the
wooing of a peascod instead of her
two cods and
weeping tears 'Wear these for my sake.' We that are
true lovers run into strange capers; but as all is
mortal in nature
Thou speakest wiser than thou art ware of.
Nay
break my shins against it.
Jove
Is much upon my fashion.
And mine; but it grows something stale with me.
I pray you
If he for gold will give us any food:
I faint almost to death.
Holla
Peace
Who calls?
Your betters
Else are they very wretched.
Peace
And to you
I prithee
Can in this desert place buy entertainment
Here's a young maid with travel much oppress'd
And faints for succor.
Fair sir
And wish
But I am shepherd to another man
And do not shear the fleeces that I graze:
My master is of churlish disposition
And little recks to find the way to heaven
By doing deeds of hospitality:
Besides
Are now on sale
That you will feed on; but what is
And in my voice most welcome shall you be.
What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture?
That young swain that you saw here but erewhile
I pray thee
And we will mend thy wages. I like this place.
And willingly could waste my time in it.
Assuredly the thing is to be sold:
Go with me: if you like upon report
The soil
And buy it with your gold right suddenly.
Exeunt
SCENE V. The Forest.
Enter AMIENS
SONG.
Under the greenwood tree
Who loves to lie with me
Unto the sweet bird's throat
Here shall he see No enemy
But winter and rough weather.
More

More

I do not desire you to please me; I do desire you to

More at your request than to please myself.

If it do come to pass

SCENE VI. The forest.
Enter ORLANDO and ADAM
Dear master
Here lie I down
Why
a little; comfort a little; cheer thyself a little.
If this uncouth forest yield any thing savage
will either be food for it or bring it for food to
thee. Thy conceit is nearer death than thy powers.
For my sake be comfortable; hold death awhile at
the arm's end: I will here be with thee presently;
and if I bring thee not something to eat
give thee leave to die: but if thou diest before I
come
thou lookest cheerly
Yet thou liest in the bleak air: come
thee to some shelter; and thou shalt not die for
lack of a dinner
desert. Cheerly
Exeunt
SCENE VII. The forest.
A table set out. Enter DUKE SENIOR
I think he be transform'd into a beast;
For I can no where find him like a man.
My lord
Here was he merry
If he
Go
Enter JAQUES
He saves my labour by his own approach.
Why
What
A fool
As I do live by food
Who laid him down and bask'd him in the sun
'Good morrow
And then he drew a dial from his poke
Thus we may see
'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine
And so
And thereby hangs a tale.' When I did hear
The motley fool thus moral on the time
An hour by his dial. O noble fool!
A worthy fool! Motley's the only wear.
What fool is this?
O worthy fool! One that hath been a courtier
After a voyage
With observation
In mangled forms. O that I were a fool!
I am ambitious for a motley coat.
Thou shalt have one.
It is my only suit;
Provided that you weed your better judgments
Of all opinion that grows rank in them
That I am wise. I must have liberty
Withal
And they that are most galled with my folly
The 'why' is plain as way to parish church:
He that a fool doth very wisely hit
Doth very foolishly
Even by the squandering glances of the fool.
Invest me in my motley; give me leave
To speak my mind
Cleanse the foul body of the infected world
Fie on thee! I can tell what thou wouldst do.
What
Most mischievous foul sin
For thou thyself hast been a libertine
And all the embossed sores and headed evils
Why
Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea
What woman in the city do I name
The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders?
Who can come in and say that I mean her
Or what is he of basest function
That says his bravery is not of my cost
His folly to the mettle of my speech?
There then; how then? what then? Let me see wherein
My tongue hath wrong'd him: if it do him right
Enter ORLANDO
Forbear
Why
Nor shalt not
Of what kind should this cock come of?
Art thou thus bolden'd
You touch'd my vein at first: the thorny point
Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show
Of smooth civility: yet am I inland bred
And know some nurture. But forbear
He dies that touches any of this fruit
Till I and my affairs are answered.
An you will not be answered with reason
What would you have? Your gentleness shall force
More than your force move us to gentleness.
I almost die for food; and let me have it.
Sit down and feed
Speak you so gently? Pardon me
I thought that all things had been savage here;
And therefore put I on the countenance
Of stern commandment. But whate'er you are
That in this desert inaccessible
If ever you have look'd on better days
And know what 'tis to pity and be pitied
In the which hope I blush
True is it that we have seen better days
And sat at good men's feasts and wiped our eyes
Of drops that sacred pity hath engender'd:
And therefore sit you down in gentleness
And take upon command what help we have
That to your wanting may be minister'd.
Then but forbear your food a little while
And give it food. There is an old poor man
Limp'd in pure love: till he be first sufficed
Go find him out
I thank ye; and be blest for your good comfort!
Exit
Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy:
This wide and universal theatre
Presents more woeful pageants than the scene
Wherein we play in.
All the world's a stage
They have their exits and their entrances;
And one man in his time plays many parts
And then the whining school-boy
And shining morning face
Unwillingly to school. And then the lover
Made to his mistress' eyebrow. Then a soldier
Even in the cannon's mouth. And then the justice
And so he plays his part. The sixth age shifts
Into the lean and slipper'd pantaloon
For his shrunk shank; and his big manly voice
And whistles in his sound. Last scene of all
Re-enter ORLANDO
Welcome. Set down your venerable burthen
I thank you most for him.
So had you need:
I scarce can speak to thank you for myself.
Welcome; fall to: I will not trouble you
As yet
Give us some music; and
SONG.
Blow
Thou art not so unkind
As man's ingratitude;
Thy tooth is not so keen
Heigh-ho! sing
Most friendship is feigning
Then
This life is most jolly.
Freeze
As benefits forgot:
Though thou the waters warp
As friend remember'd not.
Heigh-ho! sing
If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son
Most truly limn'd and living in your face
That loved your father: the residue of your fortune
Support him by the arm. Give me your hand
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. A room in the palace.
Enter DUKE FREDERICK
Not see him since? Sir
But were I not the better part made mercy
Of my revenge
Find out thy brother
Seek him with candle; bring him dead or living
Within this twelvemonth
To seek a living in our territory.
Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine
Worth seizure do we seize into our hands
Of what we think against thee.
O that your highness knew my heart in this!
I never loved my brother in my life.
More villain thou. Well
And let my officers of such a nature
Make an extent upon his house and lands:
Do this expediently and turn him going.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The forest.
Enter ORLANDO
Hang there
And thou
With thy chaste eye
O Rosalind! these trees shall be my books
And in their barks my thoughts I'll character;
That every eye which in this forest looks
Shall see thy virtue witness'd every where.
Run
The fair
Exit
Enter CORIN and TOUCHSTONE
And how like you this shepherd's life
Truly
life

but as there is no more plenty in it
against my stomach. Hast any philosophy in thee
No more but that I know the more one sickens the

that the property of rain is to wet and fire to

great cause of the night is lack of the sun; that

Such a one is a natural philosopher. Wast ever in
court
No
Then thou art damned.
Nay

All the pictures fairest lined
Are but black to Rosalind.
Let no fair be kept in mind
But the fair of Rosalind.
I'll rhyme you so eight years together

Out
For a taste:
If a hart do lack a hind

Then to cart with Rosalind.
Sweetest nut hath sourest rind
He that sweetest rose will find
Must find love's prick and Rosalind.
This is the very false gallop of verses: why do you

Why should this a desert be?
For it is unpeopled? No:
Tongues I'll hang on every tree
Some
Runs his erring pilgrimage
Buckles in his sum of age;
Some
'Twixt the souls of friend and friend:
But upon the fairest boughs
The quintessence of every sprite
Heaven would in little show.
Therefore Heaven Nature charged
That one body should be fill'd
With all graces wide-enlarged:
Nature presently distill'd
Helen's cheek

Very well: what would you?
I pray you
You should ask me what time o' day: there's no clock
in the forest.
Then there is no true lover in the forest; else
sighing every minute and groaning every hour would
detect the lazy foot of Time as well as a clock.
And why not the swift foot of Time? had not that
been as proper?

Who ambles Time withal?

With lawyers in the vacation

skirts of the forest

As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.
Your accent is something finer than you could

I have been told so of many: but indeed an old

There is none of my uncle's marks upon you: he

Never talk to me; I will weep.
Do
that tears do not become a man.
But have I not cause to weep?

His very hair is of the dissembling colour.
Something browner than Judas's marry
Judas's own children.
I' faith
An excellent colour: your chestnut was ever the only colour.
And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch

of winter's sisterhood kisses not more religiously;

SCENE V. Another part of the forest.
Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE
Sweet Phebe
Say that you love me not
In bitterness. The common executioner
But first begs pardon: will you sterner be
Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops?
Enter ROSALIND
I would not be thy executioner:
I fly thee
Thou tell'st me there is murder in mine eye:
'Tis pretty
Now I do frown on thee with all my heart;
And if mine eyes can wound
Now counterfeit to swoon; why now fall down;
Or if thou canst not
Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee:
Scratch thee but with a pin
Some scar of it; lean but upon a rush
Thy palm some moment keeps; but now mine eyes
That can do hurt.
O dear Phebe

That love's keen arrows make.

As till that time I shall not pity thee.
And why
As
Than without candle may go dark to bed--

Why

Of nature's sale-work. 'Od's my little life
No

You foolish shepherd

Than any of her lineaments can show her.

Silvius

A scatter'd smile

Not very well
And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds
That the old carlot once was master of.
Think not I love him
'Tis but a peevish boy; yet he talks well;
But what care I for words? yet words do well
When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.
It is a pretty youth: not very pretty:
But
He'll make a proper man: the best thing in him
Is his complexion; and faster than his tongue
Did make offence his eye did heal it up.
He is not very tall; yet for his years he's tall:
His leg is but so so; and yet 'tis well:
There was a pretty redness in his lip
Than that mix'd in his cheek; 'twas just the difference
Between the constant red and mingled damask.
There be some women
In parcels as I did
To fall in love with him; but
I have more cause to hate him than to love him:
For what had he to do to chide at me?
He said mine eyes were black and my hair black:
And
I marvel why I answer'd not again:
But that's all one; omittance is no quittance.
I'll write to him a very taunting letter
Phebe
I'll write it straight;
The matter's in my head and in my heart:
I will be bitter with him and passing short.
Go with me
Exeunt

According to the fool's bolt
But
quarrel on the seventh cause?
Upon a lie seven times removed:--bear your body more
seeming
cut of a certain courtier's beard: he sent me word
mind it was: this is called the Retort Courteous.
If I sent him word again 'it was not well cut
would send me word
this is called the Quip Modest. If again 'it was
not well cut
called the Reply Churlish. If again 'it was not
well cut
is called the Reproof Valiant. If again 'it was not
well cut
Counter-cheque Quarrelsome: and so to the Lie
Circumstantial and the Lie Direct.
And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut?
I durst go no further than the Lie Circumstantial
measured swords and parted.
Can you nominate in order now the degrees of the lie?
O sir
books for good manners: I will name you the degrees.
The first
Quip Modest; the third
fourth
Countercheque Quarrelsome; the sixth
Circumstance; the seventh
these you may avoid but the Lie Direct; and you may
avoid that too
justices could not take up a quarrel
parties were met themselves
of an If
they shook hands and swore brothers. Your If is the
only peacemaker; much virtue in If.
Is not this a rare fellow
any thing and yet a fool.
He uses his folly like a stalking-horse and under
the presentation of that he shoots his wit.
Enter HYMEN
Still Music
Then is there mirth in heaven
Atone together.
Good duke
Hymen from heaven brought her
Whose heart within his bosom is.
[To DUKE SENIOR]  To you I give myself
To ORLANDO
To you I give myself
If there be truth in sight
If there be truth in sight
If sight and shape be true
I'll have no father
I'll have no husband
Nor ne'er wed woman
Peace
'Tis I must make conclusion
Of these most strange events:
Here's eight that must take hands
To join in Hymen's bands
You and you no cross shall part:
You and you are heart in heart
You to his love must accord
You and you are sure together
Whiles a wedlock-hymn we sing
That reason wonder may diminish
SONG.
Wedding is great Juno's crown:
O blessed bond of board and bed!
'Tis Hymen peoples every town;
High wedlock then be honoured:
Honour
O my dear niece
Even daughter
I will not eat my word
Thy faith my fancy to thee doth combine.
Enter JAQUES DE BOYS
Let me have audience for a word or two:
I am the second son of old Sir Rowland
Duke Frederick
Men of great worth resorted to this forest
His brother here and put him to the sword:
And to the skirts of this wild wood he came;
Where meeting with an old religious man
Both from his enterprise and from the world
That were with him exiled. This to be true
Welcome
Thou offer'st fairly to thy brothers' wedding:
To one his lands withheld
A land itself at large
First
That here were well begun and well begot:
And after
That have endured shrewd days and nights with us
Shall share the good of our returned fortune
Meantime
And fall into our rustic revelry.
Play
Sir
And thrown into neglect the pompous court?
He hath.
To him will I : out of these convertites
There is much matter to be heard and learn'd.
To DUKE SENIOR
You to your former honour I bequeath;
Your patience and your virtue well deserves it:
To ORLANDO
You to a love that your true faith doth merit:
To OLIVER
You to your land and love and great allies:
To SILVIUS
You to a long and well-deserved bed:
To TOUCHSTONE
And you to wrangling; for thy loving voyage
Is but for two months victuall'd. So
I am for other than for dancing measures.
Stay
"To see no pastime I	what you would have"
I'll stay to know at your abandon'd cave.
Exit
Proceed
A dance
EPILOGUE
It is not the fashion to see the lady the epilogue;
but it is no more unhandsome than to see the lord
the prologue. If it be true that good wine needs
no bush
epilogue; yet to good wine they do use good bushes
epilogues. What a case am I in then
neither a good epilogue nor cannot insinuate with
you in the behalf of a good play! I am not
furnished like a beggar
become me: my way is to conjure you; and I'll begin
with the women. I charge you
you bear to men
please you: and I charge you
you bear to women--as I perceive by your simpering
women the play may please. If I were a woman I
would kiss as many of you as had beards that pleased
me
defied not: and
beards or good faces or sweet breaths will
kind offer
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. Alexandria. A room in CLEOPATRA's palace.
Enter DEMETRIUS and PHILO
Nay
O'erflows the measure: those his goodly eyes
Have glow'd like plated Mars
Upon a tawny front: his captain's heart
The buckles on his breast
To cool a gipsy's lust.
Flourish. Enter ANTONY
Look
Take but good note
The triple pillar of the world transform'd
Into a strumpet's fool: behold and see.
If it be love indeed
There's beggary in the love that can be reckon'd.
I'll set a bourn how far to be beloved.
Then must thou needs find out new heaven
Enter an Attendant
News
Grates me: the sum.
Nay
Fulvia perchance is angry; or
If the scarce-bearded Caesar have not sent
His powerful mandate to you
Take in that kingdom
Perform 't
How
Perchance! nay
You must not stay here longer
Is come from Caesar; therefore hear it
Where's Fulvia's process? Caesar's I would say? both?
Call in the messengers. As I am Egypt's queen
Is Caesar's homager: else so thy cheek pays shame
When shrill-tongued Fulvia scolds. The messengers!
Let Rome in Tiber melt
Of the ranged empire fall! Here is my space.
Kingdoms are clay: our dungy earth alike
Feeds beast as man: the nobleness of life
Is to do thus; when such a mutual pair
Embracing
And such a twain can do't
We stand up peerless.
Excellent falsehood!
Why did he marry Fulvia
I'll seem the fool I am not; Antony
Will be himself.
But stirr'd by Cleopatra.
Now
There's not a minute of our lives should stretch
Without some pleasure now. What sport tonight?
Hear the ambassadors.
Fie
Whom every thing becomes
To make itself
No messenger
To-night we'll wander through the streets and note
The qualities of people. Come
Last night you did desire it: speak not to us.
Exeunt MARK ANTONY and CLEOPATRA with their train
Is Caesar with Antonius prized so slight?
Sir
Which still should go with Antony.
I am full sorry
That he approves the common liar
Thus speaks of him at Rome: but I will hope
Of better deeds to-morrow. Rest you happy!
Exeunt

O excellent! I love long life better than figs.

Enter MARK ANTONY with a Messenger and Attendants
Fulvia thy wife first came into the field.
Against my brother Lucius?
Ay:
But soon that war had end
Made friends of them
Whose better issue in the war
Well
The nature of bad news infects the teller.
When it concerns the fool or coward. On:
Things that are past are done with me. 'Tis thus:
Who tells me true
Labienus--
This is stiff news--hath
His conquering banner shook from Syria
To Lydia and to Ionia; Whilst--
Antony
O
Speak to me home

Is as our earing. Fare thee well awhile.
At your noble pleasure.

From Sicyon
The man from Sicyon
He stays upon your will.

These strong Egyptian fetters I must break

There's a great spirit gone! Thus did I desire it:
What our contempt doth often hurl from us
The opposite of itself: she's good
The hand could pluck her back that shoved her on.
I must from this enchanting queen break off:
Ten thousand harms
Re-enter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
What's your pleasure
I must with haste from hence.

we see how mortal an unkindness is to them;

this

the finest part of pure love: we cannot call her

shower of rain as well as Jove.
Would I had never seen her.
O
of work; which not to have been blest withal would

Sir?

Why

with consolation; your old smock brings forth a new

The business she hath broached in the state
Cannot endure my absence.
And the business you have broached here cannot be
without you; especially that of Cleopatra's
wholly depends on your abode.
No more light answers. Let our officers
Have notice what we purpose. I shall break
The cause of our expedience to the queen
The death of Fulvia
Of many our contriving friends in Rome
Petition us at home: Sextus Pompeius
Hath given the dare to Caesar
The empire of the sea: our slippery people
Till his deserts are past
Pompey the Great and all his dignities
Upon his son; who
For the main soldier: whose quality
Our quick remove from hence.
I shall do't.
Exeunt
SCENE III. The same. Another room.
Enter CLEOPATRA
Where is he?
I did not see him since.
See where he is
I did not send you: if you find him sad
That I am sudden sick: quick
Exit ALEXAS
Madam
The like from him.
What should I do
In each thing give him way
Thou teachest like a fool; the way to lose him.
Tempt him not so too far; I wish
In time we hate that which we often fear.
But here comes Antony.
Enter MARK ANTONY
I am sick and sullen.
I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose
Help me away
It cannot be thus long
Will not sustain it.
Now
Pray you
What's the matter?
I know
What says the married woman? You may go:
Would she had never given you leave to come!
Let her not say 'tis I that keep you here:
I have no power upon you; hers you are.
The gods best know
O
So mightily betray'd! yet at the first
I saw the treasons planted.
Cleopatra
Why should I think you can be mine and true
Most sweet queen
Nay
Eternity was in our lips and eyes
How now
I would I had thy inches; thou shouldst know
There were a heart in Egypt.
Hear me
The strong necessity of time commands
Our services awhile; but my full heart
Remains in use with you. Our Italy
Shines o'er with civil swords: Sextus Pompeius
Makes his approaches to the port of Rome:
Equality of two domestic powers
Breed scrupulous faction: the hated
Upon the present state
And quietness
By any desperate change: my more particular
Though age from folly could not give me freedom
She's dead
Look here
The garboils she awaked; at the last
See when and where she died.
O most false love!
Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill
With sorrowful water? Now I see
Quarrel no more
The purposes I bear; which are
That quickens Nilus' slime
Thy soldier
As thou affect'st.
Cut my lace
But let it be: I am quickly ill
My precious queen
And give true evidence to his love
An honourable trial.
So Fulvia told me.
I prithee
Belong to Egypt: good now
Of excellent dissembling; and let it look
Life perfect honour.
You'll heat my blood: no more.
You can do better yet; but this is meetly.
Now
And target. Still he mends;
But this is not the best. Look
The carriage of his chafe.
I'll leave you
Courteous lord
Sir
Sir
That you know well: something it is I would
But that your royalty
Holds idleness your subject
For idleness itself.
'Tis sweating labour
To bear such idleness so near the heart
As Cleopatra this. But
Since my becomings kill me
Eye well to you: your honour calls you hence;
Therefore be deaf to my unpitied folly.
And all the gods go with you! upon your sword
Sit laurel victory! and smooth success
Be strew'd before your feet!
Let us go. Come;
Our separation so abides
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Rome. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's house.
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
You may see
Our great competitor: from Alexandria
This is the news: he fishes
The lamps of night in revel; is not more man-like
Than Cleopatra; nor the queen of Ptolemy
More womanly than he; hardly gave audience
Vouchsafed to think he had partners: you shall find there
A man who is the abstract of all faults
That all men follow.
I must not think there are
Evils enow to darken all his goodness:
His faults in him seem as the spots of heaven
You are too indulgent. Let us grant
Amiss to tumble on the bed of Ptolemy;
To give a kingdom for a mirth; to sit
And keep the turn of tippling with a slave;
To reel the streets at noon
With knaves that smell of sweat: say this
becomes him
As his composure must be rare indeed
Whom these things cannot blemish
No way excuse his soils
So great weight in his lightness. If he fill'd
His vacancy with his voluptuousness
As his own state and ours
As we rate boys
Enter a Messenger
Here's more news.
Thy biddings have been done; and every hour
How 'tis abroad. Pompey is strong at sea;
And it appears he is beloved of those
That only have fear'd Caesar: to the ports
The discontents repair
Give him much wrong'd.
I should have known no less.
It hath been taught us from the primal state
And the ebb'd man
Caesar
With keels of every kind: many hot inroads
They make in Italy; the borders maritime
Lack blood to think on't
No vessel can peep forth
Taken as seen; for Pompey's name strikes more
Than could his war resisted.
Antony
Wast beaten from Modena
Hirtius and Pansa
Did famine follow; whom thou fought'st against
Than savages could suffer: thou didst drink
The stale of horses
Which beasts would cough at: thy palate then did deign
The roughest berry on the rudest hedge;
Yea
It is reported thou didst eat strange flesh
It wounds thine honour that I speak it now--
Was borne so like a soldier
So much as lank'd not.
'Tis pity of him.
Let his shames quickly
Drive him to Rome: 'tis time we twain
Did show ourselves i' the field; and to that end
Assemble we immediate council: Pompey
Thrives in our idleness.
To-morrow
Both what by sea and land I can be able
To front this present time.
Till which encounter
Farewell
Of stirs abroad
Doubt not
I knew it for my bond.
Exeunt
SCENE V. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.
Enter CLEOPATRA
Charmian!
Madam?
Ha
Give me to drink mandragora.
Why
That I might sleep out this great gap of time
My Antony is away.
You think of him too much.
O
Madam
Thou
What's your highness' pleasure?
Not now to hear thee sing; I take no pleasure
In aught an eunuch has: 'tis well for thee
May not fly forth of Egypt. Hast thou affections?
Yes
Indeed!
Not in deed
But what indeed is honest to be done:
Yet have I fierce affections
What Venus did with Mars.
O Charmian
Or does he walk? or is he on his horse?
O happy horse
Do bravely
The demi-Atlas of this earth
And burgonet of men. He's speaking now
For so he calls me: now I feed myself
With most delicious poison. Think on me
A morsel for a monarch: and great Pompey
Would stand and make his eyes grow in my brow;
There would he anchor his aspect and die
With looking on his life.
Enter ALEXAS
Sovereign of Egypt
How much unlike art thou Mark Antony!
Yet
With his tinct gilded thee.
How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?
Last thing he did
This orient pearl. His speech sticks in my heart.
Mine ear must pluck it thence.
'Good friend
This treasure of an oyster; at whose foot
Her opulent throne with kingdoms; all the east
Was beastly dumb'd by him.
What
Like to the time o' the year between the extremes
Of hot and cold
O well-divided disposition! Note him
He was not sad
That make their looks by his; he was not merry
In Egypt with his joy; but between both:
O heavenly mingle! Be'st thou sad or merry
Ay
Why do you send so thick?
Who's born that day
When I forget to send to Antony
Welcome
O that brave Caesar!
Be choked with such another emphasis!
Say
The valiant Caesar!
By Isis
My man of men.
By your most gracious pardon
My salad days
Get me ink and paper:
He shall have every day a several greeting
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Messina. POMPEY's house.
Enter POMPEY
If the great gods be just
The deeds of justest men.
Know
Whiles we are suitors to their throne
The thing we sue for.
We
Deny us for our good; so find we profit
By losing of our prayers.
I shall do well:
The people love me
My powers are crescent
Says it will come to the full. Mark Antony
In Egypt sits at dinner
No wars without doors: Caesar gets money where
He loses hearts: Lepidus flatters both
Caesar and Lepidus
Are in the field: a mighty strength they carry.
Where have you this? 'tis false.
From Silvius
He dreams: I know they are in Rome together
Let witchcraft join with beauty
Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts
Sharpen with cloyless sauce his appetite;
That sleep and feeding may prorogue his honour
Even till a Lethe'd dulness!
Enter VARRIUS
How now
This is most certain that I shall deliver:
Mark Antony is every hour in Rome
Expected: since he went from Egypt 'tis
A space for further travel.
I could have given less matter
A better ear. Menas
This amorous surfeiter would have donn'd his helm
For such a petty war: his soldiership
Is twice the other twain: but let us rear
The higher our opinion
Can from the lap of Egypt's widow pluck
The ne'er-lust-wearied Antony.
I cannot hope
Caesar and Antony shall well greet together:
His wife that's dead did trespasses to Caesar;
His brother warr'd upon him; although
I know not
Were't not that we stand up against them all
themselves;
For they have entertained cause enough
To draw their swords: but how the fear of us
May cement their divisions and bind up
The petty difference
Be't as our gods will have't! It only stands
Our lives upon to use our strongest hands.
Come
Exeunt
SCENE II. Rome. The house of LEPIDUS.
Enter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS and LEPIDUS
Good Enobarbus
To soft and gentle speech.
I shall entreat him
To answer like himself: if Caesar move him
And speak as loud as Mars. By Jupiter
'Tis not a time
For private stomaching.
Every time
Serves for the matter that is then born in't.
But small to greater matters must give way.
Not if the small come first.
Your speech is passion:
But
The noble Antony.
Enter MARK ANTONY and VENTIDIUS
And yonder
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
If we compose well here
Hark
I do not know
Noble friends
A leaner action rend us. What's amiss
Our trivial difference loud
Murder in healing wounds: then
'Tis spoken well.
Were we before our armies
I should do thus.
Flourish
Welcome to Rome.
Thank you.
Sit.
Sit
Nay
I learn
I must be laugh'd at
Should say myself offended
Chiefly i' the world; more laugh'd at
Once name you derogately
It not concern'd me.
My being in Egypt
No more than my residing here at Rome
Might be to you in Egypt: yet
Did practise on my state
Might be my question.
How intend you
You may be pleased to catch at mine intent
By what did here befal me. Your wife and brother
Made wars upon me; and their contestation
Was theme for you
You do mistake your business; my brother never
Did urge me in his act: I did inquire it;
And have my learning from some true reports
Discredit my authority with yours;
And make the wars alike against my stomach
Before did satisfy you. If you'll patch a quarrel
You praise yourself
By laying defects of judgment to me; but
You patch'd up your excuses.
Not so
I know you could not lack
Which fronted mine own peace. As for my wife
The third o' the world is yours; which with a snaffle
You may pace easy
Would we had all such wives
to wars with the women!
So much uncurbable
Made out of her impatience
Shrewdness of policy too
Did you too much disquiet: for that you must
But say
I wrote to you
When rioting in Alexandria; you
Did pocket up my letters
Did gibe my missive out of audience.
Sir
Three kings I had newly feasted
Of what I was i' the morning: but next day
I told him of myself; which was as much
As to have ask'd him pardon. Let this fellow
Be nothing of our strife; if we contend
You have broken
The article of your oath; which you shall never
Have tongue to charge me with.
Soft
No
The honour is sacred which he talks on now
The article of my oath.
To lend me arms and aid when I required them;
The which you both denied.
Neglected
And then when poison'd hours had bound me up
From mine own knowledge. As nearly as I may
Shall not make poor my greatness
Work without it. Truth is
For which myself
So far ask pardon as befits mine honour
To stoop in such a case.
'Tis noble spoken.
If it might please you
The griefs between ye: to forget them quite
Were to remember that the present need
Speaks to atone you.
Worthily spoken
Or
instant
Pompey
wrangle in when you have nothing else to do.
Thou art a soldier only: speak no more.
That truth should be silent I had almost forgot.
You wrong this presence; therefore speak no more.
Go to
I do not much dislike the matter
The manner of his speech; for't cannot be
We shall remain in friendship
So differing in their acts. Yet if I knew
What hoop should hold us stanch
O' the world I would pursue it.
Give me leave
Speak
Thou hast a sister by the mother's side
Is now a widower.
Say not so
If Cleopatra heard you
Were well deserved of rashness.
I am not married
Agrippa further speak.
To hold you in perpetual amity
With an unslipping  knot
Octavia to his wife; whose beauty claims
No worse a husband than the best of men;
Whose virtue and whose general graces speak
That which none else can utter. By this marriage
Would
For 'tis a studied
Will Caesar speak?
Not till he hears how Antony is touch'd
With what is spoke already.
What power is in Agrippa
To make this good?
The power of Caesar
His power unto Octavia.
May I never
To this good purpose
Further this act of grace: and from this hour
The heart of brothers govern in our loves
And sway our great designs!
There is my hand.
A sister I bequeath you
Did ever love so dearly: let her live
To join our kingdoms and our hearts; and never
Fly off our loves again!
Happily
I did not think to draw my sword 'gainst Pompey;
For he hath laid strange courtesies and great
Of late upon me: I must thank him only
At heel of that
Time calls upon's:
Of us must Pompey presently be sought
Where lies he?
About the mount Misenum.
What is his strength by land?
Great and increasing: but by sea
He is an absolute master.
So is the fame.
Would we had spoke together! Haste we for it:
Yet
The business we have talk'd of.
With most gladness:
And do invite you to my sister's view
Let us
Noble Antony
Flourish. Exeunt OCTAVIUS CAESAR
Welcome from Egypt
Half the heart of Caesar
honourable friend
Good Enobarbus!
We have cause to be glad that matters are so well
digested. You stayed well by 't in Egypt.
Ay
made the night light with drinking.
Eight wild-boars roasted whole at a breakfast
but twelve persons there; is this true?
This was but as a fly by an eagle: we had much more
monstrous matter of feast
She's a most triumphant lady
her.
When she first met Mark Antony
his heart
There she appeared indeed; or my reporter devised
well for her.
I will tell you.
The barge she sat in
Purple the sails
The winds were love-sick with them; the oars were silver
The water which they beat to follow faster
In her pavilion--cloth-of-gold of tissue--
O'er-picturing that Venus where we see
The fancy outwork nature: on each side her
Stood pretty dimpled boys
To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool
O
Her gentlewomen
A seeming mermaid steers: the silken tackle
Swell with the touches of those flower-soft hands
A strange invisible perfume hits the sense
Of the adjacent wharfs. The city cast
Her people out upon her; and Antony
Rare Egyptian!
Upon her landing
Which she entreated: our courteous Antony
For what his eyes eat only.
Royal wench!
She made great Caesar lay his sword to bed:
He plough'd her
I saw her once
Hop forty paces through the public street;
And having lost her breath
Now Antony must leave her utterly.
Never; he will not:
Age cannot wither her
Her infinite variety: other women cloy
The appetites they feed: but she makes hungry
Where most she satisfies; for vilest things
Become themselves in her: that the holy priests
Bless her when she is riggish.
If beauty
The heart of Antony
A blessed lottery to him.
Let us go.
Good Enobarbus
Whilst you abide here.
Humbly
Exeunt
SCENE III. The same. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's house.
Enter MARK ANTONY
The world and my great office will sometimes
Divide me from your bosom.
All which time
Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers
To them for you.
Good night
I have not kept my square; but that to come
Shall all be done by the rule. Good night
Good night
Good night.
Exeunt OCTAVIUS CAESAR and OCTAVIA
Enter Soothsayer
Now
Would I had never come from thence
If you can
I see it in
My motion
Hie you to Egypt again.
Say to me
Caesar's.
Therefore
Thy demon
Noble
Becomes a fear
Make space enough between you.
Speak this no more.
To none but thee; no more
If thou dost play with him at any game
Is all afraid to govern thee near him;
But
Get thee gone:
Say to Ventidius I would speak with him:
Exit Soothsayer
He shall to Parthia. Be it art or hap
And in our sports my better cunning faints
Under his chance: if we draw lots
His cocks do win the battle still of mine
Beat mine
And though I make this marriage for my peace
Enter VENTIDIUS
O
Follow me
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The same. A street.
Enter LEPIDUS
Trouble yourselves no further: pray you
Your generals after.
Sir
Will e'en but kiss Octavia
Till I shall see you in your soldier's dress
We shall
Before you
Your way is shorter;
My purposes do draw me much about:
You'll win two days upon me.
Sir
Farewell.
Exeunt
SCENE V. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.
Enter CLEOPATRA
Give me some music; music
Of us that trade in love.
The music
Enter MARDIAN
Let it alone; let's to billiards: come
My arm is sore; best play with Mardian.
As well a woman with an eunuch play'd
As with a woman. Come
As well as I can
And when good will is show'd
too short
Give me mine angle; we'll to the river: there
Tawny-finn'd fishes; my bended hook shall pierce
Their slimy jaws; and
'Twas merry when
You wager'd on your angling; when your diver
Did hang a salt-fish on his hook
With fervency drew up.
That time
I laugh'd him out of patience; and that night
I laugh'd him into patience; and next morn
Then put my tires and mantles on him
I wore his sword Philippan.
Enter a Messenger
O
Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears
Madam
Antonius dead!--If thou say so
My bluest veins to kiss; a hand that kings
Have lipp'd
First
Why
But
To say the dead are well: bring it to that
Down thy ill-uttering throat.
Good madam
Well
But there's no goodness in thy face: if Antony
Be free and healthful
To trumpet such good tidings! If not well
Will't please you hear me?
I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak'st:
Yet if thou say Antony lives
Rich pearls upon thee.
Madam
Well said.
And friends with Caesar.
Thou'rt an honest man.
Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.
Make thee a fortune from me.
But yet
I do not like 'But yet
The good precedence; fie upon 'But yet'!
'But yet' is as a gaoler to bring forth
Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee
In state of health thou say'st; and thou say'st free.
Free
He's bound unto Octavia.
For what good turn?
For the best turn i' the bed.
I am pale
Madam
The most infectious pestilence upon thee!
Strikes him down
Good madam
What say you? Hence
Horrible villain! or I'll spurn thine eyes
Like balls before me; I'll unhair thy head:
She hales him up and down
Thou shalt be whipp'd with wire
Gracious madam
Say 'tis not so
Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage;
And I will boot thee with what gift beside
Thy modesty can beg.
He's married
Rogue
Draws a knife
Nay
What mean you
Exit
Good madam
The man is innocent.
Some innocents 'scape not the thunderbolt.
Melt Egypt into Nile! and kindly creatures
Turn all to serpents! Call the slave again:
Though I am mad
He is afeard to come.
I will not hurt him.
Exit CHARMIAN
These hands do lack nobility
A meaner than myself; since I myself
Have given myself the cause.
Re-enter CHARMIAN and Messenger
Come hither
Though it be honest
To bring bad news: give to a gracious message.
An host of tongues; but let ill tidings tell
Themselves when they be felt.
I have done my duty.
Is he married?
I cannot hate thee worser than I do
He's married
The gods confound thee! dost thou hold there still?
Should I lie
O
A cistern for scaled snakes! Go
Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face
Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married?
I crave your highness' pardon.
He is married?
Take no offence that I would not offend you:
To punish me for what you make me do.
Seems much unequal: he's married to Octavia.
O
The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome
Are all too dear for me: lie they upon thy hand
Exit Messenger
Good your highness
In praising Antony
Many times
I am paid for't now.
Lead me from hence:
I faint: O Iras
Go to the fellow
Report the feature of Octavia
The colour of her hair: bring me word quickly.
Exit ALEXAS
Let him for ever go:--let him not--Charmian
To MARDIAN
Bring me word how tall she is. Pity me
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Near Misenum.
Flourish. Enter POMPEY and MENAS at one door
Your hostages I have
And we shall talk before we fight.
Most meet
That first we come to words; and therefore have we
Our written purposes before us sent;
Which
If 'twill tie up thy discontented sword
That else must perish here.
To you all three
Wherefore my father should revengers want
That moved pale Cassius to conspire; and what
Made the all-honour'd
Have one man but a man? And that is it
Hath made me rig my navy; at whose burthen
The anger'd ocean foams; with which I meant
To scourge the ingratitude that despiteful Rome
Cast on my noble father.
Take your time.
Thou canst not fear us
We'll speak with thee at sea: at land
How much we do o'er-count thee.
At land
But
Be pleased to tell us--
For this is from the present--how you take
The offers we have sent you.
There's the point.
Which do not be entreated to
What it is worth embraced.
And what may follow
You have made me offer
Of Sicily
Rid all the sea of pirates; then
Measures of wheat to Rome; this 'greed upon
To part with unhack'd edges
Our targes undinted.
That's our offer.
Know
To take this offer: but Mark Antony
Put me to some impatience: though I lose
The praise of it by telling
Her welcome friendly.
I have heard it
And am well studied for a liberal thanks
Which I do owe you.
Let me have your hand:
I did not think
The beds i' the east are soft; and thanks to you
For I have gain'd by 't.
Since I saw you last
Well
What counts harsh fortune casts upon my face;
But in my bosom shall she never come
Well met here.
I hope so
I crave our composition may be written
That's the next to do.
We'll feast each other ere we part; and let's
Draw lots who shall begin.
That will I
No
Or last
Shall have the fame. I have heard that Julius Caesar
Grew fat with feasting there.
You have heard much.
I have fair meanings
And fair words to them.
Then so much have I heard:
And I have heard
No more of that: he did so.
What
A certain queen to Caesar in a mattress.
I know thee now: how farest thou
Well;
And well am like to do; for
Let me shake thy hand;
I never hated thee: I have seen thee fight
Sir
As I have said you did.
Enjoy thy plainness
Aboard my galley I invite you all:
Will you lead
Show us the way
Come.
Exeunt all but MENAS and ENOBARBUS
[Aside]  Thy father
made this treaty.--You and I have known
At sea
We have
You have done well by water.
And you by land.
I will praise any man that will praise me; though it
cannot be denied what I have done by land.
Nor what I have done by water.
Yes
safety: you have been a great thief by sea.
And you by land.
There I deny my land service. But give me your
hand
might take two thieves kissing.
All men's faces are true
But there is never a fair woman has a true face.
No slander; they steal hearts.
We came hither to fight with you.
For my part
Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.
If he do
You've said
here: pray you
Caesar's sister is called Octavia.
TRUE
But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.
Pray ye
'Tis true.
Then is Caesar and he for ever knit together.
If I were bound to divine of this unity
not prophesy so.
I think the policy of that purpose made more in the
marriage than the love of the parties.
I think so too. But you shall find
seems to tie their friendship together will be the
very strangler of their amity: Octavia is of a
holy
Who would not have his wife so?
Not he that himself is not so; which is Mark Antony.
He will to his Egyptian dish again: then shall the
sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar; and
I said before
amity shall prove the immediate author of their
variance. Antony will use his affection where it is:
he married but his occasion here.
And thus it may be. Come
I have a health for you.
I shall take it
Come
Exeunt
SCENE VII. On board POMPEY's galley
Music plays. Enter two or three Servants with a banquet
Here they'll be
ill-rooted already: the least wind i' the world
will blow them down.
Lepidus is high-coloured.
They have made him drink alms-drink.
As they pinch one another by the disposition
cries out 'No more;' reconciles them to his
entreaty
But it raises the greater war between him and
his discretion.
Why
fellowship: I had as lief have a reed that will do
me no service as a partisan I could not heave.
To be called into a huge sphere
to move in't
A sennet sounded. Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
[To OCTAVIUS CAESAR]  Thus do they
the flow o' the Nile
By certain scales i' the pyramid; they know
Or foison follow: the higher Nilus swells
Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain
You've strange serpents there.
Ay
Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the
operation of your sun: so is your crocodile.
They are so.
Sit
I am not so well as I should be
Not till you have slept; I fear me you'll be in till then.
Nay
pyramises are very goodly things; without
contradiction
[Aside to POMPEY]  Pompey
[Aside to MENAS]                 Say in mine ear:
what is't?
[Aside to POMPEY]  Forsake thy seat
thee
[Aside to MENAS]  Forbear me till anon.
This wine for Lepidus!
What manner o' thing is your crocodile?
It is shaped
as it hath breadth: it is just so high as it is
which nourisheth it; and the elements once out of
it
What colour is it of?
Of it own colour too.
'Tis a strange serpent.
'Tis so. And the tears of it are wet.
Will this description satisfy him?
With the health that Pompey gives him
very epicure.
[Aside to MENAS]  Go hang
that? away!
Do as I bid you. Where's this cup I call'd for?
[Aside to POMPEY]  If for the sake of merit thou
wilt hear me
[Aside to MENAS]  I think thou'rt mad.
The matter?
Rises
I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.
Thou hast served me with much faith. What's else to say?
Be jolly
These quick-sands
Wilt thou be lord of all the world?
What say'st thou?
Wilt thou be lord of the whole world? That's twice.
How should that be?
But entertain it
Will give thee all the world.
Hast thou drunk well?
Now
Thou art
Whate'er the ocean pales
Show me which way.
These three world-sharers
And
All there is thine.
Ah
In thee't had been good service. Thou must know
Mine honour
Hath so betray'd thine act: being done unknown
But must condemn it now. Desist
[Aside]  For this
Who seeks
This health to Lepidus!
Bear him ashore. I'll pledge it for him
Here's to thee
Enobarbus
Fill till the cup be hid.
There's a strong fellow
Pointing to the Attendant who carries off LEPIDUS
Why?
A' bears the third part of the world
not?
The third part
Drink thou; increase the reels.
Come.
This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.
It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels
Here is to Caesar!
I could well forbear't.
It's monstrous labour
Be a child o' the time.
Possess it
But I had rather fast from all four days
Than drink so much in one.
Ha
To MARK ANTONY
Shall we dance now the Egyptian Bacchanals
Let's ha't
Come
In soft and delicate Lethe.
All take hands.
Make battery to our ears with the loud music:
The while I'll place you: then the boy shall sing;
The holding every man shall bear as loud
As his strong sides can volley.
Music plays. DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS places them hand in hand
THE SONG.
Come
In thy fats our cares be drown'd
Cup us
What would you more? Pompey
Frowns at this levity. Gentle lords
You see we have burnt our cheeks: strong Enobarb
Is weaker than the wine; and mine own tongue
Splits what it speaks: the wild disguise hath almost
Antick'd us all. What needs more words? Good night.
Good Antony
I'll try you on the shore.
And shall
O Antony
Come
Take heed you fall not.

Menas
No
These drums! these trumpets
Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell
To these great fellows: sound and be hang'd
Sound a flourish
Ho! says a' There's my cap.
Ho! Noble captain
