ACT III
SCENE I. A plain in Syria.
Enter VENTIDIUS as it were in triumph
Now
Pleased fortune does of Marcus Crassus' death
Make me revenger. Bear the king's son's body
Before our army. Thy Pacorus
Noble Ventidius
The routed fly: so thy grand captain Antony
Shall set thee on triumphant chariots and
Put garlands on thy head.
O Silius
Better to leave undone
Acquire too high a fame when him we serve's away.
Caesar and Antony have ever won
More in their officer than person: Sossius
Who does i' the wars more than his captain can
Becomes his captain's captain: and ambition
I could do more to do Antonius good
Should my performance perish.
Thou hast
Without the which a soldier
I'll humbly signify what in his name
How
We have jaded out o' the field.
Where is he now?
He purposeth to Athens: whither
The weight we must convey with's will permit
Exeunt
SCENE II. Rome. An ante-chamber in OCTAVIUS CAESAR's house.
Enter AGRIPPA at one door
What
They have dispatch'd with Pompey
The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps
To part from Rome; Caesar is sad; and Lepidus
With the green sickness.
'Tis a noble Lepidus.
A very fine one: O
Nay
Caesar? Why
What's Antony? The god of Jupiter.
Spake you of Caesar? How! the non-pareil!
O Antony! O thou Arabian bird!
Would you praise Caesar
Indeed
But he loves Caesar best; yet he loves Antony:
Ho! hearts
Think
His love to Antony. But as for Caesar
Both he loves.
They are his shards
Trumpets within
So;
This is to horse. Adieu
Good fortune
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
No further
You take from me a great part of myself;
Use me well in 't. Sister
As my thoughts make thee
Shall pass on thy approof. Most noble Antony
Betwixt us as the cement of our love
The fortress of it; for better might we
Have loved without this mean
This be not cherish'd.
Make me not offended
In your distrust.
I have said.
You shall not find
For what you seem to fear: so
We will here part.
Farewell
The elements be kind to thee
Thy spirits all of comfort! fare thee well.
My noble brother!
The April 's in her eyes: it is love's spring
Sir
What
I'll tell you in your ear.
Her tongue will not obey her heart
Her heart inform her tongue
down-feather
[Aside to AGRIPPA]  Will Caesar weep?
[Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  He has a cloud in 's face.
[Aside to AGRIPPA]  He were the worse for that
So is he
[Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  Why
When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.
[Aside to AGRIPPA]  That year
troubled with a rheum;
What willingly he did confound he wail'd
No
Out-go my thinking on you.
Come
I'll wrestle with you in my strength of love:
Look
Adieu; be happy!
Let all the number of the stars give light
To thy fair way!
Farewell
Kisses OCTAVIA
Farewell!
Trumpets sound. Exeunt
SCENE III. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.
Enter CLEOPATRA
Where is the fellow?
Half afeard to come.
Go to
Enter the Messenger as before
Come hither
Good majesty
But when you are well pleased.
That Herod's head
I'll have: but how
Through whom I might command it? Come thou near.
Most gracious majesty
Didst thou behold Octavia?
Ay
Where?
Madam
I look'd her in the face
Between her brother and Mark Antony.
Is she as tall as me?
She is not
Didst hear her speak? is she shrill-tongued or low?
Madam
That's not so good: he cannot like her long.
Like her! O Isis! 'tis impossible.
I think so
What majesty is in her gait? Remember
She creeps:
Her motion and her station are as one;
She shows a body rather than a life
Is this certain?
Or I have no observance.
Three in Egypt
Cannot make better note.
He's very knowing;
I do perceive't: there's nothing in her yet:
The fellow has good judgment.
Excellent.
Guess at her years
Madam
Widow! Charmian
And I do think she's thirty.
Bear'st thou her face in mind? is't long or round?
Round even to faultiness.
For the most part
Her hair
Brown
As low as she would wish it.
There's gold for thee.
Thou must not take my former sharpness ill:
I will employ thee back again; I find thee
Most fit for business: go make thee ready;
Our letters are prepared.
Exit Messenger
A proper man.
Indeed
That so I harried him. Why
Nothing
The man hath seen some majesty
Hath he seen majesty? Isis else defend
I have one thing more to ask him yet
But 'tis no matter; thou shalt bring him to me
Where I will write. All may be well enough.
I warrant you
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Athens. A room in MARK ANTONY's house.
Enter MARK ANTONY and OCTAVIA
Nay
That were excusable
Of semblable import
New wars 'gainst Pompey; made his will
To public ear:
Spoke scantly of me: when perforce he could not
But pay me terms of honour
He vented them; most narrow measure lent me:
When the best hint was given him
O my good lord
The good gods me presently
Undo that prayer
'Twixt these extremes at all.
Gentle Octavia
Best to preserve it: if I lose mine honour
Than yours so branchless. But
Shall stain your brother: make your soonest haste;
So your desires are yours.
Thanks to my lord.
The Jove of power make me most weak
As if the world should cleave
Should solder up the rift.
When it appears to you where this begins
Can never be so equal
Can equally move with them. Provide your going;
Choose your own company
Your heart has mind to.
Exeunt
SCENE V. The same. Another room.
Enter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS and EROS
How now
There's strange news come
What
Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon Pompey.
This is old: what is the success?
Caesar
Pompey
him partake in the glory of the action: and not
resting here
wrote to Pompey; upon his own appeal
the poor third is up
Then
And throw between them all the food thou hast
He's walking in the garden--thus; and spurns
The rush that lies before him; cries
And threats the throat of that his officer
That murder'd Pompey.
Our great navy's rigg'd.
For Italy and Caesar. More
My lord desires you presently: my news
I might have told hereafter.
'Twill be naught:
But let it be. Bring me to Antony.
Come
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Rome. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's house.
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
Contemning Rome
I' the market-place
Were publicly enthroned: at the feet sat
Caesarion
Since then hath made between them. Unto her
He gave the stablishment of Egypt; made her
Of lower Syria
This in the public eye?
I' the common show-place
His sons he there proclaim'd the kings of kings:
Great Media
He gave to Alexander; to Ptolemy he assign'd
Syria
In the habiliments of the goddess Isis
That day appear'd; and oft before gave audience
Let Rome be thus Inform'd.
Who
Already
The people know it; and have now received
His accusations.
Who does he accuse?
Caesar: and that
Sextus Pompeius spoil'd
His part o' the isle: then does he say
Some shipping unrestored: lastly
That Lepidus of the triumvirate
Should be deposed; and
All his revenue.
Sir
'Tis done already
I have told him
That he his high authority abused
Demand the like.
He'll never yield to that.
Nor must not then be yielded to in this.
Enter OCTAVIA with her train
Hail
That ever I should call thee castaway!
You have not call'd me so
Why have you stol'n upon us thus! You come not
Like Caesar's sister: the wife of Antony
Should have an army for an usher
The neighs of horse to tell of her approach
Long ere she did appear; the trees by the way
Should have borne men; and expectation fainted
Should have ascended to the roof of heaven
A market-maid to Rome; and have prevented
The ostentation of our love
By sea and land; supplying every stage
With an augmented greeting.
Good my lord
On my free will. My lord
My grieved ear withal; whereon
His pardon for return.
Which soon he granted
Do not say so
I have eyes upon him
Where is he now?
My lord
No
Hath nodded him to her. He hath given his empire
Up to a whore; who now are levying
The kings o' the earth for war; he hath assembled
Bocchus
Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king
King Malchus of Arabia; King of Pont;
Herod of Jewry; Mithridates
Of Comagene; Polemon and Amyntas
Ay me
That do afflict each other!
Welcome hither:
Your letters did withhold our breaking forth;
Till we perceived
Be you not troubled with the time
O'er your content these strong necessities;
But let determined things to destiny
Hold unbewail'd their way. Welcome to Rome;
Nothing more dear to me. You are abused
Beyond the mark of thought: and the high gods
Of us and those that love you. Best of comfort;
And ever welcome to us.
Welcome
Welcome
Each heart in Rome does love and pity you:
Only the adulterous Antony
In his abominations
And gives his potent regiment to a trull
Is it so
Most certain. Sister
Exeunt
SCENE VII. Near Actium. MARK ANTONY's camp.
Enter CLEOPATRA and DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
I will be even with thee
But why
Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars
Well
If not denounced against us
Be there in person?
[Aside]  Well
If we should serve with horse and mares together
A soldier and his horse.
What is't you say?
Your presence needs must puzzle Antony;
Take from his heart
Traduced for levity; and 'tis said in Rome
That Photinus an eunuch and your maids
Manage this war.
Sink Rome
That speak against us! A charge we bear i' the war
Appear there for a man. Speak not against it:
I will not stay behind.
Nay
Here comes the emperor.
Enter MARK ANTONY and CANIDIUS
Is it not strange
He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea
Celerity is never more admired
Than by the negligent.
A good rebuke
Will fight with him by sea.
By sea! what else?
Why will my lord do so?
For that he dares us to't.
So hath my lord dared him to single fight.
Ay
Where Caesar fought with Pompey: but these offers
And so should you.
Your ships are not well mann'd;
Your mariners are muleters
Ingross'd by swift impress; in Caesar's fleet
Are those that often have 'gainst Pompey fought:
Their ships are yare; yours
Shall fall you for refusing him at sea
By sea
Most worthy sir
The absolute soldiership you have by land;
Distract your army
Of war-mark'd footmen; leave unexecuted
Your own renowned knowledge; quite forego
The way which promises assurance; and
Give up yourself merely to chance and hazard
I'll fight at sea.
I have sixty sails
Our overplus of shipping will we burn;
And
Beat the approaching Caesar. But if we fail
Enter a Messenger
Thy business?
The news is true
Caesar has taken Toryne.
Can he be there in person? 'tis impossible;
Strange that power should be. Canidius
Away
Enter a Soldier
How now
O noble emperor
Trust not to rotten planks: do you misdoubt
This sword and these my wounds? Let the Egyptians
And the Phoenicians go a-ducking; we
Have used to conquer
Well
Exeunt MARK ANTONY
By Hercules
Soldier
Not in the power on't: so our leader's led
You keep by land
The legions and the horse whole
Marcus Octavius
But we keep whole by land. This speed of Caesar's
Carries beyond belief.
While he was yet in Rome
Beguiled all spies.
Who's his lieutenant
They say
Well I know the man.
Enter a Messenger
The emperor calls Canidius.
With news the time's with labour
Exeunt
SCENE VIII. A plain near Actium.
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
Taurus!
My lord?
Strike not by land; keep whole: provoke not battle
The prescript of this scroll: our fortune lies
Upon this jump.
Exeunt
SCENE IX. Another part of the plain.
Enter MARK ANTONY and DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
Set we our squadrons on yond side o' the hill
We may the number of the ships behold
Exeunt
SCENE X. Another part of the plain.
CANIDIUS marcheth with his land army one way over  the stage; and TAURUS
Alarum. Enter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
Naught
The Antoniad
To see't mine eyes are blasted.
Enter SCARUS
Gods and goddesses
What's thy passion!
The greater cantle of the world is lost
With very ignorance; we have kiss'd away
Kingdoms and provinces.
How appears the fight?
On our side like the token'd pestilence
Whom leprosy o'ertake!--i' the midst o' the fight
That I beheld:
Mine eyes did sicken at the sight
Endure a further view.
She once being loof'd
I never saw an action of such shame;
Experience
Did violate so itself.
Alack
Enter CANIDIUS
Our fortune on the sea is out of breath
Been what he knew himself
O
Ay
Why
Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.
'Tis easy to't; and there I will attend
What further comes.
To Caesar will I render
My legions and my horse: six kings already
Show me the way of yielding.
I'll yet follow
The wounded chance of Antony
Sits in the wind against me.
Exeunt
SCENE XI. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.
Enter MARK ANTONY with Attendants
Hark! the land bids me tread no more upon't;
It is ashamed to bear me! Friends
I am so lated in the world
Have lost my way for ever: I have a ship
Laden with gold; take that
Fly! not we.
I have fled myself; and have instructed cowards
To run and show their shoulders. Friends
I have myself resolved upon a course
Which has no need of you; be gone:
My treasure's in the harbour
My very hairs do mutiny; for the white
Reprove the brown for rashness
For fear and doting. Friends
Have letters from me to some friends that will
Sweep your way for you. Pray you
Which my despair proclaims; let that be left
Which leaves itself: to the sea-side straightway:
I will possess you of that ship and treasure.
Leave me
Nay
Sits down
Enter CLEOPATRA led by CHARMIAN and IRAS; EROS following
Nay
Do
Do! why: what else?
Let me sit down. O Juno!
No
See you here
O fie
Madam!
Madam
Sir
Yes
His sword e'en like a dancer; while I struck
The lean and wrinkled Cassius; and 'twas I
That the mad Brutus ended: he alone
Dealt on lieutenantry
In the brave squares of war: yet now--No matter.
Ah
The queen
Go to him
He is unqualitied with very shame.
Well then
Most noble sir
Her head's declined
Your comfort makes the rescue.
I have offended reputation
Sir
O
By looking back what I have left behind
'Stroy'd in dishonour.
O my lord
You would have follow'd.
Egypt
My heart was to thy rudder tied by the strings
Thy full supremacy thou knew'st
Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods
Command me.
O
Now I must
To the young man send humble treaties
And palter in the shifts of lowness; who
With half the bulk o' the world play'd as I pleased
How much you were my conqueror; and that
My sword
Obey it on all cause.
Pardon
Fall not a tear
All that is won and lost: give me a kiss;
Even this repays me. We sent our schoolmaster;
Is he come back? Love
Some wine
We scorn her most when most she offers blows.
Exeunt
SCENE XII. Egypt. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's camp.
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
Let him appear that's come from Antony.
Know you him?
Caesar
An argument that he is pluck'd
He sends so poor a pinion off his wing
Not many moons gone by.
Enter EUPHRONIUS
Approach
Such as I am
I was of late as petty to his ends
As is the morn-dew on the myrtle-leaf
To his grand sea.
Be't so: declare thine office.
Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee
Requires to live in Egypt: which not granted
To let him breathe between the heavens and earth
Next
Submits her to thy might; and of thee craves
The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs
For Antony
Of audience nor desire shall fail
From Egypt drive her all-disgraced friend
Fortune pursue thee!
Bring him through the bands.
Exit EUPHRONIUS
To THYREUS
From Antony win Cleopatra: promise
In their best fortunes strong; but want will perjure
The ne'er touch'd vestal: try thy cunning
Make thine own edict for thy pains
Will answer as a law.
Caesar
Observe how Antony becomes his flaw
In every power that moves.
Caesar
Exeunt
SCENE XIII. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.
Enter CLEOPATRA
What shall we do
Think
Is Antony or we in fault for this?
Antony only
Lord of his reason. What though you fled
From that great face of war
Frighted each other? why should he follow?
The itch of his affection should not then
Have nick'd his captainship; at such a point
The meered question: 'twas a shame no less
Than was his loss
Prithee
Enter MARK ANTONY with EUPHRONIUS
Is that his answer?
Ay
The queen shall then have courtesy
Will yield us up.
He says so.
Let her know't.
To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head
With principalities.
That head
To him again: tell him he wears the rose
Of youth upon him; from which the world should note
Something particular: his coin
Under the service of a child as soon
As i' the command of Caesar: I dare him therefore
To lay his gay comparisons apart
Exeunt MARK ANTONY and EUPHRONIUS
[Aside]  Yes
Unstate his happiness
A parcel of their fortunes; and things outward
Do draw the inward quality after them
Answer his emptiness! Caesar
His judgment too.
Enter an Attendant
A messenger from CAESAR.
What
Against the blown rose may they stop their nose
That kneel'd unto the buds. Admit him
Exit Attendant
[Aside]  Mine honesty and I begin to square.
The loyalty well held to fools does make
Our faith mere folly: yet he that can endure
To follow with allegiance a fall'n lord
Does conquer him that did his master conquer
And earns a place i' the story.
Enter THYREUS
Caesar's will?
Hear it apart.
None but friends: say boldly.
So
He needs as many
Or needs not us. If Caesar please
Will leap to be his friend: for us
So.
Thus then
Go on: right royal.
He knows that you embrace not Antony
As you did love
O!
The scars upon your honour
Does pity
He is a god
What is most right: mine honour was not yielded
[Aside]             To be sure of that
Thy dearest quit thee.
Exit
Shall I say to Caesar
What you require of him? for he partly begs
To be desired to give. It much would please him
To lean upon: but it would warm his spirits
What's your name?
My name is Thyreus.
Most kind messenger
I kiss his conquering hand: tell him
To lay my crown at 's feet
Tell him from his all-obeying breath I hear
The doom of Egypt.
'Tis your noblest course.
Wisdom and fortune combating together
My duty on your hand.
Your Caesar's father oft
Re-enter MARK ANTONY and DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
Favours
What art thou
One that but performs
The bidding of the fullest man
To have command obey'd.
[Aside]               You will be whipp'd.
Approach
and devils!
Authority melts from me: of late
Like boys unto a muss
Antony yet.
Enter Attendants
Take hence this Jack
[Aside]  'Tis better playing with a lion's whelp
Than with an old one dying.
Moon and stars!
Whip him. Were't twenty of the greatest tributaries
That do acknowledge Caesar
So saucy with the hand of she here
Mark Antony!
Tug him away: being whipp'd
Bear us an errand to him.
Exeunt Attendants with THYREUS
You were half blasted ere I knew you: ha!
Have I my pillow left unpress'd in Rome
By one that looks on feeders?
Good my lord
You have been a boggler ever:
But when we in our viciousness grow hard--
O misery on't!--the wise gods seel our eyes;
In our own filth drop our clear judgments; make us
Adore our errors; laugh at's
To our confusion.
O
I found you as a morsel cold upon
Dead Caesar's trencher; nay
Of Cneius Pompey's; besides what hotter hours
Luxuriously pick'd out: for
Wherefore is this?
To let a fellow that will take rewards
And say 'God quit you!' be familiar with
My playfellow
And plighter of high hearts! O
Upon the hill of Basan
The horned herd! for I have savage cause;
And to proclaim it civilly
A halter'd neck which does the hangman thank
For being yare about him.
Re-enter Attendants with THYREUS
Is he whipp'd?
Soundly
Cried he? and begg'd a' pardon?
He did ask favour.
If that thy father live
Thou wast not made his daughter; and be thou sorry
To follow Caesar in his triumph
Thou hast been whipp'd for following him: henceforth
The white hand of a lady fever thee
He makes me angry with him; for he seems
Proud and disdainful
And at this time most easy 'tis to do't
Into the abysm of hell. If he mislike
My speech and what is done
Hipparchus
He may at pleasure whip
Hence with thy stripes
Exit THYREUS
Have you done yet?
Alack
Is now eclipsed; and it portends alone
The fall of Antony!
I must stay his time.
To flatter Caesar
With one that ties his points?
Not know me yet?
Cold-hearted toward me?
Ah
Drop in my neck: as it determines
Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite!
Till by degrees the memory of my womb
Have buried them for prey!
I am satisfied.
Caesar sits down in Alexandria; where
I will oppose his fate. Our force by land
Hath nobly held; our sever'd navy too
Have knit again
Where hast thou been
If from the field I shall return once more
To kiss these lips
I and my sword will earn our chronicle:
There's hope in't yet.
That's my brave lord!
I will be treble-sinew'd
Were nice and lucky
Of me for jests; but now I'll set my teeth
All my sad captains; fill our bowls once more;
Let's mock the midnight bell.
It is my birth-day:
I had thought to have held it poor: but
Is Antony again
We will yet do well.
Call all his noble captains to my lord.
Do so
The wine peep through their scars. Come on
There's sap in't yet. The next time I do fight
Even with his pestilent scythe.
Exeunt all but DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
Now he'll outstare the lightning. To be furious
The dove will peck the estridge; and I see still
Restores his heart: when valour preys on reason
Some way to leave him.
Exit
ACT IV
SCENE I. Before Alexandria. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's camp.
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
He calls me boy; and chides
To beat me out of Egypt; my messenger
He hath whipp'd with rods; dares me to personal combat
I have many other ways to die; meantime
Laugh at his challenge.
Caesar must think
Even to falling. Give him no breath
Make boot of his distraction: never anger
Made good guard for itself.
Let our best heads
Know
We mean to fight: within our files there are
And feast the army; we have store to do't
Exeunt
SCENE II. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.
Enter MARK ANTONY
He will not fight with me
No.
Why should he not?
He thinks
To-morrow
Shall make it live again. Woo't thou fight well?
I'll strike
Well said; come on.
Call forth my household servants: let's to-night
Be bounteous at our meal.
Enter three or four Servitors
Give me thy hand
Thou
[Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  What means this?
[Aside to CLEOPATRA]  'Tis one of those odd
tricks which sorrow shoots
Out of the mind.
And thou art honest too.
I wish I could be made so many men
An Antony
So good as you have done.
The gods forbid!
Well
Scant not my cups; and make as much of me
As when mine empire was your fellow too
[Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  What does he mean?
[Aside to CLEOPATRA]  To make his followers weep.
Tend me to-night;
May be it is the period of your duty:
Haply you shall not see me more; or if
You'll serve another master. I look on you
As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends
Married to your good service
Tend me to-night two hours
What mean you
And I
Ho
Now the witch take me
Grace grow where those drops fall!
My hearty friends
For I spake to you for your comfort; did desire you
To burn this night with torches: know
Where rather I'll expect victorious life
Than death and honour. Let's to supper
Exeunt
SCENE III. The same. Before the palace.
Enter two Soldiers to their guard
Brother
It will determine one way: fare you well.
Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?
Nothing. What news?
Belike 'tis but a rumour. Good night to you.
Well
Enter two other Soldiers
Soldiers
And you. Good night
They place themselves in every corner of the stage
Here we: and if to-morrow
Our navy thrive
Our landmen will stand up.
'Tis a brave army
Music of the hautboys as under the stage
Peace! what noise?
List
Hark!
Music i' the air.
Under the earth.
It signs well
No.
Peace
What should this mean?
'Tis the god Hercules
Walk; let's see if other watchmen
Do hear what we do?
They advance to another post
How now
[Speaking together]  How now!
How now! do you hear this?
Ay; is't not strange?
Do you hear
Follow the noise so far as we have quarter;
Let's see how it will give off.
Content. 'Tis strange.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The same. A room in the palace.
Enter MARK ANTONY and CLEOPATRA
Eros! mine armour
Sleep a little.
No
Enter EROS with armour
Come good fellow
If fortune be not ours to-day
Because we brave her: come.
Nay
What's this for?
Ah
The armourer of my heart: false
Sooth
Well
We shall thrive now. Seest thou
Go put on thy defences.
Briefly
Is not this buckled well?
Rarely
He that unbuckles this
To daff't for our repose
Thou fumblest
More tight at this than thou: dispatch. O love
The royal occupation! thou shouldst see
A workman in't.
Enter an armed Soldier
Good morrow to thee; welcome:
Thou look'st like him that knows a warlike charge:
To business that we love we rise betime
A thousand
Shout. Trumpets flourish
Enter Captains and Soldiers
The morn is fair. Good morrow
Good morrow
'Tis well blown
This morning
That means to be of note
So
Fare thee well
This is a soldier's kiss: rebukeable
Kisses her
And worthy shameful cheque it were
On more mechanic compliment; I'll leave thee
Now
Exeunt MARK ANTONY
Please you
Lead me.
He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might
Determine this great war in single fight!
Then Antony
Exeunt
SCENE V. Alexandria. MARK ANTONY's camp.
Trumpets sound. Enter MARK ANTONY and EROS; a Soldier meeting them
The gods make this a happy day to Antony!
Would thou and those thy scars had once prevail'd
To make me fight at land!
Hadst thou done so
That has this morning left thee
Follow'd thy heels.
Who's gone this morning?
Who!
One ever near thee: call for Enobarbus
Say 'I am none of thine.'
What say'st thou?
Sir
Sir
He has not with him.
Is he gone?
Most certain.
Go
Detain no jot
I will subscribe--gentle adieus and greetings;
Say that I wish he never find more cause
To change a master. O
Corrupted honest men! Dispatch.--Enobarbus!
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Alexandria. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's camp.
Flourish. Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
Go forth
Our will is Antony be took alive;
Make it so known.
Caesar
Exit
The time of universal peace is near:
Prove this a prosperous day
Shall bear the olive freely.
Enter a Messenger
Antony
Is come into the field.
Go charge Agrippa
Plant those that have revolted in the van
Upon himself.
Exeunt all but DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
Alexas did revolt; and went to Jewry on
Affairs of Antony; there did persuade
Great Herod to incline himself to Caesar
Caesar hath hang'd him. Canidius and the rest
That fell away have entertainment
No honourable trust. I have done ill;
Of which I do accuse myself so sorely
Enter a Soldier of CAESAR's
Enobarbus
Hath after thee sent all thy treasure
His bounty overplus: the messenger
Came on my guard; and at thy tent is now
Unloading of his mules.
I give it you.
Mock not
I tell you true: best you safed the bringer
Out of the host; I must attend mine office
Continues still a Jove.
Exit
I am alone the villain of the earth
My better service
Thou dost so crown with gold! This blows my heart:
If swift thought break it not
Shall outstrike thought: but thought will do't
I fight against thee! No: I will go seek
Some ditch wherein to die; the foul'st best fits
My latter part of life.
Exit
SCENE VII. Field of battle between the camps.
Alarum. Drums and trumpets. Enter AGRIPPA and others
Retire
Caesar himself has work
Exceeds what we expected.
Exeunt
Alarums. Enter MARK ANTONY and SCARUS wounded
O my brave emperor
Had we done so at first
With clouts about their heads.
Thou bleed'st apace.
I had a wound here that was like a T
They do retire.
We'll beat 'em into bench-holes: I have yet
Room for six scotches more.
Enter EROS
They are beaten
For a fair victory.
Let us score their backs
'Tis sport to maul a runner.
I will reward thee
Once for thy spritely comfort
For thy good valour. Come thee on.
I'll halt after.
Exeunt
SCENE VIII. Under the walls of Alexandria.
Alarum. Enter MARK ANTONY
We have beat him to his camp: run one before
That has to-day escaped. I thank you all;
For doughty-handed are you
Not as you served the cause
Each man's like mine; you have shown all Hectors.
Enter the city
Wash the congealment from your wounds
The honour'd gashes whole.
To SCARUS
Give me thy hand
Enter CLEOPATRA
To this great fairy I'll commend thy acts
To CLEOPATRA
O thou day o' the world
Ride on the pants triumphing!
Lord of lords!
O infinite virtue
The world's great snare uncaught?
My nightingale
though grey
Do something mingle with our younger brown
A brain that nourishes our nerves
Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man;
Commend unto his lips thy favouring hand:
Kiss it
As if a god
Destroy'd in such a shape.
I'll give thee
He has deserved it
Like holy Phoebus' car. Give me thy hand:
Through Alexandria make a jolly march;
Bear our hack'd targets like the men that owe them:
Had our great palace the capacity
To camp this host
Make mingle with rattling tabourines;
That heaven and earth may strike their sounds together
Exeunt
SCENE IX. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's camp.
Sentinels at their post
If we be not relieved within this hour
Is shiny; and they say we shall embattle
By the second hour i' the morn.
This last day was
A shrewd one to's.
Enter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
O
What man is this?
Stand close
Be witness to me
Bear hateful memory
Before thy face repent!
Enobarbus!
Peace!
Hark further.
O sovereign mistress of true melancholy
Against the flint and hardness of my fault:
Which
But let the world rank me in register
A master-leaver and a fugitive:
O Antony! O Antony!
Dies
Let's speak To him.
Let's hear him
May concern Caesar.
Let's do so. But he sleeps.
Swoons rather; for so bad a prayer as his
Was never yet for sleep.
Go we to him.
Awake
Hear you
The hand of death hath raught him.
Drums afar off
Hark! the drums
Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him
To the court of guard; he is of note: our hour
Is fully out.
Come on
He may recover yet.
Exeunt with the body
SCENE X. Between the two camps.
Enter MARK ANTONY and SCARUS
Their preparation is to-day by sea;
We please them not by land.
For both
I would they'ld fight i' the fire or i' the air;
We'ld fight there too. But this it is; our foot
Upon the hills adjoining to the city
Shall stay with us: order for sea is given;
They have put forth the haven
Where their appointment we may best discover
Exeunt
SCENE XI. Another part of the same.
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
But being charged
Is forth to man his galleys. To the vales
Exeunt
SCENE XII. Another part of the same.
Enter MARK ANTONY and SCARUS
Yet they are not join'd: where yond pine
does stand
Straight
Exit
Swallows have built
In Cleopatra's sails their nests: the augurers
Say they know not
Is valiant
Alarum afar off
Re-enter MARK ANTONY
All is lost;
This foul Egyptian hath betrayed me:
My fleet hath yielded to the foe; and yonder
They cast their caps up and carouse together
Like friends long lost. Triple-turn'd whore!
'tis thou
Hast sold me to this novice; and my heart
Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly;
For when I am revenged upon my charm
Exit SCARUS
O sun
Fortune and Antony part here; even here
Do we shake hands. All come to this? The hearts
That spaniel'd me at heels
Their wishes
On blossoming Caesar; and this pine is bark'd
O this false soul of Egypt! this grave charm
Whose eye beck'd forth my wars
Whose bosom was my crownet
Like a right gipsy
What
Enter CLEOPATRA
Ah
Why is my lord enraged against his love?
Vanish
Follow his chariot
Of all thy sex; most monster-like
For poor'st diminutives
Patient Octavia plough thy visage up
With her prepared nails.
Exit CLEOPATRA
'Tis well thou'rt gone
Thou fell'st into my fury
Might have prevented many. Eros
The shirt of Nessus is upon me: teach me
Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o' the moon;
And with those hands
To the young Roman boy she hath sold me
Under this plot; she dies for't. Eros
Exit
SCENE XIII. Alexandria. Cleopatra's palace.
Enter CLEOPATRA
Help me
Than Telamon for his shield; the boar of Thessaly
Was never so emboss'd.
To the monument!
There lock yourself
The soul and body rive not more in parting
Than greatness going off.
To the monument!
Mardian
Say
And word it
To the monument!
Exeunt
SCENE XIV. The same. Another room.
Enter MARK ANTONY and EROS
Eros
Ay
Sometimes we see a cloud that's dragonish;
A vapour sometime like a bear or lion
With trees upon't
these signs;
They are black vesper's pageants.
Ay
The rack dislimns
It does
My good knave Eros
Even such a body: here I am Antony:
Yet cannot hold this visible shape
I made these wars for Egypt: and the queen
Whose heart I thought I had
Which whilst it was mine had annex'd unto't
A million more
Pack'd cards with Caesar
Unto an enemy's triumph.
Nay
Ourselves to end ourselves.
Enter MARDIAN
O! thy vile lady!
She has robb'd me of my sword.
No
My mistress loved thee
With thine entirely.
Hence
She hath betray'd me and shall die the death.
Death of one person can be paid but once
Is done unto thy hand: the last she spake
Was 'Antony! most noble Antony!'
Then in the midst a tearing groan did break
The name of Antony; it was divided
Between her heart and lips: she render'd life
Dead
Dead.
Unarm
To MARDIAN
That thou depart'st hence safe
Exit MARDIAN
Off
The seven-fold shield of Ajax cannot keep
The battery from my heart. O
Heart
No more a soldier: bruised pieces
You have been nobly borne. From me awhile.
Exit EROS
I will o'ertake thee
Weep for my pardon. So it must be
All length is torture: since the torch is out
Mars what it does; yea
Itself with strength: seal then
Eros!--I come
Where souls do couch on flowers
Dido and her AEneas shall want troops
Re-enter EROS
What would my lord?
Since Cleopatra died
Detest my baseness. I
Quarter'd the world
With ships made cities
The courage of a woman; less noble mind
Than she which by her death our Caesar tells
'I am conqueror of myself.' Thou art sworn
Is come indeed
The inevitable prosecution of
Disgrace and horror
Thou strikest not me
Put colour in thy cheek.
The gods withhold me!
Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts
Eros
Thy master thus with pleach'd arms
His corrigible neck
To penetrative shame
Of fortunate Caesar
His baseness that ensued?
I would not see't.
Come
Draw that thy honest sword
Most useful for thy country.
O
When I did make thee free
To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once;
Or thy precedent services are all
But accidents unpurposed. Draw
Turn from me
Lo thee!
Turning from him
My sword is drawn.
Then let it do at once
The thing why thou hast drawn it.
My dear master
'Tis said
Farewell
Now
Why
Of Antony's death.
Kills himself
Thrice-nobler than myself!
Thou teachest me
I should
Have by their brave instruction got upon me
A nobleness in record: but I will be
A bridegroom in my death
As to a lover's bed. Come
Falling on his sword
I learn'd of thee. How! not dead? not dead?
The guard
Enter DERCETAS and Guard
What's the noise?
I have done my work in
Of what I have begun.
The star is fall'n.
And time is at his period.
Alas
Let him that loves me strike me dead.
Not I.
Nor I.
Nor any one.
Exeunt Guard
Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
This sword but shown to Caesar
Enter DIOMEDES
Where's Antony?
There
Lives he?
Wilt thou not answer
Exit DERCETAS
Art thou there
Sufficing strokes for death.
Most absolute lord
When did she send thee?
Now
Where is she?
Lock'd in her monument. She had a prophesying fear
Of what hath come to pass: for when she saw--
Which never shall be found--you did suspect
She had disposed with Caesar
Would not be purged
But
Me to proclaim the truth; and I am come
Too late
What
Come
Enter four or five of the Guard of MARK ANTONY
Bear me
'Tis the last service that I shall command you.
Woe
All your true followers out.
Most heavy day!
Nay
To grace it with your sorrows: bid that welcome
Which comes to punish us
Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up:
I have led you oft: carry me now
Exeunt
SCENE XV. The same. A monument.
Enter CLEOPATRA and her maids aloft
O Charmian
Be comforted
No
All strange and terrible events are welcome
As that which makes it.
Enter
How now! is he dead?
His death's upon him
Look out o' the other side your monument;
His guard have brought him thither.
Enter
O sun
darkling stand
The varying shore o' the world. O Antony
Help
Peace!
Not Caesar's valour hath o'erthrown Antony
So it should be
Should conquer Antony; but woe 'tis so!
I am dying
I here importune death awhile
Of many thousand kisses the poor last
I lay up thy lips.
I dare not
Dear my lord
Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall
Be brooch'd with me; if knife
Edge
Your wife Octavia
And still conclusion
Demuring upon me. But come
Help me
Assist
O
Here's sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord!
Our strength is all gone into heaviness
Wishes were ever fools
They heave MARK ANTONY aloft to CLEOPATRA
And welcome
Quicken with kissing: had my lips that power
A heavy sight!
I am dying
Give me some wine
No
One word
Of Caesar seek your honour
They do not go together.
Gentle
None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.
My resolution and my hands I'll trust;
None about Caesar.
The miserable change now at my end
Lament nor sorrow at; but please your thoughts
In feeding them with those my former fortunes
Wherein I lived
My countryman
Valiantly vanquish'd. Now my spirit is going;
I can no more.
Noblest of men
Hast thou no care of me? shall I abide
In this dull world
No better than a sty? O
The crown o' the earth doth melt. My lord!
O
Are level now with men; the odds is gone
Beneath the visiting moon.
Faints
O
She is dead too
Lady!
Madam!
O madam
Royal Egypt
Peace
No more
By such poor passion as the maid that milks
And does the meanest chares. It were for me
To throw my sceptre at the injurious gods;
To tell them that this world did equal theirs
Till they had stol'n our jewel. All's but naught;
Patience is scottish
Become a dog that's mad: then is it sin
To rush into the secret house of death
What
My noble girls! Ah
We'll bury him; and then
This case of that huge spirit now is cold:
Ah
But resolution
Exeunt; those above bearing off MARK ANTONY's body
ACT V
SCENE I. Alexandria. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's camp.
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
Go to him
Being so frustrate
The pauses that he makes.
Caesar
Exit
Enter DERCETAS
Wherefore is that? and what art thou that darest
Appear thus to us?
I am call'd Dercetas;
Mark Antony I served
Best to be served: whilst he stood up and spoke
To spend upon his haters. If thou please
To take me to thee
I'll be to Caesar; if thou pleasest not
What is't thou say'st?
I say
The breaking of so great a thing should make
A greater crack: the round world
Should have shook lions into civil streets
Is not a single doom; in the name lay
A moiety of the world.
He is dead
Not by a public minister of justice
I robb'd his wound of it; behold it stain'd
With his most noble blood.
Look you sad
The gods rebuke me
To wash the eyes of kings.
And strange it is
Our most persisted deeds.
His taints and honours
Waged equal with him.
A rarer spirit never
Did steer humanity: but you
Some faults to make us men. Caesar is touch'd.
When such a spacious mirror's set before him
O Antony!
I have follow'd thee to this; but we do lance
Diseases in our bodies: I must perforce
Have shown to thee such a declining day
In the whole world: but yet let me lament
In top of all design
Where mine his thoughts did kindle
Our equalness to this. Hear me
But I will tell you at some meeter season:
Enter an Egyptian
The business of this man looks out of him;
We'll hear him what he says. Whence are you?
A poor Egyptian yet. The queen my mistress
To the way she's forced to.
Bid her have good heart:
She soon shall know of us
Determine for her; for Caesar cannot live
To be ungentle.
So the gods preserve thee!
Exit
Come hither
The quality of her passion shall require
She do defeat us; for her life in Rome
Would be eternal in our triumph: go
Caesar
Exit
Gallus
Exit GALLUS
Where's Dolabella
Dolabella!
Let him alone
How he's employ'd: he shall in time be ready.
Go with me to my tent; where you shall see
How hardly I was drawn into this war;
How calm and gentle I proceeded still
In all my writings: go with me
What I can show in this.
Exeunt
SCENE II. Alexandria. A room in the monument.
Enter CLEOPATRA
My desolation does begin to make
A better life. 'Tis paltry to be Caesar;
Not being Fortune
To do that thing that ends all other deeds;
Which shackles accidents and bolts up change;
Which sleeps
Enter
Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt;
And bids thee study on what fair demands
Thou mean'st to have him grant thee.
What's thy name?
My name is Proculeius.
Antony
Did tell me of you
I do not greatly care to be deceived
Would have a queen his beggar
No less beg than a kingdom: if he please
To give me conquer'd Egypt for my son
Will kneel to him with thanks.
Be of good cheer;
You're fall'n into a princely hand
Make your full reference freely to my lord
On all that need: let me report to him
Your sweet dependency; and you shall find
A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness
Pray you
I am his fortune's vassal
The greatness he has got. I hourly learn
A doctrine of obedience; and would gladly
Look him i' the face.
This I'll report
Have comfort
Of him that caused it.
You see how easily she may be surprised:
Here PROCULEIUS and two of the Guard ascend the  monument by a ladder placed against a window
To PROCULEIUS and the Guard
Guard her till Caesar come.
Exit
Royal queen!
O Cleopatra! thou art taken
Quick
Drawing a dagger
Hold
Seizes and disarms her
Do not yourself such wrong
Relieved
What
Cleopatra
The undoing of yourself: let the world see
His nobleness well acted
Will never let come forth.
Where art thou
Come hither
Worthy many babes and beggars!
O
Sir
If idle talk will once be necessary
Will not wait pinion'd at your master's court;
Nor once be chastised with the sober eye
Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up
And show me to the shouting varletry
Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt
Be gentle grave unto me! rather on Nilus' mud
Lay me stark naked
Blow me into abhorring! rather make
My country's high pyramides my gibbet
You do extend
These thoughts of horror further than you shall
Find cause in Caesar.
Enter DOLABELLA
Proculeius
So
To CLEOPATRA
To Caesar I will speak what you shall please
Say
Exeunt PROCULEIUS and Soldiers
Most noble empress
I cannot tell.
Assuredly you know me.
No matter
You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams;
Is't not your trick?
I understand not
I dream'd there was an Emperor Antony:
O
But such another man!
If it might please ye
His face was as the heavens; and therein stuck
A sun and moon
The little O
Most sovereign creature
His legs bestrid the ocean: his rear'd arm
Crested the world: his voice was propertied
As all the tuned spheres
But when he meant to quail and shake the orb
That grew the more by reaping: his delights
Were dolphin-like; they show'd his back above
The element they lived in: in his livery
Walk'd crowns and crownets; realms and islands were
As plates dropp'd from his pocket.
Cleopatra!
Think you there was
As this I dream'd of?
Gentle madam
You lie
But
To vie strange forms with fancy; yet
And Antony
Hear me
Your loss is as yourself
As answering to the weight: would I might never
O'ertake pursued success
My very heart at root.
I thank you
I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.
Nay
Though he be honourable
He'll lead me
Madam
Flourish
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR
Which is the Queen of Egypt?
It is the emperor
CLEOPATRA kneels
Arise
I pray you
Sir
Will have it thus; my master and my lord
I must obey.
Take to you no hard thoughts:
The record of what injuries you did us
As things but done by chance.
Sole sir o' the world
To make it clear; but do confess I have
Been laden with like frailties which before
Have often shamed our sex.
Cleopatra
If you apply yourself to our intents
A benefit in this change; but if you seek
To lay on me a cruelty
Antony's course
Of my good purposes
To that destruction which I'll guard them from
And may
Hang in what place you please. Here
You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.
This is the brief of money
Not petty things admitted. Where's Seleucus?
Here
This is my treasurer: let him speak
To myself nothing. Speak the truth
Madam
What have I kept back?
Enough to purchase what you have made known.
Nay
Your wisdom in the deed.
See
And
The ingratitude of this Seleucus does
Even make me wild: O slave
Than love that's hired! What
Go back
O rarely base!
Good queen
O Caesar
To one so meek
Parcel the sum of my disgraces by
Addition of his envy! Say
As we greet modern friends withal; and say
For Livia and Octavia
Their mediation; must I be unfolded
With one that I have bred? The gods! it smites me
Beneath the fall I have.
To SELEUCUS
Prithee
Or I shall show the cinders of my spirits
Through the ashes of my chance: wert thou a man
Forbear
Exit SELEUCUS
Be it known
For things that others do; and
Cleopatra
Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheer'd;
Make not your thoughts your prisons: no
For we intend so to dispose you as
Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed
Our care and pity is so much upon you
My master
Not so. Adieu.
Flourish. Exeunt OCTAVIUS CAESAR and his train
He words me
Be noble to myself: but
Whispers CHARMIAN
Finish
Hie thee again:
I have spoke already
Go put it to the haste.
Madam
Re-enter DOLABELLA
Where is the queen?
Behold
Exit
Dolabella!
Madam
Intends his journey; and within three days
You with your children will he send before:
Make your best use of this: I have perform'd
Your pleasure and my promise.
Dolabella
I your servant
Farewell
Exit DOLABELLA
Now
Thou
In Rome
With greasy aprons
Uplift us to the view; in their thick breaths
The gods forbid!
Nay
Will catch at us
Ballad us out o' tune: the quick comedians
Extemporally will stage us
Our Alexandrian revels; Antony
Shall be brought drunken forth
Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness
I' the posture of a whore.
O the good gods!
Nay
I'll never see 't; for
Are stronger than mine eyes.
Why
To fool their preparation
Their most absurd intents.
Re-enter CHARMIAN
Now
Show me
My best attires: I am again for Cydnus
Now
And
To play till doomsday. Bring our crown and all.
Wherefore's this noise?
Exit IRAS. A noise within
Enter a Guardsman
Here is a rural fellow
That will not be denied your highness presence:
He brings you figs.
Let him come in.
Exit Guardsman
What poor an instrument
May do a noble deed! he brings me liberty.
My resolution's placed
Of woman in me: now from head to foot
I am marble-constant; now the fleeting moon
No planet is of mine.
Re-enter Guardsman
This is the man.
Avoid
Exit Guardsman
Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there
Truly
that should desire you to touch him
is immortal; those that do die of it do seldom or
never recover.
Rememberest thou any that have died on't?
Very many
them no longer than yesterday: a very honest woman
do
biting of it
a very good report o' the worm; but he that will
believe all that they say
half that they do: but this is most fallible
worm's an odd worm.
Get thee hence; farewell.
I wish you all joy of the worm.
Setting down his basket
Farewell.
You must think this
do his kind.
Ay
Look you
keeping of wise people; for
goodness in worm.
Take thou no care; it shall be heeded.
Very good. Give it nothing
not worth the feeding.
Will it eat me?
You must not think I am so simple but I know the
devil himself will not eat a woman: I know that a
woman is a dish for the gods
not. But
gods great harm in their women; for in every ten
that they make
Well
Yes
Exit
Re-enter IRAS with a robe
Give me my robe
Immortal longings in me: now no more
The juice of Egypt's grape shall moist this lip:
Yare
Antony call; I see him rouse himself
To praise my noble act; I hear him mock
The luck of Caesar
To excuse their after wrath: husband
Now to that name my courage prove my title!
I am fire and air; my other elements
I give to baser life. So; have you done?
Come then
Farewell
Kisses them. IRAS falls and dies
Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall?
If thou and nature can so gently part
If thus thou vanishest
It is not worth leave-taking.
Dissolve
This proves me base:
If she first meet the curled Antony
Which is my heaven to have. Come
mortal wretch
With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate
Of life at once untie: poor venomous fool
Be angry
Unpolicied!
O eastern star!
Peace
Dost thou not see my baby at my breast
O
As sweet as balm
O Antony!--Nay
Applying another asp to her arm
What should I stay--
Dies
In this vile world? So
Now boast thee
A lass unparallel'd. Downy windows
And golden Phoebus never be beheld
Of eyes again so royal! Your crown's awry;
I'll mend it
Enter the Guard
Where is the queen?
Speak softly
Caesar hath sent--
Too slow a messenger.
Applies an asp
O
Approach
There's Dolabella sent from Caesar; call him.
What work is here! Charmian
It is well done
Descended of so many royal kings.
Ah
Dies
Re-enter DOLABELLA
How goes it here?
All dead.
Caesar
Touch their effects in this: thyself art coming
To see perform'd the dreaded act which thou
So sought'st to hinder.
Within  'A way there
Re-enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR and all his train marching
O sir
That you did fear is done.
Bravest at the last
I do not see them bleed.
Who was last with them?
A simple countryman
This was his basket.
Poison'd
O Caesar
I found her trimming up the diadem
On her dead mistress; tremblingly she stood
And on the sudden dropp'd.
O noble weakness!
If they had swallow'd poison
By external swelling: but she looks like sleep
In her strong toil of grace.
Here
The like is on her arm.
This is an aspic's trail: and these fig-leaves
Have slime upon them
Upon the caves of Nile.
Most probable
That so she died; for her physician tells me
She hath pursued conclusions infinite
Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed;
And bear her women from the monument:
She shall be buried by her Antony:
No grave upon the earth shall clip in it
A pair so famous. High events as these
Strike those that make them; and their story is
No less in pity than his glory which
Brought them to be lamented. Our army shall
In solemn show attend this funeral;
And then to Rome. Come
High order in this great solemnity.
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. A hall in DUKE SOLINUS'S palace.
Enter DUKE SOLINUS
Proceed
And by the doom of death end woes and all.
Merchant of Syracuse
I am not partial to infringe our laws:
The enmity and discord which of late
Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke
To merchants
Have seal'd his rigorous statutes with their bloods
For
'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us
Both by the Syracusians and ourselves
At any Syracusian marts and fairs;
Again: if any Syracusian born
Come to the bay of Ephesus
Thy substance
Therefore by law thou art condemned to die.
Yet this my comfort: when your words are done
Well
Why thou departed'st from thy native home
And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus.
A heavier task could not have been imposed
Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable:
Yet
Was wrought by nature
In Syracusa was I born
Unto a woman
With her I lived in joy; our wealth increased
By prosperous voyages I often made
To Epidamnum; till my factor's death
And the great care of goods at random left
Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse:
From whom my absence was not six months old
Before herself
The pleasing punishment that women bear
And soon and safe arrived where I was.
There had she not been long
A joyful mother of two goodly sons;
And
That very hour
Of such a burden
Those
I bought and brought up to attend my sons.
My wife
Unwilling I agreed. Alas! too soon
A league from Epidamnum had we sail'd
Gave any tragic instance of our harm:
But longer did we not retain much hope;
For what obscured light the heavens did grant
Did but convey unto our fearful minds
A doubtful warrant of immediate death;
Which though myself would gladly have embraced
And this it was
The sailors sought for safety by our boat
My wife
To him one of the other twins was bound
The children thus disposed
And floating straight
At length the sun
And by the benefit of his wished light
Two ships from far making amain to us
But ere they came
Gather the sequel by that went before.
Nay
For we may pity
O
Worthily term'd them merciless to us!
For
Which being violently borne upon
So that
What to delight in
Her part
With lesser weight but not with lesser woe
And in our sight they three were taken up
By fishermen of Corinth
At length
And
And would have reft the fishers of their prey
And therefore homeward did they bend their course.
Thus have you heard me sever'd from my bliss;
That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd
And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for
What hath befall'n of them and thee till now.
My youngest boy
After his brother: and importuned me
That his attendant--so his case was like
Might bear him company in the quest of him:
Whom whilst I labour'd of a love to see
Five summers have I spent in furthest Greece
Hopeless to find
Or that or any place that harbours men.
But here must end the story of my life;
And happy were I in my timely death
Hapless AEgeon
To bear the extremity of dire mishap!
Now
But
And passed sentence may not be recall'd
But to our honour's great disparagement
Therefore
To seek thy life by beneficial help:
Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus;
Beg thou
Gaoler
I will
Hopeless and helpless doth AEgeon wend
Exeunt
SCENE II. The Mart.
Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse
Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum
This very day a Syracusian merchant
Is apprehended for arrival here;
And not being able to buy out his life
According to the statute of the town
There is your money that I had to keep.
ANTIPHOLUS
Go bear it to the Centaur
Within this hour it will be dinner-time:
Till that
Get thee away.
Many a man would take you at your word
Exit
ANTIPHOLUS
A trusty villain
What
I am invited
I crave your pardon. Soon at five o'clock
And afterward consort you till bed-time:
My present business calls me from you now.
ANTIPHOLUS
Farewell till then: I will go lose myself
And wander up and down to view the city.
Sir
Exit
ANTIPHOLUS
He that commends me to mine own content
Commends me to the thing I cannot get.
I to the world am like a drop of water
That in the ocean seeks another drop
So I
Enter DROMIO of Ephesus
Here comes the almanac of my true date.
What now? how chance thou art return'd so soon?
Return'd so soon! rather approach'd too late:
The capon burns
My mistress made it one upon my cheek:
She is so hot because the meat is cold;
The meat is cold because you come not home;
You come not home because you have no stomach;
You have no stomach having broke your fast;
But we that know what 'tis to fast and pray
Are penitent for your default to-day.
ANTIPHOLUS
Stop in your wind
Where have you left the money that I gave you?
O
To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?
The saddler had it
ANTIPHOLUS
I am not in a sportive humour now:
Tell me
We being strangers here
So great a charge from thine own custody?
I pray you
I from my mistress come to you in post;
If I return
Methinks your maw
ANTIPHOLUS
Come
Reserve them till a merrier hour than this.
Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?
To me
ANTIPHOLUS
Come on
My charge was but to fetch you from the mart
Home to your house
My mistress and her sister stays for you.
ANTIPHOLUS
In what safe place you have bestow'd my money
That stands on tricks when I am undisposed:
Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?
I have some marks of yours upon my pate
If I should pay your worship those again
ANTIPHOLUS
Thy mistress' marks? what mistress
Your worship's wife
She that doth fast till you come home to dinner
ANTIPHOLUS
What
What mean you
Nay
Exit
ANTIPHOLUS
Upon my life
The villain is o'er-raught of all my money.
They say this town is full of cozenage
If it prove so
I'll to the Centaur
I greatly fear my money is not safe.
Exit
ACT II
SCENE I. The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.
Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA
Neither my husband nor the slave return'd
Sure
Perhaps some merchant hath invited him
Good sister
A man is master of his liberty:
Time is their master
Why should their liberty than ours be more?
Because their business still lies out o' door.
Look
O
There's none but asses will be bridled so.
Why
There's nothing situate under heaven's eye
But hath his bound
The beasts
Men
Then let your will attend on their accords.
This servitude makes you to keep unwed.
Not this
But
Ere I learn love
How if your husband start some other where?
Till he come home again
Patience unmoved! no marvel though she pause;
They can be meek that have no other cause.
A wretched soul
But were we burdened with like weight of pain
So thou
Well
Here comes your man; now is your husband nigh.
Enter DROMIO of Ephesus
Say
Nay
can witness.
Say
Ay
Beshrew his hand
Spake he so doubtfully
Nay
blows; and withal so doubtfully that I could scarce
understand them.
But say
hath great care to please his wife.
Why
Horn-mad
I mean not cuckold-mad;
But
When I desired him to come home to dinner
''Tis dinner-time
'Your meat doth burn
'Will you come home?' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he.
'Where is the thousand marks I gave thee
'The pig
'My mistress
I know not thy mistress; out on thy mistress!'
Quoth who?
Quoth my master:
'I know
So that my errand
For
Go back again
Go back again
For God's sake
Back
And he will bless that cross with other beating:
Between you I shall have a holy head.
Hence
Am I so round with you as you with me
You spurn me hence
If I last in this service
Exit
Fie
His company must do his minions grace
Hath homely age the alluring beauty took
From my poor cheek? then he hath wasted it:
Are my discourses dull? barren my wit?
If voluble and sharp discourse be marr'd
Do their gay vestments his affections bait?
That's not my fault: he's master of my state:
What ruins are in me that can be found
Of my defeatures. My decayed fair
A sunny look of his would soon repair
But
And feeds from home; poor I am but his stale.
Self-harming jealousy! fie
Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense.
I know his eye doth homage otherwhere
Sister
Would that alone
I see the jewel best enamelled
Will lose his beauty; yet the gold bides still
Wear gold: and no man that hath a name
Since that my beauty cannot please his eye
How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!
Exeunt
SCENE II. A public place.
Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse
ANTIPHOLUS
The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up
Safe at the Centaur; and the heedful slave
Is wander'd forth
By computation and mine host's report.
I could not speak with Dromio since at first
I sent him from the mart. See
Enter DROMIO of Syracuse
How now sir! is your merry humour alter'd?
As you love strokes
You know no Centaur? you received no gold?
Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?
My house was at the Phoenix? Wast thou mad
What answer
ANTIPHOLUS
Even now
I did not see you since you sent me hence
ANTIPHOLUS
Villain
For which
I am glad to see you in this merry vein:
What means this jest? I pray you
ANTIPHOLUS
Yea
Think'st thou I jest? Hold
Beating him
Hold
Upon what bargain do you give it me?
ANTIPHOLUS
Because that I familiarly sometimes
Do use you for my fool and chat with you
And make a common of my serious hours.
When the sun shines let foolish gnats make sport
If you will jest with me
Sconce call you it? so you would leave battering
had rather have it a head: an you use these blows
long
it too; or else I shall seek my wit in my shoulders.
But
ANTIPHOLUS
Dost thou not know?
Nothing
ANTIPHOLUS
Shall I tell you why?
Ay
a wherefore.
ANTIPHOLUS
Why
For urging it the second time to me.
Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season
nor reason?
Well
ANTIPHOLUS
Thank me
Marry
ANTIPHOLUS
I'll make you amends next
something. But say
No
ANTIPHOLUS
In good time
Basting.
ANTIPHOLUS
Well
If it be
ANTIPHOLUS
Your reason?
Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another
dry basting.
ANTIPHOLUS
Well
time for all things.
I durst have denied that
ANTIPHOLUS
By what rule
Marry
pate of father Time himself.
ANTIPHOLUS
Let's hear it.
There's no time for a man to recover his hair that
grows bald by nature.
ANTIPHOLUS
May he not do it by fine and recovery?
Yes
lost hair of another man.
ANTIPHOLUS
Why is Time such a niggard of hair
Because it is a blessing that he bestows on beasts;
and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath given them in wit.
ANTIPHOLUS
Why
Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his hair.
ANTIPHOLUS
Why
The plainer dealer
it in a kind of jollity.
ANTIPHOLUS
For what reason?
For two; and sound ones too.
ANTIPHOLUS
Nay
Sure ones
ANTIPHOLUS
Nay
Certain ones then.
ANTIPHOLUS
Name them.
The one
trimming; the other
drop in his porridge.
ANTIPHOLUS
You would all this time have proved there is no
time for all things.
Marry
lost by nature.
ANTIPHOLUS
But your reason was not substantial
time to recover.
Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore
to the world's end will have bald followers.
ANTIPHOLUS
I knew 'twould be a bald conclusion:
But
Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA
Ay
Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects;
I am not Adriana nor thy wife.
The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow
That never words were music to thine ear
How comes it now
Thyself I call it
Ah
For know
A drop of water in the breaking gulf
How dearly would it touch me to the quick
And that this body
Wouldst thou not spit at me and spurn at me
And hurl the name of husband in my face
And tear the stain'd skin off my harlot-brow
And from my false hand cut the wedding-ring
And break it with a deep-divorcing vow?
I know thou canst; and therefore see thou do it.
I am possess'd with an adulterate blot;
My blood is mingled with the crime of lust:
For if we too be one and thou play false
Keep then far league and truce with thy true bed;
I live unstain'd
ANTIPHOLUS
Plead you to me
In Ephesus I am but two hours old
Who
Fie
When were you wont to use my sister thus?
She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.
ANTIPHOLUS
By Dromio?
By me?
By thee; and this thou didst return from him
ANTIPHOLUS
Did you converse
What is the course and drift of your compact?
I
ANTIPHOLUS
Villain
Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.
I never spake with her in all my life.
ANTIPHOLUS
How can she thus then call us by our names
How ill agrees it with your gravity
To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave
Be it my wrong you are from me exempt
Come
Thou art an elm
If aught possess thee from me
Who
Infect thy sap and live on thy confusion.
ANTIPHOLUS
To me she speaks; she moves me for her theme:
What
Or sleep I now and think I hear all this?
What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?
Until I know this sure uncertainty
Dromio
O
This is the fairy land: O spite of spites!
We talk with goblins
If we obey them not
Why pratest thou to thyself and answer'st not?
Dromio
I am transformed
ANTIPHOLUS
I think thou art in mind
Nay
ANTIPHOLUS
Thou hast thine own form.
No
If thou art changed to aught
'Tis true; she rides me and I long for grass.
'Tis so
But I should know her as well as she knows me.
Come
Come
Husband
And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.
Sirrah
Come
ANTIPHOLUS
Am I in earth
Sleeping or waking? mad or well-advised?
Known unto these
I'll say as they say and persever so
Master
Ay; and let none enter
Come
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.
Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus
ANTIPHOLUS
Good Signior Angelo
My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours:
Say that I linger'd with you at your shop
To see the making of her carcanet
But here's a villain that would face me down
He met me on the mart
Thou drunkard
Say what you will
That you beat me at the mart
If the skin were parchment
ANTIPHOLUS
I think thou art an ass.
Marry
By the wrongs I suffer and the blows I bear.
I should kick
ANTIPHOLUS
You're sad
May answer my good will and your good welcome here.
I hold your dainties cheap
welcome dear.
ANTIPHOLUS
O
Good meat
ANTIPHOLUS
And welcome more common; for that's nothing but words.
Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.
ANTIPHOLUS
Ay
But though my cates be mean
Better cheer may you have
But
Maud
[Within]  Mome
Either get thee from the door
Dost thou conjure for wenches
for such store
What patch is made our porter? My master stays in
the street.
[Within]  Let him walk from whence he came
catch cold on's feet.
ANTIPHOLUS
Who talks within there? ho
[Within]  Right
me wherefore.
ANTIPHOLUS
Wherefore? for my dinner: I have not dined to-day.
[Within]  Nor to-day here you must not; come again
when you may.
ANTIPHOLUS
What art thou that keepest me out from the house I owe?
[Within]  The porter for this time
is Dromio.
O villain! thou hast stolen both mine office and my name.
The one ne'er got me credit
If thou hadst been Dromio to-day in my place
name for an ass.
[Within]  What a coil is there
at the gate?
Let my master in
[Within]  Faith
And so tell your master.
O Lord
Have at you with a proverb--Shall I set in my staff?
[Within]  Have at you with another; that's--When?
can you tell?
[Within]  If thy name be call'd Luce--Luce
answered him well.
Do you hear
OF EPHESUS
[Within]  I thought to have asked you.
[Within]  And you said no.
So
ANTIPHOLUS
Thou baggage
[Within]  Can you tell for whose sake?
Master
[Within]  Let him knock till it ache.
ANTIPHOLUS
You'll cry for this
[Within]  What needs all that
[Within]  Who is that at the door that keeps all
this noise?
[Within]  By my troth
unruly boys.
ANTIPHOLUS
Are you there
[Within]  Your wife
If you went in pain
Here is neither cheer
fain have either.
In debating which was best
They stand at the door
ANTIPHOLUS
There is something in the wind
You would say so
Your cake there is warm within; you stand here in the cold:
It would make a man mad as a buck
ANTIPHOLUS
Go fetch me something: I'll break ope the gate.
[Within]  Break any breaking here
knave's pate.
A man may break a word with you
[Within]  It seems thou want'st breaking: out upon
thee
Here's too much 'out upon thee!' I pray thee
[Within]  Ay
ANTIPHOLUS
Well
A crow without feather? Master
For a fish without a fin
If a crow help us in
ANTIPHOLUS
Go get thee gone; fetch me an iron crow.
Have patience
Herein you war against your reputation
And draw within the compass of suspect
The unviolated honour of your wife.
Once this
And doubt not
Why at this time the doors are made against you.
Be ruled by me: depart in patience
To know the reason of this strange restraint.
If by strong hand you offer to break in
Now in the stirring passage of the day
Against your yet ungalled estimation
That may with foul intrusion enter in
And dwell upon your grave when you are dead;
For slander lives upon succession
ANTIPHOLUS
You have prevailed: I will depart in quiet
I know a wench of excellent discourse
There will we dine. This woman that I mean
Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal:
To her will we to dinner.
To Angelo
Get you home
And fetch the chain; by this I know 'tis made:
Bring it
For there's the house: that chain will I bestow--
Be it for nothing but to spite my wife--
Upon mine hostess there: good sir
Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me
I'll meet you at that place some hour hence.
ANTIPHOLUS
Do so. This jest shall cost me some expense.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same.
Enter LUCIANA and ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse
And may it be that you have quite forgot
A husband's office? shall
Even in the spring of love
Shall love
If you did wed my sister for her wealth
Or if you like elsewhere
Muffle your false love with some show of blindness:
Let not my sister read it in your eye;
Be not thy tongue thy own shame's orator;
Look sweet
Apparel vice like virtue's harbinger;
Bear a fair presence
Teach sin the carriage of a holy saint;
Be secret-false: what need she be acquainted?
What simple thief brags of his own attaint?
'Tis double wrong
And let her read it in thy looks at board:
Shame hath a bastard fame
Ill d eeds are doubled with an evil word.
Alas
Though others have the arm
We in your motion turn and you may move us.
Then
Comfort my sister
'Tis holy sport to be a little vain
ANTIPHOLUS
Sweet mistress--what your name is else
Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not
Than our earth's wonder
Teach me
Lay open to my earthy-gross conceit
Against my soul's pure truth why labour you
To make it wander in an unknown field?
Are you a god? would you create me new?
Transform me then
But if that I am I
Your weeping sister is no wife of mine
Far more
O
Sing
Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs
He gains by death that hath such means to die:
Let Love
What
ANTIPHOLUS
Not mad
It is a fault that springeth from your eye.
ANTIPHOLUS
For gazing on your beams
Gaze where you should
ANTIPHOLUS
As good to wink
Why call you me love? call my sister so.
ANTIPHOLUS
Thy sister's sister.
That's my sister.
ANTIPHOLUS
No;
It is thyself
All this my sister is
ANTIPHOLUS
Call thyself sister
Thee will I love and with thee lead my life:
Thou hast no husband yet nor I no wife.
Give me thy hand.
O
I'll fetch my sister
Exit
Enter DROMIO of Syracuse
ANTIPHOLUS
Why
Do you know me

I am an ass

that claims me

horse; and she would have me as a beast: not that
being a beast

A very reverent body; ay
not speak of without he say 'Sir-reverence.' I have
but lean luck in the match
wondrous fat marriage.
ANTIPHOLUS

Marry
and I know not what use to put her to but to make a

warrant
Poland winter: if she lives till doomsday
ANTIPHOLUS
What complexion is she of?
Swart
clean kept: for why
shoes in the grime of it.
ANTIPHOLUS
That's a fault that water will mend.
No
ANTIPHOLUS

Nell
an ell and three quarters
hip to hip.
ANTIPHOLUS
Then she bears some breadth?
No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip:
she is spherical
countries in her.
ANTIPHOLUS
In what part of her body stands Ireland?
Marry
ANTIPHOLUS
Where Scotland?
I found it by the barrenness; hard in the palm of the hand.
ANTIPHOLUS
Where France?
In her forehead; armed and reverted
against her heir.
ANTIPHOLUS
Where England?
I looked for the chalky cliffs
whiteness in them; but I guess it stood in her chin
ANTIPHOLUS
Where Spain?
Faith
ANTIPHOLUS
Where America
Oh
rubies
aspect to the hot breath of Spain; who sent whole

Oh
drudge
Dromio; swore I was assured to her; told me what
privy marks I had about me
shoulder

And
faith and my heart of steel
me turn i' the wheel.
ANTIPHOLUS
Go hie thee presently
An if the wind blow any way from shore
If any bark put forth
If every one knows us and we know none
As from a bear a man would run for life
Exit
ANTIPHOLUS
There's none but witches do inhabit here;
And therefore 'tis high time that I were hence.
She that doth call me husband
Doth for a wife abhor. But her fair sister
But

Master Antipholus

Ay
I know it well

What please yourself
ANTIPHOLUS
Made it for me
Not once
Go home with it and please your wife withal;

ANTIPHOLUS

You are a merry man
Exit
ANTIPHOLUS
What I should think of this
But this I think
That would refuse so fair an offer'd chain.
I see a man here needs not live by shifts
I'll to the mart
If any ship put out

ACT IV
SCENE I. A public place.
Enter Second Merchant
You know since Pentecost the sum is due
Nor now I had not
To Persia
Therefore make present satisfaction
Even just the sum that I do owe to you
Is growing to me by Antipholus
He had of me a chain: at five o'clock
I shall receive the money for the same.
Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house
Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus from the courtezan's
That labour may you save: see where he comes.
ANTIPHOLUS
While I go to the goldsmith's house
And buy a rope's end: that will I bestow
Among my wife and her confederates
But
Buy thou a rope and bring it home to me.
I buy a thousand pound a year: I buy a rope.
Exit
ANTIPHOLUS
A man is well holp up that trusts to you:
I promised your presence and the chain;
But neither chain nor goldsmith came to me.
Belike you thought our love would last too long
Saving your merry humour
How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat
Which doth amount to three odd ducats more
Than I stand debted to this gentleman:
I pray you
ANTIPHOLUS
I am not furnish'd with the present money;
Besides
Good signior
And with you take the chain and bid my wife
Disburse the sum on the receipt thereof:
Perchance I will be there as soon as you.
Then you will bring the chain to her yourself?
ANTIPHOLUS
No; bear it with you
Well
ANTIPHOLUS
An if I have not
Or else you may return without your money.
Nay
Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman
ANTIPHOLUS
Good Lord! you use this dalliance to excuse
Your breach of promise to the Porpentine.
I should have chid you for not bringing it
The hour steals on; I pray you
You hear how he importunes me;--the chain!
ANTIPHOLUS
Why
Come
Either send the chain or send me by some token.
ANTIPHOLUS
Fie
My business cannot brook this dalliance.
Good sir
If not
ANTIPHOLUS
I answer you! what should I answer you?
The money that you owe me for the chain.
ANTIPHOLUS
I owe you none till I receive the chain.
You know I gave it you half an hour since.
ANTIPHOLUS
You gave me none: you wrong me much to say so.
You wrong me more
Consider how it stands upon my credit.
Well
I do; and charge you in the duke's name to obey me.
This touches me in reputation.
Either consent to pay this sum for me
Or I attach you by this officer.
ANTIPHOLUS
Consent to pay thee that I never had!
Arrest me
Here is thy fee; arrest him
I do arrest you
ANTIPHOLUS
I do obey thee till I give thee bail.
But
As all the metal in your shop will answer.
Sir
Enter DROMIO of Syracuse
Master
That stays but till her owner comes aboard
The oil
The ship is in her trim; the merry wind
Blows fair from land: they stay for nought at all
But for their owner
ANTIPHOLUS
How now! a madman! Why
A ship you sent me to
ANTIPHOLUS
Thou drunken slave
And told thee to what purpose and what end.
You sent me for a rope's end as soon:
You sent me to the bay
ANTIPHOLUS

And teach your ears to list me with more heed.
To Adriana
Give her this key
That's cover'd o'er with Turkish tapestry
Tell her I am arrested in the street
And that shall bail me; hie thee
On
Exeunt Second Merchant
To Adriana! that is where we dined
She is too big
Thither I must

SCENE II. The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.
Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA
Ah
Mightst thou perceive austerely in his eye
That he did plead in earnest? yea or no?
Look'd he or red or pale
What observation madest thou in this case
Of his heart's meteors tilting in his face?
First he denied you had in him no right.
He meant he did me none; the more my spite.
Then swore he that he was a stranger here.
And true he swore
Then pleaded I for you.
And what said he?
That love I begg'd for you he begg'd of me.
With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?
With words that in an honest suit might move.
First he did praise my beauty
Didst speak him fair?
Have patience
I cannot
My tongue
He is deformed
Vicious
Stigmatical in making
Who would be jealous then of such a one?
No evil lost is wail'd when it is gone.
Ah
Far from her nest the lapwing cries away:
My heart prays for him
Enter DROMIO of Syracuse
Here! go; the desk
How hast thou lost thy breath?
By running fast.
Where is thy master
No
A devil in an everlasting garment hath him;
One whose hard heart is button'd up with steel;
A fiend
A wolf
A back-friend
countermands
The passages of alleys
A hound that runs counter and yet draws dryfoot well;
One that before the judgement carries poor souls to hell.
Why
I do not know the matter: he is 'rested on the case.
What
I know not at whose suit he is arrested well;
But he's in a suit of buff which 'rested him
Will you send him
Go fetch it
Exit Luciana
This I wonder at
Tell me
Not on a band

What
No
It was two ere I left him
strikes one.

O
very fear.

worth
Nay

SCENE III. A public place.
Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse
ANTIPHOLUS
There's not a man I meet but doth salute me
As if I were their well-acquainted friend;
And every one doth call me by my name.
Some tender money to me; some invite me;
Some other give me thanks for kindnesses;
Some offer me commodities to buy:
Even now a tailor call'd me in his shop
And show'd me silks that he had bought for me
Sure
And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here.

Master
you got the picture of old Adam new-apparelled?

behind you
forsake your liberty.

bass-viol

Now

For forty ducats is too much to lose.

Certes

In verity you did; my bones bear witness

It is no shame: the fellow finds his vein

Alas

Mistress

Say

I did not

Dissembling villain

Dissembling harlot

That would behold in me this shameful sport.

O

Faith

the mountain of mad flesh that claims marriage of
me
turn witch.
