ACT V
SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
Enter Second Merchant and ANGELO
I am sorry
But
How is the man esteemed here in the city?
Of very reverend reputation
His word might bear my wealth at any time.
Speak softly; yonder
Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse and DROMIO of Syracuse
'Tis so; and that self chain about his neck
Which he forswore most monstrously to have.
Good sir
Signior Antipholus
That you would put me to this shame and trouble;
And
This chain which now you wear so openly:
Beside the charge
This chain you had of me; can you deny it?
ANTIPHOLUS
I think I had; I never did deny it.
Yes
ANTIPHOLUS
Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?
These ears of mine
Fie on thee
To walk where any honest man resort.
ANTIPHOLUS
Thou art a villain to impeach me thus:
I'll prove mine honour and mine honesty
Against thee presently
I dare
They draw
Enter ADRIANA
Hold
Some get within him
Bind Dromio too
Run
This is some priory. In
Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse to the Priory
Enter the Lady Abbess
Be quiet
To fetch my poor distracted husband hence.
Let us come in
And bear him home for his recovery.
I knew he was not in his perfect wits.
I am sorry now that I did draw on him.
How long hath this possession held the man?
This week he hath been heavy
But till this afternoon his passion
Ne'er brake into extremity of rage.
Hath he not lost much wealth by wreck of sea?
Buried some dear friend? Hath not else his eye
Stray'd his affection in unlawful love?
A sin prevailing much in youthful men
Which of these sorrows is he subject to?
To none of these
Namely
You should for that have reprehended him.
Why
Ay
As roughly as my modesty would let me.
Haply
And in assemblies too.
Ay
It was the copy of our conference:
In bed he slept not for my urging it;
At board he fed not for my urging it;
Alone
In company I often glanced it;
Still did I tell him it was vile and bad.
And thereof came it that the man was mad.
The venom clamours of a jealous woman
Poisons more deadly than a mad dog's tooth.
It seems his sleeps were hinder'd by thy railing
Thou say'st his meat was sauced with thy upbraidings:
Unquiet meals make ill digestions;
Thereof the raging fire of fever bred;
And what's a fever but a fit of madness?
Thou say'st his sports were hinderd by thy brawls:
Sweet recreation barr'd
But moody and dull melancholy
Of pale distemperatures and foes to life?
In food
To be disturb'd
The consequence is then thy jealous fits
Have scared thy husband from the use of wits.
She never reprehended him but mildly
Why bear you these rebukes and answer not?
She did betray me to my own reproof.
Good people enter and lay hold on him.
No
Then let your servants bring my husband forth.
Neither: he took this place for sanctuary
Till I have brought him to his wits again
I will attend my husband
And therefore let me have him home with me.
Be patient; for I will not let him stir
Till I have used the approved means I have
It is a branch and parcel of mine oath
Therefore depart and leave him here with me.
I will not hence and leave my husband here:
And ill it doth beseem your holiness
To separate the husband and the wife.
Be quiet and depart: thou shalt not have him.
Exit
Complain unto the duke of this indignity.
Come
And never rise until my tears and prayers
Have won his grace to come in person hither
And take perforce my husband from the abbess.
By this
Anon
Comes this way to the melancholy vale
Upon what cause?
To see a reverend Syracusian merchant
Against the laws and statutes of this town
See where they come: we will behold his death.
Kneel to the duke before he pass the abbey.
Enter DUKE SOLINUS
Yet once again proclaim it publicly
Justice
She is a virtuous and a reverend lady:
It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.
May it please your grace
A most outrageous fit of madness took him;
That desperately he hurried through the street
Doing displeasure to the citizens
By rushing in their houses
Rings
Once did I get him bound and sent him home
Anon
And with his mad attendant and himself
Into this abbey
And here the abbess shuts the gates on us
And will not suffer us to fetch him out
Therefore
Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help.
Long since thy husband served me in my wars
Go
And bid the lady abbess come to me.
I will determine this before I stir.
Enter a Servant
O mistress
My master and his man are both broke loose
Whose beard they have singed off with brands of fire;
And ever
Great pails of puddled mire to quench the hair:
My master preaches patience to him and the while
His man with scissors nicks him like a fool
Peace
Mistress
I have not breathed almost since I did see it.
He cries for you
Cry within
Hark
Come
Ay me
Even now we housed him in the abbey here;
And now he's there
Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
ANTIPHOLUS
Justice
Even for the service that long since I did thee
Deep scars to save thy life; even for the blood
That then I lost for thee
Unless the fear of death doth make me dote
ANTIPHOLUS
Justice
She whom thou gavest to me to be my wife
Even in the strength and height of injury!
Beyond imagination is the wrong
That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.
Discover how
ANTIPHOLUS
This day
A grievous fault! Say
No
To-day did dine together. So befall my soul
As this is false he burdens me withal!
Ne'er may I look on day
O perjured woman! They are both forsworn:
In this the madman justly chargeth them.
ANTIPHOLUS
My liege
This woman lock'd me out this day from dinner:
That goldsmith there
Who parted with me to go fetch a chain
Our dinner done
And in his company that gentleman.
There did this perjured goldsmith swear me down
That I this day of him received the chain
He did arrest me with an officer.
I did obey
For certain ducats: he with none return'd
Then fairly I bespoke the officer
To go in person with me to my house.
By the way we met
My wife
Of vile confederates. Along with them
They brought one Pinch
They fell upon me
And in a dark and dankish vault at home
There left me and my man
Till
Ran hither to your grace; whom I beseech
To give me ample satisfaction
For these deep shames and great indignities.
My lord
But had he such a chain of thee or no?
He had
Besides
Heard you confess you had the chain of him
After you first forswore it on the mart:
And thereupon I drew my sword on you;
And then you fled into this abbey here
ANTIPHOLUS
I never came within these abbey-walls
I never saw the chain
And this is false you burden me withal.
Why
I think you all have drunk of Circe's cup.
If here you housed him
If he were mad
You say he dined at home; the goldsmith here
Denies that saying. Sirrah
Sir
He did
ANTIPHOLUS
'Tis true
Saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here?
As sure
Why
I think you are all mated or stark mad.
Exit one to Abbess
Most mighty duke
Haply I see a friend will save my life
And pay the sum that may deliver me.
Speak freely
Is not your name
And is not that your bondman
Within this hour I was his bondman sir
Now am I Dromio and his man unbound.
I am sure you both of you remember me.
Ourselves we do remember
For lately we were bound
You are not Pinch's patient
Why look you strange on me? you know me well.
I never saw you in my life till now.
O
Have written strange defeatures in my face:
But tell me yet
ANTIPHOLUS
Neither.
Dromio
No
I am sure thou dost.
Ay
man denies
Not know my voice! O time's extremity
In seven short years
Knows not my feeble key of untuned cares?
Though now this grained face of mine be hid
In sap-consuming winter's drizzled snow
All these old witnesses--I cannot err--
Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.
ANTIPHOLUS
I never saw my father in my life.
But seven years since
ANTIPHOLUS
The duke and all that know me in the city
Can witness with me that it is not so
I ne'er saw Syracusa in my life.
I tell thee
Have I been patron to Antipholus
I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.
Re-enter AEMILIA
Most mighty duke
All gather to see them
I see two husbands
One of these men is Genius to the other;
And so of these. Which is the natural man
I
I
ANTIPHOLUS
AEgeon art thou not? or else his ghost?
O
Whoever bound him
And gain a husband by his liberty.
Speak
That hadst a wife once call'd AEmilia
That bore thee at a burden two fair sons:
O
If I dream not
If thou art she
That floated with thee on the fatal raft?
By men of Epidamnum he and I
And the twin Dromio all were taken up;
But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth
By force took Dromio and my son from them
And me they left with those of Epidamnum.
What then became of them I cannot tell
I to this fortune that you see me in.
Why
These two Antipholuses
Besides her urging of her wreck at sea
These are the parents to these children
Antipholus
ANTIPHOLUS
No
Stay
ANTIPHOLUS
I came from Corinth
And I with him.
ANTIPHOLUS
Brought to this town by that most famous warrior
Which of you two did dine with me to-day?
ANTIPHOLUS
I
And are not you my husband?
ANTIPHOLUS
No; I say nay to that.
ANTIPHOLUS
And so do I; yet did she call me so:
And this fair gentlewoman
To Luciana
What I told you then
If this be not a dream I see and hear.
That is the chain
ANTIPHOLUS
I think it be
ANTIPHOLUS
And you
I think I did
I sent you money
No
ANTIPHOLUS
This purse of ducats I received from you
I see we still did meet each other's man
ANTIPHOLUS
These ducats pawn I for my father here.
It shall not need; thy father hath his life.
Sir
ANTIPHOLUS
There
Renowned duke
To go with us into the abbey here
And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes:
And all that are assembled in this place
Have suffer'd wrong
Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail
Of you
My heavy burden ne'er delivered.
The duke
After so long grief
With all my heart
Exeunt all but Antipholus of Syracuse
Master
ANTIPHOLUS
Dromio
Your goods that lay at host
ANTIPHOLUS
He speaks to me. I am your master
Come
Embrace thy brother there; rejoice with him.
Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus
There is a fat friend at your master's house
She now shall be my sister
Methinks you are my glass
I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth.
Will you walk in to see their gossiping?
Not I
That's a question: how shall we try it?
We'll draw cuts for the senior: till then lead thou first.
Nay
We came into the world like brother and brother;
And now let's go hand in hand
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. Rome. A street.
Enter a company of mutinous Citizens
Before we proceed any further
Speak
You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?
Resolved. resolved.
First
We know't
Let us kill him
Is't a verdict?
No more talking on't; let it be done: away
One word
We are accounted poor citizens
What authority surfeits on would relieve us: if they
would yield us but the superfluity
wholesome
but they think we are too dear: the leanness that
afflicts us
inventory to particularise their abundance; our
sufferance is a gain to them Let us revenge this with
our pikes
speak this in hunger for bread
Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?
Against him first: he's a very dog to the commonalty.
Consider you what services he has done for his country?
Very well; and could be content to give him good
report fort
Nay
I say unto you
it to that end: though soft-conscienced men can be
content to say it was for his country he did it to
please his mother and to be partly proud; which he
is
What he cannot help in his nature
vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.
If I must not
he hath faults
Shouts within
What shouts are these? The other side o' the city
is risen: why stay we prating here? to the Capitol!
Come
Soft! who comes here?
Enter MENENIUS AGRIPPA
Worthy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always loved
the people.
He's one honest enough: would all the rest were so!
What work's
With bats and clubs? The matter? speak
Our business is not unknown to the senate; they have
had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do
suitors have strong breaths: they shall know we
have strong arms too.
Why
We cannot
I tell you
Have the patricians of you. For your wants
Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them
Against the Roman state
The way it takes
Of more strong link asunder than can ever
Appear in your impediment. For the dearth
Your knees to them
Thither where more attends you
The helms o' the state
Care for us! True
yet: suffer us to famish
crammed with grain; make edicts for usury
support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act
established against the rich
piercing statutes daily
the poor. If the wars eat us not up
there's all the love they bear us.
Either you must
Confess yourselves wondrous malicious
A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it;
But
To stale 't a little more.
Well
fob off our disgrace with a tale: but
you
There was a time when all the body's members
Rebell'd against the belly
That only like a gulf it did remain
I' the midst o' the body
Like labour with the rest
Did see and hear
Unto the appetite and affection common
Of the whole body. The belly answer'd--
Well
Sir
For
As well as speak--it tauntingly replied
To the discontented members
That envied his receipt; even so most fitly
As you malign our senators for that
They are not such as you.
Your belly's answer? What!
The kingly-crowned head
With other muniments and petty helps
In this our fabric
What then?
'Fore me
Should by the cormorant belly be restrain'd
Well
The former agents
I will tell you
If you'll bestow a small--of what you have little--
Patience awhile
Ye're long about it.
Note me this
Your most grave belly was deliberate
'True is it
Of the whole body: but
And
From me receive that natural competency
Whereby they live: and though that all at once
Ay
'Though all at once cannot
See what I do deliver out to each
From me do back receive the flour of all
It was an answer: how apply you this?
The senators of Rome are this good belly
Their counsels and their cares
Touching the weal o' the common
No public benefit which you receive
But it proceeds or comes from them to you
And no way from yourselves. What do you think
I the great toe! why the great toe?
For that
Thou rascal
But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs:
Rome and her rats are at the point of battle;
The one side must have bale.
Enter CAIUS MARCIUS
Hail
Thanks. What's the matter
We have ever your good word.
He that will give good words to thee will flatter
Beneath abhorring. What would you have
Where foxes
To make him worthy whose offence subdues him
And curse that justice did it.
Who deserves greatness
Deserves your hate; and your affections are
A sick man's appetite
Which would increase his evil. He that depends
Upon your favours swims with fins of lead
And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust Ye?
With every minute you do change a mind
You cry against the noble senate
Would feed on one another? What's their seeking?
For corn at their own rates; whereof
Hang 'em! They say!
They'll sit by the fire
What's done i' the Capitol; who's like to rise
and give out
Conjectural marriages; making parties strong
And feebling such as stand not in their liking
Below their cobbled shoes. They say there's
grain enough!
Would the nobility lay aside their ruth
With thousands of these quarter'd slaves
As I could pick my lance.
Nay
For though abundantly they lack discretion
They are dissolved: hang 'em!
They said they were an-hungry; sigh'd forth proverbs
Corn for the rich men only: with these shreds
They vented their complainings; which being answer'd
To break the heart of generosity
As they would hang them on the horns o' the moon
What is granted them?
Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms
The rabble should have first unroof'd the city
Win upon power and throw forth greater themes
For insurrection's arguing.
This is strange.
Go
Enter a Messenger
Where's Caius Marcius?
Here: what's the matter?
The news is
I am glad on 't: then we shall ha' means to vent
Our musty superfluity. See
Enter COMINIUS
Marcius
The Volsces are in arms.
They have a leader
I sin in envying his nobility
You have fought together.
Were half to half the world by the ears and he.
Upon my party
Only my wars with him: he is a lion
That I am proud to hunt.
Then
It is your former promise.
Sir
And I am constant. Titus Lartius
Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face.
What
No
I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with t'other
O
Your company to the Capitol; where
[To COMINIUS]                Lead you on.
To MARCIUS
Right worthy you priority.
Noble Marcius!
[To the Citizens]  Hence to your homes; be gone!
Nay
The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither
To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutiners
Citizens steal away. Exeunt all but SICINIUS and BRUTUS
Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?
He has no equal.
When we were chosen tribunes for the people
Mark'd you his lip and eyes?
Nay. but his taunts.
Being moved
Be-mock the modest moon.
The present wars devour him: he is grown
Too proud to be so valiant.
Such a nature
Which he treads on at noon: but I do wonder
His insolence can brook to be commanded
Under Cominius.
Fame
Better be held nor more attain'd than by
A place below the first: for what miscarries
Shall be the general's fault
To the utmost of a man
Will then cry out of Marcius 'O if he
Had borne the business!'
Besides
Of his demerits rob Cominius.
Come:
Half all Cominius' honours are to Marcius.
Though Marcius earned them not
To Marcius shall be honours
In aught he merit not.
Let's hence
How the dispatch is made
Upon this present action.
Lets along.
Exeunt
SCENE II. Corioli. The Senate-house.
Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS and certain Senators
So
And know how we proceed.
Is it not yours?
What ever have been thought on in this state
Had circumvention? 'Tis not four days gone
Since I heard thence; these are the words: I think
I have the letter here; yes
Reads
'They have press'd a power
Whether for east or west: the dearth is great;
The people mutinous; and it is rumour'd
Whither 'tis bent: most likely 'tis for you:
Consider of it.'
Our army's in the field
We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready
To answer us.
Nor did you think it folly
To keep your great pretences veil'd till when
They needs must show themselves; which
in the hatching
We shall be shorten'd in our aim
To take in many towns ere almost Rome
Should know we were afoot.
Noble Aufidius
Let us alone to guard Corioli:
If they set down before 's
Bring your army; but
They've not prepared for us.
O
I speak from certainties. Nay
If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet
Till one can do no more.
The gods assist you!
And keep your honours safe!
Farewell.
Farewell.
Farewell.
Exeunt
SCENE III. Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
"Enter VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA	they set them down on two low stools"
I pray you
more comfortable sort: if my son were my husband
should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he
won honour than in the embracements of his bed where
he would show most love. When yet he was but
tender-bodied and the only son of my womb
youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his way
for a day of kings' entreaties a mother should not
sell him an hour from her beholding
how honour would become such a person. that it was
no better than picture-like to hang by the wall
renown made it not stir
danger where he was like to find fame. To a cruel
war I sent him; from whence he returned
bound with oak. I tell thee
more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child
than now in first seeing he had proved himself a
man.
But had he died in the business
Then his good report should have been my son; I
therein would have found issue. Hear me profess
sincerely: had I a dozen sons
alike and none less dear than thine and my good
Marcius
country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.
Enter a Gentlewoman
Madam
Beseech you
Indeed
Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum
Methinks I see him stamp thus
'Come on
With his mail'd hand then wiping
Or all or lose his hire.
His bloody brow! O Jupiter
Away
Than gilt his trophy: the breasts of Hecuba
Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood
At Grecian sword
Exit Gentlewoman
Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!
He'll beat Aufidius 'head below his knee
And tread upon his neck.
Enter VALERIA
My ladies both
Sweet madam.
I am glad to see your ladyship.
How do you both? you are manifest house-keepers.
What are you sewing here? A fine spot
faith. How does your little son?
I thank your ladyship; well
He had rather see the swords
look upon his school-master.
O' my word
very pretty boy. O' my troth
Wednesday half an hour together: has such a
confirmed countenance. I saw him run after a gilded
butterfly: and when he caught it
again; and after it again; and over and over he
comes
fall enraged him
teeth and tear it; O
it!
One on 's father's moods.
Indeed
A crack
Come
the idle husewife with me this afternoon.
No
Not out of doors!
She shall
Indeed
threshold till my lord return from the wars.
Fie
I will wish her speedy strength
my prayers; but I cannot go thither.
Why
'Tis not to save labour
You would be another Penelope: yet
the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill
Ithaca full of moths. Come; I would your cambric
were sensible as your finger
pricking it for pity. Come
No
In truth
excellent news of your husband.
O
Verily
him last night.
Indeed
In earnest
Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth; against

our Roman power: your lord and Titus Lartius are set
down before their city Corioli; they nothing doubt
prevailing and to make it brief wars. This is true
Give me excuse
thing hereafter.
Let her alone
disease our better mirth.
In troth
Come
solemness out o' door. and go along with us.
No
you much mirth.
Well

SCENE IV. Before Corioli.
Enter
Yonder comes news. A wager they have met.
My horse to yours
'Tis done.
Agreed.
Say
They lie in view; but have not spoke as yet.
So
I'll buy him of you.
No
For half a hundred years. Summon the town.
How far off lie these armies?
Within this mile and half.
Then shall we hear their 'larum
Now
They sound a parley. Enter two Senators with others on the walls
Tutus Aufidius
No
Drums afar off
Hark! our drums
Are bringing forth our youth. We'll break our walls
They'll open of themselves.
Alarum afar off
Hark you. far off!
There is Aufidius; list
Amongst your cloven army.
O
Their noise be our instruction. Ladders
Enter the army of the Volsces
They fear us not
Now put your shields before your hearts
With hearts more proof than shields. Advance
They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts
He that retires I'll take him for a Volsce
Alarum. The Romans are beat back to their trenches. Re-enter MARCIUS cursing
All the contagion of the south light on you
Plaster you o'er
Further than seen and one infect another
Against the wind a mile! You souls of geese
From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell!
All hurt behind; backs red
With flight and agued fear! Mend and charge home
And make my wars on you: look to't: come on;
If you'll stand fast
Another alarum. The Volsces fly
So
'Tis for the followers fortune widens them
Enters the gates
Fool-hardiness; not I.
Nor I.
MARCIUS is shut in
See
To the pot
Alarum continues
Re-enter TITUS LARTIUS
What is become of Marcius?
Slain
Following the fliers at the very heels
O noble fellow!
Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword
A carbuncle entire
Even to Cato's wish
Only in strokes; but
The thunder-like percussion of thy sounds
Were feverous and did tremble.
Re-enter MARCIUS
Look
O
Let's fetch him off
They fight
SCENE V. Corioli. A street.
Enter certain Romans
This will I carry to Rome.
And I this.
A murrain on't! I took this for silver.
Alarum continues still afar off
Enter MARCIUS and TITUS LARTIUS with a trumpet
See here these movers that do prize their hours
At a crack'd drachm! Cushions
Bury with those that wore them
And hark
There is the man of my soul's hate
Convenient numbers to make good the city;
Whilst I
To help Cominius.
Worthy sir
Thy exercise hath been too violent for
A second course of fight.
Sir
My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well:
The blood I drop is rather physical
Than dangerous to me: to Aufidius thus
I will appear
Now the fair goddess
Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman
Thy friend no less
Than those she placeth highest! So
Thou worthiest Marcius!
Exit MARCIUS
Go
Call thither all the officers o' the town
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Near the camp of Cominius.
Enter COMINIUS
Breathe you
we are come off
Like Romans
The charges of our friends. Ye Roman gods!
Lead their successes as we wish our own
fronts encountering
Enter a Messenger
Thy news?
The citizens of Corioli have issued
I saw our party to their trenches driven
Though thou speak'st truth
How long is't since?
Above an hour
'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums:
How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour
Spies of the Volsces
Held me in chase
Three or four miles about
Who's yonder
He has the stamp of Marcius; and I have
Before-time seen him thus.
[Within]                 Come I too late?
The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabour
More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue
From every meaner man.
Enter MARCIUS
Come I too late?
Ay
O
In arms as sound as when I woo'd
As merry as when our nuptial day was done
Flower of warriors
As with a man busied about decrees:
Condemning some to death
Ransoming him
Holding Corioli in the name of Rome
Where is that slave
Which told me they had beat you to your trenches?
Where is he? call him hither.
Let him alone;
He did inform the truth: but for our gentlemen
The mouse ne'er shunn'd the cat as they did budge
From rascals worse than they.
But how prevail'd you?
Will the time serve to tell? I do not think.
Where is the enemy? are you lords o' the field?
If not
Marcius
Retire to win our purpose.
How lies their battle? know you on which side
They have placed their men of trust?
As I guess
I do beseech you
We have made to endure friends
Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates;
And that you not delay the present
Though I could wish
You were conducted to a gentle bath
And balms applied to
Deny your asking: take your choice of those
That best can aid your action.
Those are they
That most are willing. If any such be here--
As it were sin to doubt--that love this painting
Wherein you see me smear'd; if any fear
Lesser his person than an ill report;
If any think brave death outweighs bad life
And that his country's dearer than himself;
Let him alone
They all shout and wave their swords
O
If these shows be not outward
But is four Volsces? none of you but is
Able to bear against the great Aufidius
A shield as hard as his. A certain number
from all: the rest
Shall bear the business in some other fight
And four shall quickly draw out my command
March on
Make good this ostentation
Divide in all with us.
Exeunt
SCENE VII. The gates of Corioli.
TITUS LARTIUS
So
Those centuries to our aid: the rest will serve
For a short holding: if we lose the field
Fear not our care
Hence
Our guider
Exeunt
SCENE VIII. A field of battle.
Alarum as in battle. Enter
I'll fight with none but thee; for I do hate thee
Worse than a promise-breaker.
We hate alike:
Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor
More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.
Let the first budger die the other's slave
If I fly
Within these three hours
Wherein thou seest me mask'd; for thy revenge
Wrench up thy power to the highest.
Wert thou the Hector
That was the whip of your bragg'd progeny
They fight
Officious
In your condemned seconds.
Exeunt
SCENE IX. The Roman camp.
Flourish. Alarum. A retreat is sounded. Flourish.  Enter
If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work
Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles
dull tribunes
Our Rome hath such a soldier.'
Yet camest thou to a morsel of this feast
Enter TITUS LARTIUS
O general
Hadst thou beheld--
Pray now
As you have done; that's what I can; induced
As you have been; that's for my country:
He that has but effected his good will
Hath overta'en mine act.
You shall not be
The grave of your deserving; Rome must know
The value of her own: 'twere a concealment
Worse than a theft
In sign of what you are
What you have done--before our army hear me.
I have some wounds upon me
To hear themselves remember'd.
Should they not
The treasure in this field achieved and city
Your only choice.
I thank you
But cannot make my heart consent to take
A bribe to pay my sword: I do refuse it;
And stand upon my common part with those
That have beheld the doing.
A long flourish. They all cry 'Marcius! Marcius!'  cast up their caps and lances: COMINIUS and LARTIUS stand bare
May these same instruments
I' the field prove flatterers
Made all of false-faced soothing!
When steel grows soft as the parasite's silk
No more
My nose that bled
Which
You shout me forth
In acclamations hyperbolical;
As if I loved my little should be dieted
In praises sauced with lies.
Too modest are you;
More cruel to your good report than grateful
To us that give you truly: by your patience
Wears this war's garland: in token of the which
The addition nobly ever!
Flourish. Trumpets sound
Caius Marcius Coriolanus!
I will go wash;
And when my face is fair
Whether I blush or no: howbeit
I mean to stride your steed
To undercrest your good addition
To the fairness of my power.
So
Where
To Rome of our success. You
The best
I shall
The gods begin to mock me. I
Refused most princely gifts
Of my lord general.
Take't; 'tis yours. What is't?
I sometime lay here in Corioli
At a poor man's house; he used me kindly:
He cried to me; I saw him prisoner;
But then Aufidius was with in my view
To give my poor host freedom.
O
Were he the butcher of my son
Be free as is the wind. Deliver him
Marcius
By Jupiter! forgot.
I am weary; yea
Have we no wine here?
Go we to our tent:
The blood upon your visage dries; 'tis time
It should be look'd to: come.
Exeunt
SCENE X. The camp of the Volsces.
A flourish. Cornets. Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS
The town is ta'en!
'Twill be deliver'd back on good condition.
Condition!
I would I were a Roman; for I cannot
What good condition can a treaty find
I' the part that is at mercy? Five times
As often as we eat. By the elements
Hath not that honour in't it had; for where
I thought to crush him in an equal force
Or wrath or craft may get him.
He's the devil.
Bolder
With only suffering stain by him; for him
Shall fly out of itself: nor sleep nor sanctuary
Their rotten privilege and custom 'gainst
My hate to Marcius: where I find him
At home
Wash my fierce hand in's heart. Go you to the city;
Learn how 'tis held; and what they are that must
Be hostages for Rome.
Will not you go?
I am attended at the cypress grove: I pray you--
'Tis south the city mills--bring me word thither
How the world goes
I may spur on my journey.
I shall
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Rome. A public place.
Enter MENENIUS with the two Tribunes of the people
The augurer tells me we shall have news to-night.
Good or bad?
Not according to the prayer of the people
love not Marcius.
Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.
Pray you
The lamb.
Ay
noble Marcius.
He's a lamb indeed
He's a bear indeed
are old men: tell me one thing that I shall ask you.
Well
In what enormity is Marcius poor in
have not in abundance?
He's poor in no one fault
Especially in pride.
And topping all others in boasting.
This is strange now: do you two know how you are
censured here in the city
right-hand file? do you?
Why
Because you talk of pride now
Well
Why
occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience:
give your dispositions the reins
your pleasures; at the least if you take it as a
pleasure to you in being so. You blame Marcius for
being proud?
We do it not alone
I know you can do very little alone; for your helps
are many
single: your abilities are too infant-like for
doing much alone. You talk of pride: O that you
could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks
O that you could!
What then
Why
any in Rome.
Menenius
I am known to be a humorous patrician
loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying
Tiber in't; said to be something imperfect in
favouring the first complaint; hasty and tinder-like
upon too trivial motion; one that converses more
with the buttock of the night than with the forehead
of the morning: what I think I utter
malice in my breath. Meeting two such wealsmen as
you are--I cannot call you Lycurguses--if the drink
you give me touch my palate adversely
crooked face at it. I can't say your worships have
delivered the matter well
compound with the major part of your syllables: and
though I must be content to bear with those that say
you are reverend grave men
tell you you have good faces. If you see this in
the map of my microcosm
well enough too? what barm can your bisson
conspectuities glean out of this character
known well enough too?
Come
You know neither me
are ambitious for poor knaves' caps and legs: you
wear out a good wholesome forenoon in hearing a
cause between an orange wife and a fosset-seller;
and then rejourn the controversy of three pence to a
second day of audience. When you are hearing a
matter between party and party
pinched with the colic
mummers; set up the bloody flag against all
patience; and
by your hearing: all the peace you make in their
cause is
a pair of strange ones.
Come
perfecter giber for the table than a necessary
bencher in the Capitol.
Our very priests must become mockers
encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When
you speak best unto the purpose
wagging of your beards; and your beards deserve not
so honourable a grave as to stuff a botcher's
cushion
saddle. Yet you must be saying
who in a cheap estimation
since Deucalion
best of 'em were hereditary hangmen. God-den to
your worships: more of your conversation would
infect my brain
plebeians: I will be bold to take my leave of you.
BRUTUS and SICINIUS go aside
Enter VOLUMNIA
How now
your eyes so fast?
Honourable Menenius
the love of Juno
Ha! Marcius coming home!
Ay
approbation.
Take my cap
Marcius coming home!
Nay
Look
another
at home for you.
I will make my very house reel tonight: a letter for
me!
Yes
A letter for me! it gives me an estate of seven
years' health; in which time I will make a lip at
the physician: the most sovereign prescription in
Galen is but empiricutic
not wounded? he was wont to come home wounded.
O
O

victory in his pocket? the wounds become him.

Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?
Titus Lartius writes
Aufidius got off.
And 'twas time for him too
an he had stayed by him
fidiused for all the chests in Corioli

has letters from the general
son the whole name of the war: he hath in this

In troth

true purchasing.
The gods grant them true!
True! pow
True! I'll be sworn they are true.
Where is he wounded?
To the Tribunes
God save your good worships! Marcius is coming
home: he has more cause to be proud. Where is he wounded?
I' the shoulder and i' the left arm there will be
large cicatrices to show the people
stand for his place. He received in the repulse of
Tarquin seven hurts i' the body.
One i' the neck
nine that I know.
He had
wounds upon him.
Now it's twenty-seven: every gash was an enemy's grave.
A shout and flourish
Hark! the trumpets.
These are the ushers of Marcius: before him he
carries noise
Death
Which
A sennet. Trumpets sound. Enter COMINIUS the  general
Know
Within Corioli gates: where he hath won
In honour follows Coriolanus.
Welcome to Rome
Flourish
Welcome to Rome
No more of this; it does offend my heart:
Pray now
Look
O
For my prosperity!
Kneels
Nay
My gentle Marcius
By deed-achieving honour newly named
What is it?--Coriolanus must I call thee?--
But O
My gracious silence
Wouldst thou have laugh'd had I come coffin'd home
Now
And live you yet?
To VALERIA
O my sweet lady
I know not where to turn: O
And welcome
A hundred thousand welcomes. I could weep
And I could laugh
A curse begin at very root on's heart
That Rome should dote on: yet
at home that will not
Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome
We call a nettle but a nettle and
The faults of fools but folly.
Ever right.
Menenius ever
Give way there
[To VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA]  Your hand
Ere in our own house I do shade my head
From whom I have received not only greetings
I have lived
To see inherited my very wishes
And the buildings of my fancy: only
There's one thing wanting
Our Rome will cast upon thee.
Know
On
Flourish. Cornets. Exeunt in state
All tongues speak of him
Are spectacled to see him: your prattling nurse
Into a rapture lets her baby cry
While she chats him: the kitchen malkin pins
Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck
With variable complexions
In earnestness to see him: seld-shown flamens
Do press among the popular throngs and puff
To win a vulgar station: or veil'd dames
Commit the war of white and damask in
Their nicely-gawded cheeks to the wanton spoil
Of Phoebus' burning kisses: such a pother
As if that whatsoever god who leads him
Were slily crept into his human powers
And gave him graceful posture.
On the sudden
Then our office may
He cannot temperately transport his honours
From where he should begin and end
Lose those he hath won.
In that there's comfort.
Doubt not
The commoners
Upon their ancient malice will forget
With the least cause these his new honours
That he will give them make I as little question
As he is proud to do't.
I heard him swear
Appear i' the market-place nor on him put
The napless vesture of humility;
Nor showing
To the people
'Tis right.
It was his word: O
Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him
I wish no better
Than have him hold that purpose and to put it
In execution.
'Tis most like he will.
It shall be to him then as our good wills
So it must fall out
To him or our authorities. For an end
He still hath held them; that to's power he would
Have made them mules
Dispropertied their freedoms
Than camels in the war
Only for bearing burdens
For sinking under them.
This
At some time when his soaring insolence
Shall touch the people--which time shall not want
As to set dogs on sheep--will be his fire
To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze
Shall darken him for ever.
Enter a Messenger
What's the matter?
You are sent for to the Capitol. 'Tis thought
That Marcius shall be consul:
I have seen the dumb men throng to see him and
The blind to bear him speak: matrons flung gloves
A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts:
I never saw the like.
Let's to the Capitol;
And carry with us ears and eyes for the time
Have with you.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. The Capitol.
Enter two Officers
Come
for consulships?
Three
Coriolanus will carry it.
That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud
loves not the common people.
Faith
flattered the people
be many that they have loved
wherefore: so that
Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate
him manifests the true knowledge he has in their
disposition; and out of his noble carelessness lets
them plainly see't.
If he did not care whether he had their love or no
good nor harm: but he seeks their hate with greater
devotion than can render it him; and leaves
nothing undone that may fully discover him their
opposite. Now
displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he
dislikes
He hath deserved worthily of his country: and his
ascent is not by such easy degrees as those who
an into their estimation and report: but he hath so
planted his honours in their eyes
in their hearts
silent
ingrateful injury; to report otherwise
malice
reproof and rebuke from every ear that heard it.
No more of him; he is a worthy man: make way
are coming.
A sennet. Enter
Having determined of the Volsces and
To send for Titus Lartius
Hath thus stood for his country: therefore
The present consul
In our well-found successes
A little of that worthy work perform'd
By Caius Marcius Coriolanus
We met here both to thank and to remember
With honours like himself.
Speak
Leave nothing out for length
Rather our state's defective for requital
Than we to stretch it out.
To the Tribunes
Masters o' the people
We are convented
Upon a pleasing treaty
Inclinable to honour and advance
The theme of our assembly.
Which the rather
We shall be blest to do
A kinder value of the people than
He hath hereto prized them at.
That's off
I would you rather had been silent. Please you
To hear Cominius speak?
Most willingly;
But yet my caution was more pertinent
Than the rebuke you give it.
He loves your people
But tie him not to be their bedfellow.
Worthy Cominius
CORIOLANUS offers to go away
Nay
Sit
What you have nobly done.
Your horror's pardon:
I had rather have my wounds to heal again
Than hear say how I got them.
Sir
My words disbench'd you not.
No
You soothed not
your people
Pray now
I had rather have one scratch my head i' the sun
When the alarum were struck than idly sit
To hear my nothings monster'd.
Exit
Masters of the people
That's thousand to one good one--when you now see
He had rather venture all his limbs for honour
Than one on's ears to hear it? Proceed
I shall lack voice: the deeds of Coriolanus
Should not be utter'd feebly. It is held
That valour is the chiefest virtue
Most dignifies the haver: if it be
Be singly counterpoised. At sixteen years
Beyond the mark of others: our then dictator
The bristled lips before him: be bestrid
An o'er-press'd Roman and i' the consul's view
Slew three opposers: Tarquin's self he met
Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age
Man-enter'd thus
He lurch'd all swords of the garland. For this last
And by his rare example made the coward
Turn terror into sport: as weeds before
A vessel under sail
And fell below his stem: his sword
He was a thing of blood
Was timed with dying cries: alone he enter'd
The mortal gate of the city
With shunless destiny; aidless came off
Corioli like a planet: now all's his:
When
His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit
Re-quicken'd what in flesh was fatigate
Run reeking o'er the lives of men
'Twere a perpetual spoil: and till we call'd
Both field and city ours
To ease his breast with panting.
Worthy man!
He cannot but with measure fit the honours
Which we devise him.
Our spoils he kick'd at
The common muck of the world: he covets less
Than misery itself would give; rewards
His deeds with doing them
To spend the time to end it.
He's right noble:
Let him be call'd for.
Call Coriolanus.
He doth appear.
Re-enter CORIOLANUS
The senate
To make thee consul.
I do owe them still
My life and services.
It then remains
That you do speak to the people.
I do beseech you
Put on the gown
That I may pass this doing.
Sir
Must have their voices; neither will they bate
One jot of ceremony.
Put them not to't:
Pray you
Take to you
It is apart
That I shall blush in acting
Be taken from the people.
Mark you that?
To brag unto them
Show them the unaching scars which I should hide
Of their breath only!
Do not stand upon't.
We recommend to you
Wish we all joy and honour.
To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!
Flourish of cornets. Exeunt all but SICINIUS and BRUTUS
You see how he intends to use the people.
May they perceive's intent! He will require them
Should be in them to give.
Come
Of our proceedings here: on the marketplace
Exeunt

for conscience sake

O sir

My tongue to such a pace:--'Look

O me
You must not speak of that: you must desire them
To think upon you.
Think upon me! hang 'em!
I would they would forget me
Which our divines lose by 'em.

Most sweet voices!

The custom of request you have discharged:

To meet anon

There

You may

We stay here for the people.
Fare you well.

He has it now

How now

Amen
Certainly
He flouted us downright.
No
Not one amongst us

in private;
And with his hat
Your voices therefore.' When we granted that
Your most sweet voices: now you have left
your voices
Why either were you ignorant to see't
To yield your voices?
Could you not have told him
As you were lesson'd
Your liberties and the charters that you bear
I' the body of the weal; and now
A place of potency and sway o' the state
Fast foe to the plebeii
Be curses to yourselves? You should have said
That as his worthy deeds did claim no less
Than what he stood for
Would think upon you for your voices and
Translate his malice towards you into love
Thus to have said
And tried his inclination; from him pluck'd
Either his gracious promise
Or else it would have gall'd his surly nature
Tying him to aught; so putting him to rage
And pass'd him unelected.
Did you perceive
He did solicit you in free contempt
When he did need your loves
That his contempt shall not be bruising to you
No heart among you? or had you tongues to cry
Against the rectorship of judgment?
Have you
Ere now denied the asker? and now again
Of him that did not ask
Your sued-for tongues?
He's not confirm'd; we may deny him yet.
And will deny him:
I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.
I twice five hundred and their friends to piece 'em.
Get you hence instantly
Their liberties; make them of no more voice
Than dogs that are as often beat for barking
As therefore kept to do so.
Let them assemble
Your ignorant election; enforce his pride
With what contempt he wore the humble weed
The apprehension of his present portance
After the inveterate hate he bears you.
Lay
A fault on us
Cast your election on him.
Say
More after our commandment than as guided
By your own true affections
Than what you should
To voice him consul: lay the fault on us.
Ay
How youngly he began to serve his country
That Ancus Marcius
Of the same house Publius and Quintus were
And  [Censorinus
One thus descended
To be set high in place
To your remembrances: but you have found
Your sudden approbation.
Say
Harp on that still--but by our putting on;
And presently
We will so: almost all
Repent in their election.
Exeunt Citizens
Let them go on;
This mutiny were better put in hazard
If
With their refusal
The vantage of his anger.
To the Capitol
We will be there before the stream o' the people;
And this shall seem
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. Rome. A street.
Cornets. Enter CORIOLANUS
Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?
He had
Our swifter composition.
So then the Volsces stand but as at first
Upon's again.
They are worn
Their banners wave again.
Saw you Aufidius?
On safe-guard he  came to me; and did curse
Against the Volsces
Yielded the town: he is retired to Antium.
Spoke he of me?
He did
How? what?
How often he had met you
That of all things upon the earth he hated
Your person most
To hopeless restitution
Be call'd your vanquisher.
At Antium lives he?
At Antium.
I wish I had a cause to seek him there
Enter SICINIUS and BRUTUS
Behold
For they do prank them in authority
Pass no further.
Ha! what is that?
It will be dangerous to go on: no further.
What makes this change?
The matter?
Hath he not pass'd the noble and the common?
Cominius
Have I had children's voices?
Tribunes
The people are incensed against him.
Stop
Are these your herd?
Must these have voices
And straight disclaim their tongues? What are
your offices?
You being their mouths
Have you not set them on?
Be calm
It is a purposed thing
Suffer't
Nor ever will be ruled.
Call't not a plot:
The people cry you mock'd them
Scandal'd the suppliants for the people
Time-pleasers
Why
Not to them all.
Have you inform'd them sithence?
How! I inform them!
You are like to do such business.
Not unlike
Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds
Your fellow tribune.
You show too much of that
For which the people stir: if you will pass
To where you are bound
Let's be calm.
The people are abused; set on. This paltering
Becomes not Rome
Deserved this so dishonour'd rub
I' the plain way of his merit.
Tell me of corn!
This was my speech
Not now
Not in this heat
Now
For the mutable
Regard me as I do not flatter
Therein behold themselves: I say again
The cockle of rebellion
Which they have given to beggars.
Well
No more words
How! no more!
As for my country I have shed my blood
Coin words till their decay against those measles
The very way to catch them.
You speak o' the people
A man of their infirmity.
'Twere well
We let the people know't.
What
Choler!
Were I as patient as the midnight sleep
It is a mind
That shall remain a poison where it is
Shall remain!
Hear you this Triton of the minnows? mark you
His absolute 'shall'?
'Twas from the canon.
'Shall'!
O good but most unwise patricians! why
Given Hydra here to choose an officer
The horn and noise o' the monster's
To say he'll turn your current in a ditch
Then vail your ignorance; if none
Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd
Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate
His popular 'shall' against a graver bench
Than ever frown in Greece. By Jove himself!
It makes the consuls base: and my soul aches
To know
May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take
The one by the other.
Well
Whoever gave that counsel
The corn o' the storehouse gratis
Sometime in Greece
Well
Though there the people had more absolute power
The ruin of the state.
Why
One that speaks thus their voice?
I'll give my reasons
Was not our recompense
That ne'er did service for't: being press'd to the war
Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i' the war
Their mutinies and revolts
Most valour
Which they have often made against the senate
Of our so frank donation. Well
How shall this bisson multitude digest
The senate's courtesy? Let deeds express
What's like to be their words: 'we did request it;
We are the greater poll
They gave us our demands.' Thus we debase
The nature of our seats and make the rabble
Call our cares fears; which will in time
Break ope the locks o' the senate and bring in
The crows to peck the eagles.
Come
Enough
No
What may be sworn by
Insult without all reason
Of general ignorance
Real necessities
To unstable slightness: purpose so barr'd
You that will be less fearful than discreet
More than you doubt the change on't
A noble life before a long
To jump a body with a dangerous physic
That's sure of death without it
The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick
The sweet which is their poison: your dishonour
Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state
Of that integrity which should become't
Has said enough.
Has spoken like a traitor
As traitors do.
Thou wretch
What should the people do with these bald tribunes?
On whom depending
To the greater bench: in a rebellion
Manifest treason!
This a consul? no.
The aediles
Enter an AEdile
Let him be apprehended.
Go
Exit AEdile
in whose name myself
Attach thee as a traitorous innovator
Hence
Senators
Aged sir
Hence
Out of thy garments.
Help
Enter a rabble of Citizens (Plebeians)
On both sides more respect.
Here's he that would take from you all your power.
Seize him
Down with him! down with him!
Senators
They all bustle about CORIOLANUS
'Tribunes!' 'Patricians!' 'Citizens!' 'What
'Sicinius!' 'Brutus!' 'Coriolanus!' 'Citizens!'
'Peace
What is about to be? I am out of breath;
Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You
To the people! Coriolanus
Speak
Hear me
Let's hear our tribune: peace Speak
You are at point to lose your liberties:
Marcius would have all from you; Marcius
Fie
This is the way to kindle
To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.
What is the city but the people?
TRUE
By the consent of all
The people's magistrates.
You so remain.
And so are like to do.
That is the way to lay the city flat;
To bring the roof to the foundation
This deserves death.
Or let us stand to our authority
We were elected theirs
Of present death.
Therefore lay hold of him;
Bear him to the rock Tarpeian
Into destruction cast him.
AEdiles
Yield
Hear me one word;
Beseech you
Peace
[To BRUTUS]  Be that you seem
country's friend
Thus violently redress.
Sir
Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him
No
Drawing his sword
There's some among you have beheld me fighting:
Come
Down with that sword! Tribunes
Lay hands upon him.
Help Marcius
Down with him
In this mutiny
Go
All will be naught else.
Get you gone.
Stand fast;
We have as many friends as enemies.
Sham it be put to that?
The gods forbid!
I prithee
Leave us to cure this cause.
For 'tis a sore upon us
Come
I would they were barbarians--as they are
Be gone;
Put not your worthy rage into your tongue;
One time will owe another.
On fair ground
I could beat forty of them.
I could myself
Take up a brace o' the best of them; yea
two tribunes:
But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic;
And manhood is call'd foolery
Against a falling fabric. Will you hence
Like interrupted waters and o'erbear
What they are used to bear.
Pray you
I'll try whether my old wit be in request
With those that have but little: this must be patch'd
With cloth of any colour.
Nay
Exeunt CORIOLANUS
This man has marr'd his fortune.
His nature is too noble for the world:
He would not flatter Neptune for his trident
What his breast forges
And
He heard the name of death.
A noise within
Here's goodly work!
I would they were abed!
I would they were in Tiber! What the vengeance!
Could he not speak 'em fair?
Re-enter BRUTUS and SICINIUS
Where is this viper
That would depopulate the city and
Be every man himself?
You worthy tribunes
He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock
With rigorous hands: he hath resisted law
Than the severity of the public power
Which he so sets at nought.
He shall well know
The noble tribunes are the people's mouths
He shall
Sir
Peace!
Do not cry havoc
With modest warrant.
Sir
Have holp to make this rescue?
Hear me speak:
As I do know the consul's worthiness
Consul! what consul?
The consul Coriolanus.
He consul!
No
If
The which shall turn you to no further harm
Than so much loss of time.
Speak briefly then;
For we are peremptory to dispatch
This viperous traitor: to eject him hence
Were but one danger
Our certain death: therefore it is decreed
He dies to-night.
Now the good gods forbid
That our renowned Rome
Towards her deserved children is enroll'd
In Jove's own book
Should now eat up her own!
He's a disease that must be cut away.
O
Mortal
What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?
Killing our enemies
Which
And what is left
This is clean kam.
Merely awry: when he did love his country
The service of the foot
Being once gangrened
For what before it was.
We'll hear no more.
Pursue him to his house
Lest his infection
One word more
This tiger-footed rage
The harm of unscann'd swiftness
Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process;
Lest parties
If it were so
What do ye talk?
Have we not had a taste of his obedience?
Our aediles smote? ourselves resisted? Come.
Consider this: he has been bred i' the wars
Since he could draw a sword
In bolted language; meal and bran together
He throws without distinction. Give me leave
Where he shall answer
Noble tribunes
Will prove too bloody
Unknown to the beginning.
Noble Menenius
Masters
Go not home.
Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there:
Where
In our first way.
I'll bring him to you.
To the Senators
Let me desire your company: he must come
Pray you
Exeunt
SCENE II. A room in CORIOLANUS'S house.
Enter CORIOLANUS with Patricians
Let them puff all about mine ears
Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels
Below the beam of sight
Be thus to them.
You do the nobler.
I muse my mother
Does not approve me further
To call them woollen vassals
To buy and sell with groats
In congregations
To speak of peace or war.
Enter VOLUMNIA
I talk of you:
Why did you wish me milder? would you have me
False to my nature? Rather say I play
The man I am.
O
Let go.
You might have been enough the man you are
The thwartings of your dispositions
You had not show'd them how ye were disposed
Ere they lack'd power to cross you.
Let them hang.
Ay
Enter MENENIUS and Senators
Come
too rough;
You must return and mend it.
There's no remedy;
Unless
Cleave in the midst
Pray
I have a heart as little apt as yours
To better vantage.
Well said
Before he should thus stoop to the herd
The violent fit o' the time craves it as physic
For the whole state
What must I do?
Return to the tribunes.
Well
Repent what you have spoke.
For them! I cannot do it to the gods;
Must I then do't to them?
You are too absolute;
Though therein you can never be too noble
Tush
A good demand.
If it be honour in your wars to seem
The same you are not
With honour
It stands in like request?
Why force you this?
Because that now it lies you on to speak
To the people; not by your own instruction
Your tongue
Of no allowance to your bosom's truth.
Now
Than to take in a town with gentle words
The hazard of much blood.
I would dissemble with my nature where
My fortunes and my friends at stake required
I should do so in honour: I am in this
And you will rather show our general louts
How you can frown than spend a fawn upon 'em
Of what that want might ruin.
Noble lady!
Come
Of what is past.
I prithee now
And thus far having stretch'd it--here be with them--
Thy knee bussing the stones--for in such business
Action is eloquence
More learned than the ears--waving thy head
That will not hold the handling: or say to them
Hast not the soft way which
Thyself
As thou hast power and person.
This but done
For they have pardons
As words to little purpose.
Prithee now
Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf
Than flatter him in a bower. Here is Cominius.
Enter COMINIUS
I have been i' the market-place; and
You make strong party
By calmness or by absence: all's in anger.
Only fair speech.
I think 'twill serve
Can thereto frame his spirit.
He must
Prithee now
Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce?
Must I with base tongue give my noble heart
A lie that it must bear? Well
Yet
And throw't against the wind. To the market-place!
You have put me now to such a part which never
I shall discharge to the life.
Come
I prithee now
My praises made thee first a soldier
Thou hast not done before.
Well
Away
Some harlot's spirit! my throat of war be turn'd
Small as an eunuch
That babies lulls asleep! the smiles of knaves
Tent in my cheeks
The glasses of my sight! a beggar's tongue
Make motion through my lips
That hath received an alms! I will not do't
And by my body's action teach my mind
A most inherent baseness.
At thy choice
To beg of thee
Than thou of them. Come all to ruin; let
Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear
Thy dangerous stoutness
With as big heart as thou. Do as thou list
Thy valiantness was mine
Pray
Mother
Chide me no more. I'll mountebank their loves
Of all the trades in Rome. Look
Commend me to my wife. I'll return consul;
Or never trust to what my tongue can do
I' the way of flattery further.
Do your will.
Exit
Away! the tribunes do attend you: arm yourself
To answer mildly; for they are prepared
With accusations
Than are upon you yet.
The word is 'mildly.' Pray you
Let them accuse me by invention
Will answer in mine honour.
Ay
Well
Exeunt
SCENE III. The same. The Forum.
Enter SICINIUS and BRUTUS
In this point charge him home
Tyrannical power: if he evade us there
Was ne'er distributed.
Enter an AEdile
What
He's coming.
How accompanied?
With old Menenius
That always favour'd him.
Have you a catalogue
Of all the voices that we have procured
Set down by the poll?
I have; 'tis ready.
Have you collected them by tribes?
I have.
Assemble presently the people hither;
And when they bear me say 'It shall be so
I' the right and strength o' the commons
For death
If I say fine
Insisting on the old prerogative
And power i' the truth o' the cause.
I shall inform them.
And when such time they have begun to cry
Enforce the present execution
Of what we chance to sentence.
Very well.
Make them be strong and ready for this hint
Go about it.
Exit AEdile
Put him to choler straight: he hath been used
Ever to conquer
Of contradiction: being once chafed
Be rein'd again to temperance; then he speaks
What's in his heart; and that is there which looks
With us to break his neck.
Well
Enter CORIOLANUS
Calmly
Ay
Will bear the knave by the volume. The honour'd gods
Keep Rome in safety
Supplied with worthy men! plant love among 's!
Throng our large temples with the shows of peace
Amen
A noble wish.
Re-enter AEdile
Draw near
List to your tribunes. Audience: peace
First
Well
Shall I be charged no further than this present?
Must all determine here?
I do demand
To suffer lawful censure for such faults
As shall be proved upon you?
I am content.
Lo
The warlike service he has done
Upon the wounds his body bears
Like graves i' the holy churchyard.
Scratches with briers
Consider further
His rougher accents for malicious sounds
Well
What is the matter
That being pass'd for consul with full voice
You take it off again?
Answer to us.
Say
We charge you
From Rome all season'd office and to wind
Yourself into a power tyrannical;
For which you are a traitor to the people.
How! traitor!
Nay
The fires i' the lowest hell fold-in the people!
Call me their traitor! Thou injurious tribune!
Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths
Thy lying tongue both numbers
'Thou liest' unto thee with a voice as free
As I do pray the gods.
Mark you this
To the rock
Peace!
We need not put new matter to his charge:
What you have seen him do and heard him speak
Those whose great power must try him; even this
But since he hath
Served well for Rome
What do you prate of service?
I talk of that
You?
Is this the promise that you made your mother?
Know
I know no further:
Let them pronounce the steep Tarpeian death
But with a grain a day
Their mercy at the price of one fair word;
Nor cheque my courage for what they can give
For that he has
Envied against the people
To pluck away their power
Given hostile strokes
Of dreaded justice
That do distribute it; in the name o' the people
And in the power of us the tribunes
From off the rock Tarpeian never more
To enter our Rome gates: i' the people's name
It shall be so
He's banish'd
Hear me
He's sentenced; no more hearing.
Let me speak:
I have been consul
Her enemies' marks upon me. I do love
My country's good with a respect more tender
Speak that
We know your drift: speak what?
There's no more to be said
It shall be so.
It shall be so
You common cry of curs! whose breath I hate
As reek o' the rotten fens
As the dead carcasses of unburied men
That do corrupt my air
And here remain with your uncertainty!
Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts!
Your enemies
To banish your defenders; till at length
Your ignorance
Abated captives to some nation
That won you without blows! Despising
There is a world elsewhere.
Exeunt CORIOLANUS
The people's enemy is gone
Our enemy is banish'd! he is gone! Hoo! hoo!
Shouting
Go
Give him deserved vexation. Let a guard
Attend us through the city.
Come
The gods preserve our noble tribunes! Come.
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Rome. Before a gate of the city.
Enter CORIOLANUS
Come
With many heads butts me away. Nay
To say extremity was the trier of spirits;
That common chances common men could bear;
That when the sea was calm all boats alike
Show'd mastership in floating; fortune's blows
A noble cunning: you were used to load me
With precepts that would make invincible
The heart that conn'd them.
O heavens! O heavens!
Nay! prithee
Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome
What
I shall be loved when I am lack'd. Nay
Resume that spirit
Your husband so much sweat. Cominius
I'll do well yet. Thou old and true Menenius
Heart-hardening spectacles; tell these sad women
'Tis fond to wail inevitable strokes
My hazards still have been your solace: and
Believe't not lightly--though I go alone
Makes fear'd and talk'd of more than seen--your son
Will or exceed the common or be caught
With cautelous baits and practise.
My first son.
Whither wilt thou go? Take good Cominius
With thee awhile: determine on some course
That starts i' the way before thee.
O the gods!
I'll follow thee a month
Where thou shalt rest
And we of thee: so if the time thrust forth
A cause for thy repeal
O'er the vast world to seek a single man
I' the absence of the needer.
Fare ye well:
Thou hast years upon thee; and thou art too full
Of the wars' surfeits
That's yet unbruised: bring me but out at gate.
Come
My friends of noble touch
While I remain above the ground
Hear from me still
But what is like me formerly.
That's worthily
As any ear can hear. Come
If I could shake off but one seven years
From these old arms and legs
Give me thy hand: Come.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. A  street near the gate.
Enter SICINIUS
Bid them all home; he's gone
The nobility are vex'd
In his behalf.
Now we have shown our power
Than when it was a-doing.
Bid them home:
Say their great enemy is gone
Stand in their ancient strength.
Dismiss them home.
Exit AEdile
Here comes his mother.
Let's not meet her.
Why?
They say she's mad.
They have ta'en note of us: keep on your way.
Enter VOLUMNIA
O
Requite your love!
Peace
If that I could for weeping
Nay
To BRUTUS
Will you be gone?
[To SICINIUS]  You shall stay too: I would I had the power
To say so to my husband.
Are  you mankind?
Ay
Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship
To banish him that struck more blows for Rome
Than thou hast spoken words?
O blessed heavens!
More noble blows than ever thou wise words;
And for Rome's good. I'll tell thee what; yet go:
Nay
Were in Arabia
What then?
What then!
He'ld make an end of thy posterity.
Bastards and all.
Good man
Come
I would he had continued to his country
As he began
The noble knot he made.
I would he had.
'I would he had'! 'Twas you incensed the rabble:
Cats
As I can of those mysteries which heaven
Will not have earth to know.
Pray
Now
You have done a brave deed. Ere you go
As far as doth the Capitol exceed
The meanest house in Rome
This lady's husband here
Whom you have banish'd
Well
Why stay we to be baited
With one that wants her wits?
Take my prayers with you.
Exeunt Tribunes
I would the gods had nothing else to do
But to confirm my curses! Could I meet 'em
But once a-day
Of what lies heavy to't.
You have told them home;
And
Anger's my meat; I sup upon myself
Leave this faint puling and lament as I do
Fie
Exeunt
SCENE III. A highway between Rome and Antium.
Enter a Roman and a Volsce
I know you well
me: your name
It is so
I am a Roman; and my services are
Nicanor? no.
The same
You had more beard when I last saw you; but your
favour is well approved by your tongue. What's the
news in Rome? I have a note from the Volscian state
day's journey.
There hath been in Rome strange insurrections; the
people against the senators
Hath been! is it ended
so: they are in a most warlike preparation
hope to come upon them in the heat of their division.
The main blaze of it is past
would make it flame again: for the nobles receive
so to heart the banishment of that worthy
Coriolanus
all power from the people and to pluck from them
their tribunes for ever. This lies glowing
tell you
breaking out.
Coriolanus banished!
Banished
You will be welcome with this intelligence
The day serves well for them now. I have heard it
said
when she's fallen out with her husband. Your noble
Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars
great opposer
of his country.
He cannot choose. I am most fortunate
accidentally to encounter you: you have ended my
business
I shall
strange things from Rome; all tending to the good of
their adversaries. Have you an army ready
A most royal one; the centurions and their charges
I am joyful to hear of their readiness
man
So
You take my part from me
to be glad of yours.
Well
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Antium. Before Aufidius's house.
Enter CORIOLANUS in mean apparel
A goodly city is this Antium. City
Of these fair edifices 'fore my wars
Have I heard groan and drop: then know me not
In puny battle slay me.
Enter a Citizen
Save you
And you.
Direct me
He is
At his house this night.
Which is his house
This
Thank you
Exit Citizen
O world
Unseparable
To bitterest enmity: so
And interjoin their issues. So with me:
My birth-place hate I
This enemy town. I'll enter: if he slay me
Exit
SCENE V. The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

Wine
is here! I think our fellows are asleep.
Exit

Where's Cotus? my master calls
for him. Cotus!
Exit
Enter CORIOLANUS
A goodly house: the feast smells well; but I
Appear not like a guest.
Re-enter the first Servingman
What would you have
Here's no place for you: pray
Exit
I have deserved no better entertainment
Re-enter second Servingman

head; that he gives entrance to such companions?
Pray
Away!
Away! get you away.
Now thou'rt troublesome.
Are you so brave? I'll have you talked with anon.
Enter a third Servingman. The first meets him
What fellow's this?
A strange one as ever I looked on: I cannot get him
out of the house: prithee
Retires
What have you to do here
the house.
Let me but stand; I will not hurt your hearth.
What are you?
A gentleman.
A marvellous poor one.
TRUE
Pray you
station; here's no place for you; pray you
Follow your function
Pushes him away
What
strange guest he has here.

Where dwellest thou?
Under the canopy.
Under the canopy!
Ay.
Where's that?
I' the city of kites and crows.
I' the city of kites and crows! What an ass it is!
Then thou dwellest with daws too?
No
How
Ay; 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy
mistress. Thou pratest
trencher
Beats him away. Exit third Servingman
Enter AUFIDIUS with the second Servingman
Where is this fellow?
Here
disturbing the lords within.
Retires
Whence comest thou? what wouldst thou? thy name?
Why speak'st not? speak
If
Not yet thou knowest me
Think me for the man I am
Commands me name myself.
What is thy name?
A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears
Say
Thou hast a grim appearance
Bears a command in't; though thy tackle's torn.
Thou show'st a noble vessel: what's thy name?
Prepare thy brow to frown: know'st
thou me yet?
I know thee not: thy name?
My name is Caius Marcius
To thee particularly and to all the Volsces
Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may
My surname
Shed for my thankless country are requited
But with that surname; a good memory
Which thou shouldst bear me: only that name remains;
The cruelty and envy of the people
Have all forsook me
And suffer'd me by the voice of slaves to be
Whoop'd out of Rome. Now this extremity
Hath brought me to thy hearth; not out of hope--
Mistake me not--to save my life
I had fear'd death
I would have 'voided thee
A heart of wreak in thee
Thine own particular wrongs and stop those maims
Of shame seen through thy country
thee straight
That my revengeful services may prove
As benefits to thee
Against my canker'd country with the spleen
Of all the under fiends. But if so be
Thou darest not this and that to prove more fortunes
Thou'rt tired
Longer to live most weary
My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice;
Which not to cut would show thee but a fool
It be to do thee service.
O Marcius
Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart
A root of ancient envy. If Jupiter
Should from yond cloud speak divine things
Than thee
Mine arms about that body
My grained ash an hundred times hath broke
And scarr'd the moon with splinters: here I clip
The anvil of my sword
As hotly and as nobly with thy love
As ever in ambitious strength I did
Contend against thy valour. Know thou first
Sigh'd truer breath; but that I see thee here
Than when I first my wedded mistress saw
Bestride my threshold. Why
Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn
Twelve several times
Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me;
We have been down together in my sleep
Thou art thence banish'd
From twelve to seventy
Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome
Who now are here
You bless me
Therefore
The leading of thine own revenges
The one half of my commission; and set down--
As best thou art experienced
Thy country's strength and weakness
Whether to knock against the gates of Rome
Let me commend thee first to those that shall
Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes!
And more a friend than e'er an enemy;
Yet
Exeunt CORIOLANUS and AUFIDIUS. The two Servingmen come forward
Here's a strange alteration!
By my hand
a cudgel; and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a
false report of him.
What an arm he has! he turned me about with his
finger and his thumb

him: he had

He had so; looking as it were--would I were hanged

Who

Nay
greater soldier.

Ay

O slaves
What
I would not be a Roman
lieve be a condemned man.
Wherefore? wherefore?
Why
Why do you say 'thwack our general '?
I do not say 'thwack our general;' but he was always
good enough for him.
Come
hard for him; I have heard him say so himself.
He was too hard for him directly
on't: before Corioli he scotched him and notched
him like a carbon ado.
An he had been cannibally given
broiled and eaten him too.
But
Why
and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' the table; no
question asked him by any of the senators
stand bald before him: our general himself makes a

the middle and but one half of what he was
yesterday; for the other has half
and grant of the whole table. He'll go
will mow all down before him
And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine.
Do't! he will do't; for
many friends as enemies; which friends
were
we term it
Directitude! what's that?
But when they shall see
burrows
him.
But when goes this forward?
To-morrow; to-day; presently; you shall have the
