parcel of their feast
wipe their lips.
Why
This peace is nothing
tailors
Let me have war
day does night; it's spritely
full of vent. Peace is a very apoplexy
mulled
bastard children than war's a destroyer of men.
'Tis so: and as war
be a ravisher
great maker of cuckolds.
Ay
Reason; because they then less need one another.
The wars for my money. I hope to see Romans as cheap
as Volscians. They are rising
In
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Rome. A public place.
Enter SICINIUS and BRUTUS
We hear not of him
His remedies are tame i' the present peace
And quietness of the people
Were in wild hurry. Here do we make his friends
Blush that the world goes well
Dissentious numbers pestering streets than see
Our tradesmen with in their shops and going
About their functions friendly.
We stood to't in good time.
Enter MENENIUS
Is this Menenius?
'Tis he
Hail sir!
Hail to you both!
Your Coriolanus
Is not much miss'd
The commonwealth doth stand
All's well; and might have been much better
He could have temporized.
Where is he
Nay
Hear nothing from him.
Enter three or four Citizens
The gods preserve you both!
God-den
God-den to you all
Ourselves
Live
Farewell
Had loved you as we did.
Now the gods keep you!
Farewell
Exeunt Citizens
This is a happier and more comely time
Than when these fellows ran about the streets
Caius Marcius was
A worthy officer i' the war; but insolent
And affecting one sole throne
I think not so.
We should by this
The gods have well prevented it
Sits safe and still without him.
Enter an AEdile
Worthy tribunes
Are enter'd in the Roman territories
Destroy what lies before 'em.
'Tis Aufidius
Which were inshell'd when Marcius stood for Rome
Come
Of Marcius?
Go see this rumourer whipp'd. It cannot be
The Volsces dare break with us.
Cannot be!
We have record that very well it can
Within my age. But reason with the fellow
And beat the messenger who bids beware
Of what is to be dreaded.
Tell not me:
I know this cannot be.
Not possible.
Enter a Messenger
The nobles in great earnestness are going
All to the senate-house: some news is come
That turns their countenances.
'Tis this slave;--
Go whip him
Nothing but his report.
Yes
What more fearful?
It is spoke freely out of many mouths--
How probable I do not know--that Marcius
The young'st and oldest thing.
This is most likely!
Raised only
Good Marcius home again.
The very trick on't.
This is unlikely:
He and Aufidius can no more atone
Than violentest contrariety.
Enter a second Messenger
You are sent for to the senate:
A fearful army
Associated with Aufidius
Upon our territories; and have already
O'erborne their way
What lay before them.
Enter COMINIUS
O
What news? what news?
You have holp to ravish your own daughters and
To melt the city leads upon your pates
What's the news? what's the news?
Your temples burned in their cement
Your franchises
Into an auger's bore.
Pray now
You have made fair work
If Marcius should be join'd with Volscians
If!
He is their god: he leads them like a thing
Made by some other deity than nature
Than boys pursuing summer butterflies
You have made good work
on the voice of occupation and
The breath of garlic-eaters!
He will shake
Your Rome about your ears.
As Hercules
Did shake down mellow fruit.
You have made fair work!
But is this true
Ay; and you'll look pale
Before you find it other. All the regions
Do smilingly revolt; and who resist
Are mock'd for valiant ignorance
Your enemies and his find something in him.
We are all undone
The noble man have mercy.
Who shall ask it?
The tribunes cannot do't for shame; the people
Deserve such pity of him as the wolf
Does of the shepherds: for his best friends
Should say 'Be good to Rome
As those should do that had deserved his hate
'Tis true:
If he were putting to my house the brand
That should consume it
To say 'Beseech you
You have brought
A trembling upon Rome
So incapable of help.
Say not we brought it.
How! Was it we? we loved him but
And cowardly nobles
But I fear
They'll roar him in again. Tullus Aufidius
As if he were his officer: desperation
Is all the policy
Enter a troop of Citizens
Here come the clusters.
And is Aufidius with him? You are they
That made the air unwholesome
Your stinking greasy caps in hooting at
Coriolanus' exile. Now he's coming;
And not a hair upon a soldier's head
Which will not prove a whip: as many coxcombs
As you threw caps up will he tumble down
if he could burn us all into one coal
Faith
For mine own part
And so did I.
And so did I; and
many of us: that we did
though we willingly consented to his banishment
it was against our will.
Ye re goodly things
You have made
Good work
O
Exeunt COMINIUS and MENENIUS
Go
These are a side that would be glad to have
This true which they so seem to fear. Go home
The gods be good to us! Come
I ever said we were i' the wrong when we banished
him.
So did we all. But
Exeunt Citizens
I do not like this news.
Nor I.
Let's to the Capitol. Would half my wealth
Would buy this for a lie!
Pray
Exeunt
SCENE VII. A camp
Enter AUFIDIUS and his Lieutenant
Do they still fly to the Roman?
I do not know what witchcraft's in him
Your soldiers use him as the grace 'fore meat
And you are darken'd in this action
I cannot help it now
Of our design. He bears himself more proudlier
When first I did embrace him: yet his nature
In that's no changeling; and I must excuse
What cannot be amended.
Yet I wish
I mean for your particular
Join'd in commission with him; but either
Had borne the action of yourself
To him had left it solely.
I understand thee well; and be thou sure
What I can urge against him. Although it seems
To the vulgar eye
And shows good husbandry for the Volscian state
As draw his sword; yet he hath left undone
That which shall break his neck or hazard mine
Sir
All places yield to him ere he sits down;
And the nobility of Rome are his:
The senators and patricians love him too:
The tribunes are no soldiers; and their people
Will be as rash in the repeal
To expel him thence. I think he'll be to Rome
As is the osprey to the fish
By sovereignty of nature. First he was
A noble servant to them; but he could not
Carry his honours even: whether 'twas pride
The happy man; whether defect of judgment
Which he was lord of; or whether nature
From the casque to the cushion
Even with the same austerity and garb
As he controll'd the war; but one of these--
As he hath spices of them all
Lie in the interpretation of the time:
And power
To extol what it hath done.
One fire drives out one fire; one nail
Rights by rights falter
Come
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. Rome. A public place.
Enter MENENIUS
No
Which was sometime his general; who loved him
In a most dear particular. He call'd me father:
But what o' that? Go
A mile before his tent fall down
The way into his mercy: nay
To hear Cominius speak
He would not seem to know me.
Do you hear?
Yet one time he did call me by my name:
I urged our old acquaintance
That we have bled together. Coriolanus
He would not answer to: forbad all names;
He was a kind of nothing
Of burning Rome.
Why
A pair of tribunes that have rack'd for Rome
I minded him how royal 'twas to pardon
When it was less expected: he replied
To one whom they had punish'd.
Very well:
Could he say less?
I offer'd to awaken his regard
For's private friends: his answer to me was
Of noisome musty chaff: he said 'twas folly
For one poor grain or two!
I am one of those; his mother
You are the musty chaff; and you are smelt
Above the moon: we must be burnt for you.
Nay
In this so never-needed help
Upbraid's with our distress. But
Would be your country's pleader
No
Pray you
What should I do?
Only make trial what your love can do
For Rome
Well
Return me
But as a discontented friend
With his unkindness? say't be so?
Yet your good will
must have that thanks from Rome
As you intended well.
I'll undertake 't:
I think he'll hear me. Yet
And hum at good Cominius
He was not taken well; he had not dined:
The veins unfill'd
We pout upon the morning
To give or to forgive; but when we have stuff'd
These and these conveyances of our blood
With wine and feeding
Than in our priest-like fasts: therefore I'll watch him
Till he be dieted to my request
You know the very road into his kindness
Good faith
Of my success.
Exit
He'll never hear him.
Not?
I tell you
Red as 'twould burn Rome; and his injury
The gaoler to his pity. I kneel'd before him;
'Twas very faintly he said 'Rise;' dismiss'd me
Thus
So that all hope is vain.
Unless his noble mother
Who
For mercy to his country. Therefore
Exeunt
SCENE II. Entrance of the Volscian camp before Rome.
Two Sentinels on guard.
Enter to them
Stay: whence are you?
Stand
You guard like men; 'tis well: but
To speak with Coriolanus.
From whence?
From Rome.
You may not pass
Will no more hear from thence.
You'll see your Rome embraced with fire before
You'll speak with Coriolanus.
Good my friends
Be it so; go back: the virtue of your name
Is not here passable.
I tell thee
The book of his good acts
His name unparallel'd
For I have ever verified my friends
Would without lapsing suffer: nay
Have almost stamp'd the leasing: therefore
Faith
behalf as you have uttered words in your own
should not pass here; no
to lie as to live chastely. Therefore
Prithee
Howsoever you have been his liar
have
say
Has he dined
speak with him till after dinner.
You are a Roman
I am
Then you should hate Rome
defender of them
ignorance
front his revenges with the easy groans of old
women
the palsied intercession of such a decayed dotant as
you seem to be? Can you think to blow out the
intended fire your city is ready to flame in
such weak breath as this? No
therefore
execution: you are condemned
you out of reprieve and pardon.
Sirrah
use me with estimation.
Come
I mean
My general cares not for you. Back
I let forth your half-pint of blood; back
the utmost of your having: back.
Nay
Enter CORIOLANUS and AUFIDIUS
What's the matter?
Now
You shall know now that I am in estimation; you shall
perceive that a Jack guardant cannot office me from
my son Coriolanus: guess
with him
hanging
spectatorship
presently
To CORIOLANUS
The glorious gods sit in hourly synod about thy
particular prosperity
thy old father Menenius does! O my son
thou art preparing fire for us; look thee
water to quench it. I was hardly moved to come to
thee; but being assured none but myself could move
thee
sighs; and conjure thee to pardon Rome
petitionary countrymen. The good gods assuage thy
wrath
here
access to thee.
Away!
How! away!
Wife
Are servanted to others: though I owe
My revenge properly
In Volscian breasts. That we have been familiar
Than pity note how much. Therefore
Mine ears against your suits are stronger than
Your gates against my force. Yet
Gives a letter
And would have rent it. Another word
You keep a constant temper.
Exeunt CORIOLANUS and AUFIDIUS
Now
'Tis a spell
way home again.
Do you hear how we are shent for keeping your
greatness back?
What cause
I neither care for the world nor your general: for
such things as you
himself fears it not from another: let your general
do his worst. For you
your misery increase with your age! I say to you
Exit
A noble fellow
The worthy fellow is our general: he's the rock
oak not to be wind-shaken.
Exeunt
SCENE III. The tent of Coriolanus.
Enter CORIOLANUS
We will before the walls of Rome tomorrow
Set down our host. My partner in this action
I have borne this business.
Only their ends
You have respected; stopp'd your ears against
The general suit of Rome; never admitted
A private whisper
That thought them sure of you.
This last old man
Nay
Was to send him; for whose old love I have
The first conditions
And cannot now accept; to grace him only
That thought he could do more
I have yielded to: fresh embassies and suits
Will I lend ear to. Ha! what shout is this?
Shout within
Shall I be tempted to infringe my vow
In the same time 'tis made? I will not.
Enter in mourning habits
My wife comes foremost; then the honour'd mould
Wherein this trunk was framed
The grandchild to her blood. But
All bond and privilege of nature
Let it be virtuous to be obstinate.
What is that curt'sy worth? or those doves' eyes
Of stronger earth than others. My mother bows;
As if Olympus to a molehill should
In supplication nod: and my young boy
Hath an aspect of intercession
Great nature cries 'Deny not.' let the Volsces
Plough Rome and harrow Italy: I'll never
Be such a gosling to obey instinct
And knew no other kin.
My lord and husband!
These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome.
The sorrow that delivers us thus changed
Makes you think so.
Like a dull actor now
For that 'Forgive our Romans.' O
Long as my exile
Now
I carried from thee
Hath virgin'd it e'er since. You gods! I prate
Leave unsaluted: sink
Kneels
Of thy deep duty more impression show
Than that of common sons.
O
Whilst
Show duty
Between the child and parent.
Kneels
What is this?
Your knees to me? to your corrected son?
Then let the pebbles on the hungry beach
Fillip the stars; then let the mutinous winds
Strike the proud cedars 'gainst the fiery sun;
Murdering impossibility
What cannot be
Thou art my warrior;
I holp to frame thee. Do you know this lady?
The noble sister of Publicola
That's curdied by the frost from purest snow
And hangs on Dian's temple: dear Valeria!
This is a poor epitome of yours
May show like all yourself.
The god of soldiers
Thy thoughts with nobleness; that thou mayst prove
To shame unvulnerable
Like a great sea-mark
Your knee
That's my brave boy!
Even he
I beseech you
Or
The thing I have forsworn to grant may never
Be held by you denials. Do not bid me
Dismiss my soldiers
Again with Rome's mechanics: tell me not
Wherein I seem unnatural: desire not
To ally my rages and revenges with
Your colder reasons.
O
You have said you will not grant us any thing;
For we have nothing else to ask
Which you deny already: yet we will ask;
That
May hang upon your hardness: therefore hear us.
Aufidius
Hear nought from Rome in private. Your request?
Should we be silent and not speak
And state of bodies would bewray what life
We have led since thy exile. Think with thyself
How more unfortunate than all living women
Are we come hither: since that thy sight
Make our eyes flow with joy
with comforts
Making the mother
The son
His country's bowels out. And to poor we
Thine enmity's most capital: thou barr'st us
Our prayers to the gods
That all but we enjoy; for how can we
Whereto we are bound
The country
An evident calamity
Our wish
Must
With manacles thorough our streets
triumphantly tread on thy country's ruin
Thy wife and children's blood. For myself
These wars determine: if I cannot persuade thee
Rather to show a noble grace to both parts
Than seek the end of one
March to assault thy country than to tread--
Trust to't
Ay
Living to time.
A' shall not tread on me;
I'll run away till I am bigger
Not of a woman's tenderness to be
I have sat too long.
Rising
Nay
If it were so that our request did tend
To save the Romans
The Volsces whom you serve
Is that you reconcile them: while the Volsces
May say 'This mercy we have show'd;' the Romans
Give the all-hail to thee and cry 'Be blest
For making up this peace!' Thou know'st
Which thou shalt thereby reap is such a name
Whose chronicle thus writ: 'The man was noble
Destroy'd his country
To the ensuing age abhorr'd.' Speak to me
Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour
To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o' the air
That should but rive an oak. Why dost not speak?
Think'st thou it honourable for a noble man
Still to remember wrongs? Daughter
He cares not for your weeping. Speak thou
Perhaps thy childishness will move him more
Than can our reasons. There's no man in the world
More bound to 's mother; yet here he lets me prate
Like one i' the stocks. Thou hast never in thy life
Show'd thy dear mother any courtesy
To a mother's part belongs. He turns away:
Down
To his surname Coriolanus 'longs more pride
Than pity to our prayers. Down: an end;
This is the last: so we will home to Rome
This boy
But kneels and holds up bands for fellowship
Than thou hast to deny 't. Come
This fellow had a Volscian to his mother;
His wife is in Corioli and his child
Like him by chance. Yet give us our dispatch:
I am hush'd until our city be a-fire
He holds her by the hand
O mother
What have you done? Behold
They laugh at. O my mother
You have won a happy victory to Rome;
But
Aufidius
A mother less? or granted less
I was moved withal.
I dare be sworn you were:
And
Mine eyes to sweat compassion. But
[Aside]  I am glad thou hast set thy mercy and
thy honour
At difference in thee: out of that I'll work
Myself a former fortune.
The Ladies make signs to CORIOLANUS
Ay
To VOLUMNIA
But we will drink together; and you shall bear
A better witness back than words
Come
To have a temple built you: all the swords
In Italy
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Rome. A public place.
Enter MENENIUS and SICINIUS
See you yond coign o' the Capitol
corner-stone?
Why
If it be possible for you to displace it with your
little finger
Rome
But I say there is no hope in't: our throats are
sentenced and stay upon execution.
Is't possible that so short a time can alter the
condition of a man!
There is differency between a grub and a butterfly;
yet your butterfly was a grub. This Marcius is grown
from man to dragon: he has wings; he's more than a
creeping thing.
He loved his mother dearly.
So did he me: and he no more remembers his mother
now than an eight-year-old horse. The tartness
of his face sours ripe grapes: when he walks
moves like an engine
his treading: he is able to pierce a corslet with
his eye; talks like a knell
battery. He sits in his state
Alexander. What he bids be done is finished with
his bidding. He wants nothing of a god but eternity
and a heaven to throne in.
Yes
I paint him in the character. Mark what mercy his
mother shall bring from him: there is no more mercy
in him than there is milk in a male tiger; that
shall our poor city find: and all this is long of
you.
The gods be good unto us!
No
us. When we banished him
and
Enter a Messenger
Sir
The plebeians have got your fellow-tribune
And hale him up and down
The Roman ladies bring not comfort home
Enter a second Messenger
What's the news?
Good news
A merrier day did never yet greet Rome
Friend
As certain as I know the sun is fire:
Where have you lurk'd
Ne'er through an arch so hurried the blown tide
Trumpets; hautboys; drums beat; all together
The trumpets
A shout within
This is good news:
I will go meet the ladies. This Volumnia
Is worth of consuls
This morning for ten thousand of your throats
I'd not have given a doit. Hark
Music still
First
Sir
Great cause to give great thanks.
They are near the city?
Almost at point to enter.
We will meet them
Exeunt
SCENE V. The same. A street near the gate.
Enter two Senators with VOLUMNIA
Behold our patroness
Call all your tribes together
Unshout the noise that banish'd Marcius
Cry 'Welcome
Welcome
A flourish with drums and trumpets. Exeunt
SCENE VI. Antium. A public place.
Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS
Go tell the lords o' the city I am here:
Deliver them this paper: having read it
The city ports by this hath enter'd and
Intends to appear before the people
To purge herself with words: dispatch.
Exeunt Attendants
Enter three or four Conspirators of AUFIDIUS' faction
Most welcome!
How is it with our general?
Even so
As with a man by his own alms empoison'd
Most noble sir
You wish'd us parties
Of your great danger.
Sir
We must proceed as we do find the people.
The people will remain uncertain whilst
'Twixt you there's difference; but the fall of either
Makes the survivor heir of all.
I know it;
And my pretext to strike at him admits
A good construction. I raised him
Mine honour for his truth: who being so heighten'd
But to be rough
Sir
When he did stand for consul
By lack of stooping
That I would have spoke of:
Being banish'd for't
Presented to my knife his throat: I took him;
Made him joint-servant with me; gave him way
In all his own desires; nay
Out of my files
In mine own person; holp to reap the fame
Which he did end all his; and took some pride
To do myself this wrong: till
He waged me with his countenance
I had been mercenary.
So he did
The army marvell'd at it
For no less spoil than glory
There was it:
For which my sinews shall be stretch'd upon him.
At a few drops of women's rheum
As cheap as lies
Of our great action: therefore shall he die
Drums and trumpets sound
Your native town you enter'd like a post
And patient fools
With giving him glory.
Therefore
With what he would say
His reasons with his body.
Say no more:
Here come the lords.
Enter the Lords of the city
You are most welcome home.
I have not deserved it.
But
What I have written to you?
We have.
And grieve to hear't.
What faults he made before the last
Might have found easy fines: but there to end
Where he was to begin and give away
The benefit of our levies
With our own charge
There was a yielding
He approaches: you shall hear him.
Enter CORIOLANUS
Hail
Than when I parted hence
Under your great command. You are to know
That prosperously I have attempted and
With bloody passage led your wars even to
The gates of Rome. Our spoils we have brought home
Do more than counterpoise a full third part
The charges of the action. We have made peace
With no less honour to the Antiates
Than shame to the Romans: and we here deliver
We have compounded on.
Read it not
But tell the traitor
He hath abused your powers.
Traitor! how now!
Ay
Marcius!
Ay
I'll grace thee with that robbery
Coriolanus in Corioli?
You lords and heads o' the state
He has betray'd your business
Breaking his oath and resolution like
A twist of rotten silk
Counsel o' the war
He whined and roar'd away your victory
Look'd wondering each at other.
Hear'st thou
Name not the god
Ha!
No more.
Measureless liar
Too great for what contains it. Boy! O slave!
Pardon me
I was forced to scold. Your judgments
Who wears my stripes impress'd upon him; that
Must bear my beating to his grave--shall join
To thrust the lie unto him.
Peace
Cut me to pieces
If you have writ your annals true
Flutter'd your Volscians in Corioli:
Alone I did it. Boy!
Why
Let him die for't.
'Tear him to pieces.' 'Do it presently.' 'He kill'd
my son.' 'My daughter.' 'He killed my cousin
Marcus.' 'He killed my father.'
Peace
The man is noble and his fame folds-in
This orb o' the earth. His last offences to us
Shall have judicious hearing. Stand
O that I had him
Insolent villain!
Kill
The Conspirators draw
Hold
My noble masters
O Tullus
Thou hast done a deed whereat valour will weep.
Tread not upon him. Masters all
Put up your swords.
My lords
Which this man's life did owe you
That he is thus cut off. Please it your honours
To call me to your senate
Myself your loyal servant
Your heaviest censure.
Bear from hence his body;
And mourn you for him: let him be regarded
As the most noble corse that ever herald
Did follow to his urn.
His own impatience
Takes from Aufidius a great part of blame.
Let's make the best of it.
My rage is gone;
And I am struck with sorrow. Take him up.
Help
Beat thou the drum
Trail your steel pikes. Though in this city he
Hath widow'd and unchilded many a one
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. Britain. The garden of Cymbeline's palace.
Enter two Gentlemen
You do not meet a man but frowns: our bloods
No more obey the heavens than our courtiers
Still seem as does the king.
But what's the matter?
His daughter
He purposed to his wife's sole son--a widow
That late he married--hath referr'd herself
Unto a poor but worthy gentleman: she's wedded;
Her husband banish'd; she imprison'd: all
Is outward sorrow; though I think the king
Be touch'd at very heart.
None but the king?
He that hath lost her too; so is the queen
Of the king's look's
Glad at the thing they scowl at.
And why so?
He that hath miss'd the princess is a thing
Too bad for bad report: and he that hath her--
I mean
And therefore banish'd--is a creature such
As
For one his like
In him that should compare. I do not think
So fair an outward and such stuff within
Endows a man but he.
You speak him far.
I do extend him
His measure duly.
What's his name and birth?
I cannot delve him to the root: his father
Was call'd Sicilius
Against the Romans with Cassibelan
He served with glory and admired success
And had
Died with their swords in hand; for which
their father
That he quit being
As he was born. The king he takes the babe
To his protection
Could make him the receiver of; which he took
Which rare it is to do--most praised
A glass that feated them
A child that guided dotards; to his mistress
Proclaims how she esteem'd him and his virtue;
By her election may be truly read
What kind of man he is.
I honour him
Even out of your report. But
His only child.
He had two sons: if this be worth your hearing
Were stol'n
Which way they went.
How long is this ago?
Some twenty years.
That a king's children should be so convey'd
Howsoe'er 'tis strange
I do well believe you.
We must forbear: here comes the gentleman
Exeunt
Enter the QUEEN
No
Your gaoler shall deliver you the keys
That lock up your restraint. For you
The fire of rage is in him
You lean'd unto his sentence with what patience
Your wisdom may inform you.
Please your highness
You know the peril.
I'll fetch a turn about the garden
The pangs of barr'd affections
Hath charged you should not speak together.
Exit
O
Dissembling courtesy! How fine this tyrant
Can tickle where she wounds! My dearest husband
Always reserved my holy duty--what
His rage can do on me: you must be gone;
And I shall here abide the hourly shot
Of angry eyes
That I may see again.
My queen! my mistress!
O lady
To be suspected of more tenderness
Than doth become a man. I will remain
The loyal'st husband that did e'er plight troth:
My residence in Rome at one Philario's
Known but by letter: thither write
Re-enter QUEEN
Be brief
If the king come
How much of his displeasure.
Aside
Yet I'll move him
To walk this way: I never do him wrong
Pays dear for my offences.
Exit
Should we be taking leave
As long a term as yet we have to live
Nay
Were you but riding forth to air yourself
This diamond was my mother's: take it
But keep it till you woo another wife
How
You gentle gods
With bonds of death!
Putting on the ring
Remain
While sense can keep it on. And
I still win of you: for my sake wear this;
It is a manacle of love; I'll place it
Upon this fairest prisoner.
Putting a bracelet upon her arm
O the gods!
When shall we see again?
Enter CYMBELINE and Lords
Alack
Thou basest thing
If after this command thou fraught the court
With thy unworthiness
Thou'rt poison to my blood.
The gods protect you!
And bless the good remainders of the court! I am gone.
Exit
There cannot be a pinch in death
More sharp than this is.
O disloyal thing
A year's age on me.
I beseech you
I am senseless of your wrath; a touch more rare
Subdues all pangs
Past grace? obedience?
Past hope
That mightst have had the sole son of my queen!
O blest
Thou took'st a beggar; wouldst have made my throne
A seat for baseness.
No; I rather added
A lustre to it.
O thou vile one!
Sir
You bred him as my playfellow
A man worth any woman
Almost the sum he pays.
What
Almost
A neat-herd's daughter
Our neighbour shepherd's son!
Thou foolish thing!
Re-enter QUEEN
They were again together: you have done
Not after our command. Away with her
Beseech your patience. Peace
Out of your best advice.
Nay
A drop of blood a day; and
Exeunt CYMBELINE and Lords
Fie! you must give way.
Enter PISANIO
Here is your servant. How now
My lord your son drew on my master.
Ha!
No harm
There might have been
And had no help of anger: they were parted
By gentlemen at hand.
I am very glad on't.
Your son's my father's friend; he takes his part.
To draw upon an exile! O brave sir!
I would they were in Afric both together;
Myself by with a needle
The goer-back. Why came you from your master?
On his command: he would not suffer me
To bring him to the haven; left these notes
Of what commands I should be subject to
This hath been
Your faithful servant: I dare lay mine honour
He will remain so.
I humbly thank your highness.
Pray
About some half-hour hence
Go see my lord aboard: for this time leave me.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. A public place.
Enter CLOTEN and two Lords
Sir
violence of action hath made you reek as a
sacrifice: where air comes out
there's none abroad so wholesome as that you vent.
If my shirt were bloody
[Aside]  No
Hurt him! his body's a passable carcass
not hurt: it is a thoroughfare for steel
[Aside]  His steel was in debt; it went o' the
backside the town.
The villain would not stand me.
[Aside]  No; but he fled forward still
Stand you! You have land enough of your own: but
he added to your having; gave you some ground.
[Aside]  As many inches as you have oceans. Puppies!
I would they had not come between us.
[Aside]  So would I
a fool you were upon the ground.
And that she should love this fellow and refuse me!
[Aside]  If it be a sin to make a true election
is damned.
Sir
go not together: she's a good sign
small reflection of her wit.
[Aside]  She shines not upon fools
reflection should hurt her.
Come
hurt done!
[Aside]  I wish not so; unless it had been the fall
of an ass
You'll go with us?
I'll attend your lordship.
Nay
Well
Exeunt
SCENE III. A room in Cymbeline's palace.
Enter IMOGEN and PISANIO
I would thou grew'st unto the shores o' the haven
And not have it
That he spake to thee?
It was his queen
Then waved his handkerchief?
And kiss'd it
Senseless Linen! happier therein than I!
And that was all?
No
As he could make me with this eye or ear
Distinguish him from others
The deck
Could best express how slow his soul sail'd on
Thou shouldst have made him
As little as a crow
To after-eye him.
Madam
I would have broke mine eye-strings; crack'd them
To look upon him
Of space had pointed him sharp as my needle
The smallness of a gnat to air
Have turn'd mine eye and wept. But
Be assured
I did not take my leave of him
Most pretty things to say: ere I could tell him
How I would think on him at certain hours
Such thoughts and such
The shes of Italy should not betray
Mine interest and his honour
I am in heaven for him; or ere I could
Give him that parting kiss which I had set
Betwixt two charming words
And like the tyrannous breathing of the north
Shakes all our buds from growing.
Enter a Lady
The queen
Those things I bid you do
I will attend the queen.
Madam
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Rome. Philario's house.
Enter PHILARIO
Believe it
then of a crescent note
as since he hath been allowed the name of; but I
could then have looked on him without the help of
admiration
had been tabled by his side and I to peruse him by items.
You speak of him when he was less furnished than now
he is with that which makes him both without and within.
I have seen him in France: we had very many there
could behold the sun with as firm eyes as he.
This matter of marrying his king's daughter
he must be weighed rather by her value than his own
And then his banishment.
Ay
lamentable divorce under her colours are wonderfully
to extend him; be it but to fortify her judgment
taking a beggar without less quality. But how comes
it he is to sojourn with you? How creeps
acquaintance?
His father and I were soldiers together; to whom I
have been often bound for no less than my life.
Here comes the Briton: let him be so entertained
amongst you as suits
knowing
Enter POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
I beseech you all
gentleman; whom I commend to you as a noble friend
of mine: how worthy he is I will leave to appear
hereafter
Sir
Since when I have been debtor to you for courtesies
Sir
did atone my countryman and you; it had been pity
you should have been put together with so mortal a
purpose as then each bore
slight and trivial a nature.
By your pardon
rather shunned to go even with what I heard than in
my every action to be guided by others' experiences:
but upon my mended judgment--if I offend not to say
it is mended--my quarrel was not altogether slight.
'Faith
confounded one the other
Can we
Safely
It was much like an argument that fell out last
night
country mistresses; this gentleman at that time
vouching--and upon warrant of bloody
affirmation--his to be more fair
than any the rarest of our ladies in France.
That lady is not now living
opinion by this worn out.
She holds her virtue still and I my mind.
You must not so far prefer her 'fore ours of Italy.
Being so far provoked as I was in France
abate her nothing
adorer
As fair and as good--a kind of hand-in-hand
comparison--had been something too fair and too good
for any lady in Britain. If she went before others
I have seen
many I have beheld. I could not but believe she
excelled many: but I have not seen the most
precious diamond that is
I praised her as I rated her: so do I my stone.
What do you esteem it at?
More than the world enjoys.
Either your unparagoned mistress is dead
outprized by a trifle.
You are mistaken: the one may be sold
there were wealth enough for the purchase
for the gift: the other is not a thing for sale
Which the gods have given you?
Which
You may wear her in title yours: but
ring may be stolen too: so your brace of unprizable
estimations; the one is but frail and the other
casual; a cunning thief
courtier
Your Italy contains none so accomplished a courtier
to convince the honour of my mistress
holding or loss of that
nothing doubt you have store of thieves;
notwithstanding
Let us leave here
Sir
thank him
With five times so much conversation
ground of your fair mistress
to the yielding
No
I dare thereupon pawn the moiety of my estate to

something: but I make my wager rather against your
confidence than her reputation: and
offence herein too
lady in the world.
You are a great deal abused in too bold a
persuasion; and I doubt not you sustain what you're
worthy of by your attempt.
What's that?
A repulse: though your attempt
Gentlemen
let it die as it was born
better acquainted.
Would I had put my estate and my neighbour's on the
approbation of what I have spoke!
What lady would you choose to assail?
Yours; whom in constancy you think stands so safe.
I will lay you ten thousand ducats to your ring
second conference
that honour of hers which you imagine so reserved.
I will wage against your gold
I hold dear as my finger; 'tis part of it.
You are afraid
ladies' flesh at a million a dram
preserve it from tainting: but I see you have some
religion in you
This is but a custom in your tongue; you bear a
graver purpose
I am the master of my speeches
what's spoken
Will you? I shall but lend my diamond till your
return: let there be covenants drawn between's: my
mistress exceeds in goodness the hugeness of your

I will have it no lay.
By the gods
sufficient testimony that I have enjoyed the dearest

are yours; so is your diamond too: if I come off

I embrace these conditions; let us have articles

Your hand; a covenant: we will have these things set

Britain

Agreed.

Will this hold
Signior Iachimo will not from it.

SCENE V. Britain. A room in Cymbeline's palace.
Enter QUEEN
Whiles yet the dew's on ground
Make haste: who has the note of them?
I
Dispatch.
Exeunt Ladies
Now
Pleaseth your highness
Presenting a small box
But I beseech your grace
My conscience bids me ask--wherefore you have
Commanded of me those most poisonous compounds
But though slow
I wonder
Thy pupil long? Hast thou not learn'd me how
To make perfumes? distil? preserve? yea
That our great king himself doth woo me oft
For my confections? Having thus far proceeded
Unless thou think'st me devilish--is't not meet
That I did amplify my judgment in
Other conclusions? I will try the forces
Of these thy compounds on such creatures as
We count not worth the hanging
Allayments to their act
Their several virtues and effects.
Your highness
Shall from this practise but make hard your heart:
Besides
Both noisome and infectious.
O
Enter PISANIO
Aside
Here comes a flattering rascal; upon him
Will I first work: he's for his master
Doctor
Take your own way.
[Aside]          I do suspect you
But you shall do no harm.
[To PISANIO]            Hark thee
[Aside]  I do not like her. She doth think she has
Strange lingering poisons: I do know her spirit
A drug of such damn'd nature. Those she has
Will stupefy and dull the sense awhile;
Which first
cats and dogs
No danger in what show of death it makes
With a most false effect; and I the truer
No further service
I humbly take my leave.
Exit
Weeps she still
She will not quench and let instructions enter
Where folly now possesses? Do thou work:
When thou shalt bring me word she loves my son
As great as is thy master
His fortunes all lie speechless and his name
Is at last gasp: return he cannot
Continue where he is: to shift his being
Is to exchange one misery with another
A day's work in him. What shalt thou expect
The QUEEN drops the box: PISANIO takes it up
Thou takest up
Thou know'st not what; but take it for thy labour:
It is a thing I made
Five times redeem'd from death: I do not know
What is more cordial. Nay
It is an earnest of a further good
That I mean to thee. Tell thy mistress how
The case stands with her; do't as from thyself.
Think what a chance thou changest on
Thou hast thy mistress still
To any shape of thy preferment such
As thou'lt desire; and then myself
To load thy merit richly. Call my women:
Think on my words.
Exit PISANIO
A sly and constant knave
And the remembrancer of her to hold
The hand-fast to her lord. I have given him that
Which
Of liegers for her sweet
To taste of too.
Re-enter PISANIO and Ladies
So
The violets
Think on my words.
Exeunt QUEEN and Ladies
And shall do:
But when to my good lord I prove untrue
Exit
SCENE VI. The same. Another room in the palace.
Enter IMOGEN
A father cruel
A foolish suitor to a wedded lady
My supreme crown of grief! and those repeated
Vexations of it! Had I been thief-stol'n
Is the desire that's glorious: blest be those
Enter PISANIO and IACHIMO
Madam
Change you
The worthy Leonatus is in safety
And greets your highness dearly.
Presents a letter
Thanks
You're kindly welcome.
[Aside]  All of her that is out of door most rich!
If she be furnish'd with a mind so rare
Have lost the wager. Boldness be my friend!
Arm me
Or
Rather directly fly.
[Reads]  'He is one of the noblest note
kindnesses I am most infinitely tied. Reflect upon
him accordingly
LEONATUS.'
So far I read aloud:
But even the very middle of my heart
Is warm'd by the rest
You are as welcome
Have words to bid you
In all that I can do.
Thanks
What
To see this vaulted arch
Of sea and land
The fiery orbs above and the twinn'd stones
Upon the number'd beach? and can we not
Partition make with spectacles so precious
'Twixt fair and foul?
What makes your admiration?
It cannot be i' the eye
'Twixt two such shes would chatter this way and
Contemn with mows the other; nor i' the judgment
Be wisely definite; nor i' the appetite;
Sluttery to such neat excellence opposed
Should make desire vomit emptiness
What is the matter
The cloyed will
Both fill'd and running
Longs after for the garbage.
What
Thanks
To PISANIO
Beseech you
My man's abode where I did leave him: he
Is strange and peevish.
I was going
Exit
Continues well my lord? His health
Well
Is he disposed to mirth? I hope he is.
Exceeding pleasant; none a stranger there
So merry and so gamesome: he is call'd
The Briton reveller.
When he was here
Not knowing why.
I never saw him sad.
There is a Frenchman his companion
An eminent monsieur
A Gallian girl at home; he furnaces
The thick sighs from him
Your lord
By history
But must be
Assured bondage?'
Will my lord say so?
Ay
It is a recreation to be by
And hear him mock the Frenchman. But
Not he
Not he: but yet heaven's bounty towards him might
Be used more thankfully. In himself
In you
To pity too.
What do you pity
Two creatures heartily.
Am I one
You look on me: what wreck discern you in me
Deserves your pity?
Lamentable! What
I' the dungeon by a snuff?
I pray you
To my demands. Why do you pity me?
That others do--
I was about to say--enjoy your--But
It is an office of the gods to venge it
You do seem to know
Something of me
Since doubling things go ill often hurts more
Than to be sure they do; for certainties
Either are past remedies
What both you spur and stop.
Had I this cheek
To bathe my lips upon; this hand
To the oath of loyalty; this object
Takes prisoner the wild motion of mine eye
That mount the Capitol; join gripes with hands
Made hard with hourly falsehood--falsehood
With labour; then by-peeping in an eye
Base and unlustrous as the smoky light
That's fed with stinking tallow; it were fit
That all the plagues of hell should at one time
Encounter such revolt.
My lord
And himself. Not I
The beggary of his change; but 'tis your graces
That from pay mutest conscience to my tongue
Charms this report out.
Let me hear no more.
O dearest soul! your cause doth strike my heart
With pity
So fair
With tomboys hired with that self-exhibition
Which your own coffers yield! with diseased ventures
That play with all infirmities for gold
Which rottenness can lend nature! such boil'd stuff
As well might poison poison! Be revenged;
Or she that bore you was no queen
Recoil from your great stock.
Revenged!
How should I be revenged? If this be true
As I have such a heart that both mine ears
Must not in haste abuse--if it be true
Should he make me
Live
I dedicate myself to your sweet pleasure
What
Let me my service tender on your lips.
Away! I do condemn mine ears that have
So long attended thee. If thou wert honourable
For such an end thou seek'st
Thou wrong'st a gentleman
From thy report as thou from honour
Solicit'st here a lady that disdains
Thee and the devil alike. What ho
The king my father shall be made acquainted
Of thy assault: if he shall think it fit
As in a Romish stew and to expound
His beastly mind to us
He little cares for and a daughter who
He not respects at all. What
O happy Leonatus! I may say
The credit that thy lady hath of thee
Deserves thy trust
Her assured credit. Blessed live you long!
A lady to the worthiest sir that ever
Country call'd his! and you his mistress
For the most worthiest fit! Give me your pardon.
I have spoke this
Were deeply rooted; and shall make your lord
The truest manner'd; such a holy witch
That he enchants societies into him;
Half all men's hearts are his.
You make amends.
He sits 'mongst men like a descended god:
He hath a kind of honour sets him off
To try your taking a false report; which hath
Honour'd with confirmation your great judgment
In the election of a sir so rare
Made me to fan you thus
All's well
for yours.
My humble thanks. I had almost forgot
To entreat your grace but in a small request
Your lord; myself and other noble friends
Pray
Some dozen Romans of us and your lord--
The best feather of our wing--have mingled sums
To buy a present for the emperor
Which I
In France: 'tis plate of rare device
Of rich and exquisite form; their values great;
And I am something curious
To take them in protection?
Willingly;
And pawn mine honour for their safety: since
My lord hath interest in them
In my bedchamber.
They are in a trunk
To send them to you
I must aboard to-morrow.
O
Yes
By lengthening my return. From Gallia
I cross'd the seas on purpose and on promise
To see your grace.
I thank you for your pains:
But not away to-morrow!
O
Therefore I shall beseech you
To greet your lord with writing
I have outstood my time; which is material
To the tender of our present.
I will write.
Send your trunk to me; it shall safe be kept
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Britain. Before Cymbeline's palace.
Enter CLOTEN and two Lords
Was there ever man had such luck! when I kissed the
jack
hundred pound on't: and then a whoreson jackanapes
must take me up for swearing; as if I borrowed mine
oaths of him and might not spend them at my pleasure.
What got he by that? You have broke his pate with
your bowl.
[Aside]  If his wit had been like him that broke it
When a gentleman is disposed to swear
any standers-by to curtail his oaths
No my lord;
Aside
nor crop the ears of them.
Whoreson dog! I give him satisfaction?
Would he had been one of my rank!
[Aside]  To have smelt like a fool.
I am not vexed more at any thing in the earth: a
pox on't! I had rather not be so noble as I am;
they dare not fight with me
mother: every Jack-slave hath his bellyful of
fighting
nobody can match.
[Aside]  You are cock and capon too; and you crow
Sayest thou?
It is not fit your lordship should undertake every
companion that you give offence to.
No
offence to my inferiors.
Ay
Why
Did you hear of a stranger that's come to court to-night?
A stranger
[Aside]  He's a strange fellow himself
not.
There's an Italian come; and
Leonatus' friends.
Leonatus! a banished rascal; and he's another
One of your lordship's pages.
Is it fit I went to look upon him? is there no
derogation in't?
You cannot derogate
Not easily
[Aside]  You are a fool granted; therefore your
issues
Come
to-day at bowls I'll win to-night of him. Come
I'll attend your lordship.
Exeunt CLOTEN and First Lord
That such a crafty devil as is his mother
Should yield the world this ass! a woman that
Bears all down with her brain; and this her son
Cannot take two from twenty
More hateful than the foul expulsion is
Of thy dear husband
Of the divorce he'ld make! The heavens hold firm
The walls of thy dear honour
That temple
Exit
SCENE II. Imogen's bedchamber in Cymbeline's palace:
a trunk in one corner of it.
IMOGEN in bed
Who's there? my woman Helen?
Please you
What hour is it?
Almost midnight
I have read three hours then: mine eyes are weak:
Fold down the leaf where I have left: to bed:
Take not away the taper
And if thou canst awake by four o' the clock
Exit Lady
To your protection I commend me
From fairies and the tempters of the night
Guard me
Sleeps. IACHIMO comes from the trunk
The crickets sing
Repairs itself by rest. Our Tarquin thus
Did softly press the rushes
The chastity he wounded. Cytherea
But kiss; one kiss! Rubies unparagon'd
Perfumes the chamber thus: the flame o' the taper
Bows toward her
Under these windows
With blue of heaven's own tinct. But my design
Such and such pictures; there the window; such
The adornment of her bed; the arras; figures
Ah
Would testify
O sleep
And be her sense but as a monument
Taking off her bracelet
As slippery as the Gordian knot was hard!
'Tis mine; and this will witness outwardly
A mole cinque-spotted
I' the bottom of a cowslip: here's a voucher
Will force him think I have pick'd the lock and ta'en
The treasure of her honour. No more. To what end?
Why should I write this down
The tale of Tereus; here the leaf's turn'd down
Where Philomel gave up. I have enough:
To the trunk again
Swift
May bare the raven's eye! I lodge in fear;
Though this a heavenly angel
Clock strikes
One
Goes into the trunk. The scene closes
An ante-chamber adjoining Imogen's apartments.
Enter CLOTEN and Lords
Your lordship is the most patient man in loss
most coldest that ever turned up ace.
It would make any man cold to lose.
But not every man patient after the noble temper of
your lordship. You are most hot and furious when you win.
Winning will put any man into courage. If I could
get this foolish Imogen
It's almost morning
Day
I would this music would come: I am advised to give
her music o' mornings; they say it will penetrate.
Enter Musicians
Come on; tune: if you can penetrate her with your
fingering
will do
First
after
words to it: and then let her consider.
SONG
Hark
On chaliced flowers that lies;
And winking Mary-buds begin
To ope their golden eyes:
With every thing that pretty is
Arise
So
consider your music the better: if it do not
a vice in her ears
calves'-guts
boot
Exeunt Musicians
Here comes the king.
I am glad I was up so late; for that's the reason I
was up so early: he cannot choose but take this
service I have done fatherly.
Enter CYMBELINE and QUEEN
Good morrow to your majesty and to my gracious mother.
Attend you here the door of our stern daughter?
Will she not forth?
I have assailed her with music
The exile of her minion is too new;
She hath not yet forgot him: some more time
Must wear the print of his remembrance out
You are most bound to the king
Prefer you to his daughter. Frame yourself
To orderly soliciting
With aptness of the season; make denials
Increase your services; so seem as if
You were inspired to do those duties which
You tender to her; that you in all obey her
Senseless! not so.
Enter a Messenger
So like you
The one is Caius Lucius.
A worthy fellow
But that's no fault of his: we must receive him
According to the honour of his sender;
And towards himself
To employ you towards this Roman. Come
Exeunt all but CLOTEN
If she be up
Knocks
By your leave
I Know her women are about her: what
If I do line one of their hands? 'Tis gold
Which buys admittance; oft it doth; yea
Diana's rangers false themselves
Their deer to the stand o' the stealer; and 'tis gold
Which makes the true man kill'd and saves the thief;
Nay
Can it not do and undo? I will make
One of her women lawyer to me
I yet not understand the case myself.
Knocks
By your leave.
Enter a Lady
Who's there that knocks?
A gentleman.
No more?
Yes
That's more
Than some
Your lady's person: is she ready?
Ay
There is gold for you;
Sell me your good report.
How! my good name? or to report of you
What I shall think is good?--The princess!
Enter IMOGEN
Good morrow
Exit Lady
Good morrow
For purchasing but trouble; the thanks I give
Is telling you that I am poor of thanks
And scarce can spare them.
Still
If you but said so
If you swear still
That I regard it not.
This is no answer.
But that you shall not say I yield being silent
To your best kindness: one of your great knowing
Should learn
To leave you in your madness
I will not.
Fools are not mad folks.
Do you call me fool?
As I am mad
If you'll be patient
That cures us both. I am much sorry
To accuse myself--I hate you; which I had rather
You felt than make't my boast.
You sin against
Obedience
The contract you pretend with that base wretch
And though it be allow'd in meaner parties--
Yet who than he more mean?--to knit their souls
But brats and beggary
Yet you are curb'd from that enlargement by
The consequence o' the crown
The precious note of it with a base slave.
A hilding for a livery
Profane fellow
Wert thou the son of Jupiter and no more
But what thou art besides
To be his groom: thou wert dignified enough
Comparative for your virtues
The under-hangman of his kingdom
For being preferred so well.
The south-fog rot him!
He never can meet more mischance than come
To be but named of thee. His meanest garment
In my respect than all the hairs above thee
Enter PISANIO
'His garment!' Now the devil--
To Dorothy my woman hie thee presently--
'His garment!'
I am sprited with a fool.
Frighted
Search for a jewel that too casually
Hath left mine arm: it was thy master's: 'shrew me
Of any king's in Europe. I do think
I saw't this morning: confident I am
Last night 'twas on mine arm; I kiss'd it:
I hope it be not gone to tell my lord
That I kiss aught but he.
'Twill not be lost.
I hope so: go and search.
Exit PISANIO
You have abused me:
'His meanest garment!'
Ay
If you will make't an action
I will inform your father.
Your mother too:
She's my good lady
Exit
I'll be revenged:
'His meanest garment!' Well.
Exit
CYMBELINE
SCENE IV. Rome. Philario's house.
Enter POSTHUMUS and PHILARIO
Fear it not
To win the king as I am bold her honour
Will remain hers.
What means do you make to him?
Not any
That warmer days would come: in these sear'd hopes
Your very goodness and your company
O'erpays all I can do. By this
Hath heard of great Augustus: Caius Lucius
Will do's commission throughly: and I think
He'll grant the tribute
Is yet fresh in their grief.
I do believe
The legions now in Gallia sooner landed
In our not-fearing Britain than have tidings
Of any penny tribute paid. Our countrymen
Are men more order'd than when Julius Caesar
Smiled at their lack of skill
their courage
Worthy his frowning at: their discipline
To their approvers they are people such
That mend upon the world.
Enter IACHIMO
See! Iachimo!
The swiftest harts have posted you by land;
And winds of all the comers kiss'd your sails
Welcome
I hope the briefness of your answer made
The speediness of your return.
Your lady
Is one of the fairest that I have look'd upon.
And therewithal the best; or let her beauty
Look through a casement to allure false hearts
And be false with them.
Here are letters for you.
Their tenor good
'Tis very like.
Was Caius Lucius in the Britain court
When you were there?
He was expected then
All is well yet.
Sparkles this stone as it was wont? or is't not
Too dull for your good wearing?
If I had lost it
I'll make a journey twice as far
A second night of such sweet shortness which
Was mine in Britain
The stone's too hard to come by.
Not a whit
Make not
Must not continue friends.
Good sir
The knowledge of your mistress home
We were to question further: but I now
Profess myself the winner of her honour
Of her or you
By both your wills.
If you can make't apparent
That you have tasted her in bed
And ring is yours; if not
You had of her pure honour gains or loses
Your sword or mine
To who shall find them.
Sir
I will confirm with oath; which
You need it not.
Proceed.
First
Where
Had that was well worth watching--it was hang'd
With tapesty of silk and silver; the story
Proud Cleopatra
The press of boats or pride: a piece of work
So bravely done
In workmanship and value; which I wonder'd
Could be so rarely and exactly wrought
This is true;
And this you might have heard of here
More particulars
Must justify my knowledge.
So they must
The chimney
Is south the chamber
Chaste Dian bathing: never saw I figures
So likely to report themselves: the cutter
Was as another nature
This is a thing
Which you might from relation likewise reap
The roof o' the chamber
With golden cherubins is fretted: her andirons--
I had forgot them--were two winking Cupids
Of silver
Depending on their brands.
This is her honour!
Let it be granted you have seen all this--and praise
Be given to your remembrance--the description
Of what is in her chamber nothing saves
The wager you have laid.
Then
Be pale: I beg but leave to air this jewel; see!
And now 'tis up again: it must be married
To that your diamond; I'll keep them.
Jove!
Once more let me behold it: is it that
Which I left with her?
Sir--I thank her--that:
She stripp'd it from her arm; I see her yet;
Her pretty action did outsell her gift
She prized it once.
May be she pluck'd it off
To send it me.
She writes so to you
O
Gives the ring
It is a basilisk unto mine eye
Where there is beauty; truth
Of no more bondage be
O
Have patience
It may be probable she lost it; or
Who knows if one of her women
Very true;
And so
Render to me some corporal sign about her
By Jupiter
Hark you
'Tis true:--nay
She would not lose it: her attendants are
All sworn and honourable:--they induced to steal it!
And by a stranger!--No
The cognizance of her incontinency
Is this: she hath bought the name of whore
thus dearly.
There
Divide themselves between you!
Sir
This is not strong enough to be believed
Of one persuaded well of--
Never talk on't;
She hath been colted by him.
If you seek
For further satisfying
Worthy the pressing--lies a mole
Of that most delicate lodging: by my life
To feed again
This stain upon her?
Ay
Another stain
Will you hear more?
Spare your arithmetic: never count the turns;
Once
I'll be sworn--
No swearing.
If you will swear you have not done't
And I will kill thee
Thou'st made me cuckold.
I'll deny nothing.
O
I will go there and do't
Her father. I'll do something--
Exit
Quite besides
The government of patience! You have won:
Let's follow him
He hath against himself.
With an my heart.
Exeunt
SCENE V. Another room in Philario's house.
Enter POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
Is there no way for men to be but women
Must be half-workers? We are all bastards;
And that most venerable man which I
Did call my father
When I was stamp'd; some coiner with his tools
Made me a counterfeit: yet my mother seem'd
The Dian of that time so doth my wife
The nonpareil of this. O
Me of my lawful pleasure she restrain'd
And pray'd me oft forbearance; did it with
A pudency so rosy the sweet view on't
Might well have warm'd old Saturn; that I thought her
As chaste as unsunn'd snow. O
This yellow Iachimo
Or less
But what he look'd for should oppose and she
Should from encounter guard. Could I find out
The woman's part in me! For there's no motion
That tends to vice in man
It is the woman's part: be it lying
Lust and rank thoughts
Ambitions
For even to vice
They are not constant but are changing still
One vice
Not half so old as that. I'll write against them
In a true hate
The very devils cannot plague them better.
Exit
ACT III
SCENE I. Britain. A hall in Cymbeline's palace.
Enter in state
Now say
When Julius Caesar
Lives in men's eyes and will to ears and tongues
Be theme and hearing ever
And conquer'd it
Famous in Caesar's praises
Than in his feats deserving it--for him
And his succession granted Rome a tribute
Is left untender'd.
And
There be many Caesars
A world by itself; and we will nothing pay
For wearing our own noses.
That opportunity
Which then they had to take from 's
We have again. Remember
The natural bravery of your isle
As Neptune's park
With rocks unscalable and roaring waters
Caesar made here; but made not here his brag
Of 'Came' and 'saw' and 'overcame: ' with shame--
That first that ever touch'd him--he was carried
From off our coast
Poor ignorant baubles!-- upon our terrible seas
As easily 'gainst our rocks: for joy whereof
The famed Cassibelan
O giglot fortune!--to master Caesar's sword
And Britons strut with courage.
Come
kingdom is stronger than it was at that time; and
them may have crook'd noses
straight arms
Son
We have yet many among us can gripe as hard as
Cassibelan: I do not say I am one; but I have a
hand. Why tribute? why should we pay tribute? If
Caesar can hide the sun from us with a blanket
put the moon in his pocket
for light; else
You must know
This tribute from us
Caesar's ambition
The sides o' the world
Did put the yoke upon 's; which to shake off
Becomes a warlike people
Ourselves to be.
We do.
Say
Ordain'd our laws
Hath too much mangled; whose repair and franchise
Shall
His brows within a golden crown and call'd
Himself a king.
I am sorry
Caesar
Thyself domestic officers--thine enemy:
Receive it from me
In Caesar's name pronounce I 'gainst thee: look
For fury not to be resisted. Thus defied
Thou art welcome
Thy Caesar knighted me; my youth I spent
Much under him; of him I gather'd honour;
Which he to seek of me again
That the Pannonians and Dalmatians for
Their liberties are now in arms; a precedent
Which not to read would show the Britons cold:
So Caesar shall not find them.
Let proof speak.
His majesty bids you welcome. Make
pastime with us a day or two
you seek us afterwards in other terms
shall find us in our salt-water girdle: if you
beat us out of it
the adventure
for you; and there's an end.
So
I know your master's pleasure and he mine:
All the remain is 'Welcome!'
Exeunt
SCENE II. Another room in the palace.
Enter PISANIO
How? of adultery? Wherefore write you not
What monster's her accuser? Leonatus
Is fall'n into thy ear! What false Italian
On thy too ready hearing? Disloyal! No:
She's punish'd for her truth
As would take in some virtue. O my master!
Thy mind to her is now as low as were
Thy fortunes. How! that I should murder her?
Upon the love and truth and vows which I
Have made to thy command? I
If it be so to do good service
Let me be counted serviceable. How look I
so much as this fact comes to?
Reading
'Do't: the letter
that I have sent her
Shall give thee opportunity.' O damn'd paper!
Black as the ink that's on thee! Senseless bauble
So virgin-like without? Lo
I am ignorant in what I am commanded.
Enter IMOGEN
How now
Madam
Who? thy lord? that is my lord
O
That knew the stars as I his characters;
He'ld lay the future open. You good gods
That we two are asunder; let that grieve him:
Some griefs are med'cinable; that is one of them
You bees that make these locks of counsel! Lovers
And men in dangerous bonds pray not alike:
Though forfeiters you cast in prison
You clasp young Cupid's tables. Good news
Reads
'Justice
in his dominion
you
with your eyes. Take notice that I am in Cambria
this advise you
happiness
O
He is at Milford-Haven: read
How far 'tis thither. If one of mean affairs
May plod it in a week
Glide thither in a day? Then
Who long'st
let me bate
For mine's beyond beyond--say
Love's counsellor should fill the bores of hearing
To this same blessed Milford: and by the way
Tell me how Wales was made so happy as
To inherit such a haven: but first of all
That we shall make in time
And our return
Why should excuse be born or e'er begot?
We'll talk of that hereafter. Prithee
'Twixt hour and hour?
One score 'twixt sun and sun
Aside
and too much too.
Why
riding wagers
That run i' the clock's behalf. But this is foolery:
Go bid my woman feign a sickness; say
She'll home to her father: and provide me presently
A riding-suit
A franklin's housewife.
Madam
I see before me
Do as I bid thee: there's no more to say
Exeunt
SCENE III. Wales: a mountainous country with a cave.
Enter
A goodly day not to keep house
Whose roof's as low as ours! Stoop
Instructs you how to adore the heavens and bows you
To a morning's holy office: the gates of monarchs
Are arch'd so high that giants may jet through
And keep their impious turbans on
Good morrow to the sun. Hail
We house i' the rock
As prouder livers do.
Hail
Hail
Now for our mountain sport: up to yond hill;
Your legs are young; I'll tread these flats. Consider
And you may then revolve what tales I have told you
Of courts
This service is not service
And often
The sharded beetle in a safer hold
Than is the full-wing'd eagle. O
Is nobler than attending for a cheque
Such gain the cap of him that makes 'em fine
Out of your proof you speak: we
What air's from home. Haply this life is best
That have a sharper known; well corresponding
With your stiff age: but unto us it is
A cell of ignorance; travelling a-bed;
A prison for a debtor
To stride a limit.
What should we speak of
When we are old as you? when we shall hear
The rain and wind beat dark December
The freezing hours away? We have seen nothing;
We are beastly
Our valour is to chase what flies; our cage
We make a quire
How you speak!
Did you but know the city's usuries
And felt them knowingly; the art o' the court
As hard to leave as keep; whose top to climb
Is certain falling
The fear's as bad as falling; the toil o' the war
I' the name of fame and honour; which dies i'
the search
As record of fair act; nay
The world may read in me: my body's mark'd
With Roman swords
First with the best of note: Cymbeline loved me
Was not far off: then was I as a tree
Whose boughs did bend with fruit: but in one night
Uncertain favour!
My fault being nothing--as I have told you oft--
But that two villains
Before my perfect honour
I was confederate with the Romans: so
Follow'd my banishment
This rock and these demesnes have been my world;
Where I have lived at honest freedom
More pious debts to heaven than in all
The fore-end of my time. But up to the mountains!
This is not hunters' language: he that strikes
The venison first shall be the lord o' the feast;
To him the other two shall minister;
And we will fear no poison
In place of greater state. I'll meet you in the valleys.
Exeunt GUIDERIUS and ARVIRAGUS
How hard it is to hide the sparks of nature!
These boys know little they are sons to the king;
Nor Cymbeline dreams that they are alive.
They think they are mine; and though train'd
up thus meanly
I' the cave wherein they bow
The roofs of palaces
In simple and low things to prince it much
Beyond the trick of others. This Polydore
The king his father call'd Guiderius
When on my three-foot stool I sit and tell
The warlike feats I have done
Into my story: say 'Thus
The princely blood flows in his cheek
That acts my words. The younger brother
His own conceiving.--Hark
O Cymbeline! heaven and my conscience knows
Thou didst unjustly banish me: whereon
Thinking to bar thee of succession
Thou reft'st me of my lands. Euriphile
their mother
Myself
Exit
SCENE IV. Country near Milford-Haven.
Enter PISANIO and IMOGEN
Thou told'st me
Was near at hand: ne'er long'd my mother so
To see me first
Where is Posthumus? What is in thy mind
From the inward of thee? One
Beyond self-explication: put thyself
Into a havior of less fear
Vanquish my staider senses. What's the matter?
Why tender'st thou that paper to me
A look untender? If't be summer news
But keep that countenance still. My husband's hand!
That drug-damn'd Italy hath out-craftied him
May take off some extremity
Would be even mortal to me.
Please you
And you shall find me
The most disdain'd of fortune.
[Reads]  'Thy mistress
strumpet in my bed; the testimonies whereof lie
bleeding in me. I speak not out of weak surmises
as I expect my revenge. That part thou
the breach of hers. Let thine own hands take away
her life: I shall give thee opportunity at
Milford-Haven. She hath my letter for the purpose
where
it is done
equally to me disloyal.'
What shall I need to draw my sword? the paper
Hath cut her throat already. No
Outvenoms all the worms of Nile
Rides on the posting winds and doth belie
All corners of the world: kings
This viperous slander enters. What cheer
False to his bed! What is it to be false?
To lie in watch there and to think on him?
To weep 'twixt clock and clock? if sleep
charge nature
And cry myself awake? that's false to's bed
Alas
I false! Thy conscience witness: Iachimo
Thou then look'dst like a villain; now methinks
Thy favour's good enough. Some jay of Italy
Whose mother was her painting
Poor I am stale
And
Put on for villany; not born where't grows
Good madam
True honest men being heard
Did scandal many a holy tear
From most true wretchedness: so thou
Goodly and gallant shall be false and perjured
From thy great fall. Come
Do thou thy master's bidding: when thou see'st him
I draw the sword myself: take it
The innocent mansion of my love
Fear not; 'tis empty of all things but grief;
Thy master is not there
The riches of it: do his bidding; strike
Thou mayst be valiant in a better cause;
But now thou seem'st a coward.
Hence
Thou shalt not damn my hand.
Why
And if I do not by thy hand
No servant of thy master's. Against self-slaughter
There is a prohibition so divine
That cravens my weak hand. Come
Something's afore't. Soft
Obedient as the scabbard. What is here?
The scriptures of the loyal Leonatus
Be stomachers to my heart. Thus may poor fools
Believe false teachers: though those that
are betray'd
Do feel the treason sharply
Stands in worse case of woe.
And thou
My disobedience 'gainst the king my father
And make me put into contempt the suits
Of princely fellows
It is no act of common passage
A strain of rareness: and I grieve myself
To think
That now thou tirest on
Will then be pang'd by me. Prithee
The lamb entreats the butcher: where's thy knife?
Thou art too slow to do thy master's bidding
O gracious lady
I have not slept one wink.
Do't
I'll wake mine eye-balls blind first.
Wherefore then
Didst undertake it? Why hast thou abused
So many miles with a pretence? this place?
Mine action and thine own? our horses' labour?
The time inviting thee? the perturb'd court
Purpose return. Why hast thou gone so far
But to win time
To lose so bad employment; in the which
I have consider'd of a course. Good lady
Talk thy tongue weary; speak
I have heard I am a strumpet; and mine ear
Therein false struck
Then
Most like;
Bringing me here to kill me.
Not so
But if I were as wise as honest
My purpose would prove well. It cannot be
But that my master is abused:
Some villain
Hath done you both this cursed injury.
Some Roman courtezan.
No
I'll give but notice you are dead and send him
Some bloody sign of it; for 'tis commanded
I should do so: you shall be miss'd at court
Why good fellow
Or in my life what comfort
Dead to my husband?
If you'll back to the court--
No court
With that harsh
As fearful as a siege.
If not at court
Where then
Hath Britain all the sun that shines? Day
Our Britain seems as of it
In a great pool a swan's nest: prithee
There's livers out of Britain.
I am most glad
You think of other place. The ambassador
To-morrow: now
Dark as your fortune is
That which
But by self-danger
Pretty and full of view; yea
The residence of Posthumus; so nigh at least
That though his actions were not visible
Report should render him hourly to your ear
As truly as he moves.
O
Though peril to my modesty
Well
You must forget to be a woman; change
Command into obedience: fear and niceness--
The handmaids of all women
Ready in gibes
As quarrelous as the weasel; nay
Forget that rarest treasure of your cheek
Alack
Of common-kissing Titan
Your laboursome and dainty trims
You made great Juno angry.
Nay
I see into thy end
A man already.
First
Fore-thinking this
'Tis in my cloak-bag--doublet
That answer to them: would you in their serving
From youth of such a season
Present yourself
wherein you're happy
With joy he will embrace you
And doubling that
Beginning nor supplyment.
Thou art all the comfort
The gods will diet me with. Prithee
There's more to be consider'd; but we'll even
All that good time will give us: this attempt
I am soldier to
A prince's courage. Away
Well
Your carriage from the court. My noble mistress
What's in't is precious; if you are sick at sea
Will drive away distemper. To some shade
Direct you to the best!
Amen: I thank thee.
Exeunt
SCENE V. A room in Cymbeline's palace.
Enter CYMBELINE
Thus far; and so farewell.
Thanks
My emperor hath wrote
And am right sorry that I must report ye
My master's enemy.
Our subjects
To show less sovereignty than they
Appear unkinglike.
So
A conduct over-land to Milford-Haven.
Madam
And you!
My lords
The due of honour in no point omit.
So farewell
Your hand
Receive it friendly; but from this time forth
I wear it as your enemy.
Sir
Is yet to name the winner: fare you well.
Leave not the worthy Lucius
Exeunt LUCIUS and Lords
He goes hence frowning: but it honours us
That we have given him cause.
'Tis all the better;
Your valiant Britons have their wishes in it.
Lucius hath wrote already to the emperor
How it goes here. It fits us therefore ripely
Our chariots and our horsemen be in readiness:
The powers that he already hath in Gallia
Will soon be drawn to head
His war for Britain.
'Tis not sleepy business;
But must be look'd to speedily and strongly.
Our expectation that it would be thus
Hath made us forward. But
Before the Roman
The duty of the day: she looks us like
A thing more made of malice than of duty:
We have noted it. Call her before us; for
We have been too slight in sufferance.
Exit an Attendant
Royal sir
Hath her life been; the cure whereof
So tender of rebukes that words are strokes
And strokes death to her.
Re-enter Attendant
Where is she
Can her contempt be answer'd?
Please you
That will be given to the loudest noise we make.
My lord
She wish'd me to make known; but our great court
Made me to blame in memory.
Her doors lock'd?
Not seen of late? Grant
Prove false!
Exit
Son
That man of hers
Go
Exit CLOTEN
Pisanio
He hath a drug of mine; I pray his absence
Proceed by swallowing that
It is a thing most precious. But for her
To her desired Posthumus: gone she is
To death or to dishonour; and my end
Can make good use of either: she being down
Re-enter CLOTEN
How now
'Tis certain she is fled.
Go in and cheer the king: he rages; none
Dare come about him.
[Aside]            All the better: may
This night forestall him of the coming day!
Exit
I love and hate her: for she's fair and royal
Than lady
The best she hath
Disdaining me and throwing favours on
The low Posthumus slanders so her judgment
That what's else rare is choked; and in that point
I will conclude to hate her
Enter PISANIO
Who is here? What
Come hither: ah
Thou art straightway with the fiends.
O
Where is thy lady? Or
I will not ask again. Close villain
Thy heart to find it. Is she with Posthumus?
From whose so many weights of baseness cannot
A dram of worth be drawn.
Alas
He is in Rome.
Where is she
No further halting: satisfy me home
What is become of her.
O
All-worthy villain!
Discover where thy mistress is at once
Speak
Thy condemnation and thy death.
Then
Touching her flight.
Presenting a letter
Let's see't. I will pursue her
Even to Augustus' throne.
[Aside]                 Or this
She's far enough; and what he learns by this
May prove his travel
Hum!
[Aside]  I'll write to my lord she's dead. O Imogen
Sirrah
Sir
It is Posthumus' hand; I know't. Sirrah
wouldst not be a villain
cause to use thee with a serious industry
directly and truly
man: thou shouldst neither want my means for thy
relief nor my voice for thy preferment.
Well
Wilt thou serve me? for since patiently and
constantly thou hast stuck to the bare fortune of
that beggar Posthumus
course of gratitude
mine: wilt thou serve me?
Sir
Give me thy hand; here's my purse. Hast any of thy
late master's garments in thy possession?
I have
wore when he took leave of my lady and mistress.
The first service thou dost me
hither: let it be thy lint service; go.
I shall
Exit
Meet thee at Milford-Haven!--I forgot to ask him one
thing; I'll remember't anon:--even there
villain Posthumus
garments were come. She said upon a time--the
bitterness of it I now belch from my heart--that she
held the very garment of Posthumus in more respect
than my noble and natural person together with the
adornment of my qualities. With that suit upon my
back
eyes; there shall she see my valour
be a torment to her contempt. He on the ground
speech of insultment ended on his dead body
when my lust hath dined
her I will execute in the clothes that she so
praised
her home again. She hath despised me rejoicingly
Re-enter PISANIO
Be those the garments?
Ay
How long is't since she went to Milford-Haven?
She can scarce be there yet.
Bring this apparel to my chamber; that is the second
thing that I have commanded thee: the third is
but duteous
to thee. My revenge is now at Milford: would I had
wings to follow it! Come
Exit
Thou bid'st me to my loss: for true to thee
Were to prove false
Be cross'd with slowness; labour be his meed!
Exit
SCENE VI. Wales. Before the cave of Belarius.
Enter IMOGEN
I see a man's life is a tedious one:
I have tired myself
Have made the ground my bed. I should be sick
Foundations fly the wretched; such
I could not miss my way: will poor folks lie
A punishment or trial? Yes; no wonder
Is sorer than to lie for need
Is worse in kings than beggars. My dear lord!
Thou art one o' the false ones. Now I think on thee
At point to sink for food. But what is this?
Here is a path to't: 'tis some savage hold:
I were best not to call; I dare not call:
yet famine
Of hardiness is mother. Ho! who's here?
If any thing that's civil
Best draw my sword: and if mine enemy
But fear the sword like me
Such a foe
Exit
Enter BELARIUS
You
Are master of the feast: Cadwal and I
Will play the cook and servant; 'tis our match:
The sweat of industry would dry and die
Will make what's homely savoury: weariness
Can snore upon the flint
Finds the down pillow hard. Now peace be here
I am thoroughly weary.
I am weak with toil
There is cold meat i' the cave; we'll browse on that
[Looking into the cave]
Stay; come not in.
But that it eats our victuals
Here were a fairy.
What's the matter
By Jupiter
No elder than a boy!
Re-enter IMOGEN
Good masters
Before I enter'd here
To have begg'd or bought what I have took:
good troth
Gold strew'd i' the floor. Here's money for my meat:
I would have left it on the board so soon
As I had made my meal
With prayers for the provider.
Money
All gold and silver rather turn to dirt!
As 'tis no better reckon'd
Who worship dirty gods.
I see you're angry:
Know
Have died had I not made it.
Whither bound?
To Milford-Haven.
What's your name?
Fidele
Is bound for Italy; he embark'd at Milford;
To whom being going
Prithee
By this rude place we live in. Well encounter'd!
'Tis almost night: you shall have better cheer
Ere you depart: and thanks to stay and eat it.
Boys
Were you a woman
I'll make't my comfort
He is a man; I'll love him as my brother:
And such a welcome as I'd give to him
After long absence
Be sprightly
'Mongst friends
Aside
Would it had been so
Had been my father's sons! then had my prize
Been less
To thee
He wrings at some distress.
Would I could free't!
Or I
Hark
Whispering
Great men
Which their own conscience seal'd them--laying by
That nothing-gift of differing multitudes--
Could not out-peer these twain. Pardon me
I'd change my sex to be companion with them
It shall be so.
Boys
Discourse is heavy
Pray
The night to the owl and morn to the lark
less welcome.
Thanks
I pray
Exeunt
SCENE VII. Rome. A public place.
Enter two Senators and Tribunes
This is the tenor of the emperor's writ:
That since the common men are now in action
'Gainst the Pannonians and Dalmatians
Full weak to undertake our wars against
The fall'n-off Britons
The gentry to this business. He creates
Lucius preconsul: and to you the tribunes
His absolute commission. Long live Caesar!
Is Lucius general of the forces?
Ay.
Remaining now in Gallia?
With those legions
Which I have spoke of
Must be supplyant: the words of your commission
Will tie you to the numbers and the time
Of their dispatch.
We will discharge our duty.
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Wales: near the cave of Belarius.
Enter CLOTEN
I am near to the place where they should meet
Pisanio have mapped it truly. How fit his garments
serve me! Why should his mistress
him that made the tailor
rather--saving reverence of the word--for 'tis said
a woman's fitness comes by fits. Therein I must
play the workman. I dare speak it to myself--for it
is not vain-glory for a man and his glass to confer
in his own chamber--I mean
as well drawn as his; no less young
advantage of the time
conversant in general services
in single oppositions: yet this imperceiverant
thing loves him in my despite. What mortality is!
Posthumus
shoulders
mistress enforced; thy garments cut to pieces before
thy face: and all this done
father; who may haply be a little angry for my so
rough usage; but my mother
testiness
horse is tied up safe: out
purpose! Fortune
the very description of their meeting-place; and
the fellow dares not deceive me.
Exit
SCENE II. Before the cave of Belarius.
Enter
[To IMOGEN]  You are not well: remain here in the cave;
We'll come to you after hunting.
"[To IMOGEN]	Brother"
Are we not brothers?
So man and man should be;
But clay and clay differs in dignity
Go you to hunting; I'll abide with him.
So sick I am not
But not so citizen a wanton as
To seem to die ere sick: so please you
Stick to your journal course: the breach of custom
Is breach of all. I am ill
Cannot amend me; society is no comfort
To one not sociable: I am not very sick
I'll rob none but myself; and let me die
I love thee; I have spoke it
How much the quantity
What! how! how!
If it be sin to say so
In my good brother's fault: I know not why
I love this youth; and I have heard you say
'My father
"[Aside]	O noble strain!"
O worthiness of nature! breed of greatness!
Cowards father cowards and base things sire base:
Nature hath meal and bran
I'm not their father; yet who this should be
'Tis the ninth hour o' the morn.
Brother
I wish ye sport.
You health. So please you
[Aside]  These are kind creatures. Gods
I have heard!
Our courtiers say all's savage but at court:
Experience
The imperious seas breed monsters
Poor tributary rivers as sweet fish.
I am sick still; heart-sick. Pisanio
Swallows some
I could not stir him:
He said he was gentle
Dishonestly afflicted
Thus did he answer me: yet said
I might know more.
To the field
We'll leave you for this time: go in and rest.
We'll not be long away.
Pray
Well or ill
And shalt be ever.
Exit IMOGEN
This youth
Good ancestors.
How angel-like he sings!
But his neat cookery! he cut our roots
In characters
And he her dieter.
Nobly he yokes
A smiling with a sigh
Was that it was
The smile mocking the sigh
From so divine a temple
With winds that sailors rail at.
I do note
That grief and patience
Grow
