And let the stinking elder
His perishing root with the increasing vine!
It is great morning. Come
Who's there?
Enter CLOTEN
I cannot find those runagates; that villain
Hath mock'd me. I am faint.
'Those runagates!'
Means he not us? I partly know him: 'tis
Cloten
I saw him not these many years
I know 'tis he. We are held as outlaws: hence!
He is but one: you and my brother search
What companies are near: pray you
Let me alone with him.
Exeunt BELARIUS and ARVIRAGUS
Soft! What are you
That fly me thus? some villain mountaineers?
I have heard of such. What slave art thou?
A thing
More slavish did I ne'er than answering
A slave without a knock.
Thou art a robber
To who? to thee? What art thou? Have not I
An arm as big as thine? a heart as big?
Thy words
My dagger in my mouth. Say what thou art
Thou villain base
No
Thou precious varlet
Hence
The man that gave them thee. Thou art some fool;
I am loath to beat thee.
Thou injurious thief
What's thy name?
Cloten
Cloten
Adder
To thy further fear
I am son to the queen.
I am sorry for 't; not seeming
So worthy as thy birth.
Art not afeard?
Those that I reverence those I fear
At fools I laugh
Die the death:
When I have slain thee with my proper hand
Yield
Exeunt
Re-enter BELARIUS and ARVIRAGUS
No companies abroad?
None in the world: you did mistake him
I cannot tell: long is it since I saw him
Which then he wore; the snatches in his voice
'Twas very Cloten.
In this place we left them:
I wish my brother make good time with him
Being scarce made up
Of roaring terrors; for the effect of judgment
Is oft the cause of fear. But
Re-enter GUIDERIUS
This Cloten was a fool
There was no money in't: not Hercules
Could have knock'd out his brains
Yet I not doing this
My head as I do his.
What hast thou done?
I am perfect what: cut off one Cloten's head
Who call'd me traitor
With his own single hand he'ld take us in
Displace our heads where--thank the gods!--they grow
We are all undone.
Why
Protects not us: then why should we be tender
To let an arrogant piece of flesh threat us
Discover you abroad?
No single soul
Can we set eye on; but in all safe reason
He must have some attendants. Though his humour
Was nothing but mutation
From one bad thing to worse; not frenzy
Absolute madness could so far have raved
To bring him here alone; although perhaps
It may be heard at court that such as we
Cave here
May make some stronger head; the which he hearing--
As it is like him--might break out
He'ld fetch us in; yet is't not probable
To come alone
More perilous than the head.
Let ordinance
Come as the gods foresay it: howsoe'er
I had no mind
To hunt this day: the boy Fidele's sickness
Did make my way long forth.
With his own sword
His head from him: I'll throw't into the creek
Behind our rock; and let it to the sea
That's all I reck.
Exit
I fear 'twill be revenged:
Would
Becomes thee well enough.
Would I had done't
So the revenge alone pursued me! Polydore
Thou hast robb'd me of this deed: I would revenges
And put us to our answer.
Well
We'll hunt no more to-day
Where there's no profit. I prithee
You and Fidele play the cooks: I'll stay
Till hasty Polydote return
To dinner presently.
Poor sick Fidele!
I'll weringly to him: to gain his colour
I'ld let a parish of such Clotens' blood
Exit
O thou goddess
In these two princely boys! They are as gentle
As zephyrs blowing below the violet
That an invisible instinct should frame them
To royalty unlearn'd
That wildly grows in them
As if it had been sow'd. Yet still it's strange
What Cloten's being here to us portends
Re-enter GUIDERIUS
Where's my brother?
I have sent Cloten's clotpoll down the stream
For his return.
Solemn music
My ingenious instrument!
Hark
Hath Cadwal now to give it motion? Hark!
Is he at home?
He went hence even now.
What does he mean? since death of my dear'st mother
it did not speak before. All solemn things
Should answer solemn accidents. The matter?
Triumphs for nothing and lamenting toys
Is jollity for apes and grief for boys.
Is Cadwal mad?
Look
Of what we blame him for.
Re-enter ARVIRAGUS
The bird is dead
That we have made so much on. I had rather
Have skipp'd from sixteen years of age to sixty
O sweetest
My brother wears thee not the one half so well
As when thou grew'st thyself.
O melancholy!
Who ever yet could sound thy bottom? find
The ooze
Might easiliest harbour in? Thou blessed thing!
Jove knows what man thou mightst have made; but I
How found you him?
Stark
Thus smiling
right cheek
Reposing on a cushion.
Where?
O' the floor;
His arms thus leagued: I thought he slept
My clouted brogues from off my feet
Answer'd my steps too loud.
Why
If he be gone
With female fairies will his tomb be haunted
With fairest flowers
Whilst summer lasts and I live here
The flower that's like thy face
The azured harebell
The leaf of eglantine
Those rich-left heirs that let their fathers lie
Without a monument!--bring thee all this;
Yea
Prithee
And do not play in wench-like words with that
Which is so serious. Let us bury him
Is now due debt. To the grave!
Say
By good Euriphile
Be't so:
And let us
Have got the mannish crack
Cadwal
For notes of sorrow out of tune are worse
Than priests and fanes that lie.
We'll speak it
Great griefs
Is quite forgot. He was a queen's son
And though he came our enemy
He was paid for that: though mean and
mighty
Together
Of place 'tween high and low. Our foe was princely
And though you took his life
Pray You
Thersites' body is as good as Ajax'
If you'll go fetch him
Exit BELARIUS
Nay
My father hath a reason for't.
'Tis true.
Come on then
So. Begin.
SONG
Fear no more the heat o' the sun
Thou thy worldly task hast done
Golden lads and girls all must
Fear no more the frown o' the great;
Thou art past the tyrant's stroke;
Care no more to clothe and eat;
To thee the reed is as the oak:
The sceptre
All follow this
Fear no more the lightning flash
Fear not slander
Thou hast finish'd joy and moan:
All lovers young
Consign to thee
No exorciser harm thee!
Nor no witchcraft charm thee!
Ghost unlaid forbear thee!
Nothing ill come near thee!
Quiet consummation have;
And renowned be thy grave!
Re-enter BELARIUS
We have done our obsequies: come
Here's a few flowers; but 'bout midnight
The herbs that have on them cold dew o' the night
Are strewings fitt'st for graves. Upon their faces.
You were as flowers
These herblets shall
Come on
The ground that gave them first has them again:
Their pleasures here are past
Exeunt BELARIUS
[Awaking]  Yes
the way?--
I thank you.--By yond bush?--Pray
'Ods pittikins! can it be six mile yet?--
I have gone all night. 'Faith
But
Seeing the body of CLOTEN
These flowers are like the pleasures of the world;
This bloody man
For so I thought I was a cave-keeper
'Twas but a bolt of nothing
Are sometimes like our judgments
Yet left in heaven as small a drop of pity
As a wren's eye
The dream's here still: even when I wake
Without me
A headless man! The garments of Posthumus!
I know the shape of's leg: this is his hand;
His foot Mercurial; his Martial thigh;
The brawns of Hercules: but his Jovial face
Murder in heaven?--How!--'Tis gone. Pisanio
Be henceforth treacherous! Damn'd Pisanio
Hath with his forged letters
From this most bravest vessel of the world
Struck the main-top! O Posthumus! alas
where's that?
Pisanio might have kill'd thee at the heart
'Tis he and Cloten: malice and lucre in them
Have laid this woe here. O
The drug he gave me
And cordial to me
Murderous to the senses? That confirms it home:
This is Pisanio's deed
Give colour to my pale cheek with thy blood
Which chance to find us: O
Falls on the body
Enter LUCIUS
To them the legions garrison'd in Gailia
You here at Milford-Haven with your ships:
They are in readiness.
But what from Rome?
The senate hath stirr'd up the confiners
And gentlemen of Italy
Under the conduct of bold Iachimo
When expect you them?
With the next benefit o' the wind.
This forwardness
Makes our hopes fair. Command our present numbers
Be muster'd; bid the captains look to't. Now
Last night the very gods show'd me a vision--
I fast and pray'd for their intelligence--thus:
I saw Jove's bird
From the spongy south to this part of the west
Unless my sins abuse my divination--
Success to the Roman host.
Dream often so
Without his top? The ruin speaks that sometime
It was a worthy building. How! a page!
Or dead
For nature doth abhor to make his bed
With the defunct
Let's see the boy's face.
He's alive
He'll then instruct us of this body. Young one
They crave to be demanded. Who is this
Thou makest thy bloody pillow? Or who was he
That
In this sad wreck? How came it? Who is it?
What art thou?
I am nothing: or if not
There is no more such masters: I may wander
From east to occident
Find such another master.
'Lack
Thou movest no less with thy complaining than
Thy master in bleeding: say his name
Richard du Champ.
Aside
If I do lie and do
No harm by it
They'll pardon it.--Say you
Thy name?
Fidele
Thou dost approve thyself the very same:
Thy name well fits thy faith
Wilt take thy chance with me? I will not say
Thou shalt be so well master'd
Than thine own worth prefer thee: go with me.
I'll follow
As these poor pickaxes can dig; and when
With wild wood-leaves and weeds I ha' strew'd his grave
And leaving so his service
Ay
And rather father thee than master thee.
My friends
Find out the prettiest daisied plot we can
A grave: come
By thee to us
As soldiers can. Be cheerful; wipe thine eyes
Some falls are means the happier to arise.
Exeunt
SCENE III. A room in Cymbeline's palace.
Enter CYMBELINE
Again; and bring me word how 'tis with her.
Exit an Attendant
A fever with the absence of her son
Upon a desperate bed
When fearful wars point at me; her son gone
The hope of comfort. But for thee
Dost seem so ignorant
By a sharp torture.
Sir
I humbly set it at your will; but
Good my liege
I dare be bound he's true and shall perform
All parts of his subjection loyally. For Cloten
The time is troublesome.
To PISANIO
We'll slip you for a season; but our jealousy
Does yet depend.
So please your majesty
Of Roman gentlemen
Now for the counsel of my son and queen!
I am amazed with matter.
Good my liege
Than what you hear of: come more
you're ready:
The want is but to put those powers in motion
That long to move.
I thank you. Let's withdraw;
And meet the time as it seeks us. We fear not
What can from Italy annoy us; but
We grieve at chances here. Away!
Exeunt all but PISANIO
I heard no letter from my master since
I wrote him Imogen was slain: 'tis strange:
Nor hear I from my mistress who did promise
To yield me often tidings: neither know I
What is betid to Cloten; but remain
Perplex'd in all. The heavens still must work.
Wherein I am false I am honest; not true
These present wars shall find I love my country
All other doubts
Fortune brings in some boats that are not steer'd.
Exit
SCENE IV. Wales: before the cave of Belarius.
Enter BELARIUS
The noise is round about us.
Let us from it.
What pleasure
From action and adventure?
Nay
Have we in hiding us? This way
Must or for Britons slay us
For barbarous and unnatural revolts
During their use
Sons
To the king's party there's no going: newness
Of Cloten's death--we being not known
Among the bands--may drive us to a render
Where we have lived
Which we have done
Drawn on with torture.
This is
In such a time nothing becoming you
It is not likely
That when they hear the Roman horses neigh
And ears so cloy'd importantly as now
O
Of many in the army: many years
From my remembrance. And
Hath not deserved my service nor your loves;
Who find in my exile the want of breeding
To have the courtesy your cradle promised
The shrinking slaves of winter.
Than be so
Better to cease to be. Pray
I and my brother are not known; yourself
So out of thought
By this sun that shines
Did see man die! scarce ever look'd on blood
Never bestrid a horse
A rider like myself
Nor iron on his heel! I am ashamed
To look upon the holy sun
The benefit of his blest beams
So long a poor unknown.
By heavens
If you will bless me
The hands of Romans!
"So say I	amen."
No reason I
So slight a valuation
My crack'd one to more care. Have with you
If in your country wars you chance to die
Lead
Aside
The time seems long; their blood
thinks scorn
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. Britain. The Roman camp.
Enter POSTHUMUS
Yea
Thou shouldst be colour'd thus. You married ones
Must murder wives much better than themselves
For wrying but a little! O Pisanio!
Every good servant does not all commands:
No bond but to do just ones. Gods! if you
Should have ta'en vengeance on my faults
Had lived to put on this: so had you saved
The noble Imogen to repent
Me
To second ills with ills
But Imogen is your own: do your best wills
Among the Italian gentry
Against my lady's kingdom: 'tis enough
That
I'll give no wound to thee. Therefore
Of these Italian weeds and suit myself
As does a Briton peasant: so I'll fight
Against the part I come with; so I'll die
For thee
Is every breath a death; and thus
Myself I'll dedicate. Let me make men know
More valour in me than my habits show.
Gods
To shame the guise o' the world
The fashion
Exit
SCENE II. Field of battle between the British and Roman camps.
Enter
The heaviness and guilt within my bosom
Takes off my manhood: I have belied a lady
Revengingly enfeebles me; or could this carl
In my profession? Knighthoods and honours
As I wear mine
If that thy gentry
This lout as he exceeds our lords
Is that we scarce are men and you are gods.
Exit
The battle continues; the Britons fly; CYMBELINE is  taken: then enter
Stand
The lane is guarded: nothing routs us but
The villany of our fears.
Stand
Re-enter POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
Away
For friends kill friends
As war were hoodwink'd.
'Tis their fresh supplies.
It is a day turn'd strangely: or betimes
Let's reinforce
Exeunt
SCENE III. Another part of the field.
Enter POSTHUMUS LEONATUS and a British Lord
Camest thou from where they made the stand?
I did.
Though you
I did.
No blame be to you
Of his wings destitute
Through a straight lane; the enemy full-hearted
More plentiful than tools to do't
Some mortally
Merely through fear; that the straight pass was damm'd
With dead men hurt behind
To die with lengthen'd shame.
Where was this lane?
Close by the battle
Which gave advantage to an ancient soldier
So long a breeding as his white beard came to
The country base than to commit such slaughter
With faces fit for masks
Than those for preservation cased
Made good the passage; cried to those that fled
To darkness fleet souls that fly backwards. Stand;
Or we are Romans and will give you that
Like beasts which you shun beastly
These three
For three performers are the file when all
The rest do nothing--with this word 'Stand
Accommodated by the place
With their own nobleness
A distaff to a lance
But by example--O
The way that they did
Upon the pikes o' the hunters. Then began
A stop i' the chaser
A rout
Chickens
The life o' the need: having found the backdoor open
Of the unguarded hearts
Some slain before; some dying; some their friends
O'er borne i' the former wave: ten
Those that would die or ere resist are grown
The mortal bugs o' the field.
This was strange chance
A narrow lane
Nay
Rather to wonder at the things you hear
Than to work any. Will you rhyme upon't
'Two boys
Nay
'Lack
Who dares not stand his foe
For if he'll do as he is made to do
You have put me into rhyme.
Farewell; you're angry.
Still going?
Exit Lord
This is a lord! O noble misery
To-day how many would have given their honours
To have saved their carcasses! took heel to do't
That draw his knives i' the war. Well
For being now a favourer to the Briton
The part I came in: fight I will no more
Once touch my shoulder. Great the slaughter is
Here made by the Roman; great the answer be
Britons must take. For me
On either side I come to spend my breath;
Which neither here I'll keep nor bear again
Enter two British Captains and Soldiers
Great Jupiter be praised! Lucius is taken.
'Tis thought the old man and his sons were angels.
There was a fourth man
So 'tis reported:
But none of 'em can be found. Stand! who's there?
A Roman
Had answer'd him.
Lay hands on him; a dog!
A leg of Rome shall not return to tell
What crows have peck'd them here. He brags
his service
As if he were of note: bring him to the king.
Enter CYMBELINE
SCENE IV. A British prison.
Enter POSTHUMUS LEONATUS and two Gaolers
You shall not now be stol'n
So graze as you find pasture.
Ay
Exeunt Gaolers
Most welcome
Than one that's sick o' the gout; since he had rather
Groan so in perpetuity than be cured
By the sure physician
To unbar these locks. My conscience
More than my shanks and wrists: you good gods
The penitent instrument to pick that bolt
So children temporal fathers do appease;
Gods are more full of mercy. Must I repent?
I cannot do it better than in gyves
No stricter render of me than my all.
I know you are more clement than vile men
On their abatement: that's not my desire:
For Imogen's dear life take mine; and though
'Tis not so dear
'Tween man and man they weigh not every stamp;
Though light
You rather mine
I'll speak to thee in silence.
Sleeps
Solemn music. Enter
No more
Thy spite on mortal flies:
With Mars fall out
Rates and revenges.
Hath my poor boy done aught but well
I died whilst in the womb he stay'd
Attending nature's law:
Whose father then
Thou orphans' father art
From this earth-vexing smart.
Lucina lent not me her aid
That from me was Posthumus ript
Great nature
When once he was mature for man
That could stand up his parallel;
Or fruitful object be
In eye of Imogen
Could deem his dignity?
With marriage wherefore was he mock'd
From Leonati seat
From her his dearest one
Why did you suffer Iachimo
With needless jealosy;
And to become the geck and scorn
O' th' other's villany?
For this from stiller seats we came
Fell bravely and were slain
With honour to maintain.
Like hardiment Posthumus hath
To Cymbeline perform'd:
Then
The graces for his merits due
Thy crystal window ope; look out;
No longer exercise
Upon a valiant race thy harsh
And potent injuries.
Since
Peep through thy marble mansion; help;
Or we poor ghosts will cry
To the shining synod of the rest
Against thy deity.
Help
Jupiter descends in thunder and lightning
No more
Accuse the thunderer
Poor shadows of Elysium
Upon your never-withering banks of flowers:
Be not with mortal accidents opprest;
No care of yours it is; you know 'tis ours.
Whom best I love I cross; to make my gift
Your low-laid son our godhead will uplift:
His comforts thrive
Our Jovial star reign'd at his birth
Our temple was he married. Rise
He shall be lord of lady Imogen
This tablet lay upon his breast
Our pleasure his full fortune doth confine:
and so
Express impatience
Mount
Ascends
He came in thunder; his celestial breath
Was sulphurous to smell: the holy eagle
Stoop'd as to foot us: his ascension is
More sweet than our blest fields: his royal bird
Prunes the immortal wing and cloys his beak
Thanks
The marble pavement closes
His radiant root. Away! and
The Apparitions vanish
[Waking]  Sleep
A father to me; and thou hast created
A mother and two brothers: but
Gone! they went hence so soon as they were born:
And so I am awake. Poor wretches that depend
On greatness' favour dream as I have done
Many dream not to find
What fairies haunt this ground? A book? O rare one!
Be not
Nobler than that it covers: let thy effects
So follow
Reads
'When as a lion's whelp shall
tender air; and when from a stately cedar shall be
lopped branches
freshly grow; then shall Posthumus end his miseries
'Tis still a dream
Tongue and brain not; either both or nothing;
Or senseless speaking or a speaking such
As sense cannot untie. Be what it is
I'll keep
Re-enter First Gaoler
Come
Over-roasted rather; ready long ago.
Hanging is the word
you be ready for that
So
spectators
A heavy reckoning for you
more tavern-bills; which are often the sadness of
parting
flint for want of meat
much drink; sorry that you have paid too much
sorry that you are paid too much; purse and brain
both empty; the brain the heavier for being too
light
heaviness: of this contradiction you shall now be
quit. O
thousands in a trice: you have no true debitor and
creditor but it; of what's past
counters; so the acquittance follows.
I am merrier to die than thou art to live.
Indeed
tooth-ache: but a man that were to sleep your
sleep
would change places with his officer; for
Yes
Your death has eyes in 's head then; I have not seen
him so pictured: you must either be directed by
some that take upon them to know
yourself that which I am sure you do not know
jump the after inquiry on your own peril: and how
you shall speed in your journey's end
never return to tell one.
I tell thee
direct them the way I am going
will not use them.
What an infinite mock is this
have the best use of eyes to see the way of
blindness! I am sure hanging's the way of winking.
Enter a Messenger
Knock off his manacles; bring your prisoner to the king.
Thou bring'st good news; I am called to be made free.
I'll be hang'd then.
Thou shalt be then freer than a gaoler; no bolts for the dead.
Exeunt POSTHUMUS LEONATUS and Messenger
Unless a man would marry a gallows and beget young
gibbets
conscience
too that die against their wills; so should I
were one. I would we were all of one mind
mind good; O
gallowses! I speak against my present profit
my wish hath a preferment in 't.
Exeunt
SCENE V. Cymbeline's tent.
Enter CYMBELINE
Stand by my side
Preservers of my throne. Woe is my heart
That the poor soldier that so richly fought
Stepp'd before larges of proof
He shall be happy that can find him
Our grace can make him so.
I never saw
Such noble fury in so poor a thing;
Such precious deeds in one that promises nought
But beggary and poor looks.
No tidings of him?
He hath been search'd among the dead and living
To my grief
The heir of his reward;
To BELARIUS
which I will add
To you
To ask of whence you are. Report it.
Sir
Further to boast were neither true nor modest
Bow your knees.
Arise my knights o' the battle: I create you
Companions to our person and will fit you
With dignities becoming your estates.
Enter CORNELIUS and Ladies
There's business in these faces. Why so sadly
Greet you our victory? you look like Romans
Hail
To sour your happiness
The queen is dead.
Who worse than a physician
Would this report become? But I consider
Will seize the doctor too. How ended she?
With horror
Most cruel to herself. What she confess'd
I will report
Can trip me
Were present when she finish'd.
Prithee
First
Affected greatness got by you
Married your royalty
Abhorr'd your person.
She alone knew this;
And
Believe her lips in opening it. Proceed.
Your daughter
With such integrity
Was as a scorpion to her sight; whose life
Ta'en off by poison.
O most delicate fiend!
Who is 't can read a woman? Is there more?
More
For you a mortal mineral; which
By inches waste you: in which time she purposed
O'ercome you with her show
Her son into the adoption of the crown:
But
Of heaven and men
The evils she hatch'd were not effected; so
Despairing died.
Heard you all this
We did
Mine eyes
Were not in fault
Mine ears
been vicious
To have mistrusted her: yet
That it was folly in me
Enter LUCIUS
Thou comest not
The Britons have razed out
Of many a bold one; whose kinsmen have made suit
That their good souls may be appeased with slaughter
Of you their captives
So think of your estate.
Consider
Was yours by accident; had it gone with us
Our prisoners with the sword. But since the gods
Will have it thus
May be call'd ransom
A Roman with a Roman's heart can suffer:
Augustus lives to think on't: and so much
For my peculiar care. This one thing only
I will entreat; my boy
A page so kind
With my request
Cannot deny; he hath done no Briton harm
I have surely seen him:
His favour is familiar to me. Boy
And ask of Cymbeline what boon thou wilt
Yea
I humbly thank your highness.
I do not bid thee beg my life
And yet I know thou wilt.
No
Bitter to me as death: your life
The boy disdains me
That place them on the truth of girls and boys.
Why stands he so perplex'd?
What wouldst thou
I love thee more and more: think more and more
What's best to ask. Know'st him thou look'st on? speak
He is a Roman; no more kin to me
Than I to your highness; who
Wherefore eyest him so?
I'll tell you
To give me hearing.
Ay
Fidele
Thou'rt my good youth
I'll be thy master: walk with me; speak freely.
CYMBELINE and IMOGEN converse apart
Is not this boy revived from death?
One sand another
Not more resembles that sweet rosy lad
Who died
The same dead thing alive.
Peace
Creatures may be alike: were 't he
He would have spoke to us.
But we saw him dead.
Be silent; let's see further.
"[Aside]	It is my mistress:"
Since she is living
To good or bad.
CYMBELINE and IMOGEN come forward
Come
Make thy demand aloud.
To IACHIMO
Sir
Give answer to this boy
Or
Winnow the truth from falsehood. On
My boon is
Of whom he had this ring.
[Aside]                 What's that to him?
That diamond upon your finger
How came it yours?
Thou'lt torture me to leave unspoken that
Which
How! me?
I am glad to be constrain'd to utter that
Which torments me to conceal. By villany
I got this ring: 'twas Leonatus' jewel;
Whom thou didst banish; and--which more may
grieve thee
'Twixt sky and ground. Wilt thou hear more
All that belongs to this.
That paragon
For whom my heart drops blood
Quail to remember--Give me leave; I faint.
My daughter! what of her? Renew thy strength:
I had rather thou shouldst live while nature will
Than die ere I hear more: strive
Upon a time
That struck the hour!--it was in Rome
The mansion where!--'twas at a feast
Our viands had been poison'd
Those which I heaved to head!--the good Posthumus--
What should I say? he was too good to be
Where ill men were; and was the best of all
Amongst the rarest of good ones
For beauty that made barren the swell'd boast
Of him that best could speak
The shrine of Venus
Postures beyond brief nature
Loves woman for
I stand on fire:
Come to the matter.
All too soon I shall
That had a royal lover
And
He was as calm as virtue--he began
His mistress' picture; which by his tongue
being made
Were crack'd of kitchen-trolls
Proved us unspeaking sots.
Nay
Your daughter's chastity--there it begins.
He spake of her
Pieces of gold 'gainst this which then he wore
Upon his honour'd finger
In suit the place of's bed and win this ring
By hers and mine adultery. He
Than I did truly find her
And would so
Of Phoebus' wheel
Been all the worth of's car. Away to Britain
Post I in this design: well may you
Of your chaste daughter the wide difference
'Twixt amorous and villanous. Being thus quench'd
Of hope
'Gan in your duller Britain operate
Most vilely; for my vantage
And
To make the noble Leonatus mad
With tokens thus
Of chamber-hanging
O cunning
Of secret on her person
But think her bond of chastity quite crack'd
Methinks
[Advancing]             Ay
That's due to all the villains past
For torturers ingenious: it is I
That all the abhorred things o' the earth amend
By being worse than they. I am Posthumus
That caused a lesser villain than myself
Of virtue was she; yea
Spit
The dogs o' the street to bay me: every villain
Be call'd Posthumus Leonitus; and
Be villany less than 'twas! O Imogen!
My queen
Peace
Shall's have a play of this? Thou scornful page
Striking her: she falls
O
Mine and your mistress! O
You ne'er kill'd Imogen til now. Help
Mine honour'd lady!
Does the world go round?
How come these staggers on me?
Wake
If this be so
To death with mortal joy.
How fares thy mistress?
O
Thou gavest me poison: dangerous fellow
Breathe not where princes are.
The tune of Imogen!
Lady
That box I gave you was not thought by me
A precious thing: I had it from the queen.
New matter still?
It poison'd me.
O gods!
I left out one thing which the queen confess'd.
Which must approve thee honest: 'If Pisanio
Have
Which I gave him for cordial
As I would serve a rat.'
What's this
The queen
To temper poisons for her
The satisfaction of her knowledge only
In killing creatures vile
Was of more danger
A certain stuff
The present power of life
All offices of nature should again
Do their due functions. Have you ta'en of it?
Most like I did
My boys
This is
Why did you throw your wedded lady from you?
Think that you are upon a rock; and now
Throw me again.
Embracing him
Hang there like a fruit
How now
What
Wilt thou not speak to me?
[Kneeling]               Your blessing
[To GUIDERIUS and ARVIRAGUS]  Though you did love
this youth
You had a motive for't.
My tears that fall
Prove holy water on thee! Imogen
I am sorry for't
O
That we meet here so strangely: but her son
Is gone
My lord
With his sword drawn; foam'd at the mouth
Then in my pocket; which directed him
To seek her on the mountains near to Milford;
Where
With unchaste purpose and with oath to violate
My lady's honour: what became of him
I further know not.
Let me end the story:
I slew him there.
Marry
I would not thy good deeds should from my lips
Pluck a bard sentence: prithee
I have spoke it
He was a prince.
A most incivil one: the wrongs he did me
Were nothing prince-like; for he did provoke me
With language that would make me spurn the sea
And am right glad he is not standing here
To tell this tale of mine.
I am sorry for thee:
By thine own tongue thou art condemn'd
Endure our law: thou'rt dead.
That headless man
I thought had been my lord.
Bind the offender
Stay
This man is better than the man he slew
More of thee merited than a band of Clotens
Had ever scar for.
To the Guard
Let his arms alone;
They were not born for bondage.
Why
As good as we?
In that he spake too far.
And thou shalt die for't.
We will die all three:
But I will prove that two on's are as good
As I have given out him. My sons
Your danger's ours.
And our good his.
Have at it then
Thou hadst
Was call'd Belarius.
What of him? he is
A banish'd traitor.
He it is that hath
Assumed this age; indeed a banish'd man;
I know not how a traitor.
Take him hence:
The whole world shall not save him.
Not too hot:
First pay me for the nursing of thy sons;
And let it be confiscate all
As I have received it.
Nursing of my sons!
I am too blunt and saucy: here's my knee:
Ere I arise
Then spare not the old father. Mighty sir
And think they are my sons
They are the issue of your loins
How! my issue!
So sure as you your father's. I
Your pleasure was my mere offence
Itself
Was all the harm I did. These gentle princes--
For such and so they are--these twenty years
Have I train'd up: those arts they have as I
Could put into them; my breeding was
Your highness knows. Their nurse
Upon my banishment: I moved her to't
Excited me to treason: their dear loss
Unto my end of stealing them. But
Two of the sweet'st companions in the world.
The benediction of these covering heavens
Fall on their heads like dew! for they are worthy
To inlay heaven with stars.
Thou weep'st
The service that you three have done is more
Unlike than this thou tell'st. I lost my children:
If these be they
A pair of worthier sons.
Be pleased awhile.
This gentleman
This gentleman
In a most curious mantle
Of his queen mother
I can with ease produce.
Guiderius had
Upon his neck a mole
It was a mark of wonder.
This is he;
Who hath upon him still that natural stamp:
It was wise nature's end in the donation
O
A mother to the birth of three? Ne'er mother
Rejoiced deliverance more. Blest pray you be
No
I have got two worlds by 't. O my gentle brothers
But I am truest speaker you call'd me brother
Did you e'er meet?
Ay
And at first meeting loved;
Continued so
By the queen's dram she swallow'd.
O rare instinct!
When shall I hear all through? This fierce
abridgement
Hath to it circumstantial branches
Distinction should be rich in. Where? how lived You?
And when came you to serve our Roman captive?
How parted with your brothers? how first met them?
Why fled you from the court? and whither? These
I know not how much more
And all the other by-dependencies
Will serve our long inter'gatories. See
On him
Each object with a joy: the counterchange
Is severally in all. Let's quit this ground
To BELARIUS
Thou art my brother; so we'll hold thee ever.
You are my father too
All o'erjoy'd
My good master
Happy be you!
The forlorn soldier
The thankings of a king.
I am
In poor beseeming; 'twas a fitment for
The purpose I then follow'd. That I was he
Have made you finish.
[Kneeling]          I am down again:
But now my heavy conscience sinks my knee
And here the bracelet of the truest princess
That ever swore her faith.
Kneel not to me:
The power that I have on you is
The malice towards you to forgive you: live
Nobly doom'd!
We'll learn our freeness of a son-in-law;
Pardon's the word to all.
You holp us
Joy'd are we that you are.
Your servant
Great Jupiter
Of mine own kindred: when I waked
This label on my bosom; whose containing
Is so from sense in hardness
Make no collection of it: let him show
His skill in the construction.
Philarmonus!
Here
Read
[Reads]  'When as a lion's whelp shall
unknown
piece of tender air; and when from a stately cedar
shall be lopped branches
years
stock
his miseries
peace and plenty.'
Thou
The fit and apt construction of thy name
To CYMBELINE
The piece of tender air
We term it 'mulier:' which 'mulier' I divine
Is this most constant wife; who
With this most tender air.
This hath some seeming.
The lofty cedar
Thy two sons forth; who
Promises Britain peace and plenty.
Well
My peace we will begin. And
To pay our wonted tribute
We were dissuaded by our wicked queen;
Whom heavens
The fingers of the powers above do tune
The harmony of this peace. The vision
Which I made known to Lucius
Of this yet scarce-cold battle
Is full accomplish'd; for the Roman eagle
So vanish'd: which foreshow'd our princely eagle
His favour with the radiant Cymbeline
Laud we the gods;
And let our crooked smokes climb to their nostrils
From our blest altars. Publish we this peace
To all our subjects. Set we forward: let
A Roman and a British ensign wave
Friendly together: so through Lud's-town march:
And in the temple of great Jupiter
Our peace we'll ratify; seal it with feasts.
Set on there! Never was a war did cease
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. Elsinore. A platform before the castle.
FRANCISCO at his post. Enter to him BERNARDO
Who's there?
Nay
Long live the king!
Bernardo?
He.
You come most carefully upon your hour.
'Tis now struck twelve; get thee to bed
For this relief much thanks: 'tis bitter cold
Have you had quiet guard?
Not a mouse stirring.
Well
If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus
I think I hear them. Stand
Enter HORATIO and MARCELLUS
Friends to this ground.
And liegemen to the Dane.
Give you good night.
O
Who hath relieved you?
Bernardo has my place.
Give you good night.
Exit
Holla! Bernardo!
Say
A piece of him.
Welcome
What
I have seen nothing.
Horatio says 'tis but our fantasy
Touching this dreaded sight
Therefore I have entreated him along
With us to watch the minutes of this night;
That if again this apparition come
Tush
Sit down awhile;
And let us once again assail your ears
What we have two nights seen.
Well
Last night of all
Had made his course to illume that part of heaven
Where now it burns
Enter Ghost
Peace
In the same figure
Thou art a scholar; speak to it
Looks it not like the king?  mark it
Most like: it harrows me with fear and wonder.
It would be spoke to.
Question it
What art thou that usurp'st this time of night
In which the majesty of buried Denmark
Did sometimes march? by heaven I charge thee
It is offended.
See
Stay! speak
Exit Ghost
'Tis gone
How now
Is not this something more than fantasy?
What think you on't?
Before my God
Without the sensible and true avouch
Of mine own eyes.
Is it not like the king?
As thou art to thyself:
Such was the very armour he had on
When he the ambitious Norway combated;
So frown'd he once
'Tis strange.
Thus twice before
In what particular thought to work I know not;
But in the gross and scope of my opinion
Good now
So nightly toils the subject of the land
Why such impress of shipwrights
Does not divide the Sunday from the week;
What might be toward
Doth make the night joint-labourer with the day:
Who is't that can inform me?
That can I;
At least
For so this side of our known world esteem'd him--
Did slay this Fortinbras; who by a seal'd compact
Which he stood seized of
Against the which
Was gaged by our king; which had return'd
To the inheritance of Fortinbras
Shark'd up a list of lawless resolutes
That hath a stomach in't; which is no other--
As it doth well appear unto our state--
But to recover of us
And terms compulsatory
So by his father lost: and this
Of this post-haste and romage in the land.
I think it be no other but e'en so:
Well may it sort that this portentous figure
Comes armed through our watch; so like the king
That was and is the question of these wars.
A mote it is to trouble the mind's eye.
In the most high and palmy state of Rome
Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets:
As stars with trains of fire and dews of blood
Upon whose influence Neptune's empire stands
Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse:
And even the like precurse of fierce events
And prologue to the omen coming on
Unto our climatures and countrymen.--
But soft
Re-enter Ghost
I'll cross it
If thou hast any sound
If there be any good thing to be done
Cock crows
If thou art privy to thy country's fate
Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life
Extorted treasure in the womb of earth
Shall I strike at it with my partisan?
Do
'Tis here!
'Tis here!
'Tis gone!
Exit Ghost
We do it wrong
For it is
It was about to speak
And then it started like a guilty thing
Upon a fearful summons. I have heard
Awake the god of day; and
To his confine: and of the truth herein
This present object made probation.
It faded on the crowing of the cock.
Some say that ever 'gainst that season comes
Wherein our Saviour's birth is celebrated
And then
The nights are wholesome; then no planets strike
So have I heard and do in part believe it.
But
Break we our watch up; and by my advice
Unto young Hamlet; for
Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it
Let's do't
Where we shall find him most conveniently.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A room of state in the castle.
Enter KING CLAUDIUS
Though yet of Hamlet our dear brother's death
The memory be green
To bear our hearts in grief and our whole kingdom
To be contracted in one brow of woe
That we with wisest sorrow think on him
Therefore our sometime sister
With an auspicious and a dropping eye
Taken to wife: nor have we herein barr'd
Your better wisdoms
With this affair along. For all
Now follows
Our state to be disjoint and out of frame
Lost by his father
Now for ourself and for this time of meeting:
Thus much the business is: we have here writ
To Norway
Who
Of this his nephew's purpose
His further gait herein; in that the levies
Out of his subject: and we here dispatch
You
Giving to you no further personal power
To business with the king
Of these delated articles allow.
Farewell
In that and all things will we show our duty.
We doubt it nothing: heartily farewell.
Exeunt VOLTIMAND and CORNELIUS
And now
You told us of some suit; what is't
You cannot speak of reason to the Dane
The head is not more native to the heart
What wouldst thou have
My dread lord
From whence though willingly I came to Denmark
And bow them to your gracious leave and pardon.
Have you your father's leave? What says Polonius?
He hath
By laboursome petition
Upon his will I seal'd my hard consent:
I do beseech you
Take thy fair hour
But now
[Aside]  A little more than kin
How is it that the clouds still hang on you?
Not so
Good Hamlet
Do not for ever with thy vailed lids
Seek for thy noble father in the dust:
Thou know'st 'tis common; all that lives must die
Ay
If it be
Seems
'Tis not alone my inky cloak
But I have that within which passeth show;
These but the trappings and the suits of woe.
'Tis sweet and commendable in your nature
But
That father lost
In filial obligation for some term
To do obsequious sorrow: but to persever
In obstinate condolement is a course
Of impious stubbornness; 'tis unmanly grief;
It shows a will most incorrect to heaven
For what we know must be and is as common
As any the most vulgar thing to sense
Take it to heart? Fie! 'tis a fault to heaven
Is death of fathers
This unprevailing woe
As of a father: for let the world take note
And with no less nobility of love
Than that which dearest father bears his son
In going back to school in Wittenberg
And we beseech you
Here
Let not thy mother lose her prayers
I pray thee
I shall in all my best obey you
Why
Be as ourself in Denmark. Madam
This gentle and unforced accord of Hamlet
Sits smiling to my heart: in grace whereof
Exeunt all but HAMLET
O
Thaw and resolve itself into a dew!
Or that the Everlasting had not fix'd
His canon 'gainst self-slaughter! O God! God!
How weary
Fie on't! ah fie! 'tis an unweeded garden
Possess it merely. That it should come to this!
But two months dead: nay
So excellent a king; that was
That he might not beteem the winds of heaven
Visit her face too roughly. Heaven and earth!
Must I remember? why
By what it fed on: and yet
Let me not think on't--Frailty
A little month
With which she follow'd my poor father's body
O
Than I to Hercules: within a month:
Ere yet the salt of most unrighteous tears
Had left the flushing in her galled eyes
With such dexterity to incestuous sheets!
It is not nor it cannot come to good:
But break
Enter HORATIO
Hail to your lordship!
I am glad to see you well:
Horatio
The same
Sir
And what make you from Wittenberg
My good lord--
I am very glad to see you. Good even
But what
A truant disposition
I would not hear your enemy say so
Against yourself: I know you are no truant.
But what is your affair in Elsinore?
We'll teach you to drink deep ere you depart.
My lord
I pray thee
I think it was to see my mother's wedding.
Indeed
Thrift
Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables.
Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven
Or ever I had seen that day
My father!--methinks I see my father.
Where
In my mind's eye
I saw him once; he was a goodly king.
He was a man
My lord
Saw? who?
My lord
The king my father!
Season your admiration for awhile
With an attent ear
For God's love
Two nights together had these gentlemen
Goes slow and stately by them: thrice he walk'd
By their oppress'd and fear-surprised eyes
Almost to jelly with the act of fear
In dreadful secrecy impart they did;
And I with them the third night kept the watch;
Where
These hands are not more like.
But where was this?
My lord
Did you not speak to it?
My lord
But answer made it none: yet once methought
It lifted up its head and did address
Itself to motion
But even then the morning cock crew loud
'Tis very strange.
As I do live
And we did think it writ down in our duty
To let you know of it.
Indeed
Hold you the watch to-night?
We do
Arm'd
Arm'd
From top to toe?
My lord
Then saw you not his face?
O
What
A countenance more in sorrow than in anger.
Pale or red?
Nay
And fix'd his eyes upon you?
Most constantly.
I would I had been there.
It would have much amazed you.
Very like
While one with moderate haste might tell a hundred.
Longer
Not when I saw't.
His beard was grizzled--no?
It was
I will watch to-night;
Perchance 'twill walk again.
I warrant it will.
If it assume my noble father's person
And bid me hold my peace. I pray you all
And whatsoever else shall hap to-night
I will requite your loves. So
Upon the platform
Our duty to your honour.
Your loves
Exeunt all but HAMLET
My father's spirit in arms! all is not well;
I doubt some foul play: would the night were come!
Till then sit still
Exit
SCENE III. A room in Polonius' house.
Enter LAERTES and OPHELIA
My necessaries are embark'd: farewell:
And
And convoy is assistant
Do you doubt that?
For Hamlet and the trifling of his favour
No more but so?
Think it no more;
For nature
In thews and bulk
Grows wide withal. Perhaps he loves you now
The virtue of his will: but you must fear
For he himself is subject to his birth:
He may not
The safety and health of this whole state;
And therefore must his choice be circumscribed
Unto the voice and yielding of that body
Whereof he is the head. Then if he says he loves you
As he in his particular act and place
May give his saying deed; which is no further
Than the main voice of Denmark goes withal.
Then weigh what loss your honour may sustain
To his unmaster'd importunity.
Fear it
The chariest maid is prodigal enough
Virtue itself 'scapes not calumnious strokes:
The canker galls the infants of the spring
Contagious blastments are most imminent.
Be wary then; best safety lies in fear:
Youth to itself rebels
I shall the effect of this good lesson keep
Whiles
O
I stay too long: but here my father comes.
Enter POLONIUS
A double blessing is a double grace
Yet here
The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail
And these few precepts in thy memory
See thou character. Give thy thoughts no tongue
Be thou familiar
Those friends thou hast
But do not dull thy palm with entertainment
Of each new-hatch'd
Of entrance to a quarrel
Give every man thy ear
Take each man's censure
Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy
For the apparel oft proclaims the man
Are of a most select and generous chief in that.
Neither a borrower nor a lender be;
For loan oft loses both itself and friend
This above all: to thine ownself be true
Farewell: my blessing season this in thee!
Most humbly do I take my leave
The time invites you; go; your servants tend.
Farewell
What I have said to you.
'Tis in my memory lock'd
Farewell.
Exit
What is't
So please you
Marry
'Tis told me
Given private time to you; and you yourself
Have of your audience been most free and bounteous:
If it be so
As it behoves my daughter and your honour.
What is between you? give me up the truth.
He hath
Of his affection to me.
Affection! pooh! you speak like a green girl
Do you believe his tenders
I do not know
Marry
That you have ta'en these tenders for true pay
Or--not to crack the wind of the poor phrase
My lord
In honourable fashion.
Ay
And hath given countenance to his speech
Ay
Lends the tongue vows: these blazes
Be somewhat scanter of your maiden presence;
Set your entreatments at a higher rate
Than a command to parley. For Lord Hamlet
And with a larger tether may he walk
Than may be given you: in few
I would not
Look to't
I shall obey
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The platform.
Enter HAMLET
The air bites shrewdly; it is very cold.
It is a nipping and an eager air.
What hour now?
I think it lacks of twelve.
No
Indeed? I heard it not: then it draws near the season
Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk.
A flourish of trumpets
What does this mean
The king doth wake to-night and takes his rouse
And
The triumph of his pledge.
Is it a custom?
Ay
But to my mind
And to the manner born
More honour'd in the breach than the observance.
This heavy-headed revel east and west
Makes us traduced and tax'd of other nations:
They clepe us drunkards
Soil our addition; and indeed it takes
From our achievements
So
By the o'ergrowth of some complexion
The form of plausive manners
Their virtues else--be they as pure as grace
Shall in the general censure take corruption
From that particular fault: the dram of eale
Doth all the noble substance of a doubt
To his own scandal.
Look
Enter Ghost
Angels and ministers of grace defend us!
Be thou a spirit of health or goblin damn'd
That I will speak to thee: I'll call thee Hamlet
Let me not burst in ignorance; but tell
Why thy canonized bones
Revisit'st thus the glimpses of the moon
So horridly to shake our disposition
With thoughts beyond the reaches of our souls?
Say
Ghost beckons HAMLET
It beckons you to go away with it
To you alone.
Look
It waves you to a more removed ground:
But do not go with it.
No
It will not speak; then I will follow it.
Do not
Why
I do not set my life in a pin's fee;
And for my soul
It waves me forth again: I'll follow it.
What if it tempt you toward the flood
That beetles o'er his base into the sea
And draw you into madness? think of it:
The very place puts toys of desperation
That looks so many fathoms to the sea
And hears it roar beneath.
It waves me still.
Go on; I'll follow thee.
You shall not go
Hold off your hands.
Be ruled; you shall not go.
My fate cries out
As hardy as the Nemean lion's nerve.
Still am I call'd. Unhand me
By heaven
I say
Exeunt Ghost and HAMLET
He waxes desperate with imagination.
Let's follow; 'tis not fit thus to obey him.
Have after. To what issue will this come?
Something is rotten in the state of Denmark.
Heaven will direct it.
Nay
Exeunt
SCENE V. Another part of the platform.
Enter GHOST and HAMLET
Where wilt thou lead me? speak; I'll go no further.
Mark me.
I will.
My hour is almost come
Must render up myself.
Alas
Pity me not
To what I shall unfold.
Speak; I am bound to hear.
So art thou to revenge
What?
I am thy father's spirit
Are burnt and purged away. But that I am forbid
To tell the secrets of my prison-house
Would harrow up thy soul
And each particular hair to stand on end
But this eternal blazon must not be
To ears of flesh and blood. List
If thou didst ever thy dear father love--
O God!
Revenge his foul and most unnatural murder.
Murder!
Murder most foul
But this most foul
Haste me to know't
As meditation or the thoughts of love
I find thee apt;
And duller shouldst thou be than the fat weed
That roots itself in ease on Lethe wharf
'Tis given out that
Is by a forged process of my death
Rankly abused: but know
Now wears his crown.
O my prophetic soul! My uncle!
Ay
O wicked wit and gifts
So to seduce!--won to his shameful lust
The will of my most seeming-virtuous queen:
O Hamlet
From me
That it went hand in hand even with the vow
I made to her in marriage
Upon a wretch whose natural gifts were poor
To those of mine!
But virtue
But
Brief let me be. Sleeping within my orchard
The leperous distilment; whose effect
Holds such an enmity with blood of man
That swift as quicksilver it courses through
The natural gates and alleys of the body
And curd
And a most instant tetter bark'd about
Thus was I
Of life
Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin
With all my imperfections on my head:
O
If thou hast nature in thee
Let not the royal bed of Denmark be
A couch for luxury and damned incest.
But
Against thy mother aught: leave her to heaven
And to those thorns that in her bosom lodge
The glow-worm shows the matin to be near
Adieu
Exit
O all you host of heaven! O earth! what else?
And shall I couple hell? O
And you
Ay
In this distracted globe. Remember thee!
Yea
I'll wipe away all trivial fond records
And thy commandment all alone shall live
Within the book and volume of my brain
O most pernicious woman!
O villain
My tables
At least I'm sure it may be so in Denmark:
Writing
So
It is 'Adieu

ACT II

Ay

My lord
No hat upon his head; his stockings foul'd

And with a look so piteous in purport
As if he had been loosed out of hell
To speak of horrors
Mad for thy love?
My lord
But truly
What said he?
He took me by the wrist and held me hard;
Then goes he to the length of all his arm;
And
As he would draw it. Long stay'd he so;
At last
And thrice his head thus waving up and down
As it did seem to shatter all his bulk
And end his being: that done
And
For out o' doors he went without their helps
Come
This is the very ecstasy of love
And leads the will to desperate undertakings
As oft as any passion under heaven
That does afflict our natures. I am sorry.
What
No
His access to me.
That hath made him mad.
I am sorry that with better heed and judgment
I had not quoted him: I fear'd he did but trifle
By heaven
To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions
As it is common for the younger sort
To lack discretion. Come
This must be known; which
move
More grief to hide than hate to utter love.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A room in the castle.
Enter KING CLAUDIUS
Welcome
Moreover that we much did long to see you
Our hasty sending. Something have you heard
Of Hamlet's transformation; so call it
Resembles that it was. What it should be
So much from the understanding of himself
Some little time: so by your companies
To draw him on to pleasures
Good gentlemen
And sure I am two men there are not living
To whom he more adheres. If it will please you
To show us so much gentry and good will
As to expend your time with us awhile
As fits a king's remembrance.
Both your majesties
Might
Than to entreaty.
But we both obey
To lay our service freely at your feet
Thanks
Thanks
And I beseech you instantly to visit
My too much changed son. Go

Pleasant and helpful to him!
Ay

On Fortinbras; which he

Whereon old Norway
With an entreaty

Through your dominions for this enterprise
As therein are set down.
It likes us well;
And at our more consider'd time well read
Meantime we thank you for your well-took labour:
Go to your rest; at night we'll feast together:
Most welcome home!

When he lay couched in the ominous horse

With blood of fathers

Now I am alone.
O
Is it not monstrous that this player here
That from her working all his visage wann'd

For Hecuba!
What's Hecuba to him
That I have? He would drown the stage with tears
And cleave the general ear with horrid speech
The very faculties of eyes and ears. Yet I
A damn'd defeat was made. Am I a coward?
Who calls me villain? breaks my pate across?
Plucks off my beard
Tweaks me by the nose? gives me the lie i' the throat
Ha!
'Swounds
But I am pigeon-liver'd and lack gall
To make oppression bitter
I should have fatted all the region kites
With this slave's offal: bloody
Remorseless
O
Why
Fie upon't! foh! About
That guilty creatures sitting at a play
Have by the very cunning of the scene
Been struck so to the soul that presently
They have proclaim'd their malefactions;
For murder
With most miraculous organ. I'll have these players
Play something like the murder of my father
Before mine uncle: I'll observe his looks;
I'll tent him to the quick: if he but blench
May be the devil: and the devil hath power
To assume a pleasing shape; yea
Out of my weakness and my melancholy
More relative than this: the play 's the thing
Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the king.
Exit
ACT III
SCENE I. A room in the castle.
Enter KING CLAUDIUS
And can you
With turbulent and dangerous lunacy?
He does confess he feels himself distracted;
But from what cause he will by no means speak.
Nor do we find him forward to be sounded
Of his true state.
Did he receive you well?
Most like a gentleman.
But with much forcing of his disposition.
Niggard of question; but
Did you assay him?
To any pastime?
Madam
We o'er-raught on the way: of these we told him;
And there did seem in him a kind of joy
To hear of it: they are about the court
This night to play before him.
'Tis most true:
And he beseech'd me to entreat your majesties
To hear and see the matter.
With all my heart; and it doth much content me
To hear him so inclined.
Good gentlemen
We shall
Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
Sweet Gertrude
For we have closely sent for Hamlet hither
Affront Ophelia:
Her father and myself
That thus he suffers for.
I shall obey you.
And for your part
That your good beauties be the happy cause
Of Hamlet's wildness: so shall I hope your virtues
Will bring him to his wonted way again
Madam
Exit QUEEN GERTRUDE
Ophelia
To OPHELIA
Read on this book;
That show of such an exercise may colour
Your loneliness. We are oft to blame in this
'Tis too much proved--that with devotion's visage
And pious action we do sugar o'er
The devil himself.
[Aside]          O
How smart a lash that speech doth give my conscience!
The harlot's cheek
Than is my deed to my most painted word:
O heavy burthen!
I hear him coming: let's withdraw
Exeunt KING CLAUDIUS and POLONIUS
Enter HAMLET
To be
Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer
The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune
No more; and by a sleep to say we end
The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks
That flesh is heir to
Devoutly to be wish'd. To die
To sleep: perchance to dream: ay
For in that sleep of death what dreams may come
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil
That makes calamity of so long life;
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time
That patient merit of the unworthy takes
With a bare bodkin? who would fardels bear
No traveller returns
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all;
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought
With this regard their currents turn awry
The fair Ophelia! Nymph
Be all my sins remember'd.
Good my lord
I humbly thank you; well
My lord
I pray you
No
I never gave you aught.
My honour'd lord
And
As made the things more rich: their perfume lost
Rich gifts wax poor when givers prove unkind.
There
Ha
My lord?
Are you fair?
What means your lordship?
That if you be honest and fair
admit no discourse to your beauty.
Could beauty
with honesty?
Ay
transform honesty from what it is to a bawd than the
force of honesty can translate beauty into his
likeness: this was sometime a paradox
time gives it proof. I did love you once.
Indeed
You should not have believed me; for virtue cannot
so inoculate our old stock but we shall relish of
it: I loved you not.
I was the more deceived.
Get thee to a nunnery: why wouldst thou be a
breeder of sinners? I am myself indifferent honest;
but yet I could accuse me of such things that it
were better my mother had not borne me: I am very
proud
my beck than I have thoughts to put them in
in. What should such fellows as I do crawling
between earth and heaven? We are arrant knaves
Where's your father?
At home

fool no where but in's own house. Farewell.

another: you jig

made me mad. I say

O
The courtier's
The expectancy and rose of the fair state
And I
That unmatch'd form and feature of blown youth
Blasted with ecstasy: O
Re-enter KING CLAUDIUS and POLONIUS
Love! his affections do not that way tend;
Nor what he spake
And I do doubt the hatch and the disclose
Will be some danger: which for to prevent
Thus set it down: he shall with speed to England
Haply the seas and countries different
With variable objects shall expel
This something-settled matter in his heart
From fashion of himself. What think you on't?
It shall do well: but yet do I believe
The origin and commencement of his grief
Sprung from neglected love. How now
You need not tell us what Lord Hamlet said;
We heard it all. My lord
But
Let his queen mother all alone entreat him
To show his grief: let her be round with him;
And I'll be placed
Of all their conference. If she find him not
Your wisdom best shall think.
It shall be so:
Madness in great ones must not unwatch'd go.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A hall in the castle.
Enter HAMLET and Players
Speak the speech
you
town-crier spoke my lines. Nor do not saw the air
too much with your hand
for in the very torrent
a temperance that may give it smoothness. O
offends me to the soul to hear a robustious
periwig-pated fellow tear a passion to tatters
very rags
for the most part are capable of nothing but
inexplicable dumbshows and noise: I would have such
a fellow whipped for o'erdoing Termagant; it
out-herods Herod: pray you
I warrant your honour.
Be not too tame neither
be your tutor: suit the action to the word
word to the action; with this special o'erstep not
the modesty of nature: for any thing so overdone is
from the purpose of playing
first and now
mirror up to nature; to show virtue her own feature
the time his form and pressure. Now this overdone
laugh
censure of the which one must in your allowance

players that I have seen play
praise
the gait of Christian
strutted and bellowed that I have thought some of

question of the play be then to be considered:

Here

As e'er my conversation coped withal.
O
Nay
For what advancement may I hope from thee
That no revenue hast but thy good spirits
No
Where thrift may follow fawning. Dost thou hear?
Since my dear soul was mistress of her choice
And could of men distinguish
Hath seal'd thee for herself; for thou hast been
As one
Hast ta'en with equal thanks: and blest are those
Whose blood and judgment are so well commingled
To sound what stop she please. Give me that man
That is not passion's slave
In my heart's core
There is a play to-night before the king;
One scene of it comes near the circumstance
Which I have told thee of my father's death:
I prithee
Observe mine uncle: if his occulted guilt
Do not itself unkennel in one speech
As Vulcan's stithy. Give him heedful note;
For I mine eyes will rivet to his face
In censure of his seeming.
Well
If he steal aught the whilst this play is playing
They are coming to the play; I must be idle:
Get you a place.

How fares our cousin Hamlet?
Excellent

Is this a prologue
'Tis brief
As woman's love.
Enter two Players
Full thirty times hath Phoebus' cart gone round
Neptune's salt wash and Tellus' orbed ground
About the world have times twelve thirties been
Unite commutual in most sacred bands.
So many journeys may the sun and moon
Make us again count o'er ere love be done!
But
For women's fear and love holds quantity;
In neither aught
Now
And as my love is sized
Where love is great
Where little fears grow great
'Faith
My operant powers their functions leave to do:
And thou shalt live in this fair world behind
For husband shalt thou--
O
Such love must needs be treason in my breast:
In second husband let me be accurst!
None wed the second but who kill'd the first.
[Aside]  Wormwood
The instances that second marriage move
Are base respects of thrift
A second time I kill my husband dead
I do believe you think what now you speak;
But what we do determine oft we break.
Purpose is but the slave to memory
Which now
But fall
Most necessary 'tis that we forget
To pay ourselves what to ourselves is debt:
What to ourselves in passion we propose
The violence of either grief or joy
Their own enactures with themselves destroy:
Where joy most revels
Grief joys
This world is not for aye
That even our loves should with our fortunes change;
For 'tis a question left us yet to prove
The great man down
The poor advanced makes friends of enemies.
And hitherto doth love on fortune tend;
For who not needs shall never lack a friend
But
That our devices still are overthrown;
Our thoughts are ours
So think thou wilt no second husband wed;
But die thy thoughts when thy first lord is dead.
Nor earth to me give food
Sport and repose lock from me day and night!
To desperation turn my trust and hope!
An anchor's cheer in prison be my scope!
Each opposite that blanks the face of joy
Meet what I would have well and it destroy!
Both here and hence pursue me lasting strife
If she should break it now!
'Tis deeply sworn. Sweet
My spirits grow dull
The tedious day with sleep.
Sleeps
Sleep rock thy brain
Exit

Contagion to this world: now could I drink hot blood
Would quake to look on. Soft! now to my mother.
O heart

My tongue and soul in this be hypocrites;

SCENE III. A room in the castle.
Enter KING CLAUDIUS
I like him not
To let his madness range. Therefore prepare you;
I your commission will forthwith dispatch
The terms of our estate may not endure
Hazard so dangerous as doth hourly grow
Out of his lunacies.
We will ourselves provide:
Most holy and religious fear it is
To keep those many many bodies safe
That live and feed upon your majesty.
The single and peculiar life is bound
That spirit upon whose weal depend and rest
The lives of many. The cease of majesty
Dies not alone; but
What's near it with it: it is a massy wheel
Are mortised and adjoin'd; which
Did the king sigh
Arm you
For we will fetters put upon this fear
We will haste us.
Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
Enter POLONIUS
My lord
Behind the arras I'll convey myself
And
The speech
I'll call upon you ere you go to bed
Thanks
Exit POLONIUS
O
It hath the primal eldest curse upon't
My stronger guilt defeats my strong intent;
And
Were thicker than itself with brother's blood
To wash it white as snow? Whereto serves mercy
But to confront the visage of offence?
And what's in prayer but this two-fold force
My fault is past. But
Can serve my turn? 'Forgive me my foul murder'?
That cannot be; since I am still possess'd
Of those effects for which I did the murder
May one be pardon'd and retain the offence?
In the corrupted currents of this world
Offence's gilded hand may shove by justice
Buys out the law: but 'tis not so above;
There is no shuffling
In his true nature; and we ourselves compell'd
Try what repentance can: what can it not?
Yet what can it when one can not repent?
O wretched state! O bosom black as death!
O limed soul
Bow
All may be well.
Retires and kneels
Enter HAMLET
Now might I do it pat
And now I'll do't. And so he goes to heaven;
And so am I revenged. That would be scann'd:
A villain kills my father; and for that
To heaven.
O
He took my father grossly
With all his crimes broad blown
And how his audit stands who knows save heaven?
But in our circumstance and course of thought
No!
Up
When he is drunk asleep
At gaming
That has no relish of salvation in't;
Then trip him
As hell
This physic but prolongs thy sickly days.
Exit
[Rising]  My words fly up
Words without thoughts never to heaven go.
Exit
SCENE IV. The Queen's closet.

No

Help

O

As kill a king!
Ay
Lifts up the array and discovers POLONIUS
Thou wretched
I took thee for thy better: take thy fortune;
Thou find'st to be too busy is some danger.
Leave wringing of your hands: peace! sit you down
That it is proof and bulwark against sense.
What have I done
In noise so rude against me?
Such an act
That blurs the grace and blush of modesty
From the fair forehead of an innocent love
And sets a blister there
As false as dicers' oaths: O
As from the body of contraction plucks
The very soul
A rhapsody of words: heaven's face doth glow:
Yea
Ay me
Look here
See
Hyperion's curls; the front of Jove himself;
An eye like Mars
A station like the herald Mercury
New-lighted on a heaven-kissing hill;
A combination and a form indeed
This was your husband. Look you now
Here is your husband; like a mildew'd ear
Could you on this fair mountain leave to feed
You cannot call it love; for at your age
The hey-day in the blood is tame
Would step from this to this? Sense
Is apoplex'd; for madness would not err
But it reserved some quantity of choice
That thus hath cozen'd you at hoodman-blind?
Eyes without feeling
Could not so mope.
O shame! where is thy blush? Rebellious hell
When the compulsive ardour gives the charge
And reason panders will.
O Hamlet
Thou turn'st mine eyes into my very soul;
And there I see such black and grained spots
As will not leave their tinct.
Nay
In the rank sweat of an enseamed bed
Over the nasty sty
O
These words
No more
A murderer and a villain;
A slave that is not twentieth part the tithe
Of your precedent lord; a vice of kings;
A cutpurse of the empire and the rule
No more!
A king of shreds and patches
Enter Ghost
Save me
Alas
Do you not come your tardy son to chide
The important acting of your dread command? O
Do not forget: this visitation
Is but to whet thy almost blunted purpose.
But
O
Conceit in weakest bodies strongest works:
Speak to her
How is it with you
Alas
And with the incorporal air do hold discourse?
Forth at your eyes your spirits wildly peep;
And
Sprinkle cool patience. Whereon do you look?
On him
His form and cause conjoin'd
Lest with this piteous action you convert
My stern effects: then what I have to do
Will want true colour; tears perchance for blood.
To whom do you speak this?
Do you see nothing there?
Nothing at all; yet all that is I see.
Nor did you nothing hear?
No
Why
My father
Look
Exit Ghost
This the very coinage of your brain:
This bodiless creation ecstasy
Is very cunning in.
Ecstasy!
My pulse
That I have utter'd: bring me to the test
Would gambol from. Mother
It will but skin and film the ulcerous place
Repent what's past; avoid what is to come;
And do not spread the compost on the weeds
For in the fatness of these pursy times
Virtue itself of vice must pardon beg
O Hamlet
O
Good night: but go not to mine uncle's bed;
Assume a virtue
That monster
He likewise gives a frock or livery
To the next abstinence: the next more easy;
For use almost can change the stamp of nature
With wondrous potency. Once more
And when you are desirous to be bless'd
I do repent: but heaven hath pleased it so
I will bestow him
The death I gave him. So
I must be cruel
Thus bad begins and worse remains behind.
One word more
What shall I do?
Not this
Let the bloat king tempt you again to bed;
Pinch wanton on your cheek; call you his mouse;
And let him
For who
No
Let the birds fly
Be thou assured
What thou hast said to me.
I must to England; you know that?
Alack
There's letters seal'd: and my two schoolfellows
For 'tis the sport to have the engineer
Hoist with his own petard: and 't shall go hard
But I will delve one yard below their mines
This man shall set me packing:
I'll lug the guts into the neighbour room.
Mother
Is now most still
Come
Good night
Exeunt severally; HAMLET dragging in POLONIUS
ACT IV
SCENE I. A room in the castle.
Enter KING CLAUDIUS
There's matter in these sighs
You must translate: 'tis fit we understand them.
Where is your son?
Bestow this place on us a little while.
Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
Ah
What
Mad as the sea and wind
Which is the mightier: in his lawless fit
And
The unseen good old man.
O heavy deed!
It had been so with us
His liberty is full of threats to all;
To you yourself
Alas
It will be laid to us
Should have kept short
But
Even on the pith of Life. Where is he gone?
To draw apart the body he hath kill'd:
O'er whom his very madness
Among a mineral of metals base
O Gertrude
The sun no sooner shall the mountains touch
We must
Re-enter ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
Friends both
Hamlet in madness hath Polonius slain
Go seek him out; speak fair
Into the chapel. I pray you
Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
Come
And let them know
My soul is full of discord and dismay.
Exeunt

O

Compounded it with dust
Tell us where 'tis
And bear it to the chapel.

That I can keep your counsel and not mine own.
Besides
replication should be made by the son of a king?
Take you me for a sponge
Ay
rewards
king best service in the end: he keeps them
an ape
be last swallowed: when he needs what you have
gleaned
shall be dry again.
I understand you not

My lord
with us to the king.

the body. The king is a thing--
A thing
Of nothing: bring me to him. Hide fox

SCENE III. Another room in the castle.
Enter KING CLAUDIUS
I have sent to seek him
How dangerous is it that this man goes loose!
Yet must not we put the strong law on him:
He's loved of the distracted multitude
And where tis so
Deliberate pause: diseases desperate grown
By desperate appliance are relieved
Enter ROSENCRANTZ
How now! what hath befall'n?
Where the dead body is bestow'd
But where is he?
Without
Bring him before us.
Ho
Enter HAMLET and GUILDENSTERN
Now
At supper.
At supper! where?
Not where he eats
convocation of politic worms are e'en at him. Your
worm is your only emperor for diet: we fat all
creatures else to fat us
maggots: your fat king and your lean beggar is but
variable service
that's the end.
Alas
A man may fish with the worm that hath eat of a
king
What dost you mean by this?
Nothing but to show you how a king may go a
progress through the guts of a beggar.
Where is Polonius?
In heaven; send hither to see: if your messenger
find him not there
yourself. But indeed
this month
stairs into the lobby.
Go seek him there.
To some Attendants
He will stay till ye come.

Hamlet
Which we do tender
For that which thou hast done
With fiery quickness: therefore prepare thyself;
The bark is ready
For England.
For England!
Ay
Good.
So is it
I see a cherub that sees them. But
England! Farewell
Thy loving father
My mother: father and mother is man and wife; man
and wife is one flesh; and so
Exit
Follow him at foot; tempt him with speed aboard;
Delay it not; I'll have him hence to-night:
Away! for every thing is seal'd and done
That else leans on the affair: pray you
Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
And
As my great power thereof may give thee sense
After the Danish sword
Pays homage to us--thou mayst not coldly set
Our sovereign process; which imports at full
For like the hectic in my blood he rages
Exit
SCENE IV. A plain in Denmark.
Enter FORTINBRAS
Go
Tell him that
Craves the conveyance of a promised march
Over his kingdom. You know the rendezvous.
If that his majesty would aught with us
And let him know so.
I will do't
Go softly on.
Exeunt FORTINBRAS and Soldiers
Enter HAMLET
Good sir
They are of Norway
How purposed
Against some part of Poland.
Who commands them
The nephews to old Norway
Goes it against the main of Poland
Truly to speak
That hath in it no profit but the name.
To pay five ducats
Nor will it yield to Norway or the Pole
A ranker rate
Why
Yes
Two thousand souls and twenty thousand ducats
Will not debate the question of this straw:
This is the imposthume of much wealth and peace
Why the man dies. I humbly thank you
God be wi' you
Exit
Wilt please you go
I'll be with you straight go a little before.
Exeunt all except HAMLET
How all occasions do inform against me
Be but to sleep and feed? a beast
Sure
That capability and god-like reason
To fust in us unused. Now
Bestial oblivion
Of thinking too precisely on the event
And ever three parts coward
Why yet I live to say 'This thing's to do;'
Sith I have cause and will and strength and means
To do't. Examples gross as earth exhort me:
Witness this army of such mass and charge
Led by a delicate and tender prince
Makes mouths at the invisible event
To all that fortune
Is not to stir without great argument
When honour's at the stake. How stand I then
The imminent death of twenty thousand men
Whereon the numbers cannot try the cause
To hide the slain? O
Exit
SCENE V. Elsinore. A room in the castle.
Enter QUEEN GERTRUDE
I will not speak with her.
She is importunate
Her mood will needs be pitied.
What would she have?
She speaks much of her father; says she hears
There's tricks i' the world; and hems
Spurns enviously at straws; speaks things in doubt
The hearers to collection; they aim at it
Which
yield them
'Twere good she were spoken with; for she may strew
Dangerous conjectures in ill-breeding minds.
Let her come in.
Exit HORATIO
To my sick soul
So full of artless jealousy is guilt
Re-enter HORATIO
Where is the beauteous majesty of Denmark?
How now
[Sings]
How should I your true love know
From another one?
By his cockle hat and staff

He is dead and gone

Nay

Sings
White his shroud as the mountain snow

Which bewept to the grave did go

daughter. Lord
what we may be. God be at your table!

Pretty Ophelia!

Young men will do't

good night

All from her father's death. O Gertrude

With pestilent speeches of his father's death;

In ear and ear. O my dear Gertrude
Gives me superfluous death.

I pray you
We will
They retire without the door
I thank you: keep the door. O thou vile king
Calmly
That drop of blood that's calm proclaims me bastard
Even here
Of my true mother.
What is the cause
Let him go
There's such divinity doth hedge a king
Speak
Where is my father?
Dead.
But not by him.
Let him demand his fill.
How came he dead? I'll not be juggled with:
To hell
Conscience and grace
I dare damnation. To this point I stand
Most thoroughly for my father.
Who shall stay you?
My will
And for my means
Good Laertes
Of your dear father's death
None but his enemies.
Will you know them then?
To his good friends thus wide I'll ope my arms;
And like the kind life-rendering pelican
Why
Like a good child and a true gentleman.
That I am guiltless of your father's death
As day does to your eye.
[Within]                Let her come in.
How now! what noise is that?
Re-enter OPHELIA
O heat
By heaven
Dear maid
O heavens! is't possible
Should be as moral as an old man's life?
Nature is fine in love
After the thing it loves.

And in his grave rain'd many a tear:--
Fare you well

SCENE VI. Another room in the castle.
Enter HORATIO and a Servant
What are they that would speak with me?
Sailors
