Exit Servant
I do not know from what part of the world
I should be greeted
Enter Sailors
God bless you
Let him bless thee too.
He shall
you
bound for England; if your name be Horatio
let to know it is.
[Reads]  'Horatio
this
they have letters for him. Ere we were two days old
at sea
chase. Finding ourselves too slow of sail
a compelled valour
them: on the instant they got clear of our ship; so
I alone became their prisoner. They have dealt with
me like thieves of mercy: but they knew what they
did; I am to do a good turn for them. Let the king
have the letters I have sent; and repair thou to me
with as much speed as thou wouldst fly death. I
have words to speak in thine ear will make thee
dumb; yet are they much too light for the bore of
the matter. These good fellows will bring thee
where I am. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern hold their
course for England: of them I have much to tell
thee. Farewell.
'He that thou knowest thine
Come
And do't the speedier
To him from whom you brought them.
Exeunt
SCENE VII. Another room in the castle.
Enter KING CLAUDIUS and LAERTES
Now must your conscience my acquaintance seal
Pursued my life.
It well appears: but tell me
Why you proceeded not against these feats
O
Which may to you
Lives almost by his looks; and for myself--
My virtue or my plague
She's so conjunctive to my life and soul
Who
And so have I a noble father lost;
A sister driven into desperate terms
For her perfections: but my revenge will come.
Break not your sleeps for that: you must not think
That we are made of stuff so flat and dull
That we can let our beard be shook with danger
And think it pastime. You shortly shall hear more:
I loved your father
And that
Enter a Messenger
How now! what news?
Letters
This to your majesty; this to the queen.
From Hamlet! who brought them?
Sailors
They were given me by Claudio; he received them
Of him that brought them.
Laertes
Exit Messenger
Reads
'High and mighty
your kingdom. To-morrow shall I beg leave to see
your kingly eyes: when I shall
pardon thereunto
and more strange return.                  'HAMLET.'
What should this mean? Are all the rest come back?
Or is it some abuse
Know you the hand?
'Tis Hamlets character. 'Naked!
And in a postscript here
Can you advise me?
I'm lost in it
It warms the very sickness in my heart
If it be so
As how should it be so? how otherwise?--
Will you be ruled by me?
Ay
So you will not o'errule me to a peace.
To thine own peace. If he be now return'd
No more to undertake it
To an exploit
And for his death no wind of blame shall breathe
And call it accident.
My lord
The rather
That I might be the organ.
It falls right.
You have been talk'd of since your travel much
Wherein
Did not together pluck such envy from him
As did that one
What part is that
A very riband in the cap of youth
The light and careless livery that it wears
Than settled age his sables and his weeds
I've seen myself
Had witchcraft in't; he grew unto his seat;
And to such wondrous doing brought his horse
With the brave beast: so far he topp'd my thought
A Norman was't?
A Norman.
Upon my life
The very same.
I know him well: he is the brooch indeed
And gem of all the nation.
He made confession of you
For art and exercise in your defence
And for your rapier most especially
Did Hamlet so envenom with his envy
That he could nothing do but wish and beg
Your sudden coming o'er
Now
What out of this
Laertes
Or are you like the painting of a sorrow
Why ask you this?
Not that I think you did not love your father;
But that I know love is begun by time;
And that I see
There lives within the very flame of love
A kind of wick or snuff that will abate it;
And nothing is at a like goodness still;
For goodness
We should do when we would; for this 'would' changes
And hath abatements and delays as many
As there are tongues
And then this 'should' is like a spendthrift sigh
Hamlet comes back: what would you undertake
More than in words?
To cut his throat i' the church.
No place
Revenge should have no bounds. But
Hamlet return'd shall know you are come home:
We'll put on those shall praise your excellence
And set a double varnish on the fame
The Frenchman gave you
And wager on your heads: he
A sword unbated
Requite him for your father.
I will do't:
And
I bought an unction of a mountebank
Under the moon
That is but scratch'd withal: I'll touch my point
With this contagion
Let's further think of this;
Weigh what convenience both of time and means
May fit us to our shape: if this should fail
Should have a back or second
We'll make a solemn wager on your cunnings: I ha't.
When in your motion you are hot and dry--
As make your bouts more violent to that end--
And that he calls for drink
A chalice for the nonce
Enter QUEEN GERTRUDE
How now
One woe doth tread upon another's heel
Drown'd! O
There is a willow grows aslant a brook
There with fantastic garlands did she come
Of crow-flowers
That liberal shepherds give a grosser name
There
Clambering to hang
When down her weedy trophies and herself
Fell in the weeping brook. Her clothes spread wide;
And
Which time she chanted snatches of old tunes;
As one incapable of her own distress
Unto that element: but long it could not be
Till that her garments
To muddy death.
Alas
Drown'd
Too much of water hast thou
It is our trick; nature her custom holds
I have a speech of fire
Exit
Let's follow
How much I had to do to calm his rage!
Now fear I this will give it start again;
Therefore let's follow.
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. A churchyard.
Enter two Clowns
Is she to be buried in Christian burial that
wilfully seeks her own salvation?
I tell thee she is: and therefore make her grave
straight: the crowner hath sat on her
Christian burial.
How can that be
own defence?
Why
It must be 'se offendendo;' it cannot be else. For
here lies the point:  if I drown myself wittingly
is
herself wittingly.
Nay
Give me leave. Here lies the water; good: here
stands the man; good; if the man go to this water
goes
and drown him
that is not guilty of his own death shortens not his own life.
But is this law?
Ay
Will you ha' the truth on't? If this had not been
a gentlewoman
Christian burial.
Why
great folk should have countenance in this world to
drown or hang themselves
Christian. Come
gentleman but gardeners
they hold up Adam's profession.
Was he a gentleman?
He was the first that ever bore arms.
Why
What
Scripture? The Scripture says 'Adam digged:'
could he dig without arms? I'll put another

purpose
Go to.
What is he that builds stronger than either the
mason
The gallows-maker; for that frame outlives a
thousand tenants.
I like thy wit well
does well; but how does it well? it does well to

gallows is built stronger than the church: argal
'Who builds stronger than a mason

Ay
Marry

He digs and sings
In youth

Custom hath made it in him a property of easiness.
'Tis e'en so: the hand of little employment hath
the daintier sense.

One that was a woman

Why
he will keep out water a great while; and your water

Here's a skull now; this skull has lain in the earth

A whoreson mad fellow's it was: whose do you think it was?
Nay

That is Laertes
What ceremony else?
Her obsequies have been as far enlarged

And
Till the last trumpet: for charitable prayers
Yet here she is allow'd her virgin crants
Of bell and burial.
Must there no more be done?
No more be done:
We should profane the service of the dead
To sing a requiem and such rest to her
As to peace-parted souls.
Lay her i' the earth:
And from her fair and unpolluted flesh
May violets spring! I tell thee
What
Sweets to the sweet: farewell!

O

Leaps into the grave

Conjures the wandering stars

Leaps into the grave
The devil take thy soul!

SCENE II. A hall in the castle.
Enter HAMLET and HORATIO
So much for this
You do remember all the circumstance?
Remember it
Sir
Worse than the mutines in the bilboes. Rashly
There's a divinity that shapes our ends
That is most certain.
Up from my cabin
Groped I to find out them; had my desire.
Finger'd their packet
To mine own room again; making so bold
Their grand commission; where I found
O royal knavery!--an exact command
Importing Denmark's health and England's too
Is't possible?
Here's the commission: read it at more leisure.
But wilt thou hear me how I did proceed?
I beseech you.
Being thus be-netted round with villanies
Ere I could make a prologue to my brains
I once did hold it
How to forget that learning
It did me yeoman's service: wilt thou know
The effect of what I wrote?
Ay
An earnest conjuration from the king
And stand a comma 'tween their amities
How was this seal'd?
Why
I had my father's signet in my purse
Folded the writ up in form of the other
Was our sea-fight; and what to this was sequent
Thou know'st already.
So Guildenstern and Rosencrantz go to't.
Why
They are not near my conscience; their defeat
Does by their own insinuation grow:
'Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes
Between the pass and fell incensed points
Of mighty opposites.
Why
Does it not
He that hath kill'd my king and whored my mother
In further evil?
It must be shortly known to him from England
What is the issue of the business there.
It will be short: the interim is mine;
And a man's life's no more than to say 'One.'
But I am very sorry
For
The portraiture of his: I'll court his favours.
But
Into a towering passion.
Peace! who comes here?
Enter OSRIC
Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark.
I humbly thank you
No
Thy state is the more gracious; for 'tis a vice to
know him. He hath much land
beast be lord of beasts
the king's mess: 'tis a chough; but
Sweet lord
should impart a thing to you from his majesty.
I will receive it
spirit. Put your bonnet to his right use; 'tis for the head.
I thank your lordship
No
northerly.
It is indifferent cold
But yet methinks it is very sultry and hot for my
complexion.
Exceedingly
'twere

I beseech you

Sir
me

Sir
though

Sir?

You will do't

He does well to commend it himself; there are no

This lapwing runs away with the shell on his head.
He did comply with his dug

My lord

the hall: he sends to know if your pleasure hold to

You will lose this wager

Come

Give me your pardon
But pardon't
This presence knows
With sore distraction. What I have done
Roughly awake
Was't Hamlet wrong'd Laertes? Never Hamlet:
If Hamlet from himself be ta'en away
Who does it
His madness is poor Hamlet's enemy.
Sir
Free me so far in your most generous thoughts
I am satisfied in nature
To my revenge: but in my terms of honour
I stand aloof; and will no reconcilement
I embrace it freely;
And will this brother's wager frankly play.
Give us the foils. Come on.
Come
I'll be your foil
Your skill shall
You mock me
No
Give them the foils
Very well
Your grace hath laid the odds o' the weaker side.
I do not fear it; I have seen you both:
But since he is better'd
This is too heavy
This likes me well. These foils have all a length?
They prepare to play
Ay

In Denmark's crown have worn. Give me the cups;

LAERTES wounds HAMLET; then in scuffling

Nay
QUEEN GERTRUDE falls
Look to the queen there

How is't
Why
I am justly kill'd with mine own treachery.
How does the queen?
She swounds to see them bleed.
No
The drink
Dies
O villany! Ho! let the door be lock'd:
Treachery! Seek it out.
It is here
No medicine in the world can do thee good;
In thee there is not half an hour of life;
The treacherous instrument is in thy hand
Hath turn'd itself on me lo
I can no more: the king
The point!--envenom'd too!
Then

O
Here

KING CLAUDIUS dies
He is justly served;
It is a poison temper'd by himself.
Exchange forgiveness with me
Mine and my father's death come not upon thee
Dies
Heaven make thee free of it! I follow thee.
I am dead
You that look pale and tremble at this chance
But let it be. Horatio
Thou livest; report me and my cause aright
To the unsatisfied.
Never believe it:
I am more an antique Roman than a Dane:
Here's yet some liquor left.
As thou'rt a man
O good Horatio
If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart
Absent thee from felicity awhile
March afar off
What warlike noise is this?
Young Fortinbras
This warlike volley.
O
The potent poison quite o'er-crows my spirit:
I cannot live to hear the news from England;
But I do prophesy the election lights
On Fortinbras: he has my dying voice;
So tell him
Dies
Now cracks a noble heart. Good night sweet prince:
And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!
Why does the drum come hither?
March within
Enter FORTINBRAS
Where is this sight?
What is it ye would see?
If aught of woe or wonder
This quarry cries on havoc. O proud death
So bloodily hast struck?
The sight is dismal;
And our affairs from England come too late:
The ears are senseless that should give us hearing
Where should we have our thanks?
Not from his mouth
He never gave commandment for their death.
But since
High on a stage be placed to the view;
And let me speak to the yet unknowing world
How these things came about: so shall you hear
Of carnal
Fall'n on the inventors' reads: all this can I
Truly deliver.
Let us haste to hear it
For me
I have some rights of memory in this kingdom
Of that I shall have also cause to speak
But let this same be presently perform'd
On plots and errors
Let four captains
Bear Hamlet
For he was likely
Speak loudly for him.
Take up the bodies: such a sight as this
Becomes the field
Go
A dead march. Exeunt
ACT I
PROLOGUE
Enter Chorus
O for a Muse of fire
The brightest heaven of invention
And monarchs to behold the swelling scene!
Then should the warlike Harry
Crouch for employment. But pardon
On this unworthy scaffold to bring forth
So great an object: can this cockpit hold
The vasty fields of France? or may we cram
Within this wooden O the very casques
That did affright the air at Agincourt?
O
Attest in little place a million;
And let us
Suppose within the girdle of these walls
Are now confined two mighty monarchies
The perilous narrow ocean parts asunder:
Piece out our imperfections with your thoughts;
Into a thousand parts divide on man
Think when we talk of horses
Printing their proud hoofs i' the receiving earth;
For 'tis your thoughts that now must deck our kings
Into an hour-glass: for the which supply
Who prologue-like your humble patience pray
Exit
SCENE I. London. An ante-chamber in the KING'S palace.
Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY
My lord
Was like
Did push it out of farther question.
But how
It must be thought on. If it pass against us
For all the temporal lands which men devout
By testament have given to the church
Would they strip from us; being valued thus:
As much as would maintain
And
A hundred almshouses right well supplied;
And to the coffers of the king beside
This would drink deep.
'Twould drink the cup and all.
But what prevention?
The king is full of grace and fair regard.
And a true lover of the holy church.
The courses of his youth promised it not.
The breath no sooner left his father's body
Consideration
And whipp'd the offending Adam out of him
Never was such a sudden scholar made;
Never came reformation in a flood
Nor never Hydra-headed wilfulness
So soon did lose his seat and all at once
As in this king.
We are blessed in the change.
Hear him but reason in divinity
You would desire the king were made a prelate:
Hear him debate of commonwealth affairs
List his discourse of war
A fearful battle render'd you in music:
Turn him to any cause of policy
So that the art and practic part of life
Must be the mistress to this theoric:
Which is a wonder how his grace should glean it
From open haunts and popularity.
The strawberry grows underneath the nettle
And wholesome berries thrive and ripen best
Neighbour'd by fruit of baser quality:
And so the prince obscured his contemplation
Under the veil of wildness; which
It must be so; for miracles are ceased;
And therefore we must needs admit the means
How things are perfected.
But
Urged by the commons? Doth his majesty
Incline to it
He seems indifferent
Than cherishing the exhibiters against us;
For I have made an offer to his majesty
And in regard of causes now in hand
Than ever at one time the clergy yet
Did to his predecessors part withal.
How did this offer seem received
With good acceptance of his majesty;
Save that there was not time enough to hear
Of his true titles to some certain dukedoms
And generally to the crown and seat of France
Derived from Edward
What was the impediment that broke this off?
The French ambassador upon that instant
Craved audience; and the hour
To give him hearing: is it four o'clock?
It is.
Then go we in
Which I could with a ready guess declare
I'll wait upon you
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. The Presence chamber.
Enter KING HENRY V
Where is my gracious Lord of Canterbury?
Not here in presence.
Send for him
Shall we call in the ambassador
Not yet
That task our thoughts
Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY
God and his angels guard your sacred throne
And make you long become it!
Sure
My learned lord
And justly and religiously unfold
Why the law Salique that they have in France
Or should
And God forbid
With opening titles miscreate
Suits not in native colours with the truth;
For God doth know how many now in health
Shall drop their blood in approbation
Of what your reverence shall incite us to.
Therefore take heed how you impawn our person
We charge you
For never two such kingdoms did contend
Without much fall of blood; whose guiltless drops
Are every one a woe
'Gainst him whose wrong gives edge unto the swords
That make such waste in brief mortality.
Under this conjuration
For we will hear
That what you speak is in your conscience wash'd
As pure as sin with baptism.
Then hear me
To this imperial throne. There is no bar
To make against your highness' claim to France
But this
'No woman shall succeed in Salique land:'
Which Salique land the French unjustly gloze
To be the realm of France
The founder of this law and female bar.
Yet their own authors faithfully affirm
That the land Salique is in Germany
Where Charles the Great
Who
For some dishonest manners of their life
Should be inheritrix in Salique land:
Which Salique
Then doth it well appear that Salique law
Was not devised for the realm of France:
Nor did the French possess the Salique land
Until four hundred one and twenty years
After defunction of King Pharamond
Who died within the year of our redemption
Four hundred twenty-six; and Charles the Great
Subdued the Saxons
Beyond the river Sala
Eight hundred five. Besides
Of Blithild
Hugh Capet also
Of Charles the duke of Lorraine
Of the true line and stock of Charles the Great
To Lewis the emperor
Of Charles the Great. Also King Lewis the Tenth
That fair Queen Isabel
By the which marriage the line of Charles the Great
Was re-united to the crown of France.
So that
King Pepin's title and Hugh Capet's claim
To hold in right and title of the female:
So do the kings of France unto this day;
Howbeit they would hold up this Salique law
To bar your highness claiming from the female
Than amply to imbar their crooked titles
Usurp'd from you and your progenitors.
May I with right and conscience make this claim?
The sin upon my head
For in the book of Numbers is it writ
Descend unto the daughter. Gracious lord
Look back into your mighty ancestors:
Go
Stood smiling to behold his lion's whelp
Forage in blood of French nobility.
O noble English. that could entertain
With half their forces the full Pride of France
And let another half stand laughing by
Awake remembrance of these valiant dead
And with your puissant arm renew their feats:
You are their heir; you sit upon their throne;
The blood and courage that renowned them
Runs in your veins; and my thrice-puissant liege
Is in the very May-morn of his youth
Your brother kings and monarchs of the earth
Do all expect that you should rouse yourself
They know your grace hath cause and means and might;
So hath your highness; never king of England
Had nobles richer and more loyal subjects
And lie pavilion'd in the fields of France.
O
In aid whereof we of the spiritualty
Will raise your highness such a mighty sum
As never did the clergy at one time
Bring in to any of your ancestors.
We must not only arm to invade the French
Against the Scot
With all advantages.
They of those marches
Our inland from the pilfering borderers.
We do not mean the coursing snatchers only
For you shall read that my great-grandfather
Never went with his forces into France
But that the Scot on his unfurnish'd kingdom
Came pouring
That England
She hath been then more fear'd than harm'd
For hear her but exampled by herself:
When all her chivalry hath been in France
And she a mourning widow of her nobles
But taken and impounded as a stray
The King of Scots; whom she did send to France
And make her chronicle as rich with praise
As is the ooze and bottom of the sea
With sunken wreck and sunless treasuries.
But there's a saying very old and true
For once the eagle England being in prey
Comes sneaking and so sucks her princely eggs
It follows then the cat must stay at home:
Yet that is but a crush'd necessity
While that the armed hand doth fight abroad
For government
Therefore doth heaven divide
The state of man in divers functions
To which is fixed
The act of order to a peopled kingdom.
They have a king and officers of sorts;
Where some
To the tent-royal of their emperor;
Who
The singing masons building roofs of gold
Their heavy burdens at his narrow gate
The lazy yawning drone. I this infer
To one consent
As many arrows
As many fresh streams meet in one salt sea;
As many lines close in the dial's centre;
So may a thousand actions
End in one purpose
Without defeat. Therefore to France
Divide your happy England into four;
Whereof take you one quarter into France
If we
The name of hardiness and policy.
Call in the messengers sent from the Dauphin.
Exeunt some Attendants
Now are we well resolved; and
O'er France and all her almost kingly dukedoms
Either our history shall with full mouth
Speak freely of our acts
Enter Ambassadors of France
Now are we well prepared to know the pleasure
Of our fair cousin Dauphin; for we hear
Your greeting is from him
May't please your majesty to give us leave
Freely to render what we have in charge;
Or shall we sparingly show you far off
The Dauphin's meaning and our embassy?
We are no tyrant
Unto whose grace our passion is as subject
As are our wretches fetter'd in our prisons:
Therefore with frank and with uncurbed plainness
Tell us the Dauphin's mind.
Thus
Your highness
Of your great predecessor
In answer of which claim
Says that you savour too much of your youth
That can be with a nimble galliard won;
You cannot revel into dukedoms there.
He therefore sends you
Hear no more of you. This the Dauphin speaks.
What treasure
Tennis-balls
We are glad the Dauphin is so pleasant with us;
His present and your pains we thank you for:
When we have march'd our rackets to these balls
Shall strike his father's crown into the hazard.
Tell him he hath made a match with such a wrangler
That all the courts of France will be disturb'd
With chaces. And we understand him well
We never valued this poor seat of England;
And therefore
To barbarous licence; as 'tis ever common
That men are merriest when they are from home.
But tell the Dauphin I will keep my state
When I do rouse me in my throne of France:
For that I have laid by my majesty
And plodded like a man for working-days
That I will dazzle all the eyes of France
And tell the pleasant prince this mock of his
Hath turn'd his balls to gun-stones; and his soul
Shall stand sore charged for the wasteful vengeance
That shall fly with them: for many a thousand widows
Shall this his mock mock out of their dear husbands;
Mock mothers from their sons
And some are yet ungotten and unborn
That shall have cause to curse the Dauphin's scorn.
But this lies all within the will of God
Tell you the Dauphin I am coming on
My rightful hand in a well-hallow'd cause.
So get you hence in peace; and tell the Dauphin
His jest will savour but of shallow wit
Convey them with safe conduct. Fare you well.
Exeunt Ambassadors
This was a merry message.
We hope to make the sender blush at it.
Therefore
That may give furtherance to our expedition;
For we have now no thought in us but France
Therefore let our proportions for these wars
Be soon collected and all things thought upon
That may with reasonable swiftness add
More feathers to our wings; for
Therefore let every man now task his thought
Exeunt. Flourish
ACT II
PROLOGUE
Enter Chorus
Now all the youth of England are on fire
Now thrive the armourers
Reigns solely in the breast of every man:
They sell the pasture now to buy the horse
For now sits Expectation in the air
With crowns imperial
The French
Of this most dreadful preparation
Seek to divert the English purposes.
O England! model to thy inward greatness
But see thy fault! France hath in thee found out
A nest of hollow bosoms
With treacherous crowns; and three corrupted men
Confirm'd conspiracy with fearful France;
And by their hands this grace of kings must die
Linger your patience on; and we'll digest
The abuse of distance; force a play:
The sum is paid; the traitors are agreed;
The king is set from London; and the scene
Is now transported
There is the playhouse now
And thence to France shall we convey you safe
To give you gentle pass; for
But
Exit
SCENE I. London. A street.
Enter Corporal NYM and Lieutenant BARDOLPH
Well met
Good morrow
What
For my part
time shall serve
shall be as it may. I dare not fight; but I will
wink and hold out mine iron: it is a simple one; but
what though? it will toast cheese
endure cold as another man's sword will: and
there's an end.
I will bestow a breakfast to make you friends; and
we'll be all three sworn brothers to France: let it
be so
Faith
certain of it; and when I cannot live any longer
will do as I may: that is my rest
rendezvous of it.
It is certain
Quickly: and certainly she did you wrong; for you
were troth-plight to her.
I cannot tell: things must be as they may: men may
sleep
that time; and some say knives have edges. It must
be as it may: though patience be a tired mare
she will plod. There must be conclusions. Well
cannot tell.

The grave doth gape

Base is the slave that pays.
That now I will have: that's the humour of it.
As manhood shall compound: push home.

SCENE II. Southampton. A council-chamber.
Enter EXETER
'Fore God
They shall be apprehended by and by.
How smooth and even they do bear themselves!
As if allegiance in their bosoms sat
The king hath note of all that they intend
Nay
His sovereign's life to death and treachery.
Trumpets sound. Enter KING HENRY V
Now sits the wind fair
My Lord of Cambridge
Think you not that the powers we bear with us
Will cut their passage through the force of France
For which we have in head assembled them?
No doubt
I doubt not that; since we are well persuaded
We carry not a heart with us from hence
That grows not in a fair consent with ours
Success and conquest to attend on us.
Never was monarch better fear'd and loved
Than is your majesty: there's not
That sits in heart-grief and uneasiness
Under the sweet shade of your government.
True: those that were your father's enemies
Have steep'd their galls in honey and do serve you
With hearts create of duty and of zeal.
We therefore have great cause of thankfulness;
And shall forget the office of our hand
According to the weight and worthiness.
So service shall with steeled sinews toil
We judge no less. Uncle of Exeter
it was excess of wine that set him on;
And on his more advice we pardon him.
That's mercy
Let him be punish'd
Breed
O
So may your highness
Sir
Alas
Are heavy orisons 'gainst this poor wretch!
If little faults
When capital crimes
And tender preservation of our person
Who are the late commissioners?
I one
Your highness bade me ask for it to-day.
So did you me
And I
Then
There yours
Read them; and know
My Lord of Westmoreland
What see you in those papers that you lose
So much complexion? Look ye
Their cheeks are paper. Why
That hath so cowarded and chased your blood
Out of appearance?
I do confess my fault;
And do submit me to your highness' mercy.
To which we all appeal.
The mercy that was quick in us but late
You must not dare
For your own reasons turn into your bosoms
See you
To furnish him with all appertinents
Belonging to his honour; and this man
Hath
This knight
Than Cambridge is
Thou that didst bear the key of all my counsels
Could out of thee extract one spark of evil
That might annoy my finger? 'tis so strange
As black and white
Treason and murder ever kept together
But thou
Wonder to wait on treason and on murder:
And whatsoever cunning fiend it was
That wrought upon thee so preposterously
Hath got the voice in hell for excellence:
All other devils that suggest by treasons
Do botch and bungle up damnation
With patches
From glistering semblances of piety;
But he that temper'd thee bade thee stand up
If that same demon that hath gull'd thee thus
Should with his lion gait walk the whole world
A soul so easy as that Englishman's.'
O
The sweetness of affiance! Show men dutiful?
Why
Why
Why
Why
Such and so finely bolted didst thou seem:
And thus thy fall hath left a kind of blot
With some suspicion. I will weep for thee;
For this revolt of thine
Another fall of man. Their faults are open:
Arrest them to the answer of the law;
And God acquit them of their practises!
I arrest thee of high treason
Richard Earl of Cambridge.
I arrest thee of high treason
Henry Lord Scroop of Masham.
I arrest thee of high treason
Thomas Grey
Our purposes God justly hath discover'd;
And I repent my fault more than my death;
Which I beseech your highness to forgive
For me
Although I did admit it as a motive
The sooner to effect what I intended:
But God be thanked for prevention;
Which I in sufferance heartily will rejoice
Never did faithful subject more rejoice
At the discovery of most dangerous treason
Than I do at this hour joy o'er myself.
Prevented from a damned enterprise:
My fault
God quit you in his mercy! Hear your sentence.
You have conspired against our royal person
Received the golden earnest of our death;
Wherein you would have sold your king to slaughter
And his whole kingdom into desolation.
Touching our person seek we no revenge;
But we our kingdom's safety must so tender
We do deliver you. Get you therefore hence
The taste whereof
You patience to endure
Of all your dear offences! Bear them hence.
Exeunt CAMBRIDGE
Now
Shall be to you
We doubt not of a fair and lucky war
This dangerous treason lurking in our way
To hinder our beginnings. We doubt not now
But every rub is smoothed on our way.
Then forth
Our puissance into the hand of God
Cheerly to sea; the signs of war advance:
No king of England
Exeunt

SCENE IV. France. The KING'S palace.
Flourish. Enter the FRENCH KING
Thus comes the English with full power upon us;
And more than carefully it us concerns
To answer royally in our defences.
Therefore the Dukes of Berri and of Bretagne
With men of courage and with means defendant;
For England his approaches makes as fierce
As waters to the sucking of a gulf.
It fits us then to be as provident
As fear may teach us out of late examples
Left by the fatal and neglected English
Upon our fields.
My most redoubted father
For peace itself should not so dull a kingdom
Therefore
To view the sick and feeble parts of France:
And let us do it with no show of fear;
No
Were busied with a Whitsun morris-dance:
For
By a vain
O peace
You are too much mistaken in this king:
Question your grace the late ambassadors
How terrible in constant resolution
Were but the outside of the Roman Brutus
As gardeners do with ordure hide those roots
That shall first spring and be most delicate.
Well
But though we think it so
In cases of defence 'tis best to weigh
The enemy more mighty than he seems:
So the proportions of defence are fill'd;
Which of a weak or niggardly projection
Doth
A little cloth.
Think we King Harry strong;
And
The kindred of him hath been flesh'd upon us;
And he is bred out of that bloody strain
That haunted us in our familiar paths:
Witness our too much memorable shame
When Cressy battle fatally was struck
Of that black name
Whiles that his mountain sire
The patterns that by God and by French fathers
Had twenty years been made. This is a stem
Of that victorious stock; and let us fear
The native mightiness and fate of him.
Enter a Messenger
Ambassadors from Harry King of England
Do crave admittance to your majesty.
We'll give them present audience. Go
Exeunt Messenger and certain Lords
You see this chase is hotly follow'd
Turn head
Most spend their mouths when what they seem to threaten
Runs far before them. Good my sovereign
Of what a monarchy you are the head:
Self-love
As self-neglecting.
Re-enter Lords
From our brother England?
From him; and thus he greets your majesty.
He wills you
The borrow'd glories that by gift of heaven
To him and to his heirs; namely
And all wide-stretched honours that pertain
By custom and the ordinance of times
Unto the crown of France. That you may know
'Tis no sinister nor no awkward claim
Willing to overlook this pedigree:
And when you find him evenly derived
From his most famed of famous ancestors
Your crown and kingdom
From him the native and true challenger.
Or else what follows?
Bloody constraint; for if you hide the crown
Even in your hearts
Therefore in fierce tempest is he coming
And bids you
On the poor souls for whom this hungry war
Opens his vasty jaws; and on your head
Turning the widows' tears
The dead men's blood
This is his claim
Unless the Dauphin be in presence here
For us
To-morrow shall you bear our full intent
Back to our brother England.
For the Dauphin
Scorn and defiance; slight regard
The mighty sender
Thus says my king; an' if your father's highness
Do not
Shall chide your trespass and return your mock
In second accent of his ordnance.
Say
Nothing but odds with England: to that end
He'll make your Paris Louvre shake for it
And
And these he masters now: now he weighs time
Even to the utmost grain: that you shall read
In your own losses
To-morrow shall you know our mind at full.
Dispatch us with all speed
Come here himself to question our delay;
For he is footed in this land already.
You shall be soon dispatch's with fair conditions:
A night is but small breath and little pause
To answer matters of this consequence.
Flourish. Exeunt
ACT III
PROLOGUE
Enter Chorus
Thus with imagined wing our swift scene flies
In motion of no less celerity
Than that of thought. Suppose that you have seen
The well-appointed king at Hampton pier
Embark his royalty; and his brave fleet
With silken streamers the young Phoebus fanning:
Play with your fancies
Upon the hempen tackle ship-boys climbing;
Hear the shrill whistle which doth order give
To sounds confused; behold the threaden sails
You stand upon the ravage and behold
A city on the inconstant billows dancing;
For so appears this fleet majestical
Grapple your minds to sternage of this navy
For who is he
With one appearing hair
These cull'd and choice-drawn cavaliers to France?
Work
Behold the ordnance on their carriages
Suppose the ambassador from the French comes back;
Tells Harry that the king doth offer him
Katharine his daughter
The offer likes not: and the nimble gunner
With linstock now the devilish cannon touches
And down goes all before them. Still be kind
Exit
SCENE I. France. Before Harfleur.
Alarum. Enter KING HENRY
Once more unto the breach
Or close the wall up with our English dead.
In peace there's nothing so becomes a man
As modest stillness and humility:
But when the blast of war blows in our ears
Stiffen the sinews
Then lend the eye a terrible aspect;
Let pry through the portage of the head
Like the brass cannon; let the brow o'erwhelm it
As fearfully as doth a galled rock
O'erhang and jutty his confounded base
Now set the teeth and stretch the nostril wide
To his full height. On
Whose blood is fet from fathers of war-proof!
Fathers that
And sheathed their swords for lack of argument:
Dishonour not your mothers; now attest
That those whom you call'd fathers did beget you.
Be copy now to men of grosser blood
The mettle of your pasture; let us swear
That you are worth your breeding; which I doubt not;
For there is none of you so mean and base
I see you stand like greyhounds in the slips
Follow your spirit
Cry 'God for Harry
Exeunt. Alarum
SCENE II. The same.
Enter NYM
On
Pray thee
and
the humour of it is too hot
plain-song of it.
The plain-song is most just: for humours do abound:
Knocks go and come; God's vassals drop and die;
And sword and shield
Would I were in an alehouse in London! I would give
all my fame for a pot of ale and safety.
And I:
If wishes would prevail with me
As duly
Enter FLUELLEN
Up to the breach
Driving them forward
Be merciful
Abate thy rage
Good bawcock
These be good humours! your honour wins bad humours.
Exeunt all but Boy
As young as I am
swashers. I am boy to them all three: but all they
three
to me; for indeed three such antics do not amount to
a man. For Bardolph
red-faced; by the means whereof a' faces it out
fights not. For Pistol
and a quiet sword; by the means whereof a' breaks
words
heard that men of few words are the best men; and
therefore he scorns to say his prayers
should be thought a coward: but his few bad words
are matched with as few good deeds; for a' never
broke any man's head but his own
against a post when he was drunk. They will steal
any thing
lute-case
three half pence. Nym and Bardolph are sworn
brothers in filching
fire-shovel: I knew by that piece of service the
men would carry coals. They would have me as
familiar with men's pockets as their gloves or their
handkerchers: which makes much against my manhood
mine; for it is plain pocketing up of wrongs. I
must leave them
their villany goes against my weak stomach
therefore I must cast it up.

SCENE III. The same. Before the gates.
The Governor and some Citizens on the walls; the English forces below. Enter KING HENRY and his train
How yet resolves the governor of the town?
This is the latest parle we will admit;
Therefore to our best mercy give yourselves;
Or like to men proud of destruction
Defy us to our worst: for
Till in her ashes she lie buried.
The gates of mercy shall be all shut up
With conscience wide as hell
Your fresh-fair virgins and your flowering infants.
What is it then to me
Enlink'd to waste and desolation?
What is't to me
Of hot and forcing violation?
What rein can hold licentious wickedness
When down the hill he holds his fierce career?
We may as bootless spend our vain command
Upon the enraged soldiers in their spoil
As send precepts to the leviathan
To come ashore. Therefore
Whiles yet the cool and temperate wind of grace
O'erblows the filthy and contagious clouds
Of heady murder
If not
The blind and bloody soldier with foul hand
Defile the locks of your shrill-shrieking daughters;
Your fathers taken by the silver beards
Do break the clouds
At Herod's bloody-hunting slaughtermen.
What say you? will you yield
Our expectation hath this day an end:
The Dauphin
To raise so great a siege. Therefore
Enter our gates; dispose of us and ours;
For we no longer are defensible.
Open your gates. Come
Use mercy to them all. For us
Upon our soldiers
To-night in Harfleur we will be your guest;
To-morrow for the march are we addrest.
Flourish. The King and his train enter the town

SCENE V. The same.
Enter the KING OF FRANCE
'Tis certain he hath pass'd the river Somme.
And if he be not fought withal
And give our vineyards to a barbarous people.
O Dieu vivant! shall a few sprays of us
Normans
Mort de ma vie! if they march along
Unfought withal
In that nook-shotten isle of Albion.
Dieu de batailles! where have they this mettle?
Is not their climate foggy
And shall our quick blood
Upon our houses' thatch
Sweat drops of gallant youth in our rich fields!
Poor we may call them in their native lords.
By faith and honour
Our mettle is bred out and they will give
Their bodies to the lust of English youth
To new-store France with bastard warriors.
They bid us to the English dancing-schools
Saying our grace is only in our heels
Where is Montjoy the herald? speed him hence:
Let him greet England with our sharp defiance.
Up
More sharper than your swords
Charles Delabreth
You Dukes of Orleans
Jaques Chatillon
High dukes
Bar Harry England
With pennons painted in the blood of Harfleur:
Rush on his host
Upon the valleys
The Alps doth spit and void his rheum upon:
Go down upon him
Bring him our prisoner.
This becomes the great.
Sorry am I his numbers are so few
And for achievement offer us his ransom.
Therefore
And let him say to England that we send
To know what willing ransom he will give.
Prince Dauphin
Not so
Be patient
Now forth
Exeunt

Is the Duke of Exeter safe?
The Duke of Exeter is as magnanimous as Agamemnon;

Therefore

My master's mind.

Thus says my king: Say thou to Harry of England:

What is thy name? I know thy quality.
Montjoy.
Thou dost thy office fairly. Turn thee back.
And tell thy king I do not seek him now;
But could be willing to march on to Calais
Without impeachment: for
Unto an enemy of craft and vantage
Almost no better than so many French;
Who when they were in health
Did march three Frenchmen. Yet
Hath blown that vice in me: I must repent.
Go therefore
My ransom is this frail and worthless trunk
Yet
Stand in our way. There's for thy labour
Go bid thy master well advise himself:
If we may pass

The sum of all our answer is but this:
We would not seek a battle

I shall deliver so. Thanks to your highness.

I hope they will not come upon us now.
We are in God's hand
March to the bridge; it now draws toward night:
Beyond the river we'll encamp ourselves

SCENE VII. The French camp
Enter the Constable of France
Tut! I have the best armour of the world. Would it were day!
You have an excellent armour; but let my horse have his due.
It is the best horse of Europe.
Will it never be morning?
My lord of Orleans
talk of horse and armour?
You are as well provided of both as any prince in the world.
What a long night is this! I will not change my
horse with any that treads but on four pasterns.
Ca
entrails were hairs; le cheval volant
soar
sings when he touches it; the basest horn of his
hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes.
He's of the colour of the nutmeg.
And of the heat of the ginger. It is a beast for
Perseus: he is pure air and fire; and the dull
elements of earth and water never appear in him
only in Patient stillness while his rider mounts
him: he is indeed a horse; and all other jades you
may call beasts.
Indeed
It is the prince of palfreys; his neigh is like the
bidding of a monarch and his countenance enforces homage.
No more
Nay
rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb
deserved praise on my palfrey: it is a theme as
fluent as the sea: turn the sands into eloquent
tongues
'tis a subject for a sovereign to reason on
a sovereign's sovereign to ride on; and for the
world
their particular functions and wonder at him. I
once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus:
'Wonder of nature
I have heard a sonnet begin so to one's mistress.
Then did they imitate that which I composed to my
courser
Your mistress bears well.
Me well; which is the prescript praise and
perfection of a good and particular mistress.
Nay
shook your back.
So perhaps did yours.
Mine was not bridled.
O then belike she was old and gentle; and you rode
your straight strossers.
You have good judgment in horsemanship.
Be warned by me
not warily
my horse to my mistress.
I had as lief have my mistress a jade.
I tell thee

to my mistress.
'Le chien est retourne a son propre vomissement

My lord constable
to-night
Stars
Some of them will fall to-morrow
And yet my sky shall not want.
That may be

Even as your horse bears your praises; who would
trot as well
Would I were able to load him with his desert! Will
it never be day? I will trot to-morrow a mile
my way shall be paved with English faces.
I will not say so
my way: but I would it were morning; for I would
fain be about the ears of the English.
Who will go to hazard with me for twenty prisoners?
You must first go yourself to hazard
'Tis midnight; I'll go arm myself.
Exit
The Dauphin longs for morning.
He longs to eat the English.
I think he will eat all he kills.
By the white hand of my lady
Swear by her foot
He is simply the most active gentleman of France.
Doing is activity; and he will still be doing.
He never did harm
Nor will do none to-morrow: he will keep that good name still.

I was told that  by one that knows him better than

What's he?
Marry
not who knew it

The Lord Grandpre.
A valiant and most expert gentleman. Would it were

the dawning as we do.
What a wretched and peevish fellow is this king of

If the English had any apprehension

That island of England breeds very valiant

Foolish curs
Russian bear and have their heads crushed like
rotten apples! You may as well say
valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion.
Just
mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on
their wits with their wives: and then give them
great meals of beef and iron and steel
eat like wolves and fight like devils.
Ay
Then shall we find to-morrow they have only stomachs
to eat and none to fight. Now is it time to arm:
come
It is now two o'clock: but
We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.

ACT IV
PROLOGUE
Enter Chorus
Now entertain conjecture of a time
When creeping murmur and the poring dark
Fills the wide vessel of the universe.
From camp to camp through the foul womb of night
The hum of either army stilly sounds
The secret whispers of each other's watch:
Fire answers fire
Each battle sees the other's umber'd face;
Steed threatens steed
Piercing the night's dull ear
The armourers
The country cocks do crow
Proud of their numbers and secure in soul
Do the low-rated English play at dice;
And chide the cripple tardy-gaited night
Who
So tediously away. The poor condemned English
Sit patiently and inly ruminate
The morning's danger
Investing lank-lean; cheeks and war-worn coats
Presenteth them unto the gazing moon
So many horrid ghosts. O now
The royal captain of this ruin'd band
Walking from watch to watch
For forth he goes and visits all his host.
Bids them good morrow with a modest smile
And calls them brothers
Upon his royal face there is no note
How dread an army hath enrounded him;
Nor doth he dedicate one jot of colour
Unto the weary and all-watched night
With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty;
That every wretch
A largess universal like the sun
His liberal eye doth give to every one
And so our scene must to the battle fly;
Where--O for pity!--we shall much disgrace
With four or five most vile and ragged foils
Exit
SCENE I. The English camp at Agincourt.
Enter KING HENRY
Gloucester
The greater therefore should our courage be.
Good morrow
There is some soul of goodness in things evil
For our bad neighbour makes us early stirrers
Besides
That we should dress us fairly for our end.
Thus may we gather honey from the weed
Enter ERPINGHAM
Good morrow
A good soft pillow for that good white head
Were better than a churlish turf of France.
Not so
'Tis good for men to love their present pains
Upon example; so the spirit is eased:
And when the mind is quicken'd
Lend me thy cloak
Do my good morrow to them
Desire them an to my pavilion.
We shall
Shall I attend your grace?
No
Go with my brothers to my lords of England:
I and my bosom must debate awhile
The Lord in heaven bless thee
Exeunt all but KING HENRY
God-a-mercy
Enter PISTOL
Qui va la?
A friend.
Discuss unto me; art thou officer?
Or art thou base
I am a gentleman of a company.
Trail'st thou the puissant pike?
Even so. What are you?
As good a gentleman as the emperor.
Then you are a better than the king.
The king's a bawcock
Of parents good
I kiss his dirty shoe
I love the lovely bully. What is thy name?
Harry le Roy.
Le Roy! a Cornish name: art thou of Cornish crew?
No
Know'st thou Fluellen?
Yes.
Tell him
Upon Saint Davy's day.
Do not you wear your dagger in your cap that day
Art thou his friend?
And his kinsman too.
The figo for thee
I thank you: God be with you!
My name is Pistol call'd.
Exit
It sorts well with your fierceness.
Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER
Captain Fluellen!
So! in the name of Jesu Christ
the greatest admiration of the universal world

wars is not kept: if you would take the pains but to
examine the wars of Pompey the Great

cares of it

Why
If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating
coxcomb

I will speak lower.
I pray you and beseech you that you will.

Though it appear a little out of fashion
Enter three soldiers
Brother John Bates
breaks yonder?
I think it be: but we have no great cause to desire
the approach of day.
We see yonder the beginning of the day
we shall never see the end of it. Who goes there?
A friend.
Under what captain serve you?
Under Sir Thomas Erpingham.
A good old commander and a most kind gentleman: I
pray you
Even as men wrecked upon a sand
washed off the next tide.
He hath not told his thought to the king?
No; nor it is not meet he should. For
speak it to you
am: the violet smells to him as it doth to me: the
element shows to him as it doth to me; all his
senses have but human conditions: his ceremonies
laid by
though his affections are higher mounted than ours
wing. Therefore when he sees reason of fears
do
as ours are: yet
him with any appearance of fear
it
He may show what outward courage he will; but I
believe
himself in Thames up to the neck; and so I would he
were
By my troth
I think he would not wish himself any where but
where he is.
Then I would he were here alone; so should he be
sure to be ransomed
I dare say you love him not so ill
alone
minds: methinks I could not die any where so
contented as in the king's company; his cause being
just and his quarrel honourable.
That's more than we know.
Ay
enough
his cause be wrong
the crime of it out of us.
But if the cause be not good
a heavy reckoning to make
arms and heads
together at the latter day and cry all 'We died at
such a place;' some swearing
surgeon
them
children rawly left. I am afeard there are few die
well that die in a battle; for how can they
charitably dispose of any thing
argument? Now

it; whom to disobey were against all proportion of
subjection.
So
merchandise do sinfully miscarry upon the sea
imputation of his wickedness by your rule
imposed upon his father that sent him: or if a
servant

many irreconciled iniquities
business of the master the author of the servant's
damnation: but this is not so: the king is not
bound to answer the particular endings of his
soldiers
his servant; for they purpose not their death
they purpose their services. Besides
king
the arbitrement of swords
unspotted soldiers: some peradventure have on them
the guilt of premeditated and contrived murder;
some
perjury; some
have before gored the gentle bosom of peace with
pillage and robbery. Now
defeated the law and outrun native punishment
fly from God: war is his beadle
so that here men are punished for before-breach of
the king's laws in now the king's quarrel: where
they feared the death
and where they would be safe
they die unprovided
their damnation than he was before guilty of those
impieties for the which they are now visited. Every
subject's duty is the king's; but every subject's
soul is his own. Therefore should every soldier in
the wars do as every sick man in his bed
mote out of his conscience: and dying so
is to him advantage; or not dying
blessedly lost wherein such preparation was gained:
and in him that escapes
that
outlive that day to see His greatness and to teach
others how they should prepare.
'Tis certain
his own head
But I do not desire he should answer for me; and
yet I determine to fight lustily for him.
I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.
Ay
when our throats are cut
ne'er the wiser.
If I live to see it
You pay him then. That's a perilous shot out of an
elder-gun
do against a monarch! you may as well go about to
turn the sun to ice with fanning in his face with a
peacock's feather. You'll never trust his word
after! come
Your reproof is something too round: I should be
angry with you
Let it be a quarrel between us
I embrace it.
How shall I know thee again?
Give me any gage of thine

will make it my quarrel.
Here's my glove: give me another of thine.
There.
This will I also wear in my cap: if ever thou come

by this hand
If ever I live to see it

Well. I will do it
king's company.

Be friends

Upon the king! let us our lives
We must bear all. O hard condition
Of every fool
But his own wringing! What infinite heart's-ease
Must kings neglect
And what have kings
And what art thou
What kind of god art thou
Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers?
What are thy rents? what are thy comings in?
O ceremony
What is thy soul of adoration?
Art thou aught else but place
Wherein thou art less happy being fear'd
Than they in fearing.
What drink'st thou oft
Think'st thou the fiery fever will go out
With titles blown from adulation?
Will it give place to flexure and low bending?
Canst thou
I am a king that find thee
'Tis not the balm
That beats upon the high shore of this world
Gets him to rest
Never sees horrid night
Sweats in the eye of Phoebus and all night
Sleeps in Elysium; next day after dawn
And
The slave
What watch the king keeps to maintain the peace
Enter ERPINGHAM
My lord
Good old knight
I'll be before thee.
I shall do't
Exit
O God of battles! steel my soldiers' hearts;
Possess them not with fear; take from them now
The sense of reckoning
Pluck their hearts from them. Not to-day
My father made in compassing the crown!
I Richard's body have interred anew;
And on it have bestow'd more contrite tears
Than from it issued forced drops of blood:
Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay
Toward heaven
Two chantries
Sing still for Richard's soul. More will I do;
Though all that I can do is nothing worth
Enter GLOUCESTER
My liege!
My brother Gloucester's voice? Ay;
I know thy errand
The day
Exeunt
SCENE II. The French camp.
Enter the DAUPHIN
The sun doth gild our armour; up
Montez A cheval! My horse! varlet! laquais! ha!
O brave spirit!
Via! les eaux et la terre.
Rien puis? L'air et la feu.
Ciel
Enter Constable
Now
Hark
Mount them
What
How shall we
Enter Messenger
The English are embattled
To horse
Do but behold yon poor and starved band
There is not work enough for all our hands;
Scarce blood enough in all their sickly veins
To give each naked curtle-axe a stain
'Tis positive 'gainst all exceptions
About our squares of battle
To purge this field of such a hilding foe
Took stand for idle speculation:
But that our honours must not. What's to say?
A very little little let us do.
And all is done. Then let the trumpets sound
The tucket sonance and the note to mount;
For our approach shall so much dare the field
That England shall couch down in fear and yield.
Enter GRANDPRE
Why do you stay so long
Yon island carrions
Their ragged curtains poorly are let loose
Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggar'd host
And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps:
The horsemen sit like fixed candlesticks
Lob down their heads
And in their pale dull mouths the gimmal bit
Lies foul with chew'd grass
And their executors
Description cannot suit itself in words
To demonstrate the life of such a battle
In life so lifeless as it shows itself.
They have said their prayers
Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits
And give their fasting horses provender
I stay but for my guidon: to the field!
I will the banner from a trumpet take
The sun is high
Exeunt
SCENE III. The English camp.
Enter GLOUCESTER
Where is the king?
The king himself is rode to view their battle.
Of fighting men they have full three score thousand.
There's five to one; besides
God's arm strike with us! 'tis a fearful odds.
God be wi' you
If we no more meet till we meet in heaven
Farewell
Farewell
And yet I do thee wrong to mind thee of it
Exit SALISBURY
He is full of valour as of kindness;
Princely in both.
Enter the KING
O that we now had here
But one ten thousand of those men in England
That do no work to-day!
What's he that wishes so?
My cousin Westmoreland? No
If we are mark'd to die
To do our country loss; and if to live
God's will! I pray thee
By Jove
It yearns me not if men my garments wear;
Such outward things dwell not in my desires:
But if it be a sin to covet honour
No
God's peace! I would not lose so great an honour
As one man more
For the best hope I have. O
Rather proclaim it
And crowns for convoy put into his purse:
We would not die in that man's company
That fears his fellowship to die with us.
This day is called the feast of Crispian:
He that outlives this day
He that shall live this day
Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars.
And say 'These wounds I had on Crispin's day.'
Old men forget: yet all shall be forgot
What feats he did that day: then shall our names.
Familiar in his mouth as household words
Harry the king
This story shall the good man teach his son;
And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by
We few
For he to-day that sheds his blood with me
Shall be my brother; be he ne'er so vile
And gentlemen in England now a-bed
Shall think themselves accursed they were not here
That fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day.
Re-enter SALISBURY
My sovereign lord
The French are bravely in their battles set
All things are ready
Perish the man whose mind is backward now!
Thou dost not wish more help from England
God's will! my liege
Why
Which likes me better than to wish us one.
You know your places: God be with you all!
Tucket. Enter MONTJOY
Once more I come to know of thee
For certainly thou art so near the gulf
Thy followers of repentance; that their souls
May make a peaceful and a sweet retire
From off these fields
Must lie and fester.
Who hath sent thee now?
The Constable of France.
I pray thee
Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones.
Good God! why should they mock poor fellows thus?
The man that once did sell the lion's skin
While the beast lived
A many of our bodies shall no doubt
Find native graves; upon the which
And those that leave their valiant bones in France
Leaving their earthly parts to choke your clime
Mark then abounding valour in our English
Let me speak proudly: tell the constable
We are but warriors for the working-day;
Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirch'd
With rainy marching in the painful field;
There's not a piece of feather in our host--
Good argument
And time hath worn us into slovenry:
But
And my poor soldiers tell me
They'll be in fresher robes
The gay new coats o'er the French soldiers' heads
And turn them out of service. If they do this
As
Will soon be levied. Herald
Come thou no more for ransom
They shall have none
Which if they have as I will leave 'em them
I shall
Thou never shalt hear herald any more.
Exit
I fear thou'lt once more come again for ransom.
Enter YORK
My lord
The leading of the vaward.
Take it
And how thou pleasest
Exeunt

O

O

Brass
Thou damned and luxurious mountain goat
O pardonnez moi!
Say'st thou me so? is that a ton of moys?
Come hither

Monsieur le Fer.

Master Fer! I'll fer him
him: discuss the same in French unto him.
I do not know the French for fer

He prays you to save his life: he is a gentleman of

Petit monsieur

I did never know so full a voice issue from so
empty a heart: but the saying is true 'The empty
vessel makes the greatest sound.' Bardolph and Nym
had ten times more valour than this roaring devil i'
the old play
a wooden dagger; and they are both hanged; and so
would this be
adventurously. I must stay with the lackeys
the luggage of our camp: the French might have a
good prey of us
none to guard it but boys.
Exit
SCENE V. Another part of the field.
Enter Constable
O diable!
O seigneur! le jour est perdu
Mort de ma vie! all is confounded
Reproach and everlasting shame
Sits mocking in our plumes. O merchante fortune!
Do not run away.
A short alarum
Why
O perdurable shame! let's stab ourselves.
Be these the wretches that we play'd at dice for?
Is this the king we sent to for his ransom?
Shame and eternal shame
Let us die in honour: once more back again;
And he that will not follow Bourbon now
Whilst by a slave
Disorder
Let us on heaps go offer up our lives.
We are enow yet living in the field
To smother up the English in our throngs
The devil take order now! I'll to the throng:
Let life be short; else shame will be too long.
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Another part of the field.
Alarums. Enter KING HENRY and forces
Well have we done
But all's not done; yet keep the French the field.
The Duke of York commends him to your majesty.
Lives he
I saw him down; thrice up again and fighting;
From helmet to the spur all blood he was.
In which array
Suffolk first died: and York
That bloodily did spawn upon his face;
And cries aloud 'Tarry
My soul shall thine keep company to heaven;
Tarry
We kept together in our chivalry!'
Upon these words I came and cheer'd him up:
He smiled me in the face
So did he turn and over Suffolk's neck
He threw his wounded arm and kiss'd his lips;
And so espoused to death
A testament of noble-ending love.
The pretty and sweet manner of it forced
Those waters from me which I would have stopp'd;
But I had not so much of man in me
And gave me up to tears.
I blame you not;
For
With mistful eyes
Alarum
But
The French have reinforced their scatter'd men:
Then every soldier kill his prisoners:
Give the word through.
Exeunt

No
I come to thee for charitable licence
To look our dead
To sort our nobles from our common men.
For many of our princes--woe the while!--
Lie drown'd and soak'd in mercenary blood;
So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs
In blood of princes; and their wounded steeds
Fret fetlock deep in gore and with wild rage
Yerk out their armed heels at their dead masters
Of their dead bodies!
I tell thee truly
For yet a many of your horsemen peer
And gallop o'er the field.
The day is yours.

Yes
Yes
Do we all holy rites;
Let there be sung 'Non nobis' and 'Te Deum;'
The dead with charity enclosed in clay:
And then to Calais; and to England then:
Where ne'er from France arrived more happy men.

ACT V
PROLOGUE
Enter Chorus
Vouchsafe to those that have not read the story
Of time
Be here presented. Now we bear the king
Toward Calais: grant him there; there seen
Athwart the sea. Behold
Pales in the flood with men
Seems to prepare his way: so let him land
So swift a pace hath thought that even now
You may imagine him upon Blackheath;
Where that his lords desire him to have borne
His bruised helmet and his bended sword
Before him through the city: he forbids it
Giving full trophy
Quite from himself to God. But now behold
The mayor and all his brethren in best sort
As
As yet the lamentation of the French
Invites the King of England's stay at home;
The emperor's coming in behalf of France
All the occurrences
There must we bring him; and myself have play'd
The interim
Then brook abridgment
Exit

Doth Fortune play the huswife with me now?
News have I
Of malady of France;
And there my rendezvous is quite cut off.
Old I do wax; and from my weary limbs
Honour is cudgelled. Well
To England will I steal
And patches will I get unto these cudgell'd scars
Exit
SCENE II. France. A royal palace.

Peace to this meeting
Unto our brother France
To our most fair and princely cousin Katharine;
And
And

So are you

Your eyes
Against the French
The venom of such looks
Shall change all griefs and quarrels into love.
To cry amen to that
You English princes all
My duty to you both
Unto this bar and royal interview
Since then my office hath so far prevail'd
That
Our fertile France
Alas
Her vine
The darnel
Doth root upon
That should deracinate such savagery;
The even mead

But hateful docks
And as our vineyards
Have lost
But grow like savages
That nothing do but meditate on blood
To swearing and stern looks

Which to reduce into our former favour
You are assembled: and my speech entreats
That I may know the let

And bless us with her former qualities.
If
Which you have cited

There is no answer made.
Well then the peace

She hath good leave.

God save your majesty! my royal cousin
our princess English?
I would have her learn
perfectly I love her; and that is good English.
Is she not apt?
Our tongue is rough
smooth; so that
heart of flattery about me
the spirit of love in her
his true likeness.
Pardon the frankness of my mirth
for that. If you would conjure in her
make a circle; if conjure up love in her in his true
likeness
blame her then
virgin crimson of modesty
appearance of a naked blind boy in her naked seeing
self? It were
to consign to.
Yet they do wink and yield
They are then excused
what they do.
Then
I will wink on her to consent
teach her to know my meaning: for maids
summered and warm kept
Bartholomew-tide
eyes; and then they will endure handling
before would not abide looking on.
This moral ties me over to time and a hot summer;
and so I shall catch the fly
latter end and she must be blind too.
As love is
It is so: and you may
my blindness
for one fair French maid that stands in my way.
Yes
turned into a maid; for they are all girdled with
maiden walls that war hath never entered.
Shall Kate be my wife?
So please you.
I am content; so the maiden cities you talk of may
wait on her: so the maid that stood in the way for
my wish shall show me the way to my will.
We have consented to all terms of reason.
Is't so
The king hath granted every article:
His daughter first
Only he hath not yet subscribed this:
Where your majesty demands
addition in French
d'Angleterre
Latin
Angliae
Nor this I have not
I pray you then
And thereupon give me your daughter.
Take her
Issue to me; that the contending kingdoms
Of France and England
With envy of each other's happiness
Plant neighbourhood and Christian-like accord
In their sweet bosoms
His bleeding sword 'twixt England and fair France.
Amen!
Now
Flourish
God
As man and wife
That English may as French
Amen!
Prepare we for our marriage--on which day
Then shall I swear to Kate
And may our oaths well kept and prosperous be!
Sennet. Exeunt
EPILOGUE
Enter Chorus
Thus far
Small time
This star of England: Fortune made his sword;
By which the world's best garden be achieved
Henry the Sixth
Of France and England
Whose state so many had the managing
Which oft our stage hath shown; and
Exit
ACT I
PROLOGUE
I come no more to make you laugh: things now
May
The subject will deserve it. Such as give
Their money out of hope they may believe
Only a show or two
The play may pass
Richly in two short hours. Only they
That come to hear a merry bawdy play
In a long motley coat guarded with yellow
As fool and fight is
Our own brains
Therefore
The first and happiest hearers of the town
The very persons of our noble story
As they were living; think you see them great
Of thousand friends; then in a moment
How soon this mightiness meets misery:
And
A man may weep upon his wedding-day.
SCENE I. London. An ante-chamber in the palace.
Enter NORFOLK at one door; at the other
Good morrow
Since last we saw in France?
I thank your grace
Of what I saw there.
An untimely ague
Stay'd me a prisoner in my chamber when
Those suns of glory
'Twixt Guynes and Arde:
I was then present
Beheld them
In their embracement
Which had they
Such a compounded one?
All the whole time
I was my chamber's prisoner.
Then you lost
The view of earthly glory: men might say
To one above itself. Each following day
Became the next day's master
Made former wonders its. To-day the French
Made Britain India: every man that stood
Show'd like a mine. Their dwarfish pages were
As cherubins
The pride upon them
Was to them as a painting: now this masque
Was cried incomparable; and the ensuing night
Made it a fool and beggar. The two kings
'Twas said they saw but one; and no discerner
Durst wag his tongue in censure. When these suns--
For so they phrase 'em--by their heralds challenged
The noble spirits to arms
Beyond thought's compass; that former fabulous story
O
As I belong to worship and affect
In honour honesty
Would by a good discourser lose some life
To the disposing of it nought rebell'd.
Order gave each thing view; the office did
Distinctly his full function.
Who did guide
Of this great sport together
One
In such a business.
I pray you
All this was order'd by the good discretion
Of the right reverend Cardinal of York.
The devil speed him! no man's pie is freed
From his ambitious finger. What had he
To do in these fierce vanities? I wonder
That such a keech can with his very bulk
Take up the rays o' the beneficial sun
And keep it from the earth.
Surely
For
Chalks successors their way
For high feats done to the crown; neither allied
For eminent assistants; but
A gift that heaven gives for him
A place next to the king.
I cannot tell
What heaven hath given him
Pierce into that; but I can see his pride
Peep through each part of him: whence has he that
A new hell in himself.
Why the devil
Who should attend on him? He makes up the file
Of all the gentry; for the most part such
To whom as great a charge as little honour
He meant to lay upon: and his own letter
I do know
Kinsmen of mine
By this so sickened their estates
They shall abound as formerly.
O
Have broke their backs with laying manors on 'em
For this great journey. What did this vanity
But minister communication of
A most poor issue?
Grievingly I think
The cost that did conclude it.
Every man
A thing inspired; and
Into a general prophecy; That this tempest
The sudden breach on't.
Which is budded out;
For France hath flaw'd the league
Our merchants' goods at Bourdeaux.
Is it therefore
The ambassador is silenced?
Marry
A proper title of a peace; and purchased
At a superfluous rate!
Why
Our reverend cardinal carried.
Like it your grace
Betwixt you and the cardinal. I advise you--
And take it from a heart that wishes towards you
Honour and plenteous safety--that you read
The cardinal's malice and his potency
Together; to consider further that
What his high hatred would effect wants not
A minister in his power. You know his nature
Hath a sharp edge: it's long and
That I advise your shunning.
Enter CARDINAL WOLSEY
The Duke of Buckingham's surveyor
Where's his examination?
Here
Is he in person ready?
Ay
Well
Shall lessen this big look.
Exeunt CARDINAL WOLSEY and his Train
This butcher's cur is venom-mouth'd
Have not the power to muzzle him; therefore best
Not wake him in his slumber. A beggar's book
Outworths a noble's blood.
What
Ask God for temperance; that's the appliance only
Which your disease requires.
I read in's looks
Matter against me; and his eye reviled
Me
He bores me with some trick: he's gone to the king;
I'll follow and outstare him.
Stay
What 'tis you go about: to climb steep hills
Requires slow pace at first: anger is like
A full-hot horse
Can advise me like you: be to yourself
As you would to your friend.
I'll to the king;
And from a mouth of honour quite cry down
This Ipswich fellow's insolence; or proclaim
There's difference in no persons.
Be advised;
Heat not a furnace for your foe so hot
That it do singe yourself: we may outrun
I say again
More stronger to direct you than yourself
Sir
By your prescription: but this top-proud fellow
From sincere motions
We see each grain of gravel
To be corrupt and treasonous.
Say not 'treasonous.'
To the king I'll say't; and make my vouch as strong
As shore of rock. Attend. This holy fox
As he is subtle
As able to perform't; his mind and place
Infecting one another
Only to show his pomp as well in France
As here at home
To this last costly treaty
Did break i' the rinsing.
Faith
Pray
The articles o' the combination drew
As himself pleased; and they were ratified
As he cried 'Thus let be': to as much end
As give a crutch to the dead: but our count-cardinal
Has done this
Which
To the old dam
For 'twas indeed his colour
To whisper Wolsey
His fears were
England and France might
Peep'd harms that menaced him: he privily
Deals with our cardinal; and
Which I do well; for I am sure the emperor
Paid ere he promised; whereby his suit was granted
Ere it was ask'd; but when the way was made
Does buy and sell his honour as he pleases
I am sorry
To hear this of him; and could wish he were
Something mistaken in't.
No
I  do pronounce him in that very shape
He shall appear in proof.
Enter BRANDON
Your office
Sir
Of Hereford
Arrest thee of high treason
Of our most sovereign king.
Lo
Under device and practise.
I am sorry
To see you ta'en from liberty
The business present: 'tis his highness' pleasure
You shall to the Tower.
It will help me nothing
To plead mine innocence; for that dye is on me
Which makes my whitest part black. The will of heaven
Be done in this and all things! I obey.
O my Lord Abergavenny
Nay
To ABERGAVENNY
Is pleased you shall to the Tower
How he determines further.
As the duke said
By me obey'd!
Here is a warrant from
The king to attach Lord Montacute; and the bodies
Of the duke's confessor
So
These are the limbs o' the plot: no more
A monk o' the Chartreux.
O
He.
My surveyor is false; the o'er-great cardinal
Hath show'd him gold; my life is spann'd already:
I am the shadow of poor Buckingham
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. The council-chamber.
Cornets. Enter KING HENRY VIII
My life itself
Of a full-charged confederacy
To you that choked it. Let be call'd before us
That gentleman of Buckingham's; in person
I'll hear him his confessions justify;
And point by point the treasons of his master
He shall again relate.
A noise within
Nay
Arise
Never name to us; you have half our power:
The other moiety
Repeat your will and take it.
Thank your majesty.
That you would love yourself
Not unconsider'd leave your honour
The dignity of your office
Of my petition.
Lady mine
I am solicited
Are in great grievance: there have been commissions
Sent down among 'em
Of all their loyalties: wherein
Most bitterly on you
Of these exactions
Whose honour heaven shield from soil!--even he
escapes not
Language unmannerly
The sides of loyalty
In loud rebellion.
Not almost appears
The many to them longing
The spinsters
And lack of other means
Daring the event to the teeth
Taxation!
Wherein? and what taxation? My lord cardinal
Please you
Pertains to the state; and front but in that file
Where others tell steps with me.
No
Things that are known alike; which are not wholesome
To those which would not know them
Perforce be their acquaintance. These exactions
Most pestilent to the bearing; and
They are devised by you; or else you suffer
Too hard an exclamation.
Still exaction!
The nature of it? in what kind
I am much too venturous
In tempting of your patience; but am bolden'd
Under your promised pardon. The subjects' grief
Comes through commissions
The sixth part of his substance
Without delay; and the pretence for this
Is named
Tongues spit their duties out
Allegiance in them; their curses now
Live where their prayers did: and it's come to pass
To each incensed will. I would your highness
Would give it quick consideration
There is no primer business.
By my life
And for me
A single voice; and that not pass'd me but
By learned approbation of the judges. If I am
Traduced by ignorant tongues
My faculties nor person
The chronicles of my doing
'Tis but the fate of place
That virtue must go through. We must not stint
Our necessary actions
To cope malicious censurers; which ever
That is new-trimm'd
Than vainly longing. What we oft do best
Not ours
For our best act. If we shall stand still
State-statues only.
Things done well
Things done without example
Are to be fear'd. Have you a precedent
Of this commission? I believe
We must not rend our subjects from our laws
A trembling contribution! Why
From every tree lop
And
Where this is question'd send our letters
Free pardon to each man that has denied
The force of this commission: pray
I put it to your care.
A word with you.
To the Secretary
Let there be letters writ to every shire
Hardly conceive of me; let it be noised
That through our intercession this revokement
And pardon comes: I shall anon advise you
Further in the proceeding.
Exit Secretary
Enter Surveyor
I am sorry that the Duke of Buckingham
Is run in your displeasure.
It grieves many:
The gentleman is learn'd
To nature none more bound; his training such
Not well disposed
Than ever they were fair. This man so complete
His hour of speech a minute; he
That once were his
As if besmear'd in hell. Sit by us; you shall hear--
This was his gentleman in trust--of him
Things to strike honour sad. Bid him recount
The fore-recited practises; whereof
We cannot feel too little
Stand forth
Out of the Duke of Buckingham.
Speak freely.
First
It would infect his speech
Should without issue die
To make the sceptre his: these very words
I've heard him utter to his son-in-law
Revenge upon the cardinal.
Please your highness
This dangerous conception in this point.
Not friended by by his wish
His will is most malignant; and it stretches
Beyond you
My learn'd lord cardinal
Speak on:
How grounded he his title to the crown
At any time speak aught?
He was brought to this
By a vain prophecy of Nicholas Hopkins.
What was that Hopkins?
Sir
With words of sovereignty.
How know'st thou this?
Not long before your highness sped to France
Saint Lawrence Poultney
What was the speech among the Londoners
Concerning the French journey: I replied
Said
'Twould prove the verity of certain words
Spoke by a holy monk; 'that oft
John de la Car
To hear from him a matter of some moment:
Whom after under the confession's seal
He solemnly had sworn
My chaplain to no creature living
To me
This pausingly ensued: neither the king nor's heirs
To gain the love o' the commonalty: the duke
Shall govern England.'
If I know you well
On the complaint o' the tenants: take good heed
You charge not in your spleen a noble person
And spoil your nobler soul: I say
Yes
Let him on.
Go forward.
On my soul
I told my lord the duke
The monk might be deceived; and that 'twas dangerous for him
To ruminate on this so far
It forged him some design
Should have gone off.
Ha! what
There's mischief in this man: canst thou say further?
I can
Proceed.
Being at Greenwich
About Sir William Blomer
I remember
Of such a time: being my sworn servant
'If
The part my father meant to act upon
The usurper Richard; who
Have put his knife to him.'
A giant traitor!
Now
God mend all!
There's something more would out of thee; what say'st?
After 'the duke his father
He stretch'd him
He did discharge a horrible oath; whose tenor
Was
His father by as much as a performance
Does an irresolute purpose.
There's his period
Call him to present trial: if he may
Find mercy in the law
Exeunt
SCENE III. An ante-chamber in the palace.
Enter Chamberlain and SANDS
Is't possible the spells of France should juggle
Men into such strange mysteries?
New customs
As far as I see
Have got by the late voyage is but merely
A fit or two o' the face; but they are shrewd ones;
For when they hold 'em
Their very noses had been counsellors
To Pepin or Clotharius
They have all new legs
Or springhalt reign'd among 'em.
Death! my lord
Enter LOVELL
How now!
What news
Faith
That's clapp'd upon the court-gate.
What is't for?
The reformation of our travell'd gallants
I'm glad 'tis there: now I would pray our monsieurs
To think an English courtier may be wise
They must either
Of fool and feather that they got in France
Pertaining thereunto
The faith they have in tennis
Or pack to their old playfellows: there
The lag end of their lewdness and be laugh'd at.
'Tis time to give 'em physic
Are grown so catching.
What a loss our ladies
Will have of these trim vanities!
Ay
Have got a speeding trick to lay down ladies;
A French song and a fiddle has no fellow.
The devil fiddle 'em! I am glad they are going
An honest country lord
A long time out of play
And have an hour of hearing; and
Well said
Your colt's tooth is not cast yet.
No
Nor shall not
Sir Thomas
To the cardinal's:
Your lordship is a guest too.
O
This night he makes a supper
The beauty of this kingdom
That churchman bears a bounteous mind indeed
His dews fall every where.
No doubt he's noble;
He had a black mouth that said other of him.
He may
Sparing would show a worse sin than ill doctrine:
Men of his way should be most liberal;
They are set here for examples.
TRUE
But few now give so great ones. My barge stays;
Your lordship shall along. Come
This night to be comptrollers.
I am your lordship's.
Exeunt
