SCENE IV. A Hall in York Place.
Hautboys. A small table under a state for CARDINAL  WOLSEY
Ladies
Salutes ye all; this night he dedicates
To fair content and you: none here
One care abroad; he would have all as merry
As
Enter Chamberlain
The very thought of this fair company
Clapp'd wings to me.
You are young
Sir Thomas Lovell
But half my lay thoughts in him
Should find a running banquet ere they rested
O
To one or two of these!
I would I were;
They should find easy penance.
Faith
As easy as a down-bed would afford it.
Sweet ladies
His grace is entering. Nay
Two women placed together makes cold weather:
My Lord Sands
Pray
By my faith
If I chance to talk a little wild
I had it from my father.
Was he mad
O
But he would bite none; just as I do now
Kisses her
Well said
So
Pass away frowning.
For my little cure
Hautboys. Enter CARDINAL WOLSEY
You're welcome
And to you all
Drinks
Your grace is noble:
Let me have such a bowl may hold my thanks
My Lord Sands
Ladies
The red wine first must rise
In their fair cheeks
Talk us to silence.
You are a merry gamester
Yes
Here's to your ladyship: and pledge it
You cannot show me.
I told your grace they would talk anon.
Drum and trumpet
What's that?
Look out there
Exit Servant
What warlike voice
By all the laws of war you're privileged.
Re-enter Servant
How now! what is't?
A noble troop of strangers;
For so they seem: they've left their barge and landed;
And hither make
From foreign princes.
Good lord chamberlain
And
Into our presence
Shall shine at full upon them. Some attend him.
Exit Chamberlain
You have now a broken banquet; but we'll mend it.
A good digestion to you all: and once more
I shower a welcome on ye; welcome all.
Hautboys. Enter KING HENRY VIII and others
A noble company! what are their pleasures?
Because they speak no English
To tell your grace
Of this so noble and so fair assembly
This night to meet here
Out of the great respect they bear to beauty
An hour of revels with 'em.
Say
A thousand thanks
They choose Ladies for the dance. KING HENRY VIII chooses ANNE
The fairest hand I ever touch'd! O beauty
Music. Dance
My lord!
Your grace?
Pray
There should be one amongst 'em
I would surrender it.
I will
Whispers the Masquers
What say they?
Such a one
Find out
Let me see
By all your good leaves
My royal choice.
Ye have found him
Unmasking
You hold a fair assembly; you do well
You are a churchman
I am glad
Your grace is grown so pleasant.
My lord chamberlain
An't please your grace
The Viscount Rochford
By heaven
Let it go round.
Sir Thomas Lovell
I' the privy chamber?
Yes
Your grace
I fear
There's fresher air
Lead in your ladies
Good my lord cardinal
To drink to these fair ladies
To lead 'em once again; and then let's dream
Who's best in favour. Let the music knock it.
Exeunt with trumpets
ACT II
SCENE I. Westminster. A street.
Enter two Gentlemen
Whither away so fast?
O
Even to the hall
Of the great Duke of Buckingham.
I'll save you
That labour
Of bringing back the prisoner.
Were you there?
Yes
Pray
You may guess quickly what.
Is he found guilty?
Yes
I am sorry for't.
So are a number more.
But
I'll tell you in a little. The great duke
Came to the bar; where to his accusations
He pleaded still not guilty and alleged
Many sharp reasons to defeat the law.
The king's attorney on the contrary
Urged on the examinations
Of divers witnesses; which the duke desired
To have brought viva voce to his face:
At which appear'd against him his surveyor;
Sir Gilbert Peck his chancellor; and John Car
That was he
That fed him with his prophecies?
The same.
All these accused him strongly; which he fain
Would have flung from him
And so his peers
He spoke
Was either pitied in him or forgotten.
After all this
When he was brought again to the bar
His knell rung out
With such an agony
But he fell to himself again
In all the rest show'd a most noble patience.
I do not think he fears death.
Sure
He never was so womanish; the cause
He may a little grieve at.
Certainly
The cardinal is the end of this.
'Tis likely
That trick of state
Was a deep envious one.
At his return
No doubt he will requite it. This is noted
All the commons
Hate him perniciously
They love and dote on; call him bounteous Buckingham
Stay there
Enter BUCKINGHAM from his arraignment; tip-staves  before him; the axe with the edge towards him;  halberds on each side: accompanied with LOVELL
Let's stand close
All good people
I have this day received a traitor's judgment
The law I bear no malice for my death;
'T has done
But those that sought it I could wish more Christians:
Be what they will
Yet let 'em look they glory not in mischief
For then my guiltless blood must cry against 'em.
For further life in this world I ne'er hope
More than I dare make faults. You few that loved me
Is only bitter to him
And
I do beseech your grace
Were hid against me
Sir Thomas Lovell
As I would be forgiven: I forgive all;
There cannot be those numberless offences
'Gainst me
no black envy
Shall mark my grave. Commend me to his grace;
And if he speak of Buckingham
You met him half in heaven: my vows and prayers
Yet are the king's; and
Longer than I have time to tell his years!
Ever beloved and loving may his rule be!
And when old time shall lead him to his end
To the water side I must conduct your grace;
Then give my charge up to Sir Nicholas Vaux
Prepare there
And fit it with such furniture as suits
The greatness of his person.
Nay
When I came hither
And Duke of Buckingham; now
Yet I am richer than my base accusers
And with that blood will make 'em one day groan for't.
My noble father
Henry the Seventh succeeding
My father's loss
That made me happy at one stroke has taken
For ever from the world. I had my trial
Yet thus far we are one in fortunes: both
Fell by our servants
A most unnatural and faithless service!
Heaven has an end in all: yet
Where you are liberal of your loves and counsels
Be sure you be not loose; for those you make friends
And give your hearts to
The least rub in your fortunes
Like water from ye
But where they mean to sink ye. All good people
Of my long weary life is come upon me. Farewell:
And when you would say something that is sad
Exeunt BUCKINGHAM and Train
O
That were the authors.
If the duke be guiltless
Of an ensuing evil
Good angels keep it from us!
What may it be? You do not doubt my faith
This secret is so weighty
A strong faith to conceal it.
Let me have it;
I do not talk much.
I am confident
A buzzing of a separation
Between the king and Katharine?
Yes
For when the king once heard it
He sent command to the lord mayor straight
To stop the rumor
That durst disperse it.
But that slander
Fresher than e'er it was; and held for certain
The king will venture at it. Either the cardinal
To the good queen
That will undo her: to confirm this too
As all think
'Tis the cardinal;
And merely to revenge him on the emperor
For not bestowing on him
I think you have hit the mark: but is't not cruel
That she should feel the smart of this? The cardinal
Will have his will
'Tis woful.
We are too open here to argue this;
Let's think in private more.
Exeunt
SCENE II. An ante-chamber in the palace.
Enter Chamberlain
'My lord
all the care I had
furnished. They were young and handsome
best breed in the north. When they were ready to
set out for London
commission and main power
this reason: His master would be served before a
subject
mouths
I fear he will indeed: well
He will have all
Enter
Well met
Good day to both your graces.
How is the king employ'd?
I left him private
What's the cause?
It seems the marriage with his brother's wife
Has crept too near his conscience.
No
Has crept too near another lady.
'Tis so:
This is the cardinal's doing
That blind priest
Pray God he do! he'll never know himself else.
How holily he works in all his business!
And with what zeal! for
Between us and the emperor
Dangers
And out of all these to restore the king
That
About his neck
Of her that loves him with that excellence
That angels love good men with; even of her
That
Heaven keep me from such counsel! 'Tis most true
These news are every where; every tongue speaks 'em
Look into these affairs see this main end
The king's eyes
This bold bad man.
And free us from his slavery.
We had need pray
Or this imperious man will work us all
From princes into pages: all men's honours
Lie like one lump before him
Into what pitch he please.
For me
As I am made without him
Touch me alike
I knew him
To him that made him proud
Let's in;
And with some other business put the king
From these sad thoughts
My lord
Excuse me;
The king has sent me otherwhere: besides
Health to your lordships.
Thanks
Exit Chamberlain; and KING HENRY VIII draws the curtain
How sad he looks! sure
Who's there
Pray God he be not angry.
Who's there
Into my private meditations?
Who am I? ha?
A gracious king that pardons all offences
Malice ne'er meant: our breach of duty this way
Is business of estate; in which we come
To know your royal pleasure.
Ye are too bold:
Go to; I'll make ye know your times of business:
Is this an hour for temporal affairs
Enter CARDINAL WOLSEY and CARDINAL CAMPEIUS
Who's there? my good lord cardinal? O my Wolsey
Thou art a cure fit for a king.
To CARDINAL CAMPEIUS
You're welcome
Use us and it.
To CARDINAL WOLSEY
My good lord
I be not found a talker.
Sir
I would your grace would give us but an hour
Of private conference.
[To NORFOLK and SUFFOLK]
We are busy; go.
[Aside to SUFFOLK]
This priest has no pride in him?
[Aside to NORFOLK]             Not to speak of:
I would not be so sick though for his place:
But this cannot continue.
[Aside to SUFFOLK]      If it do
[Aside to NORFOLK]          I another.
Exeunt NORFOLK and SUFFOLK
Your grace has given a precedent of wisdom
Above all princes
Your scruple to the voice of Christendom:
Who can be angry now? what envy reach you?
The Spaniard
Have their free voices: Rome
One general tongue unto us
Whom once more I present unto your highness.
And once more in mine arms I bid him welcome
They have sent me such a man I would have wish'd for.
Your grace must needs deserve all strangers' loves
I tender my commission; by whose virtue
Cardinal of York
In the unpartial judging of this business.
Two equal men. The queen shall be acquainted
Forthwith for what you come. Where's Gardiner?
I know your majesty has always loved her
So dear in heart
A woman of less place might ask by law:
Scholars allow'd freely to argue for her.
Ay
To him that does best: God forbid else. Cardinal
I find him a fit fellow.
Exit CARDINAL WOLSEY
Re-enter CARDINAL WOLSEY
[Aside to GARDINER]  Give me your hand much joy and
favour to you;
You are the king's now.
[Aside to CARDINAL WOLSEY]
But to be commanded
For ever by your grace
Come hither
Walks and whispers
My Lord of York
In this man's place before him?
Yes
Was he not held a learned man?
Yes
Believe me
Even of yourself
How! of me?
They will not stick to say you envied him
Heaven's peace be with him!
That's Christian care enough: for living murmurers
There's places of rebuke. He was a fool;
For he would needs be virtuous: that good fellow
I will have none so near else. Learn this
Deliver this with modesty to the queen.
Exit GARDINER
The most convenient place that I can think of
For such receipt of learning is Black-Friars;
There ye shall meet about this weighty business.
My Wolsey
So sweet a bedfellow? But
O
Exeunt
SCENE III. An ante-chamber of the QUEEN'S apartments.
Enter ANNE and an Old Lady
Not for that neither: here's the pang that pinches:
His highness having lived so long with her
So good a lady that no tongue could ever
Pronounce dishonour of her; by my life
So many courses of the sun enthroned
To leave a thousand-fold more bitter than
'Tis sweet at first to acquire
Would move a monster.
Hearts of most hard temper
Melt and lament for her.
O
She ne'er had known pomp: though't be temporal
It from the bearer
As soul and body's severing.
Alas
She's a stranger now again.
So much the more
Must pity drop upon her. Verily
Our content
Is our best having.
By my troth and maidenhead
Beshrew me
You
Affected eminence
Which
Of your soft cheveril conscience would receive
Nay
Yes
No
"Old Lady:	'Tis strange: a three-pence bow'd would hire me"
To bear that load of title?
No
Then you are weakly made: pluck off a little;
I would not be a young count in your way
Cannot vouchsafe this burthen
Ever to get a boy.
How you do talk!
I swear again
For all the world.
In faith
You'ld venture an emballing: I myself
Would for Carnarvonshire
No more to the crown but that. Lo
Enter Chamberlain
Good morrow
The secret of your conference?
My good lord
Our mistress' sorrows we were pitying.
It was a gentle business
The action of good women: there is hope
All will be well.
Now
You bear a gentle mind
Follow such creatures. That you may
Ta'en of your many virtues
Commends his good opinion of you
Does purpose honour to you no less flowing
Than Marchioness of Pembroke: to which title
A thousand pound a year
I do not know
What kind of my obedience I should tender;
More than my all is nothing: nor my prayers
Are not words duly hallow'd
More worth than empty vanities; yet prayers and wishes
Are all I can return. Beseech your lordship
Whose health and royalty I pray for.
Lady
The king hath of you.
Aside
I have perused her well;
Beauty and honour in her are so mingled
That they have caught the king: and who knows yet
But from this lady may proceed a gem
To lighten all this isle? I'll to the king
Exit Chamberlain
My honour'd lord.
Why
I have been begging sixteen years in court
Come pat betwixt too early and too late
For any suit of pounds; and you
A very fresh-fish here--fie
This compell'd fortune!--have your mouth fill'd up
Before you open it.
This is strange to me.
How tastes it? is it bitter? forty pence
There was a lady once
Come
With your theme
O'ermount the lark. The Marchioness of Pembroke!
A thousand pounds a year for pure respect!
No other obligation! By my life
Is longer than his foreskirt. By this time
I know your back will bear a duchess: say
Good lady
The queen is comfortless
In our long absence: pray
What here you've heard to her.
What do you think me?
Exeunt
SCENE IV. A hall in Black-Friars.
Trumpets
Whilst our commission from Rome is read
What's the need?
It hath already publicly been read
You may
Be't so. Proceed.
Say
Henry King of England
Here.
Say
Katharine Queen of England
QUEEN KATHARINE makes no answer
Sir
And to bestow your pity on me: for
I am a most poor woman
No judge indifferent
Of equal friendship and proceeding. Alas
Hath my behavior given to your displeasure
Ever in fear to kindle your dislike
As I saw it inclined: when was the hour
I ever contradicted your desire
Have I not strove to love
He were mine enemy? what friend of mine
That had to him derived your anger
Continue in my liking? nay
He was from thence discharged. Sir
That I have been your wife
With many children by you: if
And process of this time
Shut door upon me
To the sharp'st kind of justice. Please you sir
A prince most prudent
And unmatch'd wit and judgment: Ferdinand
The wisest prince that there had reign'd by many
A year before: it is not to be question'd
That they had gather'd a wise council to them
Of every realm
Beseech you
Be by my friends in Spain advised; whose counsel
I will implore: if not
You have here
Of singular integrity and learning
To plead your cause: it shall be therefore bootless
That longer you desire the court; as well
For your own quiet
What is unsettled in the king.
His grace
Hath spoken well and justly: therefore
And that
Be now produced and heard.
Lord cardinal
Your pleasure
Sir
We are a queen
The daughter of a king
I'll turn to sparks of fire.
Be patient yet.
I will
You are mine enemy
You shall not be my judge: for it is you
Have blown this coal betwixt my lord and me;
Which God's dew quench! Therefore I say again
Refuse you for my judge; whom
At all a friend to truth.
I do profess
You speak not like yourself; who ever yet
Have stood to charity
Of disposition gentle
O'ertopping woman's power. Madam
I have no spleen against you; nor injustice
For you or any: how far I have proceeded
By a commission from the consistory
That I have blown this coal: I do deny it:
The king is present: if it be known to him
That I gainsay my deed
As you have done my truth. If he know
That I am free of your report
I am not of your wrong. Therefore in him
It lies to cure me: and the cure is
Remove these thoughts from you: the which before
His highness shall speak in
You
And to say so no more.
My lord
To oppose your cunning. You're meek and
humble-mouth'd;
You sign your place and calling
Is cramm'd with arrogancy
You have
Where powers are your retainers
Yourself pronounce their office. I must tell you
Your high profession spiritual: that again
I do refuse you for my judge; and here
She curtsies to KING HENRY VIII
The queen is obstinate
Disdainful to be tried by't: 'tis not well.
She's going away.
Call her again.
Katharine Queen of England
Madam
What need you note it? pray you
When you are call'd
I will not tarry; no
Upon this business my appearance make
In any of their courts.
Exeunt QUEEN KATHARINE and her Attendants
Go thy ways
That man i' the world who shall report he has
A better wife
Sovereign and pious else
And
Carried herself towards me.
Most gracious sir
Of all these ears
At once and fully satisfied
Did broach this business to your highness; or
Laid any scruple in your way
Induce you to the question on't? or ever
Have to you
A royal lady
Be to the prejudice of her present state
My lord cardinal
That you have many enemies
Why they are so
The queen is put in anger. You're excused:
But will you be more justified? You ever
Have wish'd the sleeping of this business; never desired
It to be stirr'd; but oft have hinder'd
Then mark the inducement. Thus it came; give heed to't:
My conscience first received a tenderness
By the Bishop of Bayonne
Who had been hither sent on the debating
A marriage 'twixt the Duke of Orleans and
Our daughter Mary: i' the progress of this business
Wherein he might the king his lord advertise
Whether our daughter were legitimate
The bosom of my conscience
The region of my breast; which forced such way
And press'd in with this caution. First
I stood not in the smile of heaven; who had
Commanded nature
Do no more offices of life to't than
The grave does to the dead; for her male issue
Or died where they were made
This world had air'd them: hence I took a thought
Be gladded in't by me: then follows
I weigh'd the danger which my realms stood in
By this my issue's fail; and that gave to me
Many a groaning throe. Thus hulling in
The wild sea of my conscience
Toward this remedy
Now present here together: that's to say
I then did feel full sick
By all the reverend fathers of the land
And doctors learn'd: first I began in private
With you
How under my oppression I did reek
Very well
I have spoke long: be pleased yourself to say
How far you satisfied me.
So please your highness
And consequence of dread
The daring'st counsel which I had to doubt;
And did entreat your highness to this course
Which you are running here.
I then moved you
To make this present summons: unsolicited
I left no reverend person in this court;
But by particular consent proceeded
Under your hands and seals: therefore
For no dislike i' the world against the person
Of the good queen
Of my alleged reasons
Prove but our marriage lawful
And kingly dignity
To wear our mortal state to come with her
That's paragon'd o' the world.
So please your highness
That we adjourn this court till further day:
Meanwhile must be an earnest motion
Made to the queen
She intends unto his holiness.
"[Aside]	I may perceive"
These cardinals trifle with me: I abhor
This dilatory sloth and tricks of Rome.
My learn'd and well-beloved servant
I say
Exeunt in manner as they entered
ACT III
SCENE I. London. QUEEN KATHARINE's apartments.
Enter QUEEN KATHARINE and her Women
Take thy lute
Sing
SONG
Orpheus with his lute made trees
To his music plants and flowers
Ever sprung; as sun and showers
There had made a lasting spring.
Every thing that heard him play
In sweet music is such art
Fall asleep
Enter a Gentleman
How now!
An't please your grace
Wait in the presence.
Would they speak with me?
They will'd me say so
Pray their graces
To come near.
Exit Gentleman
What can be their business
With me
I do not like their coming. Now I think on't
But all hoods make not monks.
Enter CARDINAL WOLSEY and CARDINAL CAMPEIUS
Peace to your highness!
Your graces find me here part of a housewife
What are your pleasures with me
May it please you noble madam
Into your private chamber
The full cause of our coming.
Speak it here:
There's nothing I have done yet
Could speak this with as free a soul as I do!
My lords
Above a number
Were tried by every tongue
Seek me out
Tanta est erga te mentis integritas
serenissima
O
I am not such a truant since my coming
A strange tongue makes my cause more strange
Pray
Believe me
May be absolved in English.
Noble lady
We come not by the way of accusation
How you stand minded in the weighty difference
Between the king and you; and to deliver
And comforts to your cause.
Most honour'd madam
Both of his truth and him
"[Aside]	To betray me.--"
My lords
Ye speak like honest men; pray God
But how to make ye suddenly an answer
More near my life
Among my maids: full little
Either for such men or such business.
For her sake that I have been
The last fit of my greatness
Alas
Madam
Your hopes and friends are infinite.
In England
But little for my profit: can you think
Or be a known friend
They are
In mine own country
I would your grace
Would leave your griefs
How
Put your main cause into the king's protection;
He's loving and most gracious: 'twill be much
Both for your honour better and your cause;
For if the trial of the law o'ertake ye
He tells you rightly.
Ye tell me what ye wish for both
Is this your Christian counsel? out upon ye!
Heaven is above all yet; there sits a judge
That no king can corrupt.
Your rage mistakes us.
The more shame for ye: holy men I thought ye
But cardinal sins and hollow hearts I fear ye:
Mend 'em
The cordial that ye bring a wretched lady
I will not wish ye half my miseries;
I have more charity: but say
Take heed
The burthen of my sorrows fall upon ye.
Madam
You turn the good we offer into envy.
Ye turn me into nothing: woe upon ye
And all such false professors! would you have me--
If you have any justice
If ye be any thing but churchmen's habits--
Put my sick cause into his hands that hates me?
Alas
Is only my obedience. What can happen
To me above this wretchedness? all your studies
Make me a curse like this.
Your fears are worse.
Have I lived thus long--let me speak myself
A woman
Have I with all my full affections
Still met the king? loved him next heaven?
obey'd him?
Been
Almost forgot my prayers to content him?
And am I thus rewarded? 'tis not well
Bring me a constant woman to her husband
And to that woman
Madam
My lord
Your master wed me to: nothing but death
Shall e'er divorce my dignities.
Pray
Would I had never trod this English earth
Ye have angels' faces
What will become of me now
I am the most unhappy woman living.
Alas
Shipwreck'd upon a kingdom
Almost no grave allow'd me: like the lily
If your grace
Could but be brought to know our ends are honest
We are to cure such sorrows
For goodness' sake
How you may hurt yourself
Grow from the king's acquaintance
The hearts of princes kiss obedience
They swell
I know you have a gentle
Those we profess
Madam
With these weak women's fears: a noble spirit
Such doubts
Beware you lose it not: for us
To trust us in your business
To use our utmost  studies in your service.
Do what ye will
You know I am a woman
To make a seemly answer to such persons.
Pray
He has my heart yet; and shall have my prayers
While I shall have my life. Come
Exeunt
SCENE II. Ante-chamber to KING HENRY VIII's apartment.
Enter NORFOLK
If you will now unite in your complaints
Cannot stand under them: if you omit
The offer of this time
But that you shall sustain moe new disgraces
I am joyful
To meet the least occasion that may give me
Remembrance of my father-in-law
Which of the peers
Have uncontemn'd gone by him
Strangely neglected? when did he regard
The stamp of nobleness in any person
Out of himself?
My lords
What he deserves of you and me I know;
What we can do to him
Gives way to us
Bar his access to the king
Any thing on him; for he hath a witchcraft
Over the king in's tongue.
O
His spell in that is out: the king hath found
Matter against him that for ever mars
The honey of his language. No
Sir
Once every hour.
Believe it
In the divorce his contrary proceedings
Are all unfolded wherein he appears
As I would wish mine enemy.
How came
His practises to light?
Most strangely.
O
The cardinal's letters to the pope miscarried
To stay the judgment o' the divorce; for if
It did take place
My king is tangled in affection to
A creature of the queen's
Has the king this?
Believe it.
Will this work?
The king in this perceives him
And hedges his own way. But in this point
All his tricks founder
After his patient's death: the king already
Hath married the fair lady.
Would he had!
May you be happy in your wish
For
Now
Trace the conjunction!
My amen to't!
All men's!
There's order given for her coronation:
Marry
To some ears unrecounted. But
In mind and feature: I persuade me
Will fall some blessing to this land
In it be memorised.
But
Digest this letter of the cardinal's?
The Lord forbid!
Marry
No
There be moe wasps that buzz about his nose
Will make this sting the sooner. Cardinal Campeius
Is stol'n away to Rome; hath ta'en no leave;
Has left the cause o' the king unhandled; and
Is posted
The king cried Ha! at this.
Now
But
He is return'd in his opinions; which
Have satisfied the king for his divorce
Almost in Christendom: shortly
Her coronation. Katharine no more
Shall be call'd queen
And widow to Prince Arthur.
This same Cranmer's
A worthy fellow
In the king's business.
He has; and we shall see him
For it an archbishop.
So I hear.
'Tis so.
The cardinal!
Enter CARDINAL WOLSEY and CROMWELL
Observe
The packet
Gave't you the king?
To his own hand
Look'd he o' the inside of the paper?
Presently
He did unseal them: and the first he view'd
Was in his countenance. You he bade
Attend him here this morning.
Is he ready
To come abroad?
I think
Leave me awhile.
Exit CROMWELL
Aside
It shall be to the Duchess of Alencon
Anne Bullen! No; I'll no Anne Bullens for him:
There's more in't than fair visage. Bullen!
No
To hear from Rome. The Marchioness of Pembroke!
He's discontented.
May be
Does whet his anger to him.
Sharp enough
[Aside]  The late queen's gentlewoman
This candle burns not clear: 'tis I must snuff it;
Then out it goes. What though I know her virtuous
And well deserving? yet I know her for
A spleeny Lutheran; and not wholesome to
Our cause
Our hard-ruled king. Again
An heretic
Hath crawl'd into the favour of the king
He is vex'd at something.
I would 'twere something that would fret the string
Enter KING HENRY VIII
The king
What piles of wealth hath he accumulated
To his own portion! and what expense by the hour
Seems to flow from him! How
My lord
Stood here observing him: some strange commotion
Is in his brain: he bites his lip
Stops on a sudden
Springs out into fast gait; then stops again
His eye against the moon: in most strange postures
We have seen him set himself.
It may well be;
There is a mutiny in's mind. This morning
Papers of state he sent me to peruse
There
Forsooth
The several parcels of his plate
I find at such proud rate
Possession of a subject.
It's heaven's will:
Some spirit put this paper in the packet
If we did think
His contemplation were above the earth
Dwell in his musings: but I am afraid
His thinkings are below the moon
His serious considering.
King HENRY VIII takes his seat; whispers LOVELL
Heaven forgive me!
Ever God bless your highness!
Good my lord
Of your best graces in your mind; the which
You were now running o'er: you have scarce time
To steal from spiritual leisure a brief span
To keep your earthly audit: sure
I deem you an ill husband
To have you therein my companion.
Sir
To think upon the part of business which
I bear i' the state; and nature does require
Her times of preservation
I
You have said well.
And ever may your highness yoke together
With my well saying!
'Tis well said again;
And 'tis a kind of good deed to say well:
And yet words are no deeds. My father loved you:
His said he did; and with his deed did crown
His word upon you. Since I had my office
Employ'd you where high profits might come home
My bounties upon you.
[Aside]             What should this mean?
[Aside]  The Lord increase this business!
Have I not made you
And
My sovereign
My studied purposes requite; which went
Beyond all man's endeavours: my endeavours
Have ever come too short of my desires
Have been mine so that evermore they pointed
To the good of your most sacred person and
The profit of the state. For your great graces
Heap'd upon me
Can nothing render but allegiant thanks
Fairly answer'd;
A loyal and obedient subject is
Therein illustrated: the honour of it
Does pay the act of it; as
That
On you than any; so your hand and heart
To me
I do profess
That for your highness' good I ever labour'd
More than mine own; that am
Though all the world should crack their duty to you
Abound
Appear in forms more horrid
'Tis nobly spoken:
Take notice
Giving him papers
And after
What appetite you have.
Exit KING HENRY VIII
What should this mean?
What sudden anger's this? how have I reap'd it?
He parted frowning from me
Leap'd from his eyes: so looks the chafed lion
Upon the daring huntsman that has gall'd him;
Then makes him nothing. I must read this paper;
I fear
This paper has undone me: 'tis the account
Of all that world of wealth I have drawn together
For mine own ends; indeed
Fit for a fool to fall by: what cross devil
Made me put this main secret in the packet
I sent the king? Is there no way to cure this?
No new device to beat this from his brains?
I know 'twill stir him strongly; yet I know
A way
Will bring me off again. What's this? 'To the Pope!'
The letter
I writ to's holiness. Nay then
I have touch'd the highest point of all my greatness;
And
Like a bright exhalation m the evening
Re-enter to CARDINAL WOLSEY
Hear the king's pleasure
To render up the great seal presently
Into our hands; and to confine yourself
To Asher House
Stay:
Where's your commission
Authority so weighty.
Who dare cross 'em
Till I find more than will or words to do it
Of what coarse metal ye are moulded
How eagerly ye follow my disgraces
Ye appear in every thing may bring my ruin!
Follow your envious courses
You have Christian warrant for 'em
Bade me enjoy it
The king
It must be himself
Thou art a proud traitor
Proud lord
Within these forty hours Surrey durst better
Have burnt that tongue than said so.
Thy ambition
Of noble Buckingham
The heads of all thy brother cardinals
You sent me deputy for Ireland;
Far from his succor
That might have mercy on the fault thou gavest him;
Whilst your great goodness
This
This talking lord can lay upon my credit
Found his deserts: how innocent I was
From any private malice in his end
If I loved many words
You have as little honesty as honour
Toward the king
By my soul
shouldst feel
My sword i' the life-blood of thee else. My lords
And from this fellow? if we live thus tamely
All goodness
Is poison to thy stomach.
Yes
Of gleaning all the land's wealth into one
The goodness of your intercepted packets
You writ to the pope against the king: your goodness
My Lord of Norfolk
Of our despised nobility
Collected from his life. I'll startle you
Worse than the scaring bell
Lay kissing in your arms
How much
Those articles
But
So much fairer
And spotless shall mine innocence arise
This cannot save you:
I thank my memory
Some of these articles; and out they shall.
Now
Speak on
I dare your worst objections: if I blush
I had rather want those than my head. Have at you!
First
You maim'd the jurisdiction of all bishops.
Then
To foreign princes
Was still inscribed; in which you brought the king
To be your servant.
Then that
Either of king or council
Ambassador to the emperor
To carry into Flanders the great seal.
Item
To Gregory de Cassado
That
Your holy hat to be stamp'd on the king's coin.
Then that you have sent innumerable substance--
By what means got
To furnish Rome
You have for dignities; to the mere undoing
Of all the kingdom. Many more there are;
Which
O my lord
His faults lie open to the laws; let them
So little of his great self.
I forgive him.
Lord cardinal
To forfeit all your goods
Out of the king's protection. This is my charge.
And so we'll leave you to your meditations
How to live better. For your stubborn answer
About the giving back the great seal to us
So fare you well
Exeunt all but CARDINAL WOLSEY
So farewell to the little good you bear me.
Farewell! a long farewell
This is the state of man: to-day he puts forth
The tender leaves of hopes; to-morrow blossoms
The third day comes a frost
His greatness is a-ripening
At length broke under me and now has left me
Of a rude stream
Vain pomp and glory of this world
I feel my heart new open'd. O
Is that poor man that hangs on princes' favours!
There is
And when he falls
Enter CROMWELL
Why
I have no power to speak
What
At my misfortunes? can thy spirit wonder
A great man should decline? Nay
How does your grace?
Why
Never so truly happy
I know myself now; and I feel within me
A peace above all earthly dignities
A load would sink a navy
O
Too heavy for a man that hopes for heaven!
I am glad your grace has made that right use of it.
I hope I have: I am able now
Than my weak-hearted enemies dare offer.
What news abroad?
The heaviest and the worst
Is your displeasure with the king.
God bless him!
The next is
Lord chancellor in your place.
That's somewhat sudden:
But he's a learned man. May he continue
Long in his highness' favour
For truth's sake and his conscience; that his bones
That Cranmer is return'd with welcome
That's news indeed.
Last
Only about her coronation.
There was the weight that pull'd me down. O Cromwell
In that one woman I have lost for ever:
No sun shall ever usher forth mine honours
Upon my smiles. Go
I am a poor fall'n man
To be thy lord and master: seek the king;
That sun
What and how true thou art: he will advance thee;
Some little memory of me will stir him--
I know his noble nature--not to let
Thy hopeful service perish too: good Cromwell
For thine own future safety.
O my lord
So good
Bear witness
The king shall have my service: but my prayers
For ever and for ever shall be yours.
Cromwell
In all my miseries; but thou hast forced me
Let's dry our eyes: and thus far hear me
And
Of me more must be heard of
A sure and safe one
Mark but my fall
Cromwell
By that sin fell the angels; how can man
Love thyself last: cherish those hearts that hate thee;
Corruption wins not more than honesty.
Still in thy right hand carry gentle peace
Let all the ends thou aim'st at be thy country's
And
There take an inventory of all I have
I dare now call mine own. O Cromwell
Had I but served my God with half the zeal
I served my king
Have left me naked to mine enemies.
Good sir
So I have. Farewell
The hopes of court! my hopes in heaven do dwell.
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. A street in Westminster.
Enter two Gentlemen
You're well met once again.
So are you.
You come to take your stand here
The Lady Anne pass from her coronation?
'Tis all my business. At our last encounter
'Tis very true: but that time offer'd sorrow;
This
'Tis well: the citizens
As
In celebration of this day with shows
Never greater
May I be bold to ask at what that contains
Yes; 'tis the list
Of those that claim their offices this day
By custom of the coronation.
The Duke of Suffolk is the first
To be high-steward; next
I thank you
But
That I can tell you too. The Archbishop
Of Canterbury
Learned and reverend fathers of his order
From Ampthill where the princess lay; to which
She was often cited by them
And
The king's late scruple
Of all these learned men she was divorced
Since which she was removed to Kimbolton
Alas
Trumpets
The trumpets sound: stand close
Hautboys
THE ORDER OF THE CORONATION
1. A lively flourish of Trumpets.
2. Then
3. Lord Chancellor
before him.
4. Choristers
Music
5. Mayor of London
Garter
head a gilt copper crown.
6. Marquess Dorset
him
the dove
Collars of SS.
7. SUFFOLK
on his head
high-steward. With him
rod of marshalship
Collars of SS.
8. A canopy borne by four of the Cinque-ports;
under it
richly adorned with pearl
side her
Winchester.
9. The old Duchess of Norfolk
gold
ANNE's train.
10. Certain Ladies or Countesses
circlets of gold without flowers.
They pass over the stage in order and state
A royal train
Who's that that bears the sceptre?
Marquess Dorset:
And that the Earl of Surrey
A bold brave gentleman. That should be
The Duke of Suffolk?
'Tis the same: high-steward.
And that my Lord of Norfolk?
Yes;
Heaven bless thee!
Looking on QUEEN ANNE
Thou hast the sweetest face I ever look'd on.
Sir
Our king has all the Indies in his arms
I cannot blame his conscience.
They that bear
The cloth of honour over her
Of the Cinque-ports.
Those men are happy; and so are all are near her.
I take it
Is that old noble lady
It is; and all the rest are countesses.
Their coronets say so. These are stars indeed;
And sometimes falling ones.
No more of that.
Exit procession
Enter a third Gentleman
God save you
Among the crowd i' the Abbey; where a finger
Could not be wedged in more: I am stifled
With the mere rankness of their joy.
You saw
The ceremony?
That I did.
How was it?
Well worth the seeing.
Good sir
As well as I am able. The rich stream
Of lords and ladies
To a prepared place in the choir
A distance from her; while her grace sat down
To rest awhile
The beauty of her person to the people.
Believe me
That ever lay by man: which when the people
Had the full view of
As the shrouds make at sea in a stiff tempest
Doublets
Been loose
I never saw before. Great-bellied women
In the old time of war
Could say 'This is my wife' there; all were woven
So strangely in one piece.
But
At length her grace rose
Came to the altar; where she kneel'd
Cast her fair eyes to heaven and pray'd devoutly.
Then rose again and bow'd her to the people:
When by the Archbishop of Canterbury
She had all the royal makings of a queen;
As holy oil
Laid nobly on her: which perform'd
To York-place
Sir
For
'Tis now the king's
I know it;
But 'tis so lately alter'd
Is fresh about me.
What two reverend bishops
Were those that went on each side of the queen?
Stokesly and Gardiner; the one of Winchester
He of Winchester
Is held no great good lover of the archbishop's
All the land knows that:
However
Who may that be
Thomas Cromwell;
A man in much esteem with the king
A worthy friend. The king has made him master
O' the jewel house
He will deserve more.
Yes
Come
Is to the court
Something I can command. As I walk thither
You may command us
Exeunt
SCENE II. Kimbolton.
Enter KATHARINE
How does your grace?
O Griffith
My legs
So; now
Didst thou not tell me
Yes
Prithee
If well
For my example.
Well
For after the stout Earl Northumberland
Arrested him at York
He could not sit his mule.
Alas
At last
To whom he gave these words
Give him a little earth for charity!'
So went to bed; where eagerly his sickness
Pursued him still: and
Foretold should be his last
So may he rest; his faults lie gently on him!
Yet thus far
Of an unbounded stomach
Himself with princes; one that
His own opinion was his law: i' the presence
He would say untruths; and be ever double
Both in his words and meaning: he was never
His promises were
But his performance
Of his own body he was ill
The clergy in example.
Noble madam
We write in water. May it please your highness
To hear me speak his good now?
Yes
I were malicious else.
This cardinal
Was fashion'd to much honour from his cradle.
He was a scholar
Exceeding wise
Lofty and sour to them that loved him not;
But to those men that sought him sweet as summer.
And though he were unsatisfied in getting
Those twins Of learning that he raised in you
The other
His overthrow heap'd happiness upon him;
For then
And
Than man could give him
After my death I wish no other herald
Whom I most hated living
Patience
I have not long to trouble thee. Good Griffith
I named my knell
On that celestial harmony I go to.
Sad and solemn music
She is asleep: good wench
The vision. Enter
Spirits of peace
Madam
It is not you I call for:
Saw ye none enter since I slept?
None
No? Saw you not
Invite me to a banquet; whose bright faces
Cast thousand beams upon me
They promised me eternal happiness;
And brought me garlands
I am not worthy yet to wear: I shall
I am most joyful
Possess your fancy.
Bid the music leave
Music ceases
Do you note
How much her grace is alter'd on the sudden?
How long her face is drawn? how pale she looks
She is going
Heaven comfort her!
Enter a Messenger
An't like your grace
You are a saucy fellow:
Deserve we no more reverence?
You are to blame
I humbly do entreat your highness' pardon;
My haste made me unmannerly. There is staying
A gentleman
Admit him entrance
Let me ne'er see again.
Exeunt GRIFFITH and Messenger
Re-enter GRIFFITH
If my sight fail not
Madam
O
With me since first you knew me. But
Noble lady
Who grieves much for your weakness
Sends you his princely commendations
O my good lord
'Tis like a pardon after execution:
That gentle physic
But now I am past an comforts here
How does his highness?
Madam
So may he ever do! and ever flourish
Banish'd the kingdom! Patience
No
Giving it to KATHARINE
Sir
This to my lord the king.
Most willing
In which I have commended to his goodness
The model of our chaste loves
The dews of heaven fall thick in blessings on her!
Beseeching him to give her virtuous breeding--
She is young
To love her for her mother's sake
Is
Upon my wretched women
Have follow'd both my fortunes faithfully:
Of which there is not one
For virtue and true beauty of the soul
And
The last is
That they may have their wages duly paid 'em
If heaven had pleased to have given me longer life
And able means
These are the whole contents: and
To do me this last right.
By heaven
I thank you
In all humility unto his highness:
Say his long trouble now is passing
Out of this world; tell him
Call in more women. When I am dead
With maiden flowers
I was a chaste wife to my grave: embalm me
A queen
I can no more.
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. London. A gallery in the palace.
Enter GARDINER
It's one o'clock
It hath struck.
These should be hours for necessities
With comforting repose
To waste these times. Good hour of night
Whither so late?
Came you from the king
I did
With the Duke of Suffolk.
I must to him too
Not yet
It seems you are in haste: an if there be
No great offence belongs to't
Some touch of your late business: affairs
In them a wilder nature than the business
That seeks dispatch by day.
My lord
And durst commend a secret to your ear
Much weightier than this work. The queen's in labour
She'll with the labour end.
The fruit she goes with
I pray for heartily
Good time
Methinks I could
Cry the amen; and yet my conscience says
She's a good creature
Deserve our better wishes.
But
Of mine own way; I know you wise
And
Now
The most remark'd i' the kingdom. As for Cromwell
O' the rolls
Is the king's hand and tongue; and who dare speak
One syllable against him?
Yes
To speak my mind of him: and indeed this day
Incensed the lords o' the council
That does infect the land: with which they moved
Have broken with the king; who hath so far
Given ear to our complaint
And princely care foreseeing those fell mischiefs
Our reasons laid before him
To-morrow morning to the council-board
He be convented. He's a rank weed
I hinder you too long: good night
Many good nights
Exeunt GARDINER and Page
Enter KING HENRY VIII and SUFFOLK
Charles
My mind's not on't; you are too hard for me.
Sir
But little
Nor shall not
Now
I could not personally deliver to her
What you commanded me
I sent your message; who return'd her thanks
In the great'st humbleness
Most heartily to pray for her.
What say'st thou
To pray for her? what
So said her woman; and that her sufferance made
Almost each pang a death.
Alas
God safely quit her of her burthen
With gentle travail
Your highness with an heir!
'Tis midnight
Prithee
The estate of my poor queen. Leave me alone;
For I must think of that which company
Would not be friendly to.
I wish your highness
A quiet night; and my good mistress will
Remember in my prayers.
Charles
Exit SUFFOLK
Enter DENNY
Well
Sir
Ha! Canterbury?
Ay
'Tis true: where is he
He attends your highness' pleasure.
Exit DENNY
[Aside]  This is about that which the bishop spake:
I am happily come hither.
Re-enter DENNY
Avoid the gallery.
LOVELL seems to stay
Ha! I have said. Be gone. What!
Exeunt LOVELL and DENNY
[Aside]
I am fearful: wherefore frowns he thus?
'Tis his aspect of terror. All's not well.
How now
Wherefore I sent for you.
[Kneeling]              It is my duty
To attend your highness' pleasure.
Pray you
Come
I have news to tell you: come
Ah
I have
Heard many grievous
This morning come before us; where
Which will require your answer
Your patience to you
To make your house our Tower: you a brother of us
Would come against you.
[Kneeling]
I humbly thank your highness;
And am right glad to catch this good occasion
Most throughly to be winnow'd
And corn shall fly asunder: for
Than I myself
Stand up
Thy truth and thy integrity is rooted
In us
Prithee
What manner of man are you? My lord
You would have given me your petition
I should have ta'en some pains to bring together
Yourself and your accusers; and to have heard you
Most dread liege
If they shall fail
What can be said against me.
Know you not
How your state stands i' the world
Your enemies are many
Must bear the same proportion; and not ever
The justice and the truth o' the question carries
The due o' the verdict with it: at what ease
Might corrupt minds procure knaves as corrupt
To swear against you? such things have been done.
You are potently opposed; and with a malice
Of as great size. Ween you of better luck
Upon this naughty earth? Go to
You take a precipice for no leap of danger
God and your majesty
Protect mine innocence
The trap is laid for me!
Be of good cheer;
They shall no more prevail than we give way to.
Keep comfort to you; and this morning see
You do appear before them: if they shall chance
Fail not to use
The occasion shall instruct you: if entreaties
Will render you no remedy
Deliver them
There make before them. Look
He's honest
I swear he is true--hearted; and a soul
None better in my kingdom. Get you gone
Exit CRANMER
He has strangled
His language in his tears.
Enter Old Lady
[Within]                 Come back: what mean you?
I'll not come back; the tidings that I bring
Will make my boldness manners. Now
Fly o'er thy royal head
Under their blessed wings!
Now
I guess thy message. Is the queen deliver'd?
Say
Ay
And of a lovely boy: the God of heaven
Both now and ever bless her! 'tis a girl
Desires your visitation
Acquainted with this stranger 'tis as like you
As cherry is to cherry.
Lovell!
Sir?
Give her an hundred marks. I'll to the queen.
Exit
An hundred marks! By this light
An ordinary groom is for such payment.
I will have more
Said I for this
I will have more
Exeunt
SCENE II. Before the council-chamber. Pursuivants
attending.
Enter CRANMER
I hope I am not too late; and yet the gentleman
To make great haste. All fast? what means this? Ho!
Who waits there? Sure
Enter Keeper
Yes
But yet I cannot help you.
Why?
Enter DOCTOR BUTTS
Your grace must wait till you be call'd for.
So.
[Aside]  This is a piece of malice. I am glad
I came this way so happily: the king
Shall understand it presently.
Exit
"[Aside]	'Tis Butts"
Pray heaven
God turn their hearts! I never sought their malice--
To quench mine honour: they would shame to make me
Wait else at door
Must be fulfill'd
Enter the KING HENRY VIII and DOCTOR BUTTS at a window above
I'll show your grace the strangest sight--
What's that
I think your highness saw this many a day.
Body o' me
There
The high promotion of his grace of Canterbury;
Who holds his state at door
Ha! 'tis he
Is this the honour they do one another?
'Tis well there's one above 'em yet. I had thought
They had parted so much honesty among 'em
At least
A man of his place
By holy Mary
Let 'em alone
We shall hear more anon.
Exeunt
SCENE III. The Council-Chamber.
Enter Chancellor; places himself at the upper end  of the table on the left hand; a seat being left  void above him
Speak to the business
Why are we met in council?
Please your honours
Has he had knowledge of it?
Yes.
Who waits there?
Without
Yes.
My lord archbishop;
And has done half an hour
Let him come in.
Your grace may enter now.
CRANMER enters and approaches the council-table
My good lord archbishop
To sit here at this present
That chair stand empty: but we all are men
Of our flesh; few are angels: out of which frailty
And want of wisdom
The whole realm
Which reformation must be sudden too
Pace 'em not in their hands to make 'em gentle
To one man's honour
Commotions
Of the whole state: as
My good lords
Both of my life and office
And the strong course of my authority
Might go one way
Was ever
Pray heaven
With less allegiance in it! Men that make
Envy and crooked malice nourishment
Dare bite the best. I do beseech your lordships
Nay
My lord
Where
Ah
You are always my good friend; if your will pass
'Tis my undoing: love and meekness
Win straying souls with modesty again
In doing daily wrongs. I could say more
My lord
My Lord of Winchester
For what they have been: 'tis a cruelty
To load a falling man.
Good master secretary
Of all this table
Why
Do not I know you for a favourer
Of this new sect? ye are not sound.
Not sound?
Not sound
Would you were half so honest!
Men's prayers then would seek you
I shall remember this bold language.
Do.
Remember your bold life too.
This is too much;
Forbear
I have done.
And I.
Then thus for you
You be convey'd to the Tower a prisoner;
There to remain till the king's further pleasure
Be known unto us: are you all agreed
We are.
Is there no other way of mercy
What other
Would you expect? you are strangely troublesome.
Let some o' the guard be ready there.
Enter Guard
For me?
Must I go like a traitor thither?
Receive him
Stay
By virtue of that ring
Out of the gripes of cruel men
To a most noble judge
This is the king's ring.
'Tis no counterfeit.
'Tis the right ring
Do you think
Of this man to be vex'd?
'Tis now too certain:
How much more is his life in value with him?
Would I were fairly out on't!
My mind gave me
Against this man
And his disciples only envy at
Enter KING
Dread sovereign
In daily thanks
Not only good and wise
One that
The chief aim of his honour; and
That holy duty
The cause betwixt her and this great offender.
You were ever good at sudden commendations
To hear such flattery now
They are too thin and bare to hide offences.
To me you cannot reach
But
Thou hast a cruel nature and a bloody.
To CRANMER
Good man
He
By all that's holy
Than but once think this place becomes thee not.
May it please your grace
No
I had thought I had had men of some understanding
And wisdom of my council; but I find none.
Was it discretion
This honest man
At chamber--door? and one as great as you are?
Why
Bid ye so far forget yourselves? I gave ye
Power as he was a counsellor to try him
Which ye shall never have while I live.
Thus far
To let my tongue excuse all. What was purposed
Concerning his imprisonment
Well
Take him
I will say thus much for him
May be beholding to a subject
Am
Make me no more ado
Be friends
Canterbury
That is
The greatest monarch now alive may glory
In such an honour: how may I deserve it
That am a poor and humble subject to you?
Come
shall have two noble partners with you; the old
Duchess of Norfolk
these please you?
Once more
With a true heart
And brother-love I do it.
And let heaven
Witness
Good man
The common voice
Of thee
A shrewd turn
Come
To have this young one made a Christian.
As I have made ye one
So I grow stronger
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The palace yard.
Noise and tumult within. Enter Porter and his Man
You'll leave your noise anon
take the court for Paris-garden? ye rude slaves
Within
Good master porter
Belong to the gallows
this a place to roar in? Fetch me a dozen crab-tree
staves
'em. I'll scratch your heads: you must be seeing
christenings? do you look for ale and cakes here
Pray
Unless we sweep 'em from the door with cannons--
To scatter 'em
On May-day morning; which will never be:
We may as well push against Powle's
How got they in
Alas
As much as one sound cudgel of four foot--
You see the poor remainder--could distribute
You did nothing
I am not Samson
That had a head to hit
And that I would not for a cow
Within
Do you hear
I shall be with you presently
Keep the door close
What would you have me do?
What should you do
dozens? Is this Moorfields to muster in? or have
we some strange Indian with the great tool come to
court
fry of fornication is at door! On my Christian
conscience
thousand; here will be father
The spoons will be the bigger
fellow somewhat near the door
brazier by his face
of the dog-days now reign in's nose; all that stand
about him are under the line
penance: that fire-drake did I hit three times on
the head
against me; he stands there
blow us. There was a haberdasher's wife of small
wit near him
porringer fell off her head
combustion in the state. I missed the meteor once
might see from far some forty truncheoners draw to
her succor
she was quartered. They fell on; I made good my
place: at length they came to the broom-staff to
me; I defied 'em still: when suddenly a file of
boys behind 'em
of pebbles
'em
These are the youths that thunder at a playhouse
the tribulation of Tower-hill
Limehouse
I have some of 'em in Limbo Patrum
are like to dance these three days; besides the
running banquet of two beadles that is to come.
Enter Chamberlain
Mercy o' me
They grow still too; from all parts they are coming
There's a trim rabble let in: are all these
Your faithful friends o' the suburbs? We shall have
Great store of room
An't please
your honour
An army cannot rule 'em.
As I live
By the heels
Clap round fines for neglect: ye are lazy knaves;
And here ye lie baiting of bombards
Ye should do service. Hark! the trumpets sound;
They're come already from the christening:
Go
To let the troop pass fairly; or I'll find
A Marshalsea shall hold ye play these two months.
Make way there for the princess.
You great fellow
You i' the camlet
I'll peck you o'er the pales else.
Exeunt
SCENE V. The palace.
Enter trumpets
Heaven
life
princess of England
Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VIII and Guard
[Kneeling] And to your royal grace
All comfort
Thank you
What is her name?
Elizabeth.
Stand up
KING HENRY VIII kisses the child
With this kiss take my blessing: God protect thee!
Into whose hand I give thy life.
Amen.
My noble gossips
I thank ye heartily; so shall this lady
Let me speak
Let none think flattery
This royal infant--heaven still move about her!--
Though in her cradle
Upon this land a thousand thousand blessings
But few now living can behold that goodness--
A pattern to all princes living with her
More covetous of wisdom and fair virtue
Than this pure soul shall be: all princely graces
She shall be loved and fear'd: her own shall bless her;
Her foes shake like a field of beaten corn
In her days every man shall eat in safety
The merry songs of peace to all his neighbours:
God shall be truly known; and those about her
From her shall read the perfect ways of honour
Nor shall this peace sleep with her: but as when
The bird of wonder dies
So shall she leave her blessedness to one
Shall star-like rise
Wherever the bright sun of heaven shall shine
Shall be
To all the plains about him: our children's children
Shall see this
Thou speakest wonders.
She shall be
Would I had known no more! but she must die
To the ground
O lord archbishop
This happy child
This oracle of comfort has so pleased me
To see what this child does
I thank ye all. To you
I have received much honour by your presence
Ye must all see the queen
Has business at his house; for all shall stay:
This little one shall make it holiday.
Exeunt
EPILOGUE
'Tis ten to one this play can never please
All that are here: some come to take their ease
Abused extremely
Which we have not done neither: that
For this play at this time
The merciful construction of good women;
For such a one we show'd 'em: if they smile
All the best men are ours; for 'tis ill hap
ACT I
SCENE I. KING JOHN'S palace.
Enter KING JOHN
Now
Thus
In my behavior to the majesty
A strange beginning: 'borrow'd majesty!'
Silence
Philip of France
Of thy deceased brother Geffrey's son
To this fair island and the territories
Which sways usurpingly these several titles
What follows if we disallow of this?
The proud control of fierce and bloody war
Here have we war for war and blood for blood
Then take my king's defiance from my mouth
Bear mine to him
Be thou as lightning in the eyes of France;
For ere thou canst report I will be there
So hence! Be thou the trumpet of our wrath
And sullen presage of your own decay.
An honourable conduct let him have:
Pembroke
Exeunt CHATILLON and PEMBROKE
What now
How that ambitious Constance would not cease
Till she had kindled France and all the world
This might have been prevented and made whole
With very easy arguments of love
With fearful bloody issue arbitrate.
Our strong possession and our right for us.
Your strong possession much more than your right
So much my conscience whispers in your ear
Enter a Sheriff
My liege
Come from country to be judged by you
Let them approach.
Our abbeys and our priories shall pay
This expedition's charge.
Enter ROBERT and the BASTARD
What men are you?
Your faithful subject I
Born in Northamptonshire and eldest son
Of Coeur-de-lion knighted in the field.
What art thou?
The son and heir to that same Faulconbridge.
Is that the elder
You came not of one mother then
Most certain of one mother
That is well known; and
But for the certain knowledge of that truth
I put you o'er to heaven and to my mother:
Of that I doubt
Out on thee
And wound her honour with this diffidence.
I
That is my brother's plea and none of mine;
The which if he can prove
At least from fair five hundred pound a year:
Heaven guard my mother's honour and my land!
A good blunt fellow. Why
I know not why
But once he slander'd me with bastardy:
But whether I be as true begot or no
Fair fall the bones that took the pains for me!--
Compare our faces and be judge yourself.
If old sir Robert did beget us both
And were our father and this son like him
I give heaven thanks I was not like to thee!
Why
He hath a trick of Coeur-de-lion's face;
The accent of his tongue affecteth him.
Do you not read some tokens of my son
In the large composition of this man?
Mine eye hath well examined his parts
And finds them perfect Richard. Sirrah
Because he hath a half-face
With half that face would he have all my land:
A half-faced groat five hundred pound a year!
My gracious liege
Well
Your tale must be how he employ'd my mother.
And once dispatch'd him in an embassy
To Germany
To treat of high affairs touching that time.
The advantage of his absence took the king
And in the mean time sojourn'd at my father's;
Where how he did prevail I shame to speak
Between my father and my mother lay
Upon his death-bed he by will bequeath'd
His lands to me
That this my mother's son was none of his;
And if he were
Full fourteen weeks before the course of time.
Then
Sirrah
Your father's wife did after wedlock bear him
Which fault lies on the hazards of all husbands
That marry wives. Tell me
In sooth
This calf bred from his cow from all the world;
In sooth he might; then
My mother's son did get your father's heir;
Your father's heir must have your father's land.
Shall then my father's will be of no force
To dispossess that child which is not his?
Of no more force to dispossess me
Whether hadst thou rather be a Faulconbridge
And like thy brother
Madam
And if my legs were two such riding-rods
That in mine ear I durst not stick a rose
Lest men should say 'Look
And
I would not be sir Nob in any case.
I like thee well: wilt thou forsake thy fortune
I am a soldier and now bound to France.
Brother
Your face hath got five hundred pound a year
Madam
Nay
Our country manners give our betters way.
What is thy name?
Philip
From henceforth bear his name whose form thou bear'st:
Kneel thou down Philip
Brother by the mother's side
My father gave me honour
Now blessed by the hour
The very spirit of Plantagenet!
I am thy grandam
Madam
Something about
Who dares not stir by day must walk by night
Near or far off
Go
A landless knight makes thee a landed squire.
Come
For France
Brother
For thou wast got i' the way of honesty.
Exeunt all but BASTARD
A foot of honour better than I was;
But many a many foot of land the worse.
Well
'Good den
And if his name be George
For new-made honour doth forget men's names;
'Tis too respective and too sociable
For your conversion. Now your traveller
My picked man of countries: 'My dear sir
Thus
And then comes answer like an Absey book:
'O sir
At your employment; at your service
'No
And so
But this is worshipful society
And fits the mounting spirit like myself
That doth not smack of observation;
And so am I
And not alone in habit and device
Sweet
Which
For it shall strew the footsteps of my rising.
But who comes in such haste in riding-robes?
What woman-post is this? hath she no husband
That will take pains to blow a horn before her?
Enter LADY FAULCONBRIDGE and GURNEY
O me! it is my mother. How now
What brings you here to court so hastily?
Where is that slave
My brother Robert? old sir Robert's son?
Colbrand the giant
Is it sir Robert's son that you seek so?
Sir Robert's son! Ay
He is sir Robert's son
James Gurney
Good leave
Philip! sparrow: James
Exit GURNEY
Madam
Sir Robert might have eat his part in me
Upon Good-Friday and ne'er broke his fast:
Sir Robert could do well: marry
We know his handiwork: therefore
Sir Robert never holp to make this leg.
Hast thou conspired with thy brother too
What means this scorn
Knight
What! I am dubb'd! I have it on my shoulder.
But
I have disclaim'd sir Robert and my land;
Legitimation
Then
Some proper man
Hast thou denied thyself a Faulconbridge?
As faithfully as I deny the devil.
King Richard Coeur-de-lion was thy father:
By long and vehement suit I was seduced
To make room for him in my husband's bed:
Heaven lay not my transgression to my charge!
Thou art the issue of my dear offence
Now
Some sins do bear their privilege on earth
Needs must you lay your heart at his dispose
The aweless lion could not wage the fight
He that perforce robs lions of their hearts
May easily win a woman's. Ay
Who lives and dares but say thou didst not well
When I was got
Come
And they shall say
Who says it was
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. France. Before Angiers.
Enter AUSTRIA and forces
Before Angiers well met
Arthur
And fought the holy wars in Palestine
And for amends to his posterity
Of thy unnatural uncle
Embrace him
God shall forgive you Coeur-de-lion's death
The rather that you give his offspring life
I give you welcome with a powerless hand
Welcome before the gates of Angiers
A noble boy! Who would not do thee right?
Upon thy cheek lay I this zealous kiss
And coops from other lands her islanders
And confident from foreign purposes
Salute thee for her king: till then
O
To make a more requital to your love!
The peace of heaven is theirs that lift their swords
In such a just and charitable war.
Well then
Against the brows of this resisting town.
Call for our chiefest men of discipline
We'll lay before this town our royal bones
Stay for an answer to your embassy
My Lord Chatillon may from England bring
That hot rash haste so indirectly shed.
Enter CHATILLON
A wonder
What England says
We coldly pause for thee; Chatillon
Then turn your forces from this paltry siege
And stir them up against a mightier task.
England
To land his legions all as soon as I;
His marches are expedient to this town
With him along is come the mother-queen
With her her niece
With them a bastard of the king's deceased
In brief
Than now the English bottoms have waft o'er
Did nearer float upon the swelling tide
Drum beats
The interruption of their churlish drums
Cuts off more circumstance: they are at hand
How much unlook'd for is this expedition!
By how much unexpected
We must awake endavour for defence;
For courage mounteth with occasion:
Let them be welcome then: we are prepared.
Enter KING JOHN
Peace be to France
Our just and lineal entrance to our own;
If not
Their proud contempt that beats His peace to heaven.
Peace be to England
From France to England
England we love; and for that England's sake
With burden of our armour here we sweat.
This toil of ours should be a work of thine;
But thou from loving England art so far
Cut off the sequence of posterity
Upon the maiden virtue of the crown.
Look here upon thy brother Geffrey's face;
These eyes
This little abstract doth contain that large
Which died in Geffrey
Shall draw this brief into as huge a volume.
That Geffrey was thy elder brother born
And this is Geffrey's: in the name of God
How comes it then that thou art call'd a king
From whom hast thou this great commission
From that supernal judge
In any breast of strong authority
That judge hath made me guardian to this boy:
Under whose warrant I impeach thy wrong
And by whose help I mean to chastise it.
Alack
Excuse; it is to beat usurping down.
Who is it thou dost call usurper
Let me make answer; thy usurping son.
Out
My bed was ever to thy son as true
As thine was to thy husband; and this boy
Liker in feature to his father Geffrey
Than thou and John in manners; being as like
As rain to water
My boy a bastard! By my soul
His father never was so true begot:
It cannot be
There's a good mother
There's a good grandam
Peace!
Hear the crier.
What the devil art thou?
One that will play the devil
You are the hare of whom the proverb goes
I'll smoke your skin-coat
Sirrah
O
That did disrobe the lion of that robe!
It lies as sightly on the back of him
As great Alcides' shows upon an ass:
But
What craker is this same that deafs our ears
With this abundance of superfluous breath?
Lewis
Women and fools
King John
England and Ireland
Wilt thou resign them and lay down thy arms?
My life as soon: I do defy thee
Arthur of Bretagne
And out of my dear love I'll give thee more
Than e'er the coward hand of France can win:
Submit thee
Come to thy grandam
Do
Give grandam kingdom
Give it a plum
There's a good grandam.
Good my mother
I would that I were low laid in my grave:
I am not worth this coil that's made for me.
His mother shames him so
Now shame upon you
His grandam's wrongs
Ay
To do him justice and revenge on you.
Thou monstrous slanderer of heaven and earth!
Thou monstrous injurer of heaven and earth!
Call not me slanderer; thou and thine usurp
The dominations
Of this oppressed boy: this is thy eld'st son's son
Thy sins are visited in this poor child;
The canon of the law is laid on him
Removed from thy sin-conceiving womb.
Bedlam
I have but this to say
On this removed issue
And with her plague; her sin his injury
Thou unadvised scold
A will that bars the title of thy son.
Ay
A woman's will; a canker'd grandam's will!
Peace
It ill beseems this presence to cry aim
To these ill-tuned repetitions.
Some trumpet summon hither to the walls
These men of Angiers: let us hear them speak
Whose title they admit
Trumpet sounds. Enter certain Citizens upon the walls
Who is it that hath warn'd us to the walls?
'Tis France
England
You men of Angiers
You loving men of Angiers
For our advantage; therefore hear us first.
These flags of France
Before the eye and prospect of your town
The cannons have their bowels full of wrath
Their iron indignation 'gainst your walls:
All preparation for a bloody siege
All merciless proceeding by these French
Confronts your city's eyes
And but for our approach those sleeping stones
By this time from their fixed beds of lime
Had been dishabited
For bloody power to rush upon your peace.
But on the sight of us your lawful king
Have brought a countercheque before your gates
And now
Which trust accordingly
When I have said
Lo
Is most divinely vow'd upon the right
Of him it holds
For this down-trodden equity
In warlike march these greens before your town
Than the constraint of hospitable zeal
In the relief of this oppressed child
Religiously provokes. Be pleased then
To pay that duty which you truly owe
To that owes it
And then our arms
Our cannons' malice vainly shall be spent
Against the invulnerable clouds of heaven;
And with a blessed and unvex'd retire
Which here we came to spout against your town
But if you fondly pass our proffer'd offer
Can hide you from our messengers of war
Were harbour'd in their rude circumference.
Then tell us
Or shall we give the signal to our rage
And stalk in blood to our possession?
In brief
For him
Acknowledge then the king
That can we not; but he that proves the king
Have we ramm'd up our gates against the world.
Doth not the crown of England prove the king?
And if not that
Bastards
To verify our title with their lives.
As many and as well-born bloods as those
Some bastards too.
Stand in his face to contradict his claim.
Till you compound whose right is worthiest
Then God forgive the sin of all those souls
That to their everlasting residence
Amen
Saint George
Sits on his horseback at mine hostess' door
To AUSTRIA
Sirrah
I would set an ox-head to your lion's hide
Peace! no more.
O tremble
Up higher to the plain; where we'll set forth
In best appointment all our regiments.
Speed then
It shall be so; and at the other hill
Command the rest to stand. God and our right!
Exeunt
Here after excursions
You men of Angiers
Much work for tears in many an English mother
Many a widow's husband grovelling lies
And victory
Upon the dancing banners of the French
Arthur of Bretagne England's king and yours.
Enter English Herald
Rejoice
King John
Their armours
There stuck no plume in any English crest
That is removed by a staff of France;
Our colours do return in those same hands
That did display them when we first march'd forth;
And
Our lusty English
Open your gates and gives the victors way.
Heralds
Of both your armies; whose equality
By our best eyes cannot be censured:
Blood hath bought blood and blows have answered blows;
Strength match'd with strength
Both are alike; and both alike we like.
One must prove greatest: while they weigh so even
Re-enter KING JOHN and KING PHILIP
France
Say
Whose passage
With course disturb'd even thy confining shores
A peaceful progress to the ocean.
England
Rather
With slaughter coupled to the name of kings.
Ha
O
The swords of soldiers are his teeth
And now he feasts
Why stand these royal fronts amazed thus?
Cry
Then let confusion of one part confirm
The other's peace: till then
Whose party do the townsmen yet admit?
Speak
The king of England; when we know the king.
Know him in us
In us
And bear possession of our person here
A greater power then we denies all this;
And till it be undoubted
Our former scruple in our strong-barr'd gates;
King'd of our fears
By heaven
At your industrious scenes and acts of death.
Your royal presences be ruled by me:
Do like the mutines of Jerusalem
Your sharpest deeds of malice on this town:
By east and west let France and England mount
Their battering cannon charged to the mouths
The flinty ribs of this contemptuous city:
I'ld play incessantly upon these jades
Leave them as naked as the vulgar air.
That done
Turn face to face and bloody point to point;
Then
Out of one side her happy minion
How like you this wild counsel
Smacks it not something of the policy?
Now
And lay this Angiers even to the ground;
Then after fight who shall be king of it?
An if thou hast the mettle of a king
And when that we have dash'd them to the ground
Make work upon ourselves
Let it be so. Say
We from the west will send destruction
Into this city's bosom.
I from the north.
Our thunder from the south
Shall rain their drift of bullets on this town.
O prudent discipline! From north to south:
Austria and France shoot in each other's mouth:
I'll stir them to it. Come
Hear us
Win you this city without stroke or wound;
Rescue those breathing lives to die in beds
Persever not
Speak on with favour; we are bent to hear.
That daughter there of Spain
Of Lewis the Dauphin and that lovely maid:
If lusty love should go in quest of beauty
If zealous love should go in search of virtue
If love ambitious sought a match of birth
Such as she is
If not complete of
And she again wants nothing
He is the half part of a blessed man
And she a fair divided excellence
O
And two such shores to two such streams made one
This union shall do more than battery can
To our fast-closed gates; for at this match
More free from motion
In moral fury half so peremptory
Here's a stay
That shakes the rotten carcass of old Death
Out of his rags! Here's a large mouth
As maids of thirteen do of puppy-dogs!
What cannoneer begot this lusty blood?
He speaks plain cannon fire
He gives the bastinado with his tongue:
Our ears are cudgell'd; not a word of his
But buffets better than a fist of France:
Zounds! I was never so bethump'd with words
Since I first call'd my brother's father dad.
Son
Give with our niece a dowry large enough:
For by this knot thou shalt so surely tie
Thy now unsured assurance to the crown
The bloom that promiseth a mighty fruit.
I see a yielding in the looks of France;
Mark
Are capable of this ambition
Of soft petitions
Why answer not the double majesties
This friendly treaty of our threaten'd town?
Speak England first
To speak unto this city: what say you?
If that the Dauphin there
Her dowry shall weigh equal with a queen:
For Anjou and fair Touraine
In titles
What say'st thou
I do
A wonder
Which being but the shadow of your son
I do protest I never loved myself
Till now infixed I beheld myself
Drawn in the flattering table of her eye.
Whispers with BLANCH
Drawn in the flattering table of her eye!
Hang'd in the frowning wrinkle of her brow!
And quarter'd in her heart! he doth espy
Himself love's traitor: this is pity now
In such a love so vile a lout as he.
My uncle's will in this respect is mine:
If he see aught in you that makes him like
Or if you will
Further I will not flatter you
What say these young ones? What say you my niece?
That she is bound in honour still to do
What you in wisdom still vouchsafe to say.
Speak then
Nay
For I do love her most unfeignedly.
Then do I give Volquessen
Philip of France
It likes us well; young princes
And your lips too; for I am well assured
That I did so when I was first assured.
Now
For at Saint Mary's chapel presently
The rites of marriage shall be solemnized.
Is not the Lady Constance in this troop?
I know she is not
Her presence would have interrupted much:
Where is she and her son? tell me
She is sad and passionate at your highness' tent.
And
Will give her sadness very little cure.
Brother of England
This widow lady? In her right we came;
Which we
We will heal up all;
For we'll create young Arthur Duke of Bretagne
And Earl of Richmond; and this rich fair town
We make him lord of. Call the Lady Constance;
Some speedy messenger bid her repair
To our solemnity: I trust we shall
That we shall stop her exclamation.
Go we
Exeunt all but the BASTARD
Mad world! mad kings! mad composition!
John
As God's own soldier
With that same purpose-changer
But the word 'maid
And this same bias
And why rail I on this Commodity?
But for because he hath not woo'd me yet:
Not that I have the power to clutch my hand
But for my hand
Well
And say there is no sin but to be rich;
And being rich
To say there is no vice but beggary.
Since kings break faith upon commodity
Exit
ACT III
SCENE I. The French King's pavilion.
Enter CONSTANCE
Gone to be married! gone to swear a peace!
False blood to false blood join'd! gone to be friends!
Shall Lewis have Blanch
It is not so; thou hast misspoke
Be well advised
It cannot be; thou dost but say 'tis so:
I trust I may not trust thee; for thy word
Is but the vain breath of a common man:
Believe me
I have a king's oath to the contrary.
Thou shalt be punish'd for thus frighting me
And though thou now confess thou didst but jest
What dost thou mean by shaking of thy head?
Why dost thou look so sadly on my son?
What means that hand upon that breast of thine?
Why holds thine eye that lamentable rheum
Be these sad signs confirmers of thy words?
Then speak again; not all thy former tale
As true as I believe you think them false
That give you cause to prove my saying true.
O
As doth the fury of two desperate men
Which in the very meeting fall and die.
Lewis marry Blanch! O boy
France friend with England
Fellow
This news hath made thee a most ugly man.
What other harm have I
Which harm within itself so heinous is
As it makes harmful all that speak of it.
I do beseech you
If thou
Become thy great birth nor deserve a crown.
But thou art fair
Of Nature's gifts thou mayst with lilies boast
She adulterates hourly with thine uncle John
To tread down fair respect of sovereignty
France is a bawd to Fortune and King John
Tell me
Envenom him with words
And leave those woes alone which I alone
Am bound to under-bear.
Pardon me
Thou mayst
I will instruct my sorrows to be proud;
For grief is proud and makes his owner stoop.
To me and to the state of my great grief
Let kings assemble; for my grief's so great
That no supporter but the huge firm earth
Can hold it up: here I and sorrows sit;
Here is my throne
Seats herself on the ground
Enter KING JOHN
'Tis true
Ever in France shall be kept festival:
To solemnize this day the glorious sun
Stays in his course and plays the alchemist
The meagre cloddy earth to glittering gold:
The yearly course that brings this day about
Shall never see it but a holiday.
A wicked day
Rising
What hath this day deserved? what hath it done
Among the high tides in the calendar?
Nay
Or
Pray that their burthens may not fall this day
But on this day let seamen fear no wreck;
No bargains break that are not this day made:
This day
By heaven
To curse the fair proceedings of this day:
Have I not pawn'd to you my majesty?
You have beguiled me with a counterfeit
Resembling majesty
You came in arms to spill mine enemies' blood
The grappling vigour and rough frown of war
Is cold in amity and painted peace
Arm
A widow cries; be husband to me
Let not the hours of this ungodly day
Wear out the day in peace; but
Hear me
Lady Constance
War! war! no peace! peace is to me a war
O Lymoges! O Austria! thou dost shame
That bloody spoil: thou slave
Thou little valiant
Thou ever strong upon the stronger side!
Thou Fortune's champion that dost never fight
But when her humorous ladyship is by
To teach thee safety! thou art perjured too
Upon my party! Thou cold-blooded slave
Upon thy stars
Thou wear a lion's hide! doff it for shame
O
And hang a calf's-skin on those recreant limbs.
Thou darest not say so
And hang a calf's-skin on those recreant limbs.
We like not this; thou dost forget thyself.
Enter CARDINAL PANDULPH
Here comes the holy legate of the pope.
Hail
To thee
I Pandulph
Why thou against the church
Keep Stephen Langton
Of Canterbury
This
What earthy name to interrogatories
Can task the free breath of a sacred king?
Thou canst not
So slight
Tell him this tale; and from the mouth of England
Add thus much more
Shall tithe or toll in our dominions;
But as we
So tell the pope
To him and his usurp'd authority.
Brother of England
Though you and all the kings of Christendom
Are led so grossly by this meddling priest
And by the merit of vile gold
This juggling witchcraft with revenue cherish
Against the pope and count his friends my foes.
Then
And blessed shall he be that doth revolt
From his allegiance to an heretic;
And meritorious shall that hand be call'd
Thy hateful life.
O
That I have room with Rome to curse awhile!
Good father cardinal
To my keen curses; for without my wrong
There is no tongue hath power to curse him right.
