There's law and warrant
And for mine too: when law can do no right
Law cannot give my child his kingdom here
Therefore
Philip of France
And raise the power of France upon his head
Look'st thou pale
Look to that
King Philip
And hang a calf's-skin on his recreant limbs.
Well
Your breeches best may carry them.
Philip
What should he say
Bethink you
Is purchase of a heavy curse from Rome
Forego the easier.
That's the curse of Rome.
O Lewis
In likeness of a new untrimmed bride.
The Lady Constance speaks not from her faith
O
O then
Keep my need up
The king is moved
O
Do so
Hang nothing but a calf's-skin
I am perplex'd
What canst thou say but will perplex thee more
Good reverend father
This royal hand and mine are newly knit
Married in league
With all religious strength of sacred vows;
The latest breath that gave the sound of words
Was deep-sworn faith
Between our kingdoms and our royal selves
To clap this royal bargain up of peace
With slaughter's pencil
The fearful difference of incensed kings:
And shall these hands
Play fast and loose with faith? so jest with heaven
Of smiling peace to march a bloody host
Of true sincerity? O
Out of your grace
Some gentle order; and then we shall be blest
To do your pleasure and continue friends.
All form is formless
Therefore to arms! be champion of our church
France
I may disjoin my hand
So makest thou faith an enemy to faith;
And like a civil war set'st oath to oath
First made to heaven
What since thou sworest is sworn against thyself
And may not be performed by thyself
Is not amiss when it is truly done
The better act of purposes mistook
Is to mistake again; though indirect
Within the scorched veins of one new-burn'd.
It is religion that doth make vows kept;
But thou hast sworn against religion
Against an oath: the truth thou art unsure
To swear
Else what a mockery should it be to swear!
But thou dost swear only to be forsworn;
And most forsworn
Therefore thy later vows against thy first
Is in thyself rebellion to thyself;
And better conquest never canst thou make
Than arm thy constant and thy nobler parts
Against these giddy loose suggestions:
Upon which better part our prayers come in
The peril of our curses light on thee
So heavy as thou shalt not shake them off
Rebellion
Will't not be?
Will not a calfs-skin stop that mouth of thine?
Father
Upon thy wedding-day?
Against the blood that thou hast married?
What
Shall braying trumpets and loud churlish drums
O husband
Is husband in my mouth! even for that name
Against mine uncle.
O
Forethought by heaven!
Now shall I see thy love: what motive may
Be stronger with thee than the name of wife?
That which upholdeth him that thee upholds
I muse your majesty doth seem so cold
I will denounce a curse upon his head.
Thou shalt not need. England
O fair return of banish'd majesty!
O foul revolt of French inconstancy!
France
Old Time the clock-setter
The sun's o'ercast with blood: fair day
Which is the side that I must go withal?
I am with both: each army hath a hand;
And in their rage
Husband
Uncle
Father
Grandam
Whoever wins
Assured loss before the match be play'd.
Lady
There where my fortune lives
Cousin
Exit BASTARD
France
A rage whose heat hath this condition
Thy rage sham burn thee up
To ashes
Look to thyself
No more than he that threats. To arms let's hie!
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. Plains near Angiers.
Alarums
Now
Some airy devil hovers in the sky
And pours down mischief. Austria's head lie there
Enter KING JOHN
Hubert
My mother is assailed in our tent
My lord
Her highness is in safety
But on
Will bring this labour to an happy end.
Exeunt
SCENE III. The same.
Alarums
[To QUEEN ELINOR]  So shall it be; your grace shall
stay behind
So strongly guarded.
To ARTHUR
Cousin
Thy grandam loves thee; and thy uncle will
As dear be to thee as thy father was.
O
[To the BASTARD]  Cousin
haste before:
And
Of hoarding abbots; imprisoned angels
Set at liberty: the fat ribs of peace
Must by the hungry now be fed upon:
Use our commission in his utmost force.
Bell
I leave your highness. Grandam
Farewell
Coz
Exit the BASTARD
Come hither
Come hither
There is a soul counts thee her creditor
And with advantage means to pay thy love:
And my good friend
Lives in this bosom
Give me thy hand. I had a thing to say
By heaven
To say what good respect I have of thee.
I am much bounden to your majesty.
Good friend
I had a thing to say
The sun is in the heaven
To give me audience: if the midnight bell
Did
If this same were a churchyard where we stand
And strain their cheeks to idle merriment
Without a tongue
Then
But
And
So well
Do not I know thou wouldst?
Good Hubert
On yon young boy: I'll tell thee what
And whereso'er this foot of mine doth tread
Thou art his keeper.
And I'll keep him so
Death.
My lord?
A grave.
He shall not live.
Enough.
I could be merry now. Hubert
Well
Remember. Madam
I'll send those powers o'er to your majesty.
My blessing go with thee!
For England
Hubert shall be your man
With all true duty. On toward Calais
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The same. KING PHILIP'S tent.
Enter KING PHILIP
So
Is scatter'd and disjoin'd from fellowship.
Courage and comfort! all shall yet go well.
What can go well
Are we not beaten? Is not Angiers lost?
Arthur ta'en prisoner? divers dear friends slain?
And bloody England into England gone
What he hath won
So hot a speed with such advice disposed
Of any kindred action like to this?
Well could I bear that England had this praise
Enter CONSTANCE
Look
Holding the eternal spirit against her will
I prithee
Lo
Patience
No
Thou odouriferous stench! sound rottenness!
Arise forth from the couch of lasting night
And put my eyeballs in thy vaulty brows
And ring these fingers with thy household worms
And stop this gap of breath with fulsome dust
And be a carrion monster like thyself:
Come
And buss thee as thy wife. Misery's love
O fair affliction
No
O
Then with a passion would I shake the world;
And rouse from sleep that fell anatomy
Which cannot hear a lady's feeble voice
Lady
Thou art not holy to belie me so;
I am not mad: this hair I tear is mine;
My name is Constance; I was Geffrey's wife;
Young Arthur is my son
I am not mad: I would to heaven I were!
For then
O
Preach some philosophy to make me mad
For being not mad but sensible of grief
How I may be deliver'd of these woes
If I were mad
I am not mad; too well
The different plague of each calamity.
Bind up those tresses. O
In the fair multitude of those her hairs!
Where but by chance a silver drop hath fallen
Do glue themselves in sociable grief
To England
Bind up your hairs.
Yes
I tore them from their bonds and cried aloud
'O that these hands could so redeem my son
But now I envy at their liberty
And
That we shall see and know our friends in heaven:
If that be true
For since the birth of Cain
But now will canker-sorrow eat my bud
And chase the native beauty from his cheek
And he will look as hollow as a ghost
I shall not know him: therefore never
Must I behold my pretty Arthur more.
You hold too heinous a respect of grief.
He talks to me that never had a son.
You are as fond of grief as of your child.
Grief fills the room up of my absent child
Then
Fare you well: had you such a loss as I
I will not keep this form upon my head
O Lord! my boy
My life
My widow-comfort
Exit
I fear some outrage
Exit
There's nothing in this world can make me joy:
Life is as tedious as a twice-told tale
Vexing the dull ear of a drowsy man;
And bitter shame hath spoil'd the sweet world's taste
That it yields nought but shame and bitterness.
Before the curing of a strong disease
What have you lost by losing of this day?
All days of glory
If you had won it
No
'Tis strange to think how much King John hath lost
In this which he accounts so clearly won:
Are not you grieved that Arthur is his prisoner?
As heartily as he is glad he hath him.
Your mind is all as youthful as your blood.
Now hear me speak with a prophetic spirit;
For even the breath of what I mean to speak
Shall blow each dust
Thy foot to England's throne; and therefore mark.
John hath seized Arthur; and it cannot be
That
A sceptre snatch'd with an unruly hand
Must be as boisterously maintain'd as gain'd;
And he that stands upon a slippery place
Makes nice of no vile hold to stay him up:
That John may stand
So be it
But what shall I gain by young Arthur's fall?
You
And lose it
How green you are and fresh in this old world!
John lays you plots; the times conspire with you;
For he that steeps his safety in true blood
Shall find but bloody safety and untrue.
This act so evilly born shall cool the hearts
Of all his people and freeze up their zeal
To cheque his reign
No natural exhalation in the sky
And call them meteors
May be he will not touch young Arthur's life
O
Of all his people shall revolt from him
And kiss the lips of unacquainted change
And pick strong matter of revolt and wrath
Out of the bloody fingers' ends of John.
Methinks I see this hurly all on foot:
And
Than I have named! The bastard Faulconbridge
Is now in England
Were there in arms
To train ten thousand English to their side
What may be wrought out of their discontent
For England go: I will whet on the king.
Strong reasons make strong actions: let us go:
If you say ay
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. A room in a castle.
Enter HUBERT and Executioners
Heat me these irons hot; and look thou stand
Within the arras: when I strike my foot
Upon the bosom of the ground
Fast to the chair: be heedful: hence
I hope your warrant will bear out the deed.
Uncleanly scruples! fear not you: look to't.
Exeunt Executioners
Young lad
Enter ARTHUR
Good morrow
Good morrow
As little prince
To be more prince
Indeed
Mercy on me!
Methinks no body should be sad but I:
Yet
And so I would be here
My uncle practises more harm to me:
He is afraid of me and I of him:
Is it my fault that I was Geffrey's son?
No
I were your son
[Aside]  If I talk to him
He will awake my mercy which lies dead:
Therefore I will be sudden and dispatch.
Are you sick
In sooth
I warrant I love you more than you do me.
[Aside]  His words do take possession of my bosom.
Read here
Showing a paper
Aside
How now
Turning dispiteous torture out of door!
I must be brief
Out at mine eyes in tender womanish tears.
Can you not read it? Is it not fair writ?
Too fairly
Must you with hot irons burn out both mine eyes?
Young boy
And will you?
And I will.
Have you the heart? When your head did but ache
And with my hand at midnight held your head
Or 'What good love may I perform for you?'
Many a poor man's son would have lien still
And ne'er have spoke a loving word to you;
But you at your sick service had a prince.
Nay
And call it cunning: do
If heaven be pleased that you must use me ill
These eyes that never did nor never shall
So much as frown on you.
I have sworn to do it;
And with hot irons must I burn them out.
Ah
The iron of itself
And quench his fiery indignation
Even in the matter of mine innocence;
Nay
But for containing fire to harm mine eye.
Are you more stubborn-hard than hammer'd iron?
An if an angel should have come to me
And told me Hubert should put out mine eyes
Come forth.
Stamps
Re-enter Executioners
Do as I bid you do.
O
Even with the fierce looks of these bloody men.
Give me the iron
Alas
I will not struggle
For heaven sake
Nay
I will not stir
Thrust but these men away
Go
I am best pleased to be from such a deed.
Exeunt Executioners
Alas
He hath a stern look
Let him come back
Give life to yours.
Come
Is there no remedy?
None
O heaven
Then feeling what small things are boisterous there
Is this your promise? go to
Hubert
Must needs want pleading for a pair of eyes:
Let me not hold my tongue
Or
Though to no use but still to look on you!
Lo
And would not harm me.
I can heat it
No
In undeserved extremes: see else yourself;
There is no malice in this burning coal;
The breath of heaven has blown his spirit out
And strew'd repentent ashes on his head.
But with my breath I can revive it
An if you do
And glow with shame of your proceedings
Nay
And like a dog that is compell'd to fight
All things that you should use to do me wrong
Deny their office: only you do lack
That mercy which fierce fire and iron extends
Well
For all the treasure that thine uncle owes:
Yet am I sworn and I did purpose
O
You were disguised.
Peace; no more. Adieu.
Your uncle must not know but you are dead;
I'll fill these dogged spies with false reports:
And
O heaven! I thank you
Silence; no more: go closely in with me:
Much danger do I undergo for thee.
Exeunt
SCENE II. KING JOHN'S palace.
Enter KING JOHN
Here once again we sit
This 'once again
Fresh expectation troubled not the land
With any long'd-for change or better state.
Therefore
Unto the rainbow
To seek the beauteous eye of heaven to garnish
But that your royal pleasure must be done
In this the antique and well noted face
Of plain old form is much disfigured;
And
When workmen strive to do better than well
And oftentimes excusing of a fault
Doth make the fault the worse by the excuse
Discredit more in hiding of the fault
Than did the fault before it was so patch'd.
To this effect
To overbear it
Doth make a stand at what your highness will.
Some reasons of this double coronation
I have possess'd you with and think them strong;
And more
What you would have reform'd that is not well
I will both hear and grant you your requests.
Then I
Bend their best studies
The enfranchisement of Arthur; whose restraint
Doth move the murmuring lips of discontent
To break into this dangerous argument
If what in rest you have in right you hold
The steps of wrong
Your tender kinsman and to choke his days
With barbarous ignorance and deny his youth
The rich advantage of good exercise?
That the time's enemies may not have this
To grace occasions
That you have bid us ask his liberty;
Which for our goods we do no further ask
Than whereupon our weal
Enter HUBERT
Let it be so: I do commit his youth
To your direction. Hubert
Taking him apart
This is the man should do the bloody deed;
He show'd his warrant to a friend of mine:
The image of a wicked heinous fault
Lives in his eye; that close aspect of his
Does show the mood of a much troubled breast;
And I do fearfully believe 'tis done
The colour of the king doth come and go
Between his purpose and his conscience
His passion is so ripe
And when it breaks
The foul corruption of a sweet child's death.
We cannot hold mortality's strong hand:
Good lords
He tells us Arthur is deceased to-night.
Indeed we fear'd his sickness was past cure.
Indeed we heard how near his death he was
Before the child himself felt he was sick:
This must be answer'd either here or hence.
Why do you bend such solemn brows on me?
Think you I bear the shears of destiny?
Have I commandment on the pulse of life?
It is apparent foul play; and 'tis shame
That greatness should so grossly offer it:
So thrive it in your game! and so
Stay yet
That blood which owed the breadth of all this isle
This must not be thus borne: this will break out
To all our sorrows
Exeunt Lords
They burn in indignation. I repent:
There is no sure foundation set on blood
Enter a Messenger
A fearful eye thou hast: where is that blood
That I have seen inhabit in those cheeks?
So foul a sky clears not without a storm:
Pour down thy weather: how goes all in France?
From France to England. Never such a power
For any foreign preparation
Was levied in the body of a land.
The copy of your speed is learn'd by them;
For when you should be told they do prepare
O
Where hath it slept? Where is my mother's care
My liege
Is stopp'd with dust; the first of April died
Your noble mother: and
Three days before: but this from rumour's tongue
I idly heard; if true or false I know not.
Withhold thy speed
O
My discontented peers! What! mother dead!
How wildly then walks my estate in France!
Under whose conduct came those powers of France
That thou for truth givest out are landed here?
Under the Dauphin.
Thou hast made me giddy
With these ill tidings.
Enter the BASTARD and PETER of Pomfret
Now
To your proceedings? do not seek to stuff
My head with more ill news
But if you be afeard to hear the worst
Bear with me cousin
Under the tide: but now I breathe again
Aloft the flood
To any tongue
How I have sped among the clergymen
But as I travell'd hither through the land
Possess'd with rumours
And here a prophet
From forth the streets of Pomfret
With many hundreds treading on his heels;
To whom he sung
Thou idle dreamer
Foreknowing that the truth will fall out so.
Hubert
And on that day at noon whereon he says
I shall yield up my crown
Deliver him to safety; and return
Exeunt HUBERT with PETER
O my gentle cousin
The French
Besides
Of Arthur
On your suggestion.
Gentle kinsman
I have a way to win their loves again;
Bring them before me.
I will seek them out.
Nay
O
With dreadful pomp of stout invasion!
Be Mercury
The spirit of the time shall teach me speed.
Exit
Spoke like a sprightful noble gentleman.
Go after him; for he perhaps shall need
Some messenger betwixt me and the peers;
And be thou he.
With all my heart
Exit
My mother dead!
Re-enter HUBERT
My lord
Four fixed
The other four in wondrous motion.
Five moons!
Old men and beldams in the streets
Do prophesy upon it dangerously:
Young Arthur's death is common in their mouths:
And when they talk of him
And whisper one another in the ear;
And he that speaks doth gripe the hearer's wrist
I saw a smith stand with his hammer
Who
Had falsely thrust upon contrary feet
That were embattailed and rank'd in Kent:
Another lean unwash'd artificer
Cuts off his tale and talks of Arthur's death.
Why seek'st thou to possess me with these fears?
Why urgest thou so oft young Arthur's death?
Thy hand hath murder'd him: I had a mighty cause
To wish him dead
No had
It is the curse of kings to be attended
By slaves that take their humours for a warrant
To break within the bloody house of life
To understand a law
Of dangerous majesty
More upon humour than advised respect.
Here is your hand and seal for what I did.
O
Is to be made
Witness against us to damnation!
How oft the sight of means to do ill deeds
Make deeds ill done! Hadst not thou been by
But taking note of thy abhorr'd aspect
And thou
My lord--
Hadst thou but shook thy head or made a pause
When I spake darkly what I purposed
But thou didst understand me by my signs
And didst in signs again parley with sin;
Yea
The deed
Out of my sight
My nobles leave me; and my state is braved
Nay
Between my conscience and my cousin's death.
Arm you against your other enemies
Young Arthur is alive: this hand of mine
Is yet a maiden and an innocent hand
Within this bosom never enter'd yet
The dreadful motion of a murderous thought;
And you have slander'd nature in my form
Than to be butcher of an innocent child.
Doth Arthur live? O
Forgive the comment that my passion made
Upon thy feature; for my rage was blind
Presented thee more hideous than thou art.
O
The angry lords with all expedient haste.
I conjure thee but slowly; run more fast.
Exeunt
SCENE III. Before the castle.
Enter ARTHUR
The wall is high
Good ground
There's few or none do know me: if they did
I am afraid; and yet I'll venture it.
If I get down
As good to die and go
Leaps down
O me! my uncle's spirit is in these stones:
Heaven take my soul
Dies
Enter PEMBROKE
Lords
It is our safety
This gentle offer of the perilous time.
Who brought that letter from the cardinal?
The Count Melun
Is much more general than these lines import.
To-morrow morning let us meet him then.
Or rather then set forward; for 'twill be
Two long days' journey
Enter the BASTARD
Once more to-day well met
The king by me requests your presence straight.
The king hath dispossess'd himself of us:
We will not line his thin bestained cloak
With our pure honours
That leaves the print of blood where'er it walks.
Return and tell him so: we know the worst.
Whate'er you think
Our griefs
But there is little reason in your grief;
Therefore 'twere reason you had manners now.
Sir
'Tis true
This is the prison. What is he lies here?
Seeing ARTHUR
O death
The earth had not a hole to hide this deed.
Murder
Or
Sir Richard
Or do you almost think
Presented to the tears of soft remorse.
All murders past do stand excused in this:
And this
And prove a deadly bloodshed but a jest
It is a damned and a bloody work;
The graceless action of a heavy hand
If that it be the work of any hand!
We had a kind of light what would ensue:
It is the shameful work of Hubert's hand;
The practise and the purpose of the king:
From whose obedience I forbid my soul
The incense of a vow
Our souls religiously confirm thy words.
Enter HUBERT
Lords
Arthur doth live; the king hath sent for you.
O
Avaunt
I am no villain.
Must I rob the law?
Drawing his sword
Your sword is bright
Not till I sheathe it in a murderer's skin.
Stand back
By heaven
I would not have you
Lest I
Your worth
Out
Not for my life: but yet I dare defend
My innocent life against an emperor.
Thou art a murderer.
Do not prove me so;
Yet I am none: whose tongue soe'er speaks false
Cut him to pieces.
Keep the peace
Stand by
Thou wert better gall the devil
If thou but frown on me
Or I'll so maul you and your toasting-iron
What wilt thou do
Second a villain and a murderer?
Lord Bigot
Who kill'd this prince?
'Tis not an hour since I left him well:
I honour'd him
My date of life out for his sweet life's loss.
Trust not those cunning waters of his eyes
And he
Like rivers of remorse and innocency.
Away with me
The uncleanly savours of a slaughter-house;
For I am stifled with this smell of sin.
Away toward Bury
There tell the king he may inquire us out.
Exeunt Lords
Here's a good world! Knew you of this fair work?
Beyond the infinite and boundless reach
Of mercy
Do but hear me
Ha! I'll tell thee what;
Thou'rt damn'd as black--nay
Thou art more deep damn'd than Prince Lucifer:
There is not yet so ugly a fiend of hell
As thou shalt be
Upon my soul--
If thou didst but consent
To this most cruel act
And if thou want'st a cord
That ever spider twisted from her womb
Will serve to strangle thee
To hang thee on; or wouldst thou drown thyself
I do suspect thee very grievously.
If I in act
Which was embounded in this beauteous clay
I left him well.
Go
I am amazed
Among the thorns and dangers of this world.
How easy dost thou take all England up!
From forth this morsel of dead royalty
Is fled to heaven; and England now is left
To tug and scamble and to part by the teeth
The unowed interest of proud-swelling state.
Now for the bare-pick'd bone of majesty
Doth dogged war bristle his angry crest
And snarleth in the gentle eyes of peace:
Now powers from home and discontents at home
Meet in one line; and vast confusion waits
Now happy he whose cloak and cincture can
Hold out this tempest. Bear away that child
And follow me with speed: I'll to the king:
A thousand businesses are brief in hand
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. KING JOHN'S palace.
Enter KING JOHN
Thus have I yielded up into your hand
The circle of my glory.
Giving the crown
Take again
From this my hand
Your sovereign greatness and authority.
Now keep your holy word: go meet the French
To stop their marches 'fore we are inflamed.
Our discontented counties do revolt;
Our people quarrel with obedience
To stranger blood
This inundation of mistemper'd humour
Rests by you only to be qualified:
Then pause not; for the present time's so sick
It was my breath that blew this tempest up
But since you are a gentle convertite
And make fair weather in your blustering land.
On this Ascension-day
Exit
Is this Ascension-day? Did not the prophet
Say that before Ascension-day at noon
My crown I should give off? Even so I have:
I did suppose it should be on constraint:
But
Enter the BASTARD
All Kent hath yielded; nothing there holds out
But Dover castle: London hath received
Your nobles will not hear you
To offer service to your enemy
The little number of your doubtful friends.
Would not my lords return to me again
They found him dead and cast into the streets
By some damn'd hand was robb'd and ta'en away.
That villain Hubert told me he did live.
So
But wherefore do you droop? why look you sad?
Be great in act
Let not the world see fear and sad distrust
Govern the motion of a kingly eye:
Be stirring as the time; be fire with fire;
Threaten the threatener and outface the brow
Of bragging horror: so shall inferior eyes
The dauntless spirit of resolution.
Away
Show boldness and aspiring confidence.
What
O
To meet displeasure farther from the doors
The legate of the pope hath been with me
And he hath promised to dismiss the powers
Led by the Dauphin.
O inglorious league!
Shall we
To arms invasive? shall a beardless boy
Perchance the cardinal cannot make your peace;
Or if he do
They saw we had a purpose of defence.
Have thou the ordering of this present time.
Away
Exeunt
SCENE II. LEWIS's camp at St. Edmundsbury.
Enter
My Lord Melun
Return the precedent to these lords again;
That
And keep our faiths firm and inviolable.
Upon our sides it never shall be broken.
And
A voluntary zeal and an unurged faith
To your proceedings; yet believe me
Should seek a plaster by contemn'd revolt
By making many. O
To be a widow-maker! O
Where honourable rescue and defence
Cries out upon the name of Salisbury!
But such is the infection of the time
Of stern injustice and confused wrong.
And is't not pity
Wherein we step after a stranger march
Upon her gentle bosom
Her enemies' ranks
Upon the spot of this enforced cause
To grace the gentry of a land remote
What
That Neptune's arms
Where these two Christian armies might combine
The blood of malice in a vein of league
A noble temper dost thou show in this;
And great affections wrestling in thy bosom
Doth make an earthquake of nobility.
O
Between compulsion and a brave respect!
Let me wipe off this honourable dew
My heart hath melted at a lady's tears
But this effusion of such manly drops
Than had I seen the vaulty top of heaven
Figured quite o'er with burning meteors.
Lift up thy brow
Commend these waters to those baby eyes
That never saw the giant world enraged;
Nor met with fortune other than at feasts
Come
Into the purse of rich prosperity
As Lewis himself: so
And even there
Enter CARDINAL PANDULPH
Look
And on our actions set the name of right
With holy breath.
Hail
The next is this
Himself to Rome; his spirit is come in
Therefore thy threatening colours now wind up;
And tame the savage spirit of wild war
Your grace shall pardon me
I am too high-born to be propertied
Your breath first kindled the dead coal of wars
Between this chastised kingdom and myself
And now 'tis far too huge to be blown out
With that same weak wind which enkindled it.
You taught me how to know the face of right
And come ye now to tell me John hath made
His peace with Rome? What is that peace to me?
I
And
Because that John hath made his peace with Rome?
Am I Rome's slave? What penny hath Rome borne
That undergo this charge? who else but I
Have I not heard these islanders shout out
'Vive le roi!' as I have bank'd their towns?
Have I not here the best cards for the game
And shall I now give o'er the yielded set?
No
You look but on the outside of this work.
Outside or inside
Till my attempt so much be glorified
As to my ample hope was promised
Before I drew this gallant head of war
Even in the jaws of danger and of death.
Trumpet sounds
What lusty trumpet thus doth summon us?
Enter the BASTARD
According to the fair play of the world
My holy lord of Milan
I come
And
And warrant limited unto my tongue.
The Dauphin is too wilful-opposite
He flatly says he'll not lay down his arms.
By all the blood that ever fury breathed
For thus his royalty doth speak in me.
He is prepared
This apish and unmannerly approach
To whip this dwarfish war
That hand which had the strength
In vaults and prisons
Even at the crying of your nation's crow
Shall that victorious hand be feebled here
No: know the gallant monarch is in arms
And like an eagle o'er his aery towers
And you degenerate
Of your dear mother England
For your own ladies and pale-visaged maids
Like Amazons come tripping after drums
To fierce and bloody inclination.
There end thy brave
We grant thou canst outscold us: fare thee well;
We hold our time too precious to be spent
With such a brabbler.
Give me leave to speak.
No
We will attend to neither.
Strike up the drums; and let the tongue of war
Plead for our interest and our being here.
Indeed your drums
And so shall you
An echo with the clamour of thy drum
That shall reverberate all as loud as thine;
Sound but another
As loud as thine rattle the welkin's ear
And mock the deep-mouth'd thunder: for at hand
Is warlike John; and in his forehead sits
A bare-ribb'd death
To feast upon whole thousands of the French.
Strike up our drums
And thou shalt find it
Exeunt
SCENE III. The field of battle.
Alarums. Enter KING JOHN and HUBERT
How goes the day with us? O
Badly
This fever
Enter a Messenger
My lord
And send him word by me which way you go.
Tell him
Be of good comfort; for the great supply
That was expected by the Dauphin here
This news was brought to Richard but even now:
The French fight coldly
Ay me! this tyrant fever burns me up
Set on toward Swinstead: to my litter straight;
Weakness possesseth me
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Another part of the field.
Enter SALISBURY
I did not think the king so stored with friends.
Up once again; put spirit in the French:
If they miscarry
That misbegotten devil
They say King John sore sick hath left the field.
Enter MELUN
Lead me to the revolts of England here.
When we were happy we had other names.
It is the Count Melun.
Wounded to death.
Fly
Unthread the rude eye of rebellion
And welcome home again discarded faith.
Seek out King John and fall before his feet;
For if the French be lords of this loud day
By cutting off your heads: thus hath he sworn
And I with him
Even on that altar where we swore to you
Dear amity and everlasting love.
May this be possible? may this be true?
Have I not hideous death within my view
Resolveth from his figure 'gainst the fire?
What in the world should make me now deceive
Why should I then be false
That I must die here and live hence by truth?
I say again
Behold another day break in the east:
But even this night
Already smokes about the burning crest
Of the old
Even with a treacherous fine of all your lives
Commend me to one Hubert with your king:
The love of him
In lieu whereof
From forth the noise and rumour of the field
In peace
With contemplation and devout desires.
We do believe thee: and beshrew my soul
But I do love the favour and the form
Of this most fair occasion
We will untread the steps of damned flight
And cabby run on in obedience
Even to our ocean
My arm shall give thee help to bear thee hence;
For I do see the cruel pangs of death
Right in thine eye. Away
And happy newness
Exeunt
SCENE V. The French camp.
Enter LEWIS and his train
The sun of heaven methought was loath to set
In faint retire. O
And wound our tattering colours clearly up
Enter a Messenger
Where is my prince
Here: what news?
The Count Melun is slain; the English lords
By his persuasion are again fall'n off
Ah
I did not think to be so sad to-night
As this hath made me. Who was he that said
King John did fly an hour or two before
The stumbling night did part our weary powers?
Whoever spoke it
Well; keep good quarter and good care to-night:
The day shall not be up so soon as I
Exeunt
SCENE VI. An open place in the neighbourhood of Swinstead Abbey.
Enter the BASTARD and HUBERT
Who's there? speak
A friend. What art thou?
Of the part of England.
Whither dost thou go?
What's that to thee? why may not I demand
Of thine affairs
Hubert
Thou hast a perfect thought:
I will upon all hazards well believe
Thou art my friend
Who art thou?
Who thou wilt: and if thou please
I come one way of the Plantagenets.
Unkind remembrance! thou and eyeless night
Have done me shame: brave soldier
Should 'scape the true acquaintance of mine ear.
Come
Why
Brief
O
Show me the very wound of this ill news:
I am no woman
The king
I left him almost speechless; and broke out
To acquaint you with this evil
The better arm you to the sudden time
How did he take it? who did taste to him?
A monk
Yet speaks and peradventure may recover.
Who didst thou leave to tend his majesty?
Why
At whose request the king hath pardon'd them
Withhold thine indignation
I'll tell tree
These Lincoln Washes have devoured them;
Myself
Away before: conduct me to the king;
I doubt he will be dead or ere I come.
Exeunt
SCENE VII. The orchard in Swinstead Abbey.
Enter PRINCE HENRY
It is too late: the life of all his blood
Is touch'd corruptibly
Foretell the ending of mortality.
Enter PEMBROKE
His highness yet doth speak
That
Of that fell poison which assaileth him.
Let him be brought into the orchard here.
Doth he still rage?
Exit BIGOT
He is more patient
Than when you left him; even now he sung.
O vanity of sickness! fierce extremes
In their continuance will not feel themselves.
Death
Against the mind
With many legions of strange fantasies
should sing.
I am the cygnet to this pale faint swan
His soul and body to their lasting rest.
Be of good comfort
To set a form upon that indigest
Which he hath left so shapeless and so rude.
Enter Attendants
Ay
It would not out at windows nor at doors.
There is so hot a summer in my bosom
I am a scribbled form
Upon a parchment
Do I shrink up.
How fares your majesty?
Poison'd
And none of you will bid the winter come
To thrust his icy fingers in my maw
Through my burn'd bosom
To make his bleak winds kiss my parched lips
And comfort me with cold. I do not ask you much
And so ingrateful
O that there were some virtue in my tears
The salt in them is hot.
Within me is a hell; and there the poison
Is as a fiend confined to tyrannize
On unreprievable condemned blood.
Enter the BASTARD
O
O cousin
The tackle of my heart is crack'd and burn'd
Are turned to one thread
My heart hath one poor string to stay it by
And then all this thou seest is but a clod
And module of confounded royalty.
The Dauphin is preparing hitherward
For in a night the best part of my power
Devoured by the unexpected flood.
KING JOHN dies
You breathe these dead news in as dead an ear.
My liege! my lord! but now a king
Even so must I run on
What surety of the world
Art thou gone so? I do but stay behind
To do the office for thee of revenge
Now
Out of the weak door of our fainting land.
Straight let us seek
The Dauphin rages at our very heels.
It seems you know not
The Cardinal Pandulph is within at rest
As we with honour and respect may take
He will the rather do it when he sees
Ourselves well sinewed to our defence.
Nay
For many carriages he hath dispatch'd
To the sea-side
To the disposing of the cardinal:
With whom yourself
To consummate this business happily.
Let it be so: and you
At Worcester must his body be interr'd;
For so he will'd it.
Thither shall it then:
And happily may your sweet self put on
The lineal state and glory of the land!
To whom with all submission
I do bequeath my faithful services
And true subjection everlastingly.
And the like tender of our love we make
I have a kind soul that would give you thanks
And knows not how to do it but with tears.
O
This England never did
Now these her princes are come home again
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. Rome. A street.
Enter FLAVIUS
Hence! home
Is this a holiday? what! know you not
Upon a labouring day without the sign
Of your profession? Speak
Why
Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?
What dost thou with thy best apparel on?
You
Truly
But what trade art thou? answer me directly.
A trade
conscience; which is
What trade
Nay
What meanest thou by that? mend me
Why
Thou art a cobbler
Truly
meddle with no tradesman's matters
matters
to old shoes; when they are in great danger
recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon
neat's leather have gone upon my handiwork.
But wherefore art not in thy shop today?
Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?
Truly
into more work. But
Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home?
What tributaries follow him to Rome
You blocks
O you hard hearts
Have you climb'd up to walls and battlements
The livelong day
And when you saw his chariot but appear
Made in her concave shores?
And do you now put on your best attire?
And do you now cull out a holiday?
And do you now strew flowers in his way
That comes in triumph over Pompey's blood? Be gone!
Run to your houses
That needs must light on this ingratitude.
Go
Draw them to Tiber banks
Into the channel
Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.
Exeunt all the Commoners
See whether their basest metal be not moved;
They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness.
Go you down that way towards the Capitol;
This way will I disrobe the images
May we do so?
You know it is the feast of Lupercal.
It is no matter; let no images
Be hung with Caesar's trophies. I'll about
So do you too
These growing feathers pluck'd from Caesar's wing
Will make him fly an ordinary pitch
And keep us all in servile fearfulness.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A public place.
Flourish. Enter CAESAR; ANTONY
Calpurnia!
Peace
Calpurnia!
Here
Stand you directly in Antonius' way
Caesar
Forget not
I shall remember:
When Caesar says 'do this
Set on; and leave no ceremony out.
Flourish
Caesar!
Ha! who calls?
Bid every noise be still: peace yet again!
Who is it in the press that calls on me?
I hear a tongue
Beware the ides of March.
What man is that?
A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.
Set him before me; let me see his face.
Fellow
What say'st thou to me now? speak once again.
Beware the ides of March.
He is a dreamer; let us leave him: pass.
Sennet. Exeunt all except BRUTUS and CASSIUS
Will you go see the order of the course?
Not I.
I pray you
I am not gamesome: I do lack some part
Of that quick spirit that is in Antony.
Let me not hinder
I'll leave you.
Brutus
I have not from your eyes that gentleness
And show of love as I was wont to have:
You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand
Over your friend that loves you.
Cassius
Merely upon myself. Vexed I am
Of late with passions of some difference
But let not therefore my good friends be grieved--
Among which number
Nor construe any further my neglect
Then
By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried
Thoughts of great value
Tell me
No
'Tis just:
And it is very much lamented
Your hidden worthiness into your eye
And groaning underneath this age's yoke
Into what dangers would you lead me
For that which is not in me?
Therefore
And since you know you cannot see yourself
So well as by reflection
That of yourself which you yet know not of.
And be not jealous on me
Were I a common laugher
To stale with ordinary oaths my love
To every new protester; if you know
That I do fawn on men and hug them hard
And after scandal them
That I profess myself in banqueting
To all the rout
Flourish
What means this shouting? I do fear
Choose Caesar for their king.
Ay
Then must I think you would not have it so.
I would not
But wherefore do you hold me here so long?
What is it that you would impart to me?
If it be aught toward the general good
The name of honour more than I fear death.
I know that virtue to be in you
Well
I cannot tell what you and other men
Think of this life; but
In awe of such a thing as I myself.
I was born free as Caesar; so were you:
We both have fed as well
Endure the winter's cold as well as he:
For once
Leap in with me into this angry flood
And bade him follow; so indeed he did.
The torrent roar'd
With lusty sinews
And stemming it with hearts of controversy;
But ere we could arrive the point proposed
I
The old Anchises bear
Did I the tired Caesar. And this man
Is now become a god
A wretched creature and must bend his body
He had a fever when he was in Spain
How he did shake: 'tis true
His coward lips did from their colour fly
Did lose his lustre: I did hear him groan:
Ay
Mark him and write his speeches in their books
As a sick girl. Ye gods
A man of such a feeble temper should
So get the start of the majestic world
And bear the palm alone.
Shout. Flourish
Another general shout!
I do believe that these applauses are
For some new honours that are heap'd on Caesar.
Why
Like a Colossus
Walk under his huge legs and peep about
To find ourselves dishonourable graves.
Men at some time are masters of their fates:
The fault
Brutus and Caesar: what should be in that 'Caesar'?
Why should that name be sounded more than yours?
Write them together
Sound them
Weigh them
Now
Rome
When went there by an age
When could they say till now
Now is it Rome indeed and room enough
O
The eternal devil to keep his state in Rome
As easily as a king.
That you do love me
What you would work me to
How I have thought of this and of these times
I will consider; what you have to say
I will with patience hear
Both meet to hear and answer such high things.
Till then
Brutus had rather be a villager
Than to repute himself a son of Rome
Under these hard conditions as this time
Is like to lay upon us.
I am glad that my weak words
Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus.
The games are done and Caesar is returning.
As they pass by
And he will
What hath proceeded worthy note to-day.
Re-enter CAESAR and his Train
I will do so. But
Calpurnia's cheek is pale; and Cicero
Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes
As we have seen him in the Capitol
Casca will tell us what the matter is.
Antonius!
Caesar?
Let me have men about me that are fat;
Sleek-headed men and such as sleep o' nights:
Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look;
He thinks too much: such men are dangerous.
Fear him not
He is a noble Roman and well given.
Would he were fatter! But I fear him not:
Yet if my name were liable to fear
So soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much;
He is a great observer and he looks
Quite through the deeds of men: he loves no plays
Seldom he smiles
As if he mock'd himself and scorn'd his spirit
That could be moved to smile at any thing.
Such men as he be never at heart's ease
Whiles they behold a greater than themselves
I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd
Than what I fear; for always I am Caesar.
Come on my right hand
Sennet. Exeunt CAESAR and all his Train
You pull'd me by the cloak; would you speak with me?
Ay
Why
I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.
Why
offered him
What was the second noise for?
Why
They shouted thrice: what was the last cry for?
Why
Was the crown offered him thrice?
Ay
time gentler than other
mine honest neighbours shouted.
Who offered him the crown?
Why
Tell us the manner of it
I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it:
it was mere foolery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark
Antony offer him a crown;--yet 'twas not a crown
neither
you
thinking
offered it to him again; then he put it by again:
but
fingers off it. And then he offered it the third
time; he put it the third time by: and still as he
refused it
chapped hands and threw up their sweaty night-caps
and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because
Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked
Caesar; for he swounded and fell down at it: and
for mine own part
opening my lips and receiving the bad air.
But
He fell down in the market-place
mouth
'Tis very like: he hath the failing sickness.
No
I know not what you mean by that; but
clap him and hiss him
displeased them
the theatre
What said he when he came unto himself?
Marry
common herd was glad he refused the crown
plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his

he fell. When he came to himself again
their worships to think it was his infirmity. Three

soul!' and forgave him with all their hearts: but
there's no heed to be taken of them; if Caesar had
stabbed their mothers
And after that
Ay.
Did Cicero say any thing?
Ay
To what effect?
Nay
face again: but those that understood him smiled at
one another and shook their heads; but
part
