off Caesar's images
well. There was more foolery yet
remember it.
Will you sup with me to-night
No
Will you dine with me to-morrow?
Ay
worth the eating.
Good: I will expect you.
Do so. Farewell
Exit
What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!
He was quick mettle when he went to school.
So is he now in execution
Of any bold or noble enterprise
This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit
With better appetite.
And so it is. For this time I will leave you:
To-morrow
I will do so: till then
Exit BRUTUS
Well
From that it is disposed: therefore it is meet
That noble minds keep ever with their likes;
For who so firm that cannot be seduced?
Caesar doth bear me hard; but he loves Brutus:
If I were Brutus now and he were Cassius
That Rome holds of his name; wherein obscurely
Caesar's ambition shall be glanced at:
And after this let Caesar seat him sure;
For we will shake him
Exit
SCENE III. The same. A street.
Thunder and lightning. Enter from opposite sides
Good even
Why are you breathless? and why stare you so?
Are not you moved
Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero
Have rived the knotty oaks
The ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam
But never till to-night
Either there is a civil strife in heaven
Why
A common slave--you know him well by sight--
Held up his left hand
Like twenty torches join'd
Besides--I ha' not since put up my sword--
Against the Capitol I met a lion
Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women
Men all in fire walk up and down the streets.
And yesterday the bird of night did sit
Even at noon-day upon the market-place
Do so conjointly meet
'These are their reasons; they are natural;'
For
Unto the climate that they point upon.
Indeed
But men may construe things after their fashion
Come Caesar to the Capitol to-morrow?
He doth; for he did bid Antonius
Send word to you he would be there to-morrow.
Good night then
Is not to walk in.
Farewell
Exit CICERO
Enter CASSIUS
Who's there?
A Roman.
Casca
Your ear is good. Cassius
A very pleasing night to honest men.
Who ever knew the heavens menace so?
Those that have known the earth so full of faults.
For my part
And when the cross blue lightning seem'd to open
The breast of heaven
Even in the aim and very flash of it.
But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens?
It is the part of men to fear and tremble
Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.
You are dull
That should be in a Roman you do want
And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder
But if you would consider the true cause
Why all these fires
Their natures and preformed faculties
To monstrous quality
That heaven hath infused them with these spirits
Unto some monstrous state.
Now could I
Most like this dreadful night
As doth the lion in the Capitol
In personal action
And fearful
'Tis Caesar that you mean; is it not
Let it be who it is: for Romans now
Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors;
But
Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.
Indeed
Mean to establish Caesar as a king;
And he shall wear his crown by sea and land
I know where I will wear this dagger then;
Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius:
Therein
Therein
Nor stony tower
But life
If I know this
I can shake off at pleasure.
Thunder still
So can I:
So every bondman in his own hand bears
The power to cancel his captivity.
And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?
Poor man! I know he would not be a wolf
He were no lion
Those that with haste will make a mighty fire
Begin it with weak straws: what trash is Rome
For the base matter to illuminate
So vile a thing as Caesar! But
Before a willing bondman; then I know
My answer must be made. But I am arm'd
You speak to Casca
That is no fleering tell-tale. Hold
Be factious for redress of all these griefs
As who goes farthest.
There's a bargain made.
Now know you
Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans
To undergo with me an enterprise
Of honourable-dangerous consequence;
And I do know
In Pompey's porch: for now
And the complexion of the element
In favour's like the work we have in hand
Stand close awhile
'Tis Cinna; I do know him by his gait;
He is a friend.
Enter CINNA
Cinna
To find out you. Who's that? Metellus Cimber?
No
To our attempts. Am I not stay'd for
I am glad on 't. What a fearful night is this!
There's two or three of us have seen strange sights.
Am I not stay'd for? tell me.
Yes
O Cassius
But win the noble Brutus to our party--
Be you content: good Cinna
In at his window; set this up with wax
Upon old Brutus' statue: all this done
Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?
All but Metellus Cimber; and he's gone
To seek you at your house. Well
That done
Exit CINNA
Come
See Brutus at his house: three parts of him
Is ours already
Upon the next encounter yields him ours.
O
And that which would appear offence in us
Him and his worth and our great need of him
You have right well conceited. Let us go
We will awake him and be sure of him.
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Rome. BRUTUS's orchard.
Enter BRUTUS
What
I cannot
I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly.
When
Enter LUCIUS
Call'd you
Get me a taper in my study
When it is lighted
I will
Exit
It must be by his death: and for my part
How that might change his nature
It is the bright day that brings forth the adder;
And that craves wary walking. Crown him?--that;--
And then
The abuse of greatness is
Remorse from power: and
More than his reason. But 'tis a common proof
But when he once attains the upmost round.
He then unto the ladder turns his back
By which he did ascend. So Caesar may.
Then
Will bear no colour for the thing he is
And therefore think him as a serpent's egg
Which
Re-enter LUCIUS
The taper burneth in your closet
Searching the window for a flint
This paper
Gives him the letter
Get you to bed again; it is not day.
Is not to-morrow
I know not
Look in the calendar
I will
Exit
The exhalations whizzing in the air
Give so much light that I may read by them.
Opens the letter and reads
'Brutus
Shall Rome
Brutus
Such instigations have been often dropp'd
Where I have took them up.
'Shall Rome
Shall Rome stand under one man's awe? What
My ancestors did from the streets of Rome
The Tarquin drive
'Speak
To speak and strike? O Rome
If the redress will follow
Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus!
Re-enter LUCIUS
Sir
Knocking within
'Tis good. Go to the gate; somebody knocks.
Exit LUCIUS
Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar
Between the acting of a dreadful thing
And the first motion
Like a phantasma
The Genius and the mortal instruments
Are then in council; and the state of man
The nature of an insurrection.
Re-enter LUCIUS
Sir
Is he alone?
No
Do you know them?
No
By any mark of favour.
Let 'em enter.
Exit LUCIUS
They are the faction. O conspiracy
Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough
To mask thy monstrous visage? Seek none
Hide it in smiles and affability:
For if thou path
To hide thee from prevention.
Enter the conspirators
I think we are too bold upon your rest:
Good morrow
I have been up this hour
Know I these men that come along with you?
Yes
But honours you; and every one doth wish
You had but that opinion of yourself
Which every noble Roman bears of you.
This is Trebonius.
He is welcome hither.
This
He is welcome too.
This
They are all welcome.
What watchful cares do interpose themselves
Betwixt your eyes and night?
Shall I entreat a word?
BRUTUS and CASSIUS whisper
Here lies the east: doth not the day break here?
No.
O
That fret the clouds are messengers of day.
You shall confess that you are both deceived.
Here
Some two months hence up higher toward the north
He first presents his fire; and the high east
Stands
Give me your hands all over
And let us swear our resolution.
No
If these be motives weak
So let high-sighted tyranny range on
To kindle cowards and to steel with valour
The melting spirits of women
Than secret Romans
Than honesty to honesty engaged
Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous
That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear
Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain
The even virtue of our enterprise
Did need an oath; when every drop of blood
That every Roman bears
Of any promise that hath pass'd from him.
But what of Cicero? shall we sound him?
I think he will stand very strong with us.
Let us not leave him out.
No
O
Will purchase us a good opinion
And buy men's voices to commend our deeds:
It shall be said
Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear
O
For he will never follow any thing
That other men begin.
Then leave him out.
Indeed he is not fit.
Shall no man else be touch'd but only Caesar?
Decius
A shrewd contriver; and
As to annoy us all: which to prevent
Our course will seem too bloody
For Antony is but a limb of Caesar:
Let us be sacrificers
We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar;
And in the spirit of men there is no blood:
O
Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods
And let our hearts
Our purpose necessary and not envious:
Which so appearing to the common eyes
And for Mark Antony
For he can do no more than Caesar's arm
When Caesar's head is off.
Yet I fear him;
For in the ingrafted love he bears to Caesar--
Alas
If he love Caesar
Is to himself
And that were much he should; for he is given
To sports
There is no fear in him; let him not die;
For he will live
Clock strikes
Peace! count the clock.
The clock hath stricken three.
'Tis time to part.
But it is doubtful yet
For he is superstitious grown of late
Of fantasy
It may be
Never fear that: if he be so resolved
That unicorns may be betray'd with trees
But when I tell him he hates flatterers
Let me work;
For I can give his humour the true bent
Nay
By the eighth hour: is that the uttermost?
Be that the uttermost
Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard
I wonder none of you have thought of him.
Now
He loves me well
Send him but hither
The morning comes upon 's: we'll leave you
And
What you have said
Good gentlemen
Let not our looks put on our purposes
And so good morrow to you every one.
Exeunt all but BRUTUS
Boy! Lucius! Fast asleep? It is no matter;
Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber:
Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies
Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.
Enter PORTIA
Brutus
Portia
It is not for your health thus to commit
Your weak condition to the raw cold morning.
Nor for yours neither. You've ungently
I urged you further; then you scratch'd your head
Yet I insisted
Fearing to strengthen that impatience
Which seem'd too much enkindled
Hoping it was but an effect of humour
It will not let you eat
As it hath much prevail'd on your condition
I am not well in health
Brutus is wise
Why
Is Brutus sick? and is it physical
To walk unbraced and suck up the humours
Of the dank morning? What
And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air
To add unto his sickness? No
You have some sick offence within your mind
Which did incorporate and make us one
Have had to resort to you: for here have been
Some six or seven
Even from darkness.
Kneel not
I should not need
Within the bond of marriage
That appertain to you? Am I yourself
But
Of your good pleasure? If it be no more
You are my true and honourable wife
That visit my sad heart
If this were true
I grant I am a woman; but withal
A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife:
I grant I am a woman; but withal
A woman well-reputed
Think you I am no stronger than my sex
Tell me your counsels
I have made strong proof of my constancy
Here
And not my husband's secrets?
O ye gods
Knocking within
Hark
And by and by thy bosom shall partake
The secrets of my heart.
All my engagements I will construe to thee
Leave me with haste.
Exit PORTIA
Lucius
Re-enter LUCIUS with LIGARIUS
He is a sick man that would speak with you.
Caius Ligarius
Boy
Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.
O
I am not sick
Any exploit worthy the name of honour.
Such an exploit have I in hand
By all the gods that Romans bow before
Brave son
Thou
My mortified spirit. Now bid me run
Yea
A piece of work that will make sick men whole.
But are not some whole that we must make sick?
That must we also. What it is
To whom it must be done.
Set on your foot
That Brutus leads me on.
Follow me
Exeunt
SCENE II. CAESAR's house.
Thunder and lightning. Enter CAESAR
Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace to-night:
Thrice hath Calpurnia in her sleep cried out
Enter a Servant
My lord?
Go bid the priests do present sacrifice
And bring me their opinions of success.
I will
Exit
Enter CALPURNIA
What mean you
You shall not stir out of your house to-day.
Caesar shall forth: the things that threaten'd me
Ne'er look'd but on my back; when they shall see
The face of Caesar
Caesar
A lioness hath whelped in the streets;
And graves have yawn'd
Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds
The noise of battle hurtled in the air
O Caesar! these things are beyond all use
What can be avoided
Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?
Yet Caesar shall go forth; for these predictions
Are to the world in general as to Caesar.
When beggars die
The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.
Cowards die many times before their deaths;
The valiant never taste of death but once.
Of all the wonders that I yet have heard.
It seems to me most strange that men should fear;
Seeing that death
Re-enter Servant
What say the augurers?
They would not have you to stir forth to-day.
Plucking the entrails of an offering forth
The gods do this in shame of cowardice:
Caesar should be a beast without a heart
No
That Caesar is more dangerous than he:
We are two lions litter'd in one day
And Caesar shall go forth.
Alas
Do not go forth to-day: call it my fear
That keeps you in the house
We'll send Mark Antony to the senate-house:
And he shall say you are not well to-day:
Let me
Mark Antony shall say I am not well
Enter DECIUS BRUTUS
Here's Decius Brutus
Caesar
I come to fetch you to the senate-house.
And you are come in very happy time
And tell them that I will not come to-day:
Cannot
I will not come to-day: tell them so
Say he is sick.
Shall Caesar send a lie?
Have I in conquest stretch'd mine arm so far
Decius
Most mighty Caesar
The cause is in my will: I will not come;
That is enough to satisfy the senate.
But for your private satisfaction
Calpurnia here
She dreamt to-night she saw my statua
Came smiling
And these does she apply for warnings
Hath begg'd that I will stay at home to-day.
This dream is all amiss interpreted;
It was a vision fair and fortunate:
Your statue spouting blood in many pipes
Reviving blood
For tinctures
This by Calpurnia's dream is signified.
And this way have you well expounded it.
I have
And know it now: the senate have concluded
To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
If you shall send them word you will not come
Apt to be render'd
'Break up the senate till another time
If Caesar hide himself
'Lo
Pardon me
To our proceeding bids me tell you this;
And reason to my love is liable.
How foolish do your fears seem now
I am ashamed I did yield to them.
Give me my robe
Enter PUBLIUS
And look where Publius is come to fetch me.
Good morrow
Welcome
What
Good morrow
As that same ague which hath made you lean.
What is 't o'clock?
Caesar
I thank you for your pains and courtesy.
Enter ANTONY
See! Antony
So to most noble Caesar.
Bid them prepare within:
I am to blame to be thus waited for.
Now
I have an hour's talk in store for you;
Remember that you call on me to-day:
Be near me
Caesar
Aside
and so near will I be
Good friends
And we
[Aside]  That every like is not the same
Exeunt
SCENE III. A street near the Capitol.
Enter ARTEMIDORUS
'Caesar
come not near Casca; have an eye to Cinna
Trebonius: mark well Metellus Cimber: Decius Brutus
loves thee not: thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius.
There is but one mind in all these men
bent against Caesar. If thou beest not immortal
The mighty gods defend thee! Thy lover
Here will I stand till Caesar pass along
My heart laments that virtue cannot live
Out of the teeth of emulation.
If thou read this
If not
Exit
SCENE IV. Another part of the same street
Enter PORTIA and LUCIUS
I prithee
Stay not to answer me
Why dost thou stay?
To know my errand
I would have had thee there
O constancy
I have a man's mind
How hard it is for women to keep counsel!
Art thou here yet?
Madam
Run to the Capitol
And so return to you
Yes
What Caesar doth
Hark
I hear none
Prithee
I heard a bustling rumour
Sooth
Enter the Soothsayer
Come hither
At mine own house
What is't o'clock?
About the ninth hour
Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?
Madam
Thou hast some suit to Caesar
That I have
To be so good to Caesar as to hear me
Why
None that I know will be
Good morrow to you. Here the street is narrow:
The throng that follows Caesar at the heels
I'll get me to a place more void
Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.
Exit
I must go in. Ay me
The heart of woman is! O Brutus
Sure
That Caesar will not grant. O
Run
Say I am merry: come to me again
Exeunt severally
ACT III
SCENE I. Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
A crowd of people; among them ARTEMIDORUS and the  Soothsayer. Flourish. Enter CAESAR
[To the Soothsayer]  The ides of March are come.
Ay
Hail
Trebonius doth desire you to o'erread
O Caesar
That touches Caesar nearer: read it
What touches us ourself shall be last served.
Delay not
What
Sirrah
What
Come to the Capitol.
CAESAR goes up to the Senate-House
I wish your enterprise to-day may thrive.
What enterprise
Fare you well.
Advances to CAESAR
What said Popilius Lena?
He wish'd to-day our enterprise might thrive.
I fear our purpose is discovered.
Look
Casca
Brutus
Cassius
Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes;
For
Trebonius knows his time; for
He draws Mark Antony out of the way.
Exeunt ANTONY and TREBONIUS
Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go
He is address'd: press near and second him.
Casca
Are we all ready? What is now amiss
That Caesar and his senate must redress?
Most high
An humble heart
Kneeling
I must prevent thee
These couchings and these lowly courtesies
Might fire the blood of ordinary men
Into the law of children. Be not fond
That will be thaw'd from the true quality
With that which melteth fools; I mean
Thy brother by decree is banished:
If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him
Know
Will he be satisfied.
Is there no voice more worthy than my own
To sound more sweetly in great Caesar's ear
For the repealing of my banish'd brother?
I kiss thy hand
Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may
Have an immediate freedom of repeal.
What
Pardon
As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall
I could be well moved
If I could pray to move
But I am constant as the northern star
There is no fellow in the firmament.
The skies are painted with unnumber'd sparks
So in the world; 'tis furnish'd well with men
Yet in the number I do know but one
That unassailable holds on his rank
That I was constant Cimber should be banish'd
O Caesar
Hence! wilt thou lift up Olympus?
Great Caesar
Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?
Speak
CASCA first
Et tu
Dies
Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead!
Run hence
Some to the common pulpits
'Liberty
People and senators
Fly not; stand stiff: ambition's debt is paid.
Go to the pulpit
And Cassius too.
Where's Publius?
Here
Stand fast together
Should chance--
Talk not of standing. Publius
There is no harm intended to your person
And leave us
Do so: and let no man abide this deed
Re-enter TREBONIUS
Where is Antony?
Fled to his house amazed:
Men
As it were doomsday.
Fates
That we shall die
And drawing days out
Why
Cuts off so many years of fearing death.
Grant that
So are we Caesar's friends
His time of fearing death. Stoop
Up to the elbows
Then walk we forth
Stoop
Shall this our lofty scene be acted over
In states unborn and accents yet unknown!
How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport
No worthier than the dust!
So oft as that shall be
The men that gave their country liberty.
What
Ay
Brutus shall lead; and we will grace his heels
With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.
Enter a Servant
Soft! who comes here? A friend of Antony's.
Thus
Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down;
And
Brutus is noble
Caesar was mighty
Say I love Brutus
Say I fear'd Caesar
If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony
May safely come to him
How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death
So well as Brutus living; but will follow
The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus
Thorough the hazards of this untrod state
With all true faith. So says my master Antony.
Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman;
I never thought him worse.
Tell him
I'll fetch him presently.
Exit
I know that we shall have him well to friend.
I wish we may: but yet have I a mind
That fears him much; and my misgiving still
Falls shrewdly to the purpose.
But here comes Antony.
Re-enter ANTONY
Welcome
O mighty Caesar! dost thou lie so low?
Are all thy conquests
I know not
If I myself
As Caesar's death hour
Of half that worth as those your swords
With the most noble blood of all this world.
I do beseech ye
No place will please me so
O Antony
Though now we must appear bloody and cruel
And this the bleeding business they have done:
Our hearts you see not; they are pitiful;
And pity to the general wrong of Rome--
As fire drives out fire
Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part
Our arms
Of brothers' temper
With all kind love
Your voice shall be as strong as any man's
In the disposing of new dignities.
Only be patient till we have appeased
The multitude
I doubt not of your wisdom.
Let each man render me his bloody hand:
First
Next
Now
Yours
Though last
Gentlemen all
My credit now stands on such slippery ground
That I did love thee
If then thy spirit look upon us now
Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds
In terms of friendship with thine enemies.
Pardon me
Here didst thou fall; and here thy hunters stand
O world
And this
How like a deer
Mark Antony
Pardon me
The enemies of Caesar shall say this;
Then
I blame you not for praising Caesar so;
But what compact mean you to have with us?
Will you be prick'd in number of our friends;
Or shall we on
Therefore I took your hands
Friends am I with you all and love you all
Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.
Or else were this a savage spectacle:
Our reasons are so full of good regard
That were you
That's all I seek:
And am moreover suitor that I may
Produce his body to the market-place;
And in the pulpit
You shall
Brutus
Aside to BRUTUS
You know not what you do: do not consent
That Antony speak in his funeral:
Know you how much the people may be moved
By that which he will utter?
By your pardon;
I will myself into the pulpit first
What Antony shall speak
He speaks by leave and by permission
Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.
It shall advantage more than do us wrong.
I know not what may fall; I like it not.
Mark Antony
You shall not in your funeral speech blame us
Else shall you not have any hand at all
About his funeral: and you shall speak
In the same pulpit whereto I am going
Be it so.
I do desire no more.
Prepare the body then
Exeunt all but ANTONY
O
Thou art the ruins of the noblest man
That ever lived in the tide of times.
Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!
Over thy wounds now do I prophesy
Which
A curse shall light upon the limbs of men;
Domestic fury and fierce civil strife
Shall cumber all the parts of Italy;
Blood and destruction shall be so in use
And dreadful objects so familiar
That mothers shall but smile when they behold
Their infants quarter'd with the hands of war;
All pity choked with custom of fell deeds:
And Caesar's spirit
Cry  'Havoc
That this foul deed shall smell above the earth
With carrion men
Enter a Servant
You serve Octavius Caesar
I do
Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.
He did receive his letters
And bid me say to you by word of mouth--
O Caesar!--
Seeing the body
Thy heart is big
Passion
He lies to-night within seven leagues of Rome.
Post back with speed
Here is a mourning Rome
Hie hence
Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse
Into the market-place: there shall I try
In my oration
The cruel issue of these bloody men;
According to the which
To young Octavius of the state of things.
Lend me your hand.
Exeunt with CAESAR's body
SCENE II. The Forum.
Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS
We will be satisfied; let us be satisfied.
Then follow me
Cassius
Those that will hear me speak
Those that will follow Cassius
And public reasons shall be rendered
Of Caesar's death.
I will hear Brutus speak.
I will hear Cassius; and compare their reasons
Exit CASSIUS
The noble Brutus is ascended: silence!
Be patient till the last.
Romans
cause
for mine honour
you may believe: censure me in your wisdom
awake your senses
If there be any in this assembly
Caesar's
was no less than his. If then that friend demand
why Brutus rose against Caesar
#NAME?
Rome more. Had you rather Caesar were living and
die all slaves
all free men? As Caesar loved me
as he was fortunate
valiant
slew him. There is tears for his love; joy for his
fortune; honour for his valour; and death for his
ambition. Who is here so base that would be a
bondman? If any
Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman? If
any
vile that will not love his country? If any
for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.
None
Then none have I offended. I have done no more to
Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The question of
his death is enrolled in the Capitol; his glory not
extenuated
enforced
Enter ANTONY and others
Here comes his body
the benefit of his dying
commonwealth; as which of you shall not? With this
I depart
good of Rome
Live
Bring him with triumph home unto his house.
Give him a statue with his ancestors.
Let him be Caesar.
Caesar's better parts
Shall be crown'd in Brutus.
We'll bring him to his house
With shouts and clamours.
My countrymen
Peace
Peace
Good countrymen
Do grace to Caesar's corpse
Tending to Caesar's glories; which Mark Antony
I do entreat you
Exit
Stay
Let him go up into the public chair;
We'll hear him. Noble Antony
For Brutus' sake
Goes into the pulpit
What does he say of Brutus?
He says
'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.
This Caesar was a tyrant.
Nay
We are blest that Rome is rid of him.
Peace! let us hear what Antony can say.
You gentle Romans
Peace
Friends
I come to bury Caesar
The evil that men do lives after them;
The good is oft interred with their bones;
So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus
Hath told you Caesar was ambitious:
If it were so
Here
For Brutus is an honourable man;
So are they all
Come I to speak in Caesar's funeral.
He was my friend
But Brutus says he was ambitious;
And Brutus is an honourable man.
He hath brought many captives home to Rome
Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill:
Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?
When that the poor have cried
Ambition should be made of sterner stuff:
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;
And Brutus is an honourable man.
You all did see that on the Lupercal
I thrice presented him a kingly crown
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;
And
I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke
You all did love him once
What cause withholds you then
O judgment! thou art fled to brutish beasts
My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar
Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.
If thou consider rightly of the matter
Has he
I fear there will a worse come in his place.
Mark'd ye his words? He would not take the crown;
Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitious.
If it be found so
Poor soul! his eyes are red as fire with weeping.
There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.
Now mark him
But yesterday the word of Caesar might
Have stood against the world; now lies he there.
And none so poor to do him reverence.
O masters
Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage
I will not do them wrong; I rather choose
To wrong the dead
But here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar;
I found it in his closet
Let but the commons hear this testament--
Which
And they would go and kiss dead Caesar's wounds
And dip their napkins in his sacred blood
Unto their issue.
We'll hear the will: read it
The will
Have patience
It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.
You are not wood
And
'Tis good you know not that you are his heirs;
For
Read the will; we'll hear it
You shall read us the will
Will you be patient? will you stay awhile?
I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it:
I fear I wrong the honourable men
Whose daggers have stabb'd Caesar; I do fear it.
They were traitors: honourable men!
The will! the testament!
They were villains
You will compel me
Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar
Shall I descend? and will you give me leave?
Come down.
Descend.
You shall have leave.
ANTONY comes down
A ring; stand round.
Stand from the hearse
Room for Antony
Nay
Stand back; room; bear back.
If you have tears
You all do know this mantle: I remember
The first time ever Caesar put it on;
'Twas on a summer's evening
Look
See what a rent the envious Casca made:
Through this the well-beloved Brutus stabb'd;
And as he pluck'd his cursed steel away
If Brutus so unkindly knock'd
For Brutus
Judge
This was the most unkindest cut of all;
For when the noble Caesar saw him stab
And
O
Then I
O
The dint of pity: these are gracious drops.
Kind souls
Our Caesar's vesture wounded? Look you here
O piteous spectacle!
O noble Caesar!
O woful day!
O traitors
O most bloody sight!
We will be revenged.
Revenge! About! Seek! Burn! Fire! Kill! Slay!
Let not a traitor live!
Stay
Peace there! hear the noble Antony.
We'll hear him
Good friends
To such a sudden flood of mutiny.
They that have done this deed are honourable:
What private griefs they have
I come not
I am no orator
But
That gave me public leave to speak of him:
For I have neither wit
I tell you that which you yourselves do know;
Show you sweet Caesar's wounds
Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue
In every wound of Caesar that should move
The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.
We'll mutiny.
We'll burn the house of Brutus.
Away
Yet hear me
Peace
Why
Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?
Alas
You have forgot the will I told you of.
Most true. The will! Let's stay and hear the will.
Here is the will
To every Roman citizen he gives
Most noble Caesar! We'll revenge his death.
O royal Caesar!
Hear me with patience.
Peace
Moreover
Here was a Caesar! when comes such another?
Never
We'll burn his body in the holy place
Take up the body.
Go fetch fire.
Pluck down benches.
Pluck down forms
Exeunt Citizens with the body
Now let it work. Mischief
Enter a Servant
How now
Sir
Where is he?
He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.
And thither will I straight to visit him:
He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry
I heard him say
Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.
Belike they had some notice of the people
Exeunt
SCENE III. A street.
Enter CINNA the poet
I dreamt to-night that I did feast with Caesar
I have no will to wander forth of doors
Enter Citizens
What is your name?
Whither are you going?
Where do you dwell?
Are you a married man or a bachelor?
Answer every man directly.
Ay
Ay
Ay
What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I
dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then
answer every man directly and briefly
truly: wisely I say
That's as much as to say
you'll bear me a bang for that
Directly
As a friend or an enemy?
As a friend.
That matter is answered directly.
For your dwelling
Briefly
Your name
Truly
Tear him to pieces; he's a conspirator.
I am Cinna the poet
Tear him for his bad verses
I am not Cinna the conspirator.
It is no matter
name out of his heart
Tear him
to Brutus'
house
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. A house in Rome.
ANTONY
These many
Your brother too must die; consent you
I do consent--
Prick him down
Upon condition Publius shall not live
He shall not live; look
But
Fetch the will hither
How to cut off some charge in legacies.
What
Or here
Exit LEPIDUS
This is a slight unmeritable man
One of the three to share it?
So you thought him;
And took his voice who should be prick'd to die
Octavius
And though we lay these honours on this man
And having brought our treasure where we will
You may do your will;
But he's a tried and valiant soldier.
So is my horse
I do appoint him store of provender:
It is a creature that I teach to fight
And
He must be taught and train'd and bid go forth;
A barren-spirited fellow; one that feeds
On abjects
Are levying powers: we must straight make head:
Therefore let our alliance be combined
And let us presently go sit in council
Let us do so: for we are at the stake
And some that smile have in their hearts
Exeunt
SCENE II. Camp near Sardis. Before BRUTUS's tent.
Drum. Enter BRUTUS
Stand
Give the word
What now
He is at hand; and Pindarus is come
To do you salutation from his master.
He greets me well. Your master
Things done
I do not doubt
But that my noble master will appear
Such as he is
He is not doubted. A word
How he received you
With courtesy and with respect enough;
But not with such familiar instances
Thou hast described
A hot friend cooling: ever note
There are no tricks in plain and simple faith;
But hollow men
But when they should endure the bloody spur
They mean this night in Sardis to be quarter'd;
The greater part
Hark! he is arrived.
Low march within
March gently on to meet him.
Enter CASSIUS and his powers
Stand
Stand
Stand!
Stand!
Stand!
Most noble brother
Judge me
And
Brutus
And when you do them--
Cassius
Speak your griefs softly: I do know you well.
Before the eyes of both our armies here
Then in my tent
Pindarus
A little from this ground.
Lucilius
Come to our tent till we have done our conference.
Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door.
Exeunt
SCENE III. Brutus's tent.
Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS
That you have wrong'd me doth appear in this:
You have condemn'd and noted Lucius Pella
For taking bribes here of the Sardians;
Wherein my letters
You wronged yourself to write in such a case.
In such a time as this it is not meet
That every nice offence should bear his comment.
Let me tell you
Are much condemn'd to have an itching palm;
To sell and mart your offices for gold
To undeservers.
I an itching palm!
You know that you are Brutus that speak this
The name of Cassius honours this corruption
Chastisement!
Remember March
Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?
What villain touch'd his body
That struck the foremost man of all this world
But for supporting robbers
Contaminate our fingers with base bribes
For so much trash as may be grasped thus?
I had rather be a dog
Brutus
I'll not endure it: you forget yourself
To make conditions.
Go to; you are not
I am.
I say you are not.
Urge me no more
Have mind upon your health
Away
Is't possible?
Hear me
Must I give way and room to your rash choler?
Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?
O ye gods
All this! ay
Go show your slaves how choleric you are
Must I observe you? must I stand and crouch
Under your testy humour? By the gods
You shall digest the venom of your spleen
Is it come to this?
You say you are a better soldier:
Let it appear so; make your vaunting true
You wrong me every way; you wrong me
I said
Did I say 'better'?
If you did
When Caesar lived
Peace
I durst not!
No.
What
For your life you durst not!
Do not presume too much upon my love;
I may do that I shall be sorry for.
You have done that you should be sorry for.
There is no terror
That they pass by me as the idle wind
For certain sums of gold
For I can raise no money by vile means:
By heaven
From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash
By any indirection: I did send
To you for gold to pay my legions
Should I have answer'd Caius Cassius so?
When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous
Dash him to pieces!
I denied you not.
You did.
I did not: he was but a fool that brought
My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart:
A friend should bear his friend's infirmities
I do not
You love me not.
I do not like your faults.
A friendly eye could never see such faults.
A flatterer's would not
As huge as high Olympus.
Come
Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother;
Cheque'd like a bondman; all his faults observed
My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger
Dearer than Plutus' mine
If that thou be'st a Roman
I
Strike
Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.
Sheathe your dagger:
Be angry when you will
Do what you will
O Cassius
That carries anger as the flint bears fire;
Who
Hath Cassius lived
To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus
When I spoke that
Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.
And my heart too.
O Brutus!
What's the matter?
Have not you love enough to bear with me
Makes me forgetful?
Yes
[Within]  Let me go in to see the generals;
There is some grudge between 'em
They be alone.
[Within]  You shall not come to them.
[Within]  Nothing but death shall stay me.
Enter Poet
How now! what's the matter?
For shame
Love
For I have seen more years
Ha
Get you hence
Bear with him
I'll know his humour
What should the wars do with these jigging fools?
Companion
Away
Exit Poet
Lucilius and Titinius
Prepare to lodge their companies to-night.
And come yourselves
Immediately to us.
Exeunt LUCILIUS and TITINIUS
Lucius
Exit LUCIUS
I did not think you could have been so angry.
O Cassius
Of your philosophy you make no use
No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.
Ha! Portia!
She is dead.
How 'scaped I killing when I cross'd you so?
O insupportable and touching loss!
Upon what sickness?
Impatient of my absence
Have made themselves so strong:--for with her death
That tidings came;--with this she fell distract
And died so?
Even so.
O ye immortal gods!
Re-enter LUCIUS
Speak no more of her. Give me a bowl of wine.
In this I bury all unkindness
My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.
Fill
I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.
Come in
Exit LUCIUS
Re-enter TITINIUS
Welcome
Now sit we close about this taper here
Portia
No more
Messala
Come down upon us with a mighty power
Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.
With what addition?
That by proscription and bills of outlawry
Therein our letters do not well agree;
Mine speak of seventy senators that died
By their proscriptions
Cicero one!
Cicero is dead
Had you your letters from your wife
No
Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?
Nothing
That
Why ask you? hear you aught of her in yours?
No
Now
Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell:
For certain she is dead
Why
With meditating that she must die once
Even so great men great losses should endure.
I have as much of this in art as you
Well
Of marching to Philippi presently?
I do not think it good.
Your reason?
This it is:
'Tis better that the enemy seek us:
So shall he waste his means
Good reasons must
The people 'twixt Philippi and this ground
Do stand but in a forced affection;
For they have grudged us contribution:
The enemy
From which advantage shall we cut him off
Hear me
Under your pardon. You must note beside
The enemy increaseth every day;
We
There is a tide in the affairs of men
Omitted
Is bound in shallows and in miseries.
On such a full sea are we now afloat;
And we must take the current when it serves
Then
We'll along ourselves
The deep of night is crept upon our talk
Which we will niggard with a little rest.
There is no more to say?
No more. Good night:
Early to-morrow will we rise
Lucius!
Enter LUCIUS
My gown.
Exit LUCIUS
Farewell
Good night
O my dear brother!
This was an ill beginning of the night:
Never come such division 'tween our souls!
Let it not
Every thing is well.
Good night
Good night
Good night
Farewell
Exeunt all but BRUTUS
Re-enter LUCIUS
Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?
Here in the tent.
What
Poor knave
Call Claudius and some other of my men:
I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.
Varro and Claudius!
Enter VARRO and CLAUDIUS
Calls my lord?
I pray you
It may be I shall raise you by and by
On business to my brother Cassius.
So please you
I will not have it so: lie down
It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.
Look
I put it in the pocket of my gown.
VARRO and CLAUDIUS lie down
I was sure your lordship did not give it me.
Bear with me
Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile
Ay
It does
I trouble thee too much
It is my duty
I should not urge thy duty past thy might;
I know young bloods look for a time of rest.
I have slept
It was well done; and thou shalt sleep again;
I will not hold thee long: if I do live
Music
This is a sleepy tune. O murderous slumber
I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee:
If thou dost nod
I'll take it from thee; and
Let me see
Where I left reading? Here it is
Enter the Ghost of CAESAR
How ill this taper burns! Ha! who comes here?
I think it is the weakness of mine eyes
That shapes this monstrous apparition.
It comes upon me. Art thou any thing?
Art thou some god
Speak to me what thou art.
Thy evil spirit
Why comest thou?
To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.
Well; then I shall see thee again?
Ay
Why
Exit Ghost
Now I have taken heart thou vanishest:
Ill spirit
Boy
The strings
He thinks he still is at his instrument.
Lucius
My lord?
Didst thou dream
My lord
Yes
Nothing
Sleep again
To VARRO
Fellow thou
My lord?
My lord?
Why did you so cry out
Did we
Ay: saw you any thing?
No
Nor I
Go and commend me to my brother Cassius;
Bid him set on his powers betimes before
It shall be done
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. The plains of Philippi.
Enter OCTAVIUS
Now
You said the enemy would not come down
It proves not so: their battles are at hand;
They mean to warn us at Philippi here
Tut
Wherefore they do it: they could be content
To visit other places; and come down
With fearful bravery
To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage;
But 'tis not so.
Enter a Messenger
Prepare you
The enemy comes on in gallant show;
Their bloody sign of battle is hung out
Octavius
Upon the right hand I; keep thou the left.
Why do you cross me in this exigent?
I do not cross you; but I will do so.
March
Drum. Enter BRUTUS
They stand
Stand fast
Mark Antony
No
Make forth; the generals would have some words.
Stir not until the signal.
Words before blows: is it so
Not that we love words better
Good words are better than bad strokes
In your bad strokes
Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart
Antony
But for your words
Not stingless too.
O
For you have stol'n their buzzing
Villains
Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar:
You show'd your teeth like apes
Whilst damned Casca
Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!
Flatterers! Now
This tongue had not offended so to-day
Come
I draw a sword against conspirators;
When think you that the sword goes up again?
Never
Be well avenged; or till another Caesar
Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.
Caesar
So I hope;
I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.
O
A peevish schoolboy
Old Cassius still!
Come
Defiance
If you dare fight to-day
If not
Exeunt OCTAVIUS
Why
The storm is up
Ho
"[Standing forth]	My lord?"
BRUTUS and LUCILIUS converse apart
Messala!
[Standing forth]  What says my general?
Messala
Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand
Be thou my witness that against my will
Upon one battle all our liberties.
You know that I held Epicurus strong
And his opinion: now I change my mind
Coming from Sardis
Two mighty eagles fell
Who to Philippi here consorted us:
This morning are they fled away and gone;
And in their steads do ravens
A canopy most fatal
Our army lies
Believe not so.
I but believe it partly;
For I am fresh of spirit and resolved
To meet all perils very constantly.
Even so
Now
But since the affairs of men rest still incertain
If we do lose this battle
The very last time we shall speak together:
What are you then determined to do?
Even by the rule of that philosophy
By which I did blame Cato for the death
Which he did give himself
The time of life: arming myself with patience
To stay the providence of some high powers
That govern us below.
Then
Thorough the streets of Rome?
No
He bears too great a mind. But this same day
Must end that work the ides of March begun;
And whether we shall meet again I know not.
Therefore our everlasting farewell take:
For ever
If we do meet again
If not
For ever
If we do meet again
If not
Why
The end of this day's business ere it come!
But it sufficeth that the day will end
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. The field of battle.

Ride
Unto the legions on the other side.
Loud alarum
Let them set on at once; for I perceive
But cold demeanor in Octavius' wing
Ride

Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power

Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.

The last of all the Romans

I shall find time

Safe

Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus:
The gods defend him from so great a shame!
When you do find him
This is not Brutus
Give him all kindness: I had rather have
Such men my friends than enemies. Go on
And bring us word unto Octavius' tent
How every thing is chanced.

Strato

I found no man but he was true to me.
I shall have glory by this losing day
More than Octavius and Mark Antony
By this vile conquest shall attain unto.
So fare you well at once; for Brutus' tongue
Hath almost ended his life's history:
Night hangs upon mine eyes; my bones would rest
Alarum. Cry within

I prithee

Hold then my sword

My master's man. Strato
Free from the bondage you are in
The conquerors can but make a fire of him;

All that served Brutus
Fellow
Ay

How died my master
I held the sword
Octavius
This was the noblest Roman of them all:
All the conspirators save only he
Did that they did in envy of great Caesar;
He only
And common good to all
His life was gentle
So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up
And say to all the world 'This was a man!'
According to his virtue let us use him
Within my tent his bones to-night shall lie
So call the field to rest; and let's away
Exeunt
ACT I

Meantime we shall express our darker purpose.
Give me the map there. Know that we have divided
In three our kingdom: and 'tis our fast intent
To shake all cares and business from our age;
Conferring them on younger strengths
Unburthen'd crawl toward death. Our son of Cornwall
Our daughters' several dowers
May be prevented now. The princes
Since now we will divest us both of rule
Which of you shall we say doth love us most?
That we our largest bounty may extend
Where nature doth with merit challenge. Goneril
Sir
Dearer than eye-sight
Beyond what can be valued
No less than life
As much as child e'er loved
A love that makes breath poor
Beyond all manner of so much I love you.

Love
Of all these bounds
Be this perpetual. What says our second daughter
Sir
Of the self-same metal that my sister is
I find she names my very deed of love;
Only she comes too short: that I profess
Myself an enemy to all other joys
And find I am alone felicitate
In your dear highness' love.
"[Aside]	Then poor Cordelia!"
And yet not so; since
More richer than my tongue.
To thee and thine hereditary ever
Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom;
No less in space
The vines of France and milk of Burgundy
Strive to be interess'd; what can you say to draw
A third more opulent than your sisters? Speak.
Nothing
Nothing!
Nothing.
Nothing will come of nothing: speak again.
Unhappy that I am
My heart into my mouth: I love your majesty
According to my bond; nor more nor less.
How

Why have my sisters husbands

Half my love with him
Sure

Ay
So young
So young

From whom we do exist

Hold thee
To gorge his appetite
Be as well neighbour'd
Good my liege
Peace
Come not between the dragon and his wrath.
I loved her most
On her kind nursery. Hence
So be my grave my peace
Her father's heart from her! Call France; who stirs?
Call Burgundy. Cornwall and Albany

I do invest you jointly with my power
That troop with majesty. Ourself
Make with you by due turns. Only we still retain

Giving the crown
Royal Lear
The bow is bent and drawn
Let it fall rather
The region of my heart: be Kent unmannerly
Think'st thou that duty shall have dread to speak
And
This hideous rashness: answer my life my judgment
Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound
Reverbs no hollowness.
Kent
My life I never held but as a pawn
To wage against thy enemies; nor fear to lose it
Out of my sight!
See better
The true blank of thine eye.
Now
Now
O
Laying his hand on his sword
Dear sir
Do:
Kill thy physician
Upon thy foul disease. Revoke thy doom;
Or
Hear me
On thine allegiance
Since thou hast sought to make us break our vow
To come between our sentence and our power
Five days we do allot thee
To shield thee from diseases of the world;
And on the sixth to turn thy hated back
Upon our kingdom: if
Fare thee well
To CORDELIA
The gods to their dear shelter take thee
To REGAN and GONERIL
And your large speeches may your deeds approve

Here's France and Burgundy

Hath rivall'd for our daughter: what
Most royal majesty

For you
To avert your liking a more worthier way
Than on a wretch whom nature is ashamed
Almost to acknowledge hers.
This is most strange

So many folds of favour. Sure
Must be of such unnatural degree
Fall'n into taint: which to believe of her
Could never plant in me.

It is no vicious blot
But even for want of that for which I am richer

Hath lost me in your liking.
Better thou
Hadst not been born than not to have pleased me better.
Is it but this
Which often leaves the history unspoke

When it is mingled with regards that stand

Royal Lear
Nothing: I have sworn; I am firm.

Peace be with Burgundy!
Since that respects of fortune are his love
Fairest Cordelia
Most choice

Gods

The jewels of our father

But yet
So
Prescribe not us our duties.
Let your study

At fortune's alms. You have obedience scanted
Time shall unfold what plaited cunning hides:
Who cover faults
Well may you prosper!
Come

Sister
most nearly appertains to us both. I think our
father will hence to-night.
That's most certain
You see how full of changes his age is; the
observation we have made of it hath not been
little: he always loved our sister most; and
with what poor judgment he hath now cast her off
appears too grossly.
'Tis the infirmity of his age: yet he hath ever
but slenderly known himself.
The best and soundest of his time hath been but
rash; then must we look to receive from his age
condition
that infirm and choleric years bring with them.

There is further compliment of leavetaking
between France and him. Pray you
together: if our father carry authority with
such dispositions as he bears
surrender of his will but offend us.
We shall further think on't.
We must do something

SCENE III. The Duke of Albany's palace.
Enter GONERIL
Did my father strike my gentleman for chiding of his fool?
Yes
By day and night he wrongs me; every hour
He flashes into one gross crime or other
His knights grow riotous
On every trifle. When he returns from hunting
If you come slack of former services
He's coming
Horns within
Put on what weary negligence you please
If he dislike it
That he hath given away! Now
With cheques as flatteries
Remember what I tell you.
Well
And let his knights have colder looks among you;
What grows of it
I would breed from hence occasions

SCENE IV. A hall in the same.

If but as well I other accents borrow
May carry through itself to that full issue
For which I razed my likeness. Now
Horns within. Enter KING LEAR

How now! what art thou?
A man
What dost thou profess? what wouldst thou with us?
I do profess to be no less than I seem; to serve
him truly that will put me in trust: to love him
that is honest; to converse with him that is wise
cannot choose; and to eat no fish.
What art thou?
A very honest-hearted fellow

king

You.

Not so young

draws the horse? Whoop
Doth any here know me? This is not Lear:
Doth Lear walk thus? speak thus? Where are his eyes?
Either his notion weakens
Are lethargied--Ha! waking? 'tis not so.
Who is it that can tell me who I am?
Lear's shadow.
I would learn that; for
marks of sovereignty
Which they will make an obedient father.
Your name
This admiration
Of other your new pranks. I do beseech you
To understand my purposes aright:
As you are old and reverend
Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires;
Men so disorder'd
Make it more like a tavern or a brothel
Than a graced palace. The shame itself doth speak
For instant remedy: be then desired
By her
And the remainder
Darkness and devils!
Saddle my horses; call my train together:
Degenerate bastard! I'll not trouble thee.
Yet have I left a daughter.
You strike my people; and your disorder'd rabble
Make servants of their betters.
Enter ALBANY
Woe
To ALBANY
O
Is it your will? Speak
Ingratitude
Than the sea-monster!
Pray
[To GONERIL]  Detested kite! thou liest.
My train are men of choice and rarest parts
The worships of their name. O most small fault
That
From the fix'd place; drew from heart all love
Beat at this gate
And thy dear judgment out! Go
My lord
Of what hath moved you.
It may be so
Hear
Suspend thy purpose
To make this creature fruitful!
Into her womb convey sterility!
Dry up in her the organs of increase;
And from her derogate body never spring
A babe to honour her! If she must teem
Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth;
With cadent tears fret channels in her cheeks;
Turn all her mother's pains and benefits
To laughter and contempt; that she may feel
How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is
To have a thankless child! Away
Exit
Now
Never afflict yourself to know the cause;
But let his disposition have that scope
That dotage gives it.
Re-enter KING LEAR
What
Within a fortnight!
What's the matter
I'll tell thee:
To GONERIL
Life and death! I am ashamed
That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus;
That these hot tears
The untented woundings of a father's curse
Pierce every sense about thee! Old fond eyes
Let is be so: yet have I left a daughter
When she shall hear this of thee
She'll flay thy wolvish visage. Thou shalt find
That I'll resume the shape which thou dost think
I have cast off for ever: thou shalt
Exeunt KING LEAR
Do you mark that
I cannot be so partial
Pray you
To the Fool
You
Nuncle Lear
with thee.
A fox
So the fool follows after.
Exit
This man hath had good counsel:--a hundred knights!
'Tis politic and safe to let him keep
At point a hundred knights: yes
Well
Safer than trust too far:
Let me still take away the harms I fear
What he hath utter'd I have writ my sister
If she sustain him and his hundred knights
When I have show'd the unfitness
Re-enter OSWALD
How now
What
Yes
Take you some company
Inform her full of my particular fear;
And thereto add such reasons of your own
As may compact it more. Get you gone;
And hasten your return.
Exit OSWALD
No
Though I condemn not
Than praised for harmful mildness.
How far your eyes may pierce I can not tell:
Striving to better
Nay
Well
Exeunt
SCENE V. Court before the same.
Enter KING LEAR
Go you before to Gloucester with these letters.
Acquaint my daughter no further with any thing you
know than comes from her demand out of the letter.

I will not sleep
your letter.
Exit

danger of kibes?
Ay
Then
slip-shod.
Ha
Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly;

Why
She will taste as like this as a crab does to a

the middle on's face?
No.
Why
what a man cannot smell out
I did her wrong--
Canst tell how an oyster makes his shell?
No.

Why?
Why
daughters
I will forget my nature. So kind a father! Be my
horses ready?
Thy asses are gone about 'em. The reason why the
seven stars are no more than seven is a pretty reason.
Because they are not eight?
Yes
To take 't again perforce! Monster ingratitude!
If thou wert my fool
for being old before thy time.
How's that?
Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst
been wise.
O
Keep me in temper: I would not be mad!
Enter Gentleman

Ready
Come
She that's a maid now

ACT II
SCENE I. GLOUCESTER's castle.
Enter EDMUND
Save thee
And you
given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan
his duchess will be here with him this night.
How comes that?
Nay
I mean the whispered ones
ear-kissing arguments?
"Not I	pray you"
Have you heard of no likely wars toward
Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?
Not a word.
You may do
Exit
The duke be here to-night? The better! best!
This weaves itself perforce into my business.
My father hath set guard to take my brother;
And I have one thing
Brother
Enter EDGAR
My father watches: O sir
Intelligence is given where you are hid;
You have now the good advantage of the night:
Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall?
He's coming hither: now
Upon his party 'gainst the Duke of Albany?
Advise yourself.
I am sure on't
I hear my father coming: pardon me:
In cunning I must draw my sword upon you
Draw; seem to defend yourself; now quit you well.
Yield: come before my father. Light
Fly
Exit EDGAR
Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion.
Wounds his arm
Of my more fierce endeavour: I have seen drunkards
Do more than this in sport. Father
Stop
Enter GLOUCESTER
Now
Here stood he in the dark
To stand auspicious mistress
But where is he?
Look
Where is the villain
Fled this way
Pursue him
Exeunt some Servants
By no means what?
Persuade me to the murder of your lordship;
But that I told him
'Gainst parricides did all their thunders bend;
Spoke
The child was bound to the father; sir
To his unnatural purpose
My unprovided body
But when he saw my best alarum'd spirits
Let him fly far:
Not in this land shall he remain uncaught;
And found--dispatch. The noble duke my master
By his authority I will proclaim it
He that conceals him
When I dissuaded him from his intent
I threaten'd to discover him: he replied
Of any trust
Make thy words faith'd? No: what I should deny
As this I would: ay
My very character
To thy suggestion
And thou must make a dullard of the world
Were very pregnant and potential spurs
To make thee seek it.'
Strong and fasten'd villain
Would he deny his letter? I never got him.
Tucket within
Hark
All ports I'll bar; the villain shall not 'scape;
The duke must grant me that: besides
I will send far and near
May have the due note of him; and of my land
To make thee capable.
Enter CORNWALL
How now
If it be true
Which can pursue the offender. How dost
O
What
He whom my father named? your Edgar?
O
Was he not companion with the riotous knights
That tend upon my father?
I know not
Yes
No marvel
'Tis they have put him on the old man's death
I have this present evening from my sister
Been well inform'd of them; and with such cautions
Nor I
Edmund
A child-like office.
'Twas my duty
He did bewray his practise; and received
This hurt you see
Is he pursued?
Ay
If he be taken
Be fear'd of doing harm: make your own purpose
So much commend itself
Natures of such deep trust we shall much need;
You we first seize on.
I shall serve you
For him I thank your grace.
You know not why we came to visit you
Thus out of season
Occasions
Our father he hath writ
To answer from our home; the several messengers
From hence attend dispatch. Our good old friend
Your needful counsel to our business
I serve you
Your graces are right welcome.
Exeunt
SCENE II. Before Gloucester's castle.
Enter KENT and OSWALD
Good dawning to thee
Ay.
Where may we set our horses?
I' the mire.
Prithee
I love thee not.
Why
If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold
care for me.
Why dost thou use me thus? I know thee not.
Fellow
What dost thou know me for?
A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a
base

will beat into clamorous whining

With you

Keep peace
He dies that strikes again. What is the matter?
The messengers from our sister and the king.

I am scarce in breath
No marvel
cowardly rascal

You beastly knave
Yes
Why art thou angry?
That such a slave as this should wear a sword
Which are too intrinse t' unloose; smooth every passion
That in the natures of their lords rebel;
Bring oil to fire
Renege
With every gale and vary of their masters
A plague upon your epileptic visage!
Smile you my speeches
Goose
Why
How fell you out? say that.
No contraries hold more antipathy
Than I and such a knave.
Why dost thou call him a knave?  What's his offence?
His countenance likes me not.
No more
Sir
I have seen better faces in my time
Than stands on any shoulder that I see
Before me at this instant.
This is some fellow
A saucy roughness
Quite from his nature: he cannot flatter
An they will take it
These kind of knaves I know
Harbour more craft and more corrupter ends
Than twenty silly ducking observants
That stretch their duties nicely.
Sir
On flickering Phoebus' front
What mean'st by this?
To go out of my dialect
discommend so much. I know
flatterer: he that beguiled you in a plain

I will not be
to entreat me to 't.
What was the offence you gave him?
I never gave him any:
It pleased the king his master very late
To strike at me
When he
For him attempting who was self-subdued;
And
None of these rogues and cowards
But Ajax is their fool.
Fetch forth the stocks!
You stubborn ancient knave
Sir
Call not your stocks for me: I serve the king;
On whose employment I was sent to you:
You shall do small respect
Against the grace and person of my master
Fetch forth the stocks! As I have life and honour
Till noon! till night
Why
Sir
This is a fellow of the self-same colour
Our sister speaks of. Come
Stocks brought out
Let me beseech your grace not to do so:
His fault is much
Will cheque him for 't: your purposed low correction
Is such as basest and contemned'st wretches
For pilferings and most common trespasses
Are punish'd with: the king must take it ill
I'll answer that.
My sister may receive it much more worse
KENT is put in the stocks
Come
Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER and KENT
I am sorry for thee
Pray
Some time I shall sleep out
A good man's fortune may grow out at heels:
Give you good morrow!
The duke's to blame in this; 'twill be ill taken.
Exit
Good king
To the warm sun!
Approach
Peruse this letter! Nothing almost sees miracles
But misery: I know 'tis from Cordelia
Of my obscured course; and shall find time
From this enormous state
Losses their remedies. All weary and o'erwatch'd
This shameful lodging.
Fortune
Sleeps
SCENE III. A wood.
Enter EDGAR
I heard myself proclaim'd;
And by the happy hollow of a tree
Escaped the hunt. No port is free; no place
To take the basest and most poorest shape
That ever penury
Blanket my loins: elf all my hair in knots;
And with presented nakedness out-face
The winds and persecutions of the sky.
The country gives me proof and precedent
Of Bedlam beggars
Pins
And with this horrible object
That's something yet: Edgar I nothing am.
Exit
SCENE IV. Before GLOUCESTER's castle. KENT in the stocks.
Enter KING LEAR
'Tis strange that they should so depart from home
As I learn'd
Of this remove.
Hail to thee
Ha!
Makest thou this shame thy pastime?
No
Ha
by the heads
the loins
over-lusty at legs
nether-stocks.
What's he that hath so much thy place mistook
To set thee here?
It is both he and she;
Your son and daughter.
No.
Yes.
No
I say
No
Yes
By Jupiter
By Juno
They durst not do 't;
They could not
Resolve me
Thou mightst deserve
My lord
I did commend your highness' letters to them
My duty kneeling
From Goneril his mistress salutations;
Deliver'd letters
Commanded me to follow
The leisure of their answer; gave me cold looks:
And meeting here the other messenger
Being the very fellow that of late
Display'd so saucily against your highness
Having more man than wit about me
He raised the house with loud and coward cries.
Your son and daughter found this trespass worth
The shame which here it suffers.
Winter's not gone yet
Fathers that wear rags
Do make their children blind;
But fathers that bear bags
Shall see their children kind.
Fortune
But
for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year.
O
Hysterica passio
With the earl
Follow me not;
Stay here.
Exit
Made you no more offence but what you speak of?
None.
How chance the king comes with so small a train?
And thou hadst been set i' the stocks for that
question
Why
We'll set thee to school to an ant
there's no labouring i' the winter. All that follow
their noses are led by their eyes but blind men; and
there's not a nose among twenty but can smell him
that's stinking. Let go thy hold when a great wheel
runs down a hill
following it: but the great one that goes up the
hill
gives thee better counsel
would have none but knaves follow it
That sir which serves and seeks for gain
The knave turns fool that runs away;
The fool no knave
Where learned you this
Not i' the stocks
Re-enter KING LEAR with GLOUCESTER
Deny to speak with me? They are sick? they are weary?
They have travell'd all the night? Mere fetches;
The images of revolt and flying off.
Fetch me a better answer.
My dear lord
How unremoveable and fix'd he is
In his own course.
Vengeance! plague! death! confusion!
Fiery? what quality? Why
Well
Inform'd them! Dost thou understand me
Ay
The king would speak with Cornwall; the dear father
Would with his daughter speak
Are they inform'd of this? My breath and blood!
Fiery? the fiery duke? Tell the hot duke that--
No
Infirmity doth still neglect all office
Whereto our health is bound; we are not ourselves
When nature
To suffer with the body: I'll forbear;
And am fall'n out with my more headier will
For the sound man. Death on my state! wherefore
Looking on KENT
Should he sit here? This act persuades me
That this remotion of the duke and her
Is practise only. Give me my servant forth.
Go tell the duke and 's wife I'ld speak with them
Till it cry sleep to death.
I would have all well betwixt you.
Exit
O me
Cry to it
when she put 'em i' the paste alive; she knapped 'em

kindness to his horse

KENT is set at liberty

Regan
I have to think so: if thou shouldst not be glad
To KENT
O
Some other time for that. Beloved Regan
Sharp-tooth'd unkindness
Points to his heart
I can scarce speak to thee; thou'lt not believe
With how depraved a quality--O Regan!
I pray you
You less know how to value her desert
Than she to scant her duty.
Say
I cannot think my sister in the least
Would fail her obligation: if
She have restrain'd the riots of your followers
My curses on her!
O
Nature in you stands on the very verge
Of her confine: you should be ruled and led
By some discretion
Better than you yourself. Therefore
Say you have wrong'd her
Ask her forgiveness?
Do you but mark how this becomes the house:
'Dear daughter
Kneeling
Age is unnecessary: on my knees I beg
That you'll vouchsafe me raiment
Good sir
Return you to my sister.
[Rising]  Never
She hath abated me of half my train;
Look'd black upon me; struck me with her tongue
All the stored vengeances of heaven fall
On her ingrateful top! Strike her young bones
Fie
You nimble lightnings
Into her scornful eyes! Infect her beauty
O the blest gods! so will you wish on me
No
Thy tender-hefted nature shall not give
Thee o'er to harshness: her eyes are fierce; but thine
Do comfort and not burn. 'Tis not in thee
To grudge my pleasures
Against my coming in: thou better know'st
The offices of nature
Thy half o' the kingdom hast thou not forgot
Good sir
Who put my man i' the stocks?
Tucket within
What trumpet's that?
I know't
Enter OSWALD
Is your lady come?
This is a slave
Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows.
Out
What means your grace?
Who stock'd my servant? Regan
Thou didst not know on't. Who comes here? O heavens
If you do love old men
Allow obedience
To GONERIL
Art not ashamed to look upon this beard?
O Regan
Why not by the hand
All's not offence that indiscretion finds
And dotage terms so.
O sides
Will you yet hold? How came my man i' the stocks?
I set him there
Deserved much less advancement.
You! did you?
I pray you
If
I am now from home
Which shall be needful for your entertainment.
Return to her
No
To wage against the enmity o' the air;
To be a comrade with the wolf and owl
Necessity's sharp pinch! Return with her?
Why
Our youngest born
To knee his throne
To keep base life afoot. Return with her?
Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter
To this detested groom.
Pointing at OSWALD
At your choice
I prithee
I will not trouble thee
We'll no more meet
But yet thou art my flesh
Or rather a disease that's in my flesh
Let shame come when it will
I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot
Mend when thou canst; be better at thy leisure:
I can be patient; I can stay with Regan
Not altogether so:
I look'd not for you yet
For your fit welcome. Give ear
For those that mingle reason with your passion
Must be content to think you old
But she knows what she does.
Is this well spoken?
I dare avouch it
Is it not well? What should you need of more?
Yea
Speak 'gainst so great a number? How
Why might not you
From those that she calls servants or from mine?
Why not
For now I spy a danger
To bring but five and twenty: to no more
Will I give place or notice.
I gave you all--
And in good time you gave it.
Made you my guardians
But kept a reservation to be follow'd
With such a number. What
With five and twenty
And speak't again
Those wicked creatures yet do look well-favour'd
Stands in some rank of praise.
To GONERIL
I'll go with thee:
Thy fifty yet doth double five and twenty
Hear me
What need you five and twenty
Have a command to tend you?
What need one?
O
Are in the poorest thing superfluous:
Allow not nature more than nature needs
If only to go warm were gorgeous
You heavens
You see me here
If it be you that stir these daughters' hearts
Against their father
To bear it tamely; touch me with noble anger
What they are
The terrors of the earth. You think I'll weep
No
I have full cause of weeping; but this heart
Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws
Exeunt KING LEAR
Storm and tempest
Let us withdraw; 'twill be a storm.
This house is little: the old man and his people
Cannot be well bestow'd.
'Tis his own blame; hath put himself from rest
For his particular
So am I purposed.
Where is my lord of Gloucester?
Follow'd the old man forth: he is return'd.
Re-enter GLOUCESTER
The king is in high rage.
Whither is he going?
He calls to horse; but will I know not whither.
'Tis best to give him way; he leads himself.
My lord
Alack
Do sorely ruffle; for many miles a bout
There's scarce a bush.
O
Must be their schoolmasters. Shut up your doors:
He is attended with a desperate train;
And what they may incense him to
To have his ear abused
Shut up your doors
My Regan counsels well; come out o' the storm.
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. A heath.
Storm still. Enter KENT and a Gentleman
Who's there
One minded like the weather
I know you. Where's the king?
Contending with the fretful element:
Bids the winds blow the earth into the sea
Strives in his little world of man to out-scorn
The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain.
This night
Keep their fur dry
But who is with him?
None but the fool; who labours to out-jest
His heart-struck injuries.
Sir
And dare
With mutual cunning
Who have--as who have not
Throned and set high?--servants
Intelligent of our state; what hath been seen
Against the old kind king; or something deeper
But
Into this scatter'd kingdom; who already
In some of our best ports
To show their open banner. Now to you:
If on my credit you dare build so far
To make your speed to Dover
Some that will thank you
Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow
The king hath cause to plain.
I am a gentleman of blood and breeding;
And
This office to you.
I will talk further with you.
No
For confirmation that I am much more
Than my out-wall
What it contains. If you shall see Cordelia
As fear not but you shall
And she will tell you who your fellow is
That yet you do not know. Fie on this storm!
I will go seek the king.
Give me your hand: have you no more to say?
Few words
That
That way
Holla the other.
Exeunt severally
SCENE II. Another part of the heath. Storm still.
Enter KING LEAR and Fool
Blow
You cataracts and hurricanoes
Till you have drench'd our steeples
You sulphurous and thought-executing fires
Crack nature's moulds
O nuncle
house is better than this rain-water out o' door.
Good nuncle
here's a night pities neither wise man nor fool.
Rumble thy bellyful! Spit
Nor rain
I tax not you
I never gave you kingdom
Your horrible pleasure: here I stand
But yet I call you servile ministers
Your high engender'd battles 'gainst a head
So old and white as this. O! O! 'tis foul!
He that has a house to put's head in has a good
head-piece.
The cod-piece that will house
Before the head has any
So beggars marry many.
The man that makes his toe
What he his heart should make
Shall of a corn cry woe
For there was never yet fair woman but she made
mouths in a glass.
No
I will say nothing.
Enter KENT
Who's there?
Marry
man and a fool.
Alas
Love not such nights as these; the wrathful skies
Gallow the very wanderers of the dark
Remember to have heard: man's nature cannot carry
The affliction nor the fear.
Let the great gods
Thou perjured
That art incestuous: caitiff
Hast practised on man's life: close pent-up guilts
These dreadful summoners grace. I am a man
More sinn'd against than sinning.
Alack
Gracious my lord
Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest:
Repose you there; while I to this hard house--
More harder than the stones whereof 'tis raised;
Which even but now
Their scanted courtesy.
My wits begin to turn.
Come on
I am cold myself. Where is this straw
The art of our necessities is strange
Poor fool and knave
That's sorry yet for thee.
[Singing]
He that has and a little tiny wit--
With hey
Must make content with his fortunes fit
TRUE
Exeunt KING LEAR and KENT
This is a brave night to cool a courtezan.
I'll speak a prophecy ere I go:
When priests are more in word than matter;
When brewers mar their malt with water;
When nobles are their tailors' tutors;
No heretics burn'd
When every case in law is right;
No squire in debt
When slanders do not live in tongues;
Nor cutpurses come not to throngs;
When usurers tell their gold i' the field;
And bawds and whores do churches build;
Then shall the realm of Albion
Come to great confusion:
Then comes the time
This prophecy Merlin shall make; for I live before his time.
Exit
SCENE III. Gloucester's castle.
Enter GLOUCESTER and EDMUND
Alack
dealing. When I desire their leave that I might
pity him
house; charged me
displeasure
him
Most savage and unnatural!
Go to; say you nothing. There's a division betwixt
the dukes; and a worse matter than that: I have
received a letter this night; 'tis dangerous to be
spoken; I have locked the letter in my closet:
these injuries the king now bears will be revenged
home; there's part of a power already footed: we
must incline to the king. I will seek him
privily relieve him: go you and maintain talk with
the duke
if he ask for me. I am ill
Though I die for it
some strange thing toward
Exit
This courtesy
Instantly know; and of that letter too:
This seems a fair deserving
That which my father loses; no less than all:
The younger rises when the old doth fall.
Exit
SCENE IV. The heath. Before a hovel.
Enter KING LEAR
Here is the place
The tyranny of the open night's too rough
For nature to endure.
Storm still
Let me alone.
Good my lord
Wilt break my heart?
I had rather break mine own. Good my lord
Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm
Invades us to the skin: so 'tis to thee;
But where the greater malady is fix'd
But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea
mind's free
Doth from my senses take all feeling else
Save what beats there. Filial ingratitude!
Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
For lifting food to't? But I will punish home:
No
To shut me out! Pour on; I will endure.
In such a night as this! O Regan
Your old kind father
O
No more of that.
Good my lord
Prithee
This tempest will not give me leave to ponder
On things would hurt me more. But I'll go in.
To the Fool
In
Nay

Poor naked wretches
From seasons such as these? O
Too little care of this! Take physic
Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel

The Fool runs out from the hovel
Come not in here
Help me

A spirit
What art thou that dost grumble there i' the straw?
Come forth.
Enter EDGAR disguised as a mad man
Away! the foul fiend follows me!
Through the sharp hawthorn blows the cold wind.
Hum! go to thy cold bed
Hast thou given all to thy two daughters?
And art thou come to this?
Who gives any thing to poor Tom? whom the foul
fiend hath led through fire and through flame

in his pew; set ratsbane by his porridge; made film
proud of heart

What
Couldst thou save nothing? Didst thou give them all?
Nay
Now

He hath no daughters
Death
To such a lowness but his unkind daughters.
Is it the fashion
Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?
Judicious punishment! 'twas this flesh begot
Those pelican daughters.
Pillicock sat on Pillicock-hill:
Halloo
This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen.
Take heed o' the foul fiend: obey thy parents;
keep thy word justly; swear not; commit not with
man's sworn spouse; set not thy sweet heart on proud
array. Tom's a-cold.
What hast thou been?
A serving-man
my hair; wore gloves in my cap; served the lust of

What is the cause of thunder?

SCENE VI. A chamber in a farmhouse adjoining the castle.
Enter GLOUCESTER
Here is better than the open air; take it
thankfully. I will piece out the comfort with what
addition I can: I will not be long from you.
All the power of his wits have given way to his
impatience: the gods reward your kindness!
Exit GLOUCESTER
Frateretto calls me; and tells me
Nero is an angler in the lake of darkness.
Pray

A king
No

The foul fiend bites my back.

When we our betters see bearing our woes
Who alone suffers suffers most i' the mind
But then the mind much sufferance doth o'er skip
How light and portable my pain seems now
Mark the high noises; and thyself bewray
What will hap more to-night
Lurk
