SCENE VII. Gloucester's castle.
Enter CORNWALL
Post speedily to my lord your husband; show him
this letter: the army of France is landed. Seek
out the villain Gloucester.
Exeunt some of the Servants
Hang him instantly.
Pluck out his eyes.
Leave him to my displeasure. Edmund
sister company: the revenges we are bound to take
upon your traitorous father are not fit for your
beholding. Advise the duke
a most festinate preparation: we are bound to the
like. Our posts shall be swift and intelligent
betwixt us. Farewell
lord of Gloucester.
Enter OSWALD
How now! where's the king?
My lord of Gloucester hath convey'd him hence:
Some five or six and thirty of his knights
Who
To have well-armed friends.
Get horses for your mistress.
Farewell
Edmund
Exeunt GONERIL
Go seek the traitor Gloucester
Exeunt other Servants
Though well we may not pass upon his life
Without the form of justice
Shall do a courtesy to our wrath
May blame
Enter GLOUCESTER
Ingrateful fox! 'tis he.
Bind fast his corky arms.
What mean your graces? Good my friends
You are my guests: do me no foul play
Bind him
Servants bind him
Hard
Unmerciful lady as you are
To this chair bind him. Villain
REGAN plucks his beard
By the kind gods
To pluck me by the beard.
So white
Naughty lady
With robbers' hands my hospitable favours
You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?
Come
Be simple answerer
And what confederacy have you with the traitors
Late footed in the kingdom?
To whose hands have you sent the lunatic king? Speak.
I have a letter guessingly set down
Cunning.
And false.
Where hast thou sent the king?
To Dover.
Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charged at peril--
Wherefore to Dover? Let him first answer that.
I am tied to the stake
Wherefore to Dover
Because I would not see thy cruel nails
Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister
In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.
The sea
In hell-black night endured
Yet
If wolves had at thy gate howl'd that stern time
All cruels else subscribed: but I shall see
The winged vengeance overtake such children.
See't shalt thou never. Fellows
Upon these eyes of thine I'll set my foot.
He that will think to live till he be old
One side will mock another; the other too.
If you see vengeance
Hold your hand
I have served you ever since I was a child;
But better service have I never done you
Than now to bid you hold.
How now
If you did wear a beard upon your chin
My villain!
They draw and fight
Nay
Give me thy sword. A peasant stand up thus!
Takes a sword
O
To see some mischief on him. O!
Dies
Lest it see more
Where is thy lustre now?
All dark and comfortless. Where's my son Edmund?
Edmund
Out
Thou call'st on him that hates thee: it was he
That made the overture of thy treasons to us;
Who is too good to pity thee.
O my follies! then Edgar was abused.
Kind gods
Go thrust him out at gates
His way to Dover.
Exit one with GLOUCESTER
How is't
I have received a hurt: follow me
Turn out that eyeless villain; throw this slave
Upon the dunghill. Regan
Untimely comes this hurt: give me your arm.
Exit CORNWALL
I'll never care what wickedness I do
If she live long
Let's follow the old earl
To lead him where he would: his roguish madness
Allows itself to any thing.
Go thou: I'll fetch some flax and whites of eggs
To apply to his bleeding face. Now
Exeunt severally
ACT IV
SCENE I. The heath.
Enter EDGAR
Yet better thus
The lamentable change is from the best;
The worst returns to laughter. Welcome
The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst
Owes nothing to thy blasts. But who comes here?
Enter GLOUCESTER
My father
But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee
O
your father's tenant
Away
Thy comforts can do me no good at all;
Thee they may hurt.
Alack
I have no way
I stumbled when I saw: full oft 'tis seen
Prove our commodities. O dear son Edgar
Might I but live to see thee in my touch
How now! Who's there?
[Aside]  O gods! Who is't can say 'I am at
the worst'?
I am worse than e'er I was.
'Tis poor mad Tom.
[Aside]  And worse I may be yet: the worst is not
So long as we can say  'This is the worst.'
Fellow
Is it a beggar-man?
Madman and beggar too.
He has some reason
I' the last night's storm I such a fellow saw;
Which made me think a man a worm: my son
Came then into my mind; and yet my mind
Was then scarce friends with him: I have heard
more since.
As flies to wanton boys
They kill us for their sport.
"[Aside]	How should this be?"
Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow
Is that the naked fellow?
Ay
Then
And bring some covering for this naked soul
Alack
'Tis the times' plague
Do as I bid thee
Above the rest
I'll bring him the best 'parel that I have
Exit
Sirrah
Poor Tom's a-cold.
Aside
I cannot daub it further.
Come hither
[Aside]  And yet I must.--Bless thy sweet eyes
Know'st thou the way to Dover?
Both stile and gate
Tom hath been scared out of his good wits: bless
thee
fiends have been in poor Tom at once; of lust
Obidicut; Hobbididence
stealing; Modo
mopping and mowing
and waiting-women. So
Here
Have humbled to all strokes: that I am wretched
Makes thee the happier: heavens
Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man
Because he doth not feel
So distribution should undo excess
Ay
There is a cliff
Looks fearfully in the confined deep:
Bring me but to the very brim of it
With something rich about me: from that place
I shall no leading need.
Give me thy arm:
Poor Tom shall lead thee.
Exeunt
SCENE II. Before ALBANY's palace.
Enter GONERIL and EDMUND
Welcome
Not met us on the way.
Enter OSWALD
Now
Madam
I told him of the army that was landed;
He smiled at it: I told him you were coming:
His answer was 'The worse:' of Gloucester's treachery
What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him;
What like
[To EDMUND]  Then shall you go no further.
It is the cowish terror of his spirit
Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way
May prove effects. Back
Hasten his musters and conduct his powers:
I must change arms at home
Into my husband's hands. This trusty servant
Shall pass between us: ere long you are like to hear
Giving a favour
Decline your head: this kiss
Conceive
Yours in the ranks of death.
My most dear Gloucester!
Exit EDMUND
O
To thee a woman's services are due:
My fool usurps my body.
Madam
Exit
Enter ALBANY
I have been worth the whistle.
O Goneril!
You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blows in your face. I fear your disposition:
That nature
She that herself will sliver and disbranch
From her material sap
And come to deadly use.
No more; the text is foolish.
Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile:
Filths savour but themselves. What have you done?
Tigers
A father
Could my good brother suffer you to do it?
A man
If that the heavens do not their visible spirits
Send quickly down to tame these vile offences
Milk-liver'd man!
That bear'st a cheek for blows
Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning
Thine honour from thy suffering; that not know'st
Fools do those villains pity who are punish'd
Ere they have done their mischief. Where's thy drum?
France spreads his banners in our noiseless land;
With plumed helm thy slayer begins threats;
Whiles thou
'Alack
See thyself
Proper deformity seems not in the fiend
So horrid as in woman.
O vain fool!
Thou changed and self-cover'd thing
To let these hands obey my blood
Thy flesh and bones: howe'er thou art a fiend
Marry
Enter a Messenger
What news?
O
Slain by his servant
The other eye of Gloucester.
Gloucester's eye!
A servant that he bred
To his great master; who
But not without that harmful stroke
Hath pluck'd him after.
This shows you are above
So speedily can venge! But
Lost he his other eye?
Both
This letter
'Tis from your sister.
[Aside]              One way I like this well;
But being widow
Upon my hateful life: another way
Exit
Where was his son when they did take his eyes?
Come with my lady hither.
He is not here.
No
Knows he the wickedness?
Ay
And quit the house on purpose
Might have the freer course.
Gloucester
To thank thee for the love thou show'dst the king
Tell me what more thou know'st.
Exeunt
SCENE III. The French camp near Dover.
Enter KENT and a Gentleman
Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back
know you the reason?
Something he left imperfect in the
state
of; which imports to the kingdom so much
fear and danger
most required and necessary.
Who hath he left behind him general?
The Marshal of France
Did your letters pierce the queen to any
demonstration of grief?
Ay
And now and then an ample tear trill'd down
Her delicate cheek: it seem'd she was a queen
Over her passion; who
O
Not to a rage: patience and sorrow strove
Who should express her goodliest. You have seen
Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears
Were like a better way: those happy smilets
What guests were in her eyes; which parted thence
Made she no verbal question?
'Faith
Pantingly forth
Cried 'Sisters! sisters! Shame of ladies! sisters!
Kent! father! sisters! What
Let pity not be believed!' There she shook
The holy water from her heavenly eyes
To deal with grief alone.
It is the stars
Else one self mate and mate could not beget
Such different issues. You spoke not with her since?
No.
Was this before the king return'd?
No
Well
Who sometime
What we are come about
Will yield to see his daughter.
Why
A sovereign shame so elbows him: his own unkindness
To foreign casualties
To his dog-hearted daughters
His mind so venomously
Detains him from Cordelia.
Alack
Of Albany's and Cornwall's powers you heard not?
'Tis so
Well
Will in concealment wrap me up awhile;
When I am known aright
Lending me this acquaintance. I pray you
Along with me.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The same. A tent.
Enter
Alack
As mad as the vex'd sea; singing aloud;
Crown'd with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds
In our sustaining corn. A century send forth;
Search every acre in the high-grown field
Exit an Officer
What can man's wisdom
In the restoring his bereaved sense?
He that helps him take all my outward worth.
There is means
Our foster-nurse of nature is repose
Will close the eye of anguish.
All blest secrets
In the good man's distress! Seek
Lest his ungovern'd rage dissolve the life
That wants the means to lead it.
Enter a Messenger
News
The British powers are marching hitherward.
'Tis known before; our preparation stands
In expectation of them. O dear father
Therefore great France
My mourning and important tears hath pitied.
No blown ambition doth our arms incite
Soon may I hear and see him!
Exeunt
SCENE V. Gloucester's castle.
Enter REGAN and OSWALD
But are my brother's powers set forth?
Ay
Himself in person there?
Madam
Your sister is the better soldier.
Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home?
No
What might import my sister's letter to him?
I know not
'Faith
It was great ignorance
All hearts against us: Edmund
His nighted life: moreover
The strength o' the enemy.
I must needs after him
Our troops set forth to-morrow: stay with us;
The ways are dangerous.
I may not
My lady charged my duty in this business.
Why should she write to Edmund? Might not you
Transport her purposes by word? Belike
Madam
I know your lady does not love her husband;
I am sure of that: and at her late being here
She gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks
To noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosom.
I
I speak in understanding; you are; I know't:
Therefore I do advise you
My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talk'd;
And more convenient is he for my hand
Than for your lady's: you may gather more.
If you do find him
And when your mistress hears thus much from you
So
If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor
Would I could meet him
What party I do follow.
Fare thee well.
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Fields near Dover.
Enter GLOUCESTER
When shall we come to the top of that same hill?
You do climb up it now: look
Methinks the ground is even.
Horrible steep.
Hark
No
Why
By your eyes' anguish.
So may it be
Methinks thy voice is alter'd; and thou speak'st
In better phrase and matter than thou didst.
You're much deceived: in nothing am I changed
But in my garments.
Methinks you're better spoken.
Come on
And dizzy 'tis
The crows and choughs that wing the midway air
Show scarce so gross as beetles: half way down
Hangs one that gathers samphire
Methinks he seems no bigger than his head:
The fishermen
Almost too small for sight: the murmuring surge
Lest my brain turn
Topple down headlong.
Set me where you stand.
Give me your hand: you are now within a foot
Of the extreme verge: for all beneath the moon
Would I not leap upright.
Let go my hand.
Here
Well worth a poor man's taking: fairies and gods
Prosper it with thee! Go thou farther off;
Bid me farewell
Now fare you well
With all my heart.
Why I do trifle thus with his despair
Is done to cure it.
[Kneeling]  O you mighty gods!
This world I do renounce
If I could bear it longer
To quarrel with your great opposeless wills
Burn itself out. If Edgar live
Now
He falls forward
Gone
And yet I know not how conceit may rob
The treasury of life
Yields to the theft: had he been where he thought
Ho
Thus might he pass indeed: yet he revives.
What are you
Away
Hadst thou been aught but gossamer
Hast heavy substance; bleed'st not; speak'st; art sound.
Ten masts at each make not the altitude
Which thou hast perpendicularly fell:
Thy life's a miracle. Speak yet again.
But have I fall'n
From the dread summit of this chalky bourn.
Look up a-height; the shrill-gorged lark so far
Cannot be seen or heard: do but look up.
Alack
Is wretchedness deprived that benefit
Give me your arm:
Up: so. How is 't? Feel you your legs? You stand.
Too well
This is above all strangeness.
Upon the crown o' the cliff
Which parted from you?
A poor unfortunate beggar.
As I stood here below
Were two full moons; he had a thousand noses
It was some fiend; therefore
Of men's impossibilities
I do remember now: henceforth I'll bear
Affliction till it do cry out itself
'Enough
'The fiend
Bear free and patient thoughts. But who comes here?
Enter KING LEAR
The safer sense will ne'er accommodate
His master thus.
No
king himself.
O thou side-piercing sight!
Nature's above art in that respect. There's your
press-money. That fellow handles his bow like a
crow-keeper: draw me a clothier's yard. Look
cheese will do 't. There's my gauntlet; I'll prove
it on a giant. Bring up the brown bills. O
flown
Give the word.
Sweet marjoram.
Pass.
I know that voice.
Ha! Goneril
me like a dog; and told me I had white hairs in my
beard ere the black ones were there. To say 'ay'
and 'no' to every thing that I said!--'Ay' and 'no'
too was no good divinity. When the rain came to
wet me once
the thunder would not peace at my bidding; there I
found 'em
not men o' their words: they told me I was every
thing; 'tis a lie
The trick of that voice I do well remember:
Is 't not the king?
Ay
When I do stare
I pardon that man's life. What was thy cause? Adultery?
Thou shalt not die: die for adultery! No:
The wren goes to 't
Does lecher in my sight.
Let copulation thrive; for Gloucester's bastard son
Was kinder to his father than my daughters
Got 'tween the lawful sheets.
To 't
Behold yond simpering dame
That minces virtue
To hear of pleasure's name;
The fitchew
With a more riotous appetite.
Down from the waist they are Centaurs
But to the girdle do the gods inherit
There's hell
sulphurous pit
there's money for thee.
O
Let me wipe it first; it smells of mortality.
O ruin'd piece of nature! This great world
Shall so wear out to nought. Dost thou know me?
I remember thine eyes well enough. Dost thou squiny
at me? No
love. Read thou this challenge; mark but the
penning of it.
Were all the letters suns
I would not take this from report; it is
Read.
What
O
head
a heavy case
this world goes.
I see it feelingly.
What
with no eyes. Look with thine ears: see how yond
justice rails upon yond simple thief. Hark
thine ear: change places; and
is the justice
a farmer's dog bark at a beggar?
Ay
And the creature run from the cur? There thou
mightst behold the great image of authority: a
dog's obeyed in office.
Thou rascal beadle
Why dost thou lash that whore? Strip thine own back;
Thou hotly lust'st to use her in that kind
For which thou whipp'st her. The usurer hangs the cozener.
Through tatter'd clothes small vices do appear;
Robes and furr'd gowns hide all. Plate sin with gold
Arm it in rags
None does offend
Take that of me
To seal the accuser's lips. Get thee glass eyes;
And like a scurvy politician
To see the things thou dost not. Now
Pull off my boots: harder
O
If thou wilt weep my fortunes
I know thee well enough; thy name is Gloucester:
Thou must be patient; we came crying hither:
Thou know'st
Alack
When we are born
To this great stage of fools: this a good block;
It were a delicate stratagem
A troop of horse with felt: I'll put 't in proof;
And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law
Enter a Gentleman
O
No rescue? What
The natural fool of fortune. Use me well;
You shall have ransom. Let me have surgeons;
I am cut to the brains.
You shall have any thing.
No seconds? all myself?
Why
Good sir
I will die bravely
I will be jovial: come
You are a royal one
Then there's life in't. Nay
shall get it with running. Sa
Exit running; Attendants follow
A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch
Which twain have brought her to.
Hail
Sir
Do you hear aught
Most sure and vulgar: every one hears that
But
Near and on speedy foot; the main descry
Stands on the hourly thought.
I thank you
Though that the queen on special cause is here
I thank you
Exit Gentleman
You ever-gentle gods
Let not my worser spirit tempt me again
To die before you please!
Well pray you
Now
A most poor man
Who
Hearty thanks:
The bounty and the benison of heaven
To boot
Enter OSWALD
A proclaim'd prize! Most happy!
That eyeless head of thine was first framed flesh
To raise my fortunes. Thou old unhappy traitor
That must destroy thee.
Now let thy friendly hand
Put strength enough to't.
EDGAR interposes
Wherefore
Lest that the infection of his fortune take
Like hold on thee. Let go his arm.
Ch'ill not let go
Let go
Good gentleman
pass. An chud ha' bin zwaggered out of my life

the harder: ch'ill be plain with you.
Out

your foins.
They fight

To Edmund earl of Gloucester; seek him out

Dies
I know thee well: a serviceable villain;
As duteous to the vices of thy mistress
As badness would desire.
What
Sit you down
Let's see these pockets: the letters that he speaks of
May be my friends. He's dead; I am only sorry
He had no other death's-man. Let us see:

Their papers
Reads
'Let our reciprocal vows be remembered. You have
many opportunities to cut him off: if your will
want not
There is nothing done
then am I the prisoner
the loathed warmth whereof deliver me

'Your--wife
'Affectionate servant
O undistinguish'd space of woman's will!
A plot upon her virtuous husband's life;
And the exchange my brother! Here
Of murderous lechers: and in the mature time
With this ungracious paper strike the sight
Of the death practised duke: for him 'tis well
That of thy death and business I can tell.
The king is mad: how stiff is my vile sense
Of my huge sorrows! Better I were distract:
So should my thoughts be sever'd from my griefs
The knowledge of themselves.
Give me your hand:
Drum afar off
Far off
Come
Exeunt
SCENE VII. A tent in the French camp. LEAR on a bed asleep
Enter CORDELIA
O thou good Kent
To be acknowledged
All my reports go with the modest truth;
Nor more nor clipp'd
Be better suited:
These weeds are memories of those worser hours:
I prithee
Pardon me
Yet to be known shortens my made intent:
My boon I make it
Till time and I think meet.
Then be't so
To the Doctor
How does the king?
Madam
O you kind gods
The untuned and jarring senses
Of this child-changed father!
So please your majesty
That we may wake the king: he hath slept long.
Be govern'd by your knowledge
I' the sway of your own will. Is he array'd?
Ay
We put fresh garments on him.
Be by
I doubt not of his temperance.
Very well.
Please you
O my dear father! Restoration hang
Thy medicine on my lips; and let this kiss
Repair those violent harms that my two sisters
Have in thy reverence made!
Kind and dear princess!
Had you not been their father
Had challenged pity of them. Was this a face
To be opposed against the warring winds?
To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder?
In the most terrible and nimble stroke
Of quick
With this thin helm? Mine enemy's dog
Against my fire; and wast thou fain
'Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once
Had not concluded all. He wakes; speak to him.
Madam
How does my royal lord? How fares your majesty?
You do me wrong to take me out o' the grave:
Thou art a soul in bliss; but I am bound
Upon a wheel of fire
Do scald like moulten lead.
Sir
You are a spirit
Still
He's scarce awake: let him alone awhile.
Where have I been? Where am I? Fair daylight?
I am mightily abused. I should e'en die with pity
I will not swear these are my hands: let's see;
I feel this pin prick. Would I were assured
Of my condition!
O
No
Pray
I am a very foolish fond old man
And
Methinks I should know you
Yet I am doubtful for I am mainly ignorant
What place this is; and all the skill I have
Remembers not these garments; nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me;
For
To be my child Cordelia.
And so I am
Be your tears wet? yes
If you have poison for me
I know you do not love me; for your sisters
Have
You have some cause
No cause
Am I in France?
In your own kingdom
Do not abuse me.
Be comforted
To make him even o'er the time he has lost.
Desire him to go in; trouble him no more
Till further settling.
Will't please your highness walk?
You must bear with me:
Pray you now
Exeunt all but KENT and Gentleman
Holds it true
Most certain
Who is conductor of his people?
As 'tis said
They say Edgar
of Kent in Germany.
Report is changeable. 'Tis time to look about; the
powers of the kingdom approach apace.
The arbitrement is like to be bloody. Fare you
well
Exit
My point and period will be throughly wrought
Exit
ACT V
SCENE I. The British camp
Enter
Know of the duke if his last purpose hold
To change the course: he's full of alteration
And self-reproving: bring his constant pleasure.
To a Gentleman
Our sister's man is certainly miscarried.
'Tis to be doubted
Now
Tell me--but truly--but then speak the truth
In honour'd love.
But have you never found my brother's way
To the forfended place?
That thought abuses you.
I am doubtful that you have been conjunct
And bosom'd with her
No
I never shall endure her: dear my lord
Fear me not:
She and the duke her husband!
Enter
[Aside]  I had rather lose the battle than that sister
Should loosen him and me.
Our very loving sister
Sir
Forced to cry out. Where I could not be honest
Sir
Why is this reason'd?
Combine together 'gainst the enemy;
For these domestic and particular broils
Are not the question here.
Let's then determine
With the ancient of war on our proceedings.
I shall attend you presently at your tent.
Sister
No.
'Tis most convenient; pray you
[Aside]  O
As they are going out
If e'er your grace had speech with man so poor
I'll overtake you. Speak.
Exeunt all but ALBANY and EDGAR
Before you fight the battle
If you have victory
For him that brought it: wretched though I seem
What is avouched there. If you miscarry
Stay till I have read the letter.
I was forbid it.
When time shall serve
Why
Exit EDGAR
Re-enter EDMUND
The enemy's in view; draw up your powers.
Here is the guess of their true strength and forces
By diligent discovery; but your haste
Is now urged on you.
We will greet the time.
Exit
To both these sisters have I sworn my love;
Each jealous of the other
Are of the adder. Which of them shall I take?
Both? one? or neither? Neither can be enjoy'd
Exasperates
And hardly shall I carry out my side
His countenance for the battle; which being done
His speedy taking off. As for the mercy
Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia
Stands on me to defend
Exit
SCENE II. A field between the two camps.
Alarum within. Enter
Enter EDGAR and GLOUCESTER
Here
For your good host; pray that the right may thrive:
If ever I return to you again
Grace go with you
Exit EDGAR
Alarum and retreat within. Re-enter EDGAR
Away
King Lear hath lost
Give me thy hand; come on.
No farther
What
Their going hence
Ripeness is all: come on.
And that's true too.
Exeunt
SCENE III. The British camp near Dover.
Enter
Some officers take them away: good guard
That are to censure them.
We are not the first
Who
For thee
Myself could else out-frown false fortune's frown.
Shall we not see these daughters and these sisters?
No
We two alone will sing like birds i' the cage:
When thou dost ask me blessing
At gilded butterflies
Talk of court news; and we'll talk with them too
And take upon's the mystery of things
Take them away.
Upon such sacrifices
He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven
The good-years shall devour them
first. Come.
Exeunt KING LEAR and CORDELIA
Come hither
Take thou this note;
Giving a paper
go follow them to prison:
One step I have advanced thee; if thou dost
As this instructs thee
To noble fortunes: know thou this
Are as the time is: to be tender-minded
Does not become a sword: thy great employment
Will not bear question; either say thou'lt do 't
I'll do 't
About it; and write happy when thou hast done.
Mark
As I have set it down.
I cannot draw a cart
If it be man's work
Exit
Flourish. Enter ALBANY
Sir
That were the opposites of this day's strife:
We do require them of you
As we shall find their merits and our safety
May equally determine.
Sir
To send the old and miserable king
To some retention and appointed guard;
Whose age has charms in it
Which do command them. With him I sent the queen;
My reason all the same; and they are ready
To-morrow
Where you shall hold your session. At this time
We sweat and bleed: the friend hath lost his friend;
And the best quarrels
By those that feel their sharpness:
The question of Cordelia and her father
Requires a fitter place.
Sir
That's as we list to grace him.
Methinks our pleasure might have been demanded
Bore the commission of my place and person;
The which immediacy may well stand up
Not so hot:
In his own grace he doth exalt himself
In my rights
That were the most
Jesters do oft prove prophets.
Holla
That eye that told you so look'd but a-squint.
Lady
From a full-flowing stomach. General
Dispose of them
Witness the world
My lord and master.
Mean you to enjoy him?
The let-alone lies not in your good will.
Nor in thine
Half-blooded fellow
[To EDMUND]  Let the drum strike
Stay yet; hear reason. Edmund
On capital treason; and
Pointing to Goneril
For your claim
'Tis she is sub-contracted to this lord
If you will marry
An interlude!
Thou art arm'd
If none appear to prove upon thy head
Thy heinous
Throwing down a glove
I'll prove it on thy heart
Than I have here proclaim'd thee.
Sick

There's my exchange:
Throwing down a glove
what in the world he is
That names me traitor
Call by thy trumpet: he that dares approach
My truth and honour firmly.
A herald
A herald

Took their discharge.
My sickness grows upon me.

Enter EDGAR
Ask him his purposes
Upon this call o' the trumpet.
What are you?
Your name
This present summons?
Know
By treason's tooth bare-gnawn and canker-bit:
Yet am I noble as the adversary
I come to cope.
Which is that adversary?
What's he that speaks for Edmund Earl of Gloucester?
Himself: what say'st thou to him?
Draw thy sword
Behold
False to thy gods
Conspirant 'gainst this high-illustrious prince;
And
To the descent and dust below thy foot
This sword
To prove upon thy heart
In wisdom I should ask thy name;
But
By rule of knighthood
Back do I toss these treasons to thy head;
With the hell-hated lie o'erwhelm thy heart;
Which
Alarums. They fight. EDMUND falls
Save him
This is practise
By the law of arms thou wast not bound to answer
An unknown opposite; thou art not vanquish'd
Shut your mouth
Thou worse than any name
No tearing
Gives the letter to EDMUND
Say
Who can arraign me for't.
Most monstrous! oh!
Know'st thou this paper?
Ask me not what I know.
Exit
Go after her: she's desperate; govern her.
What you have charged me with
And more
'Tis past
That hast this fortune on me? If thou'rt noble
Let's exchange charity.
I am no less in blood than thou art
If more
My name is Edgar
The gods are just
Make instruments to plague us:
The dark and vicious place where thee he got
Cost him his eyes.
Thou hast spoken right
The wheel is come full circle: I am here.
Methought thy very gait did prophesy
A royal nobleness: I must embrace thee:
Let sorrow split my heart
Did hate thee or thy father!
Worthy prince
Where have you hid yourself?
How have you known the miseries of your father?
By nursing them
And when 'tis told
The bloody proclamation to escape
That we the pain of death would hourly die
Rather than die at once!--taught me to shift
Into a madman's rags; to assume a semblance
That very dogs disdain'd: and in this habit
Met I my father with his bleeding rings
Never
Not sure
Told him my pilgrimage: but his flaw'd heart
'Twixt two extremes of passion
This speech of yours hath moved me
You look as you had something more to say.
If there be more
For I am almost ready to dissolve
This would have seem'd a period
To such as love not sorrow; but another
Whilst I was big in clamour came there in a man
Who 'twas that so endured
He fastened on my neck
As he'ld burst heaven; threw him on my father;
Told the most piteous tale of Lear and him
That ever ear received: which in recounting
His grief grew puissant and the strings of life
Began to crack: twice then the trumpets sounded
But who was this?
Kent
Follow'd his enemy king
Improper for a slave.
Enter a Gentleman
Help
What kind of help?
Speak
What means that bloody knife?
'Tis hot
It came even from the heart of--O
Who dead? speak
Your lady
By her is poisoned; she hath confess'd it.
I was contracted to them both: all three
Now marry in an instant.
Here comes Kent.
Produce their bodies
This judgment of the heavens
Exit Gentleman
Enter KENT
O
The time will not allow the compliment
Which very manners urges.
I am come
To bid my king and master aye good night:
Is he not here?
Great thing of us forgot!
Speak
See'st thou this object
The bodies of GONERIL and REGAN are brought in
Alack
Yet Edmund was beloved:
The one the other poison'd for my sake
Even so. Cover their faces.
I pant for life: some good I mean to do
Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia:
Nay
Run
To who
Thy token of reprieve.
Well thought on: take my sword
Haste thee
Exit EDGAR
He hath commission from thy wife and me
To hang Cordelia in the prison
To lay the blame upon her own despair
The gods defend her! Bear him hence awhile.
EDMUND is borne off
Re-enter KING LEAR
Howl
Had I your tongues and eyes
That heaven's vault should crack. She's gone for ever!
I know when one is dead
She's dead as earth. Lend me a looking-glass;
If that her breath will mist or stain the stone
Is this the promised end
Or image of that horror?
Fall
This feather stirs; she lives! if it be so
That ever I have felt.
[Kneeling]  O my good master!
Prithee
'Tis noble Kent
A plague upon you
I might have saved her; now she's gone for ever!
Cordelia
What is't thou say'st? Her voice was ever soft
I kill'd the slave that was a-hanging thee.
'Tis true
Did I not
I have seen the day
I would have made them skip: I am old now
Mine eyes are not o' the best: I'll tell you straight.
If fortune brag of two she loved and hated
This is a dull sight. Are you not Kent?
The same
He's a good fellow
He'll strike
No
I'll see that straight.
That
You are welcome hither.
Nor no man else: all's cheerless
Your eldest daughters have fordone them selves
Ay
He knows not what he says: and vain it is
That we present us to him.
Very bootless.
Enter a Captain
Edmund is dead
That's but a trifle here.
You lords and noble friends
What comfort to this great decay may come
Shall be applied: for us we will resign
To EDGAR and KENT
you
With boot
Have more than merited. All friends shall taste
The wages of their virtue
The cup of their deservings. O
And my poor fool is hang'd! No
Why should a dog
Pray you
Do you see this? Look on her
Dies
He faints! My lord
Break
Look up
Vex not his ghost: O
That would upon the rack of this tough world
Stretch him out longer.
He is gone
The wonder is
He but usurp'd his life.
Bear them from hence. Our present business
Is general woe.
To KENT and EDGAR
Friends of my soul
Rule in this realm
I have a journey
My master calls me
The weight of this sad time we must obey;
Speak what we feel
The oldest hath borne most: we that are young
Shall never see so much
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. The king of Navarre's park.
Enter FERDINAND king of Navarre
Let fame
And then grace us in the disgrace of death;
When
That honour which shall bate his scythe's keen edge
And make us heirs of all eternity.
Therefore
And the huge army of the world's desires
Our late edict shall strongly stand in force:
Navarre shall be the wonder of the world;
Our court shall be a little Academe
You three
My fellow-scholars
That are recorded in this schedule here:
Your oaths are pass'd; and now subscribe your names
That violates the smallest branch herein:
If you are arm'd to do as sworn to do
I am resolved; 'tis but a three years' fast:
The mind shall banquet
Fat paunches have lean pates
Make rich the ribs
My loving lord
The grosser manner of these world's delights
He throws upon the gross world's baser slaves:
To love
With all these living in philosophy.
I can but say their protestation over;
So much
But there are other strict observances;
As
And one day in a week to touch no food
And but one meal on every day beside
And then
When I was wont to think no harm all night
And make a dark night too of half the day--
Which I hope well is not enrolled there:
O
Your oath is pass'd to pass away from these.
Let me say no
I only swore to study with your grace
And stay here in your court for three years' space.
You swore to that
By yea and nay
What is the end of study? let me know.
Why
Things hid and barr'd
Ay
Come on
As thus
Or study where to meet some mistress fine
Or
If study's gain be thus and this be so
Swear me to this
These be the stops that hinder study quite
And train our intellects to vain delight.
Why
As
To seek the light of truth; while truth the while
Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his look:
Light seeking light doth light of light beguile:
So
Study me how to please the eye indeed
By fixing it upon a fairer eye
And give him light that it was blinded by.
Study is like the heaven's glorious sun
That will not be deep-search'd with saucy looks:
Small have continual plodders ever won
Save base authority from others' books
These earthly godfathers of heaven's lights
That give a name to every fixed star
Have no more profit of their shining nights
Than those that walk and wot not what they are.
Too much to know is to know nought but fame;
And every godfather can give a name.
How well he's read
Proceeded well
He weeds the corn and still lets grow the weeding.
The spring is near when green geese are a-breeding.
How follows that?
Fit in his place and time.
In reason nothing.
Something then in rhyme.
Biron is like an envious sneaping frost
Well
Before the birds have any cause to sing?
Why should I joy in any abortive birth?
At Christmas I no more desire a rose
Than wish a snow in May's new-fangled mirth;
But like of each thing that in season grows.
So you
Well
No
And though I have for barbarism spoke more
Than for that angel knowledge you can say
And bide the penance of each three years' day.
Give me the paper; let me read the same;
And to the strict'st decrees I'll write my name.
How well this yielding rescues thee from shame!
[Reads]  'Item
mile of my court:' Hath this been proclaimed?
Four days ago.
Let's see the penalty.
Reads
'On pain of losing her tongue.' Who devised this penalty?
Marry
Sweet lord
To fright them hence with that dread penalty.
A dangerous law against gentility!
Reads
'Item
within the term of three years
public shame as the rest of the court can possibly devise.'
This article
For well you know here comes in embassy
The French king's daughter with yourself to speak--
A maid of grace and complete majesty--
About surrender up of Aquitaine
To her decrepit
Therefore this article is made in vain
What say you
So study evermore is overshot:
While it doth study to have what it would
It doth forget to do the thing it should
We must of force dispense with this decree;
She must lie here on mere necessity.
Necessity will make us all forsworn
Three thousand times within this three years' space;
For every man with his affects is born
If I break faith
I am forsworn on 'mere necessity.'
So to the laws at large I write my name:
Subscribes
And he that breaks them in the least degree
Stands in attainder of eternal shame:
Suggestions are to other as to me;
But I believe
But is there no quick recreation granted?
Ay
With a refined traveller of Spain;
A man in all the world's new fashion planted
One whom the music of his own vain tongue
Doth ravish like enchanting harmony;
A man of complements
Have chose as umpire of their mutiny:
This child of fancy
In high-born words the worth of many a knight
From tawny Spain lost in the world's debate.
How you delight
But
And I will use him for my minstrelsy.
Armado is a most illustrious wight
Costard the swain and he shall be our sport;
And so to study
Enter DULL with a letter
Which is the duke's own person?
This
I myself reprehend his own person
grace's tharborough: but I would see his own person
in flesh and blood.
This is he.
Signior Arme--Arme--commends you. There's villany
abroad: this letter will tell you more.
Sir
A letter from the magnificent Armado.
How low soever the matter
A high hope for a low heaven: God grant us patience!
To hear? or forbear laughing?
To hear meekly
forbear both.
Well
climb in the merriness.
The matter is to me
The manner of it is
In what manner?
In manner and form following
I was seen with her in the manor-house
her upon the form
park; which
following. Now
manner of a man to speak to a woman: for the form
in some form.
For the following
As it shall follow in my correction: and God defend
the right!
Will you hear this letter with attention?
As we would hear an oracle.
Such is the simplicity of man to hearken after the flesh.
[Reads]  'Great deputy
sole dominator of Navarre
Not a word of Costard yet.
[Reads]  'So it is
It may be so: but if he say it is so
telling true
Peace!
Be to me and every man that dares not fight!
No words!
Of other men's secrets
[Reads]  'So it is
melancholy
to the most wholesome physic of thy health-giving
air; and
walk. The time when. About the sixth hour; when
beasts most graze
to that nourishment which is called supper: so much
for the time when. Now for the ground which; which
for the place where; where
that obscene and preposterous event
from my snow-white pen the ebon-coloured ink
here thou viewest
but to the place where; it standeth north-north-east
and by east from the west corner of thy curious-
knotted garden: there did I see that low-spirited
swain
Me?
[Reads]  'that unlettered small-knowing soul
Me?
[Reads]  'that shallow vassal
Still me?

O

established proclaimed edict and continent canon
wherewith

female; or

punishment

'Me

called which I apprehended with the aforesaid

and heart-burning heat of duty.
DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO.'
This is not so well as I looked for
that ever I heard.
Ay
you to this?
Sir
Did you hear the proclamation?
I do confess much of the hearing it but little of
the marking of it.
It was proclaimed a year's imprisonment
with a wench.
I was taken with none
Well
This was no damsel
It is so varied
If it were
This maid will not serve your turn
This maid will serve my turn
Sir
a week with bran and water.
I had rather pray a month with mutton and porridge.
And Don Armado shall be your keeper.
My Lord Biron
And go we

I'll lay my head to any good man's hat
Sirrah
I suffer for the truth
taken with Jaquenetta

prosperity! Affliction may one day smile again; and
till then

LOVE'S LABOURS LOST
SCENE II. The same.
Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO and MOTH
DON
Boy
grows melancholy?
A great sign
DON
Why
No
DON
How canst thou part sadness and melancholy
tender juvenal?
By a familiar demonstration of the working
DON
Why tough senior? why tough senior?
Why tender juvenal? why tender juvenal?
DON
I spoke it
appertaining to thy young days
nominate tender.
And I
old time
DON ADRIANO DE
Pretty and apt.
How mean you
I apt
DON
Thou pretty
Little pretty
DON
And therefore apt
Speak you this in my praise
DON
In thy condign praise.
I will praise an eel with the same praise.
DON
What
That an eel is quick.
DON
I do say thou art quick in answers: thou heatest my blood.
I am answered
DON
I love not to be crossed.
[Aside]  He speaks the mere contrary; crosses love not him.
DON
I have promised to study three years with the duke.
You may do it in an hour
DON
Impossible.
How many is one thrice told?
DON
I am ill at reckoning; it fitteth the spirit of a tapster.
You are a gentleman and a gamester
DON
I confess both: they are both the varnish of a
complete man.
Then
deuce-ace amounts to.
DON
It doth amount to one more than two.
Which the base vulgar do call three.
DON
True.
Why
is three studied
easy it is to put 'years' to the word 'three
study three years in two words
will tell you.
DON
A most fine figure!
To prove you a cipher.
DON
I will hereupon confess I am in love: and as it is
base for a soldier to love
base wench. If drawing my sword against the humour
of affection would deliver me from the reprobate
thought of it
ransom him to any French courtier for a new-devised
courtesy. I think scorn to sigh: methinks I should
outswear Cupid. Comfort
have been in love?
Hercules
DON
Most sweet Hercules! More authority
more; and
repute and carriage.
Samson
carriage
like a porter: and he was in love.
DON
O well-knit Samson! strong-jointed Samson! I do
excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst me in
carrying gates. I am in love too. Who was Samson's
love
A woman
DON
Of what complexion?
Of all the four
DON

Of the sea-water green
DON
Is that one of the four complexions?
As I have read
DON
Green indeed is the colour of lovers; but to have a
love of that colour
for it. He surely affected her for her wit.
It was so
DON
My love is most immaculate white and red.
Most maculate thoughts
such colours.
DON

My father's wit and my mother's tongue
DON
Sweet invocation of a child; most pretty and
pathetical!
If she be made of white and red
And fears by pale white shown:
Then if she fear
Which native she doth owe.
A dangerous rhyme
white and red.

Is there not a ballad

found; or

LOVE'S LABOURS LOST
ACT II
SCENE I. The same.
Enter the PRINCESS of France
Now
Consider who the king your father sends
Yourself
Of all perfections that a man may owe
Than Aquitaine
Be now as prodigal of all dear grace
As Nature was in making graces dear
When she did starve the general world beside
And prodigally gave them all to you.
Good Lord Boyet
Beauty is bought by judgement of the eye
I am less proud to hear you tell my worth
Than you much willing to be counted wise
In spending your wit in the praise of mine.
But now to task the tasker: good Boyet
Doth noise abroad
Therefore to's seemeth it a needful course
As our best-moving fair solicitor.
Tell him
Haste
Proud of employment
All pride is willing pride
Exit BOYET
Who are the votaries
Lord Longaville is one.
Know you the man?
I know him
Of Jaques Falconbridge
In Normandy
A man of sovereign parts he is esteem'd;
Well fitted in arts
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
The only soil of his fair virtue's gloss
Whose edge hath power to cut
It should none spare that come within his power.
Some merry mocking lord
They say so most that most his humours know.
Such short-lived wits do wither as they grow.
Who are the rest?
The young Dumain
Most power to do most harm
For he hath wit to make an ill shape good
I saw him at the Duke Alencon's once;
And much too little of that good I saw
Is my report to his great worthiness.
Another of these students at that time
Was there with him
Biron they call him; but a merrier man
His eye begets occasion for his wit;
For every object that the one doth catch
The other turns to a mirth-moving jest
That aged ears play truant at his tales
And younger hearings are quite ravished;
So sweet and voluble is his discourse.
God bless my ladies! are they all in love
With such bedecking ornaments of praise?
Here comes Boyet.
Re-enter BOYET
Now
Navarre had notice of your fair approach;
And he and his competitors in oath
Were all address'd to meet you
He rather means to lodge you in the field
Here comes Navarre.
Enter FERDINAND
Fair princess
'Fair' I give you back again; and 'welcome' I have
not yet: the roof of this court is too high to be
yours; and welcome to the wide fields too base to be mine.
You shall be welcome
I will be welcome
Hear me
Our Lady help my lord! he'll be forsworn.
Not for the world
Why
Your ladyship is ignorant what it is.
Were my lord so
I hear your grace hath sworn out house-keeping:
Tis deadly sin to keep that oath
But pardon me. I am too sudden-bold:
To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me.
Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming
Madam
You will the sooner
For you'll prove perjured if you make me stay.
Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?
Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?
I know you did.
How needless was it then to ask the question!
You must not be so quick.
'Tis 'long of you that spur me with such questions.
Your wit's too hot
Not till it leave the rider in the mire.
What time o' day?
The hour that fools should ask.
Now fair befall your mask!
Fair fall the face it covers!
And send you many lovers!
Amen
Nay
Madam
The payment of a hundred thousand crowns;
Being but the one half of an entire sum
Disbursed by my father in his wars.
But say that he or we
A hundred thousand more; in surety of the which
If then the king your father will restore
But that one half which is unsatisfied
But that
A hundred thousand crowns; and not demands
Which we much rather had depart withal
And have the money by our father lent
Than Aquitaine so gelded as it is.
Dear Princess
From reason's yielding
A yielding 'gainst some reason in my breast
And go well satisfied to France again.
You do the king my father too much wrong
And wrong the reputation of your name
Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.
I do protest I never heard of it;
And if you prove it
Or yield up Aquitaine.
We arrest your word.
Boyet
For such a sum from special officers
Of Charles his father.
Satisfy me so.
So please your grace
Where that and other specialties are bound:
To-morrow you shall have a sight of them.
It shall suffice me: at which interview
All liberal reason I will yield unto.
Meantime receive such welcome at my hand
As honour without breach of honour may
Make tender of to thy true worthiness:
You may not come
But here without you shall be so received
As you shall deem yourself lodged in my heart
Your own good thoughts excuse me
To-morrow shall we visit you again.
Sweet health and fair desires consort your grace!
Thy own wish wish I thee in every place!
Exit
Lady
Pray you
I would you heard it groan.
Is the fool sick?
Sick at the heart.
Alack
Would that do it good?
My physic says 'ay.'
Will you prick't with your eye?
No point
Now
And yours from long living!
I cannot stay thanksgiving.
Retiring
Sir
The heir of Alencon
A gallant lady. Monsieur
Exit
I beseech you a word: what is she in the white?
A woman sometimes

She hath but one for herself; to desire that were a shame.

Good sir

Nay

That last is Biron
Not a word with him but a jest.
And every jest but a word.

I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.
Two hot sheeps
And wherefore not ships?
No sheep
You sheep
So you grant pasture for me.
Offering to kiss her
Not so
My lips are no common

To my fortunes and me.
Good wits will be jangling; but
This civil war of wits were much better used
On Navarre and his book-men; for here 'tis abused.
If my observation
With what?
With that which we lovers entitle affected.
Your reason?
Why
To the court of his eye

All senses to that sense did make their repair

That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes.

I only have made a mouth of his eye

Then was Venus like her mother

See see

The poor deer's blood
Do not curst wives hold that self-sovereignty
Only for praise sake
Lords o'er their lords?
Only for praise: and praise we may afford
To any lady that subdues a lord.
Here comes a member of the commonwealth.

Thou shalt know her
Which is the greatest lady
The thickest and the tallest.

An your waist

TRUE
thou art lovely. More fairer than fair

commiseration on thy heroical vassal! The

vulgar
came
overcame
come? to see: why did he see? to overcome: to
whom came he? to the beggar: what saw he? the
beggar: who overcame he? the beggar. The
conclusion is victory: on whose side? the king's.
The captive is enriched: on whose side? the
beggar's. The catastrophe is a nuptial: on whose
side? the king's: no
both. I am the king; for so stands the comparison:
thou the beggar; for so witnesseth thy lowliness.
Shall I command thy love? I may: shall I enforce
thy love? I could: shall I entreat thy love? I
will. What shalt thou exchange for rags? robes;
for tittles? titles; for thyself? me. Thus
part. Thine
Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar
'Gainst thee

Else your memory is bad

So sweet a kiss the golden sun gives not
To those fresh morning drops upon the rose
The night of dew that on my cheeks down flows:
Nor shines the silver moon one half so bright
Through the transparent bosom of the deep
Thou shinest in every tear that I do weep:
No drop but as a coach doth carry thee;
So ridest thou triumphing in my woe.
Do but behold the tears that swell in me
But do not love thyself; then thou wilt keep

And I mine too
Amen
I would forget her; but a fever she
Reigns in my blood and will remember'd be.
A fever in your blood! why
Would let her out in saucers: sweet misprision!
Once more I'll read the ode that I have writ.
Once more I'll mark how love can vary wit.
[Reads]
On a day--alack the day!--
Love
Playing in the wanton air:
Through the velvet leaves the wind
That the lover
Air
Air
But
Ne'er to pluck thee from thy thorn;
Vow
Do not call it sin in me
Thou for whom Jove would swear
Juno but an Ethiope were;
And deny himself for Jove
This will I send
O
For none offend where all alike do dote.
[Advancing]  Dumain
You may look pale
[Advancing]  Come
You chide at him
You do not love Maria; Longaville
Did never sonnet for her sake compile
His loving bosom to keep down his heart.
I have been closely shrouded in this bush
And mark'd you both and for you both did blush:
I heard your guilty rhymes
Ay me! says one; O Jove! the other cries;
One
To LONGAVILLE
You would for paradise break faith
To DUMAIN
And Jove
What will Biron say when that he shall hear
Faith so infringed
How will he scorn! how will he spend his wit!
How will he triumph
For all the wealth that ever I did see
Now step I forth to whip hypocrisy.
Advancing
Ah
Good heart
These worms for loving
Your eyes do make no coaches; in your tears
There is no certain princess that appears;
You'll not be perjured
Tush
But are you not ashamed? nay
You found his mote; the king your mote did see;
But I a beam do find in each of three.
O
O me
To see great Hercules whipping a gig
Where lies thy grief
And gentle Longaville
And where my liege's? all about the breast:
A caudle
Too bitter is thy jest.
Are we betray'd thus to thy over-view?
Not you to me
I
To break the vow I am engaged in;
I am betray'd
With men like men of inconstancy.
When shall you see me write a thing in rhyme?
Or groan for love? or spend a minute's time
In pruning me? When shall you hear that I
Will praise a hand
Soft! whither away so fast?
A true man or a thief that gallops so?
I post from love: good lover
Enter JAQUENETTA and COSTARD
God bless the king!
What present hast thou there?
Some certain treason.
What makes treason here?
Nay
If it mar nothing neither
I beseech your grace
Our parson misdoubts it; 'twas treason
Biron
Giving him the paper
Where hadst thou it?
Of Costard.
Where hadst thou it?
Of Dun Adramadio
BIRON tears the letter
How now! what is in you? why dost thou tear it?
A toy
It did move him to passion
It is Biron's writing
Gathering up the pieces
[To COSTARD]  Ah
born to do me shame.
Guilty
What?
That you three fools lack'd me fool to make up the mess:
He
O
Now the number is even.
TRUE
Will these turtles be gone?
Hence
Walk aside the true folk
Exeunt COSTARD and JAQUENETTA
Sweet lords
As true we are as flesh and blood can be:
The sea will ebb and flow
Young blood doth not obey an old decree:
We cannot cross the cause why we were born;
Therefore of all hands must we be forsworn.
What
Did they
Kisses the base ground with obedient breast?
What peremptory eagle-sighted eye
Dares look upon the heaven of her brow
What zeal
My love
She an attending star
My eyes are then no eyes
O
Of all complexions the cull'd sovereignty
Do meet
Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues
Fie
To things of sale a seller's praise belongs
A wither'd hermit
Beauty doth varnish age
O
By heaven
Is ebony like her? O wood divine!
A wife of such wood were felicity.
O
That I may swear beauty doth beauty lack
No face is fair that is not full so black.
O paradox! Black is the badge of hell
And beauty's crest becomes the heavens well.
Devils soonest tempt
O
Should ravish doters with a false aspect;
And therefore is she born to make black fair.
Her favour turns the fashion of the days
And therefore red
To look like her are chimney-sweepers black.
And since her time are colliers counted bright.
And Ethiopes of their sweet complexion crack.
Dark needs no candles now
Your mistresses dare never come in rain
'Twere good
I'll prove her fair
No devil will fright thee then so much as she.
I never knew man hold vile stuff so dear.
Look
O
O
The street should see as she walk'd overhead.
But what of this? are we not all in love?
Nothing so sure; and thereby all forsworn.
Then leave this chat; and
Our loving lawful
Ay
O
Some tricks
Some salve for perjury.
'Tis more than need.
Have at you
Consider what you first did swear unto
Flat treason 'gainst the kingly state of youth.
Say
And abstinence engenders maladies.
And where that you have vow'd to study
For when would you
Without the beauty of a woman's face?
From women's eyes this doctrine I derive;  They are the ground
Why
The nimble spirits in the arteries
The sinewy vigour of the traveller.
Now
And study too
For where is any author in the world
Teaches such beauty as a woman's eye?
Learning is but an adjunct to ourself
And where we are our learning likewise is:
Then when ourselves we see in ladies' eyes
O
For when would you
Such fiery numbers as the prompting eyes
Of beauty's tutors have enrich'd you with?
Other slow arts entirely keep the brain;
And therefore
But love
But
It adds a precious seeing to the eye;
A lover's eyes will gaze an eagle blind;
A lover's ear will hear the lowest sound
Love's feeling is more soft and sensible
Than are the tender horns of cockl'd snails;
Love's tongue proves dainty Bacchus gross in taste:
For valour
Subtle as Sphinx; as sweet and musical
As bright Apollo's lute
And when Love speaks
Makes heaven drowsy with the harmony.
Never durst poet touch a pen to write
Until his ink were temper'd with Love's sighs;
O
And plant in tyrants mild humility.
From women's eyes this doctrine I derive:
They sparkle still the right Promethean fire;
They are the books
Else none at all in ought proves excellent.
Then fools you were these women to forswear
For wisdom's sake
It is religion to be thus forsworn
Saint Cupid
Advance your standards
Pell-mell
Now to plain-dealing; lay these glozes by:
Shall we resolve to woo these girls of France?
And win them too: therefore let us devise
Some entertainment for them in their tents.
First
Then homeward every man attach the hand
Of his fair mistress: in the afternoon
We will with some strange pastime solace them
For revels
Forerun fair Love
Away
That will betime
Allons! allons! Sow'd cockle reap'd no corn;
And justice always whirls in equal measure:
Light wenches may prove plagues to men forsworn;
If so
Exeunt

LOVE'S LABOURS LOST
SCENE II. The same.
Enter the PRINCESS
Sweet hearts
A lady wall'd about with diamonds!
Look you what I have from the loving king.
Madame
Nothing but this! yes
As would be cramm'd up in a sheet of paper
That was the way to make his godhead wax
Ay
You'll ne'er be friends with him; a' kill'd your sister.
He made her melancholy
And so she died: had she been light
And so may you; for a light heart lives long.
What's your dark meaning
A light condition in a beauty dark.
We need more light to find your meaning out.
You'll mar the light by taking it in snuff;
Therefore I'll darkly end the argument.
Look what you do
So do not you
Indeed I weigh not you
You weigh me not? O
Great reason; for 'past cure is still past care.'
Well bandied both; a set of wit well play'd.
But Rosaline
Who sent it? and what is it?
I would you knew:
An if my face were but as fair as yours
Nay
The numbers true; and
I am compared to twenty thousand fairs.
O
Any thing like?
Much in the letters; nothing in the praise.
Beauteous as ink; a good conclusion.
Fair as a text B in a copy-book.
'Ware pencils
O
A pox of that jest! and I beshrew all shrows.
But
Madam
Did he not send you twain?
Yes
Some thousand verses of a faithful lover
This and these pearls to me sent Longaville:
The letter is too long by half a mile.
I think no less. Dost thou not wish in heart
The chain were longer and the letter short?
Ay
We are wise girls to mock our lovers so.
They are worse fools to purchase mocking so.
That same Biron I'll torture ere I go:
O that I knew he were but in by the week!
How I would make him fawn and beg and seek
And wait the season and observe the times
And spend his prodigal wits in bootless rhymes
And shape his service wholly to my hests
And make him proud to make me proud that jests!
So perttaunt-like would I o'ersway his state
That he should be my fool and I his fate.
None are so surely caught
And wit's own grace to grace a learned fool.
The blood of youth burns not with such excess
As gravity's revolt to wantonness.
Folly in fools bears not so strong a note
As foolery in the wise
Since all the power thereof it doth apply
To prove
Here comes Boyet
Enter BOYET
O
Thy news Boyet?
Prepare
Arm
Against your peace: Love doth approach disguised
Muster your wits; stand in your own defence;
Or hide your heads like cowards
Saint Denis to Saint Cupid! What are they
That charge their breath against us? say
Under the cool shade of a sycamore
I thought to close mine eyes some half an hour;
When
The king and his companions: warily
I stole into a neighbour thicket by
Their herald is a pretty knavish page
Action and accent did they teach him there;
'Thus must thou speak
And ever and anon they made a doubt
Presence majestical would put him out
Yet fear not thou
The boy replied
I should have fear'd her had she been a devil.'
With that
One rubb'd his elbow thus
A better speech was never spoke before;
Another
The third he caper'd
The fourth turn'd on the toe
With that
But what
They do
Like Muscovites or Russians
Their purpose is to parle
And every one his love-feat will advance
Unto his several mistress
By favours several which they did bestow.
And will they so? the gallants shall be task'd;
For
And not a man of them shall have the grace
Hold
Hold
And change your favours too; so shall your loves
Woo contrary
Come on
But in this changing what is your intent?
The effect of my intent is to cross theirs:
They do it but in mocking merriment;
And mock for mock is only my intent.
Their several counsels they unbosom shall
To loves mistook
Upon the next occasion that we meet
But shall we dance
No
Nor to their penn'd speech render we no grace
Why
Therefore I do it; and I make no doubt
The rest will ne'er come in
There's no such sport as sport by sport o'erthrown
So shall we stay
Trumpets sound within
The trumpet sounds: be mask'd; the maskers come.
The Ladies mask
Enter Blackamoors with music; MOTH; FERDINAND
All hail
Beauties no richer than rich taffeta.
A holy parcel of the fairest dames.
The Ladies turn their backs to him
That ever turn'd their--backs--to mortal views!
[Aside to MOTH]  Their eyes
That ever turn'd their eyes to mortal views!--Out--
True; out indeed.
Out of your favours
Not to behold--
[Aside to MOTH]  Once to behold
Once to behold with your sun-beamed eyes
They will not answer to that epithet;
You were best call it 'daughter-beamed eyes.'
They do not mark me
Is this your perfectness? be gone
Exit MOTH
What would these strangers? know their minds
If they do speak our language
That some plain man recount their purposes
Know what they would.
What would you with the princess?
Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.
What would they
Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.
Why
She says
Say to her
To tread a measure with her on this grass.
They say
To tread a measure with you on this grass.
It is not so. Ask them how many inches
Is in one mile: if they have measured many
If to come hither you have measured miles
How many inches doth fill up one mile.
Tell her
She hears herself.
How many weary steps
We number nothing that we spend for you:
Our duty is so rich
Vouchsafe to show the sunshine of your face
My face is but a moon
Blessed are clouds
Vouchsafe
O vain petitioner! beg a greater matter;
Thou now request'st but moonshine in the water.
Then
Thou bid'st me beg: this begging is not strange.
Play
Music plays
Not yet! no dance! Thus change I like the moon.
Will you not dance? How come you thus estranged?
You took the moon at full
Yet still she is the moon
The music plays; vouchsafe some motion to it.
Our ears vouchsafe it.
But your legs should do it.
Since you are strangers and come here by chance
Why take we hands
Only to part friends:
Curtsy
More measure of this measure; be not nice.
We can afford no more at such a price.
Prize you yourselves: what buys your company?
Your absence only.
That can never be.
Then cannot we be bought: and so
Twice to your visor
If you deny to dance
In private
I am best pleased with that.
They converse apart
White-handed mistress
Honey
Nay then
There's half-a-dozen sweets.
Seventh sweet
Since you can cog
One word in secret.
Let it not be sweet.
Thou grievest my gall.
Gall! bitter.
Therefore meet.
They converse apart
Will you vouchsafe with me to change a word?
Name it.
Fair lady
Say you so? Fair lord
Take that for your fair lady.
Please it you
They converse apart
What
I know the reason
O for your reason! quickly
You have a double tongue within your mask
Veal
A calf
No
Let's part the word.
No
Take all
Look
Will you give horns
Then die a calf
One word in private with you
Bleat softly then; the butcher hears you cry.
They converse apart
The tongues of mocking wenches are as keen
As is the razor's edge invisible
Seemeth their conference; their conceits have wings
Fleeter than arrows
Not one word more
By heaven
Farewell
Twenty adieus

Are these the breed of wits so wonder'd at?
Tapers they are
Well-liking wits they have; gross
O poverty in wit
Will they not
Or ever
This pert Biron was out of countenance quite.
O

Qualm

Go

Dumain is mine
Madam
Immediately they will again be here
In their own shapes; for it can never be
They will digest this harsh indignity.
Will they return?
They will
Therefore change favours; and
How blow? how blow? speak to be understood.
Fair ladies mask'd are roses in their bud;
Dismask'd
Avaunt
Good madam
Let us complain to them what fools were here
And wonder what they were and to what end
Their shallow shows and prologue vilely penn'd
And their rough carriage so ridiculous
Ladies
Whip to our tents

Fair sir
Gone to her tent. Please it your majesty
Command me any service to her thither?
That she vouchsafe me audience for one word.
I will; and so will she
Exit
This fellow pecks up wit as pigeons pease
He is wit's pedler
At wakes and wassails
And we that sell by gross
This gallant pins the wenches on his sleeve;
Had he been Adam
A' can carve too
That kiss'd his hand away in courtesy;
This is the ape of form
In honourable terms: nay
A mean most meanly; and in ushering
Mend him who can: the ladies call him sweet;
The stairs
This is the flower that smiles on every one
And consciences
A blister on his sweet tongue
See where it comes! Behavior
Till this madman show'd thee? and what art thou now?
Re-enter the PRINCESS
All hail
'Fair' in 'all hail' is foul
Construe my speeches better
Then wish me better; I will give you leave.
We came to visit you
To lead you to our court; vouchsafe it then.
This field shall hold me; and so hold your vow:
Nor God
Rebuke me not for that which you provoke:
The virtue of your eye must break my oath.
You nickname virtue; vice you should have spoke;
For virtue's office never breaks men's troth.
Now by my maiden honour
As the unsullied lily
So much I hate a breaking cause to be
Of heavenly oaths
O
Not so
We have had pastimes here and pleasant game:
A mess of Russians left us but of late.
How
Ay
Trim gallants
Madam
My lady
We four indeed confronted were with four
In Russian habit: here they stay'd an hour
I dare not call them fools; but this I think
This jest is dry to me. Fair gentle sweet
Is of that nature that to your huge store
Wise things seem foolish and rich things but poor.
This proves you wise and rich
I am a fool
But that you take what doth to you belong
O
All the fool mine?
I cannot give you less.
Which of the vizards was it that you wore?

There
That hid the worse and show'd the better face.

Let us confess and turn it to a jest.
Amazed

lady

And I will wish thee never more to dance
O

And

They have the plague

No

It is not so; for how can this be true

Teach us

The fairest is confession.

I was

Biron
We are shame-proof

I say they shall not come.
Nay
That sport best pleases that doth least know how:
Where zeal strives to content
Dies in the zeal of that which it presents:
Their form confounded makes most form in mirth
A right description of our sport

Great Hercules is presented by this imp
And when he was a babe

MOTH retires
Judas I am
A Judas!
Not Iscariot
Judas I am
Judas Maccabaeus clipt is plain Judas.
A kissing traitor. How art thou proved Judas?
Judas I am
The more shame for you
What mean you
To make Judas hang himself.
Begin
Well followed: Judas was hanged on an elder.
I will not be put out of countenance.
Because thou hast no face.
What is this?
A cittern-head.
The head of a bodkin.
A Death's face in a ring.
The face of an old Roman coin
The pommel of Caesar's falchion.
The carved-bone face on a flask.
Saint George's half-cheek in a brooch.
Ay
Ay
And now forward; for we have put thee in countenance.
You have put me out of countenance.
False; we have given thee faces.
But you have out-faced them all.
An thou wert a lion
Therefore
And so adieu
For the latter end of his name.
For the ass to the Jude; give it him:--Jud-as
This is not generous
A light for Monsieur Judas! it grows dark
HOLOFERNES retires
Alas
Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
Hide thy head
Though my mocks come home by me
Hector was but a Troyan in respect of this.
But is this Hector?
I think Hector was not so clean-timbered.
His leg is too big for Hector's.
More calf
No; he is best endued in the small.
This cannot be Hector.
He's a god or a painter; for he makes faces.
DON
The armipotent Mars
A gilt nutmeg.
A lemon.
Stuck with cloves.
No
DON
Peace!--
The armipotent Mars
Gave Hector a gift
A man so breathed
From morn till night
I am that flower
That mint.
That columbine.

Sweet Lord Longaville
I must rather give it the rein
Ay
DON
The sweet war-man is dead and rotten; sweet chucks
To the PRINCESS
Sweet royalty
Speak
DON

[Aside to DUMAIN]  Loves her by the foot

DON
This Hector far surmounted Hannibal
The party is gone
is two months on her way.

What meanest thou?
Faith
wench is cast away: she's quick; the child brags in

DON
Dost thou infamonize me among potentates? thou shalt
die.
Then shall Hector be whipped for Jaquenetta that is
quick by him and hanged for Pompey that is dead by
him.
Most rare Pompey!
Renowned Pompey!
Greater than great
Pompey the Huge!
Hector trembles.
Pompey is moved. More Ates
on! stir them on!
Hector will challenge him.
Ay
sup a flea.
DON
By the north pole
I will not fight with a pole
I'll slash; I'll do it by the sword. I bepray you
Room for the incensed Worthies!
I'll do it in my shirt.
Most resolute Pompey!
Master
not see Pompey is uncasing for the combat? What mean

DON
Gentlemen and soldiers
in my shirt.
You may not deny it: Pompey hath made the challenge.

Sweet bloods
What reason have you for't?
DON
The naked truth of it is
woolward for penance.
TRUE
linen: since when

Enter MERCADE
God save you
Welcome
But that thou interrupt'st our merriment.
I am sorry
Is heavy in my tongue. The king your father--
Dead
Even so; my tale is told.
Worthies
DON
For mine own part
seen the day of wrong through the little hole of
discretion
Exeunt Worthies
How fares your majesty?
Boyet
Madam
Prepare
In your rich wisdom to excuse or hide
The liberal opposition of our spirits
In the converse of breath: your gentleness
Was guilty of it. Farewell worthy lord!
A heavy heart bears not a nimble tongue:
Excuse me so
For my great suit so easily obtain'd.
The extreme parts of time extremely forms
All causes to the purpose of his speed
That which long process could not arbitrate:
And though the mourning brow of progeny
Forbid the smiling courtesy of love
The holy suit which fain it would convince
From what it purposed; since
Is not by much so wholesome-profitable
As to rejoice at friends but newly found.
I understand you not: my griefs are double.
Honest plain words best pierce the ear of grief;
And by these badges understand the king.
For your fair sakes have we neglected time
Even to the opposed end of our intents:
And what in us hath seem'd ridiculous
As love is full of unbefitting strains
To every varied object in his glance:
Which parti-coated presence of loose love
Put on by us
Is likewise yours: we to ourselves prove false
To those that make us both
And even that falsehood
We have received your letters full of love;
Your favours
And
At courtship
But more devout than this in our respects
Have we not been; and therefore met your loves
In their own fashion
Our letters
So did our looks.
We did not quote them so.
Now
A time
To make a world-without-end bargain in.
No
If for my love
Your oath I will not trust; but go with speed
To some forlorn and naked hermitage
There stay until the twelve celestial signs
Have brought about the annual reckoning.
If this austere insociable life
Change not your offer made in heat of blood;
If frosts and fasts
Nip not the gaudy blossoms of your love
Then
I will be thine; and till that instant shut
My woeful self up in a mourning house
For the remembrance of my father's death.
If this thou do deny
If this
Hence ever then my heart is in thy breast.
But what to me
A beard
With three-fold love I wish you all these three.
O
Not so
I'll mark no words that smooth-faced wooers say:
Come when the king doth to my lady come;
Then
I'll serve thee true and faithfully till then.
Yet swear not
What says Maria?
At the twelvemonth's end
I'll change my black gown for a faithful friend.
I'll stay with patience; but the time is long.
The liker you; few taller are so young.
Studies my lady? mistress
Behold the window of my heart
Impose some service on me for thy love.
Oft have I heard of you
Proclaims you for a man replete with mocks
That lie within the mercy of your wit.
To weed this wormwood from your fruitful brain
Visit the speechless sick and still converse
With groaning wretches; and your task shall be
To enforce the pained impotent to smile.
To move wild laughter in the throat of death?
It cannot be; it is impossible:
Mirth cannot move a soul in agony.
Why
Which shallow laughing hearers give to fools:
A jest's prosperity lies in the ear
Of him that hears it
Of him that makes it: then
But if they will not
A twelvemonth! well; befall what will befall
[To FERDINAND]  Ay
No
Our wooing doth not end like an old play;
Jack hath not Jill: these ladies' courtesy
Might well have made our sport a comedy.
Come
That's too long for a play.
Re-enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
DON
Sweet majesty
Was not that Hector?
The worthy knight of Troy.
DON
I will kiss thy royal finger
a votary; I have vowed to Jaquenetta to hold the
plough for her sweet love three years. But
esteemed greatness
the two learned men have compiled in praise of the
owl and the cuckoo? It should have followed in the
end of our show.
Call them forth quickly; we will do so.
DON
Holla! approach.
Re-enter HOLOFERNES
This side is Hiems
