THE SONG
SPRING.
When daisies pied and violets blue
And lady-smocks all silver-white
And cuckoo-buds of yellow hue
Do paint the meadows with delight
Cuckoo
When shepherds pipe on oaten straws
And merry larks are ploughmen's clocks
The cuckoo then
Cuckoo
WINTER.
When icicles hang by the wall
And Dick the shepherd blows his nail
And Tom bears logs into the hall
And milk comes frozen home in pail
Tu-who
When all aloud the wind doth blow
And coughing drowns the parson's saw
And birds sit brooding in the snow
And Marian's nose looks red and raw
Tu-who
DON
The words of Mercury are harsh after the songs of
Apollo. You that way: we this way.
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. A desert place.
Thunder and lightning. Enter three Witches
When shall we three meet again
In thunder
When the hurlyburly's done
That will be ere the set of sun.
Where the place?
Upon the heath.
There to meet with Macbeth.
I come
Paddock calls.
Anon.
Fair is foul
Hover through the fog and filthy air.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A camp near Forres.
Alarum within. Enter DUNCAN
What bloody man is that? He can report
The newest state.
This is the sergeant
Who like a good and hardy soldier fought
'Gainst my captivity. Hail
Say to the king the knowledge of the broil
As thou didst leave it.
Doubtful it stood;
As two spent swimmers
And choke their art. The merciless Macdonwald--
Worthy to be a rebel
The multiplying villanies of nature
Do swarm upon him--from the western isles
Of kerns and gallowglasses is supplied;
And fortune
For brave Macbeth--well he deserves that name--
Disdaining fortune
Till he faced the slave;
Which ne'er shook hands
O valiant cousin! worthy gentleman!
As whence the sun 'gins his reflection
Shipwrecking storms and direful thunders break
Discomfort swells. Mark
No sooner justice had with valour arm'd
Compell'd these skipping kerns to trust their heels
Began a fresh assault.
Dismay'd not this
Our captains
Yes;
As sparrows eagles
If I say sooth
As cannons overcharged with double cracks
Doubly redoubled strokes upon the foe:
Except they meant to bathe in reeking wounds
But I am faint
So well thy words become thee as thy wounds;
They smack of honour both. Go get him surgeons.
Exit Sergeant
Who comes here?
Enter ROSS
The worthy thane of Ross.
What a haste looks through his eyes! So should he look
That seems to speak things strange.
God save the king!
Whence camest thou
From Fife
Where the Norweyan banners flout the sky
And fan our people cold. Norway himself
The thane of Cawdor
Till that Bellona's bridegroom
Curbing his lavish spirit: and
Great happiness!
That now
Sweno
Nor would we deign him burial of his men
Till he disbursed at Saint Colme's inch
Ten thousand dollars to our general use.
No more that thane of Cawdor shall deceive
Our bosom interest: go pronounce his present death
I'll see it done.
What he hath lost noble Macbeth hath won.
Exeunt
SCENE III. A heath near Forres.
Thunder. Enter the three Witches
Where hast thou been
Killing swine.
Sister
A sailor's wife had chestnuts in her lap
'Give me
'Aroint thee
Her husband's to Aleppo gone
But in a sieve I'll thither sail
I'll give thee a wind.
Thou'rt kind.
And I another.
I myself have all the other
I' the shipman's card.
I will drain him dry as hay:
Sleep shall neither night nor day
Hang upon his pent-house lid;
He shall live a man forbid:
Weary se'nnights nine times nine
Shall he dwindle
Though his bark cannot be lost
Look what I have.
Show me
Here I have a pilot's thumb
Drum within
A drum
Macbeth doth come.
The weird sisters
Thrice to thine and thrice to mine
And thrice again
Peace! the charm's wound up.
Enter MACBETH and BANQUO
So foul and fair a day I have not seen.
How far is't call'd to Forres? What are these
So wither'd and so wild in their attire
That man may question? You seem to understand me
Upon her skinny lips: you should be women
That you are so.
Speak
All hail
All hail
All hail
Good sir
Things that do sound so fair? I' the name of truth
Which outwardly ye show? My noble partner
You greet with present grace and great prediction
Of noble having and of royal hope
If you can look into the seeds of time
Your favours nor your hate.
Hail!
Hail!
Hail!
Lesser than Macbeth
Not so happy
Thou shalt get kings
So all hail
Banquo and Macbeth
Stay
By Sinel's death I know I am thane of Glamis;
But how of Cawdor? the thane of Cawdor lives
Stands not within the prospect of belief
You owe this strange intelligence? or why
Upon this blasted heath you stop our way
With such prophetic greeting? Speak
Witches vanish
The earth hath bubbles
Into the air; and what seem'd corporal melted
As breath into the wind. Would they had stay'd!
Were such things here as we do speak about?
Or have we eaten on the insane root
That takes the reason prisoner?
Your children shall be kings.
You shall be king.
And thane of Cawdor too: went it not so?
To the selfsame tune and words. Who's here?
Enter ROSS and ANGUS
The king hath happily received
Thy personal venture in the rebels' fight
Which should be thine or his: silenced with that
Came post with post; and every one did bear
Thy praises in his kingdom's great defence
We are sent
To give thee from our royal master thanks;
Only to herald thee into his sight
And
In which addition
For it is thine.
What
The thane of Cawdor lives: why do you dress me
In borrow'd robes?
Who was the thane lives yet;
But under heavy judgment bears that life
Which he deserves to lose. Whether he was combined
With those of Norway
With hidden help and vantage
He labour'd in his country's wreck
But treasons capital
[Aside]  Glamis
The greatest is behind.
To ROSS and ANGUS
Thanks for your pains.
To BANQUO
Do you not hope your children shall be kings
Promised no less to them?
That trusted home
Might yet enkindle you unto the crown
And oftentimes
In deepest consequence.
Cousins
"[Aside]	Two truths are told"
Of the imperial theme.--I thank you
Aside
Cannot be ill
If good
Whose horrid image doth unfix my hair
And make my seated heart knock at my ribs
Are less than horrible imaginings:
My thought
Is smother'd in surmise
But what is not.
Look
[Aside]  If chance will have me king
New horrors come upon him
But with the aid of use.
[Aside]                Come what come may
Worthy Macbeth
Give me your favour: my dull brain was wrought
With things forgotten. Kind gentlemen
Are register'd where every day I turn
The leaf to read them. Let us toward the king.
Think upon what hath chanced
Our free hearts each to other.
Very gladly.
Till then
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Forres. The palace.
Flourish. Enter DUNCAN
Is execution done on Cawdor? Are not
Those in commission yet return'd?
My liege
With one that saw him die: who did report
That very frankly he confess'd his treasons
A deep repentance: nothing in his life
Became him like the leaving it; he died
As one that had been studied in his death
To throw away the dearest thing he owed
There's no art
To find the mind's construction in the face:
He was a gentleman on whom I built
An absolute trust.
Enter MACBETH
O worthiest cousin!
The sin of my ingratitude even now
Was heavy on me: thou art so far before
That swiftest wing of recompense is slow
To overtake thee. Would thou hadst less deserved
Might have been mine! only I have left to say
The service and the loyalty I owe
Is to receive our duties; and our duties
Are to your throne and state children and servants
Safe toward your love and honour.
Welcome hither:
I have begun to plant thee
To make thee full of growing. Noble Banquo
No less to have done so
And hold thee to my heart.
There if I grow
My plenteous joys
In drops of sorrow. Sons
We will establish our estate upon
Our eldest
The Prince of Cumberland; which honour must
Not unaccompanied invest him only
On all deservers. From hence to Inverness
The rest is labour
I'll be myself the harbinger and make joyful
The hearing of my wife with your approach;
So humbly take my leave.
My worthy Cawdor!
[Aside]  The Prince of Cumberland! that is a step
On which I must fall down
Let not light see my black and deep desires:
The eye wink at the hand; yet let that be
Exit
TRUE
It is a banquet to me. Let's after him
It is a peerless kinsman.
Flourish. Exeunt
SCENE V. Inverness. Macbeth's castle.
Enter LADY MACBETH
'They met me in the day of success: and I have
learned by the perfectest report
them than mortal knowledge. When I burned in desire
to question them further
the wonder of it
all-hailed me 'Thane of Cawdor;' by which title
me to the coming on of time
shalt be!' This have I thought good to deliver
thee
mightst not lose the dues of rejoicing
ignorant of what greatness is promised thee. Lay it
to thy heart
Glamis thou art
What thou art promised: yet do I fear thy nature;
It is too full o' the milk of human kindness
To catch the nearest way: thou wouldst be great;
Art not without ambition
The illness should attend it: what thou wouldst highly
And that which rather thou dost fear to do
Than wishest should be undone.' Hie thee hither
And chastise with the valour of my tongue
All that impedes thee from the golden round
To have thee crown'd withal.
Enter a Messenger
What is your tidings?
The king comes here to-night.
Thou'rt mad to say it:
Is not thy master with him? who
So please you
One of my fellows had the speed of him
Than would make up his message.
Give him tending;
He brings great news.
Exit Messenger
The raven himself is hoarse
That croaks the fatal entrance of Duncan
Under my battlements. Come
That tend on mortal thoughts
Of direst cruelty! make thick my blood;
Stop up the access and passage to remorse
Shake my fell purpose
The effect and it! Come to my woman's breasts
You wait on nature's mischief! Come
Enter MACBETH
Great Glamis! worthy Cawdor!
Greater than both
Thy letters have transported me beyond
This ignorant present
The future in the instant.
My dearest love
And when goes hence?
To-morrow
O
Shall sun that morrow see!
Your face
May read strange matters. To beguile the time
Must be provided for: and you shall put
This night's great business into my dispatch;
Which shall to all our nights and days to come
Give solely sovereign sway and masterdom.
We will speak further.
Only look up clear;
To alter favour ever is to fear:
Leave all the rest to me.
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Before Macbeth's castle.
Hautboys and torches. Enter DUNCAN
This castle hath a pleasant seat; the air
Nimbly and sweetly recommends itself
Unto our gentle senses.
This guest of summer
Smells wooingly here: no jutty
Hath made his pendent bed and procreant cradle:
Where they most breed and haunt
Enter LADY MACBETH
See
The love that follows us sometime is our trouble
How you shall bid God 'ild us for your pains
All our service
In every point twice done and then done double
Were poor and single business to contend
Against those honours deep and broad wherewith
Your majesty loads our house: for those of old
Where's the thane of Cawdor?
We coursed him at the heels
To be his purveyor: but he rides well;
And his great love
To his home before us. Fair and noble hostess
Your servants ever
Have theirs
Give me your hand;
Conduct me to mine host: we love him highly
By your leave
Exeunt
SCENE VII. Macbeth's castle.
Hautboys and torches. Enter a Sewer
If it were done when 'tis done
It were done quickly: if the assassination
Could trammel up the consequence
With his surcease success; that but this blow
Might be the be-all and the end-all here
We still have judgment here; that we but teach
Bloody instructions
To plague the inventor: this even-handed justice
Commends the ingredients of our poison'd chalice
To our own lips. He's here in double trust;
First
Hath borne his faculties so meek
So clear in his great office
Will plead like angels
The deep damnation of his taking-off;
And pity
Upon the sightless couriers of the air
To prick the sides of my intent
Vaulting ambition
And falls on the other.
Enter LADY MACBETH
How now! what news?
He has almost supp'd: why have you left the chamber?
Hath he ask'd for me?
Know you not he has?
We will proceed no further in this business:
He hath honour'd me of late; and I have bought
Golden opinions from all sorts of people
Was the hope drunk
Wherein you dress'd yourself? hath it slept since?
And wakes it now
At what it did so freely? From this time
Such I account thy love. Art thou afeard
To be the same in thine own act and valour
As thou art in desire? Wouldst thou have that
Which thou esteem'st the ornament of life
Like the poor cat i' the adage?
Prithee
I dare do all that may become a man;
Who dares do more is none.
What beast was't
When you durst do it
And
Be so much more the man. Nor time nor place
Did then adhere
They have made themselves
Does unmake you. I have given suck
How tender 'tis to love the babe that milks me:
I would
Have done to this.
If we should fail?
We fail!
But screw your courage to the sticking-place
Whereto the rather shall his day's hard journey
Soundly invite him--his two chamberlains
Will I with wine and wassail so convince
That memory
A limbeck only: when in swinish sleep
Their drenched natures lie as in a death
The unguarded Duncan? what not put upon
His spongy officers
Of our great quell?
Bring forth men-children only;
For thy undaunted mettle should compose
Nothing but males. Will it not be received
Of his own chamber and used their very daggers
Who dares receive it other
Upon his death?
I am settled
Each corporal agent to this terrible feat.
Away
False face must hide what the false heart doth know.
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Court of Macbeth's castle.
Enter BANQUO
How goes the night
The moon is down; I have not heard the clock.
And she goes down at twelve.
I take't
Hold
Their candles are all out. Take thee that too.
A heavy summons lies like lead upon me
Gives way to in repose!
Enter MACBETH
Give me my sword.
Who's there?
A friend.
What
He hath been in unusual pleasure
Sent forth great largess to your offices.
This diamond he greets your wife withal
In measureless content.
Being unprepared
Which else should free have wrought.
All's well.
I dreamt last night of the three weird sisters:
To you they have show'd some truth.
I think not of them:
Yet
At your kind'st leisure.
If you shall cleave to my consent
So I lose none
In seeking to augment it
My bosom franchised and allegiance clear
Good repose the while!
Thanks
Exeunt BANQUO and FLEANCE
Go bid thy mistress
Exit Servant
Is this a dagger which I see before me
I have thee not
Art thou not
To feeling as to sight? or art thou but
A dagger of the mind
I see thee yet
As this which now I draw.
Thou marshall'st me the way that I was going;
And such an instrument I was to use.
Mine eyes are made the fools o' the other senses
It is the bloody business which informs
Thus to mine eyes. Now o'er the one halfworld
Nature seems dead
The curtain'd sleep; witchcraft celebrates
Pale Hecate's offerings
With Tarquin's ravishing strides
Moves like a ghost. Thou sure and firm-set earth
Thy very stones prate of my whereabout
Words to the heat of deeds too cold breath gives.
A bell rings
I go
Hear it not
That summons thee to heaven or to hell.
Exit
SCENE II. The same.
Enter LADY MACBETH
That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold;
What hath quench'd them hath given me fire.
Hark! Peace!
It was the owl that shriek'd
The doors are open; and the surfeited grooms
Do mock their charge with snores: I have drugg'd
their possets
[Within]  Who's there? what
Alack
Confounds us. Hark! I laid their daggers ready;
He could not miss 'em. Had he not resembled
My father as he slept
Enter MACBETH
My husband!
I have done the deed. Didst thou not hear a noise?
I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry.
Did not you speak?
When?
Now.
As I descended?
Ay.
Hark!
Who lies i' the second chamber?
Donalbain.
This is a sorry sight.
Looking on his hands
A foolish thought
There's one did laugh in's sleep
'Murder!'
That they did wake each other: I stood and heard them:
But they did say their prayers
Again to sleep.
There are two lodged together.
One cried 'God bless us!' and 'Amen' the other;
As they had seen me with these hangman's hands.
Listening their fear
When they did say 'God bless us!'
Consider it not so deeply.
But wherefore could not I pronounce 'Amen'?
I had most need of blessing
Stuck in my throat.
These deeds must not be thought
After these ways; so
Methought I heard a voice cry 'Sleep no more!
Macbeth does murder sleep'
What do you mean?
Still it cried 'Sleep no more!' to all the house:
'Glamis hath murder'd sleep
Shall sleep no more; Macbeth shall sleep no more.'
Who was it that thus cried? Why
So brainsickly of things. Go get some water
Why did you bring these daggers from the place?
They must lie there: go carry them; and smear
The sleepy grooms with blood.
I'll go no more:
I am afraid to think what I have done;
Look on't again I dare not.
Infirm of purpose!
Give me the daggers: the sleeping and the dead
Are but as pictures: 'tis the eye of childhood
That fears a painted devil. If he do bleed
For it must seem their guilt.
Exit. Knocking within
Whence is that knocking?
How is't with me
What hands are here? ha! they pluck out mine eyes.
Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood
Clean from my hand? No
The multitudinous seas in incarnadine
Re-enter LADY MACBETH
My hands are of your colour; but I shame
To wear a heart so white.
Knocking within
I hear a knocking
At the south entry: retire we to our chamber;
A little water clears us of this deed:
How easy is it
Hath left you unattended.
Knocking within
Hark! more knocking.
Get on your nightgown
So poorly in your thoughts.
To know my deed
Knocking within
Wake Duncan with thy knocking! I would thou couldst!
Exeunt
SCENE III. The same.
Knocking within. Enter a Porter
Here's a knocking indeed! If a
man were porter of hell-gate
old turning the key.
Knocking within
Knock
Beelzebub? Here's a farmer
himself on the expectation of plenty: come in
time; have napkins enow about you; here
you'll sweat for't.
Knocking within
Knock
name? Faith
swear in both the scales against either scale;
who committed treason enough for God's sake
in
Knocking within
Knock
English tailor come hither
a French hose: come in
roast your goose.
Knocking within
Knock
this place is too cold for hell. I'll devil-porter
it no further: I had thought to have let in
some of all professions that go the primrose
way to the everlasting bonfire.
Knocking within
Anon
Opens the gate
Enter MACDUFF and LENNOX
Was it so late
'Faith sir
second cock: and drink
provoker of three things.
What three things does drink especially provoke?
Marry
urine. Lechery
it provokes the desire
away the performance: therefore
may be said to be an equivocator with lechery:
it makes him
him on
not stand to; in conclusion
in a sleep
I believe drink gave thee the lie last night.
That it did
me: but I requited him for his lie; and
think
up my legs sometime
him.
Is thy master stirring?
Enter MACBETH
Our knocking has awaked him; here he comes.
Good morrow
Good morrow
Is the king stirring
Not yet.
He did command me to call timely on him:
I have almost slipp'd the hour.
I'll bring you to him.
I know this is a joyful trouble to you;
But yet 'tis one.
The labour we delight in physics pain.
This is the door.
I'll make so bold to call
Exit
Goes the king hence to-day?
He does: he did appoint so.
The night has been unruly: where we lay
Of dire combustion and confused events
New hatch'd to the woeful time: the obscure bird
Clamour'd the livelong night: some say
Was feverous and did shake.
'Twas a rough night.
My young remembrance cannot parallel
A fellow to it.
Re-enter MACDUFF
O horror
Cannot conceive nor name thee!
What's the matter.
Confusion now hath made his masterpiece!
Most sacrilegious murder hath broke ope
The Lord's anointed temple
The life o' the building!
What is 't you say? the life?
Mean you his majesty?
Approach the chamber
With a new Gorgon: do not bid me speak;
See
Exeunt MACBETH and LENNOX
Awake
Ring the alarum-bell. Murder and treason!
Banquo and Donalbain! Malcolm! awake!
Shake off this downy sleep
The great doom's image! Malcolm! Banquo!
As from your graves rise up
Bell rings
Enter LADY MACBETH
What's the business
The sleepers of the house? speak
O gentle lady
The repetition
Enter BANQUO
O Banquo
Woe
What
Too cruel any where.
Dear Duff
Re-enter MACBETH and LENNOX
Had I but died an hour before this chance
All is but toys: renown and grace is dead;
The wine of life is drawn
Is left this vault to brag of.
Enter MALCOLM and DONALBAIN
What is amiss?
You are
The spring
Is stopp'd; the very source of it is stopp'd.
Your royal father 's murder'd.
O
Those of his chamber
Their hands and faces were an badged with blood;
So were their daggers
Upon their pillows:
They stared
Was to be trusted with them.
O
Wherefore did you so?
Who can be wise
The expedition my violent love
Outrun the pauser
And his gash'd stabs look'd like a breach in nature
For ruin's wasteful entrance: there
Unmannerly breech'd with gore: who could refrain
Courage to make 's love kno wn?
Help me hence
Look to the lady.
[Aside to DONALBAIN]  Why do we hold our tongues
[Aside to MALCOLM]  What should be spoken here
Let 's away;
Our tears are not yet brew'd.
[Aside to DONALBAIN]        Nor our strong sorrow
Upon the foot of motion.
Look to the lady:
LADY MACBETH is carried out
And when we have our naked frailties hid
In the great hand of God I stand; and thence
Against the undivulged pretence I fight
Of treasonous malice.
And so do I.
So all.
Let's briefly put on manly readiness
Well contented.
Exeunt all but Malcolm and Donalbain.
What will you do? Let's not consort with them:
To show an unfelt sorrow is an office
Which the false man does easy. I'll to England.
To Ireland
Shall keep us both the safer: where we are
This murderous shaft that's shot
Hath not yet lighted
Is to avoid the aim. Therefore
And let us not be dainty of leave-taking
Which steals itself
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Outside Macbeth's castle.
Enter ROSS and an old Man
Threescore and ten I can remember well:
Within the volume of which time I have seen
Hours dreadful and things strange; but this sore night
Hath trifled former knowings.
Ah
Is't night's predominance
'Tis unnatural
And Duncan's horses--a thing most strange and certain--
Beauteous and swift
War with mankind.
'Tis said they eat each other.
They did so
That look'd upon't. Here comes the good Macduff.
Enter MACDUFF
How goes the world
Why
Is't known who did this more than bloody deed?
Those that Macbeth hath slain.
Alas
What good could they pretend?
They were suborn'd:
Malcolm and Donalbain
Suspicion of the deed.
'Gainst nature still!
Thriftless ambition
Thine own life's means! Then 'tis most like
The sovereignty will fall upon Macbeth.
He is already named
To be invested.
Where is Duncan's body?
Carried to Colmekill
Will you to Scone?
No
Well
Well
Lest our old robes sit easier than our new!
Farewell
God's benison go with you; and with those
That would make good of bad
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. Forres. The palace.
Enter BANQUO
Thou hast it now: king
It should not stand in thy posterity
Of many kings. If there come truth from them--
As upon thee
Why
Sennet sounded. Enter MACBETH
Here's our chief guest.
If he had been forgotten
To-night we hold a solemn supper sir
Let your highness
Command upon me; to the which my duties
Are with a most indissoluble tie
For ever knit.
Ride you this afternoon?
Ay
We should have else desired your good advice
Is't far you ride?
As far
'Twixt this and supper: go not my horse the better
For a dark hour or twain.
Fail not our feast.
My lord
We hear
In England and in Ireland
Their cruel parricide
With strange invention: but of that to-morrow
Craving us jointly. Hie you to horse: adieu
Ay
I wish your horses swift and sure of foot;
And so I do commend you to their backs. Farewell.
Exit BANQUO
Let every man be master of his time
Till seven at night: to make society
The sweeter welcome
Till supper-time alone: while then
Exeunt all but MACBETH
Sirrah
Our pleasure?
They are
Bring them before us.
Exit Attendant
To be thus is nothing;
But to be safely thus.--Our fears in Banquo
Stick deep; and in his royalty of nature
Reigns that which would be fear'd: 'tis much he dares;
And
To act in safety. There is none but he
Whose being I do fear: and
When first they put the name of king upon me
They hail'd him father to a line of kings:
Upon my head they placed a fruitless crown
For them the gracious Duncan have I murder'd;
Put rancours in the vessel of my peace
Only for them; and mine eternal jewel
Given to the common enemy of man
Rather than so
And champion me to the utterance! Who's there!
Re-enter Attendant
Now go to the door
Exit Attendant
Was it not yesterday we spoke together?
It was
Well then
Have you consider'd of my speeches? Know
That it was he in the times past which held you
So under fortune
Our innocent self: this I made good to you
In our last conference
To half a soul and to a notion crazed
Say 'Thus did Banquo.'
You made it known to us.
I did so
Our point of second meeting. Do you find
Your patience so predominant in your nature
That you can let this go? Are you so gospell'd
To pray for this good man and for his issue
And beggar'd yours for ever?
We are men
Ay
As hounds and greyhounds
All by the name of dogs: the valued file
Distinguishes the swift
According to the gift which bounteous nature
Hath in him closed; whereby he does receive
Particular addition. from the bill
That writes them all alike: and so of men.
Now
And I will put that business in your bosoms
I am one
Have so incensed that I am reckless what
I do to spite the world.
And I another
So weary with disasters
Both of you
Know Banquo was your enemy.
TRUE
So is he mine; and in such bloody distance
Against my near'st of life: and though I could
With barefaced power sweep him from my sight
And bid my will avouch it
Who I myself struck down; and thence it is
For sundry weighty reasons.
We shall
Though our lives--
Your spirits shine through you. Within this hour at most
I will advise you where to plant yourselves;
Acquaint you with the perfect spy o' the time
That I require a clearness: and with him--
To leave no rubs nor botches in the work--
Fleance his son
Than is his father's
Of that dark hour. Resolve yourselves apart:
I'll come to you anon.
We are resolved
I'll call upon you straight: abide within.
Exeunt Murderers
It is concluded. Banquo
Exit
SCENE II. The palace.
Enter LADY MACBETH and a Servant
Is Banquo gone from court?
Ay
Say to the king
For a few words.
Madam
Exit
Nought's had
'Tis safer to be that which we destroy
Than by destruction dwell in doubtful joy.
Enter MACBETH
How now
With them they think on? Things without all remedy
Should be without regard: what's done is done.
We have scotch'd the snake
She'll close and be herself
Remains in danger of her former tooth.
But let the frame of things disjoint
worlds suffer
In the affliction of these terrible dreams
That shake us nightly: better be with the dead
In restless ecstasy. Duncan is in his grave;
After life's fitful fever he sleeps well;
Treason has done his worst: nor steel
Come on;
Gentle my lord
Be bright and jovial among your guests to-night.
So shall I
Let your remembrance apply to Banquo;
Present him eminence
Unsafe the while
Must lave our honours in these flattering streams
You must leave this.
O
Thou know'st that Banquo
But in them nature's copy's not eterne.
There's comfort yet; they are assailable;
Then be thou jocund: ere the bat hath flown
His cloister'd flight
The shard-borne beetle with his drowsy hums
Hath rung night's yawning peal
A deed of dreadful note.
What's to be done?
Be innocent of the knowledge
And with thy bloody and invisible hand
Cancel and tear to pieces that great bond
Which keeps me pale! Light thickens; and the crow
Makes wing to the rooky wood:
Good things of day begin to droop and drowse;
While night's black agents to their preys do rouse.
Thou marvell'st at my words: but hold thee still;
Things bad begun make strong themselves by ill.
So
Exeunt
SCENE III. A park near the palace.
Enter three Murderers
But who did bid thee join with us?
Macbeth.
He needs not our mistrust
Our offices and what we have to do
To the direction just.
Then stand with us.
The west yet glimmers with some streaks of day:
Now spurs the lated traveller apace
To gain the timely inn; and near approaches
The subject of our watch.
Hark! I hear horses.
[Within]  Give us a light there
Then 'tis he: the rest
That are within the note of expectation
Already are i' the court.
His horses go about.
Almost a mile: but he does usually
Make it their walk.
A light
Enter BANQUO
'Tis he.
Stand to't.
It will be rain to-night.
Let it come down.
They set upon BANQUO
O
Thou mayst revenge. O slave!
Dies. FLEANCE escapes
Who did strike out the light?
Wast not the way?
There's but one down; the son is fled.
We have lost
Best half of our affair.
Well
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The same. Hall in the palace.
A banquet prepared. Enter MACBETH
You know your own degrees; sit down: at first
And last the hearty welcome.
Thanks to your majesty.
Ourself will mingle with society
Our hostess keeps her state
We will require her welcome.
Pronounce it for me
For my heart speaks they are welcome.
First Murderer appears at the door
See
Both sides are even: here I'll sit i' the midst:
Be large in mirth; anon we'll drink a measure
The table round.
Approaching the door
There's blood on thy face.
'Tis Banquo's then.
'Tis better thee without than he within.
Is he dispatch'd?
My lord
Thou art the best o' the cut-throats: yet he's good
That did the like for Fleance: if thou didst it
Most royal sir
Then comes my fit again: I had else been perfect
But now I am cabin'd
To saucy doubts and fears. But Banquo's safe?
Ay
The least a death to nature.
Thanks for that:
There the grown serpent lies; the worm that's fled
Hath nature that in time will venom breed
We'll hear
Exit Murderer
My royal lord
That is not often vouch'd
From thence the sauce to meat is ceremony;
Meeting were bare without it.
Sweet remembrancer!
Now
May't please your highness sit.
The GHOST OF BANQUO enters
Here had we now our country's honour roof'd
Who may I rather challenge for unkindness
Than pity for mischance!
His absence
To grace us with your royal company.
The table's full.
Here is a place reserved
Where?
Here
Which of you have done this?
What
Thou canst not say I did it: never shake
Thy gory locks at me.
Gentlemen
Sit
The fit is momentary; upon a thought
He will again be well: if much you note him
Feed
Ay
Which might appal the devil.
O proper stuff!
This is the very painting of your fear:
This is the air-drawn dagger which
A woman's story at a winter's fire
Why do you make such faces? When all's done
Prithee
how say you?
Why
If charnel-houses and our graves must send
Those that we bury back
Shall be the maws of kites.
GHOST OF BANQUO vanishes
What
If I stand here
Fie
Blood hath been shed ere now
Ay
Too terrible for the ear: the times have been
Than such a murder is.
My worthy lord
I do forget.
Do not muse at me
To those that know me. Come
Then I'll sit down. Give me some wine; fill full.
I drink to the general joy o' the whole table
Would he were here! to all
Our duties
Re-enter GHOST OF BANQUO
Avaunt! and quit my sight! let the earth hide thee!
Thy bones are marrowless
Thou hast no speculation in those eyes
Which thou dost glare with!
Think of this
Only it spoils the pleasure of the time.
What man dare
Approach thou like the rugged Russian bear
Take any shape but that
Shall never tremble: or be alive again
If trembling I inhabit then
The baby of a girl. Hence
Unreal mockery
GHOST OF BANQUO vanishes
Why
You have displaced the mirth
Can such things be
Even to the disposition that I owe
What sights
I pray you
Question enrages him. At once
Stand not upon the order of your going
Good night; and better health
Attend his majesty!
A kind good night to all!
Exeunt all but MACBETH and LADY MACBETH
It will have blood; they say
Stones have been known to move and trees to speak;
Augurs and understood relations have
By magot-pies and choughs and rooks brought forth
The secret'st man of blood. What is the night?
Almost at odds with morning
How say'st thou
At our great bidding?
Did you send to him
I hear it by the way; but I will send:
There's not a one of them but in his house
I keep a servant fee'd. I will to-morrow
More shall they speak; for now I am bent to know
Stepp'd in so far that
Strange things I have in head
Which must be acted ere they may be scann'd.
You lack the season of all natures
Come
Is the initiate fear that wants hard use:
We are yet but young in deed.
Exeunt
SCENE V. A Heath.
Thunder. Enter the three Witches meeting HECATE
Why
Have I not reason
To trade and traffic with Macbeth
In riddles and affairs of death;
And I
And
Hath been but for a wayward son
But make amends now: get you gone
Meet me i' the morning: thither he
Will come to know his destiny:
Your vessels and your spells provide
I am for the air; this night I'll spend
Unto a dismal and a fatal end:
Great business must be wrought ere noon:
Upon the corner of the moon
There hangs a vaporous drop profound;
I'll catch it ere it come to ground:
And that distill'd by magic sleights
Shall raise such artificial sprites
As by the strength of their illusion
Shall draw him on to his confusion:
He shall spurn fate
He hopes 'bove wisdom
And you all know
Is mortals' chiefest enemy.
Music and a song within: 'Come away
Hark! I am call'd; my little spirit
Exit
Come
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Forres. The palace.
Enter LENNOX and another Lord
My former speeches have but hit your thoughts
gracious Duncan
Was pitied of Macbeth: marry
And the right-valiant Banquo walk'd too late;
Whom
Who cannot want the thought how monstrous
It was for Malcolm and for Donalbain
To kill their gracious father? damned fact!
How it did grieve Macbeth! did he not straight
In pious rage the two delinquents tear
Was not that nobly done? Ay
For 'twould have anger'd any heart alive
To hear the men deny't. So that
That had he Duncan's sons under his key--
As
should find
What 'twere to kill a father; so should Fleance.
But
His presence at the tyrant's feast
Macduff lives in disgrace: sir
Where he bestows himself?
The son of Duncan
Lives in the English court
Of the most pious Edward with such grace
That the malevolence of fortune nothing
Takes from his high respect: thither Macduff
Is gone to pray the holy king
To wake Northumberland and warlike Siward:
That
To ratify the work--we may again
Give to our tables meat
All which we pine for now: and this report
Hath so exasperate the king that he
Prepares for some attempt of war.
Sent he to Macduff?
He did: and with an absolute 'Sir
The cloudy messenger turns me his back
That clogs me with this answer.'
And that well might
Advise him to a caution
His wisdom can provide. Some holy angel
Fly to the court of England and unfold
His message ere he come
May soon return to this our suffering country
Under a hand accursed!
I'll send my prayers with him.
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. A cavern. In the middle
Thunder. Enter the three Witches
Thrice the brinded cat hath mew'd.
Thrice and once the hedge-pig whined.
Harpier cries 'Tis time
Round about the cauldron go;
In the poison'd entrails throw.
Toad
Days and nights has thirty-one
Swelter'd venom sleeping got
Double
Fire burn
Fillet of a fenny snake
Eye of newt and toe of frog
Double
Fire burn and cauldron bubble.
Scale of dragon
Of the ravin'd salt-sea shark
Silver'd in the moon's eclipse
Ditch-deliver'd by a drab
Add thereto a tiger's chaudron
Double
Fire burn and cauldron bubble.
Cool it with a baboon's blood
Enter HECATE to the other three Witches
O well done! I commend your pains;
And every one shall share i' the gains;
And now about the cauldron sing
Music and a song: 'Black spirits
HECATE retires
By the pricking of my thumbs
Open
Enter MACBETH
How now
What is't you do?
A deed without a name.
I conjure you
Though you untie the winds and let them fight
Against the churches; though the yesty waves
Confound and swallow navigation up;
Though bladed corn be lodged and trees blown down;
Though castles topple on their warders' heads;
Though palaces and pyramids do slope
Their heads to their foundations; though the treasure
Of nature's germens tumble all together
To what I ask you.
Speak.
Demand.
We'll answer.
Say
Call 'em; let me see 'em.
Pour in sow's blood
Her nine farrow; grease that's sweaten
From the murderer's gibbet throw
Into the flame.
Come
Thyself and office deftly show!
Thunder. First Apparition: an armed Head
Tell me
He knows thy thought:
Hear his speech
Macbeth! Macbeth! Macbeth! beware Macduff;
Beware the thane of Fife. Dismiss me. Enough.
Descends
Whate'er thou art
Thou hast harp'd my fear aright: but one
word more
He will not be commanded: here's another
Thunder. Second Apparition: A bloody Child
Macbeth! Macbeth! Macbeth!
Had I three ears
Be bloody
The power of man
Shall harm Macbeth.
Descends
Then live
But yet I'll make assurance double sure
That I may tell pale-hearted fear it lies
Thunder. Third Apparition: a Child crowned
What is this
That rises like the issue of a king
And top of sovereignty?
Listen
Be lion-mettled
Who chafes
Macbeth shall never vanquish'd be until
Great Birnam wood to high Dunsinane hill
Shall come against him.
Descends
That will never be
Who can impress the forest
Unfix his earth-bound root? Sweet bodements! good!
Rebellion's head
Of Birnam rise
Shall live the lease of nature
To time and mortal custom. Yet my heart
Throbs to know one thing: tell me
Can tell so much: shall Banquo's issue ever
Reign in this kingdom?
Seek to know no more.
I will be satisfied: deny me this
Why sinks that cauldron? and what noise is this?
Hautboys
Show!
Show!
Show!
Show his eyes
Come like shadows
A show of Eight Kings
Thou art too like the spirit of Banquo: down!
Thy crown does sear mine eye-balls. And thy hair
A third is like the former. Filthy hags!
Why do you show me this? A fourth! Start
What
Another yet! A seventh! I'll see no more:
And yet the eighth appears
Which shows me many more; and some I see
That two-fold balls and treble scepters carry:
Horrible sight! Now
For the blood-bolter'd Banquo smiles upon me
Apparitions vanish
What
Ay
Stands Macbeth thus amazedly?
Come
I'll charm the air to give a sound
That this great king may kindly say
Music. The witches dance and then vanish
Where are they? Gone? Let this pernicious hour
Stand aye accursed in the calendar!
Come in
Enter LENNOX
What's your grace's will?
Saw you the weird sisters?
No
Came they not by you?
No
Infected be the air whereon they ride;
And damn'd all those that trust them! I did hear
The galloping of horse: who was't came by?
'Tis two or three
Macduff is fled to England.
Fled to England!
Ay
Time
The flighty purpose never is o'ertook
Unless the deed go with it; from this moment
The very firstlings of my heart shall be
The firstlings of my hand. And even now
The castle of Macduff I will surprise;
Seize upon Fife; give to the edge o' the sword
His wife
That trace him in his line. No boasting like a fool;
This deed I'll do before this purpose cool.
But no more sights!--Where are these gentlemen?
Come
Exeunt
SCENE II. Fife. Macduff's castle.
Enter LADY MACDUFF
What had he done
You must have patience
He had none:
His flight was madness: when our actions do not
You know not
Whether it was his wisdom or his fear.
Wisdom! to leave his wife
From whence himself does fly? He loves us not;
He wants the natural touch: for the poor wren
All is the fear and nothing is the love;
As little is the wisdom
So runs against all reason.
My dearest coz
The fits o' the season. I dare not speak
much further;
But cruel are the times
And do not know ourselves
From what we fear
Each way and move. I take my leave of you:
Shall not be long but I'll be here again:
Things at the worst will cease
To what they were before. My pretty cousin
Father'd he is
I am so much a fool
I take my leave at once.
Exit
Sirrah
And what will you do now? How will you live?
As birds do
What
With what I get
Poor bird! thou'ldst never fear the net nor lime
Why should I
My father is not dead
Yes
Nay
Why
Then you'll buy 'em to sell again.
Thou speak'st with all thy wit: and yet
Was my father a traitor
Ay
What is a traitor?
Why
And be all traitors that do so?
Every one that does so is a traitor
And must they all be hanged that swear and lie?
Every one.
Who must hang them?
Why
Then the liars and swearers are fools
the honest men and hang up them.
Now
But how wilt thou do for a father?
If he were dead
him: if you would not
that I should quickly have a new father.
Poor prattler
Enter a Messenger
Bless you
I doubt some danger does approach you nearly:
If you will take a homely man's advice
To fright you thus
To do worse to you were fell cruelty
I dare abide no longer.
Exit
Whither should I fly?
I have done no harm. But I remember now
I am in this earthly world; where to do harm
Is often laudable
Accounted dangerous folly: why then
Enter Murderers
What are these faces?
Where is your husband?
I hope
Where such as thou mayst find him.
He's a traitor.
Thou liest
What
Stabbing him
Young fry of treachery!
He has kill'd me
Run away
Dies
Exit LADY MACDUFF
SCENE III. England. Before the King's palace.
Enter MALCOLM and MACDUFF
Let us seek out some desolate shade
Weep our sad bosoms empty.
Let us rather
Hold fast the mortal sword
Bestride our down-fall'n birthdom: each new morn
New widows howl
Strike heaven on the face
As if it felt with Scotland and yell'd out
Like syllable of dolour.
What I believe I'll wail
What you have spoke
This tyrant
He hath not touch'd you yet. I am young;
but something
You may deserve of him through me
To offer up a weak poor innocent lamb
To appease an angry god.
I am not treacherous.
But Macbeth is.
A good and virtuous nature may recoil
In an imperial charge. But I shall crave
your pardon;
That which you are my thoughts cannot transpose:
Angels are bright still
Though all things foul would wear the brows of grace
I have lost my hopes.
Perchance even there where I did find my doubts.
Why in that rawness left you wife and child
Bleed
Great tyranny! lay thou thy basis sure
thy wrongs;
The title is affeer'd! Fare thee well
I would not be the villain that thou think'st
For the whole space that's in the tyrant's grasp
Be not offended:
I speak not as in absolute fear of you.
I think our country sinks beneath the yoke;
It weeps
Is added to her wounds: I think withal
There would be hands uplifted in my right;
And here from gracious England have I offer
Of goodly thousands: but
Shall have more vices than it had before
What should he be?
It is myself I mean: in whom I know
All the particulars of vice so grafted
That
Will seem as pure as snow
Esteem him as a lamb
With my confineless harms.
Not in the legions
Of horrid hell can come a devil more damn'd
In evils to top Macbeth.
I grant him bloody
That has a name: but there's no bottom
The cistern of my lust
All continent impediments would o'erbear
That did oppose my will: better Macbeth
Than such an one to reign.
Boundless intemperance
In nature is a tyranny; it hath been
The untimely emptying of the happy throne
And fall of many kings. But fear not yet
To take upon you what is yours: you may
Convey your pleasures in a spacious plenty
We have willing dames enough: there cannot be
That vulture in you
As will to greatness dedicate themselves
With this there grows
In my most ill-composed affection such
A stanchless avarice that
And my more-having would be as a sauce
To make me hunger more; that I should forge
Quarrels unjust against the good and loyal
This avarice
Sticks deeper
Than summer-seeming lust
The sword of our slain kings: yet do not fear;
Scotland hath foisons to fill up your will.
Of your mere own: all these are portable
But I have none: the king-becoming graces
In the division of each several crime
Pour the sweet milk of concord into hell
All unity on earth.
O Scotland
If such a one be fit to govern
I am as I have spoken.
Fit to govern!
No
By his own interdiction stands accursed
Was a most sainted king: the queen that bore thee
These evils thou repeat'st upon thyself
Have banish'd me from Scotland. O my breast
Macduff
Wiped the black scruples
To thy good truth and honour. Devilish Macbeth
By many of these trains hath sought to win me
Into his power
From over-credulous haste: but God above
Deal between thee and me! for even now
I put myself to thy direction
Unspeak mine own detraction
The taints and blames I laid upon myself
Unknown to woman
The devil to his fellow and delight
No less in truth than life: my first false speaking
Was this upon myself: what I am truly
Whither indeed
Now we'll together; and the chance of goodness
Be like our warranted quarrel! Why are you silent?
Such welcome and unwelcome things at once
'Tis hard to reconcile.
Enter a Doctor
Well; more anon.--Comes the king forth
Ay
That stay his cure: their malady convinces
The great assay of art; but at his touch--
Such sanctity hath heaven given his hand--
They presently amend.
I thank you
Exit Doctor
What's the disease he means?
'Tis call'd the evil:
A most miraculous work in this good king;
Which often
The healing benediction. With this strange virtue
Enter ROSS
See
My countryman; but yet I know him not.
My ever-gentle cousin
I know him now. Good God
The means that makes us strangers!
Sir
Stands Scotland where it did?
Alas
Almost afraid to know itself. It cannot
Be call'd our mother
Where sighs and groans and shrieks that rend the air
Are made
A modern ecstasy; the dead man's knell
Is there scarce ask'd for who; and good men's lives
Expire before the flowers in their caps
O
Too nice
What's the newest grief?
That of an hour's age doth hiss the speaker:
Each minute teems a new one.
How does my wife?
Why
And all my children?
Well too.
The tyrant has not batter'd at their peace?
No; they were well at peace when I did leave 'em.
But not a niggard of your speech: how goes't?
When I came hither to transport the tidings
Of many worthy fellows that were out;
Which was to my belief witness'd the rather
Now is the time of help; your eye in Scotland
Would create soldiers
Be't their comfort
We are coming thither: gracious England hath
Lent us good Siward and ten thousand men;
An older and a better soldier none
That Christendom gives out.
Would I could answer
This comfort with the like! But I have words
That would be howl'd out in the desert air
What concern they?
The general cause? or is it a fee-grief
Due to some single breast?
No mind that's honest
But in it shares some woe; though the main part
Pertains to you alone.
If it be mine
Let not your ears despise my tongue for ever
That ever yet they heard.
Hum! I guess at it.
Your castle is surprised; your wife and babes
Savagely slaughter'd: to relate the manner
Merciful heaven!
What
Give sorrow words: the grief that does not speak
Whispers the o'er-fraught heart and bids it break.
My children too?
Wife
That could be found.
And I must be from thence!
My wife kill'd too?
I have said.
Be comforted:
Let's make us medicines of our great revenge
He has no children. All my pretty ones?
Did you say all? O hell-kite! All?
What
At one fell swoop?
Dispute it like a man.
I shall do so;
But I must also feel it as a man:
I cannot but remember such things were
Be this the whetstone of your sword: let grief
Convert to anger; blunt not the heart
O
And braggart with my tongue! But
Bring thou this fiend of Scotland and myself;
Within my sword's length set him; if he 'scape
This tune goes manly.
Come
Our lack is nothing but our leave; Macbeth
Is ripe for shaking
Put on their instruments. Receive what cheer you may:
The night is long that never finds the day.
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. Dunsinane. Ante-room in the castle.
Enter a Doctor of Physic and a Waiting-Gentlewoman
I have two nights watched with you
no truth in your report. When was it she last walked?
Since his majesty went into the field
her rise from her bed
her
return to bed; yet all this while in a most fast sleep.
A great perturbation in nature
the benefit of sleep
watching! In this slumbery agitation
walking and other actual performances
time
That
You may to me: and 'tis most meet you should.
Neither to you nor any one; having no witness to
confirm my speech.
Enter LADY MACBETH
Lo you
and
How came she by that light?
Why
continually; 'tis her command.
You see
Ay
What is it she does now? Look
It is an accustomed action with her
washing her hands: I have known her continue in
this a quarter of an hour.
Yet here's a spot.
Hark! she speaks: I will set down what comes from
her
Out
lord
fear who knows it
account?--Yet who would have thought the old man
to have had so much blood in him.
Do you mark that?
The thane of Fife had a wife: where is she now?--
What
that
this starting.
Go to
She has spoke what she should not
that: heaven knows what she has known.
Here's the smell of the blood still: all the
perfumes of Arabia will not sweeten this little
hand. Oh
What a sigh is there! The heart is sorely charged.
I would not have such a heart in my bosom for the
dignity of the whole body.
Well
Pray God it be
This disease is beyond my practise: yet I have known
those which have walked in their sleep who have died
holily in their beds.
Wash your hands
pale.--I tell you yet again
cannot come out on's grave.
Even so?
To bed
come
done cannot be undone.--To bed
Exit
Will she go now to bed?
Directly.
Foul whisperings are abroad: unnatural deeds
Do breed unnatural troubles: infected minds
To their deaf pillows will discharge their secrets:
More needs she the divine than the physician.
God
Remove from her the means of all annoyance
My mind she has mated
I think
Good night
Exeunt
SCENE II. The country near Dunsinane.
Drum and colours. Enter MENTEITH
The English power is near
Revenges burn in them; for their dear causes
Would to the bleeding and the grim alarm
Excite the mortified man.
Near Birnam wood
Shall we well meet them; that way are they coming.
Who knows if Donalbain be with his brother?
For certain
Of all the gentry: there is Siward's son
Protest their first of manhood.
What does the tyrant?
Great Dunsinane he strongly fortifies:
Some say he's mad; others that lesser hate him
Do call it valiant fury: but
Within the belt of rule.
Now does he feel
His secret murders sticking on his hands;
Now minutely revolts upbraid his faith-breach;
Those he commands move only in command
Hang loose about him
Upon a dwarfish thief.
Who then shall blame
His pester'd senses to recoil and start
Itself for being there?
Well
Meet we the medicine of the sickly weal
Each drop of us.
Or so much as it needs
Make we our march towards Birnam.
Exeunt
SCENE III. Dunsinane. A room in the castle.
Enter MACBETH
Bring me no more reports; let them fly all:
Till Birnam wood remove to Dunsinane
Was he not born of woman? The spirits that know
All mortal consequences have pronounced me thus:
'Fear not
Shall e'er have power upon thee.' Then fly
The mind I sway by and the heart I bear
Shall never sag with doubt nor shake with fear.
Enter a Servant
The devil damn thee black
Where got'st thou that goose look?
There is ten thousand--
Geese
Soldiers
Go prick thy face
Death of thy soul! those linen cheeks of thine
Are counsellors to fear. What soldiers
The English force
Take thy face hence.
Exit Servant
Seyton!--I am sick at heart
Will cheer me ever
I have lived long enough: my way of life
Is fall'n into the sear
And that which should accompany old age
Enter SEYTON
What is your gracious pleasure?
What news more?
All is confirm'd
I'll fight till from my bones my flesh be hack'd.
Give me my armour.
'Tis not needed yet.
I'll put it on.
Send out more horses; skirr the country round;
Hang those that talk of fear. Give me mine armour.
How does your patient
Not so sick
Cure her of that.
Canst thou not minister to a mind diseased
And with some sweet oblivious antidote
Cleanse the stuff'd bosom of that perilous stuff
Which weighs upon the heart?
Therein the patient
Must minister to himself.
Throw physic to the dogs; I'll none of it.
Come
Seyton
Come
The water of my land
What rhubarb
Ay
Makes us hear something.
Bring it after me.
I will not be afraid of death and bane
[Aside]  Were I from Dunsinane away and clear
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Country near Birnam wood.
Drum and colours. Enter MALCOLM
Cousins
That chambers will be safe.
We doubt it nothing.
What wood is this before us?
The wood of Birnam.
Let every soldier hew him down a bough
And bear't before him: thereby shall we shadow
The numbers of our host and make discovery
Err in report of us.
It shall be done.
We learn no other but the confident tyrant
Keeps still in Dunsinane
Our setting down before 't.
'Tis his main hope:
For where there is advantage to be given
Whose hearts are absent too.
Let our just censures
Attend the true event
Industrious soldiership.
The time approaches
That will with due decision make us know
What we shall say we have and what we owe.
Thoughts speculative their unsure hopes relate
Towards which advance the war.
Exeunt
SCENE V. Dunsinane. Within the castle.
Enter MACBETH
Hang out our banners on the outward walls;
The cry is still 'They come:' our castle's strength
Will laugh a siege to scorn: here let them lie
Till famine and the ague eat them up:
Were they not forced with those that should be ours
A cry of women within
What is that noise?
It is the cry of women
Exit
I have almost forgot the taste of fears;
The time has been
To hear a night-shriek; and my fell of hair
Would at a dismal treatise rouse and stir
As life were in't: I have supp'd full with horrors;
Direness
Cannot once start me.
Re-enter SEYTON
Wherefore was that cry?
The queen
She should have died hereafter;
There would have been a time for such a word.
To-morrow
To the last syllable of recorded time
The way to dusty death. Out
Life's but a walking shadow
That struts and frets his hour upon the stage
And then is heard no more: it is a tale
Told by an idiot
Enter a Messenger
Thou comest to use thy tongue; thy story quickly.
Gracious my lord
Well
As I did stand my watch upon the hill
Liar and slave!
Let me endure your wrath
Within this three mile may you see it coming;
I say
If thou speak'st false
I pull in resolution
To doubt the equivocation of the fiend
That lies like truth: 'Fear not
Do come to Dunsinane:'  and now a wood
Comes toward Dunsinane. Arm
If this which he avouches does appear
I gin to be aweary of the sun
Ring the alarum-bell! Blow
At least we'll die with harness on our back.
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Dunsinane. Before the castle.
Drum and colours. Enter MALCOLM
Now near enough: your leafy screens throw down.
And show like those you are. You
Shall take upon 's what else remains to do
Fare you well.
Do we but find the tyrant's power to-night
Make all our trumpets speak; give them all breath
Exeunt
SCENE VII. Another part of the field.
Alarums. Enter MACBETH
They have tied me to a stake; I cannot fly
That was not born of woman? Such a one
Am I to fear
Enter YOUNG SIWARD
What is thy name?
Thou'lt be afraid to hear it.
No; though thou call'st thyself a hotter name
Than any is in hell.
My name's Macbeth.
The devil himself could not pronounce a title
More hateful to mine ear.
No
Thou liest
I'll prove the lie thou speak'st.
They fight and YOUNG SIWARD is slain
Thou wast born of woman
But swords I smile at
Exit
Alarums. Enter MACDUFF
That way the noise is. Tyrant
If thou be'st slain and with no stroke of mine
I cannot strike at wretched kerns
Are hired to bear their staves: either thou
I sheathe again undeeded. There thou shouldst be;
By this great clatter
Seems bruited. Let me find him
And more I beg not.
Exit. Alarums
Enter MALCOLM and SIWARD
This way
The tyrant's people on both sides do fight;
The noble thanes do bravely in the war;
The day almost itself professes yours
We have met with foes
That strike beside us.
Enter
Exeunt. Alarums
SCENE VIII. Another part of the field.
Enter MACBETH
Why should I play the Roman fool
On mine own sword? whiles I see lives
Do better upon them.
Enter MACDUFF
Turn
Of all men else I have avoided thee:
But get thee back; my soul is too much charged
With blood of thine already.
I have no words:
My voice is in my sword: thou bloodier villain
Than terms can give thee out!
They fight
Thou losest labour:
As easy mayst thou the intrenchant air
With thy keen sword impress as make me bleed:
Let fall thy blade on vulnerable crests;
I bear a charmed life
Despair thy charm;
And let the angel whom thou still hast served
Tell thee
Untimely ripp'd.
Accursed be that tongue that tells me so
And be these juggling fiends no more believed
That keep the word of promise to our ear
Then yield thee
We'll have thee
I will not yield
Though Birnam wood be come to Dunsinane
I throw my warlike shield. Lay on
Exeunt
Retreat. Flourish. Enter
I would the friends we miss were safe arrived.
Some must go off: and yet
Macduff is missing
Your son
He only lived but till he was a man;
The which no sooner had his prowess confirm'd
In the unshrinking station where he fought
Then he is dead?
Ay
Must not be measured by his worth
It hath no end.
Had he his hurts before?
Ay
Why then
Had I as many sons as I have hairs
And so
He's worth more sorrow
He's worth no more
They say he parted well
And so
Re-enter MACDUFF
Hail
The usurper's cursed head: the time is free:
I see thee compass'd with thy kingdom's pearl
Whose voices I desire aloud with mine:
Hail
Hail
Flourish
We shall not spend a large expense of time
Before we reckon with your several loves
In such an honour named. What's more to do
That fled the snares of watchful tyranny;
Producing forth the cruel ministers
Of this dead butcher and his fiend-like queen
Took off her life; this
That calls upon us
So
Flourish. Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. An apartment in the DUKE'S palace.
Enter DUKE VINCENTIO
Escalus.
My lord.
Of government the properties to unfold
Since I am put to know that your own science
Exceeds
My strength can give you: then no more remains
For common justice
As art and practise hath enriched any
That we remember. There is our commission
Exit an Attendant
What figure of us think you he will bear?
For you must know
Elected him our absence to supply
Of our own power: what think you of it?
If any in Vienna be of worth
To undergo such ample grace and honour
Look where he comes.
Enter ANGELO
Always obedient to your grace's will
Angelo
Fully unfold. Thyself and thy belongings
Are not thine own so proper as to waste
Thyself upon thy virtues
Heaven doth with us as we with torches do
Did not go forth of us
As if we had them not. Spirits are not finely touch'd
But to fine issues
The smallest scruple of her excellence
But
Herself the glory of a creditor
To one that can my part in him advertise;
Hold therefore
In our remove be thou at full ourself;
Mortality and mercy in Vienna
Live in thy tongue and heart: old Escalus
Take thy commission.
Now
Be stamp'd upon it.
No more evasion:
We have with a leaven'd and prepared choice
Proceeded to you; therefore take your honours.
Our haste from hence is of so quick condition
That it prefers itself and leaves unquestion'd
Matters of needful value. We shall write to you
What doth befall you here. So
To the hopeful execution do I leave you
Of your commissions.
Yet give leave
My haste may not admit it;
Nor need you
With any scruple; your scope is as mine own
So to enforce or qualify the laws
As to your soul seems good. Give me your hand:
I'll privily away. I love the people
Through it do well
Their loud applause and Aves vehement;
Nor do I think the man of safe discretion
That does affect it. Once more
The heavens give safety to your purposes!
Lead forth and bring you back in happiness!
I thank you. Fare you well.
Exit
I shall desire you
To have free speech with you; and it concerns me
To look into the bottom of my place:
A power I have
I am not yet instructed.
'Tis so with me. Let us withdraw together
Touching that point.
I'll wait upon your honour.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A Street.
Enter LUCIO and two Gentlemen
If the duke with the other dukes come not to
composition with the King of Hungary
the dukes fall upon the king.
Heaven grant us its peace
Hungary's!
Amen.
Thou concludest like the sanctimonious pirate
went to sea with the Ten Commandments
one out of the table.
'Thou shalt not steal'?
Ay
Why
all the rest from their functions: they put forth
to steal. There's not a soldier of us all
the thanksgiving before meat
well that prays for peace.
I never heard any soldier dislike it.
I believe thee; for I think thou never wast where
grace was said.
No? a dozen times at least.
What
In any proportion or in any language.
I think
Ay
controversy: as
wicked villain
Well
I grant; as there may between the lists and the
velvet. Thou art the list.
And thou the velvet: thou art good velvet; thou'rt
a three-piled piece
be a list of an English kersey as be piled
art piled
feelingly now?
I think thou dost; and
feeling of thy speech: I will
confession
live
I think I have done myself wrong
Yes
Behold
have purchased as many diseases under her roof as come to--
To what
Judge.
To three thousand dolours a year.
Ay
A French crown more.
Thou art always figuring diseases in me; but thou
art full of error; I am sound.
Nay
things that are hollow: thy bones are hollow;
impiety has made a feast of thee.
Enter MISTRESS OVERDONE
How now! which of your hips has the most profound sciatica?
Well
to prison was worth five thousand of you all.
Who's that
Marry
Claudio to prison? 'tis not so.
Nay
him carried away; and
three days his head to be chopped off.
But
Art thou sure of this?
I am too sure of it: and it is for getting Madam
Julietta with child.
Believe me
hours since
promise-keeping.
Besides
speech we had to such a purpose.
But
Away! let's go learn the truth of it.
Exeunt LUCIO and Gentlemen
Thus
with the gallows and what with poverty
custom-shrunk.
Enter POMPEY
How now! what's the news with you?
Yonder man is carried to prison.
Well; what has he done?
A woman.
But what's his offence?
Groping for trouts in a peculiar river.
What
No
not heard of the proclamation
What proclamation
All houses in the suburbs of Vienna must be plucked down.
And what shall become of those in the city?
They shall stand for seed: they had gone down too
But shall all our houses of resort in the suburbs be
pulled down?
To the ground
Why
What shall become of me?
Come; fear you not: good counsellors lack no
clients: though you change your place
change your trade; I'll be your tapster still.
Courage! there will be pity taken on you: you that
have worn your eyes almost out in the service
will be considered.
What's to do here
Here comes Signior Claudio
prison; and there's Madam Juliet.
Exeunt
Enter Provost
Fellow
Bear me to prison
I do it not in evil disposition
Thus can the demigod Authority
Make us pay down for our offence by weight
The words of heaven; on whom it will
On whom it will not
Re-enter LUCIO and two Gentlemen
Why
From too much liberty
As surfeit is the father of much fast
Turns to restraint. Our natures do pursue
If could speak so wisely under an arrest
send for certain of my creditors: and yet
the truth
as the morality of imprisonment. What's thy
offence
What but to speak of would offend again.
What
No.
Lechery?
Call it so.
Away
One word
A hundred
Is lechery so look'd after?
Thus stands it with me: upon a true contract
I got possession of Julietta's bed:
You know the lady; she is fast my wife
Of outward order: this we came not to
Remaining in the coffer of her friends
Till time had made them for us. But it chances
The stealth of our most mutual entertainment
With character too gross is writ on Juliet.
With child
Unhappily
And the new deputy now for the duke--
Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newness
A horse whereon the governor doth ride
He can command
Whether the tyranny be in his place
Awakes me all the enrolled penalties
Which have
So long that nineteen zodiacs have gone round
And none of them been worn; and
Freshly on me: 'tis surely for a name.
I warrant it is: and thy head stands so tickle on
thy shoulders that a milkmaid
him.
I have done so
I prithee
This day my sister should the cloister enter
And there receive her approbation:
Acquaint her with the danger of my state:
Implore her
To the strict deputy; bid herself assay him:
I have great hope in that; for in her youth
There is a prone and speechless dialect
When she will play with reason and discourse
I pray she may; as well for the encouragement of the
like
imposition
would be sorry should be thus foolishly lost at a
game of tick-tack. I'll to her.
I thank you
Within two hours.
Come
Exeunt
SCENE III. A monastery.
Enter DUKE VINCENTIO and FRIAR THOMAS
No
Believe not that the dribbling dart of love
Can pierce a complete bosom. Why I desire thee
To give me secret harbour
More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends
Of burning youth.
May your grace speak of it?
My holy sir
How I have ever loved the life removed
And held in idle price to haunt assemblies
Where youth
I have deliver'd to Lord Angelo
For so I have strew'd it in the common ear
Gladly
We have strict statutes and most biting laws.
The needful bits and curbs to headstrong weeds
Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave
For terror
Becomes more mock'd than fear'd; so our decrees
And liberty plucks justice by the nose;
The baby beats the nurse
Goes all decorum.
It rested in your grace
To unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased:
And it in you more dreadful would have seem'd
Than in Lord Angelo.
I do fear
Sith 'twas my fault to give the people scope
For what I bid them do: for we bid this be done
And not the punishment. Therefore indeed
Who may
To do in slander. And to behold his sway
How I may formally in person bear me
Like a true friar. More reasons for this action
At our more leisure shall I render you;
Only
Stands at a guard with envy; scarce confesses
That his blood flows
Is more to bread than stone: hence shall we see
Exeunt
SCENE IV. A nunnery.
Enter ISABELLA and FRANCISCA
And have you nuns no farther privileges?
Are not these large enough?
Yes
But rather wishing a more strict restraint
Upon the sisterhood
[Within]  Ho! Peace be in this place!
Who's that which calls?
It is a man's voice. Gentle Isabella
You may
When you have vow'd
But in the presence of the prioress:
Then
He calls again; I pray you
Exit
Peace and prosperity! Who is't that calls
Enter LUCIO
Hail
Proclaim you are no less! Can you so stead me
As bring me to the sight of Isabella
To her unhappy brother Claudio?
Why 'her unhappy brother'? let me ask
I am that Isabella and his sister.
Gentle and fair
Not to be weary with you
Woe me! for what?
For that which
He hath got his friend with child.
Sir
It is true.
I would not--though 'tis my familiar sin
With maids to seem the lapwing and to jest
I hold you as a thing ensky'd and sainted.
By your renouncement an immortal spirit
You do blaspheme the good in mocking me.
Do not believe it. Fewness and truth
Your brother and his lover have embraced:
As those that feed grow full
That from the seedness the bare fallow brings
To teeming foison
Expresseth his full tilth and husbandry.
Some one with child by him? My cousin Juliet?
Is she your cousin?
Adoptedly; as school-maids change their names
By vain though apt affection.
She it is.
O
This is the point.
The duke is very strangely gone from hence;
Bore many gentlemen
By those that know the very nerves of state
From his true-meant design. Upon his place
Is very snow-broth; one who never feels
The wanton stings and motions of the sense
With profits of the mind
He--to give fear to use and liberty
Falls into forfeit: he arrests him on it;
And follows close the rigour of the statute
To soften Angelo: and that's my pith of business
'Twixt you and your poor brother.
Doth he so seek his life?
Has censured him
Already; and
A warrant for his execution.
Alas! what poor ability's in me
To do him good?
Assay the power you have.
My power? Alas
Our doubts are traitors
And make us lose the good we oft might win
By fearing to attempt. Go to Lord Angelo
As they themselves would owe them.
I'll see what I can do.
But speedily.
I will about it straight;
No longer staying but to give the mother
Notice of my affair. I humbly thank you:
Commend me to my brother: soon at night
I'll send him certain word of my success.
I take my leave of you.
Good sir
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. A hall In ANGELO's house.
Enter ANGELO
We must not make a scarecrow of the law
Their perch and not their terror.
Ay
Let us be keen
Whom I would save
Let but your honour know
Could have attain'd the effect of your own purpose
Err'd in this point which now you censure him
'Tis one thing to be tempted
Guiltier than him they try. What's open made to justice
That thieves do pass on thieves? 'Tis very pregnant
Because we see it; but what we do not see
We tread upon
You may not so extenuate his offence
For I have had such faults; but rather tell me
Be it as your wisdom will.
Where is the provost?
Here
See that Claudio
Be executed by nine to-morrow morning:
Bring him his confessor
For that's the utmost of his pilgrimage.
Exit Provost
[Aside]  Well
Some rise by sin
Some run from brakes of ice
And some condemned for a fault alone.
Enter ELBOW
Come
a commonweal that do nothing but use their abuses in
common houses
How now
If it Please your honour
constable
justice
honour two notorious benefactors.
Benefactors? Well; what benefactors are they? are
they not malefactors?
If it? please your honour
are: but precise villains they are
of; and void of all profanation in the world that
good Christians ought to have.
This comes off well; here's a wise officer.
Go to: what quality are they of? Elbow is your
name? why dost thou not speak
He cannot
What are you
He
serves a bad woman; whose house
say
professes a hot-house
How know you that?
My wife

Ay

I say
she

Marry
cardinally given

Ay
spit in his face
Sir

man; prove it.

Sir

distant time stood
dish of some three-pence; your honours have seen

No

Mistress Elbow

Who is it that hath died for this offence?
There's many have committed it.
[Aside to ISABELLA]           Ay
The law hath not been dead
Those many had not dared to do that evil
Had answer'd for his deed: now 'tis awake
Takes note of what is done; and
Yet show some pity.
I show it most of all when I show justice;
For then I pity those I do not know
And do him right that
Your brother dies to-morrow; be content.
So you must be the first that gives this sentence
To have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous
To use it like a giant.
[Aside to ISABELLA]   That's well said.
Could great men thunder
As Jove himself does
Would use his heaven for thunder;
Nothing but thunder! Merciful Heaven
Split'st the unwedgeable and gnarled oak
Than the soft myrtle: but man
As make the angels weep; who

will relent;

When judges steal themselves. What
O cunning enemy

Subdues me quite. Even till now

SCENE III. A room in a prison.
Enter
Hail to you
I am the provost. What's your will
Bound by my charity and my blest order
Here in the prison. Do me the common right
To let me see them and to make me know
The nature of their crimes
To them accordingly.
I would do more than that
Enter JULIET
Look
And he that got it
More fit to do another such offence
Than die for this.
When must he die?
As I do think

And you shall be conducted.
Repent you
I do; and bear the shame most patiently.
I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience
I'll gladly learn.
Love you the man that wrong'd you?
Yes

Mutually.

I do confess it
'Tis meet so

Must die to-morrow! O injurious love
Is still a dying horror!
'Tis pity of him.

SCENE IV. A room in ANGELO's house.
Enter ANGELO
When I would pray and think
To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words;
Whilst my invention
And in my heart the strong and swelling evil
Of my conception. The state
Is like a good thing
To thy false seeming! Blood
Let's write good angel on the devil's horn:
'Tis not the devil's crest.
Enter a Servant
How now! who's there?
One Isabel
Teach her the way.
Exit Servant
O heavens!
Why does my blood thus muster to my heart
Of necessary fitness?
So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons;
Come all to help him
By which he should revive: and even so
The general
Crowd to his presence
Must needs appear offence.
Enter ISABELLA
How now
I am come to know your pleasure.
That you might know it
Than to demand what 'tis. Your brother cannot live.
Even so. Heaven keep your honour!
Yet may he live awhile; and
Under your sentence?
Yea.
When
That his soul sicken not.
Ha! fie
To pardon him that hath from nature stolen
A man already made
Their saucy sweetness that do coin heaven's image
In stamps that are forbid: 'tis all as easy
Falsely to take away a life true made
As to put metal in restrained means
To make a false one.
'Tis set down so in heaven
Say you so? then I shall pose you quickly.
Which had you rather
Now took your brother's life; or
As she that he hath stain'd?
Sir
I talk not of your soul: our compell'd sins
Stand more for number than for accompt.
How say you?
Nay
Against the thing I say. Answer to this:
I
Might there not be a charity in sin
To save this brother's life?
Please you to do't
Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul
That I do beg his life
To have it added to the faults of mine
Nay
Your sense pursues not mine: either you are ignorant
Let me be ignorant
Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright
When it doth tax itself; as these black masks
Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder
Than beauty could
To be received plain
Your brother is to die.
So.
And his offence is so
True.
Admit no other way to save his life
As I subscribe not that
Of the all-building law; and that there were
No earthly mean to save him
You must lay down the treasures of your body
To this supposed
What would you do?
As much for my poor brother as myself:
That is
That longing have been sick for
My body up to shame.
Then must your brother die.
And 'twere the cheaper way:
Better it were a brother died at once
Were not you then as cruel as the sentence
That you have slander'd so?
Ignomy in ransom and free pardon
Are of two houses: lawful mercy
Is nothing kin to foul redemption.
You seem'd of late to make the law a tyrant;
And rather proved the sliding of your brother
A merriment than a vice.
O
I something do excuse the thing I hate
We are all frail.
Else let my brother die
Owe and succeed thy weakness.
Nay
Ay
Which are as easy broke as they make forms.
Women! Help Heaven! men their creation mar
In profiting by them. Nay
For we are soft as our complexions are
I think it well:
And from this testimony of your own sex
Since I suppose we are made to be no stronger
Than faults may shake our frames
I do arrest your words. Be that you are
If you be one
By all external warrants
I have no tongue but one: gentle my lord
Plainly conceive
My brother did love Juliet
He shall not
I know your virtue hath a licence in't
Believe me
Ha! little honour to be much believed
I will proclaim thee
Sign me a present pardon for my brother
What man thou art.
Who will believe thee
My unsoil'd name
And smell of calumny. I have begun
Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite;
Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes
By yielding up thy body to my will;
Or else he must not only die the death
To lingering sufferance. Answer me to-morrow
Exit
To whom should I complain? Did I tell this
Bidding the law make court'sy to their will:
Hooking both right and wrong to the appetite
Though he hath fallen by prompture of the blood
That
On twenty bloody blocks
To such abhorr'd pollution.
Then
More than our brother is our chastity.
I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request
Exit
ACT III
SCENE I. A room in the prison.
Enter DUKE VINCENTIO disguised as before
So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?
The miserable have no other medicine
But only hope:
I've hope to live
Be absolute for death; either death or life
Shall thereby be the sweeter. Reason thus with life:
If I do lose thee
That none but fools would keep: a breath thou art
For him thou labour'st by thy flight to shun
And yet runn'st toward him still. Thou art not noble;
For all the accommodations that thou bear'st
Are nursed by baseness. Thou'rt by no means valiant;
For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork
Of a poor worm. Thy best of rest is sleep
Thy death
For thou exist'st on many a thousand grains
That issue out of dust. Happy thou art not;
For what thou hast not
For thy complexion shifts to strange effects
For
For thine own bowels
Becomes as aged
Of palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich
That bears the name of life? Yet in this life
Lie hid moe thousand deaths: yet death we fear
I humbly thank you.
To sue to live
And
[Within]  What
Who's there? come in: the wish deserves a welcome.
Dear sir
Most holy sir

And very welcome. Look
Provost
As many as you please.

Exeunt DUKE VINCENTIO and Provost
Now
Why
Lord Angelo
Therefore your best appointment make with speed;
To-morrow you set on.
Is there no remedy?
None
But is there any?
Yes
There is a devilish mercy in the judge
Perpetual durance?
Ay
But in what nature?
In such a one as
Let me know the point.
O
Than a perpetual honour. Darest thou die?
The sense of death is most in apprehension;
And the poor beetle
As when a giant dies.
Why give you me this shame?
Think you I can a resolution fetch
From flowery tenderness? If I must die
There spake my brother; there my father's grave
Did utter forth a voice. Yes
Thou art too noble to conserve a life
In base appliances. This outward-sainted deputy
Nips youth i' the head and follies doth emmew
As falcon doth the fowl
His filth within being cast
A pond as deep as hell.
The prenzie Angelo!
O
In prenzie guards! Dost thou think
If I would yield him my virginity
O heavens! it cannot be.
Yes
That I should do what I abhor to name
Thou shalt not do't.
O
As frankly as a pin.
Thanks
Be ready
Yes. Has he affections in him
Which is the least?
If it were damnable
Be perdurably fined? O Isabel!
What says my brother?
Death is a fearful thing.
And shamed life a hateful.
Ay
To lie in cold obstruction and to rot;
This sensible warm motion to become
A kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit
To bathe in fiery floods
In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice;
To be imprison'd in the viewless winds
The pendent world; or to be worse than worst
Of those that lawless and incertain thought
Imagine howling: 'tis too horrible!
The weariest and most loathed worldly life
That age
Can lay on nature is a paradise
To what we fear of death.
Alas
Sweet sister
What sin you do to save a brother's life
That it becomes a virtue.
O you beast!
O faithless coward! O dishonest wretch!
Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice?
Is't not a kind of incest
From thine own sister's shame? What should I think?
Heaven shield my mother play'd my father fair!
For such a warped slip of wilderness
Ne'er issued from his blood. Take my defiance!
Die
Reprieve thee from thy fate
I'll pray a thousand prayers for thy death
Nay
O
Thy sin's not accidental
Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd:
'Tis best thou diest quickly.
O hear me
Re-enter DUKE VINCENTIO
Vouchsafe a word
What is your will?
Might you dispense with your leisure
by have some speech with you: the satisfaction I
would require is likewise your own benefit.
I have no superfluous leisure; my stay must be
stolen out of other affairs; but I will attend you awhile.
Walks apart
Son
and your sister. Angelo had never the purpose to
corrupt her; only he hath made an essay of her
virtue to practise his judgment with the disposition
of natures: she
glad to receive. I am confessor to Angelo
know this to be true; therefore prepare yourself to
death: do not satisfy your resolution with hopes
that are fallible: tomorrow you must die; go to
your knees and make ready.
Let me ask my sister pardon. I am so out of love
with life that I will sue to be rid of it.
Hold you there: farewell.

That now you are come

It is a rupture that you may easily heal: and the

This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance

Some report a sea-maid spawned him; some

certain that when he makes water his urine is

motion generative; that's infallible.
