duke
Fridays. He's not past it yet
bread and garlic: say that I said so. Farewell.
Exit
No might nor greatness in mortality
Can censure 'scape; back-wounding calumny
The whitest virtue strikes. What king so strong
Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue?
But who comes here?
Enter ESCALUS
Go; away with her to prison!
Good my lord
a merciful man; good my lord.
Double and treble admonition
the same kind! This would make mercy swear and play
the tyrant.
A bawd of eleven years' continuance
your honour.
My lord
Mistress Kate Keepdown was with child by him in the
duke's time; he promised her marriage: his child
is a year and a quarter old
I have kept it myself; and see how he goes about to abuse me!
That fellow is a fellow of much licence: let him be
called before us. Away with her to prison! Go to;
no more words.
Exeunt Officers with MISTRESS OVERDONE
Provost
Claudio must die to-morrow: let him be furnished
with divines
if my brother wrought by my pity
so with him.
So please you
advised him for the entertainment of death.
Good even
Bliss and goodness on you!
Of whence are you?
Not of this country
To use it for my time: I am a brother
Of gracious order
In special business from his holiness.
What news abroad i' the world?
None
goodness
novelty is only in request; and it is as dangerous
to be aged in any kind of course
to be constant in any undertaking. There is scarce
truth enough alive to make societies secure; but
security enough to make fellowships accurst: much
upon this riddle runs the wisdom of the world. This
news is old enough
pray you
One that
especially to know himself.
What pleasure was he given to?
Rather rejoicing to see another merry
any thing which professed to make him rejoice: a
gentleman of all temperance. But leave we him to
his events
and let me desire to know how you find Claudio
prepared. I am made to understand that you have
lent him visitation.
He professes to have received no sinister measure
from his judge
to the determination of justice: yet had he framed
to himself
deceiving promises of life; which I by my good
leisure have discredited to him
resolved to die.
You have paid the heavens your function
prisoner the very debt of your calling. I have
laboured for the poor gentleman to the extremest
shore of my modesty: but my brother justice have I
found so severe
he is indeed Justice.
If his own life answer the straitness of his
proceeding
chance to fail
I am going to visit the prisoner. Fare you well.
Peace be with you!
Exeunt ESCALUS and Provost
He who the sword of heaven will bear
Should be as holy as severe;
Pattern in himself to know
More nor less to others paying
Than by self-offences weighing.
Shame to him whose cruel striking
Kills for faults of his own liking!
Twice treble shame on Angelo
O
How may likeness made in crimes
Most ponderous and substantial things!
Craft against vice I must apply:
With Angelo to-night shall lie
His old betrothed but despised;
So disguise shall
Exit
ACT IV
SCENE I. The moated grange at ST. LUKE's.
Enter MARIANA and a Boy
Boy sings
Take
And those eyes
But my kisses bring again
Seals of love
Break off thy song
Here comes a man of comfort
Hath often still'd my brawling discontent.
Exit Boy
Enter DUKE VINCENTIO disguised as before
I cry you mercy
You had not found me here so musical:
Let me excuse me
'Tis good; though music oft hath such a charm
To make bad good
I pray
for me here to-day? much upon this time have
I promised here to meet.
You have not been inquired after:
I have sat here all day.
Enter ISABELLA
I do constantly believe you. The time is come even
now. I shall crave your forbearance a little: may
be I will call upon you anon
I am always bound to you.
Exit
Very well met
What is the news from this good deputy?
He hath a garden circummured with brick
And to that vineyard is a planched gate
This other doth command a little door
Which from the vineyard to the garden leads;
There have I made my promise
Upon the heavy middle of the night
To call upon him.
But shall you on your knowledge find this way?
I have ta'en a due and wary note upon't:
With whispering and most guilty diligence
The way twice o'er.
Are there no other tokens
Between you 'greed concerning her observance?
No
And that I have possess'd him my most stay
Can be but brief; for I have made him know
I have a servant comes with me along
I come about my brother.
'Tis well borne up.
I have not yet made known to Mariana
A word of this. What
Re-enter MARIANA
I pray you
She comes to do you good.
I do desire the like.
Do you persuade yourself that I respect you?
Good friar
Take
I shall attend your leisure: but make haste;
The vaporous night approaches.
Will't please you walk aside?
Exeunt MARIANA and ISABELLA
O place and greatness! millions of false eyes
Are stuck upon thee: volumes of report
Run with these false and most contrarious quests
Upon thy doings: thousand escapes of wit
Make thee the father of their idle dreams
And rack thee in their fancies.
Re-enter MARIANA and ISABELLA
Welcome
She'll take the enterprise upon her
It is not my consent
Little have you to say
When you depart from him
Fear me not.
Nor
He is your husband on a pre-contract:
To bring you thus together
Doth flourish the deceit. Come
Our corn's to reap
Exeunt

Proof?

Sir

Enter CLAUDIO
Look
'Tis now dead midnight
Thou must be made immortal. Where's Barnardine?
As fast lock'd up in sleep as guiltless labour
When it lies starkly in the traveller's bones:
He will not wake.
Who can do good on him?
Well
Knocking within
But
Heaven give your spirits comfort!
Exit CLAUDIO
By and by.
I hope it is some pardon or reprieve
For the most gentle Claudio.
Enter DUKE VINCENTIO disguised as before
Welcome father.
The best and wholesomest spirts of the night
Envelope you
None
Not Isabel?
No.
They will
What comfort is for Claudio?
There's some in hope.
It is a bitter deputy.
Not so
Even with the stroke and line of his great justice:
He doth with holy abstinence subdue
That in himself which he spurs on his power
To qualify in others: were he meal'd with that
Which he corrects
But this being so
Knocking within
Now are they come.
Exit Provost
This is a gentle provost: seldom when
The steeled gaoler is the friend of men.
Knocking within
How now! what noise? That spirit's possessed with haste
That wounds the unsisting postern with these strokes.
Re-enter Provost
There he must stay until the officer
Arise to let him in: he is call'd up.
Have you no countermand for Claudio yet
None
As near the dawning
Happily
You something know; yet I believe there comes
No countermand; no such example have we:
Besides
Lord Angelo hath to the public ear
Profess'd the contrary.
Enter a Messenger
This is his lordship's man.
And here comes Claudio's pardon.
[Giving a paper]
My lord hath sent you this note; and by me this
further charge
smallest article of it
other circumstance. Good morrow; for
I shall obey him.

[Aside]  This is his pardon
For which the pardoner himself is in.
Hence hath offence his quick celerity
When vice makes mercy
Now
I told you. Lord Angelo
in mine office
putting-on; methinks strangely
Pray you
[Reads]
'Whatsoever you may hear to the contrary
Claudio be executed by four of the clock; and in the

this be duly performed; with a thought that more
depends on it than we must yet deliver. Thus fail
not to do your office
What say you to this

A Bohemian born
that is a prisoner nine years old.
How came it that the absent duke had not either

have heard it was ever his manner to do so.
His friends still wrought reprieves for him: and
Angelo
It is now apparent?
Most manifest
Hath he born himself penitently in prison? how

A man that apprehends death no more dreadfully but

mortality
He wants advice.

are amazed; but this shall absolutely resolve you.
Come away; it is almost clear dawn.

I am as well acquainted here as I was in our house

This shall be done

And how shall we continue Claudio
If he were known alive?
Let this be done.
Put them in secret holds
Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greeting
To the under generation

I am your free dependant.
Quick

The provost

Re-enter Provost
Here is the head; I'll carry it myself.

That want no ear but yours.

The tongue of Isabel. She's come to know

Mark what I say
By every syllable a faithful verity:
The duke comes home to-morrow; nay
One of our convent

This letter

SCENE IV. A room in ANGELO's house.
Enter ANGELO and ESCALUS
Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched other.
In most uneven and distracted manner. His actions
show much like to madness: pray heaven his wisdom be
not tainted! And why meet him at the gates
redeliver our authorities there
I guess not.
And why should we proclaim it in an hour before his
entering
He shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch of
complaints
hereafter
against us.
Well
i' the morn; I'll call you at your house: give
notice to such men of sort and suit as are to meet
him.
I shall
Good night.
Exit ESCALUS
This deed unshapes me quite
And dull to all proceedings. A deflower'd maid!
And by an eminent body that enforced
The law against it! But that her tender shame
Will not proclaim against her maiden loss
For my authority bears of a credent bulk
But it confounds the breather. He should have lived
With ransom of such shame. Would yet he had lived!
A lack
Exit
SCENE V. Fields without the town.
Enter DUKE VINCENTIO in his own habit
These letters at fit time deliver me
Giving letters
The provost knows our purpose and our plot.
The matter being afoot
Though sometimes you do blench from this to that
To Valentinus
But send me Flavius first.
It shall be speeded well.
Exit

I thank thee
Come
Will greet us here anon

SCENE VI. Street near the city gate.
Enter ISABELLA and MARIANA
To speak so indirectly I am loath:
I would say the truth; but to accuse him so
He says
Be ruled by him.
Besides
He speak against me on the adverse side
That's bitter to sweet end.
I would Friar Peter--
O
Enter FRIAR PETER
Come
The generous and gravest citizens
Have hent the gates
The duke is entering: therefore

ACT V
SCENE I. The city gate.
MARIANA veiled
My very worthy cousin
Our old and faithful friend
Happy return be to your royal grace!
Many and hearty thankings to you both.
We have made inquiry of you; and we hear
Such goodness of your justice
Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks
You make my bonds still greater.
O
And razure of oblivion. Give me your hand
That outward courtesies would fain proclaim
Favours that keep within. Come
And good supporters are you.
FRIAR PETER and ISABELLA come forward
Now is your time: speak loud and kneel before him.
Justice
Upon a wrong'd
O worthy prince
By throwing it on any other object
Till you have heard me in my true complaint
And given me justice
Relate your wrongs; in what? by whom? be brief.
Here is Lord Angelo shall give you justice:
Reveal yourself to him.
O worthy duke
Hear me yourself; for that which I must speak
Must either punish me
My lord
She hath been a suitor to me for her brother
Cut off by course of justice
By course of justice!
And she will speak most bitterly and strange.
Most strange
That Angelo's forsworn; is it not strange?
That Angelo's a murderer; is 't not strange?
That Angelo is an adulterous thief
Is it not strange and strange?
Nay
It is not truer he is Angelo
Than this is all as true as it is strange:
Nay
To the end of reckoning.
Away with her! Poor soul
O prince
There is another comfort than this world
That I am touch'd with madness! Make not impossible
That which but seems unlike: 'tis not impossible
But one
As Angelo; even so may Angelo
If he be less
By mine honesty
Her madness hath the oddest frame of sense
O gracious duke
For inequality; but let your reason serve
To make the truth appear where it seems hid
Many that are not mad
Have
I am the sister of one Claudio
To lose his head; condemn'd by Angelo:
I
As then the messenger
That's I
I came to her from Claudio
To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo
For her poor brother's pardon.
That's he indeed.
You were not bid to speak.
No
Nor wish'd to hold my peace.
I wish you now
Pray you
A business for yourself
Be perfect.
I warrant your honour.
The warrants for yourself; take heed to't.
This gentleman told somewhat of my tale
Right.
It may be right; but you are i' the wrong
To speak before your time. Proceed.
I went
To this pernicious caitiff deputy
That's somewhat madly spoken.
Pardon it;
The phrase is to the matter.
Mended again. The matter; proceed.
In brief
For this was of much length
I now begin with grief and shame to utter:
He would not
To his concupiscible intemperate lust
For my poor brother's head.
This is most likely!
O
By heaven
In hateful practise. First
Stands without blemish. Next
That with such vehemency he should pursue
Faults proper to himself: if he had so offended
And not have cut him off. Some one hath set you on:
Confess the truth
Thou camest here to complain.
And is this all?
Then
Unfold the evil which is here wrapt up
In countenance! Heaven shield your grace from woe
I know you'ld fain be gone. An officer!
To prison with her! Shall we thus permit
A blasting and a scandalous breath to fall
On him so near us? This needs must be a practise.
Who knew of Your intent and coming hither?
One that I would were here
A ghostly father
My lord
I do not like the man: had he been lay
For certain words he spake against your grace
In your retirement
Words against me? this is a good friar
And to set on this wretched woman here
Against our substitute! Let this friar be found.
But yesternight
Blessed be your royal grace!
I have stood by
Your royal ear abused. First
Most wrongfully accused your substitute
As she from one ungot.
We did believe no less.
Know you that Friar Lodowick that she speaks of?
I know him for a man divine and holy;
Not scurvy
And
Did
My lord
Well
But at this instant he is sick my lord
Intended 'gainst Lord Angelo
Is true and false; and what he with his oath
And all probation will make up full clear
To justify this worthy nobleman
Good friar
ISABELLA is carried off guarded; and MARIANA comes forward
Do you not smile at this
O heaven
Give us some seats. Come
In this I'll be impartial; be you judge
Of your own cause. Is this the witness
First
Pardon
Until my husband bid me.
What
No
Are you a maid?
No
A widow
Neither
Why
My lord
neither maid
Silence that fellow: I would he had some cause
To prattle for himself.
Well
My lord; I do confess I ne'er was married;
And I confess besides I am no maid:
I have known my husband; yet my husband
Knows not that ever he knew me.
He was drunk then
For the benefit of silence
Well
This is no witness for Lord Angelo.
Now I come to't my lord
She that accuses him of fornication
When I'll depose I had him in mine arms
With all the effect of love.
Charges she more than me?
Not that I know.
No? you say your husband.
Why
This is a strange abuse. Let's see thy face.
My husband bids me; now I will unmask.
Unveiling
This is that face
This is the hand which
That took away the match from Isabel
In her imagined person.
Know you this woman?
Carnally
Sirrah
Enough
My lord
And five years since there was some speech of marriage
Betwixt myself and her; which was broke off
Came short of composition
For that her reputation was disvalued
In levity: since which time of five years
I never spake with her
Noble prince
As words could make up vows: and
He knew me as a wife. As this is true
Or else for ever be confixed here
I did but smile till now:
Now
My patience here is touch'd. I do perceive
These poor informal women are no more
But instruments of some more mightier member
That sets them on: let me have way
Ay
And punish them to your height of pleasure.
Thou foolish friar
That's seal'd in approbation? You
To find out this abuse
There is another friar that set them on;
Let him be sent for.
Would he were here
Hath set the women on to this complaint:
Your provost knows the place where he abides
And he may fetch him.
Go do it instantly.
Exit Provost
And you
But stir not you till you have well determined
Upon these slanderers.
My lord
Exit DUKE

Friar Lodowick to be a dishonest person?
'Cucullus non facit monachum:' honest in nothing
but in his clothes; and one that hath spoke most
villanous speeches of the duke.
We shall entreat you to abide here till he come and
enforce them against him: we shall find this friar a
notable fellow.
As any in Vienna
Call that same Isabel here once again; I would speak with her.

shall see how I'll handle her.
Not better than he
Say you?
Marry
I will go darkly to work with her.
That's the way; for women are light at midnight.

Come on
that you have said.
My lord
the provost.
In very good time: speak not you to him till we

Mum.
Come
Lord Angelo? they have confessed you did.
'Tis false.
How! know you where you are?
Respect to your great place! and let the devil
Be sometime honour'd for his burning throne!
Where is the duke? 'tis he should hear me speak.
The duke's in us; and we will hear you speak:
Look you speak justly.
Boldly
Good night to your redress! Is the duke gone?
Then is your cause gone too. The duke's unjust
Which here you come to accuse.
This is the rascal; this is he I spoke of.
Why
To accuse this worthy man
And in the witness of his proper ear
To the duke himself
Take him hence; to the rack with him! We'll touse you
Joint by joint
What 'unjust'!
Be not so hot; the duke
Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he
Dare rack his own: his subject am I not
Made me a looker on here in Vienna
Till it o'er-run the stew; laws for all faults
Stand like the forfeits in a barber's shop
Slander to the state! Away with him to prison!
What can you vouch against him
Is this the man that you did tell us of?

do you know me?

O
Most notedly

fool

that my report: you
much more
O thou damnable fellow! Did not I pluck thee by the

Hark
treasonable abuses!
Such a fellow is not to be talked withal. Away with

bald-pated

To LUCIO
Sneak not away
Must have a word anon. Lay hold on him.
This may prove worse than hanging.
[To ESCALUS]  What you have spoke I pardon: sit you down:
We'll borrow place of him.
To ANGELO
Sir
Hast thou or word
O my dread lord
Immediate sentence then and sequent death
Is all the grace I beg.
Come hither
Say
I was
Go take her hence
Do you the office
Exeunt ANGELO
My lord
Than at the strangeness of it.
Come hither
Your friar is now your prince: as I was then
Advertising and holy to your business
Attorney'd at your service.
O
Your unknown sovereignty!
You are pardon'd
And now
Your brother's death
And you may marvel why I obscured myself
Make rash remonstrance of my hidden power
Than let him so be lost. O most kind maid
That life is better life
I do
Re-enter ANGELO
For this new-married man approaching here
Your well defended honour
For Mariana's sake: but as he adjudged your brother
Being criminal
Of sacred chastity and of promise-breach
Thereon dependent
The very mercy of the law cries out
Most audible
Haste still pays haste
Like doth quit like
Then
Which
We do condemn thee to the very block
Where Claudio stoop'd to death
Away with him!
O my most gracious lord
It is your husband mock'd you with a husband.
Consenting to the safeguard of your honour
And choke your good to come; for his possessions
O my dear lord
Never crave him; we are definitive.
Gentle my liege
Kneeling
You do but lose your labour.
Away with him to death!
To LUCIO
Now
O my good lord! Sweet Isabel
Lend me your knees
I'll lend you all my life to do you service.
Against all sense you do importune her:
Should she kneel down in mercy of this fact
Isabel
Hold up your hands
They say
And
For being a little bad: so may my husband.
O Isabel
He dies for Claudio's death.
Most bounteous sir
Look
A due sincerity govern'd his deeds
For Angelo
That perish'd by the way: thoughts are no subjects;
Intents but merely thoughts.
Merely
Your suit's unprofitable; stand up
I have bethought me of another fault.
Provost
At an unusual hour?
It was commanded so.
Had you a special warrant for the deed?
No
For which I do discharge you of your office:
Give up your keys.
Pardon me
I thought it was a fault
Yet did repent me
For testimony whereof
What's he?
His name is Barnardine.
I would thou hadst done so by Claudio.
Go fetch him hither; let me look upon him.
Exit Provost
I am sorry
As you
And lack of temper'd judgment afterward.
I am sorry that such sorrow I procure:
And so deep sticks it in my penitent heart
That I crave death more willingly than mercy;
'Tis my deserving
Re-enter Provost
Which is that Barnardine?
This
There was a friar told me of this man.
Sirrah
That apprehends no further than this world
But
And pray thee take this mercy to provide
For better times to come. Friar
I leave him to your hand. What muffled fellow's that?
This is another prisoner that I saved.
Who should have died when Claudio lost his head;
As like almost to Claudio as himself.
Unmuffles CLAUDIO
[To ISABELLA]  If he be like your brother
Is he pardon'd; and
He is my brother too: but fitter time for that.
By this Lord Angelo perceives he's safe;
Methinks I see a quickening in his eye.
Well
Look that you love your wife; her worth worth yours.
I find an apt remission in myself;
And yet here's one in place I cannot pardon.
To LUCIO
You
Wherein have I so deserved of you
'Faith
trick. If you will hang me for it

Whipt first
Proclaim it

Whom he begot with child

Your highness said even now
good my lord
Upon mine honour

And see our pleasure herein executed.
Marrying a punk

ACT I
SCENE I. Venice. A street.
Enter ANTONIO
In sooth
It wearies me; you say it wearies you;
But how I caught it
And such a want-wit sadness makes of me
Your mind is tossing on the ocean;
There
Believe me
Be with my hopes abroad. I should be still
Plucking the grass
And every object that might make me fear
Misfortune to my ventures
Would make me sad.
My wind cooling my broth
Would blow me to an ague
What harm a wind too great at sea might do.
I should not see the sandy hour-glass run
To kiss her burial. Should I go to church
And see the holy edifice of stone
To think on this
That such a thing bechanced would make me sad?
But tell not me; I know
Is sad to think upon his merchandise.
Believe me
Upon the fortune of this present year:
Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad.
Why
Fie
Not in love neither? Then let us say you are sad
For you to laugh and leap and say you are merry
Some that will evermore peep through their eyes
And laugh like parrots at a bag-piper
That they'll not show their teeth in way of smile
Enter BASSANIO
Here comes Bassanio
We leave you now with better company.
I would have stay'd till I had made you merry
Your worth is very dear in my regard.
I take it
And you embrace the occasion to depart.
Good morrow
Good signiors both
You grow exceeding strange: must it be so?
We'll make our leisures to attend on yours.
Exeunt Salarino and Salanio
My Lord Bassanio
I will not fail you.
You look not well
You have too much respect upon the world:
They lose it that do buy it with much care:
Believe me
I hold the world but as the world
A stage where every man must play a part
Let me play the fool:
With mirth and laughter let old wrinkles come
Than my heart cool with mortifying groans.
Why should a man
Sleep when he wakes and creep into the jaundice
By being peevish? I tell thee what
I love thee
There are a sort of men whose visages
Do cream and mantle like a standing pond
Of wisdom
O my Antonio
That therefore only are reputed wise
For saying nothing; when
I'll tell thee more of this another time:
But fish not
Come
I'll end my exhortation after dinner.
Well
I must be one of these same dumb wise men
Well
Farewell: I'll grow a talker for this gear.
Thanks
In a neat's tongue dried and a maid not vendible.
Exeunt GRATIANO and LORENZO
Is that any thing now?
Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing
than any man in all Venice. His reasons are as two
grains of wheat hid in two bushels of chaff: you
shall seek all day ere you find them
have them
Well
To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage
'Tis not unknown to you
Than my faint means would grant continuance:
Nor do I now make moan to be abridged
From such a noble rate; but my chief care
Is to come fairly off from the great debts
Wherein my time something too prodigal
Hath left me gaged. To you
To unburden all my plots and purposes
How to get clear of all the debts I owe.
I pray you
And if it stand
In my school-days
The self-same way with more advised watch
I oft found both: I urge this childhood proof
I owe you much
To shoot another arrow that self way
Which you did shoot the first
Or bring your latter hazard back again
And thankfully rest debtor for the first.
You know me well
To wind about my love with circumstance;
And out of doubt you do me now more wrong
In making question of my uttermost
Than if you had made waste of all I have:
Then do but say to me what I should do
That in your knowledge may by me be done
In Belmont is a lady richly left;
And she is fair
I did receive fair speechless messages:
Her name is Portia
To Cato's daughter
Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth
Renowned suitors
Hang on her temples like a golden fleece;
Which makes her seat of Belmont Colchos' strand
O my Antonio
To hold a rival place with one of them
Thou know'st that all my fortunes are at sea;
Neither have I money nor commodity
To raise a present sum: therefore go forth;
Try what my credit can in Venice do:
That shall be rack'd
Go
To have it of my trust or for my sake.
Exeunt

By my troth
this great world.
You would be

yet

SCENE III. Venice. A public place.
Enter BASSANIO and SHYLOCK
Three thousand ducats; well.
Ay
For three months; well.
For the which
Antonio shall become bound; well.
May you stead me? will you pleasure me? shall I
know your answer?
Three thousand ducats for three months and Antonio bound.
Your answer to that.
Antonio is a good man.
Have you heard any imputation to the contrary?
Oh
good man is to have you understand me that he is
sufficient. Yet his means are in supposition: he
hath an argosy bound to Tripolis

Be assured you may.
I will be assured I may; and

Yes

with you
news on the Rialto? Who is he comes here?
Enter ANTONIO
This is Signior Antonio.
[Aside]  How like a fawning publican he looks!
I hate him for he is a Christian
He lends out money gratis and brings down
The rate of usance here with us in Venice.
If I can catch him once upon the hip
He hates our sacred nation
Shylock
I am debating of my present store
Of full three thousand ducats. What of that?
Tubal
Do you desire?
To ANTONIO
Rest you fair
Your worship was the last man in our mouths.
Shylock
By taking nor by giving of excess
How much ye would?
Ay
And for three months.
I had forgot; three months; you told me so.
Well then
Methought you said you neither lend nor borrow
Upon advantage.
I do never use it.
When Jacob grazed his uncle Laban's sheep--
This Jacob from our holy Abram was
And what of him? did he take interest?
No
When Laban and himself were compromised
That all the eanlings which were streak'd and pied
Should fall as Jacob's hire
Between these woolly breeders in the act
Fall parti-colour'd lambs
This was a way to thrive
And thrift is blessing
This was a venture
A thing not in his power to bring to pass
Was this inserted to make interest good?
Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams?
I cannot tell; I make it breed as fast:
But note me
Mark you this
An evil soul producing holy witness
Is like a villain with a smiling cheek
O
Three thousand ducats; 'tis a good round sum.
Three months from twelve; then
Well
Signior Antonio
In the Rialto you have rated me
About my moneys and my usances:
Still have I borne it with a patient shrug
You call me misbeliever
Well then
Go to
'Shylock
You
And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur
Over your threshold: moneys is your suit
What should I say to you? Should I not say
'Hath a dog money? is it possible
A cur can lend three thousand ducats?' Or
Shall I bend low and in a bondman's key
'Fair sir
You spurn'd me such a day; another time
You call'd me dog; and for these courtesies
I'll lend you thus much moneys'?
I am as like to call thee so again
If thou wilt lend this money
As to thy friends; for when did friendship take
A breed for barren metal of his friend?
But lend it rather to thine enemy
Exact the penalty.
Why
I would be friends with you and have your love
Of usance for my moneys
This is kind I offer.
This were kindness.
This kindness will I show.
Go with me to a notary
Your single bond; and
Express'd in the condition
Be nominated for an equal pound
Of your fair flesh
In what part of your body pleaseth me.
Content
And say there is much kindness in the Jew.
You shall not seal to such a bond for me:
I'll rather dwell in my necessity.
Why
Within these two months
This bond expires
Of thrice three times the value of this bond.
O father Abram
The thoughts of others! Pray you
If he should break his day
By the exaction of the forfeiture?
A pound of man's flesh taken from a man
Is not so estimable
If he will take it
And
Yes Shylock
Then meet me forthwith at the notary's;
Give him direction for this merry bond
Of an unthrifty knave
I will be with you.
Hie thee
Exit Shylock
The Hebrew will turn Christian: he grows kind.
I like not fair terms and a villain's mind.
Come on: in this there can be no dismay;
My ships come home a month before the day.
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.
Flourish of cornets. Enter the PRINCE OF MOROCCO  and his train; PORTIA
Mislike me not for my complexion
Bring me the fairest creature northward born
I tell thee
Hath fear'd the valiant: by my love I swear
The best-regarded virgins of our clime
Have loved it too: I would not change this hue
In terms of choice I am not solely led
By nice direction of a maiden's eyes;
Besides
Bars me the right of voluntary choosing:
But if my father had not scanted me
And hedged me by his wit
His wife who wins me by that means I told you
As any comer I have look'd on yet
For my affection.
Even for that I thank you:
Therefore
To try my fortune. By this scimitar
That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince
That won three fields of Sultan Solyman
If Hercules and Lichas play at dice
Which is the better man
May turn by fortune from the weaker hand:
So is Alcides beaten by his page;
And so may I
You must take your chance
Or swear before you choose
Never to speak to lady afterward
In way of marriage: therefore be advised.
Nor will not. Come
First
Your hazard shall be made.
Good fortune then!
To make me blest or cursed'st among men.
Cornets

Well
What
And sleep and snore
Why
Why

Enter Jessica
Call you? what is your will?
I am bid forth to supper
There are my keys. But wherefore should I go?
I am not bid for love; they flatter me:
But yet I'll go in hate
The prodigal Christian. Jessica
There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest

Lock up my doors; and when you hear the drum

Let not the sound of shallow foppery enter
My sober house. By Jacob's staff
But I will go. Go you before me

window

What says that fool of Hagar's offspring
His words were 'Farewell mistress;' nothing else.
The patch is kind enough
Snail-slow in profit
More than the wild-cat: drones hive not with me;
Therefore I part with him
To one that would have him help to waste
His borrow'd purse. Well
Perhaps I will return immediately:
Do as I bid you; shut doors after you:
Fast bind
A proverb never stale in thrifty mind.
Exit
Farewell; and if my fortune be not crost

SCENE VI. The same.
Enter GRATIANO and SALARINO
This is the pent-house under which Lorenzo
Desired us to make stand.
His hour is almost past.
And it is marvel he out-dwells his hour
O
To seal love's bonds new-made
To keep obliged faith unforfeited!
That ever holds: who riseth from a feast
With that keen appetite that he sits down?
Where is the horse that doth untread again
His tedious measures with the unbated fire
That he did pace them first? All things that are
How like a younker or a prodigal
The scarfed bark puts from her native bay
How like the prodigal doth she return
Here comes Lorenzo: more of this hereafter.
Enter LORENZO
Sweet friends
Not I
When you shall please to play the thieves for wives
Here dwells my father Jew. Ho! who's within?
Enter JESSICA
Who are you? Tell me
Lorenzo
Lorenzo
But you
Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.
Here
I am glad 'tis night
But love is blind and lovers cannot see
The pretty follies that themselves commit;
For if they could
To see me thus transformed to a boy.
Descend
What
They in themselves
Why
And I should be obscured.
So are you
But come at once;
For the close night doth play the runaway
I will make fast the doors
With some more ducats
Exit above
Now
Beshrew me but I love her heartily;
For she is wise
Enter JESSICA
What
Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.
Exit with Jessica and Salarino
Enter ANTONIO
Who's there?
Signior Antonio!
Fie
'Tis nine o'clock: our friends all stay for you.
No masque to-night: the wind is come about;
Bassanio presently will go aboard:
I have sent twenty out to seek for you.
I am glad on't: I desire no more delight
Than to be under sail and gone to-night.
Exeunt
SCENE VII. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.
Flourish of cornets. Enter PORTIA
Go draw aside the curtains and discover
The several caskets to this noble prince.
Now make your choice.
The first
The second
This third
How shall I know if I do choose the right?
The one of them contains my picture
If you choose that
Some god direct my judgment! Let me see;
I will survey the inscriptions back again.
What says this leaden casket?
'Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.'
Must give: for what? for lead? hazard for lead?
This casket threatens. Men that hazard all
Do it in hope of fair advantages:
A golden mind stoops not to shows of dross;
I'll then nor give nor hazard aught for lead.
What says the silver with her virgin hue?
'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.'
As much as he deserves! Pause there
If thou be'st rated by thy estimation
May not extend so far as to the lady:
And yet to be afeard of my deserving
Were but a weak disabling of myself.
As much as I deserve! Why
I do in birth deserve her
But more than these
What if I stray'd no further
Let's see once more this saying graved in gold
'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.'
Why
From the four corners of the earth they come
The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds
Of wide Arabia are as thoroughfares now
For princes to come view fair Portia:
The watery kingdom
Spits in the face of heaven
To stop the foreign spirits
One of these three contains her heavenly picture.
Is't like that lead contains her? 'Twere damnation
To think so base a thought: it were too gross
To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.
Or shall I think in silver she's immured
O sinful thought! Never so rich a gem
Was set in worse than gold. They have in England
A coin that bears the figure of an angel
Stamped in gold
But here an angel in a golden bed
Lies all within. Deliver me the key:
Here do I choose
There
He unlocks the golden casket
O hell! what have we here?
A carrion Death
There is a written scroll! I'll read the writing.
Reads
All that glitters is not gold;
Often have you heard that told:
Many a man his life hath sold
But my outside to behold:
Gilded tombs do worms enfold.
Had you been as wise as bold
Fare you well; your suit is cold.
Cold
Then
Portia
To take a tedious leave: thus losers part.
Exit with his train. Flourish of cornets
A gentle riddance. Draw the curtains
Let all of his complexion choose me so.
Exeunt
SCENE VIII. Venice. A street.
Enter SALARINO and SALANIO
Why
With him is Gratiano gone along;
And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not.
The villain Jew with outcries raised the duke
He came too late
But there the duke was given to understand
That in a gondola were seen together
Lorenzo and his amorous Jessica:
Besides
They were not with Bassanio in his ship.
I never heard a passion so confused
'My daughter! O my ducats! O my daughter!
Fled with a Christian! O my Christian ducats!
Justice! the law! my ducats
A sealed bag
And jewels
She hath the stones upon her
Why
Let good Antonio look he keep his day
Marry
I reason'd with a Frenchman yesterday
The French and English
A vessel of our country richly fraught:
I thought upon Antonio when he told me;
And wish'd in silence that it were not his.
You were best to tell Antonio what you hear;
Yet do not suddenly
A kinder gentleman treads not the earth.
I saw Bassanio and Antonio part:
Bassanio told him he would make some speed
Of his return: he answer'd
Slubber not business for my sake
But stay the very riping of the time;
And for the Jew's bond which he hath of me
Be merry
To courtship and such fair ostents of love
As shall conveniently become you there:'
And even there
He wrung Bassanio's hand; and so they parted.
I think he only loves the world for him.
I pray thee
And quicken his embraced heaviness
With some delight or other.
Do we so.
Exeunt
SCENE IX. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.
Enter NERISSA with a Servitor
Quick
The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath
Flourish of cornets. Enter the PRINCE OF ARRAGON
Behold
If you choose that wherein I am contain'd
But if you fail
I am enjoin'd by oath to observe three things:
First
Which casket 'twas I chose; next
Of the right casket
To woo a maid in way of marriage: Lastly
To these injunctions every one doth swear
That comes to hazard for my worthless self.
And so have I address'd me. Fortune now
To my heart's hope! Gold; silver; and base lead.
'Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.'
You shall look fairer
What says the golden chest? ha! let me see:
'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.'
What many men desire! that 'many' may be meant
By the fool multitude
Which pries not to the interior
I will not choose what many men desire
And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.
Why
Tell me once more what title thou dost bear:
'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves:'
And well said too; for who shall go about
To cozen fortune and be honourable
Without the stamp of merit? Let none presume
To wear an undeserved dignity.
O
Were not derived corruptly
Were purchased by the merit of the wearer!
How many then should cover that stand bare!
How many be commanded that command!
How much low peasantry would then be glean'd
From the true seed of honour! and how much honour
Pick'd from the chaff and ruin of the times
To be new-varnish'd! Well
'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.'
I will assume desert. Give me a key for this
He opens the silver casket
Too long a pause for that which you find there.
What's here? the portrait of a blinking idiot
How much unlike art thou to Portia!
How much unlike my hopes and my deservings!
'Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves.'
Did I deserve no more than a fool's head?
Is that my prize? are my deserts no better?
To offend
And of opposed natures.
What is here?
Reads
The fire seven times tried this:
Seven times tried that judgment is
Some there be that shadows kiss;
Such have but a shadow's bliss:
There be fools alive
Take what wife you will to bed
So be gone: you are sped.
Still more fool I shall appear
By the time I linger here
With one fool's head I came to woo
Sweet
Exeunt Arragon and train
Thus hath the candle singed the moth.
O
The ancient saying is no heresy
Come
Enter a Servant
Where is my lady?
Here: what would my lord?
Madam
A young Venetian
To signify the approaching of his lord;
From whom he bringeth sensible regreets
So likely an ambassador of love:
A day in April never came so sweet
No more
Thou wilt say anon he is some kin to thee
Come
Quick Cupid's post that comes so mannerly.
Bassanio
Exeunt

SCENE II. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.
Enter BASSANIO
I pray you
Before you hazard; for
There's something tells me
But lest you should not understand me well
And yet a maiden hath no tongue but thought
I would detain you here some month or two
Before you venture for me. I could teach you
How to choose right
So will I never be: so may you miss me;
But if you do
One half of me is yours
Put bars between the owners and their rights!
And so
I speak too long; but 'tis to peize the time
Let me choose
For as I am
Upon the rack
What treason there is mingled with your love.
None but that ugly treason of mistrust
There may as well be amity and life
'Tween snow and fire
Ay
Promise me life
Well then
'Confess' and 'love'
Had been the very sum of my confession:
O happy torment
Doth teach me answers for deliverance!
But let me to my fortune and the caskets.
Away
If you do love me
Nerissa and the rest
Let music sound while he doth make his choice;
Then
May stand more proper
And watery death-bed for him. He may win;
And what is music then? Then music is
Even as the flourish when true subjects bow
To a new-crowned monarch: such it is
As are those dulcet sounds in break of day
That creep into the dreaming bridegroom's ear
The virgin tribute paid by howling Troy
To the sea-monster: I stand for sacrifice
The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives
The issue of the exploit. Go
Live thou
I view the fight than thou that makest the fray.
Music
SONG.
Tell me where is fancy bred
How begot
Reply
It is engender'd in the eyes
In the cradle where it lies.
Let us all ring fancy's knell
I'll begin it
Ding
So may the outward shows be least themselves:
The world is still deceived with ornament.
In law
Will bless it and approve it with a text
There is no vice so simple but assumes
Some mark of virtue on his outward parts:
How many cowards
As stairs of sand
The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars;
Who
And these assume but valour's excrement
To render them redoubted! Look on beauty
Which therein works a miracle in nature
So are those crisped snaky golden locks
Which make such wanton gambols with the wind
To be the dowry of a second head
Thus ornament is but the guiled shore
To a most dangerous sea; the beauteous scarf
Veiling an Indian beauty; in a word
To entrap the wisest. Therefore
Nor none of thee
'Tween man and man: but thou
And here choose I; joy be the consequence!
[Aside]  How all the other passions fleet to air
I feel too much thy blessing: make it less
What find I here?
Opening the leaden casket
Fair Portia's counterfeit! What demi-god
Hath come so near creation? Move these eyes?
Or whether
Should sunder such sweet friends. Here in her hairs
The painter plays the spider and hath woven
A golden mesh to entrap the hearts of men
How could he see to do them? having made one
And leave itself unfurnish'd. Yet look
The substance of my praise doth wrong this shadow
In underprizing it
Doth limp behind the substance. Here's the scroll
Reads
You that choose not by the view
Since this fortune falls to you
And hold your fortune for your bliss
And claim her with a loving kiss.
A gentle scroll. Fair lady
I come by note
Like one of two contending in a prize
Whether these pearls of praise be his or no;
So
As doubtful whether what I see be true
You see me
I would not be ambitious in my wish
I would be trebled twenty times myself;
A thousand times more fair
That only to stand high in your account
Is sum of something
Happy in this
But she may learn; happier than this
Happiest of all is that her gentle spirit
Commits itself to yours to be directed
Myself and what is mine to you and yours
Is now converted: but now I was the lord
Of this fair mansion
Are yours
Which when you part from
And be my vantage to exclaim on you.
Madam
And there is such confusion in my powers
By a beloved prince
Among the buzzing pleased multitude;
Where every something
Parts from this finger
O
My lord and lady
My lord Bassanio and my gentle lady
For I am sure you can wish none from me:
And when your honours mean to solemnize
The bargain of your faith
With all my heart
I thank your lordship
My eyes
You saw the mistress
You loved
No more pertains to me
Your fortune stood upon the casket there
For wooing here until I sweat again
With oaths of love
To have her love
Achieved her mistress.
Is this true
Madam
And do you
Yes
Our feast shall be much honour'd in your marriage.
We'll play with them the first boy for a thousand ducats.
What
No; we shall ne'er win at that sport
But who comes here? Lorenzo and his infidel? What
Enter LORENZO
Lorenzo and Salerio
If that the youth of my new interest here
Have power to bid you welcome. By your leave
So do I
They are entirely welcome.
I thank your honour. For my part
But meeting with Salerio by the way
I did
And I have reason for it. Signior Antonio
Commends him to you.
Gives Bassanio a letter
Ere I ope his letter
Not sick
Nor well
Will show you his estate.
Nerissa
Your hand
How doth that royal merchant
I know he will be glad of our success;
We are the Jasons
I would you had won the fleece that he hath lost.
There are some shrewd contents in yon same paper
Some dear friend dead; else nothing in the world
Could turn so much the constitution
Of any constant man. What
With leave
That this same paper brings you.
O sweet Portia
That ever blotted paper! Gentle lady
Ran in my veins
And then I told you true: and yet
How much I was a braggart. When I told you
My state was nothing
That I was worse than nothing; for
The paper as the body of my friend
Have all his ventures fail'd? What
From Tripolis
And not one vessel 'scape the dreadful touch
Of merchant-marring rocks?
Not one
Besides
The present money to discharge the Jew
A creature
He plies the duke at morning and at night
Of greatest port
But none can drive him from the envious plea
Of forfeiture
When I was with him I have heard him swear
To Tubal and to Chus
Than twenty times the value of the sum
That he did owe him: and I know
Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?
The dearest friend to me
In doing courtesies
The ancient Roman honour more appears
Than any that draws breath in Italy.
What sum owes he the Jew?
For me three thousand ducats.
What
Pay him six thousand
Double six thousand
Shall lose a hair through Bassanio's fault.
First go with me to church and call me wife
For never shall you lie by Portia's side
With an unquiet soul. You shall have gold
To pay the petty debt twenty times over:
When it is paid
My maid Nerissa and myself meantime
Will live as maids and widows. Come
For you shall hence upon your wedding-day:
Bid your friends welcome
Since you are dear bought
But let me hear the letter of your friend.
[Reads]  Sweet Bassanio
miscarried
very low
in paying it
debts are cleared between you and I
see you at my death. Notwithstanding
pleasure: if your love do not persuade you to come
O love
Since I have your good leave to go away

SCENE III. Venice. A street.
Enter SHYLOCK
Gaoler
This is the fool that lent out money gratis:
Gaoler
Hear me yet
I'll have my bond; speak not against my bond:
I have sworn an oath that I will have my bond.
Thou call'dst me dog before thou hadst a cause;
But
The duke shall grant me justice. I do wonder
To come abroad with him at his request.
I pray thee
I'll have my bond; I will not hear thee speak:
I'll have my bond; and therefore speak no more.
I'll not be made a soft and dull-eyed fool
To Christian intercessors. Follow not;
I'll have no speaking: I will have my bond.
Exit
It is the most impenetrable cur
That ever kept with men.
Let him alone:
I'll follow him no more with bootless prayers.
He seeks my life; his reason well I know:
I oft deliver'd from his forfeitures
Many that have at times made moan to me;
Therefore he hates me.
I am sure the duke
Will never grant this forfeiture to hold.
The duke cannot deny the course of law:
For the commodity that strangers have
With us in Venice
Since that the trade and profit of the city
Consisteth of all nations. Therefore
These griefs and losses have so bated me
To-morrow to my bloody creditor.
Well
To see me pay his debt
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.
Enter PORTIA
Madam
Of godlike amity; which appears most strongly
In bearing thus the absence of your lord.
But if you  knew to whom you show this honour
Than customary bounty can enforce you.
I never did repent for doing good
That do converse and waste the time together
Of lineaments
Which makes me think that this Antonio
In purchasing the semblance of my soul
From out the state of hellish misery!
This comes too near the praising of myself;
Therefore no more of it: hear other things.
Lorenzo
The husbandry and manage of my house
Until my lord's return: for mine own part
To live in prayer and contemplation
There is a monastery two miles off;
And there will we abide. I do desire you
Not to deny this imposition;
The which my love and some necessity
Now lays upon you.
Madam
I shall obey you in all fair commands.
My people do already know my mind
In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
And so farewell
Fair thoughts and happy hours attend on you!
I wish your ladyship all heart's content.
I thank you for your wish
To wish it back on you: fare you well Jessica.
Exeunt JESSICA and LORENZO
Now
In speed to Padua: see thou render this
Into my cousin's hand
And
Unto the tranect
Which trades to Venice. Waste no time in words
Madam
Exit
Come on
That you yet know not of: we'll see our husbands
Before they think of us.
Shall they see us?
They shall
With that we lack. I'll hold thee any wager
With a reed voice
Into a manly stride
Like a fine bragging youth
I could not do withal; then I'll repent
And twenty of these puny lies I'll tell
Above a twelvemonth. I have within my mind
A thousand raw tricks of these bragging Jacks
Why
Fie
But come
When I am in my coach
At the park gate; and therefore haste away
Exeunt

ACT IV
SCENE I. Venice. A court of justice.
Enter the DUKE
What
Ready
I am sorry for thee: thou art come to answer
A stony adversary
uncapable of pity
From any dram of mercy.
I have heard
Your grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify
His rigorous course; but since he stands obdurate
And that no lawful means can carry me
Out of his envy's reach
My patience to his fury
To suffer
Go one
He is ready at the door: he comes
Enter SHYLOCK
Make room
Shylock
To the last hour of act; and then 'tis thought
Thou'lt show thy mercy and remorse more strange
Than is thy strange apparent cruelty;
And where thou now exact'st the penalty
Glancing an eye of pity on his losses
And pluck commiseration of his state
From brassy bosoms and rough hearts of flint
To offices of tender courtesy.
We all expect a gentle answer
I have possess'd your grace of what I purpose;
And by our holy Sabbath have I sworn
To have the due and forfeit of my bond:
If you deny it
Upon your charter and your city's freedom.
You'll ask me
A weight of carrion flesh than to receive
Three thousand ducats: I'll not answer that:
But
What if my house be troubled with a rat
And I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats
To have it baned? What
Some men there are love not a gaping pig;
Some
And others
Of what it likes or loathes. Now
As there is no firm reason to be render'd
Why he
Why he
Must yield to such inevitable shame
As to offend
So can I give no reason
I bear Antonio
A losing suit against him. Are you answer'd?
This is no answer
I am not bound to please thee with my answers.
Do all men kill the things they do not love?
Hates any man the thing he would not kill?
Every offence is not a hate at first.
What
I pray you
You may as well go stand upon the beach
And bid the main flood bate his usual height;
You may as well use question with the wolf
Why he hath made the ewe bleat for the lamb;
You may as well forbid the mountain pines
To wag their high tops and to make no noise
You may as well do anything most hard
His Jewish heart: therefore
Let me have judgment and the Jew his will.
For thy three thousand ducats here is six.
What judgment shall I dread
Were in six parts and every part a ducat
How shalt thou hope for mercy
What judgment shall I dread
You have among you many a purchased slave
Why sweat they under burthens? let their beds
Be made as soft as yours and let their palates
Be season'd with such viands? You will answer
'The slaves are ours:' so do I answer you:
The pound of flesh
If you deny me
There is no force in the decrees of Venice.
I stand for judgment: answer; shall I have it?
Upon my power I may dismiss this court
My lord
A messenger with letters from the doctor
Bring us the letter; call the messenger.
Good cheer
The Jew shall have my flesh
I am a tainted wether of the flock
Drops earliest to the ground; and so let me
You cannot better be employ'd
Enter NERISSA
Came you from Padua
From both
Presenting a letter
Why dost thou whet thy knife so earnestly?
To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there.
Not on thy sole
Of thy sharp envy. Can no prayers pierce thee?
No
O
And for thy life let justice be accused.
Thou almost makest me waver in my faith
To hold opinion with Pythagoras
Into the trunks of men: thy currish spirit
Govern'd a wolf
Are wolvish
Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond
Repair thy wit
To cureless ruin. I stand here for law.
This letter from Bellario doth commend
A young and learned doctor to our court.
Where is he?
He attendeth here hard by
With all my heart. Some three or four of you
Go give him courteous conduct to this place.
Meantime the court shall hear Bellario's letter.
[Reads]
Your grace shall understand that at the receipt of
your letter I am very sick: but in the instant that
your messenger came
me a young doctor of Rome; his name is Balthasar. I
acquainted him with the cause in controversy between
the Jew and Antonio the merchant: we turned o'er
many books together: he is furnished with my
opinion; which
greatness whereof I cannot enough commend
with him
request in my stead. I beseech you
years be no impediment to let him lack a reverend
estimation; for I never knew so young a body with so
old a head. I leave him to your gracious
acceptance
commendation.
You hear the learn'd Bellario
And here
Enter PORTIA
Give me your hand. Come you from old Bellario?
I did
You are welcome: take your place.
Are you acquainted with the difference
That holds this present question in the court?
I am informed thoroughly of the cause.
Which is the merchant here
Antonio and old Shylock
Is your name Shylock?
Shylock is my name.
Of a strange nature is the suit you follow;
Yet in such rule that the Venetian law
Cannot impugn you as you do proceed.
You stand within his danger
Ay
Do you confess the bond?
I do.
Then must the Jew be merciful.
On what compulsion must I? tell me that.
The quality of mercy is not strain'd
Upon the place beneath: it is twice blest;
It blesseth him that gives and him that takes:
'Tis mightiest in the mightiest: it becomes
The throned monarch better than his crown;
His sceptre shows the force of temporal power
But mercy is above this sceptred sway;
It is enthroned in the hearts of kings
And earthly power doth then show likest God's
When mercy seasons justice. Therefore
Should see salvation: we do pray for mercy;
And that same prayer doth teach us all to render
The deeds of mercy. I have spoke thus much
To mitigate the justice of thy plea;
Which if thou follow
Must needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there.
My deeds upon my head! I crave the law
Is he not able to discharge the money?
Yes
Yea
If this will not suffice
That malice bears down truth. And I beseech you
To do a great right
It must not be; there is no power in Venice
Can alter a decree established:
'Twill be recorded for a precedent
Will rush into the state: it cannot be.
A Daniel come to judgment! yea
O wise young judge
I pray you
Here 'tis
Shylock
An oath
Shall I lay perjury upon my soul?
No
Why
And lawfully by this the Jew may claim
A pound of flesh
Nearest the merchant's heart. Be merciful:
Take thrice thy money; bid me tear the bond.
When it is paid according to the tenor.
It doth appear you are a worthy judge;
You know the law
Hath been most sound: I charge you by the law
There is no power in the tongue of man
To alter me: I stay here on my bond.
Most heartily I do beseech the court
To give the judgment.
Why then
You must prepare your bosom for his knife.
O noble judge! O excellent young man!
For the intent and purpose of the law
Hath full relation to the penalty
'Tis very true: O wise and upright judge!
How much more elder art thou than thy looks!
Therefore lay bare your bosom.
Ay
So says the bond: doth it not
'Nearest his heart:' those are the very words.
It is so. Are there balance here to weigh
The flesh?
I have them ready.
Have by some surgeon
Is it so nominated in the bond?
It is not so express'd: but what of that?
'Twere good you do so much for charity.
I cannot find it; 'tis not in the bond.
You
But little: I am arm'd and well prepared.
Give me your hand
Grieve not that I am fallen to this for you;
For herein Fortune shows herself more kind
Than is her custom: it is still her use
To let the wretched man outlive his wealth
An age of poverty; from which lingering penance
Of such misery doth she cut me off.
Commend me to your honourable wife:
Tell her the process of Antonio's end;
Say how I loved you
And
Whether Bassanio had not once a love.
Repent but you that you shall lose your friend
For if the Jew do cut but deep enough
Antonio
Which is as dear to me as life itself;
But life itself
I would lose all
Here to this devil
Your wife would give you little thanks for that
I have a wife
I would she were in heaven
Entreat some power to change this currish Jew.
'Tis well you offer it behind her back;
The wish would make else an unquiet house.
These be the Christian husbands. I have a daughter;
Would any of the stock of Barrabas
Had been her husband rather than a Christian!
Aside
We trifle time: I pray thee
A pound of that same merchant's flesh is thine:
The court awards it
Most rightful judge!
And you must cut this flesh from off his breast:
The law allows it
Most learned judge! A sentence! Come
Tarry a little; there is something else.
This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood;
The words expressly are 'a pound of flesh:'
Take then thy bond
But
One drop of Christian blood
Are
Unto the state of Venice.
O upright judge! Mark
Is that the law?
Thyself shalt see the act:
For
Thou shalt have justice
O learned judge! Mark
I take this offer
And let the Christian go.
Here is the money.
Soft!
The Jew shall have all justice; soft! no haste:
He shall have nothing but the penalty.
O Jew! an upright judge
Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh.
Shed thou no blood
But just a pound of flesh: if thou cut'st more
Or less than a just pound
As makes it light or heavy in the substance
Of one poor scruple
But in the estimation of a hair
A second Daniel
Now
Why doth the Jew pause? take thy forfeiture.
Give me my principal
I have it ready for thee; here it is.
He hath refused it in the open court:
He shall have merely justice and his bond.
A Daniel
I thank thee
Shall I not have barely my principal?
Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture
Why
I'll stay no longer question.
Tarry
The law hath yet another hold on you.
It is enacted in the laws of Venice
That by direct or indirect attempts
He seek the life of any citizen
Shall seize one half his goods; the other half
Comes to the privy coffer of the state;
And the offender's life lies in the mercy
Of the duke only
In which predicament
For it appears
Thou hast contrived against the very life
Of the defendant; and thou hast incurr'd
The danger formerly by me rehearsed.
Down therefore and beg mercy of the duke.
Beg that thou mayst have leave to hang thyself:
And yet
Therefore thou must be hang'd at the state's charge.
That thou shalt see the difference of our spirits
For half thy wealth
The other half comes to the general state
Ay
Nay
You take my house when you do take the prop
That doth sustain my house; you take my life
When you do take the means whereby I live.
What mercy can you render him
A halter gratis; nothing else
So please my lord the duke and all the court
To quit the fine for one half of his goods
The other half in use
That lately stole his daughter:
Two things provided more
The other
He shall do this
The pardon that I late pronounced here.
Art thou contented
I am content.
Clerk
I pray you
I am not well: send the deed after me
Get thee gone
In christening shalt thou have two god-fathers:
Had I been judge
Exit SHYLOCK
Sir
I humbly do desire your grace of pardon:
I must away this night toward Padua
I am sorry that your leisure serves you not.
Antonio
Exeunt Duke and his train
Most worthy gentleman
Have by your wisdom been this day acquitted
Of grievous penalties; in lieu whereof
And stand indebted
He is well paid that is well satisfied;
And I
And therein do account myself well paid:
My mind was never yet more mercenary.
I pray you
I wish you well
Dear sir
Take some remembrance of us
You press me far
To ANTONIO
Give me your gloves
To BASSANIO
And
Do not draw back your hand; I'll take no more;
And you in love shall not deny me this.
This ring
I will not shame myself to give you this.
I will have nothing else but only this;
And now methinks I have a mind to it.
There's more depends on this than on the value.
The dearest ring in Venice will I give you
Only for this
I see
You taught me first to beg; and now methinks
You teach me how a beggar should be answer'd.
Good sir
And when she put it on
That I should neither sell nor give nor lose it.
That 'scuse serves many men to save their gifts.
An if your wife be not a mad-woman
Exeunt Portia and Nerissa
My Lord Bassanio
Let his deservings and my love withal
Be valued against your wife's commandment.
Go

Exit Gratiano
Come

SCENE II. The same. A street.
Enter PORTIA and NERISSA
Inquire the Jew's house out
And let him sign it: we'll away to-night
And be a day before our husbands home:
This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.
Enter GRATIANO
Fair sir
My Lord Bassanio upon more advice
Hath sent you here this ring
Your company at dinner.
That cannot be:
His ring I do accept most thankfully:
And so
That will I do.
Sir

I'll see if I can get my husband's ring
[Aside to NERISSA]  Thou mayst
We shall have old swearing
That they did give the rings away to men;
But we'll outface them
Aloud
Away! make haste: thou knowist where I will tarry.
Come
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. Belmont. Avenue to PORTIA'S house.
Enter LORENZO and JESSICA
The moon shines bright: in such a night as this
And they did make no noise
Troilus methinks mounted the Troyan walls
And sigh'd his soul toward the Grecian tents
In such a night
Did Thisbe fearfully o'ertrip the dew
And saw the lion's shadow ere himself
And ran dismay'd away.
In such a night
Stood Dido with a willow in her hand
Upon the wild sea banks and waft her love
To come again to Carthage.
In such a night
Medea gather'd the enchanted herbs
That did renew old AEson.
In such a night
Did Jessica steal from the wealthy Jew
And with an unthrift love did run from Venice
As far as Belmont.
In such a night
Did young Lorenzo swear he loved her well
And ne'er a true one.
In such a night
Did pretty Jessica
I would out-night you
But
Enter STEPHANO
Who comes so fast in silence of the night?
A friend.
A friend! what friend? your name
Stephano is my name; and I bring word
My mistress will before the break of day
Be here at Belmont; she doth stray about
By holy crosses
For happy wedlock hours.
Who comes with her?
None but a holy hermit and her maid.
I pray you
He is not
But go we in
Some welcome for the mistress of the house.
Enter LAUNCELOT
Sola
Who calls?
Sola! did you see Master Lorenzo?
Master Lorenzo
Leave hollaing
Sola! where? where?
Here.
Tell him there's a post come from my master
his horn full of good news: my master will be here
ere morning.
Exit
Sweet soul
And yet no matter: why should we go in?
My friend Stephano
And bring your music forth into the air.
Exit Stephano
How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!
Here will we sit and let the sounds of music
Creep in our ears: soft stillness and the night
Become the touches of sweet harmony.
Sit
Is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold:
There's not the smallest orb which thou behold'st
But in his motion like an angel sings
Such harmony is in immortal souls;
But whilst this muddy vesture of decay
Doth grossly close it in
Enter Musicians
Come
With sweetest touches pierce your mistress' ear
Music
I am never merry when I hear sweet music.
The reason is
For do but note a wild and wanton herd
If they but hear perchance a trumpet sound
By the sweet power of music: therefore the poet
Did feign that Orpheus drew trees
Since nought so stockish
The man that hath no music in himself
The motions of his spirit are dull as night
And his affections dark as Erebus:
Let no such man be trusted. Mark the music.
Enter PORTIA and NERISSA
That light we see is burning in my hall.
How far that little candle throws his beams!
So shines a good deed in a naughty world.
When the moon shone
So doth the greater glory dim the less:
A substitute shines brightly as a king
Unto the king be by
Empties itself
Into the main of waters. Music! hark!
It is your music
Nothing is good
Methinks it sounds much sweeter than by day.
Silence bestows that virtue on it
The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark
The nightingale
No better a musician than the wren.
How many things by season season'd are
To their right praise and true perfection!
Peace
And would not be awaked.
Music ceases
That is the voice
He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo
Dear lady
We have been praying for our husbands' healths
Are they return'd?
Madam
But there is come a messenger before
Go in
Give order to my servants that they take
No note at all of our being absent hence;
Nor you
A tucket sounds
Your husband is at hand; I hear his trumpet:
We are no tell-tales
This night methinks is but the daylight sick;
It looks a little paler: 'tis a day
Enter BASSANIO
We should hold day with the Antipodes
Let me give light
For a light wife doth make a heavy husband
But God sort all! You are welcome home
I thank you
This is the man
You should in all sense be much bound to him.
For
No more than I am well acquitted of.
Sir
It must appear in other ways than words
[To NERISSA]  By yonder moon I swear you do me wrong;
In faith
Would he were gelt that had it
A quarrel
About a hoop of gold
That she did give me
For all the world like cutler's poetry
Upon  a knife
What talk you of the posy or the value?
You swore to me
And that it should lie with you in your grave:
Though not for me
Gave it a judge's clerk! no
He will
Ay
Now
I could not for my heart deny it him.
You were to blame
A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger
And so riveted with faith unto your flesh.
I gave my love a ring and made him swear
Never to part with it; and here he stands;
I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it
Nor pluck it from his finger
That the world masters. Now
An 'twere to me
[Aside]  Why
And swear I lost the ring defending it.
My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away
Unto the judge that begg'd it and indeed
Deserved it too; and then the boy
And neither man nor master would take aught
But the two rings.
What ring gave you my lord?
Not that
If I could add a lie unto a fault
Hath not the ring upon it; it is gone.
Even so void is your false heart of truth.
By heaven
Until I see the ring.
Nor I in yours
Till I again see mine.
Sweet Portia
And would conceive for what I gave the ring
And how unwillingly I left the ring
If you had known the virtue of the ring
What man is there so much unreasonable
With any terms of zeal
To urge the thing held as a ceremony?
Nerissa teaches me what to believe:
I'll die for't but some woman had the ring.
No
And begg'd the ring; the which I did deny him
And suffer'd him to go displeased away;
Even he that did uphold the very life
Of my dear friend. What should I say
I was enforced to send it after him;
I was beset with shame and courtesy;
My honour would not let ingratitude
So much besmear it. Pardon me
For
The ring of me to give the worthy doctor.
Let not that doctor e'er come near my house:
Since he hath got the jewel that I loved
I'll not deny him any thing I have
Know him I shall
Lie not a night from home; watch me like Argus:
If you do not
And I his clerk; therefore be well advised
How you do leave me to mine own protection.
Well
For if I do
I am the unhappy subject of these quarrels.
Sir
Portia
And

In both my eyes he doubly sees himself;
In each eye
Nay
Pardon this fault
I never more will break an oath with thee.
I once did lend my body for his wealth;
Which
Will never more break faith advisedly.
Then you shall be his surety. Give him this
And bid him keep it better than the other.
Here

I had it of him: pardon me

It comes from Padua

Shall witness I set forth as soon as you
And even but now return'd; I have not yet
Enter'd my house. Antonio

Are richly come to harbour suddenly:
You shall not know by what strange accident
I chanced on this letter.
I am dumb.
Were you the doctor and I knew you not?
Were you the clerk that is to make me cuckold?
Ay
Sweet doctor

Ay

It is a life that I have desired: I will thrive.

SCENE IV. A room in FORD'S house.

What is the matter
Have a care of your entertainments: there is a

cozen-germans that has cozened all the hosts of
Readins
money. I tell you for good will
are wise and full of gibes and vlouting-stocks

Vere is mine host de Jarteer?
Here

I would all the world might be cozened; for I have

the ear of the court
and how my transformation hath been washed and
cudgelled
drop and liquor fishermen's boots with me; I warrant
they would whip me with their fine wits till I were
as crest-fallen as a dried pear. I never prospered
since I forswore myself at primero. Well
wind were but long enough to say my prayers

Now
From the two parties
The devil take one party and his dam the other! and
so they shall be both bestowed. I have suffered more
for their sakes
of man's disposition is able to bear.

white spot about her.

SCENE VI. Another room in the Garter Inn.
Enter FENTON and Host
Master Fenton
will give over all.
Yet hear me speak. Assist me in my purpose
A hundred pound in gold more than your loss.
I will hear you
least keep your counsel.
From time to time I have acquainted you
With the dear love I bear to fair Anne Page;
Who mutually hath answer'd my affection
Of such contents as you will wonder at;
The mirth whereof so larded with my matter
Hath a great scene: the image of the jest
I'll show you here at large. Hark
To-night at Herne's oak
The purpose why
Away with Slender and with him at Eton
Immediately to marry: she hath consented: Now
And firm for Doctor Caius
That he shall likewise shuffle her away
She seemingly obedient likewise hath
Made promise to the doctor. Now
Her father means she shall be all in white
To take her by the hand and bid her go
And when the doctor spies his vantage ripe
Which means she to deceive
Both
And here it rests
To stay for me at church 'twixt twelve and one
Well
Bring you the maid
So shall I evermore be bound to thee;
Besides

the third time; I hope good luck lies in odd

odd numbers
I'll provide you a chain; and I'll do what I can to

Away

That's good too: but what needs either your 'mum'

The night is dark; light and spirits will become it
well. Heaven prosper our sport! No man means evil
but the devil

Have I laid my brain in the sun and dried it

ACT I
SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
Enter THESEUS
Now
Draws on apace; four happy days bring in
Another moon: but
This old moon wanes! she lingers my desires
Long withering out a young man revenue.
Four days will quickly steep themselves in night;
Four nights will quickly dream away the time;
And then the moon
New-bent in heaven
Of our solemnities.
Go
Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth;
Turn melancholy forth to funerals;
The pale companion is not for our pomp.
Exit PHILOSTRATE
Hippolyta
But I will wed thee in another key
Enter EGEUS
Happy be Theseus
Thanks
Full of vexation come I
Against my child
Stand forth
Stand forth
Thou
Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung
With bracelets of thy hair
Of strong prevailment in unharden'd youth:
With cunning hast thou filch'd my daughter's heart
Consent to marry with Demetrius
Which shall be either to this gentleman
Or to her death
Immediately provided in that case.
What say you
To you your father should be as a god;
One that composed your beauties
To whom you are but as a form in wax
By him imprinted and within his power
To leave the figure or disfigure it.
Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.
So is Lysander.
In himself he is;
But in this kind
I would my father look'd but with my eyes.
Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.
I do entreat your grace to pardon me.
I know not by what power I am made bold
But I beseech your grace that I may know
The worst that may befall me in this case
Either to die the death or to abjure
For ever the society of men.
Therefore
Know of your youth
Thrice-blessed they that master so their blood
But earthlier happy is the rose distill'd
Grows
So will I grow
Unto his lordship
My soul consents not to give sovereignty.
Take time to pause; and
The sealing-day betwixt my love and me
Upon that day either prepare to die
For disobedience to your father's will
Or on Diana's altar to protest
For aye austerity and single life.
Relent
Thy crazed title to my certain right.
You have her father's love
Let me have Hermia's: do you marry him.
Scornful Lysander! true
And she is mine
I do estate unto Demetrius.
I am
My fortunes every way as fairly rank'd
And
Why should not I then prosecute my right?
Demetrius
I must confess that I have heard so much
But
And come
For you
To fit your fancies to your father's will;
Or else the law of Athens yields you up--
Which by no means we may extenuate--
To death
Come
Demetrius and Egeus
I must employ you in some business
Against our nuptial and confer with you
Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.
With duty and desire we follow you.
Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
How now
How chance the roses there do fade so fast?
Belike for want of rain
Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.
Ay me! for aught that I could ever read
But
O cross! too high to be enthrall'd to low.
Or else misgraffed in respect of years
O spite! too old to be engaged to young.
Or else it stood upon the choice of friends
O hell! to choose love by another's eyes.
Or
Brief as the lightning in the collied night
The jaws of darkness do devour it up:
So quick bright things come to confusion.
If then true lovers have been ever cross'd
Then let us teach our trial patience
A good persuasion: therefore
I have a widow aunt
Of great revenue
From Athens is her house remote seven leagues;
And she respects me as her only son.
There
And to that place the sharp Athenian law
Cannot pursue us. If thou lovest me then
And in the wood
My good Lysander!
I swear to thee
Keep promise
Enter HELENA
God speed fair Helena! whither away?
Call you me fair? that fair again unsay.
Demetrius loves your fair: O happy fair!
Your eyes are lode-stars; and your tongue's sweet air
More tuneable than lark to shepherd's ear
Sickness is catching: O
My ear should catch your voice
Were the world mine
O
You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart.
I frown upon him
O that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!
I give him curses
O that my prayers could such affection move!
The more I hate
The more I love
His folly
None
Take comfort: he no more shall see my face;
Lysander and myself will fly this place.
Before the time I did Lysander see
O
Helen
To-morrow night
Her silver visage in the watery glass
And in the wood
Upon faint primrose-beds were wont to lie
And thence from Athens turn away our eyes
Farewell
And good luck grant thee thy Demetrius!
Keep word
From lovers' food till morrow deep midnight.
I will
Exit HERMIA
Helena
As you on him
Exit
How happy some o'er other some can be!
Through Athens I am thought as fair as she.
But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so;
He will not know what all but he do know:
And as he errs
Things base and vile
Love looks not with the eyes
And therefore is wing'd Cupid painted blind:
Nor hath Love's mind of any judgement taste;
Wings and no eyes figure unheedy haste:
And therefore is Love said to be a child
As waggish boys in game themselves forswear
For ere Demetrius look'd on Hermia's eyne
And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt
I will go tell him of fair Hermia's flight:
Then to the wood will he to-morrow night
Pursue her; and for this intelligence
If I have thanks
But herein mean I to enrich my pain
Exit
SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
Enter QUINCE
Is all our company here?
You were best to call them generally
Here is the scroll of every man's name
thought fit
interlude before the duke and the duchess
wedding-day at night.
First
on
to a point.
Marry
most cruel death of Pyramus and Thisby.
A very good piece of work
merry. Now
actors by the scroll. Masters
Answer as I call you. Nick Bottom
Ready. Name what part I am for
You
What is Pyramus? a lover
A lover
That will ask some tears in the true performing of
it: if I do it
eyes; I will move storms
measure. To the rest: yet my chief humour is for a
tyrant: I could play Ercles rarely
tear a cat in
The raging rocks
And shivering shocks
Shall break the locks
Of prison gates;
And Phibbus' car
Shall shine from far
And make and mar
The foolish Fates.
This was lofty! Now name the rest of the players.
This is Ercles' vein
more condoling.

Here

What is Thisby? a wandering knight?
It is the lady that Pyramus must love.
Nay

You may do it extempore
Let me play the lion too: I will roar

An you should do it too terribly
the duchess and the ladies
and that were enough to hang us all.
That would hang us
I grant you
ladies out of their wits
discretion but to hang us: but I will aggravate my

nightingale.
You can play no part but Pyramus; for Pyramus is a

Well

Why

At the duke's oak we meet.
Enough; hold or cut bow-strings.
