ACT II
SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
Enter
How now
Over hill
And I serve the fairy queen
The cowslips tall her pensioners be:
In their gold coats spots you see;
Those be rubies
I must go seek some dewdrops here
And hang a pearl in every cowslip's ear.
Farewell
Our queen and all our elves come here anon.
The king doth keep his revels here to-night:
Take heed the queen come not within his sight;
For Oberon is passing fell and wrath
A lovely boy
She never had so sweet a changeling;
And jealous Oberon would have the child
Knight of his train
But she perforce withholds the loved boy
And now they never meet in grove or green
Creep into acorn-cups and hide them there.
Either I mistake your shape and making quite
Call'd Robin Goodfellow: are not you he
That frights the maidens of the villagery;
Skim milk
And bootless make the breathless housewife churn;
And sometime make the drink to bear no barm;
Mislead night-wanderers
Those that Hobgoblin call you and sweet Puck
Are not you he?
Thou speak'st aright;
I am that merry wanderer of the night.
I jest to Oberon and make him smile
When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile
And sometime lurk I in a gossip's bowl
And on her wither'd dewlap pour the ale.
The wisest aunt
Then slip I from her bum
And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh
A merrier hour was never wasted there.
But
And here my mistress. Would that he were gone!
Enter
Ill met by moonlight
What
I have forsworn his bed and company.
Tarry
Then I must be thy lady: but I know
When thou hast stolen away from fairy land
To amorous Phillida. Why art thou here
But that
To give their bed joy and prosperity.
How canst thou thus for shame
Didst thou not lead him through the glimmering night
From Perigenia
And make him with fair AEgle break his faith
These are the forgeries of jealousy:
And never
Therefore the winds
Contagious fogs; which falling in the land
Have every pelting river made so proud
That they have overborne their continents:
The ox hath therefore stretch'd his yoke in vain
Hath rotted ere his youth attain'd a beard;
The fold stands empty in the drowned field
The nine men's morris is fill'd up with mud
For lack of tread are undistinguishable:
The human mortals want their winter here;
No night is now with hymn or carol blest:
Therefore the moon
And thorough this distemperature we see
The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts
Far in the fresh lap of the crimson rose
An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds
Is
Their wonted liveries
And this same progeny of evils comes
From our debate
We are their parents and original.
Do you amend it then; it lies in you:
Why should Titania cross her Oberon?
I do but beg a little changeling boy
Set your heart at rest:
The fairy land buys not the child of me.
His mother was a votaress of my order:
And
And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind;
Which she
Following
Would imitate
But she
And for her sake do I rear up her boy
How long within this wood intend you stay?
Perchance till after Theseus' wedding-day.
If you will patiently dance in our round
And see our moonlight revels
If not
Give me that boy
Not for thy fairy kingdom. Fairies
We shall chide downright
Exit TITANIA with her train
Well
Till I torment thee for this injury.
My gentle Puck
Since once I sat upon a promontory
Uttering such dulcet and harmonious breath
That the rude sea grew civil at her song
And certain stars shot madly from their spheres
I remember.
That very time I saw
At a fair vestal throned by the west
But I might see young Cupid's fiery shaft
Quench'd in the chaste beams of the watery moon
Yet mark'd I where the bolt of Cupid fell:
It fell upon a little western flower
Fetch me that flower; the herb I shew'd thee once:
The juice of it on sleeping eye-lids laid
Will make or man or woman madly dote
Upon the next live creature that it sees.
Fetch me this herb; and be thou here again
Ere the leviathan can swim a league.
I'll put a girdle round about the earth
In forty minutes.
Exit
Having once this juice
The next thing then she waking looks upon
And ere I take this charm from off her sight
But who comes here? I am invisible;
And I will overhear their conference.
Enter DEMETRIUS
I love thee not
Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?
The one I'll slay
Thou told'st me they were stolen unto this wood;
And here am I
Hence
You draw me
But yet you draw not iron
Is true as steel: leave you your power to draw
Do I entice you? do I speak you fair?
Or
Tell you
And even for that do I love you the more.
I am your spaniel; and
Use me but as your spaniel
What worser place can I beg in your love
And yet a place of high respect with me
Than to be used as you use your dog?
Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit;
For I am sick when I do look on thee.
And I am sick when I look not on you.
You do impeach your modesty too much
Into the hands of one that loves you not;
To trust the opportunity of night
And the ill counsel of a desert place
With the rich worth of your virginity.
Your virtue is my privilege: for that
It is not night when I do see your face
Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company
Then how can it be said I am alone
I'll run from thee and hide me in the brakes
The wildest hath not such a heart as you.
Run when you will
Apollo flies
The dove pursues the griffin; the mild hind
Makes speed to catch the tiger; bootless speed
I will not stay thy questions; let me go:
Or
But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.
Ay
Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex:
We cannot fight for love
We should be wood and were not made to woo.
Exit DEMETRIUS
I'll follow thee and make a heaven of hell
Exit
Fare thee well
Re-enter PUCK
Hast thou the flower there? Welcome
Ay
I pray thee
I know a bank where the wild thyme blows
There sleeps Titania sometime of the night
And there the snake throws her enamell'd skin
And with the juice of this I'll streak her eyes
Take thou some of it
A sweet Athenian lady is in love
With a disdainful youth: anoint his eyes;
But do it when the next thing he espies
May be the lady: thou shalt know the man
By the Athenian garments he hath on.
Effect it with some care
More fond on her than she upon her love:
And look thou meet me ere the first cock crow.
Fear not
Exeunt
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
Enter TITANIA
Come
Then
Some to kill cankers in the musk-rose buds
The clamorous owl that nightly hoots and wonders
At our quaint spirits. Sing me now asleep;
Then to your offices and let me rest.
The Fairies sing
You spotted snakes with double tongue
Newts and blind-worms
Philomel
Sing in our sweet lullaby;
Lulla
Never harm
So
Weaving spiders
Hence
Beetles black
Worm nor snail
Philomel
Hence
One aloof stand sentinel.
Exeunt Fairies. TITANIA sleeps
Enter OBERON and squeezes the flower on TITANIA's eyelids
What thou seest when thou dost wake
Be it ounce
When thou wakest
Wake when some vile thing is near.
Exit
Enter LYSANDER and HERMIA
Fair love
And to speak troth
We'll rest us
Be it so
For I upon this bank will rest my head.
One turf shall serve as pillow for us both;
One heart
Nay
O
Love takes the meaning in love's conference.
I mean
So that but one heart we can make of it;
Two bosoms interchained with an oath;
So then two bosoms and a single troth.
Then by your side no bed-room me deny;
For lying so
Lysander riddles very prettily:
Now much beshrew my manners and my pride
But
Lie further off; in human modesty
Becomes a virtuous bachelor and a maid
Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end!
Amen
And then end life when I end loyalty!
Here is my bed: sleep give thee all his rest!
With half that wish the wisher's eyes be press'd!
They sleep

Through the forest have I gone.
But Athenian found I none
This flower's force in stirring love.

This is he

Not Hermia but Helena I love:
Who will not change a raven for a dove?
The will of man is by his reason sway'd;
And reason says you are the worthier maid.
Things growing are not ripe until their season
So I
And touching now the point of human skill
And leads me to your eyes
Love's stories written in love's richest book.

Is't not enough
Good troth

The shallowest thick-skin of that barren sort

Lies down and sleeps
What hast thou done? thou hast mistaken quite

Some true love turn'd and not a false turn'd true.
Then fate o'er-rules
About the wood go swifter than the wind
All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer

I'll charm his eyes against she do appear.
I go

Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail.

ACT V
SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
Enter THESEUS
'Tis strange my Theseus
lovers speak of.
More strange than true: I never may believe
These antique fables
Lovers and madmen have such seething brains
More than cool reason ever comprehends.
The lunatic
Are of imagination all compact:
One sees more devils than vast hell can hold
The poet's eye
And as imagination bodies forth
The forms of things unknown
Turns them to shapes and gives to airy nothing
A local habitation and a name.
Such tricks hath strong imagination
Or in the night
But all the story of the night told over
And grows to something of great constancy;
But
Here come the lovers
Enter LYSANDER
Joy
Accompany your hearts!
More than to us
Wait in your royal walks
Come now; what masques
Between our after-supper and bed-time?
Where is our usual manager of mirth?
What revels are in hand? Is there no play
Call Philostrate.
Here
Say
What masque? what music? How shall we beguile
The lazy time
There is a brief how many sports are ripe:
Make choice of which your highness will see first.
Giving a paper
[Reads]  'The battle with the Centaurs
By an Athenian eunuch to the harp.'
We'll none of that: that have I told my love
Reads
'The riot of the tipsy Bacchanals
That is an old device; and it was play'd
When I from Thebes came last a conqueror.
Reads
'The thrice three Muses mourning for the death
Of Learning
That is some satire
Reads
'A tedious brief scene of young Pyramus
And his love Thisbe; very tragical mirth.'
Merry and tragical! tedious and brief!
That is
How shall we find the concord of this discord?
A play there is
But by ten words
There is not one word apt
And tragical
For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.
Which
The passion of loud laughter never shed.
What are they that do play it?
Hard-handed men that work in Athens here
With this same play
And we will hear it.
No
It is not for you: I have heard it over
Unless you can find sport in their intents
I will hear that play;
For never anything can be amiss
Go
Exit PHILOSTRATE
I love not to see wretchedness o'er charged
And duty in his service perishing.
Why
He says they can do nothing in this kind.
The kinder we
Our sport shall be to take what they mistake:
And what poor duty cannot do
Takes it in might
Where I have come
To greet me with premeditated welcomes;
Where I have seen them shiver and look pale
And in conclusion dumbly have broke off
And in the modesty of fearful duty
I read as much as from the rattling tongue
Of saucy and audacious eloquence.
Love
In least speak most
Re-enter PHILOSTRATE
So please your grace
Let him approach.
Flourish of trumpets
Enter QUINCE for the Prologue
If we offend
That you should think
Consider then we come but in despite.
We do not come as minding to contest you
We are not here. That you should here repent you
You shall know all that you are like to know.
This fellow doth not stand upon points.
He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt; he knows
not the stop. A good moral
enough to speak
Indeed he hath played on his prologue like a child
on a recorder; a sound

impaired

I wonder if the lion be to speak.
No wonder

This loam
That I am that same wall; the truth is so:
And this the cranny is
Would you desire lime and hair to speak better?

Now is the mural down between the two neighbours.

without warning.
This is the silliest stuff that ever I heard.
The best in this kind are but shadows; and the worst

A very gentle beast

This lion is a very fox for his valour.
True; and a goose for his discretion.
Not so
discretion; and the fox carries the goose.
His discretion
for the goose carries not the fox. It is well:
leave it to his discretion
This lanthorn doth the horned moon present;--
He should have worn the horns on his head.
He is no crescent
invisible within the circumference.
This lanthorn doth the horned moon present;
Myself the man i' the moon do seem to be.
This is the greatest error of all the rest: the man
should be put into the lanthorn. How is it else the
man i' the moon?
He dares not come there for the candle; for
see

A dance
The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve:
Lovers
I fear we shall out-sleep the coming morn
As much as we this night have overwatch'd.
This palpable-gross play hath well beguiled
The heavy gait of night. Sweet friends
A fortnight hold we this solemnity
Exeunt
Enter PUCK
Now the hungry lion roars
Whilst the heavy ploughman snores
Now the wasted brands do glow
In remembrance of a shroud.
Now it is the time of night
That the graves all gaping wide
And we fairies
By the triple Hecate's team
Shall disturb this hallow'd house:
I am sent with broom before
Enter OBERON and TITANIA with their train
Through the house give gathering light
Every elf and fairy sprite
Hop as light as bird from brier;
And this ditty
First
To each word a warbling note:
Hand in hand
Song and dance
Now
To the best bride-bed will we
And the issue there create
Ever shall be fortunate.
So shall all the couples three
Ever true in loving be;
And the blots of Nature's hand
Shall not in their issue stand;
Never mole
Despised in nativity
With this field-dew consecrate
And each several chamber bless
And the owner of it blest
Ever shall in safety rest.
Trip away; make no stay;
Meet me all by break of day.
Exeunt OBERON
If we shadows have offended
While these visions did appear.
And this weak and idle theme
if you pardon
And
Now to 'scape the serpent's tongue
Else the Puck a liar call;
So
Give me your hands
ACT I
SCENE I. Before LEONATO'S house.
Enter LEONATO
I learn in this letter that Don Peter of Arragon
comes this night to Messina.
He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off
when I left him.
How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?
But few of any sort
A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings
home full numbers. I find here that Don Peter hath
bestowed much honour on a young Florentine called Claudio.
Much deserved on his part and equally remembered by
Don Pedro: he hath borne himself beyond the
promise of his age
bettered expectation than you must expect of me to
tell you how.
He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much
glad of it.
I have already delivered him letters
appears much joy in him; even so much that joy could
not show itself modest enough without a badge of
bitterness.
Did he break out into tears?
In great measure.
A kind overflow of kindness: there are no faces
truer than those that are so washed. How much
better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!
I pray you
wars or no?
I know none of that name
in the army of any sort.
What is he that you ask for
My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.
O
He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged
Cupid at the flight; and my uncle's fool
the challenge
him at the bird-bolt. I pray you
killed and eaten in these wars? But how many hath
he killed? for indeed I promised to eat all of his killing.
Faith
but he'll be meet with you
He hath done good service
You had musty victual
he is a very valiant trencherman; he hath an
excellent stomach.
And a good soldier too
And a good soldier to a lady: but what is he to a lord?
A lord to a lord
honourable virtues.
It is so
but for the stuffing
You must not
kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick and her:
they never meet but there's a skirmish of wit
between them.
Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last
conflict four of his five wits went halting off
now is the whole man governed with one: so that if
he have wit enough to keep himself warm
bear it for a difference between himself and his
horse; for it is all the wealth that he hath left
companion now? He hath every month a new sworn brother.
Is't possible?
Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as
the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with the
next block.
I see
No; an he were
you
squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the devil?
He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.
O Lord
is sooner caught than the pestilence
runs presently mad. God help the noble Claudio! if
he have caught the Benedick
thousand pound ere a' be cured.
I will hold friends with you
Do
You will never run mad
No
Don Pedro is approached.
Enter DON PEDRO
Good Signior Leonato
trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid
cost
Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of
your grace: for trouble being gone
remain; but when you depart from me
and happiness takes his leave.
You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this
is your daughter.
Her mother hath many times told me so.
Were you in doubt
Signior Benedick
You have it full
what you are
herself. Be happy
honourable father.
If Signior Leonato be her father
have his head on her shoulders for all Messina
like him as she is.
I wonder that you will still be talking
Benedick: nobody marks you.
What
Is it possible disdain should die while she hath
such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick?
Courtesy itself must convert to disdain
in her presence.
Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I
am loved of all ladies
would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard
heart; for
A dear happiness to women: they would else have
been troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God
and my cold blood
had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man
swear he loves me.
God keep your ladyship still in that mind! so some
gentleman or other shall 'scape a predestinate
scratched face.
Scratching could not make it worse
a face as yours were.
Well
A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.
I would my horse had the speed of your tongue
so good a continuer. But keep your way
name; I have done.
You always end with a jade's trick: I know you of old.
That is the sum of all
and Signior Benedick
invited you all. I tell him we shall stay here at
the least a month; and he heartily prays some
occasion may detain us longer. I dare swear he is no
hypocrite
If you swear

the prince your brother
I thank you: I am not of many words
you.

Your hand

Benedick
I noted her not; but I looked on her.
Is she not a modest young lady?
Do you question me
my simple true judgment; or would you have me speak
after my custom
No; I pray thee speak in sober judgment.
Why
praise
for a great praise: only this commendation I can

Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me

Would you buy her

Yea

you
In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I

My liege
My love is thine to teach: teach it but how
Any hard lesson that may do thee good.
Hath Leonato any son
No child but Hero; she's his only heir.
Dost thou affect her
O
Than to drive liking to the name of love:
But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts
Have left their places vacant
Come thronging soft and delicate desires
Thou wilt be like a lover presently
And tire the hearer with a book of words.
If thou dost love fair Hero
That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?
How sweetly you do minister to love
But lest my liking might too sudden seem
What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
The fairest grant is the necessity.
Look
I know we shall have revelling to-night:
I will assume thy part in some disguise
And tell fair Hero I am Claudio
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong encounter of my amorous tale:
Then after to her father will I break;
And the conclusion is
In practise let us put it presently.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.
Enter LEONATO and ANTONIO
How now
hath he provided this music?
He is very busy about it. But
you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.
Are they good?
As the event stamps them: but they have a good
cover; they show well outward. The prince and Count
Claudio
orchard

niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge it
this night in a dance: and if he found her
accordant
top and instantly break with you of it.

A good sharp fellow: I will send for him; and
question him yourself.
No
itself: but I will acquaint my daughter withal

SCENE III. The same.
Enter DON JOHN and CONRADE
What the good-year
of measure sad?
There is no measure in the occasion that breeds;
therefore the sadness is without limit.
You should hear reason.
And when I have heard it
If not a present remedy
sufferance.
I wonder that thou
medicine to a mortifying mischief. I cannot hide
what I am: I must be sad when I have cause and smile
at no man's jests
for no man's leisure
tend on no man's business
claw no man in his humour.
Yea
till you may do it without controlment. You have of
late stood out against your brother
ta'en you newly into his grace; where it is
impossible you should take true root but by the
fair weather that you make yourself: it is needful
that you frame the season for your own harvest.
I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in
his grace
disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob
love from any: in this
be a flattering honest man
but I am a plain-dealing villain. I am trusted with
a muzzle and enfranchised with a clog; therefore I
have decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had my
mouth
my liking: in the meantime let me be that I am and
seek not to alter me.
Can you make no use of your discontent?
I make all use of it
Who comes here?
Enter BORACHIO
What news
I came yonder from a great supper: the prince your
brother is royally entertained by Leonato: and I
can give you intelligence of an intended marriage.
Will it serve for any model to build mischief on?
What is he for a fool that betroths himself to
unquietness?
Marry
Who? the most exquisite Claudio?
Even he.
A proper squire! And who
he?
Marry
A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?
Being entertained for a perfumer

in hand in sad conference: I whipt me behind the
arras; and there heard it agreed upon that the
prince should woo Hero for himself
obtained her
Come
my displeasure. That young start-up hath all the
glory of my overthrow: if I can cross him any way
bless myself every way. You are both sure
To the death
Let us to the great supper: their cheer is the
greater that I am subdued. Would the cook were of
my mind! Shall we go prove what's to be done?
We'll wait upon your lordship.
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
Enter LEONATO
Was not Count John here at supper?
I saw him not.
How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see
him but I am heart-burned an hour after.
He is of a very melancholy disposition.
He were an excellent man that were made just in the
midway between him and Benedick: the one is too
like an image and says nothing
like my lady's eldest son
Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's
mouth
Benedick's face
With a good leg and a good foot
enough in his purse
in the world
By my troth
husband
In faith
Too curst is more than curst: I shall lessen God's
sending that way; for it is said
cow short horns;' but to a cow too curst he sends none.
So
Just
blessing I am at him upon my knees every morning and
evening. Lord
beard on his face: I had rather lie in the woollen.
You may light on a husband that hath no beard.
What should I do with him? dress him in my apparel
and make him my waiting-gentlewoman? He that hath a
beard is more than a youth
beard is less than a man: and he that is more than

man

Well

Lady

I may say so

I love you the better: the hearers may cry

Amen.

To tell you true

That I was disdainful

Not I

Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath

The ladies follow her and but one visor remains.
And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.

You know me well; I am he.
Signior
he is enamoured on Hero; I pray you
from her: she is no equal for his birth: you may

How know you he loves her?
I heard him swear his affection.
So did I too; and he swore he would marry her to-night.
Come
Exeunt DON JOHN and BORACHIO
Thus answer I in the name of Benedick
'Tis certain so; the prince wooes for himself.
Friendship is constant in all other things
Save in the office and affairs of love:
Therefore
Let every eye negotiate for itself
And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch
Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
This is an accident of hourly proof

Count Claudio?
Yea

Alas

Now
Troth
I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a

lady; and I offered him my company to a willow-tree

To be whipped! What's his fault?
The flat transgression of a schoolboy

companion
Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The

Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made
worn himself
you
I will but teach them to sing
the owner.
If their singing answer your saying
The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the

O
an oak but with one green leaf on it would have
answered her; my very visor began to assume life and
scold with her. She told me
myself
duller than a great thaw; huddling jest upon jest
with such impossible conveyance upon me that I stood
like a man at a mark
me. She speaks poniards
if her breath were as terrible as her terminations
the north star. I would not marry her
were endowed with all that Adam bad left him before
he transgressed: she would have made Hercules have
turned spit
the fire too. Come
her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God
some scholar would conjure her; for certainly
she is here
sanctuary; and people sin upon purpose
would go thither; so
and perturbation follows her.
Look
Enter CLAUDIO

ACT III
SCENE I. LEONATO'S garden.
Enter HERO
Good Margaret
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
Proposing with the prince and Claudio:
Whisper her ear and tell her
Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse
Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us;
And bid her steal into the pleached bower
Against that power that bred it: there will she hide her
Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.
I'll make her come
Exit
Now
When I do name him
To praise him more than ever man did merit:
My talk to thee must be how Benedick
Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter
Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made
Enter BEATRICE
Now begin;
For look where Beatrice
Close by the ground
The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream
So angle we for Beatrice; who even now
Is couched in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
Then go we near her
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.
Approaching the bower
No
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggerds of the rock.
But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
So says the prince and my new-trothed lord.
And did they bid you tell her of it
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man:
But Nature never framed a woman's heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes
Values itself so highly that to her
All matter else seems weak: she cannot love
Sure

Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.
Sure

As Beatrice is

Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.
No; rather I will go to Benedick

And
To stain my cousin with: one doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.
O
She cannot be so much without true judgment--
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is prized to have--as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.
He is the only man of Italy.
Always excepted my dear Claudio.
I pray you
Indeed
His excellence did earn it
When are you married
Why
I'll show thee some attires
Which is the best to furnish me to-morrow.
She's limed
If it proves so
Some Cupid kills with arrows

Contempt
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And
If thou dost love
To bind our loves up in a holy band;
For others say thou dost deserve
Believe it better than reportingly.
Exit

May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?
Nothing
Sweet prince
There
Give not this rotten orange to your friend;
She's but the sign and semblance of her honour.
Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
O
Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
Comes not that blood as modest evidence
To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed;
Her blush is guiltiness
What do you mean
Not to be married
Dear my lord
I know what you would say: if I have known her
No
But
Bashful sincerity and comely love.
And seem'd I ever otherwise to you?
Out on thee! Seeming! I will write against it:
You seem to me as Dian in her orb
But you are more intemperate in your blood
Than Venus
That rage in savage sensuality.
Is my lord well
Sweet prince
What should I speak?
I stand dishonour'd
To link my dear friend to a common stale.
Are these things spoken
Sir
This looks not like a nuptial.
True! O God!
Leonato
Is this the prince? is this the prince's brother?
Is this face Hero's? are our eyes our own?
All this is so: but what of this
Let me but move one question to your daughter;
And
That you have in her
I charge thee do so
O
What kind of catechising call you this?
To make you answer truly to your name.
Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name
With any just reproach?
Marry
Hero itself can blot out Hero's virtue.
What man was he talk'd with you yesternight
Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Now
I talk'd with no man at that hour

Who hath indeed
A thousand times in secret.
Fie

Without offence to utter them. Thus
O Hero
About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!
But fare thee well
For thee I'll lock up all the gates of love

Hero! why

Death is the fairest cover for her shame
That may be wish'd for.
How now
Have comfort
Dost thou look up?
Yea

Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny
The story that is printed in her blood?

For

O
Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Took up a beggar's issue at my gates
This shame derives itself from unknown loins'?
But mine and mine I loved and mine I praised
And mine that I was proud on
That I myself was to myself not mine
Into a pit of ink
Hath drops too few to wash her clean again
And salt too little which may season give
To her foul-tainted flesh!
Sir
For my part
O
Lady

Confirm'd
Which was before barr'd up with ribs of iron!
Would the two princes lie
Hear me a little;
For I have only been silent so long
And given way unto this course of fortune.
...
By noting of the lady I have mark'd
A thousand blushing apparitions
To start into her face
In angel whiteness beat away those blushes;
And in her eye there hath appear'd a fire
Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool;
Trust not my reading nor my observations
The tenor of my book; trust not my age
Under some biting error.
Friar
Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left
Is that she will not add to her damnation
A sin of perjury; she not denies it:
Why seek'st thou then to cover with excuse
That which appears in proper nakedness?
Lady
They know that do accuse me; I know none:
If I know more of any man alive
Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant
At hours unmeet
Maintain'd the change of words with any creature
There is some strange misprision in the princes.
Two of them have the very bent of honour;
And if their wisdoms be misled in this
I know not. If they speak but truth of her
Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine
Pause awhile
Your daughter here the princes left for dead:
Let her awhile be secretly kept in
Maintain a mourning ostentation
And on your family's old monument
Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites
That appertain unto a burial.
What shall become of this? what will this do?
Marry
Change slander to remorse; that is some good:
But not for that dream I on this strange course
She dying
Of every hearer: for it so falls out
That what we have we prize not to the worth
Whiles we enjoy it
The virtue that possession would not show us
Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio:
When he shall hear she died upon his words
Into his study of imagination
Shall come apparell'd in more precious habit
Let this be so
Will fashion the event in better shape
Than I can lay it down in likelihood.
But if all aim but this be levell'd false
Will quench the wonder of her infamy:
And if it sort not well
Signior Leonato
And though you know my inwardness and love
Is very much unto the prince and Claudio
As secretly and justly as your soul
Should with your body.
Being that I flow in grief
'Tis well consented: presently away;
For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure.
Come
Perhaps is but prolong'd: have patience and endure.

Yea

Ah

ACT V
SCENE I. Before LEONATO'S house.
Enter LEONATO and ANTONIO
If you go on thus
And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief
Against yourself.
I pray thee
As water in a sieve: give not me counsel;
Nor let no comforter delight mine ear
But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.
Bring me a father that so loved his child
Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine
And let it answer every strain for strain
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard
With candle-wasters; bring him yet to me
But there is no such man: for
Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief
Which they themselves not feel; but
Would give preceptial medicine to rage
No
To those that wring under the load of sorrow
To be so moral when he shall endure
The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel:
My griefs cry louder than advertisement.
Therein do men from children nothing differ.
I pray thee
For there was never yet philosopher
That could endure the toothache patiently
And made a push at chance and sufferance.
Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself;
Make those that do offend you suffer too.
There thou speak'st reason: nay
My soul doth tell me Hero is belied;
And that shall Claudio know; so shall the prince
And all of them that thus dishonour her.
Here comes the prince and Claudio hastily.

ACT I
SCENE I. Venice. A street.
Enter RODERIGO and IAGO
Tush! never tell me; I take it much unkindly
That thou
As if the strings were thine
'Sblood
If ever I did dream of such a matter
Thou told'st me thou didst hold him in thy hate.
Despise me
But he; as loving his own pride and purposes
Horribly stuff'd with epithets of war;
And
And what was he?
Forsooth
That never set a squadron in the field
More than a spinster; unless the bookish theoric
As masterly as he: mere prattle
And I
At Rhodes
Christian and heathen
By debitor and creditor: this counter-caster
By heaven
Why
Stood heir to the first. Now
To love the Moor.
I would not follow him then.
O
I follow him to serve my turn upon him:
We cannot all be masters
Cannot be truly follow'd. You shall mark
Many a duteous and knee-crooking knave
Whip me such honest knaves. Others there are
Who
their coats
Do themselves homage: these fellows have some soul;
And such a one do I profess myself. For
In following him
Heaven is my judge
For when my outward action doth demonstrate
The native act and figure of my heart
In compliment extern
But I will wear my heart upon my sleeve
For daws to peck at: I am not what I am.
What a full fortune does the thicklips owe
If he can carry't thus!
Call up her father
Here is her father's house; I'll call aloud.
Do
As when

What

My name is Roderigo.
The worser welcome:

To start my quiet.
Sir

Sir
But with a knave of common hire
If this be known to you and your allowance
But if you know not this
We have your wrong rebuke. Do not believe
That
Your daughter
Tying her duty
In an extravagant and wheeling stranger
Of here and every where. Straight satisfy yourself:
If she be in her chamber or your house
For thus deluding you.
Strike on the tinder
Give me a taper! call up all my people!
This accident is not unlike my dream:
Belief of it oppresses me already.
Light
Exit above
Farewell; for I must leave you:
It seems not meet
Against the Moor: for
With such loud reason to the Cyprus wars
Yet
And there will I be with him. So
Exit
Enter
It is too true an evil: gone she is;
And what's to come of my despised time
Is nought but bitterness. Now
With the Moor
How didst thou know 'twas she? O she deceives me
Past thought! What said she to you? Get more tapers:
Raise all my kindred. Are they married
Truly
O heaven! How got she out? O treason of the blood!
Fathers
By what you see them act. Is there not charms
By which the property of youth and maidhood
May be abused? Have you not read
Yes

Some one way
Where we may apprehend her and the Moor?
I think I can discover him
Pray you
I may command at most. Get weapons
And raise some special officers of night.
On
Exeunt
SCENE II. Another street.
Enter OTHELLO
Though in the trade of war I have slain men
To do no contrived murder: I lack iniquity
Sometimes to do me service: nine or ten times
I had thought to have yerk'd him here under the ribs.
'Tis better as it is.
Nay
Against your honour
That
As double as the duke's: he will divorce you;
Or put upon you what restraint and grievance
The law
Let him do his spite:
My services which I have done the signiory
Shall out-tongue his complaints. 'Tis yet to know
Which
From men of royal siege
May speak unbonneted to as proud a fortune
As this that I have reach'd: for know
Put into circumscription and confine
For the sea's worth. But
Those are the raised father and his friends:
You were best go in.
"Not I	I must be found:"
My parts
Shall manifest me rightly. Is it they?
By Janus
Enter CASSIO
The servants of the duke
The goodness of the night upon you
What is the news?
The duke does greet you
What is the matter
Something from Cyprus as I may divine:
It is a business of some heat: the galleys
Have sent a dozen sequent messengers
This very night at one another's heels
hotly call'd for;
When
To search you out.
'Tis well I am found by you.
I will but spend a word here in the house
Exit
Ancient
'Faith
If it prove lawful prize
I do not understand.
He's married.

Marry

It is Brabantio. General
He comes to bad intent.
Enter BRABANTIO
Holla! stand there!
Signior
Down with him
They draw on both sides
You
Keep up your bright swords
Good signior
Than with your weapons.
O thou foul thief
Damn'd as thou art
For I'll refer me to all things of sense
The wealthy curled darlings of our nation
Of such a thing as thou
Judge me the world
That thou hast practised on her with foul charms
That weaken motion: I'll have't disputed on;
'Tis probable and palpable to thinking.
I therefore apprehend and do attach thee
For an abuser of the world
Of arts inhibited and out of warrant.
Lay hold upon him: if he do resist
Hold your hands
Were it my cue to fight
Without a prompter. Where will you that I go
To answer this your charge?
To prison
Of law and course of direct session
Call thee to answer.
What if I do obey?
How may the duke be therewith satisfied
To bring me to him?
'Tis true
The duke's in council and your noble self
How! the duke in council!
In this time of the night! Bring him away:
Mine's not an idle cause: the duke himself
For if such actions may have passage free
Exeunt
SCENE III. A council-chamber.
The DUKE and Senators sitting at a table; Officers attending
There is no composition in these news
That gives them credit.
Indeed
My letters say a hundred and seven galleys.
And mine
And mine
But though they jump not on a just account
As in these cases
A Turkish fleet
Nay
I do not so secure me in the error
In fearful sense.
[Within]  What
A messenger from the galleys.
Enter a Sailor
Now
The Turkish preparation makes for Rhodes;
So was I bid report here to the state
By Signior Angelo.
How say you by this change?
This cannot be
The importancy of Cyprus to the Turk
That Rhodes is dress'd in: if we make thought of this
To leave that latest which concerns him first
Nay
Here is more news.
Enter a Messenger
The Ottomites
Ay
Of thirty sail: and now they do restem
Their backward course
Their purposes toward Cyprus. Signior Montano
'Tis certain
Marcus Luccicos
He's now in Florence.
Write from us to him; post-post-haste dispatch.
Here comes Brabantio and the valiant Moor.
Enter BRABANTIO
Valiant Othello
Against the general enemy Ottoman.
To BRABANTIO
I did not see you; welcome
We lack'd your counsel and your help tonight.
So did I yours. Good your grace
Neither my place nor aught I heard of business
Hath raised me from my bed
Take hold on me
Is of so flood-gate and o'erbearing nature
That it engluts and swallows other sorrows
And it is still itself.
Why
My daughter! O
Dead?
Ay
She is abused
By spells and medicines bought of mountebanks;
For nature so preposterously to err
Whoe'er he be that in this foul proceeding
Hath thus beguiled your daughter of herself
And you of her
You shall yourself read in the bitter letter
After your own sense
Stood in your action.
Humbly I thank your grace.
Here is the man
Hath hither brought.
We are very sorry for't.
[To OTHELLO]  What
Nothing
Most potent
The very head and front of my offending
Hath this extent
For since these arms of mine had seven years' pith
Their dearest action in the tented field
In speaking for myself. Yet
Of my whole course of love; what drugs
A maiden never bold;
Of spirit so still and quiet
Blush'd at herself; and she
It is a judgment maim'd and most imperfect
That will confess perfection so could err
Against all rules of nature
To find out practises of cunning hell
That with some mixtures powerful o'er the blood
To vouch this
Than these thin habits and poor likelihoods
Of modern seeming do prefer against him.
But
Did you by indirect and forced courses
Subdue and poison this young maid's affections?
Or came it by request and such fair question
As soul to soul affordeth?
I do beseech you
If you do find me foul in her report
Even fall upon my life.
Fetch Desdemona hither.
Ancient
Exeunt IAGO and Attendants
And
I do confess the vices of my blood
How I did thrive in this fair lady's love
Say it
Her father loved me; oft invited me;
Still question'd me the story of my life
I ran it through
Wherein I spake of most disastrous chances
Of hair-breadth scapes i' the imminent deadly breach
And sold to slavery
And portance in my travels' history:
Wherein of antres vast and deserts idle
It was my hint to speak
And of the Cannibals that each other eat
Do grow beneath their shoulders. This to hear
Would Desdemona seriously incline:
But still the house-affairs would draw her thence:
Which ever as she could with haste dispatch
Devour up my discourse: which I observing
To draw from her a prayer of earnest heart
That I would all my pilgrimage dilate
That my youth suffer'd. My story being done
She swore
She wish'd she had not heard it
That heaven had made her such a man: she thank'd me
And that would woo her. Upon this hint I spake:
She loved me for the dangers I had pass'd
This only is the witchcraft I have used:
Here comes the lady; let her witness it.
Enter DESDEMONA
I think this tale would win my daughter too.
Good Brabantio
Men do their broken weapons rather use
Than their bare hands.
I pray you
If she confess that she was half the wooer
Light on the man! Come hither
Do you perceive in all this noble company
Where most you owe obedience?
My noble father
To you I am bound for life and education;
My life and education both do learn me
How to respect you; you are the lord of duty;
I am hitherto your daughter: but here's my husband
To you
Due to the Moor my lord.
God be wi' you! I have done.
Please it your grace
I had rather to adopt a child than get it.
Come hither
I here do give thee that with all my heart
Which
I would keep from thee. For your sake
For thy escape would teach me tyranny
Let me speak like yourself
Into your favour.
When remedies are past
By seeing the worst
To mourn a mischief that is past and gone
Is the next way to draw new mischief on.
What cannot be preserved when fortune takes
Patience her injury a mockery makes.
The robb'd that smiles steals something from the thief;
He robs himself that spends a bootless grief.
So let the Turk of Cyprus us beguile;
We lose it not
He bears the sentence well that nothing bears
But the free comfort which from thence he hears
That
These sentences
But words are words; I never yet did hear
That the bruised heart was pierced through the ear.
I humbly beseech you
The Turk with a most mighty preparation makes for
Cyprus. Othello
known to you; and though we have there a substitute
of most allowed sufficiency
sovereign mistress of effects
voice on you: you must therefore be content to
slubber the gloss of your new fortunes with this
more stubborn and boisterous expedition.
The tyrant custom
My thrice-driven bed of down: I do agnise
A natural and prompt alacrity
I find in hardness
These present wars against the Ottomites.
Most humbly therefore bending to your state
Due reference of place and exhibition
As levels with her breeding.
If you please
I'll not have it so.
Nor I.
Nor I; I would not there reside
By being in his eye. Most gracious duke
And let me find a charter in your voice
What would You
That I did love the Moor to live with him
May trumpet to the world: my heart's subdued
Even to the very quality of my lord:
I saw Othello's visage in his mind
Did I my soul and fortunes consecrate.
So that
By his dear absence. Let me go with him.
Let her have your voices.
Vouch with me
In me defunct--and proper satisfaction.
But to be free and bounteous to her mind:
And heaven defend your good souls
I will your serious and great business scant
For she is with me: no
Of feather'd Cupid seal with wanton dullness
My speculative and officed instruments
Make head against my estimation!
Be it as you shall privately determine
You must away to-night.
With all my heart.
At nine i' the morning here we'll meet again.
Othello
With such things else of quality and respect
As doth import you.
So please your grace
A man he is of honest and trust:
To his conveyance I assign my wife
To be sent after me.
Let it be so.
Good night to every one.
To BRABANTIO
And
Adieu
Look to her
She has deceived her father

My life upon her faith! Honest Iago
I prithee
And bring them after in the best advantage.
Come
Of love
Exeunt OTHELLO and DESDEMONA
Iago
What say'st thou
What will I do
Why
I will incontinently drown myself.
If thou dost
It is silliness to live when to live is torment; and
then have we a prescription to die when death is our physician.
O villainous! I have looked upon the world for four
times seven years; and since I could distinguish
betwixt a benefit and an injury
that knew how to love himself. Ere I would say
would drown myself for the love of a guinea-hen
would change my humanity with a baboon.
What should I do? I confess it is my shame to be so
fond; but it is not in my virtue to amend it.
Virtue! a fig! 'tis in ourselves that we are thus
or thus. Our bodies are our gardens
our wills are gardeners: so that if we will plant
nettles
thyme
distract it with many
with idleness
power and corrigible authority of this lies in our
wills. If the balance of our lives had not one
scale of reason to poise another of sensuality
blood and baseness of our natures would conduct us
to most preposterous conclusions: but we have
reason to cool our raging motions
stings
you call love to be a sect or scion.
It cannot be.
It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of
the will. Come
cats and blind puppies. I have professed me thy
friend and I confess me knit to thy deserving with
cables of perdurable toughness; I could never
better stead thee than now. Put money in thy
purse; follow thou the wars; defeat thy favour with
an usurped beard; I say
cannot be that Desdemona should long continue her
love to the Moor
his to her: it was a violent commencement
shalt see an answerable sequestration:--put but
money in thy purse. These Moors are changeable in
their wills: fill thy purse with money:--the food
that to him now is as luscious as locusts
to him shortly as bitter as coloquintida. She must
change for youth: when she is sated with his body
have change
purse. If thou wilt needs damn thyself
more delicate way than drowning. Make all the money
thou canst: if sanctimony and a frail vow betwixt
an erring barbarian and a supersubtle Venetian not
too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell
shalt enjoy her; therefore make money. A pox of
drowning thyself! it is clean out of the way: seek
thou rather to be hanged in compassing thy joy than
to be drowned and go without her.
Wilt thou be fast to my hopes
the issue?
Thou art sure of me:--go
thee often
hate the Moor: my cause is hearted; thine hath no
less reason. Let us be conjunctive in our revenge
against him: if thou canst cuckold him
thyself a pleasure
events in the womb of time which will be delivered.
Traverse! go
of this to-morrow. Adieu.
Where shall we meet i' the morning?
At my lodging.
I'll be with thee betimes.
Go to; farewell. Do you hear
What say you?
No more of drowning
I am changed: I'll go sell all my land.
Exit
Thus do I ever make my fool my purse:
For I mine own gain'd knowledge should profane
But for my sport and profit. I hate the Moor:
And it is thought abroad
He has done my office: I know not if't be true;
But I
The better shall my purpose work on him.
Cassio's a proper man: let me see now:
To get his place and to plume up my will
In double knavery--How
After some time
That he is too familiar with his wife.
He hath a person and a smooth dispose
To be suspected
The Moor is of a free and open nature
As asses are.
I have't. It is engender'd. Hell and night
Must bring this monstrous birth to the world's light.
Exit
ACT II
SCENE I. A Sea-port in Cyprus. An open place near the quay.
Enter MONTANO and two Gentlemen
What from the cape can you discern at sea?
Nothing at all: it is a highwrought flood;
I cannot
Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land;
A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements:
If it hath ruffian'd so upon the sea
A segregation of the Turkish fleet:
For do but stand upon the foaming shore
The wind-shaked surge
I never did like molestation view
On the enchafed flood.
If that the Turkish fleet
Be not enshelter'd and embay'd
It is impossible they bear it out.
Enter a third Gentleman
News
The desperate tempest hath so bang'd the Turks
Hath seen a grievous wreck and sufferance
On most part of their fleet.
How! is this true?
The ship is here put in
I am glad on't; 'tis a worthy governor.
But this same Cassio
Touching the Turkish loss
With foul and violent tempest.
Pray heavens he be;
For I have served him
Like a full soldier. Let's to the seaside
As well to see the vessel that's come in
As to throw out our eyes for brave Othello
An indistinct regard.
Come
For every minute is expectancy
Of more arrivance.
Enter CASSIO
Thanks
Give him defence against the elements
Is he well shipp'd?
His bark is stoutly timber'd
Of very expert and approved allowance;
Therefore my hopes
A cry within 'A sail
Enter a fourth Gentleman
What noise?
The town is empty; on the brow o' the sea
Stand ranks of people
My hopes do shape him for the governor.
Guns heard
They do discharge their shot of courtesy:
Our friends at least.
I pray you
I shall.
Exit
But
Most fortunately: he hath achieved a maid
That paragons description and wild fame;
One that excels the quirks of blazoning pens
Does tire the ingener.
Re-enter second Gentleman
How now! who has put in?
'Tis one Iago
Has had most favourable and happy speed:
Tempests themselves
Traitors ensteep'd to clog the guiltless keel
As having sense of beauty
Their mortal natures
The divine Desdemona.
What is she?
She that I spake of
A se'nnight's speed. Great Jove
And bring all Cyprus comfort!
Enter DESDEMONA
O
Ye men of Cyprus
Hail to thee
I thank you
What tidings can you tell me of my lord?
He is not yet arrived: nor know I aught
But that he's well and will be shortly here.
O
The great contention of the sea and skies
Parted our fellowship--But
Within 'A sail
They give their greeting to the citadel;
This likewise is a friend.
See for the news.
Exit Gentleman
Good ancient
To EMILIA
Welcome
Let it not gall your patience
That gives me this bold show of courtesy.
Kissing her
Sir
As of her tongue she oft bestows on me
Alas
In faith
I find it still
Marry
You have little cause to say so.
Come on
O
Nay
You rise to play and go to bed to work.
You shall not write my praise.
No
What wouldst thou write of me
praise me?
O gentle lady
For I am nothing
Come on assay. There's one gone to the harbour?
Ay
I am not merry; but I do beguile
The thing I am
Come
I am about it; but indeed my invention
Comes from my pate as birdlime does from frize;
It plucks out brains and all: but my Muse labours
If she be fair and wise
Well praised! How if she be black and witty?
If she be black
Worse and worse.
How if fair and foolish?
She never yet was foolish that was fair;
For even her folly help'd her to an heir.
These are old fond paradoxes to make fools laugh i'
the alehouse. What miserable praise hast thou for
her that's foul and foolish?
There's none so foul and foolish thereunto
O heavy ignorance! thou praisest the worst best.
But what praise couldst thou bestow on a deserving
woman indeed
merit
She that was ever fair and never proud
She that being anger'd
To change the cod's head for the salmon's tail;
She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind
To do what?
To suckle fools and chronicle small beer.
O most lame and impotent conclusion! Do not learn
of him
you
counsellor?
He speaks home
the soldier than in the scholar.

her

to your lips? would they were clyster-pipes for your sake!
Trumpet within
The Moor! I know his trumpet.
'Tis truly so.
Let's meet him and receive him.
Lo
Enter OTHELLO and Attendants
O my fair warrior!
My dear Othello!
It gives me wonder great as my content
To see you here before me. O my soul's joy!
If after every tempest come such calms
And let the labouring bark climb hills of seas
Olympus-high and duck again as low
As hell's from heaven! If it were now to die
That not another comfort like to this
Succeeds in unknown fate.
The heavens forbid
But that our loves and comforts should increase
Amen to that
I cannot speak enough of this content;
It stops me here; it is too much of joy:
And this
Kissing her
That e'er our hearts shall make!
[Aside]  O
But I'll set down the pegs that make this music

are drown'd.

Honey

In mine own comforts. I prithee

Does challenge much respect. Come
Exeunt OTHELLO
Do thou meet me presently at the harbour. Come

directly in love with him.
With him! why
Lay thy finger thus

the Moor is defective in: now
required conveniences

finder of occasions

present itself; a devilish knave. Besides

requisites in him that folly and green minds look
after: a pestilent complete knave; and the woman
hath found him already.
I cannot believe that in her; she's full of
most blessed condition.
Blessed fig's-end! the wine she drinks is made of

have loved the Moor. Blessed pudding! Didst thou

Yes

opportunity.

That Cassio loves her
That she loves him
The Moor
A most dear husband. Now
Not out of absolute lust
I stand accountant for as great a sin
Hath leap'd into my seat; the thought whereof
Doth
And nothing can or shall content my soul
Till I am even'd with him
At least into a jealousy so strong
That judgment cannot cure. Which thing to do
For his quick hunting
For I fear Cassio with my night-cap too--
Make the Moor thank me
For making him egregiously an ass
And practising upon his peace and quiet
Even to madness. 'Tis here
Knavery's plain face is never seen tin used.
Exit

revels his addiction leads him: for
beneficial news
nuptial. So much was his pleasure should be
proclaimed. All offices are open
liberty of feasting from this present hour of five

isle of Cyprus and our noble general Othello!
Exeunt
SCENE III. A hall in the castle.

Iago hath direction what to do;
But

Iago is most honest.

Welcome
Not this hour
clock. Our general cast us thus early for the love

she is sport for Jove.
She's a most exquisite lady.
And
Indeed
What an eye she has! methinks it sounds a parley of
provocation.
An inviting eye; and yet methinks right modest.
And when she speaks
She is indeed perfection.

Potations pottle-deep; and he's to watch:

To the platform
You see this fellow that is gone before;
He is a soldier fit to stand by Caesar
And give direction: and do but see his vice;
'Tis to his virtue a just equinox
I fear the trust Othello puts him in.
On some odd time of his infirmity
But is he often thus?
'Tis evermore the prologue to his sleep:
He'll watch the horologe a double set
It were well
The general were put in mind of it.
Perhaps he sees it not; or his good nature
Prizes the virtue that appears in Cassio

Exit RODERIGO
And 'tis great pity that the noble Moor
Should hazard such a place as his own second
With one of an ingraft infirmity:
It were an honest action to say
So to the Moor.
Not I
I do love Cassio well; and would do much
To cure him of this evil--But
Cry within: 'Help! help!'
Re-enter CASSIO
You rogue! you rascal!
What's the matter
A knave teach me my duty!
I'll beat the knave into a twiggen bottle.
Beat me!
Dost thou prate
Striking RODERIGO
Nay
Staying him
I pray you
Let me go
Come
Drunk!
They fight
[Aside to RODERIGO]  Away
Exit RODERIGO
Nay
Help
Help
Bell rings
Who's that which rings the bell?--Diablo
The town will rise: God's will
You will be shamed for ever.
Re-enter OTHELLO and Attendants
What is the matter here?
'Zounds
Faints
Hold
Hold
Have you forgot all sense of place and duty?
Hold! the general speaks to you; hold
Why
Are we turn'd Turks
Which heaven hath forbid the Ottomites?
For Christian shame
He that stirs next to carve for his own rage
Holds his soul light; he dies upon his motion.
Silence that dreadful bell: it frights the isle
From her propriety. What is the matter
Honest Iago
I do not know: friends all but now
Devesting them for bed; and then
As if some planet had unwitted men--
Swords out
Any beginning to this peevish odds;
And would in action glorious I had lost
Those legs that brought me to a part of it!
How comes it
I pray you
Worthy Montano
The gravity and stillness of your youth
The world hath noted
In mouths of wisest censure: what's the matter
And spend your rich opinion for the name
Of a night-brawler? give me answer to it.
Worthy Othello
Your officer
While I spare speech
offends me
Of all that I do know: nor know I aught
By me that's said or done amiss this night;
Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice
When violence assails us.
Now
And passion
Shall sink in my rebuke. Give me to know
How this foul rout began
And he that is approved in this offence
'Tis monstrous. Iago
If partially affined
Touch me not so near:
I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth
Than it should do offence to Michael Cassio;
Yet
Shall nothing wrong him. Thus it is
Montano and myself being in speech
And Cassio following him with determined sword
Steps in to Cassio
Myself the crying fellow did pursue
The town might fall in fright: he
For that I heard the clink and fall of swords
I ne'er might say before. When I came back--
For this was brief--I found them close together
When you yourself did part them.
More of this matter cannot I report:
But men are men; the best sometimes forget:
Though Cassio did some little wrong to him
From him that fled some strange indignity
I know
But never more be officer of mine.
Re-enter DESDEMONA
Look
I'll make thee an example.
What's the matter?
All's well now
Sir
Lead him off.
To MONTANO
Iago
Come
To have their balmy slumbers waked with strife.
Exeunt all but IAGO and CASSIO
What
Ay
Marry
Reputation
my reputation! I have lost the immortal part of
myself
As I am an honest man
some bodily wound; there is more sense in that than

deserving: you have lost no reputation at all
there are ways to recover the general again: you
are but now cast in his mood
policy than in malice
offenceless dog to affright an imperious lion: sue
to him again
I will rather sue to be despised than to deceive so
good a commander with so slight
indiscreet an officer. Drunk? and speak parrot?
and squabble? swagger? swear? and discourse
fustian with one's own shadow? O thou invisible
spirit of wine
What was he that you followed with your sword? What
had he done to you?
I know not.
Is't possible?
I remember a mass of things
a quarrel
should put an enemy in their mouths to steal away

revel and applause

recovered?
It hath pleased the devil drunkenness to give place

Come

but
I will ask him for my place again; he shall tell me
I am a drunkard! Had I as many mouths as Hydra
sensible man
beast! O strange! Every inordinate cup is

Come
And
I have well approved it
You or any man living may be drunk! at a time
I'll tell you what you shall do. Our general's wife
is now the general: may say so in this respect
that he hath devoted and given up himself to the
contemplation
graces: confess yourself freely to her; importune

so free
than she is requested: this broken joint between
you and her husband entreat her to splinter; and
fortunes against any lay worth naming
crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.
You advise me well.
I protest
I think it freely; and betimes in the morning I will
beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me:
I am desperate of my fortunes if they cheque me here.
You are in the right. Good night
must to the watch.
CASSIO: Good night
Exit
And what's he then that says I play the villain?
When this advice is free I give and honest
To win the Moor again? For 'tis most easy
The inclining Desdemona to subdue
In any honest suit: she's framed as fruitful
As the free elements. And then for her
To win the Moor--were't to renounce his baptism
With his weak function. How am I then a villain
To counsel Cassio to this parallel course
When devils will the blackest sins put on
Plies Desdemona to repair his fortunes
And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor
And by how much she strives to do him good
So will I turn her virtue into pitch
That shall enmesh them all.
Re-enter RODERIGO
How now
I do follow here in the chase
hunts
almost spent; I have been to-night exceedingly well
cudgelled; and I think the issue will be
have so much experience for my pains
no money at all and a little more wit
How poor are they that have not patience!
What wound did ever heal but by degrees?
Thou know'st we work by wit
And wit depends on dilatory time.
Does't not go well? Cassio hath beaten thee.
And thou
Though other things grow fair against the sun
Content thyself awhile. By the mass
Pleasure and action make the hours seem short.
Retire thee; go where thou art billeted:
Away
Nay
Exit RODERIGO
Two things are to be done:
My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress;
I'll set her on;
Myself the while to draw the Moor apart
Soliciting his wife: ay
Dull not device by coldness and delay.
Exit

I never knew
A Florentine more kind and honest.
Enter EMILIA
Good morrow
For your displeasure; but all will sure be well.
The general and his wife are talking of it;
And she speaks for you stoutly: the Moor replies
He might not but refuse you; but he protests he loves you
And needs no other suitor but his likings
To take the safest occasion by the front
To bring you in again.
Yet
With Desdemona alone.
Pray you
I will bestow you where you shall have time
To speak your bosom freely.
I am much bound to you.
Exeunt

Enter OTHELLO
These letters give
And by him do my duties to the senate:
That done
Repair there to me.
Well
This fortification
We'll wait upon your lordship.

SCENE III. The garden of the castle.
Enter DESDEMONA
Be thou assured
All my abilities in thy behalf.
Good madam
O
As friendly as you were.
Bounteous madam
I know't; I thank you. You do love my lord:
You have known him long; and be you well assured
He shall in strangeness stand no further off
Than in a polite distance.
Ay
Do not doubt that; before Emilia here
I give thee warrant of thy place: assure thee
To the last article: my lord shall never rest;
I'll watch him tame and talk him out of patience;
His bed shall seem a school
I'll intermingle every thing he does
With Cassio's suit: therefore be merry
For thy solicitor shall rather die
Than give thy cause away.
Madam
Madam
Why
Madam
Well

How now

Why

Ay
That he hath left part of his grief with me
Not now
But shall't be shortly?
The sooner
Shall't be to-night at supper?
No
To-morrow dinner

I meet the captains at the citadel.
Why

I prithee

And yet his trespass
Save that
Out of their best--is not almost a fault

Tell me
To bring him in! Trust me
Prithee

Why

To your own person: nay
Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed
And fearful to be granted.
I will deny thee nothing:
Whereon
Shall I deny you? no: farewell

Emilia
Whate'er you be

Excellent wretch! Perdition catch my soul
My noble lord--

Did Michael Cassio
He did
But for a satisfaction of my thought;

O
Indeed!

Honest

My lord

Think
Think
By heaven
Too hideous to be shown. Thou dost mean something:
I heard thee say even now
And when I told thee he was of my counsel
In my whole course of wooing
And didst contract and purse thy brow together
Some horrible conceit: if thou dost love me
My lord
I think thou dost;
And
For such things in a false disloyal knave
Are tricks of custom
They are close delations
That passion cannot rule.
For Michael Cassio
I think so too.
Men should be what they seem;
Or those that be not
Certain
Why
Nay
I prithee
The worst of words.
Good my lord
Though I am bound to every act of duty
Utter my thoughts? Why
As where's that palace whereinto foul things
Sometimes intrude not? who has a breast so pure
Keep leets and law-days and in session sit
With meditations lawful?
Thou dost conspire against thy friend
A stranger to thy thoughts.
I do beseech you--
Though I perchance am vicious in my guess
To spy into abuses
Shapes faults that are not--that your wisdom yet
Out of his scattering and unsure observance.
It were not for your quiet nor your good
What dost thou mean?
Good name in man and woman
Who steals my purse steals trash; 'tis something
'Twas mine
But he that filches from me my good name
Robs me of that which not enriches him
And makes me poor indeed.
By heaven
You cannot
Nor shall not
Ha!
O
It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock
The meat it feeds on; that cuckold lives in bliss
Who
But
Who dotes
O misery!
Poor and content is rich and rich enough
To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
Good heaven
From jealousy!
Why
Think'st thou I'ld make a lie of jealousy
With fresh suspicions? No; to be once in doubt
Is once to be resolved: exchange me for a goat
To such exsufflicate and blown surmises
To say my wife is fair
Where virtue is
Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw
The smallest fear or doubt of her revolt;
For she had eyes
I'll see before I doubt; when I doubt
And on the proof
Away at once with love or jealousy!
I am glad of it; for now I shall have reason
To show the love and duty that I bear you
With franker spirit: therefore
Look to your wife; observe her well with Cassio;
Wear your eye thus
I would not have your free and noble nature
I know our country disposition well;
In Venice they do let heaven see the pranks
They dare not show their husbands; their best conscience
Is not to leave't undone
Dost thou say so?
She did deceive her father
And when she seem'd to shake and fear your looks
And so she did.
Why
She that
He thought 'twas witchcraft--but I am much to blame;
I humbly do beseech you of your pardon
For too much loving you.
I am bound to thee for ever.
I see this hath a little dash'd your spirits.
Not a jot
I' faith
I hope you will consider what is spoke
Comes from my love. But I do see you're moved:
I am to pray you not to strain my speech
To grosser issues nor to larger reach
Than to suspicion.
I will not.
Should you do so
As my thoughts aim not at. Cassio's my worthy friend--
My lord
No

Long live she so! and long live you to think so!
And yet
Ay
Not to affect many proposed matches
Of her own clime
Foh! one may smell in such a will most rank

Her will
And happily repent.
Farewell

Set on thy wife to observe: leave me

Sees and knows more

your honour
To scan this thing no further; leave it to time:
Though it be fit that Cassio have his place
Note
With any strong or vehement importunity;

And hold her free
Fear not my government.
I once more take my leave.
Exit
This fellow's of exceeding honesty
And have not those soft parts of conversation
That chamberers have
Into the vale of years
She's gone. I am abused; and my relief
Must be to loathe her. O curse of marriage
For others' uses. Yet
Prerogatived are they less than the base;
'Tis destiny unshunnable
Even then this forked plague is fated to us
When we do quicken. Desdemona comes:
Re-enter DESDEMONA and EMILIA
If she be false

Your dinner
By you invited
I am to blame.

'Faith

It will be well.
Your napkin is too little:
He puts the handkerchief from him; and it drops
Let it alone. Come
I am very sorry that you are not well.
Exeunt OTHELLO and DESDEMONA
I am glad I have found this napkin:
This was her first remembrance from the Moor:
My wayward husband hath a hundred times
Woo'd me to steal it; but she so loves the token
To kiss and talk to. I'll have the work ta'en out
Heaven knows
I nothing but to please his fantasy.

What handkerchief?

I will in Cassio's lodging lose this napkin
Are to the jealous confirmations strong
As proofs of holy writ: this may do something.
The Moor already changes with my poison:
Dangerous conceits are
Which at the first are scarce found to distaste
Burn like the mines of Sulphur. I did say so:
Look

Not poppy
Which thou owedst yesterday.

Why

Than but to know't a little.
How now

I saw't not
I slept the next night well
I found not Cassio's kisses on her lips:
He that is robb'd
I am sorry to hear this.
I had been happy
Farewell the tranquil mind! farewell content!
Farewell the plumed troop

And
The immortal Jove's dead clamours counterfeit
Is't possible
Villain
Or by the worth of man's eternal soul
Than answer my waked wrath!
Is't come to this?
Make me to see't; or
To hang a doubt on; or woe upon thy life!
My noble lord
If thou dost slander her and torture me
On horror's head horrors accumulate;
Do deeds to make heaven weep
For nothing canst thou to damnation add
Greater than that.
O grace! O heaven forgive me!
Are you a man? have you a soul or sense?
God be wi' you; take mine office. O wretched fool.
That livest to make thine honesty a vice!
O monstrous world! Take note
I thank you for this profit; and from hence
I'll love no friend
Nay
I should be wise
And loses that it works for.
By the world
I think that thou art just and think thou art not.
I'll have some proof. Her name
As Dian's visage
As mine own face. If there be cords
I see
I do repent me that I put it to you.
You would be satisfied?
Would! nay
And may: but
Would you
Behold her topp'd?
Death and damnation! O!
It were a tedious difficulty
More than their own! What then? how then?
What shall I say? Where's satisfaction?
It is impossible you should see this
As ignorance made drunk. But yet
Give me a living reason she's disloyal.
I do not like the office:
But
And
There are a kind of men so loose of soul
One of this kind is Cassio:
In sleep I heard him say 'Sweet Desdemona
And then
That grew upon my lips: then laid his leg
Over my thigh
Cried 'Cursed fate that gave thee to the Moor!'
O monstrous! monstrous!
Nay
But this denoted a foregone conclusion:
'Tis a shrewd doubt
And this may help to thicken other proofs
That do demonstrate thinly.
I'll tear her all to pieces.
Nay
She may be honest yet. Tell me but this
Spotted with strawberries in your wife's hand?
I gave her such a one; 'twas my first gift.
I know not that; but such a handkerchief--
I am sure it was your wife's--did I to-day
See Cassio wipe his beard with.
If it be that--
If it be that
O
One is too poor
Now do I see 'tis true. Look here
All my fond love thus do I blow to heaven.
'Tis gone.
Arise
Yield up

Yet be content.
O
Patience
Never
Ne'er feels retiring ebb
To the Propontic and the Hellespont
Swallow them up. Now

I here engage my words.
Do not rise yet.
Kneels
Witness
The execution of his wit
They rise
I greet thy love

That Cassio's not alive.
My friend is dead; 'tis done at your request:
But let her live.
Damn her
Come
For the fair devil. Now art thou my lieutenant.
I am your own for ever.

Full of crusadoes: and
Is true of mind and made of no such baseness

Who

Give me your hand: this hand is moist
It yet hath felt no age nor known no sorrow.
This argues fruitfulness and liberal heart:
Hot
A sequester from liberty
For here's a young and sweating devil here
You may
For 'twas that hand that gave away my heart.
A liberal hand: the hearts of old gave hands;
But our new heraldry is hands

What promise
I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.
I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me;

Here
That which I gave you.
I have it not about me.
Not?
No
That is a fault.
That handkerchief
Did an Egyptian to my mother give;
She was a charmer
The thoughts of people: she told her
she kept it
Entirely to her love
Or made gift of it
Should hold her loathed and his spirits should hunt
After new fancies: she
And bid me
Make it a darling like your precious eye;
To lose't or give't away were such perdition
As nothing else could match.
Is't possible?
'Tis true: there's magic in the web of it:
A sibyl
The sun to course two hundred compasses
The worms were hallow'd that did breed the silk;
And it was dyed in mummy which the skilful
Conserved of maidens' hearts.
Indeed! is't true?
Most veritable; therefore look to't well.
Then would to God that I had never seen't!
Ha! wherefore?
Why do you speak so startingly and rash?
Is't lost? is't gone? speak
o' the way?
Heaven bless us!
Say you?
It is not lost; but what an if it were?
How!
I say
Fetch't
Why
This is a trick to put me from my suit:
Pray you
Fetch me the handkerchief: my mind misgives.
Come
You'll never meet a more sufficient man.
The handkerchief!
I pray
The handkerchief!
A man that all his time
Hath founded his good fortunes on your love
The handkerchief!
In sooth
Away!
Exit
Is not this man jealous?
I ne'er saw this before.
Sure
I am most unhappy in the loss of it.
'Tis not a year or two shows us a man:
They are all but stomachs
To eat us hungerly
Enter CASSIO and IAGO
There is no other way; 'tis she must do't:
And
How now
Madam
That by your virtuous means I may again
Exist
Whom I with all the office of my heart
Entirely honour: I would not be delay'd.
If my offence be of such mortal kind
That nor my service past
So shall I clothe me in a forced content
Alas
My advocation is not now in tune;
My lord is not my lord; nor should I know him
So help me every spirit sanctified
And stood within the blank of his displeasure
For my free speech! you must awhile be patient:
What I can do I will; and more I will
Than for myself I dare: let that suffice you.
Is my lord angry?
He went hence but now
Can he be angry? I have seen the cannon
Puff'd his own brother:--and can he be angry?
Something of moment then: I will go meet him:
There's matter in't indeed
I prithee
Exit IAGO
Something
Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him
Men's natures wrangle with inferior things
For let our finger ache
Our other healthful members even to that sense
Of pain: nay
As fit the bridal. Beshrew me much
But now I find I had suborn'd the witness
Pray heaven it be state-matters
Concerning you.
Alas the day! I never gave him cause.
But jealous souls will not be answer'd so;
They are not ever jealous for the cause
Begot upon itself
Heaven keep that monster from Othello's mind!
Lady
I will go seek him. Cassio
If I do find him fit
And seek to effect it to my uttermost.
I humbly thank your ladyship.
Exeunt DESDEMONA and EMILIA
Enter BIANCA
Save you
What make you from home?
How is it with you
I' faith
And I was going to your lodging
What
Eight score eight hours? and lovers' absent hours
O weary reckoning!
Pardon me
I have this while with leaden thoughts been press'd:
But I shall
Take me this work out.
O Cassio
This is some token from a newer friend:
To the felt absence now I feel a cause:
Is't come to this? Well
Go to
Throw your vile guesses in the devil's teeth
That this is from some mistress
No
Why
I know not
I like the work well: ere it be demanded--
As like enough it will--I'ld have it copied:
Take it
Leave you! wherefore?
I do attend here on the general;
And think it no addition
Why
Not that I love you not.
But that you do not love me.
I pray you
'Tis but a little way that I can bring you;
For I attend here: but I'll see you soon.
'Tis very good; I must be circumstanced.
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Cyprus. Before the castle.
Enter OTHELLO and IAGO
Will you think so?
Think so
What
An unauthorized kiss.
Or to be naked with her friend in bed
An hour or more
Naked in bed
It is hypocrisy against the devil:
They that mean virtuously
So they do nothing
But if I give my wife a handkerchief
What then?
Why
She is protectress of her honour too:
May she give that?
Her honour is an essence that's not seen;
They have it very oft that have it not:
But
By heaven
Thou said'st
Ay
That's not so good now.
What
Or heard him say
But they must blab--
Hath he said any thing?
He hath
What hath he said?
'Faith
What? what?
Lie--
With her?
With her
Lie with her! lie on her! We say lie on her
they belie her. Lie with her! that's fulsome.
--Handkerchief--confessions--handkerchief!--To
confess
hanged
Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing
passion without some instruction. It is not words
that shake me thus. Pish! Noses
--Is't possible?--Confess--handkerchief!--O devil!--
Falls in a trance
Work on
And many worthy and chaste dames even thus
My lord
Enter CASSIO
How now
What's the matter?
My lord is fall'n into an epilepsy:
This is his second fit; he had one yesterday.
Rub him about the temples.
No
The lethargy must have his quiet course:
If not
Breaks out to savage madness. Look he stirs:
Do you withdraw yourself a little while
Exit CASSIO
How is it
Dost thou mock me?
I mock you! no
Would you would bear your fortune like a man!
A horned man's a monster and a beast.
There's many a beast then in a populous city
Did he confess it?
Good sir
Think every bearded fellow that's but yoked
May draw with you: there's millions now alive
That nightly lie in those unproper beds
Which they dare swear peculiar: your case is better.
O
And knowing what I am
O
Stand you awhile apart;
Confine yourself but in a patient list.
Whilst you were here o'erwhelmed with your grief--
A passion most unsuiting such a man--
Cassio came hither: I shifted him away
The which he promised. Do but encave yourself
For I will make him tell the tale anew
He hath
I say
Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen
Dost thou hear
I will be found most cunning in my patience;
But--dost thou hear?--most bloody.
That's not amiss;
But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw?
OTHELLO retires
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca
Buys herself bread and clothes: it is a creature
That dotes on Cassio; as 'tis the strumpet's plague
To beguile many and be beguiled by one:
He
From the excess of laughter. Here he comes:
Re-enter CASSIO
As he shall smile
And his unbookish jealousy must construe
Poor Cassio's smiles
The worser that you give me the addition
Whose want even kills me.
Ply Desdemona well
Speaking lower
Now
Alas
Look
I never knew woman love man so.
Alas
Now he denies it faintly
Do you hear
Now he importunes him
To tell it o'er: go to; well said
She gives it out that you shall marry hey:
Do you intend it?
Ha
Do you triumph
I marry her! what? a customer! Prithee
charity to my wit: do not think it so unwholesome.
Ha
So
'Faith
Prithee
I am a very villain else.
Have you scored me? Well.
This is the monkey's own giving out: she is
persuaded I will marry her
flattery
Iago beckons me; now he begins the story.
She was here even now; she haunts me in every place.
I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with
certain Venetians; and thither comes the bauble
Crying 'O dear Cassio!' as it were: his gesture
imports it.
So hangs
Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber. O
throw it to.
Well
Before me! look

I was a fine fool to take it. I must take out the

Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?
O Iago!
And did you see the handkerchief?
Was that mine?
Yours by this hand: and to see how he prizes the
