hath given it his whore.
I would have him nine years a-killing.
A fine woman! a fair woman! a sweet woman!
Nay
Ay
for she shall not live: no
stone; I strike it
world hath not a sweeter creature: she might lie by

Nay
Hang her! I do but say what she is: so delicate
with her needle: an admirable musician: O! she
will sing the savageness out of a bear: of so high
and plenteous wit and invention:--
She's the worse for all this.
O
gentle a condition!
Ay
Nay

patent to offend; for
near nobody.

O

That's fouler.

the bed she hath contaminated.
Good

shall hear more by midnight.
Excellent good.

What trumpet is that same?
Something from Venice
Come from the duke: and

Save you
With all my heart
The duke and senators of Venice greet you.
Gives him a letter
I kiss the instrument of their pleasures.
Opens the letter
And what's the news
I am very glad to see you
Welcome to Cyprus.
I thank you. How does Lieutenant Cassio?
Lives
Cousin
An unkind breach: but you shall make all well.
Are you sure of that?
My lord?
[Reads]  'This fail you not to do
He did not call; he's busy in the paper.

A most unhappy one: I would do much

My lord?

For

My lord?

Going

Ay; you did wish that I would make her turn:

Is this the noble Moor whom our full senate
Call all in all sufficient? Is this the nature
Whom passion could not shake? whose solid virtue
The shot of accident
He is much changed.
Are his wits safe? is he not light of brain?
He's that he is: I may not breathe my censure
What he might be: if what he might he is not
What
'Faith
That stroke would prove the worst!
Is it his use?
Or did the letters work upon his blood
Alas
It is not honesty in me to speak
What I have seen and known. You shall observe him
That I may save my speech: do but go after
I am sorry that I am deceived in him.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A room in the castle.
Enter OTHELLO and EMILIA
You have seen nothing then?
Nor ever heard
Yes
But then I saw no harm
Each syllable that breath made up between them.
What

Never.
To fetch her fan
Never
That's strange.
I durst
If any wretch have put this in your head
For
Is foul as slander.
Bid her come hither: go.
Exit EMILIA
She says enough; yet she's a simple bawd
That cannot say as much. This is a subtle whore
And yet she'll kneel and pray; I have seen her do't.
Enter DESDEMONA with EMILIA
My lord
Pray
What is your pleasure?
Let me see your eyes;
Look in my face.
What horrible fancy's this?
[To EMILIA]  Some of your function
Leave procreants alone and shut the door;
Cough
Your mystery

Upon my knees
I understand a fury in your words.
But not the words.
Why
Your wife
And loyal wife.
Come
Lest
Should fear to seize thee: therefore be double damn'd:
Swear thou art honest.
Heaven doth truly know it.
Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.
To whom
O Desdemona! away! away! away!
Alas the heavy day! Why do you weep?
Am I the motive of these tears
If haply you my father do suspect
An instrument of this your calling back
Had it pleased heaven
To try me with affliction; had they rain'd
All kinds of sores and shames on my bare head.
Steep'd me in poverty to the very lips
A drop of patience: but
A fixed figure for the time of scorn
To point his slow unmoving finger at!
Yet could I bear that too; well
But there
The fountain from the which my current runs
Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads
To knot and gender in! Turn thy complexion there
Ay
I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.
O
That the sense aches at thee
ne'er been born!
Alas
Was this fair paper
Committed! O thou public commoner!
I should make very forges of my cheeks
Heaven stops the nose at it and the moon winks
Is hush'd within the hollow mine of earth
Impudent strumpet!
By heaven
Are you not a strumpet?
No
If to preserve this vessel for my lord
From any other foul unlawful touch
Be not to be a strumpet
What
No

O

Alas

'Faith
Good madam

Why
Who is thy lord?
He that is yours
I have none: do not talk to me

Lay on my bed my wedding sheets: remember;
And call thy husband hither.
Here's a change indeed!
Exit
'Tis meet I should be used so
How have I been behaved
The small'st opinion on my least misuse?
Re-enter EMILIA with IAGO
What is your pleasure
How is't with you?
I cannot tell. Those that do teach young babes
Do it with gentle means and easy tasks:
He might have chid me so; for
What's the matter
Alas
Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her
Am I that name
What name
Such as she says my lord did say I was.
He call'd her whore: a beggar in his drink
Could not have laid such terms upon his callat.
Why did he so?
I do not know; I am sure I am none such.
Do not weep
Hath she forsook so many noble matches
It is my wretched fortune.
Beshrew him for't!
How comes this trick upon him?
Nay
I will be hang'd
Fie
If any such there be
A halter pardon him! and hell gnaw his bones!
Why should he call her whore? who keeps her company?
What place? what time? what form? what likelihood?
The Moor's abused by some most villanous knave
O heaven
To lash the rascals naked through the world
Even from the east to the west!
Speak within door.
O
That turn'd your wit the seamy side without
You are a fool; go to.
O good Iago
Good friend
If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love
Or that I do not yet
And ever will--though he do shake me off
To beggarly divorcement--love him dearly
And his unkindness may defeat my life
It does abhor me now I speak the word;
To do the act that might the addition earn
Not the world's mass of vanity could make me.
I pray you
The business of the state does him offence
If 'twere no other--
'Tis but so
Trumpets within
Hark
The messengers of Venice stay the meat;
Go in

Enter RODERIGO
How now

What in the contrary?
Every day thou daffest me with some device
and rather

it
already I have foolishly suffered.
Will you hear me
'Faith
performances are no kin together.
You charge me most unjustly.
With nought but truth. I have wasted myself out of

and returned me expectations and comforts of sudden
respect and acquaintance

Very well! go to! I cannot go to
not very well: nay

Very well.

You have said now.
Ay

this instant to build on thee a better opinion than

SCENE III. Another room In the castle.
Enter OTHELLO
I do beseech you
O

O
My lord?

Exeunt OTHELLO
How goes it now? he looks gentler than he did.
He says he will return incontinent:
He hath commanded me to go to bed
Dismiss me!
It was his bidding: therefore
Give me my nightly wearing
We must not now displease him.
I would you had never seen him!
"So would not I	my love doth so approve him"
Prithee
I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.
All's one. Good faith
If I do die before thee prithee
In one of those same sheets.
Come
My mother had a maid call'd Barbara:
She was in love
And did forsake her: she had a song of 'willow;'
An old thing 'twas
Will not go from my mind; I have much to do
Shall I go fetch your night-gown?
No
This Lodovico is a proper man.
A very handsome man.
He speaks well.
I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefoot
to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.
[Singing]  The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree
Her hand on her bosom
The fresh streams ran by her
Sing willow
Her salt tears fell from her
Lay by these:--
Singing

Singing

Let nobody blame him; his scorn I approve
Nay
It's the wind.
[Singing]  I call'd my love false love; but what

Sing willow
If I court moe women
So
Doth that bode weeping?
'Tis neither here nor there.
I have heard it said so. O
Dost thou in conscience think
That there be women do abuse their husbands
In such gross kind?
There be some such
Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
Why
No
Nor I neither by this heavenly light;
I might do't as well i' the dark.
Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
The world's a huge thing: it is a great price.
For a small vice.
In troth

For the whole world.
Why the wrong is but a wrong i' the world: and

own world
I do not think there is any such woman.
Yes
store the world they played for.
But I do think it is their husbands' faults
If wives do fall: say that they slack their duties
Why
Their wives have sense like them: they see and smell
And have their palates both for sweet and sour
When they change us for others? Is it sport?
I think it is: and doth affection breed it?
I think it doth: is't frailty that thus errs?
It is so too: and have not we affections
Then let them use us well: else let them know
Good night
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. Cyprus. A street.
Enter IAGO and RODERIGO
Here
Wear thy good rapier bare
Quick
It makes us
Be near at hand; I may miscarry in't.
Here
Retires
I have no great devotion to the deed;
And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons:
'Tis but a man gone. Forth
I have rubb'd this young quat almost to the sense
Of gold and jewels that I bobb'd from him
It must not be: if Cassio do remain
That makes me ugly; and
May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril:
No
Enter CASSIO
I know his gait
Makes a pass at CASSIO
That thrust had been mine enemy indeed
I will make proof of thine.
Draws
O
IAGO from behind wounds CASSIO in the leg
I am maim'd for ever. Help
Falls
Enter OTHELLO
The voice of Cassio: Iago keeps his word.
O
It is even so.
O
'Tis he:--O brave Iago
Thou teachest me. Minion
Forth of my heart those charms
Thy bed
Exit
Enter LODOVICO and GRATIANO
What
'Tis some mischance; the cry is very direful.
O
Hark!
O wretched villain!
Two or three groan: it is a heavy night:
These may be counterfeits: let's think't unsafe
To come in to the cry without more help.
Nobody come? then shall I bleed to death.
Hark!
Re-enter IAGO
Here's one comes in his shirt
Who's there? whose noise is this that ones on murder?
We do not know.
Did not you hear a cry?
Here
What's the matter?
This is Othello's ancient
The same indeed; a very valiant fellow.
What are you here that cry so grievously?
Iago? O
Give me some help.
O me
I think that one of them is hereabout
O treacherous villains!
What are you there? come in
To LODOVICO and GRATIANO
O
That's one of them.
O murderous slave! O villain!
Stabs RODERIGO
O damn'd Iago! O inhuman dog!
Kill men i' the dark!--Where be these bloody thieves?--
How silent is this town!--Ho! murder! murder!--
What may you be? are you of good or evil?
As you shall prove us
Signior Lodovico?
He
I cry you mercy. Here's Cassio hurt by villains.
Cassio!
How is't
My leg is cut in two.
Marry
Light
Enter BIANCA
What is the matter
Who is't that cried!
O my dear Cassio! my sweet Cassio! O Cassio
O notable strumpet! Cassio

No.

What
Even he

These bloody accidents must excuse my manners

How do you
Roderigo!
He

For you
here

o' the air.
CASSIO and RODERIGO are borne off

Nay

'Las
Cassio hath here been set on in the dark

He's almost slain
Alas

To BIANCA
What
He supp'd at my house; but I therefore shake not.
O
Fie
I am no strumpet; but of life as honest
As you that thus abuse me.
As I! foh! fie upon thee!
Kind gentlemen
Come
Emilia run you to the citadel
Will you go on? I pray.
Aside
This is the night
That either makes me or fordoes me quite.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A bedchamber in the castle: DESDEMONA in bed asleep;
a light burning.
Enter OTHELLO
It is the cause
Let me not name it to you
It is the cause. Yet I'll not shed her blood;
Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow
Yet she must die
Put out the light
If I quench thee
That can thy light relume. When I have pluck'd the rose
It must needs wither: I'll smell it on the tree.
Kissing her
Ah balmy breath
Justice to break her sword! One more
Be thus when thou art dead
So sweet was ne'er so fatal. I must weep
It strikes where it doth love. She wakes.
Who's there? Othello?
Ay. Desdemona.
Will you come to bed
Have you pray'd to-night
Ay
If you bethink yourself of any crime
Unreconciled as yet to heaven and grace
Alas
Well
I would not kill thy unprepared spirit;
No; heaven forfend! I would not kill thy soul.
Talk you of killing?
Ay
Then heaven
Have mercy on me!
Amen
If you say so
Hum!
And yet I fear you; for you are fatal then
When your eyes roll so: why I should fear I know not
Think on thy sins.
They are loves I bear to you.
Ay
That death's unnatural that kills for loving.
Alas
Some bloody passion shakes your very frame:
These are portents; but yet I hope
Peace
I will so. What's the matter?
That handkerchief which I so loved and gave thee
Thou gavest to Cassio.
No
Send for the man
Sweet soul
Ay
Yes
Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin;
For to deny each article with oath
Cannot remove nor choke the strong conception
That I do groan withal. Thou art to die.
Then Lord have mercy on me!
I say
And have you mercy too! I never did
Offend you in my life; never loved Cassio
But with such general warranty of heaven
As I might love: I never gave him token.
By heaven
O perjured woman! thou dost stone my heart
A murder
I saw the handkerchief.
He found it then;
I never gave it him: send for him hither;
Let him confess a truth.
He hath confess'd.
What
That he hath used thee.
How? unlawfully?
Ay.
He will not say so.
No
Honest Iago hath ta'en order for't.
O! my fear interprets: what
Had all his hairs been lives
Had stomach for them all.
Alas! he is betray'd and I undone.
Out
O
Down
Kill me to-morrow: let me live to-night!
Nay
But half an hour!
Being done
But while I say one prayer!
It is too late.
He stifles her
[Within]  My lord
What noise is this? Not dead? not yet quite dead?
I that am cruel am yet merciful;
I would not have thee linger in thy pain: So
[Within]  What
Who's there?
[Within]  O
Yes: 'tis Emilia. By and by. She's dead.
'Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio's death.--
The noise was here. Ha! no more moving?
Still as the grave. Shall she come in? were't good?--
I think she stirs again:--no. What's best to do?
If she come in
My wife! my wife! what wife? I have no wife.
O insupportable! O heavy hour!
Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse
Of sun and moon
Should yawn at alteration.
[Within]  I do beseech you
That I may speak with you
I had forgot thee: O
Soft; by and by. Let me the curtains draw.
Where art thou?
Unlocks the door
Enter EMILIA
What's the matter with thee now?
O
What
But now
It is the very error of the moon;
She comes more nearer earth than she was wont
Cassio
Call'd Roderigo.
Roderigo kill'd!
And Cassio kill'd!
No
Not Cassio kill'd! then murder's out of tune
O
Alas
That! what?
Out
Help! help
Sweet Desdemona! O sweet mistress
A guiltless death I die.
O
Nobody; I myself. Farewell
Commend me to my kind lord: O
Dies
Why
Alas
You heard her say herself
She said so: I must needs report the truth.
She's
'Twas I that kill'd her.
O
She turn'd to folly
Thou dost belie her
She was false as water.
Thou art rash as fire
That she was false: O
Cassio did top her; ask thy husband else.
O
To this extremity. Thy husband knew it all.
My husband!
Thy husband.
That she was false to wedlock?
Ay
Of one entire and Perfect chrysolite
My husband!
Ay
An honest man he is
That sticks on filthy deeds.
My husband!
What needs this iteration
O mistress
He
I say thy husband: dost understand the word?
My friend
If he say so
Rot half a grain a day! he lies to the heart:
She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.
Ha!
Do thy worst:
This deed of thine is no more worthy heaven
Than thou wast worthy her.
Peace
Thou hast not half that power to do me harm
As I have to be hurt. O gull! O dolt!
As ignorant as dirt! thou hast done a deed--
I care not for thy sword; I'll make thee known
The Moor hath kill'd my mistress! Murder! murder!
Enter MONTANO
What is the matter? How now
O
What is the matter?
Disprove this villain
He says thou told'st him that his wife was false:
I know thou didst not
Speak
I told him what I thought
Than what he found himself was apt and true.
But did you ever tell him she was false?
I did.
You told a lie
Upon my soul
She false with Cassio!--did you say with Cassio?
With Cassio
I will not charm my tongue; I am bound to speak:
My mistress here lies murder'd in her bed
O heavens forfend!
And your reports have set the murder on.
Nay
'Tis a strange truth.
O monstrous act!
Villany
I think upon't
I thought so then:--I'll kill myself for grief:--
O villany
What
Good gentlemen
'Tis proper I obey him
Perchance
O! O! O!
He falls on the bed
Nay
For thou hast kill'd the sweetest innocent
That e'er did lift up eye.
[Rising]  O
I scarce did know you
I know this act shows horrible and grim.
Poor Desdemona! I am glad thy father's dead:
Thy match was mortal to him
Shore his old thread in twain: did he live now
'Tis pitiful; but yet Iago knows
That she with Cassio hath the act of shame
A thousand times committed; Cassio confess'd it:
And she did gratify his amorous works
With that recognizance and pledge of love
Which I first gave her; I saw it in his hand:
It was a handkerchief
My father gave my mother.
O heaven! O heavenly powers!
Come
'Twill out
No
Let heaven and men and devils
Be wise
I will not.
IAGO offers to stab EMILIA
Fie!
Your sword upon a woman?
O thou dull Moor! that handkerchief thou speak'st of
I found by fortune and did give my husband;
For often
Villanous whore!
She give it Cassio! no
Filth
By heaven
O murderous coxcomb! what should such a fool
Do with so good a woman?
Are there no stones in heaven
But what serve for the thunder?--Precious villain!
He runs at IAGO  IAGO
The woman falls; sure
Ay
He's gone
'Tis a notorious villain. Take you this weapon
Come
Exeunt MONTANO and GRATIANO
I am not valiant neither
But why should honour outlive honesty?
Let it go all.
What did thy song bode
Hark
And die in music.
Singing
Willow
Moor
So come my soul to bliss
So speaking as I think
Dies
I have another weapon in this chamber;
It is a sword of Spain
O
[Within]  If thou attempt it
Thou hast no weapon
Look in upon me then and speak with me
Re-enter GRATIANO
What is the matter?
Behold
A better never did itself sustain
Upon a soldier's thigh: I have seen the day
Than twenty times your stop: but
Who can control his fate? 'tis not so now.
Be not afraid
Here is my journey's end
Do you go back dismay'd? 'tis a lost fear;
Man but a rush against Othello's breast
Now
Pale as thy smock! when we shall meet at compt
Even like thy chastity. O cursed slave!
Whip me
Blow me about in winds! roast me in sulphur!
Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire!
O Desdemona! Desdemona! dead!
Oh! Oh! Oh!
Enter LODOVICO. MONTANO
Where is this rash and most unfortunate man?
That's he that was Othello: here I am.
Where is that viper? bring the villain forth.
I look down towards his feet; but that's a fable.
If that thou best a devil
Wounds IAGO
Wrench his sword from him.
I bleed
I am not sorry neither: I'ld have thee live;
For
O thou Othello
Why
An honourable murderer
For nought I did in hate
This wretch hath part confess'd his villany:
Did you and he consent in Cassio's death?
Ay.
Dear general
I do believe it
Will you
Why he hath thus ensnared my soul and body?
Demand me nothing: what you know
From this time forth I never will speak word.
What
Torments will ope your lips.
Well
Sir
Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo;
And here another: the one of them imports
The death of Cassio to be undertook
By Roderigo.
O villain!
Most heathenish and most gross!
Now here's another discontented paper
But that belike Iago in the interim
Came in and satisfied him.
O the pernicious caitiff!
How came you
That was my wife's?
I found it in my chamber:
And he himself confess'd but even now
That there he dropp'd it for a special purpose
Which wrought to his desire.
O fool! fool! fool!
There is besides in Roderigo's letter
Brave me upon the watch; whereon it came
That I was cast: and even but now he spake
You must forsake this room
Your power and your command is taken off
That can torment him much and hold him long
To the Venetian state. Come
Soft you; a word or two before you go.
I have done the state some service
No more of that. I pray you
Of one that loved not wisely but too well;
Of one not easily jealous
Perplex'd in the extreme; of one whose hand
Richer than all his tribe; of one whose subdued eyes
Their medicinal gum. Set you down this;
And say besides
Beat a Venetian and traduced the state
Stabs himself
O bloody period!
All that's spoke is marr'd.
I kiss'd thee ere I kill'd thee: no way but this;
Killing myself
Falls on the bed
This did I fear
For he was great of heart.
[To IAGO]  O Spartan dog
Look on the tragic loading of this bed;
This is thy work: the object poisons sight;
Let it be hid. Gratiano
The time
Myself will straight aboard: and to the state
This heavy act with heavy heart relate.
Exeunt
ACT I
PROLOGUE
Enter GOWER
Before the palace of Antioch
To sing a song that old was sung
Assuming man's infirmities
It hath been sung at festivals
And lords and ladies in their lives
Have read it for restoratives:
The purchase is to make men glorious;
Et bonum quo antiquius
If you
And that to hear an old man sing
May to your wishes pleasure bring
I life would wish
Waste it for you
This Antioch
Built up
The fairest in all Syria
This king unto him took a fere
With whom the father liking took
Bad child; worse father! to entice his own
To evil should be done by none:
But custom what they did begin
Was with long use account no sin.
The beauty of this sinful dame
Made many princes thither frame
Which to prevent he made a law
So for her many a wight did die
What now ensues
I give
Exit
SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
Enter ANTIOCHUS
Young prince of Tyre
The danger of the task you undertake.
I have
Embolden'd with the glory of her praise
Bring in our daughter
At whose conception
Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
See where she comes
Of every virtue gives renown to men!
Her face the book of praises
Nothing but curious pleasures
Sorrow were ever razed and testy wrath
Could never be her mild companion.
You gods that made me man
To taste the fruit of yon celestial tree
Prince Pericles
That would be son to great Antiochus.
Before thee stands this fair Hesperides
For death-like dragons here affright thee hard:
Her face
Her countless glory
And which
Presumes to reach
Yon sometimes famous princes
And with dead cheeks advise thee to desist
For going on death's net
Antiochus
My frail mortality to know itself
This body
For death remember'd should be like a mirror
I'll make my will then
Who know the world
So I bequeath a happy peace to you
And all good men
My riches to the earth from whence they came;
But my unspotted fire of love to you.
To the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
Thus ready for the way of life or death
Scorning advice
Which read and not expounded
Of all say'd yet
Of all say'd yet
Like a bold champion
But faithfulness and courage.
He reads the riddle
I am no viper
On mother's flesh which did me breed.
I sought a husband
I found that kindness in a father:
He's father
I mother
How they may be
Sharp physic is the last: but
That give heaven countless eyes to view men's acts
Fair glass of light
Were not this glorious casket stored with ill:
But I must tell you
For he's no man on whom perfections wait
That
You are a fair viol
Who
But being play'd upon before your time
Good sooth
Prince Pericles
For that's an article within our law
Either expound now
Great king
'Twould braid yourself too near for me to tell it.
Who has a book of all that monarchs do
For vice repeated is like the wandering wind.
Blows dust in other's eyes
And yet the end of all is bought thus dear
To stop the air would hurt them. The blind mole casts
Copp'd hills towards heaven
By man's oppression; and the poor worm doth die for't.
Kings are earth's gods; in vice their law's
their will;
And if Jove stray
It is enough you know; and it is fit
All love the womb that their first being bred
[Aside]  Heaven
the meaning:
But I will gloze with him.--Young prince of Tyre
Yet hope
As your fair self
Forty days longer we do respite you;
If by which time our secret be undone
And until then your entertain shall be
As doth befit our honour and your worth.
Exeunt all but PERICLES
How courtesy would seem to cover sin
If it be true that I interpret false
As with foul incest to abuse your soul;
Where now you're both a father and a son
And she an eater of her mother's flesh
And both like serpents are
On sweetest flowers
Antioch
Blush not in actions blacker than the night
One sin
Murder's as near to lust as flame to smoke:
Poison and treason are the hands of sin
Then
Exit
Re-enter ANTIOCHUS
He hath found the meaning
To have his head.
He must not live to trumpet forth my infamy
In such a loathed manner;
And therefore instantly this prince must die:
For by his fall my honour must keep high.
Who attends us there?
Enter THALIARD
Doth your highness call?
Thaliard
Her private actions to your secrecy;
And for your faithfulness we will advance you.
Thaliard
We hate the prince of Tyre
It fits thee not to ask the reason why
My lord
Enough.
Enter a Messenger
Let your breath cool yourself
My lord
Exit
As thou
Wilt live
From a well-experienced archer hits the mark
His eye doth level at
Unless thou say 'Prince Pericles is dead.'
My lord
Thaliard
Exit THALIARD
Till Pericles be dead
Exit
SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
Enter PERICLES
[To Lords without]  Let none disturb us.--Why should
this change of thoughts
Here pleasures court mine eyes
Yet neither pleasure's art can joy my spirits
Then it is thus: the passions of the mind
And what was first but fear what might be done
And so with me: the great Antiochus
Nor boots it me to say I honour him.
If he suspect I may dishonour him:
And what may make him blush in being known
With hostile forces he'll o'erspread the land
Our men be vanquish'd ere they do resist
Which care of them
Enter HELICANUS
Joy and all comfort in your sacred breast!
And keep your mind
Peace
They do abuse the king that flatter him:
For flattery is the bellows blows up sin;
The thing which is flatter'd
Whereas reproof
When Signior Sooth here does proclaim a peace
Prince
I cannot be much lower than my knees.
All leave us else; but let your cares o'erlook
What shipping and what lading's in our haven
Exeunt Lords
Helicanus
Hast moved us: what seest thou in our looks?
An angry brow
If there be such a dart in princes' frowns
How dare the plants look up to heaven
They have their nourishment?
Thou know'st I have power
To take thy life from thee.
[Kneeling]
I have ground the axe myself;
Do you but strike the blow.
Rise
Sit down: thou art no flatterer:
I thank thee for it; and heaven forbid
That kings should let their ears hear their
faults hid!
Fit counsellor and servant for a prince
To bear with patience
Such griefs as you yourself do lay upon yourself.
Thou speak'st like a physician
That thou wouldst tremble to receive thyself.
Attend me
From whence an issue I might propagate
Her face was to mine eye beyond all wonder;
The rest--hark in thine ear--as black as incest:
Which by my knowledge found
Seem'd not to strike
know'st this
Such fear so grew in me
I knew him tyrannous; and tyrants' fears
Decrease not
And should he doubt it
How many worthy princes' bloods were shed
When all
Which love to all
Alas
Drew sleep out of mine eyes
How I might stop this tempest ere it came;
And finding little comfort to relieve them
Well
Freely will I speak. Antiochus you fear
Will take away your life.
Therefore
Your rule direct to any; if to me.
Day serves not light more faithful than I'll be.
I do not doubt thy faith;
But should he wrong my liberties in my absence?
We'll mingle our bloods together in the earth
Tyre
Intend my travel
And by whose letters I'll dispose myself.
The care I had and have of subjects' good
On thee I lay whose wisdom's strength can bear it.
I'll take thy word for faith
Who shuns not to break one will sure crack both:
But in our orbs we'll live so round and safe
Exeunt
SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
Enter THALIARD
So
kill King Pericles; and if I do it not
be hanged at home: 'tis dangerous. Well
he was a wise fellow
he might know none of his secrets: now do I see he
had some reason for't; for if a king bid a man be a
villain
be one! Hush! here come the lords of Tyre.
Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES
You shall not need
His seal'd commission
[Aside]  How! the king gone!
If further yet you will be satisfied
Being at Antioch--
[Aside]          What from Antioch?
Royal Antiochus--on what cause I know not--
Took some displeasure at him; at least he judged so:
And doubting lest that he had err'd or sinn'd
So puts himself unto the shipman's toil
[Aside]  Well
I shall not be hang'd now
But since he's gone
He 'scaped the land
I'll present myself. Peace to the lords of Tyre!
Lord Thaliard from Antiochus is welcome.
From him I come
With message unto princely Pericles;
But since my landing I have understood
Your lord has betook himself to unknown travels
We have no reason to desire it
Yet
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
Enter CLEON
My Dionyza
That were to blow at fire in hope to quench it;
For who digs hills because they do aspire
Throws down one mountain to cast up a higher.
O my distressed lord
Here they're but felt
O Dionyza
Our tongues and sorrows do sound deep
Our woes into the air; our eyes do weep
That
I'll then discourse our woes
I'll do my best
This Tarsus
Whose towers bore heads so high they kiss'd the clouds
Whose men and dames so jetted and adorn'd
Their tables were stored full
All poverty was scorn'd
O
But see what heaven can do! By this our change
Those palates who
Those mothers who
To eat those little darlings whom they loved.
So sharp are hunger's teeth
Draw lots who first shall die to lengthen life:
Here stands a lord
Here many sink
Have scarce strength left to give them burial.
Is not this true?
Our cheeks and hollow eyes do witness it.
O
And her prosperities so largely taste
The misery of Tarsus may be theirs.
Enter a Lord
Where's the lord governor?
Here.
Speak out thy sorrows which thou bring'st in haste
We have descried
I thought as much.
One sorrow never comes but brings an heir
And so in ours: some neighbouring nation
And make a conquest of unhappy me
That's the least fear; for
Of their white flags display'd
Thou speak'st like him's untutor'd to repeat:
Who makes the fairest show means most deceit.
But bring they what they will and what they can
The ground's the lowest
Go tell their general we attend him here
I go
Exit
Welcome is peace
If wars
Enter PERICLES with Attendants
Lord governor
Be like a beacon fired to amaze your eyes.
We have heard your miseries as far as Tyre
Nor come we to add sorrow to your tears
And these our ships
Are like the Trojan horse was stuff'd within
With bloody veins
The gods of Greece protect you!
And we'll pray for you.
Arise
We do not look for reverence
The which when any shall not gratify
Till when
Your grace is welcome to our town and us.
Which welcome we'll accept; feast here awhile
Exeunt
ACT II
Enter GOWER
Here have you seen a mighty king
His child
A better prince and benign lord
Be quiet then as men should be
I'll show you those in troubles reign
The good in conversation
Thinks all is writ he speken can;
And
But tidings to the contrary
Are brought your eyes; what need speak I?
DUMB SHOW.
Enter at one door PERICLES talking with CLEON; all  the train with them. Enter at another door a  Gentleman
Good Helicane
From others' labours; for though he strive
To killen bad
And to fulfil his prince' desire
How Thaliard came full bent with sin
And had intent to murder him;
And that in Tarsus was not best
Longer for him to make his rest.
He
For now the wind begins to blow;
Thunder above and deeps below
Make such unquiet
Should house him safe is wreck'd and split;
And he
All perishen of man
Till fortune
And here he comes. What shall be next
Exit
SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
Enter PERICLES
Yet cease your ire
Wind
Is but a substance that must yield to you;
And I
Alas
Nothing to think on but ensuing death:
Let it suffice the greatness of your powers
To have bereft a prince of all his fortunes;
And having thrown him from your watery grave
Enter three FISHERMEN
What
Ha
What
What say you
Look how thou stirrest now! come away
fetch thee with a wanion.
Faith
were cast away before us even now.
Alas
pitiful cries they made to us to help them
Nay
porpus how he bounced and tumbled? they say
they're half fish
marvel how the fishes live in the sea.
Why
little ones: I can compare our rich misers to
nothing so fitly as to a whale; a' plays and
tumbles
last devours them all at a mouthful: such whales
have I heard on o' the land
till they've swallowed the whole parish
[Aside]  A pretty moral.
But
been that day in the belfry.
Why
Because he should have swallowed me too: and when I
had been in his belly
jangling of the bells
left
parish up again. But if the good King Simonides
were of my mind
[Aside]  Simonides!
We would purge the land of these drones
the bee of her honey.
[Aside]  How from the finny subject of the sea
These fishers tell the infirmities of men;
And from their watery empire recollect
All that may men approve or men detect!
Peace be at your labour
Honest! good fellow
fits you
look after it.
May see the sea hath cast upon your coast.
What a drunken knave was the sea to cast thee in our
way!
A man whom both the waters and the wind
For them to play upon
He asks of you
No
country Greece gets more with begging than we can do
with working.
Canst thou catch any fishes
I never practised it.
Nay
to be got now-a-days
What I have been I have forgot to know;
But what I am
A man throng'd up with cold: my veins are chill
To give my tongue that heat to ask your help;
Which if you shall refuse
Die quoth-a? Now gods forbid! I have a gown here;
come
handsome fellow! Come
we'll have flesh for holidays
fasting-days
I thank you
Hark you
I did but crave.
But crave! Then I'll turn craver too
shall 'scape whipping.
Why
O
beggars were whipped
than to be beadle. But
net.
Exit with Third Fisherman
[Aside]  How well this honest mirth becomes their labour!
Hark you
Not well.
Why
our king the good Simonides.
The good King Simonides
Ay
peaceable reign and good government.
He is a happy king
the name of good by his government. How far is his
court distant from this shore?
Marry
you
birth-day; and there are princes and knights come
from all parts of the world to just and tourney for her love.
Were my fortunes equal to my desires
to make one there.
O
cannot get
Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen
Help
come out. Ha! bots on't
'tis turned to a rusty armour.
An armour
Thanks
And though it was mine own
With this strict charge
Twixt me and death;'--and pointed to this brace;--
'For that it saved me
The which the gods protect thee from!--may
defend thee.'
It kept where I kept
Till the rough seas
I thank thee for't: my shipwreck now's no ill
What mean you
To beg of you
I know it by this mark. He loved me dearly
And that you'ld guide me to your sovereign's court
And if that ever my low fortune's better
Why
I'll show the virtue I have borne in arms.
Why
Ay
this garment through the rough seams of the waters:
there are certain condolements
hope
whence you had it.
Believe 't
By your furtherance I am clothed in steel;
And
Unto thy value I will mount myself
Upon a courser
Shall make the gazer joy to see him tread.
Only
Of a pair of bases.
We'll sure provide: thou shalt have my best gown to
make thee a pair; and I'll bring thee to the court myself.
Then honour be but a goal to my will
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the
lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the
reception of King
Enter SIMONIDES
Are the knights ready to begin the triumph?
They are
And stay your coming to present themselves.
Return them
For men to see
Exit a Lord
It pleaseth you
My commendations great
It's fit it should be so; for princes are
A model which heaven makes like to itself:
As jewels lose their glory if neglected
'Tis now your honour
The labour of each knight in his device.
Which
Enter a Knight; he passes over
Who is the first that doth prefer himself?
A knight of Sparta
And the device he bears upon his shield
Is a black Ethiope reaching at the sun
The word
He loves you well that holds his life of you.
The Second Knight passes over
Who is the second that presents himself?
A prince of Macedon
And the device he bears upon his shield
Is an arm'd knight that's conquer'd by a lady;
The motto thus
The Third Knight passes over
And what's the third?
The third of Antioch;
And his device
The word
The Fourth Knight passes over
What is the fourth?
A burning torch that's turned upside down;
The word
Which shows that beauty hath his power and will
The Fifth Knight passes over
The fifth
The motto thus
The Sixth Knight
And what's
The sixth and last
With such a graceful courtesy deliver'd?
He seems to be a stranger; but his present is
A wither'd branch
The motto
A pretty moral;
From the dejected state wherein he is
He had need mean better than his outward show
Can any way speak in his just commend;
For by his rusty outside he appears
To have practised more the whipstock than the lance.
He well may be a stranger
To an honour'd triumph strangely furnished.
And on set purpose let his armour rust
Until this day
Opinion's but a fool
The outward habit by the inward man.
But stay
Into the gallery.
Exeunt
Great shouts within and all cry 'The mean knight!'
SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
Enter SIMONIDES
Knights
To place upon the volume of your deeds
Prepare for mirth
You are princes and my guests.
But you
To whom this wreath of victory I give
'Tis more by fortune
Call it by what you will
And here
In framing an artist
And you are her labour'd scholar. Come
the feast
For
Marshal the rest
We are honour'd much by good Simonides.
Your presence glads our days: honour we love;
For who hates honour hates the gods above.
Sir
Some other is more fit.
Contend not
That neither in our hearts nor outward eyes
Envy the great nor do the low despise.
You are right courteous knights.
Sit
By Jove
By Juno
Wishing him my meat. Sure
He's but a country gentleman;
Has done no more than other knights have done;
Has broken a staff or so; so let it pass.
To me he seems like diamond to glass.
Yon king's to me like to my father's picture
Had princes sit
None that beheld him
Where now his son's like a glow-worm in the night
Whereby I see that Time's the king of men
What
Who can be other in this royal presence?
Here
As you do love
We drink this health to you.
We thank your grace.
Yet pause awhile:
Yon knight doth sit too melancholy
Had not a show might countervail his worth.
Note it not you
What is it
To me
O
Princes in this should live like gods above
To honour them:
And princes not doin g so are like to gnats
Therefore to make his entrance more sweet
Alas
Unto a stranger knight to be so bold:
He may my proffer take for an offence
How!
Do as I bid you
[Aside]  Now
And furthermore tell him
The king my father
I thank him.
Wishing it so much blood unto your life.
I thank both him and you
And further he desires to know of you
A gentleman of Tyre; my name
My education been in arts and arms;
Who
He thanks your grace; names himself Pericles
Bereft of ships and men
Now
Come
Even in your armours
I will not have excuse
Loud music is too harsh for ladies' heads
The Knights dance
So
Come
Here is a lady that wants breathing too:
And I have heard
Are excellent in making ladies trip;
And that their measures are as excellent.
In those that practise them they are
O
Of your fair courtesy.
The Knights and Ladies dance
Unclasp
Thanks
To PERICLES
But you the best. Pages and lights
These knights unto their several lodgings!
To PERICLES
Yours
I am at your grace's pleasure.
Princes
And that's the mark I know you level at:
Therefore each one betake him to his rest;
To-morrow all for speeding do their best.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES
No
For which
To withhold the vengeance that they had in store
Of an inestimable value
Their bodies
Scorn now their hand should give them burial.
'Twas very strange.
And yet but justice; for though
This king were great
To bar heaven's shaft
'Tis very true.
Enter two or three Lords
See
Or council has respect with him but he.
It shall no longer grieve without reproof.
And cursed be he that will not second it.
Follow me
With me? and welcome: happy day
Know that our griefs are risen to the top
Your griefs! for what? wrong not your prince you love.
Wrong not yourself
But if the prince do live
If in the world he live
If in his grave he rest
And be resolved he lives to govern us
Whose death indeed's the strongest in our censure:
And knowing this kingdom is without a head
Like goodly buildings left without a roof
Soon fall to ruin
Live
For honour's cause
If that you love Prince Pericles
Take I your wish
A twelvemonth longer
Forbear the absence of your king:
If in which time expired
But if I cannot win you to this love
Whom if you find
To wisdom he's a fool that will not yield;
And since Lord Helicane enjoineth us
Then you love us
When peers thus knit
Exeunt
SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
Enter SIMONIDES
Good morrow to the good Simonides.
Knights
A married life.
Her reason to herself is only known
May we not get access to her
'Faith
Her to her chamber
One twelve moons more she'll wear Diana's livery;
This by the eye of Cynthia hath she vow'd
And on her virgin honour will not break it.
Loath to bid farewell
Exeunt Knights
So
She tells me here
'Tis well
I like that well: nay
Well
And will no longer have it be delay'd.
Soft! here he comes: I must dissemble it.
Enter PERICLES
All fortune to the good Simonides!
To you as much
For your sweet music this last night: I do
Protest my ears were never better fed
With such delightful pleasing harmony.
It is your grace's pleasure to commend;
Not my desert.
Sir
The worst of all her scholars
Let me ask you one thing:
What do you think of my daughter
A most virtuous princess.
And she is fair too
As a fair day in summer
Sir
Ay
I am unworthy for her schoolmaster.
She thinks not so; peruse this writing else.
[Aside]  What's here?
A letter
'Tis the king's subtlety to have my life.
O
Thou hast bewitch'd my daughter
A villain.
By the gods
Never did thought of mine levy offence;
Nor never did my actions yet commence
A deed might gain her love or your displeasure.
Traitor
Traitor!
Ay
Even in his throat--unless it be the king--
That calls me traitor
[Aside]  Now
My actions are as noble as my thoughts
I came unto your court for honour's cause
And he that otherwise accounts of me
No?
Here comes my daughter
Enter THAISA
Then
Did ere solicit
To any syllable that made love to you.
Why
Yea
Aside
I am glad on't with all my heart.--
I'll tame you; I'll bring you in subjection.
Will you
Upon a stranger?
Aside
who
Therefore hear you
Your will to mine
Man and wife:
Nay
And being join'd
And for a further grief
What
Yes
Even as my life
What
Yes
It pleaseth me so well
And then with what haste you can get you to bed.
Exeunt
ACT III
Enter GOWER
Now sleep y-slaked hath the rout;
No din but snores the house about
Of this most pompous marriage-feast.
The cat
And crickets sing at the oven's mouth
Hymen hath brought the bride to bed.
Where
With your fine fancies quaintly eche:
What's dumb in show I'll plain with speech.
DUMB SHOW.
Enter
By many a dern and painful perch
Of Pericles the careful search
Which the world together joins
That horse and sail and high expense
Can stead the quest. At last from Tyre
Are letters brought
Antiochus and his daughter dead;
The men of Tyrus on the head
Of Helicanus would set on
The crown of Tyre
The mutiny he there hastes t' oppress;
Says to 'em
Come not home in twice six moons
Who dream'd
Brief
His queen with child makes her desire--
Which who shall cross?--along to go:
Omit we all their dole and woe:
Lychorida
On Neptune's billow; half the flood
Hath their keel cut: but fortune's mood
Varies again; the grisly north
Disgorges such a tempest forth
The lady shrieks
Does fall in travail with her fear:
And what ensues in this fell storm
Shall for itself itself perform.
I nill relate
Conveniently the rest convey;
Which might not what by me is told.
In your imagination hold
This stage the ship
The sea-tost Pericles appears to speak.
Exit
SCENE I:
Enter PERICLES
Thou god of this great vast
Upon the winds command
Thy deafening
Thy nimble
Wilt thou spit all thyself? The seaman's whistle
Is as a whisper in the ears of death
Divinest patroness
To those that cry by night
Aboard our dancing boat; make swift the pangs
Of my queen's travails!
Enter LYCHORIDA
Now
Here is a thing too young for such a place
Am like to do: take in your arms this piece
Of your dead queen.
How
Patience
Here's all that is left living of your queen
O you gods!
Why do you make us love your goodly gifts
Recall not what we give
Use honour with you.
Patience
Now
For a more blustrous birth had never babe:
Quiet and gentle thy conditions! for
Thou art the rudeliest welcome to this world
That ever was prince's child. Happy what follows!
Thou hast as chiding a nativity
As fire
Thy loss is more than can thy portage quit
Throw their best eyes upon't!
Enter two Sailors
What courage
Courage enough: I do not fear the flaw;
It hath done to me the worst. Yet
Of this poor infant
Slack the bolins there! Thou wilt not
Blow
But sea-room
the moon
Sir
cleared of the dead.
That's your superstition.
Pardon us
observed: and we are strong in custom. Therefore
briefly yield her; for she must overboard straight.
As you think meet. Most wretched queen!
Here she lies
A terrible childbed hast thou had
No light
Forgot thee utterly: nor have I time
To give thee hallow'd to thy grave
Must cast thee
Where
And humming water must o'erwhelm thy corpse
Bring me the satin coffer: lay the babe
Upon the pillow: hie thee
A priestly farewell to her: suddenly
Exit LYCHORIDA
Sir
and bitumed ready.
I thank thee. Mariner
We are near Tarsus.
Thither
Alter thy course for Tyre. When canst thou reach it?
By break of day
O
There will I visit Cleon
Cannot hold out to Tyrus: there I'll leave it
At careful nursing. Go thy ways
I'll bring the body presently.
Exeunt
SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
Enter CERIMON
Philemon
Enter PHILEMON
Doth my lord call?
Get fire and meat for these poor men:
'T has been a turbulent and stormy night.
I have been in many; but such a night as this
Your master will be dead ere you return;
There's nothing can be minister'd to nature
That can recover him.
To PHILEMON
Give this to the 'pothecary
Exeunt all but CERIMON
Enter two Gentlemen
Good morrow.
Good morrow to your lordship.
Gentlemen
Sir
The very principals did seem to rend
Made me to quit the house.
That is the cause we trouble you so early;
'Tis not our husbandry.
O
But I much marvel that your lordship
Rich tire about you
Shake off the golden slumber of repose.
'Tis most strange
I hold it ever
Than nobleness and riches: careless heirs
May the two latter darken and expend;
But immortality attends the former.
Making a man a god. 'Tis known
Have studied physic
To me and to my aid the blest infusions
That dwell in vegetives
And I can speak of the disturbances
That nature works
A more content in course of true delight
Than to be thirsty after tottering honour
Your honour has through Ephesus pour'd forth
Your charity
Your creatures
And not your knowledge
Your purse
Such strong renown as time shall ne'er decay.
Enter two or three Servants with a chest
So; lift there.
What is that?
Sir
Did the sea toss upon our shore this chest:
'Tis of some wreck.
Set 't down
'Tis like a coffin
Whate'er it be
If the sea's stomach be o'ercharged with gold
'Tis so
How close 'tis caulk'd and bitumed!
Did the sea cast it up?
I never saw so huge a billow
Wrench it open;
Soft! it smells most sweetly in my sense.
A delicate odour.
As ever hit my nostril. So
O you most potent gods! what's here? a corse!
Most strange!
Shrouded in cloth of state; balm'd and entreasured
With full bags of spices! A passport too!
Apollo
Reads from a scroll
'Here I give to understand
This queen
Who finds her
She was the daughter of a king:
Besides this treasure for a fee
If thou livest
That even cracks for woe! This chanced tonight.
Most likely
Nay
For look how fresh she looks! They were too rough
That threw her in the sea. Make a fire within:
Fetch hither all my boxes in my closet.
Exit a Servant
Death may usurp on nature many hours
The o'erpress'd spirits. I heard of an Egyptian
That had nine hours lien dead
Re-enter a Servant
Well said
The rough and woeful music that we have
The viol once more: how thou stirr'st
The music there!--I pray you
Gentlemen.
This queen will live: nature awakes; a warmth
Breathes out of her: she hath not been entranced
Above five hours: see how she gins to blow
Into life's flower again!
The heavens
Your fame forever.
She is alive; behold
Which Pericles hath lost
The diamonds of a most praised water
Do appear
She moves
O dear Diana
Is not this strange?
Most rare.
Hush
Lend me your hands; to the next chamber bear her.
Get linen: now this matter must be look'd to
And AEsculapius guide us!
Exeunt
SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
Enter PERICLES
Most honour'd Cleon
My twelve months are expired
In a litigious peace. You
Make up the rest upon you!
Your shafts of fortune
O your sweet queen!
That the strict fates had pleased you had brought her hither
We cannot but obey
The powers above us. Could I rage and roar
As doth the sea she lies in
Must be as 'tis. My gentle babe Marina
I charge your charity withal
The infant of your care; beseeching you
To give her princely training
Manner'd as she is born.
Fear not
Your grace
Should therein make me vile
But if to that my nature need a spur
I believe you;
Your honour and your goodness teach me to't
Unscissor'd shall this hair of mine remain
Good madam
In bringing up my child.
I have one myself
Than yours
Madam
We'll bring your grace e'en to the edge o' the shore
The gentlest winds of heaven.
I will embrace
Your offer. Come
Look to your little mistress
You may depend hereafter. Come
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
Enter CERIMON and THAISA
Madam
At your command. Know you the character?
It is my lord's.
That I was shipp'd at sea
Deliver'd
Madam
Moreover
Shall there attend you.
My recompense is thanks
Yet my good will is great
Exeunt
ACT IV
Enter GOWER
Imagine Pericles arrived at Tyre
His woeful queen we leave at Ephesus
Now to Marina bend your mind
At Tarsus
In music
Of education all the grace
Of general wonder. But
Of earned praise
Seeks to take off by treason's knife.
And in this kind hath our Cleon
One daughter
Hight Philoten: and it is said
For certain in our story
Would ever with Marina be:
Be't when she weaved the sleided silk
With fingers long
Or when she would with sharp needle wound
The cambric
By hurting it; or when to the lute
She sung
She would with rich and constant pen
Vail to her mistress Dian; still
This Philoten contends in skill
With absolute Marina: so
With the dove of Paphos might the crow
Vie feathers white. Marina gets
All praises
In Philoten all graceful marks
For good Marina
Might stand peerless by this slaughter.
The sooner her vile thoughts to stead
And cursed Dionyza hath
The pregnant instrument of wrath
Prest for this blow. The unborn event
I do commend to your content:
Only I carry winged time
Post on the lame feet of my rhyme;
Which never could I so convey
Dionyza does appear
Exit
SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
Enter DIONYZA and LEONINE
Thy oath remember; thou hast sworn to do't:
'Tis but a blow
Thou canst not do a thing in the world so soon
Even women have cast off
A soldier to thy purpose.
I will do't; but yet she is a goodly creature.
The fitter
she comes weeping for her only mistress' death.
Thou art resolved?
I am resolved.
Enter MARINA
No
How now
How chance my daughter is not with you? Do not
Consume your blood with sorrowing: you have
A nurse of me. Lord
With this unprofitable woe!
Come
Walk with Leonine; the air is quick there
No
I'll not bereave you of your servant.
Come
I love the king your father
Expect him here: when he shall come and find
Our paragon to all reports thus blasted
Blame both my lord and me
No care to your best courses. Go
That excellent complexion
The eyes of young and old. Care not for me
I can go home alone.
Well
But yet I have no desire to it.
Come
Walk half an hour
Remember what I have said.
I warrant you
I'll leave you
Pray
What! I must have a care of you.
My thanks
Exit DIONYZA
Is this wind westerly that blows?
South-west.
When I was born
Was't so?
My father
His kingly hands
And
That almost burst the deck.
When was this?
When I was born:
Never was waves nor wind more violent;
And from the ladder-tackle washes off
A canvas-climber. 'Ha!' says one
And with a dropping industry they skip
From stem to stern: the boatswain whistles
The master calls
Come
What mean you?
If you require a little space for prayer
To do my work with haste.
Why will you kill me?
To satisfy my lady.
Why would she have me kill'd?
Now
I never spake bad word
To any living creature: believe me
I trod upon a worm against my will
My commission
Is not to reason of the deed
You will not do't for all the world
You are well favour'd
You have a gentle heart. I saw you lately
Good sooth
Your lady seeks my life; come you between
I am sworn
He seizes her
Enter Pirates
Hold
LEONINE runs away
A prize! a prize!
Half-part
Come
Exeunt Pirates with MARINA
Re-enter LEONINE
These roguing thieves serve the great pirate Valdes;
And they have seized Marina. Let her go:
There's no hope she will return. I'll swear
she's dead
Perhaps they will but please themselves upon her
Exit
SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
Enter Pandar
Boult!
Sir?
Search the market narrowly; Mytilene is full of
gallants. We lost too much money this mart by being
too wenchless.
We were never so much out of creatures. We have but
poor three
do; and they with continual action are even as good as rotten.
Therefore let's have fresh ones
them. If there be not a conscience to be used in
every trade
Thou sayest true: 'tis not our bringing up of poor
bastards
Ay
shall I search the market?
What else
will blow it to pieces
Thou sayest true; they're too unwholesome
conscience. The poor Transylvanian is dead
lay with the little baggage.
Ay
for worms. But I'll go search the market.
Exit
Three or four thousand chequins were as pretty a
proportion to live quietly
Why to give over
when we are old?
O
the commodity wages not with the danger: therefore
estate
Besides
will be strong with us for giving over.
Come
As well as we! ay
Neither is our profession any trade; it's no

she's a virgin?
O
Master
if you like her

Alack that Leonine was so slack
He should have struck
For to seek my mother!
Why lament you
That I am pretty.
Come

You are light into my hands

To scape his hands where I was like to die.

SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
Enter CLEON and DIONYZA
Why
O Dionyza
The sun and moon ne'er look'd upon!
I think
You'll turn a child again.
Were I chief lord of all this spacious world
To equal any single crown o' the earth
I' the justice of compare! O villain Leonine!
Whom thou hast poison'd too:
If thou hadst drunk to him
Becoming well thy fact: what canst thou say
When noble Pericles shall demand his child?
That she is dead. Nurses are not the fates
She died at night; I'll say so. Who can cross it?
Unless you play the pious innocent
'She died by foul play.'
O
Do like this worst.
Be one of those that think
The petty wrens of Tarsus will fly hence
To think of what a noble strain you are
To such proceeding
Who ever but his approbation added
From honourable sources.
Be it so
Yet none does know
She did disdain my child
Her and her fortunes: none would look on her
Whilst ours was blurted at and held a malkin
Not worth the time of day. It pierced me through;
And though you call my course unnatural
It greets me as an enterprise of kindness
Perform'd to your sole daughter.
Heavens forgive it!
And as for Pericles
Is almost finish'd
In glittering golden characters express
A general praise to her
At whose expense 'tis done.
Thou art like the harpy
You are like one that superstitiously
Doth swear to the gods that winter kills the flies:
But yet I know you'll do as I advise.
Exeunt
SCENE IV:
Enter GOWER
Thus time we waste
Sail seas in cockles
Making
By you being pardon'd
To use one language in each several clime
Where our scenes seem to live. I do beseech you
To learn of me
Is now again thwarting the wayward seas
To see his daughter
Old Escanes
Advanced in time to great and high estate
Well-sailing ships and bounteous winds have brought
This king to Tarsus
So with his steerage shall your thoughts grow on
To fetch his daughter home
Like motes and shadows see them move awhile;
Your ears unto your eyes I'll reconcile.
DUMB SHOW.
Enter PERICLES
See how belief may suffer by foul show!
This borrow'd passion stands for true old woe;
And Pericles
o'ershower'd
Never to wash his face
He puts on sackcloth
A tempest
The epitaph is for Marina writ
By wicked Dionyza.
Reads the inscription on MARINA's monument
'The fairest
She was of Tyrus the king's daughter
Marina was she call'd; and at her birth
Therefore the earth
Wherefore she does
No visor does become black villany
So well as soft and tender flattery.
Let Pericles believe his daughter's dead
By Lady Fortune; while our scene must play
His daughter's woe and heavy well-a-day
In her unholy service. Patience
Exit
SCENE V. Mytilene. A street before the brothel.
Enter
Did you ever hear the like?
No
being once gone.
But to have divinity preached there! did you ever
dream of such a thing?
No
shall's go hear the vestals sing?
I'll do any thing now that is virtuous; but I
am out of the road of rutting for ever.
Exeunt

Is she not a fair creature?

Next

If he govern the country

What he will do graciously

My lord
pains to work her to your manage. Come

Now
What trade
Why
I cannot be offended with my trade. Please you to name it.
How long have you been of this profession?
E'er since I can remember.
Did you go to 't so young? Were you a gamester at

Earlier too
Why
creature of sale.

Why

of shame and iniquity. O

If you were born to honour

That thought you worthy of it.
How's this? how's this? Some more; be sage.
For me
Have placed me in this sty
Would set me free from this unhallow'd place
That flies i' the purer air!
I did not think
Thou couldst have spoke so well; ne'er dream'd thou couldst.
Had I brought hither a corrupted mind
Persever in that clear way thou goest
The good gods preserve you!
For me
That I came with no ill intent; for to me
The very doors and windows savour vilely.
Fare thee well. Thou art a piece of virtue
I doubt not but thy training hath been noble.
Hold
A curse upon him
Hear from me

Your house
Exit
How's this? We must take another course with you.
If your peevish chastity
breakfast in the cheapest country under the cope

Whither would you have me?
I must have your maidenhead taken off

Re-enter Bawd
How now! what's the matter?
Worse and worse
words to the Lord Lysimachus.
O abominable!
She makes our profession as it were to stink afore

Marry
The nobleman would have dealt with her like a
nobleman

Boult
crack the glass of her virginity
An if she were a thornier piece of ground than she
is
Hark
She conjures: away with her! Would she had never

to undo us. Will you not go the way of women-kind?
Marry
Exit
Come
Whither wilt thou have me?
To take from you the jewel you hold so dear.
Prithee
Come now
What canst thou wish thine enemy to be?
Why
Neither of these are so bad as thou art
Thou hold'st a place
Of hell would not in reputation change:
Thou art the damned doorkeeper to every
Coistrel that comes inquiring for his Tib;
To the choleric fisting of every rogue
Thy ear is liable; thy food is such
As hath been belch'd on by infected lungs.
What would you have me do? go to the wars
you? where a man may serve seven years for the loss
of a leg
buy him a wooden one?
Do any thing but this thou doest. Empty
OLD receptacles
Serve by indenture to the common hangman:
Any of these ways are yet better than this;
For what thou professest
Would safely deliver me from this place!
Here
If that thy master would gain by thee
And I will undertake all these to teach.
I doubt not but this populous city will
Yield many scholars.
But can you teach all this you speak of?
Prove that I cannot
That doth frequent your house.
Well
place thee
But amongst honest women.
'Faith
But since my master and mistress have bought you
will make them acquainted with your purpose
doubt not but I shall find them tractable enough.
Come
Exeunt
ACT V
Enter GOWER
Marina thus the brothel 'scapes
Into an honest house
She sings like one immortal
As goddess-like to her admired lays;
Deep clerks she dumbs; and with her needle composes
Nature's own shape
Her inkle
That pupils lacks she none of noble race
She gives the cursed bawd. Here we her place;
And to her father turn our thoughts again
Whence
Here where his daughter dwells; and on this coast
Suppose him now at anchor. The city strived
God Neptune's annual feast to keep: from whence
Lysimachus our Tyrian ship espies
And to him in his barge with fervor hies.
In your supposing once more put your sight
Of heavy Pericles; think this his bark:
Where what is done in action
Exit
SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship
pavilion on deck
within it
beside the Tyrian vessel.
Enter two Sailors
[To the Sailor of Mytilene]  Where is lord Helicanus?
he can resolve you.
O
Sir
That he have his. Call up some gentlemen.
Ho
Enter two or three Gentlemen
Doth your lordship call?
Gentlemen
I pray ye
The Gentlemen and the two Sailors descend
Enter
Sir
Hail
And you
You wish me well.
Being on shore
First
I am the governor of this place you lie before.
Sir
A man who for this three months hath not spoken
To any one
But to prorogue his grief.
Upon what ground is his distemperature?
'Twould be too tedious to repeat;
But the main grief springs from the loss
Of a beloved daughter and a wife.
May we not see him?
You may;
But bootless is your sight: he will not speak To any.
Yet let me obtain my wish.
Behold him.
PERICLES discovered
This was a goodly person
Sir king
Hail
It is in vain; he will not speak to you.
Sir
'Tis well bethought.
She questionless with her sweet harmony
And other chosen attractions
She is all happy as the fairest of all
The leafy shelter that abuts against
The island's side.
Whispers a Lord
Sure
That bears recovery's name. But
We have stretch'd thus far
That for our gold we may provision have
O
Which if we should deny
For every graff would send a caterpillar
Let me entreat to know at large the cause
Of your king's sorrow.
Sit
But
Re-enter
O
The lady that I sent for. Welcome
Is't not a goodly presence?
She's a gallant lady.
She's such a one
Came of a gentle kind and noble stock
Fair one
Expect even here
If that thy prosperous and artificial feat
Can draw him but to answer thee in aught
As thy desires can wish.
Sir
My utmost skill in his recovery
That none but I and my companion maid
Be suffer'd to come near him.
Come
And the gods make her prosperous!
MARINA sings
Mark'd he your music?
No
See
Hail
Hum
I am a maid
Might equal yours
Though wayward fortune did malign my state
Who stood equivalent with mighty kings:
But time hath rooted out my parentage
Bound me in servitude.
Aside
I will desist;
But there is something glows upon my cheek
My fortunes--parentage--good parentage--
To equal mine!--was it not thus? what say you?
I said
I do think so. Pray you
You are like something that--What country-woman?
Here of these shores?
No
Yet I was mortally brought forth
No other than I appear.
I am great with woe
My dearest wife was like this maid
My daughter might have been: my queen's square brows;
Her stature to an inch; as wand-like straight;
As silver-voiced; her eyes as jewel-like
And cased as richly; in pace another Juno;
Who starves the ears she feeds
Where I am but a stranger: from the deck
You may discern the place.
Where were you bred?
And how achieved you these endowments
You make more rich to owe?
If I should tell my history
Like lies disdain'd in the reporting.
Prithee
Falseness cannot come from thee; for thou look'st
Modest as Justice
For the crown'd Truth to dwell in: I will
believe thee
To points that seem impossible; for thou look'st
Like one I loved indeed. What were thy friends?
Didst thou not say
Which was when I perceived thee--that thou camest
From good descending?
So indeed I did.
Report thy parentage. I think thou said'st
Thou hadst been toss'd from wrong to injury
Some such thing
I said
Did warrant me was likely.
Tell thy story;
If thine consider'd prove the thousandth part
Of my endurance
Have suffer'd like a girl: yet thou dost look
Like Patience gazing on kings' graves
Extremity out of act. What were thy friends?
How lost thou them? Thy name
Recount
My name is Marina.
O
To make the world to laugh at me.
Patience
Nay
Thou little know'st how thou dost startle me
The name
Was given me by one that had some power
How! a king's daughter?
And call'd Marina?
You said you would believe me;
But
But are you flesh and blood?
Have you a working pulse? and are no fairy?
Motion! Well; speak on. Where were you born?
And wherefore call'd Marina?
Call'd Marina
For I was born at sea.
At sea! what mother?
My mother was the daughter of a king;
Who died the minute I was born
Deliver'd weeping.
O
Aside
This is the rarest dream that e'er dull sleep
Did mock sad fools withal: this cannot be:
My daughter's buried. Well: where were you bred?
I'll hear you more
You scorn: believe me
I will believe you by the syllable
Of what you shall deliver. Yet
How came you in these parts? where were you bred?
The king my father did in Tarsus leave me;
Till cruel Cleon
A villain to attempt it
Brought me to Mytilene. But
It may be
I am the daughter to King Pericles
Ho
Calls my lord?
Thou art a grave and noble counsellor
I know not; but
Here is the regent
Speaks nobly of her.
She would never tell
Her parentage; being demanded that
O Helicanus
Give me a gash
Lest this great sea of joys rushing upon me
O'erbear the shores of my mortality
Thou that wast born at sea
As thunder threatens us: this is Marina.
What was thy mother's name? tell me but that
First
I am Pericles of Tyre: but tell me now
My drown'd queen's name
Thou hast been godlike perfect
To Pericles thy father.
Is it no more to be your daughter than
To say my mother's name was Thaisa?
Thaisa was my mother
The minute I began.
Now
Give me fresh garments. Mine own
She is not dead at Tarsus
When thou shalt kneel
She is thy very princess. Who is this?
Sir
I embrace you.
Give me my robes. I am wild in my beholding.
O heavens bless my girl! But
Tell Helicanus
O'er
My lord
None!
The music of the spheres! List
It is not good to cross him; give him way.
Rarest sounds! Do ye not hear?
My lord
Music
Most heavenly music!
It nips me unto listening
Hangs upon mine eyes: let me rest.
Sleeps
A pillow for his head:
So
Exeunt all but PERICLES
DIANA appears to PERICLES as in a vision
My temple stands in Ephesus: hie thee thither
There
To mourn thy crosses
And give them repetition to the life.
Or perform my bidding
Do it
Awake
Disappears
Celestial Dian
Re-enter HELICANUS
Sir?
My purpose was for Tarsus
The inhospitable Cleon; but I am
For other service first: toward Ephesus
Turn our blown sails; eftsoons I'll tell thee why.
To LYSIMACHUS
Shall we refresh us
As our intents will need?
Sir
You shall prevail
You have been noble towards her.
Sir
Come
Exeunt
SCENE II:
Enter GOWER
Now our sands are almost run;
More a little
This
What pageantry
To greet the king. So he thrived
To fair Marina; but in no wise
Till he had done his sacrifice
In feather'd briefness sails are fill'd
At Ephesus
That he can hither come so soon
Exit
SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing
near the altar
Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants
of Ephesus attending.
Enter PERICLES
Hail
Who
At Pentapolis the fair Thaisa.
At sea in childbed died she
A maid-child call'd Marina; who
Was nursed with Cleon; who at fourteen years
He sought to murder: but her better stars
Brought her to Mytilene; 'gainst whose shore
Riding
Made known herself my daughter.
Voice and favour!
You are
Faints
What means the nun? she dies! help
Noble sir
Reverend appearer
I threw her overboard with these very arms.
Upon this coast
'Tis most certain.
Look to the lady; O
Early in blustering morn this lady was
Thrown upon this shore. I oped the coffin
Here in Diana's temple.
May we see them?
Great sir
O
If he be none of mine
Will to my sense bend no licentious ear
The voice of dead Thaisa!
That Thaisa am I
And drown'd.
Immortal Dian!
Now I know you better.
When we with tears parted Pentapolis
Shows a ring
This
Makes my past miseries sports: you shall do well
Melt and no more be seen. O
A second time within these arms.
My heart
Leaps to be gone into my mother's bosom.
Kneels to THAISA
Look
Thy burden at the sea
For she was yielded there.
Blest
Hail
I know you not.
You have heard me say
Can you remember what I call'd the man?
I have named him oft.
'Twas Helicanus then.
Still confirmation:
Embrace him
Now do I long to hear how you were found;
How possibly preserved; and who to thank
Lord Cerimon
From first to last resolve you.
Reverend sir
More like a god than you. Will you deliver
How this dead queen re-lives?
I will
Beseech you
How she came placed here in the temple;
No needful thing omitted.
Pure Dian
Will offer night-oblations to thee. Thaisa
Makes me look dismal will I clip to form;
And what this fourteen years no razor touch'd
Lord Cerimon hath letters of good credit
Heavens make a star of him! Yet there
Will in that kingdom spend our following days:
Our son and daughter shall in Tyrus reign.
Lord Cerimon
To hear the rest untold: sir
Exeunt
Enter GOWER
In Antiochus and his daughter you have heard
Of monstrous lust the due and just reward:
In Pericles
In Helicanus may you well descry
A figure of truth
In reverend Cerimon there well appears
The worth that learned charity aye wears:
For wicked Cleon and his wife
Had spread their cursed deed
Of Pericles
The gods for murder seemed so content
To punish them; although not done
So
Exit
ACT I
SCENE I. London. KING RICHARD II's palace.
Enter KING RICHARD II
Old John of Gaunt
I have
Tell me
Or worthily
As near as I could sift him on that argument
Aim'd at your highness
Then call them to our presence; face to face
The accuser and the accused freely speak:
High-stomach'd are they both
Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE and THOMAS MOWBRAY
Many years of happy days befal
My gracious sovereign
Each day still better other's happiness;
Until the heavens
We thank you both: yet one but flatters us
Namely to appeal each other of high treason.
Cousin of Hereford
Against the Duke of Norfolk
First
In the devotion of a subject's love
Now
My body shall make good upon this earth
Thou art a traitor and a miscreant
Once more
And wish
Let not my cold words here accuse my zeal:
'Tis not the trial of a woman's war
The blood is hot that must be cool'd for this:
Yet can I not of such tame patience boast
As to be hush'd and nought at all to say:
First
From giving reins and spurs to my free speech;
Which else would post until it had return'd
These terms of treason doubled down his throat.
Setting aside his high blood's royalty
Call him a slanderous coward and a villain:
Which to maintain I would allow him odds
Even to the frozen ridges of the Alps
Mean time let this defend my loyalty
Pale trembling coward
If guilty dread have left thee so much strength
As to take up mine honour's pawn
By that and all the rites of knighthood else
I take it up; and by that sword I swear
Which gently laid my knighthood on my shoulder
And when I mount
What doth our cousin lay to Mowbray's charge?
It must be great that can inherit us
So much as of a thought of ill in him.
Look
That Mowbray hath received eight thousand nobles
In name of lendings for your highness' soldiers
Besides I say and will in battle prove
That ever was survey'd by English eye
Complotted and contrived in this land
Fetch from false Mowbray their first head and spring.
Further I say and further will maintain
Upon his bad life to make all this good
Which blood
And
How high a pitch his resolution soars!
Thomas of Norfolk
O
And bid his ears a little while be deaf
Mowbray
Were he my brother
Should nothing privilege him
The unstooping firmness of my upright soul:
He is our subject
Free speech and fearless I to thee allow.
Then
Three parts of that receipt I had for Calais
Disbursed I duly to his highness' soldiers;
The other part reserved I by consent
Upon remainder of a dear account
Now swallow down that lie. For Gloucester's death
Neglected my sworn duty in that case.
For you
Once did I lay an ambush for your life
But ere I last received the sacrament
I did confess it
Your grace's pardon
This is my fault: as for the rest appeall'd
Which in myself I boldly will defend;
And interchangeably hurl down my gage
Upon this overweening traitor's foot
Even in the best blood chamber'd in his bosom.
In haste whereof
Your highness to assign our trial day.
Wrath-kindled gentlemen
Let's purge this choler without letting blood:
This we prescribe
Deep malice makes too deep incision;
Forget
Our doctors say this is no month to bleed.
Good uncle
We'll calm the Duke of Norfolk
To be a make-peace shall become my age:
Throw down
And
When
Obedience bids I should not bid again.
Norfolk
Myself I throw
My life thou shalt command
The one my duty owes; but my fair name
I am disgraced
Which breathed this poison.
Rage must be withstood:
Give me his gage: lions make leopards tame.
Yea
And I resign my gage. My dear dear lord
Is spotless reputation: that away
A jewel in a ten-times-barr'd-up chest
Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast.
Mine honour is my life; both grow in one:
Take honour from me
Then
In that I live and for that will I die.
Cousin
O
Shall I seem crest-fall'n in my father's sight?
Or with pale beggar-fear impeach my height
Before this out-dared dastard? Ere my tongue
Shall wound my honour with such feeble wrong
The slavish motive of recanting fear
Exit JOHN OF GAUNT
We were not born to sue
Which since we cannot do to make you friends
There shall your swords and lances arbitrate
The swelling difference of your settled hate:
Since we can not atone you
Justice design the victor's chivalry.
Lord marshal
Be ready to direct these home alarms.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The DUKE OF LANCASTER'S palace.
Enter JOHN OF GAUNT with DUCHESS
Alas
Doth more solicit me than your exclaims
But since correction lieth in those hands
Which made the fault that we cannot correct
Who
Finds brotherhood in thee no sharper spur?
Hath love in thy old blood no living fire?
Edward's seven sons
Some of those seven are dried by nature's course
But Thomas
Ah
Made him a man; and though thou livest and breathest
In some large measure to thy father's death
Call it not patience
In suffering thus thy brother to be slaughter'd
That which in mean men we intitle patience
Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts.
What shall I say? to safeguard thine own life
God's is the quarrel; for God's substitute
An angry arm against His minister.
Where then
To God
Why
Thou goest to Coventry
Our cousin Hereford and fell Mowbray fight:
O
Or
Farewell
With her companion grief must end her life.
Sister
As much good stay with thee as go with me!
Yet one word more: grief boundeth where it falls
I take my leave before I have begun
Commend me to thy brother
Lo
Though this be all
I shall remember more. Bid him--ah
With all good speed at Plashy visit me.
Alack
But empty lodgings and unfurnish'd walls
And what hear there for welcome but my groans?
Therefore commend me; let him not come there
Desolate
The last leave of thee takes my weeping eye.
Exeunt
SCENE III. The lists at Coventry.
Enter the Lord Marshal and the DUKE OF AUMERLE
My Lord Aumerle
Yea
The Duke of Norfolk
Why
For nothing but his majesty's approach.
The trumpets sound
Marshal
The cause of his arrival here in arms:
Ask him his name and orderly proceed
To swear him in the justice of his cause.
In God's name and the king's
And why thou comest thus knightly clad in arms
Speak truly
As so defend thee heaven and thy valour!
My name is Thomas Mowbray
Who hither come engaged by my oath--
Which God defend a knight should violate!--
Both to defend my loyalty and truth
To God
And
And as I truly fight
The trumpets sound. Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Marshal
Thus plated in habiliments of war
What is thy name? and wherefore comest thou hither
Against whom comest thou? and what's thy quarrel?
Speak like a true knight
Harry of Hereford
Am I; who ready here do stand in arms
And as I truly fight
On pain of death
Or daring-hardy as to touch the lists
Appointed to direct these fair designs.
Lord marshal
For Mowbray and myself are like two men
That vow a long and weary pilgrimage;
Then let us take a ceremonious leave
And loving farewell of our several friends.
The appellant in all duty greets your highness
We will descend and fold him in our arms.
Cousin of Hereford
Farewell
O let no noble eye profane a tear
For me
As confident as is the falcon's flight
Against a bird
My loving lord
Of you
Not sick
Lo
The daintiest last
O thou
To reach at victory above my head
And with thy blessings steel my lance's point
God in thy good cause make thee prosperous!
Be swift like lightning in the execution;
And let thy blows
Of thy adverse pernicious enemy:
Rouse up thy youthful blood
Mine innocency and Saint George to thrive!
However God or fortune cast my lot
Never did captive with a freer heart
Cast off his chains of bondage and embrace
His golden uncontroll'd enfranchisement
This feast of battle with mine adversary.
Most mighty liege
As gentle and as jocund as to jest
Go I to fight: truth hath a quiet breast.
Farewell
Virtue with valour couched in thine eye.
Order the trial
Harry of Hereford
Strong as a tower in hope
Go bear this lance to Thomas
Harry of Hereford
And dares him to set forward to the fight.
Here standeth Thomas Mowbray
Henry of Hereford
Courageously and with a free desire
Attending but the signal to begin.
Sound
A charge sounded
Stay
Let them lay by their helmets and their spears
Withdraw with us: and let the trumpets sound
While we return these dukes what we decree.
A long flourish
Draw near
For that our kingdom's earth should not be soil'd
With that dear blood which it hath fostered;
And for our eyes do hate the dire aspect
Of civil wounds plough'd up with neighbours' sword;
And for we think the eagle-winged pride
Of sky-aspiring and ambitious thoughts
To wake our peace
Draws the sweet infant breath of gentle sleep;
Which so roused up with boisterous untuned drums
And make us wade even in our kindred's blood
You
Shall not regreet our fair dominions
Your will be done: this must my comfort be
And those his golden beams to you here lent
Shall point on me and gild my banishment.
Norfolk
The sly slow hours shall not determinate
The dateless limit of thy dear exile;
The hopeless word of 'never to return'
Breathe I against thee
A heavy sentence
A dearer merit
As to be cast forth in the common air
The language I have learn'd these forty years
And now my tongue's use is to me no more
Than an unstringed viol or a harp
That knows no touch to tune the harmony:
Within my mouth you have engaol'd my tongue
And dull unfeeling barren ignorance
Is made my gaoler to attend on me.
I am too old to fawn upon a nurse
What is thy sentence then but speechless death
It boots thee not to be compassionate:
After our sentence plaining comes too late.
Then thus I turn me from my country's light
Return again
Lay on our royal sword your banish'd hands;
Swear by the duty that you owe to God--
Our part therein we banish with yourselves--
To keep the oath that we administer:
You never shall
Embrace each other's love in banishment;
Nor never look upon each other's face;
Nor never write
This louring tempest of your home-bred hate;
Nor never by advised purpose meet
To plot
'Gainst us
I swear.
And I
Norfolk
By this time
Banish'd this frail sepulchre of our flesh
Confess thy treasons ere thou fly the realm;
Since thou hast far to go
The clogging burthen of a guilty soul.
No
But what thou art
And all too soon
Farewell
Save back to England
Exit
Uncle
I see thy grieved heart: thy sad aspect
Hath from the number of his banish'd years
Pluck'd four away.
To HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Six frozen winter spent
