How long a time lies in one little word!
Four lagging winters and four wanton springs
End in a word: such is the breath of kings.
I thank my liege
He shortens four years of my son's exile:
But little vantage shall I reap thereby;
For
Can change their moons and bring their times about
My oil-dried lamp and time-bewasted light
Shall be extinct with age and endless night;
My inch of taper will be burnt and done
Why uncle
But not a minute
Shorten my days thou canst with sullen sorrow
Thou canst help time to furrow me with age
Thy word is current with him for my death
Thy son is banish'd upon good advice
Why at our justice seem'st thou then to lour?
Things sweet to taste prove in digestion sour.
You urged me as a judge; but I had rather
You would have bid me argue like a father.
O
A partial slander sought I to avoid
Alas
But you gave leave to my unwilling tongue
Against my will to do myself this wrong.
Cousin
Six years we banish him
Flourish. Exeunt KING RICHARD II and train
Cousin
My lord
O
I have too few to take my leave of you
To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart.
Thy grief is but thy absence for a time.
Joy absent
What is six winters? they are quickly gone.
To men in joy; but grief makes one hour ten.
Call it a travel that thou takest for pleasure.
My heart will sigh when I miscall it so
The sullen passage of thy weary steps
Esteem as foil wherein thou art to set
The precious jewel of thy home return.
Nay
Will but remember me what a deal of world
I wander from the jewels that I love.
Must I not serve a long apprenticehood
To foreign passages
But that I was a journeyman to grief?
All places that the eye of heaven visits
Are to a wise man ports and happy havens.
Teach thy necessity to reason thus;
There is no virtue like necessity.
Think not the king did banish thee
Go
And not the king exiled thee; or suppose
Devouring pestilence hangs in our air
And thou art flying to a fresher clime:
Look
To lie that way thou go'st
Suppose the singing birds musicians
Than a delightful measure or a dance;
For gnarling sorrow hath less power to bite
The man that mocks at it and sets it light.
O
By thinking on the frosty Caucasus?
Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite
By bare imagination of a feast?
Or wallow naked in December snow
By thinking on fantastic summer's heat?
O
Gives but the greater feeling to the worse:
Fell sorrow's tooth doth never rankle more
Than when he bites
Come
Had I thy youth and cause
Then
My mother
Where'er I wander
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The court.
Enter KING RICHARD II
We did observe. Cousin Aumerle
I brought high Hereford
And say
Faith
Did grace our hollow parting with a tear.
What said our cousin when you parted with him?
'Farewell:'
And
Should so profane the word
To counterfeit oppression of such grief
That words seem'd buried in my sorrow's grave.
Marry
And added years to his short banishment
But since it would not
He is our cousin
Ourself and Bushy
Observed his courtship to the common people;
How he did seem to dive into their hearts
With humble and familiar courtesy
And patient underbearing of his fortune
Off goes his bonnet to an oyster-wench;
A brace of draymen bid God speed him well
And had the tribute of his supple knee
As were our England in reversion his
Well
Now for the rebels which stand out in Ireland
For their advantage and your highness' loss.
We will ourself in person to this war:
And
And liberal largess
The revenue whereof shall furnish us
For our affairs in hand: if that come short
Whereto
And send them after to supply our wants;
For we will make for Ireland presently.
Enter BUSHY
Bushy
Old John of Gaunt is grievous sick
To entreat your majesty to visit him.
Where lies he?
At Ely House.
Now put it
To help him to his grave immediately!
The lining of his coffers shall make coats
To deck our soldiers for these Irish wars.
Come
Pray God we may make haste
Amen.
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Ely House.
Enter JOHN OF GAUNT sick
Will the king come
In wholesome counsel to his unstaid youth?
Vex not yourself
For all in vain comes counsel to his ear.
O
Enforce attention like deep harmony:
Where words are scarce
He that no more must say is listen'd more
Than they whom youth and ease have taught to glose;
More are men's ends mark'd than their lives before:
The setting sun
Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear
No; it is stopp'd with other flattering sounds
The open ear of youth doth always listen;
Report of fashions in proud Italy
Limps after in base imitation.
Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity--
So it be new
That is not quickly buzzed into his ears?
Then all too late comes counsel to be heard
Direct not him whose way himself will choose:
'Tis breath thou lack'st
Methinks I am a prophet new inspired
And thus expiring do foretell of him:
His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot last
Small showers last long
He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes;
With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder:
Light vanity
This royal throne of kings
Against infection and the hand of war
England
Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege
Of watery Neptune
That England
Ah
Enter KING RICHARD II and QUEEN
The king is come: deal mildly with his youth;
For young hot colts being raged do rage the more.
How fares our noble uncle
What comfort
O how that name befits my composition!
Old Gaunt indeed
Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast;
And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?
For sleeping England long time have I watch'd;
Watching breeds leanness
The pleasure that some fathers feed upon
And therein fasting
Gaunt am I for the grave
Can sick men play so nicely with their names?
No
Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me
Should dying men flatter with those that live?
No
Thou
O
I am in health
Now He that made me knows I see thee ill;
Ill in myself to see
Thy death-bed is no lesser than thy land
Wherein thou liest in reputation sick;
And thou
Of those physicians that first wounded thee:
A thousand flatterers sit within thy crown
And yet
O
Seen how his son's son should destroy his sons
Why
But for thy world enjoying but this land
Landlord of England art thou now
Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; And thou--
A lunatic lean-witted fool
Make pale our cheek
With fury from his native residence.
Now
Should run thy head from thy unreverent shoulders.
O
That blood already
My brother Gloucester
May be a precedent and witness good
That thou respect'st not spilling Edward's blood:
Join with the present sickness that I have;
And thy unkindness be like crooked age
Live in thy shame
These words hereafter thy tormentors be!
Convey me to my bed
Love they to live that love and honour have.
Exit
And let them die that age and sullens have;
For both hast thou
I do beseech your majesty
To wayward sickliness and age in him:
He loves you
As Harry Duke of Hereford
Right
As theirs
Enter NORTHUMBERLAND
My liege
What says he?
Nay
His tongue is now a stringless instrument;
Words
Be York the next that must be bankrupt so!
Though death be poor
The ripest fruit first falls
His time is spent
So much for that. Now for our Irish wars:
We must supplant those rough rug-headed kerns
But only they have privilege to live.
And for these great affairs do ask some charge
The plate
How long shall I be patient? ah
Shall tender duty make me suffer wrong?
Not Gloucester's death
Not Gaunt's rebukes
About his marriage
I am the last of noble Edward's sons
In war was never lion raged more fierce
His face thou hast
But when he frown'd
And not against his friends; his noble hand
Did will what he did spend and spent not that
Which his triumphant father's hand had won;
His hands were guilty of no kindred blood
O Richard! York is too far gone with grief
Why
O my liege
Not to be pardon'd
Seek you to seize and gripe into your hands
The royalties and rights of banish'd Hereford?
Is not Gaunt dead
Was not Gaunt just
Did not the one deserve to have an heir?
Is not his heir a well-deserving son?
Take Hereford's rights away
His charters and his customary rights;
Let not to-morrow then ensue to-day;
Be not thyself; for how art thou a king
But by fair sequence and succession?
Now
If you do wrongfully seize Hereford's rights
By his attorneys-general to sue
His livery
And prick my tender patience
Which honour and allegiance cannot think.
Think what you will
His plate
I'll not be by the while: my liege
What will ensue hereof
But by bad courses may be understood
That their events can never fall out good.
Exit
Go
Bid him repair to us to Ely House
To see this business. To-morrow next
We will for Ireland; and 'tis time
And we create
For he is just and always loved us well.
Come on
Be merry
Flourish. Exeunt KING RICHARD II
Well
And living too; for now his son is duke.
Barely in title
Richly in both
My heart is great; but it must break with silence
Nay
That speaks thy words again to do thee harm!
Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke of Hereford?
If it be so
Quick is mine ear to hear of good towards him.
No good at all that I can do for him;
Unless you call it good to pity him
Now
In him
Of noble blood in this declining land.
The king is not himself
By flatterers; and what they will inform
'Gainst us
The commons hath he pill'd with grievous taxes
For ancient quarrels
And daily new exactions are devised
But what
Wars have not wasted it
That which his noble ancestors achieved with blows:
More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.
The Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm.
The king's grown bankrupt
Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.
He hath not money for these Irish wars
His noble kinsman: most degenerate king!
But
We see the wind sit sore upon our sails
We see the very wreck that we must suffer;
And unavoided is the danger now
Not so; even through the hollow eyes of death
I spy life peering; but I dare not say
How near the tidings of our comfort is.
Nay
Be confident to speak
We three are but thyself; and
Then thus: I have from Port le Blanc
In Brittany
That Harry Duke of Hereford
With eight tall ships
And shortly mean to touch our northern shore:
Perhaps they had ere this
The first departing of the king for Ireland.
If then we shall shake off our slavish yoke
And make high majesty look like itself
But if you faint
To horse
Hold out my horse
Exeunt
SCENE II. The palace.
Enter QUEEN
Madam
You promised
And entertain a cheerful disposition.
To please the king I did; to please myself
I cannot do it; yet I know no cause
Why I should welcome such a guest as grief
As my sweet Richard: yet again
With nothing trembles: at some thing it grieves
Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows
For sorrow's eye
Like perspectives
Show nothing but confusion
Distinguish form: so your sweet majesty
Which
Of what it is not. Then
Or if it be
It may be so; but yet my inward soul
Persuades me it is otherwise: howe'er it be
As
'Tis nothing but conceit
'Tis nothing less: conceit is still derived
From some forefather grief; mine is not so
Or something hath the nothing that I grieve:
'Tis in reversion that I do possess;
But what it is
I cannot name; 'tis nameless woe
Enter GREEN
God save your majesty! and well met
I hope the king is not yet shipp'd for Ireland.
Why hopest thou so? 'tis better hope he is;
For his designs crave haste
Then wherefore dost thou hope he is not shipp'd?
That he
The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals himself
At Ravenspurgh.
Now God in heaven forbid!
Ah
Why have you not proclaim'd Northumberland
And all the rest revolted faction traitors?
We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester
Hath broke his staff
To Bolingbroke.
So
Now hath my soul brought forth her prodigy
Despair not
Who shall hinder me?
I will despair
With cozening hope: he is a flatterer
Enter DUKE OF YORK
Here comes the Duke of York.
With signs of war about his aged neck:
O
Uncle
Should I do so
Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth
Your husband
Here am I left to underprop his land
Now comes the sick hour that his surfeit made;
Now shall he try his friends that flatter'd him.
Enter a Servant
My lord
He was? Why
The nobles they are fled
Sirrah
Bid her send me presently a thousand pound:
Hold
My lord
But I shall grieve you to report the rest.
What is't
An hour before I came
God for his mercy! what a tide of woes
Comes rushing on this woeful land at once!
I know not what to do: I would to God
What
How shall we do for money for these wars?
Come
Go
And bring away the armour that is there.
Exit Servant
Gentlemen
If I know how or which way to order these affairs
Thus thrust disorderly into my hands
The one is my sovereign
And duty bids defend; the other again
Is my kinsman
Well
Dispose of you.
Gentlemen
I should to Plashy too;
But time will not permit: all is uneven
Exeunt DUKE OF YORK and QUEEN
The wind sits fair for news to go to Ireland
Proportionable to the enemy
Is all unpossible.
Besides
Is near the hate of those love not the king.
And that's the wavering commons: for their love
Lies in their purses
By so much fills their hearts with deadly hate.
Wherein the king stands generally condemn'd.
If judgement lie in them
Well
The Earl of Wiltshire is already there.
Thither will I with you; for little office
The hateful commons will perform for us
Will you go along with us?
No; I will to Ireland to his majesty.
Farewell: if heart's presages be not vain
That's as York thrives to beat back Bolingbroke.
Alas
Is numbering sands and drinking oceans dry:
Where one on his side fights
Farewell at once
Well
I fear me
Exeunt
SCENE III. Wilds in Gloucestershire.
Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE and NORTHUMBERLAND
How far is it
Believe me
These high wild hills and rough uneven ways
Draws out our miles
But I bethink me what a weary way
From Ravenspurgh to Cotswold will be found
In Ross and Willoughby
The tediousness and process of my travel:
But theirs is sweetened with the hope to have
The present benefit which I possess;
And hope to joy is little less in joy
Than hope enjoy'd: by this the weary lords
Shall make their way seem short
By sight of what I have
Of much less value is my company
Than your good words. But who comes here?
Enter HENRY PERCY
It is my son
Harry
I had thought
Why
No
The household of the king.
What was his reason?
He was not so resolved when last we spake together.
Because your lordship was proclaimed traitor.
But he
What power the Duke of York had levied there;
Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh.
Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford
No
Which ne'er I did remember: to my knowledge
Then learn to know him now; this is the duke.
My gracious lord
Which elder days shall ripen and confirm
To more approved service and desert.
I thank thee
I count myself in nothing else so happy
As in a soul remembering my good friends;
And
My heart this covenant makes
How far is it to Berkeley? and what stir
Keeps good old York there with his men of war?
There stands the castle
And in it are the Lords of York
None else of name and noble estimate.
Enter LORD ROSS and LORD WILLOUGHBY
Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby
Welcome
A banish'd traitor: all my treasury
Is yet but unfelt thanks
Shall be your love and labour's recompense.
Your presence makes us rich
And far surmounts our labour to attain it.
Evermore thanks
Which
Enter LORD BERKELEY
It is my Lord of Berkeley
My Lord of Hereford
My lord
And I am come to seek that name in England;
And I must find that title in your tongue
Mistake me not
To raze one title of your honour out:
To you
To take advantage of the absent time
And fright our native peace with self-born arms.
Enter DUKE OF YORK attended
I shall not need transport my words by you;
Here comes his grace in person. My noble uncle!
Kneels
Show me thy humble heart
My gracious uncle--
Tut
Grace me no grace
I am no traitor's uncle; and that word 'grace.'
In an ungracious mouth is but profane.
Why have those banish'd and forbidden legs
Dared once to touch a dust of England's ground?
But then more 'why?' why have they dared to march
So many miles upon her peaceful bosom
And ostentation of despised arms?
Comest thou because the anointed king is hence?
Why
Were I but now the lord of such hot youth
As when brave Gaunt
Rescued the Black Prince
Now prisoner to the palsy
And minister correction to thy fault!
My gracious uncle
On what condition stands it and wherein?
Even in condition of the worst degree
Thou art a banish'd man
Before the expiration of thy time
As I was banish'd
But as I come
And
Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye:
You are my father
I see old Gaunt alive; O
A wandering vagabond; my rights and royalties
Pluck'd from my arms perforce and given away
To upstart unthrifts? Wherefore was I born?
If that my cousin king be King of England
You have a son
Had you first died
I am denied to sue my livery here
My father's goods are all distrain'd and sold
What would you have me do? I am a subject
And therefore
To my inheritance of free descent.
The noble duke hath been too much abused.
It stands your grace upon to do him right.
Base men by his endowments are made great.
My lords of England
I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs
And laboured all I could to do him right;
But in this kind to come
And you that do abet him in this kind
Cherish rebellion and are rebels all.
The noble duke hath sworn his coming is
But for his own; and for the right of that
We all have strongly sworn to give him aid;
And let him ne'er see joy that breaks that oath!
Well
I cannot mend it
But if I could
Unto the sovereign mercy of the king;
But since I cannot
I do remain as neuter. So
Unless you please to enter in the castle
And there repose you for this night.
An offer
But we must win your grace to go with us
To Bristol castle
By Bushy
It may be I will go with you: but yet I'll pause;
For I am loath to break our country's laws.
Nor friends nor foes
Things past redress are now with me past care.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. A camp in Wales.
Enter EARL OF SALISBURY and a Welsh Captain
My lord of Salisbury
Therefore we will disperse ourselves: farewell.
Stay yet another day
The king reposeth all his confidence in thee.
'Tis thought the king is dead; we will not stay.
The bay-trees in our country are all wither'd
And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven;
The pale-faced moon looks bloody on the earth
And lean-look'd prophets whisper fearful change;
Rich men look sad and ruffians dance and leap
These signs forerun the death or fall of kings.
Farewell: our countrymen are gone and fled
Exit
Ah
I see thy glory like a shooting star
Fall to the base earth from the firmament.
Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west
Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes
Exit
ACT III
SCENE I. Bristol. Before the castle.
Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Bring forth these men.
Bushy and Green
Since presently your souls must part your bodies--
With too much urging your pernicious lives
From off my hands
I will unfold some causes of your deaths.
You have misled a prince
You have in manner with your sinful hours
Made a divorce betwixt his queen and him
And stain'd the beauty of a fair queen's cheeks
With tears drawn from her eyes by your foul wrongs.
Myself
Till you did make him misinterpret me
Whilst you have fed upon my signories
This and much more
To execution and the hand of death.
More welcome is the stroke of death to me
Than Bolingbroke to England. Lords
My comfort is that heaven will take our souls
And plague injustice with the pains of hell.
My Lord Northumberland
Exeunt NORTHUMBERLAND and others
Uncle
For God's sake
Tell her I send to her my kind commends;
Take special care my greetings be deliver'd.
A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'd
With letters of your love to her at large.
Thank
To fight with Glendower and his complices:
Awhile to work
Exeunt
SCENE II. The coast of Wales. A castle in view.
Drums; flourish and colours. Enter KING RICHARD II
Barkloughly castle call they this at hand?
Yea
Needs must I like it well: I weep for joy
To stand upon my kingdom once again.
Dear earth
As a long-parted mother with her child
Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in meeting
Feed not thy sovereign's foe
But let thy spiders
Which with usurping steps do trample thee:
Yield stinging nettles to mine enemies;
And when they from thy bosom pluck a flower
Whose double tongue may with a mortal touch
Throw death upon thy sovereign's enemies.
Mock not my senseless conjuration
This earth shall have a feeling and these stones
Prove armed soldiers
Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms.
Fear not
Hath power to keep you king in spite of all.
The means that heaven yields must be embraced
He means
Whilst Bolingbroke
Discomfortable cousin! know'st thou not
That when the searching eye of heaven is hid
In murders and in outrage
But when from under this terrestrial ball
He fires the proud tops of the eastern pines
And darts his light through every guilty hole
So when this thief
Whilst we were wandering with the antipodes
Not all the water in the rough rude sea
Can wash the balm off from an anointed king;
The breath of worldly men cannot depose
The deputy elected by the Lord:
For every man that Bolingbroke hath press'd
To lift shrewd steel against our golden crown
A glorious angel: then
Enter EARL OF SALISBURY
Welcome
Nor near nor farther off
And bids me speak of nothing but despair.
One day too late
O
To-day
For all the Welshmen
Are gone to Bolingbroke
Comfort
But now the blood of twenty thousand men
Did triumph in my face
And
All souls that will be safe fly from my side
Comfort
I had forgot myself; am I not king?
Awake
Is not the king's name twenty thousand names?
Arm
At thy great glory. Look not to the ground
High be our thoughts: I know my uncle York
Hath power enough to serve our turn. But who comes here?
Enter SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
More health and happiness betide my liege
Than can my care-tuned tongue deliver him!
Mine ear is open and my heart prepared;
The worst is worldly loss thou canst unfold.
Say
And what loss is it to be rid of care?
Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we?
Greater he shall not be; if he serve God
Revolt our subjects? that we cannot mend;
They break their faith to God as well as us:
Cry woe
The worst is death
Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd
To bear the tidings of calamity.
Like an unseasonable stormy day
Of Bolingbroke
With hard bright steel and hearts harder than steel.
White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairless scalps
Against thy majesty; boys
In stiff unwieldy arms against thy crown:
The very beadsmen learn to bend their bows
Of double-fatal yew against thy state;
Yea
Against thy seat: both young and old rebel
Too well
Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? where is Bagot?
What is become of Bushy? where is Green?
That they have let the dangerous enemy
Measure our confines with such peaceful steps?
If we prevail
I warrant they have made peace with Bolingbroke.
Peace have they made with him indeed
O villains
Dogs
Snakes
Three Judases
Would they make peace? terrible hell make war
Upon their spotted souls for this offence!
Sweet love
Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made
With heads
Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound
And lie full low
Is Bushy
Ay
Where is the duke my father with his power?
No matter where; of comfort no man speak:
Let's talk of graves
Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes
Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth
And yet not so
Save our deposed bodies to the ground?
Our lands
And that small model of the barren earth
Which serves as paste and cover to our bones.
For God's sake
And tell sad stories of the death of kings;
How some have been deposed; some slain in war
Some poison'd by their wives: some sleeping kill'd;
All murder'd: for within the hollow crown
That rounds the mortal temples of a king
Keeps Death his court and there the antic sits
Comes at the last and with a little pin
Bores through his castle wall
Cover your heads and mock not flesh and blood
With solemn reverence: throw away respect
I live with bread like you
My lord
To fear the foe
Fear and be slain; no worse can come to fight:
And fight and die is death destroying death;
Where fearing dying pays death servile breath.
My father hath a power; inquire of him
And learn to make a body of a limb.
Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke
To change blows with thee for our day of doom.
This ague fit of fear is over-blown;
An easy task it is to win our own.
Say
Speak sweetly
Men judge by the complexion of the sky
The state and inclination of the day:
So may you by my dull and heavy eye
I play the torturer
To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken:
Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke
Upon his party.
Thou hast said enough.
Beshrew thee
To DUKE OF AUMERLE
Of that sweet way I was in to despair!
What say you now? what comfort have we now?
By heaven
That bids me be of comfort any more.
Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away;
A king
That power I have
To ear the land that hath some hope to grow
To alter this
My liege
He does me double wrong
That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue.
Discharge my followers: let them hence away
Exeunt
SCENE III. Wales. Before Flint castle.
Enter
So that by this intelligence we learn
The Welshmen are dispersed
Is gone to meet the king
With some few private friends upon this coast.
The news is very fair and good
Richard not far from hence hath hid his head.
It would beseem the Lord Northumberland
To say 'King Richard:' alack the heavy day
When such a sacred king should hide his head.
Your grace mistakes; only to be brief
Left I his title out.
The time hath been
Have been so brief with you
Mistake not
Take not
Lest you mistake the heavens are o'er our heads.
I know it
Against their will. But who comes here?
Enter HENRY PERCY
Welcome
The castle royally is mann'd
Royally!
Why
Yes
Within the limits of yon lime and stone:
And with him are the Lord Aumerle
Of holy reverence; who
O
Noble lords
Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley
Into his ruin'd ears
Henry Bolingbroke
On both his knees doth kiss King Richard's hand
And sends allegiance and true faith of heart
To his most royal person
Even at his feet to lay my arms and power
And lands restored again be freely granted:
If not
And lay the summer's dust with showers of blood
Rain'd from the wounds of slaughter'd Englishmen:
The which
It is
The fresh green lap of fair King Richard's land
Go
Upon the grassy carpet of this plain.
Let's march without the noise of threatening drum
Our fair appointments may be well perused.
Methinks King Richard and myself should meet
With no less terror than the elements
Of fire and water
At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven.
Be he the fire
The rage be his
My waters; on the earth
March on
Parle without
See
From out the fiery portal of the east
To dim his glory and to stain the track
Of his bright passage to the occident.
Yet looks he like a king: behold
Controlling majesty: alack
We are amazed; and thus long have we stood
To watch the fearful bending of thy knee
Because we thought ourself thy lawful king:
And if we be
To pay their awful duty to our presence?
If we be not
That hath dismissed us from our stewardship;
For well we know
Can gripe the sacred handle of our sceptre
And though you think that all
Yet know
Armies of pestilence; and they shall strike
Your children yet unborn and unbegot
And threat the glory of my precious crown.
Tell Bolingbroke--for yond methinks he stands--
That every stride he makes upon my land
Is dangerous treason: he is come to open
The purple testament of bleeding war;
But ere the crown he looks for live in peace
Shall ill become the flower of England's face
To scarlet indignation and bedew
Her pastures' grass with faithful English blood.
The king of heaven forbid our lord the king
Should so with civil and uncivil arms
Be rush'd upon! Thy thrice noble cousin
Harry Bolingbroke doth humbly kiss thy hand;
And by the honourable tomb he swears
Than for his lineal royalties and to beg
Enfranchisement immediate on his kn ees:
Which on thy royal party granted once
To faithful service of your majesty.
This swears he
And
Northumberland
His noble cousin is right welcome hither;
And all the number of his fair demands
Shall be accomplish'd without contradiction:
With all the gracious utterance thou hast
Speak to his gentle hearing kind commends.
We do debase ourselves
To look so poorly and to speak so fair?
Shall we call back Northumberland
Defiance to the traitor
No
Till time lend friends and friends their helpful swords.
O God
On yon proud man
With words of sooth! O that I were as great
As is my grief
Or that I could forget what I have been
Swell'st thou
Northumberland comes back from Bolingbroke.
What must the king do now? must he submit?
The king shall do it: must he be deposed?
The king shall be contented: must he lose
The name of king? o' God's name
I'll give my jewels for a set of beads
And my large kingdom for a little grave
Or I'll be buried in the king's highway
May hourly trample on their sovereign's head;
For on my heart they tread now whilst I live;
And buried once
Aumerle
We'll make foul weather with despised tears;
Our sighs and they shall lodge the summer corn
Or shall we play the wantons with our woes
As thus
Within the earth; and
Two kinsmen digg'd their graves with weeping eyes.
Would not this ill do well? Well
I talk but idly
Most mighty prince
Give Richard leave to live till Richard die?
You make a leg
My lord
To speak with you; may it please you to come down.
Down
In the base court? Base court
In the base court? Come down? Down
down
For night-owls shriek where mounting larks
should sing.
Exeunt from above
What says his majesty?
Sorrow and grief of heart
Makes him speak fondly
Yet he is come.
Enter KING RICHARD and his attendants below
Stand all apart
He kneels down
My gracious lord
Fair cousin
To make the base earth proud with kissing it:
Me rather had my heart might feel your love
Than my unpleased eye see your courtesy.
Up
My gracious lord
Your own is yours
So far be mine
Well you deserve: they well deserve to have
Uncle
Tears show their love
Cousin
What you will have
For do we must what force will have us do.
Set on towards London
Yea
Then I must not say no.
Flourish. Exeunt
SCENE IV. LANGLEY. The DUKE OF YORK's garden.
Enter the QUEEN and two Ladies
What sport shall we devise here in this garden
Madam
'Twill make me think the world is full of rubs
Madam
My legs can keep no measure in delight
Therefore
Madam
Of sorrow or of joy?
Of either
Of neither
For of joy
Or if of grief
For what I have I need not to repeat;
And what I want it boots not to complain.
Madam
'Tis well that thou hast cause
But thou shouldst please me better
I could weep
And I could sing
Enter a Gardener
But stay
Let's step into the shadow of these trees.
My wretchedness unto a row of pins
Against a change; woe is forerun with woe.
QUEEN and Ladies retire
Go
Stoop with oppression of their prodigal weight:
Give some supportance to the bending twigs.
Go thou
All must be even in our government.
You thus employ'd
The noisome weeds
The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers.
Why should we in the compass of a pale
Keep law and form and due proportion
Swarming with caterpillars?
Hold thy peace:
He that hath suffer'd this disorder'd spring
Hath now himself met with the fall of leaf:
The weeds which his broad-spreading leaves did shelter
What
They are; and Bolingbroke
Hath seized the wasteful king. O
That he had not so trimm'd and dress'd his land
As we this garden! We at time of year
Do wound the bark
Had he done so to great and growing men
Their fruits of duty: superfluous branches
We lop away
Had he done so
What
Depress'd he is already
'Tis doubt he will be: letters came last night
To a dear friend of the good Duke of York's
O
Coming forward
Thou
What Eve
To make a second fall of cursed man?
Why dost thou say King Richard is deposed?
Darest thou
Pardon me
To breathe this news; yet what I say is true.
King Richard
Of Bolingbroke: their fortunes both are weigh'd:
In your lord's scale is nothing but himself
But in the balance of great Bolingbroke
Post you to London
I speak no more than every one doth know.
Nimble mischance
To serve me last
Thy sorrow in my breast. Come
What
Should grace the triumph of great Bolingbroke?
Gardener
Exeunt QUEEN and Ladies
Poor queen! so that thy state might be no worse
Here did she fall a tear; here in this place
I'll set a bank of rue
Rue
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Westminster Hall.
Enter
Call forth Bagot.
Now
What thou dost know of noble Gloucester's death
The bloody office of his timeless end.
Then set before my face the Lord Aumerle.
Cousin
My Lord Aumerle
Scorns to unsay what once it hath deliver'd.
In that dead time when Gloucester's death was plotted
As far as Calais
Amongst much other talk
The offer of an hundred thousand crowns
Than Bolingbroke's return to England;
Adding withal how blest this land would be
In this your cousin's death.
Princes and noble lords
Shall I so much dishonour my fair stars
Either I must
With the attainder of his slanderous lips.
There is my gage
In thy heart-blood
To stain the temper of my knightly sword.
Bagot
Excepting one
In all this presence that hath moved me so.
If that thy valour stand on sympathy
By that fair sun which shows me where thou stand'st
That thou wert cause of noble Gloucester's death.
If thou deny'st it twenty times
And I will turn thy falsehood to thy heart
Thou darest not
Now by my soul
Fitzwater
Aumerle
In this appeal as thou art all unjust;
And that thou art so
Of mortal breathing: seize it
An if I do not
And never brandish more revengeful steel
Over the glittering helmet of my foe!
I task the earth to the like
And spur thee on with full as many lies
As may be holloa'd in thy treacherous ear
From sun to sun: there is my honour's pawn;
Engage it to the trial
Who sets me else? by heaven
I have a thousand spirits in one breast
My Lord Fitzwater
The very time Aumerle and you did talk.
'Tis very true: you were in presence then;
And you can witness with me this is true.
As false
Surrey
Dishonourable boy!
That lie shall lie so heavy on my sword
Till thou the lie-giver and that lie do lie
In earth as quiet as thy father's skull:
In proof whereof
Engage it to the trial
How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse!
If I dare eat
As I intend to thrive in this new world
Besides
That thou
To execute the noble duke at Calais.
Some honest Christian trust me with a gage
That Norfolk lies: here do I throw down this
These differences shall all rest under gage
Till Norfolk be repeal'd: repeal'd he shall be
To all his lands and signories: when he's return'd
That honourable day shall ne'er be seen.
Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought
For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field
Against black pagans
And toil'd with works of war
To Italy; and there at Venice gave
His body to that pleasant country's earth
Why
As surely as I live
Sweet peace conduct his sweet soul to the bosom
Of good old Abraham! Lords appellants
Till we assign you to your days of trial.
Enter DUKE OF YORK
Great Duke of Lancaster
From plume-pluck'd Richard; who with willing soul
Adopts thee heir
To the possession of thy royal hand:
Ascend his throne
And long live Henry
In God's name
Marry. God forbid!
Worst in this royal presence may I speak
Would God that any in this noble presence
Were enough noble to be upright judge
Of noble Richard! then true noblesse would
Learn him forbearance from so foul a wrong.
What subject can give sentence on his king?
And who sits here that is not Richard's subject?
Thieves are not judged but they are by to hear
And shall the figure of God's majesty
Should show so heinous
I speak to subjects
My Lord of Hereford here
And if you crown him
The blood of English shall manure the ground
Peace shall go sleep with Turks and infidels
Shall kin with kin and kind with kind confound;
Disorder
Shall here inhabit
The field of Golgotha and dead men's skulls.
O
That ever fell upon this cursed earth.
Prevent it
Well have you argued
My Lord of Westminster
To keep him safely till his day of trial.
May it please you
Fetch hither Richard
He may surrender; so we shall proceed
Without suspicion.
I will be his conduct.
Exit
Lords
Little are we beholding to your love
Re-enter DUKE OF YORK
Alack
Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd
To insinuate
Give sorrow leave awhile to tutor me
To this submission. Yet I well remember
The favours of these men: were they not mine?
Did they not sometime cry
So Judas did to Christ: but he
God save the king! Will no man say amen?
Am I both priest and clerk? well then
God save the king! although I be not he;
And yet
To do what service am I sent for hither?
To do that office of thine own good will
Which tired majesty did make thee offer
To Henry Bolingbroke.
Give me the crown. Here
Here cousin:
On this side my hand
Now is this golden crown like a deep well
That owes two buckets
That bucket down and full of tears am I
I thought you had been willing to resign.
My crown I am; but still my griefs are mine:
You may my glories and my state depose
Part of your cares you give me with your crown.
Your cares set up do not pluck my cares down.
My care is loss of care
Your care is gain of care
The cares I give I have
They tend the crown
Are you contented to resign the crown?
Ay
Therefore no no
Now mark me
I give this heavy weight from off my head
And this unwieldy sceptre from my hand
With mine own tears I wash away my balm
All pomp and majesty I do forswear;
My manors
My acts
God pardon all oaths that are broke to me!
God keep all vows unbroke that swear to thee!
Make me
Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit
God save King Harry
What more remains?
No more
These accusations and these grievous crimes
Committed by your person and your followers
Against the state and profit of this land;
That
May deem that you are worthily deposed.
Must I do so? and must I ravel out
My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland
To read a lecture of them? If thou wouldst
And cracking the strong warrant of an oath
Nay
Showing an outward pity; yet you Pilates
Have here deliver'd me to my sour cross
My lord
Mine eyes are full of tears
And yet salt water blinds them not so much
But they can see a sort of traitors here.
Nay
For I have given here my soul's consent
To undeck the pompous body of a king;
Made glory base and sovereignty a slave
My lord
No lord of thine
O that I were a mockery king of snow
Good king
Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.
Exit an attendant
Read o'er this paper while the glass doth come.
Fiend
Urge it no more
The commons will not then be satisfied.
They shall be satisfied: I'll read enough
Where all my sins are writ
Re-enter Attendant
Give me the glass
No deeper wrinkles yet? hath sorrow struck
So many blows upon this face of mine
That every day under his household roof
Did keep ten thousand men? was this the face
That
Was this the face that faced so many follies
A brittle glory shineth in this face:
As brittle as the glory is the face;
Dashes the glass against the ground
For there it is
Mark
The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd
The shadow or your face.
Say that again.
The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let's see:
'Tis very true
And these external manners of laments
Are merely shadows to the unseen grief
That swells with silence in the tortured soul;
There lies the substance: and I thank thee
Me cause to wail but teachest me the way
How to lament the cause. I'll beg one boon
Shall I obtain it?
Name it
'Fair cousin'? I am greater than a king:
For when I was a king
Were then but subjects; being now a subject
Being so great
Yet ask.
And shall I have?
You shall.
Then give me leave to go.
Whither?
Whither you will
Go
O
Exeunt KING RICHARD II
On Wednesday next we solemnly set down
Our coronation: lords
Exeunt all except the BISHOP OF CARLISLE
A woeful pageant have we here beheld.
The woe's to come; the children yet unborn.
Shall feel this day as sharp to them as thorn.
You holy clergymen
To rid the realm of this pernicious blot?
My lord
To bury mine intents
Whatever I shall happen to devise.
I see your brows are full of discontent
Come home with me to supper; and I'll lay
A plot shall show us all a merry day.
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. London. A street leading to the Tower.
Enter QUEEN and Ladies
This way the king will come; this is the way
To Julius Caesar's ill-erected tower
Is doom'd a prisoner by proud Bolingbroke:
Here let us rest
Have any resting for her true king's queen.
Enter KING RICHARD II and Guard
But soft
Ah
Join not with grief
From which awaked
Shows us but this: I am sworn brother
Will keep a league till death. Hie thee to France
And cloister thee in some religious house:
Our holy lives must win a new world's crown
What
Transform'd and weaken'd? hath Bolingbroke deposed
Thine intellect? hath he been in thy heart?
The lion dying thrusteth forth his paw
To be o'erpower'd; and wilt thou
A king of beasts
Good sometime queen
Think I am dead and that even here thou takest
In winter's tedious nights sit by the fire
With good old folks and let them tell thee tales
Of woeful ages long ago betid;
And ere thou bid good night
And send the hearers weeping to their beds:
For why
The heavy accent of thy moving tongue
And in compassion weep the fire out;
And some will mourn in ashes
Enter NORTHUMBERLAND and others
My lord
You must to Pomfret
And
With all swift speed you must away to France.
Northumberland
The mounting Bolingbroke ascends my throne
More than it is ere foul sin gathering head
Shalt break into corruption: thou shalt think
And he shall think that thou
To plant unrightful kings
To pluck him headlong from the usurped throne.
The love of wicked men converts to fear;
That fear to hate
To worthy danger and deserved death.
My guilt be on my head
Take leave and part; for you must part forthwith.
Doubly divorced! Bad men
A twofold marriage
Let me unkiss the oath 'twixt thee and me;
And yet not so
Part us
My wife to France: from whence
And must we be divided? must we part?
Ay
Banish us both and send the king with me.
That were some love but little policy.
Then whither he goes
So two
Weep thou for me in France
Better far off than near
Go
So longest way shall have the longest moans.
Twice for one step I'll groan
Come
One kiss shall stop our mouths
Thus give I mine
Give me mine own again; 'twere no good part
To take on me to keep and kill thy heart.
So
We make woe wanton with this fond delay:
Once more
Exeunt
SCENE II. The DUKE OF YORK's palace.
Enter DUKE OF YORK and DUCHESS OF YORK
My lord
Where did I leave?
At that sad stop
Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.
Then
Which his aspiring rider seem'd to know
You would have thought the very windows spake
Through casements darted their desiring eyes
Upon his visage
With painted imagery had said at once
'Jesu preserve thee! welcome
Whilst he
And thus still doing
Alack
As in a theatre
Even so
Did scowl on gentle Richard; no man cried 'God save him!'
No joyful tongue gave him his welcome home:
But dust was thrown upon his sacred head:
Which with such gentle sorrow he shook off
The hearts of men
And barbarism itself have pitied him.
But heaven hath a hand in these events
To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now
Here comes my son Aumerle.
Aumerle that was;
But that is lost for being Richard's friend
I am in parliament pledge for his truth
And lasting fealty to the new-made king.
Enter DUKE OF AUMERLE
Welcome
That strew the green lap of the new come spring?
Madam
God knows I had as lief be none as one.
Well
What news from Oxford? hold those justs and triumphs?
For aught I know
You will be there
If God prevent not
What seal is that
Yea
My lord
No matter
I will be satisfied; let me see the writing.
I do beseech your grace to pardon me:
It is a matter of small consequence
Which for some reasons
I fear
What should you fear?
'Tis nothing but some bond
For gay apparel 'gainst the triumph day.
Bound to himself! what doth he with a bond
That he is bound to? Wife
Boy
I do beseech you
I will be satisfied; let me see it
He plucks it out of his bosom and reads it
Treason! foul treason! Villain! traitor! slave!
What is the matter
Ho! who is within there?
Enter a Servant
Saddle my horse.
God for his mercy
Why
Give me my boots
Now
What is the matter?
Peace
I will not peace. What is the matter
Good mother
Than my poor life must answer.
Thy life answer!
Bring me my boots: I will unto the king.
Re-enter Servant with boots
Strike him
Hence
Give me my boots
Why
Wilt thou not hide the trespass of thine own?
Have we more sons? or are we like to have?
Is not my teeming date drunk up with time?
And wilt thou pluck my fair son from mine age
Is he not like thee? is he not thine own?
Thou fond mad woman
A dozen of them here have ta'en the sacrament
He shall be none;
We'll keep him here: then what is that to him?
Away
Hadst thou groan'd for him
As I have done
But now I know thy mind; thou dost suspect
That I have been disloyal to thy bed
Sweet York
He is as like thee as a man may be
Make way
Exit
After
Spur post
I'll not be long behind; though I be old
And never will I rise up from the ground
Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee. Away
Exeunt
SCENE III. A royal palace.
Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Can no man tell me of my unthrifty son?
'Tis full three months since I did see him last;
If any plague hang over us
I would to God
Inquire at London
Which he
So dissolute a crew.
My lord
And what said the gallant?
His answer was
He would unhorse the lustiest challenger.
As dissolute as desperate; yet through both
I see some sparks of better hope
May happily bring forth. But who comes here?
Enter DUKE OF AUMERLE
Where is the king?
What means our cousin
So wildly?
God save your grace! I do beseech your majesty
Withdraw yourselves
Exeunt HENRY PERCY and Lords
What is the matter with our cousin now?
For ever may my knees grow to the earth
Unless a pardon ere I rise or speak.
Intended or committed was this fault?
If on the first
Then give me leave that I may turn the key
Have thy desire.
[Within]  My liege
Thou hast a traitor in thy presence there.
Villain
Drawing
Stay thy revengeful hand; thou hast no cause to fear.
[Within]  Open the door
Shall I for love speak treason to thy face?
Open the door
Enter DUKE OF YORK
What is the matter
Recover breath; tell us how near is danger
Peruse this writing here
The treason that my haste forbids me show.
Remember
I do repent me; read not my name there
My heart is not confederate with my hand.
It was
I tore it from the traitor's bosom
Fear
Forget to pity him
A serpent that will sting thee to the heart.
O heinous
O loyal father of a treacherous son!
Thou sheer
Hath held his current and defiled himself!
Thy overflow of good converts to bad
This deadly blot in thy digressing son.
So shall my virtue be his vice's bawd;
And he shall spend mine honour with his shame
Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies
Thou kill'st me in his life; giving him breath
[Within]  What ho
What shrill-voiced suppliant makes this eager cry?
A woman
Speak with me
A beggar begs that never begg'd before.
Our scene is alter'd from a serious thing
My dangerous cousin
I know she is come to pray for your foul sin.
If thou do pardon
This fester'd joint cut off
This let alone will all the rest confound.
Enter DUCHESS OF YORK
O king
Love loving not itself none other can.
Thou frantic woman
Shall thy old dugs once more a traitor rear?
Sweet York
Kneels
Rise up
Not yet
For ever will I walk upon my knees
Unto my mother's prayers I bend my knee.
Against them both my true joints bended be.
Ill mayst thou thrive
Pleads he in earnest? look upon his face;
His eyes do drop no tears
His words come from his mouth
He prays but faintly and would be denied;
We pray with heart and soul and all beside:
His weary joints would gladly rise
Our knees shall kneel till to the ground they grow:
His prayers are full of false hypocrisy;
Ours of true zeal and deep integrity.
Our prayers do out-pray his; then let them have
That mercy which true prayer ought to have.
Good aunt
Nay
Say
And if I were thy nurse
I never long'd to hear a word till now;
Say 'pardon
The word is short
No word like 'pardon' for kings' mouths so meet.
Speak it in French
Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy?
Ah
Speak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land;
The chopping French we do not understand.
Thine eye begins to speak; set thy tongue there;
Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear;
That hearing how our plaints and prayers do pierce
Good aunt
I do not sue to stand;
Pardon is all the suit I have in hand.
I pardon him
O happy vantage of a kneeling knee!
Yet am I sick for fear: speak it again;
Twice saying 'pardon' doth not pardon twain
With all my heart
I pardon him.
A god on earth thou art.
But for our trusty brother-in-law and the abbot
Good uncle
To Oxford
They shall not live within this world
Uncle
Your mother well hath pray'd
Come
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The same.
Enter EXTON and Servant
Didst thou not mark the king
Was it not so?
These were his very words.
'Have I no friend?' quoth he: he spake it twice
He did.
And speaking it
That would divorce this terror from my heart;'
Meaning the king at Pomfret. Come
I am the king's friend
Exeunt
SCENE V. Pomfret castle.
Enter KING RICHARD
I have been studying how I may compare
This prison where I live unto the world:
And for because the world is populous
And here is not a creature but myself
My brain I'll prove the female to my soul
A generation of still-breeding thoughts
With scruples and do set the word itself
Against the word:
As thus
To thread the postern of a small needle's eye.'
Thoughts tending to ambition
Unlikely wonders; how these vain weak nails
May tear a passage through the flinty ribs
Of this hard world
Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves
That they are not the first of fortune's slaves
Who sitting in the stocks refuge their shame
And in this thought they find a kind of ease
Of such as have before endured the like.
Thus play I in one person many people
Then treasons make me wish myself a beggar
Persuades me I was better when a king;
Then am I king'd again: and by and by
Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke
With nothing shall be pleased
With being nothing. Music do I hear?
Music
Ha
So is it in the music of men's lives.
And here have I the daintiness of ear
To cheque time broke in a disorder'd string;
But for the concord of my state and time
Had not an ear to hear my true time broke.
I wasted time
For now hath time made me his numbering clock:
My thoughts are minutes; and with sighs they jar
Their watches on unto mine eyes
Now sir
Are clamorous groans
Show minutes
Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud joy
This music mads me; let it sound no more;
For though it have holp madmen to their wits
Yet blessing on his heart that gives it me!
For 'tis a sign of love; and love to Richard
Is a strange brooch in this all-hating world.
Enter a Groom of the Stable
Hail
Thanks
The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear.
What art thou? and how comest thou hither
That brings me food to make misfortune live?
I was a poor groom of thy stable
To look upon my sometimes royal master's face.
O
In London streets
Rode he on Barbary? Tell me
So proudly as if he disdain'd the ground.
So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back!
That jade hath eat bread from my royal hand;
This hand hath made him proud with clapping him.
Would he not stumble? would he not fall down
Of that proud man that did usurp his back?
Forgiveness
And yet I bear a burthen like an ass
Enter Keeper
Fellow
If thou love me
What my tongue dares not
Exit
My lord
Taste of it first
My lord
lately came from the king
The devil take Henry of Lancaster and thee!
Patience is stale
Beats the keeper
Help
Enter EXTON and Servants
How now! what means death in this rude assault?
Villain
Snatching an axe from a Servant and killing him
Go thou
He kills another. Then Exton strikes him down
That hand shall burn in never-quenching fire
That staggers thus my person. Exton
Hath with the king's blood stain'd the king's own land.
Mount
Whilst my gross flesh sinks downward
Dies
As full of valour as of royal blood:
Both have I spill'd; O would the deed were good!
For now the devil
This dead king to the living king I'll bear
Take hence the rest
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Windsor castle.
Flourish. Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Kind uncle York
Is that the rebels have consumed with fire
Our town of Cicester in Gloucestershire;
But whether they be ta'en or slain we hear not.
Enter NORTHUMBERLAND
Welcome
First
The next news is
The heads of Oxford
The manner of their taking may appear
At large discoursed in this paper here.
We thank thee
And to thy worth will add right worthy gains.
Enter LORD FITZWATER
My lord
The heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely
That sought at Oxford thy dire overthrow.
Thy pains
Right noble is thy merit
Enter HENRY PERCY
The grand conspirator
Hath yielded up his body to the grave;
But here is Carlisle living
Thy kingly doom and sentence of his pride.
Carlisle
Choose out some secret place
So as thou livest in peace
For though mine enemy thou hast ever been
Enter EXTON
Great king
Thy buried fear: herein all breathless lies
The mightiest of thy greatest enemies
Exton
A deed of slander with thy fatal hand
Upon my head and all this famous land.
From your own mouth
They love not poison that do poison need
The guilt of conscience take thou for thy labour
With Cain go wander through shades of night
Lords
Come
I'll make a voyage to the Holy Land
March sadly after; grace my mournings here;
In weeping after this untimely bier.
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. London. A street.
Enter GLOUCESTER
Now is the winter of our discontent
Made glorious summer by this sun of York;
And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house
In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths;
Our bruised arms hung up for monuments;
Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings
Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;
And now
To fright the souls of fearful adversaries
To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
But I
I
To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;
I
Into this breathing world
That dogs bark at me as I halt by them;
Why
And descant on mine own deformity:
And therefore
And hate the idle pleasures of these days.
Plots have I laid
In deadly hate the one against the other:
And if King Edward be as true and just
As I am subtle
Of Edward's heirs the murderer shall be.
Dive
Clarence comes.
Enter CLARENCE
Brother
That waits upon your grace?
His majesty
Tendering my person's safety
This conduct to convey me to the Tower.
Upon what cause?
Because my name is George.
Alack
He should
O
That you shall be new-christen'd in the Tower.
But what's the matter
Yea
As yet I do not: but
And from the cross-row plucks the letter G.
And says a wizard told him that by G
His issue disinherited should be;
And
These
Have moved his highness to commit me now.
Why
'Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower:
My Lady Grey his wife
That tempers him to this extremity.
Was it not she and that good man of worship
We are not safe
By heaven
But the queen's kindred and night-walking heralds
That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.
Heard ye not what an humble suppliant
Lord hastings was to her for his delivery?
Humbly complaining to her deity
Got my lord chamberlain his liberty.
I'll tell you what; I think it is our way
The jealous o'erworn widow and herself
Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.
I beseech your graces both to pardon me;
His majesty hath straitly given in charge
That no man shall have private conference
Even so; an't please your worship
We speak no treason
Is wise and virtuous
Well struck in years
We say that Shore's wife hath a pretty foot
And that the queen's kindred are made gentle-folks:
How say you sir? Can you deny all this?
With this
Naught to do with mistress Shore! I tell thee
What one
Her husband
I beseech your grace to pardon me
Forbear your conference with the noble duke.
We know thy charge
We are the queen's abjects
Brother
And whatsoever you will employ me in
Meantime
Touches me deeper than you can imagine.
I know it pleaseth neither of us well.
Well
Meantime
I must perforce. Farewell.
Exeunt CLARENCE
Go
Simple
But who comes here? the new-deliver'd Hastings?
Enter HASTINGS
Good time of day unto my gracious lord!
As much unto my good lord chamberlain!
Well are you welcome to the open air.
How hath your lordship brook'd imprisonment?
With patience
But I shall live
That were the cause of my imprisonment.
No doubt
For they that were your enemies are his
More pity that the eagle should be mew'd
What news abroad?
No news so bad abroad as this at home;
The King is sickly
Now
O
'Tis very grievous to be thought upon.
What
He is.
Go you before
Exit HASTINGS
He cannot live
Till George be pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.
I'll in
And
Which done
For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter.
What though I kill'd her husband and her father?
The readiest way to make the wench amends
Is to become her husband and her father:
The which will I; not all so much for love
As for another secret close intent
But yet I run before my horse to market:
Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns:
When they are gone
Exit
SCENE II. The same. Another street.
Enter the corpse of KING HENRY the Sixth
Set down
The untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.
Poor key-cold figure of a holy king!
Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster!
Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood!
Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost
Lo
Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes!
Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it!
Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence!
More direful hap betide that hated wretch
If ever he have child
May fright the hopeful mother at the view;
And that be heir to his unhappiness!
If ever he have wife
A miserable by the death of him
As I am made by my poor lord and thee!
Come
And still
Enter GLOUCESTER
Stay
What black magician conjures up this fiend
Villains
My lord
Unmanner'd dog! stand thou
Advance thy halbert higher than my breast
What
Alas
Avaunt
Thou hadst but power over his mortal body
Sweet saint
Foul devil
For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell
If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds
O
Open their congeal'd mouths and bleed afresh!
Blush
For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood
From cold and empty veins
Thy deed
O God
O earth
Either heaven with lightning strike the
murderer dead
Which his hell-govern'd arm hath butchered!
Lady
Villain
No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.
But I know none
O wonderful
More wonderful
Vouchsafe
Vouchsafe
Fairer than tongue can name thee
Some patient leisure to excuse myself.
Fouler than heart can think thee
No excuse current
By such despair
And
For doing worthy vengeance on thyself
Say that I slew them not?
Why
But dead they are
I did not kill your husband.
Why
Nay
In thy foul throat thou liest: Queen Margaret saw
Thy murderous falchion smoking in his blood;
The which thou once didst bend against her breast
I was provoked by her slanderous tongue
Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind.
Which never dreamt on aught but butcheries:
Didst thou not kill this king?
I grant ye.
Dost grant me
Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed!
O
The fitter for the King of heaven
He is in heaven
Let him thank me
For he was fitter for that place than earth.
And thou unfit for any place but hell.
Yes
Some dungeon.
Your bed-chamber.
I'll rest betide the chamber where thou liest!
So will it
I hope so.
I know so. But
Of these Plantagenets
Thou art the cause
Your beauty was the cause of that effect;
Your beauty: which did haunt me in my sleep
To undertake the death of all the world
If I thought that
These eyes could never endure sweet beauty's wreck;
You should not blemish it
As all the world is cheered by the sun
Black night o'ershade thy day
Curse not thyself
I would I were
It is a quarrel most unnatural
It is a quarrel just and reasonable
He that bereft thee
His better doth not breathe upon the earth.
He lives that loves thee better than he could.
Name him.
Plantagenet.
Why
The selfsame name
Where is he?
Here.
She spitteth at him
Why dost thou spit at me?
Would it were mortal poison
Never came poison from so sweet a place.
Never hung poison on a fouler toad.
Out of my sight! thou dost infect my eyes.
Thine eyes
Would they were basilisks
I would they were
For now they kill me with a living death.
Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears
These eyes that never shed remorseful tear
When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him;
Nor when thy warlike father
Like trees bedash'd with rain: in that sad time
My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear;
And what these sorrows could not thence exhale
I never sued to friend nor enemy;
My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word;
But now thy beauty is proposed my fee
She looks scornfully at him
Teach not thy lips such scorn
For kissing
If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive
Which if thou please to hide in this true bosom.
And let the soul forth that adoreth thee
He lays his breast open: she offers at it with his sword
Nay
Nay
Here she lets fall the sword
Take up the sword again
Arise
Then bid me kill myself
I have already.
Tush
Speak it again
To both their deaths thou shalt be accessary.
I would I knew thy heart.
'Tis figured in my tongue.
I fear me both are false.
Then never man was true.
Well
Say
That shall you know hereafter.
But shall I live in hope?
All men
Vouchsafe to wear this ring.
To take is not to give.
Look
Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart;
Wear both of them
And if thy poor devoted suppliant may
But beg one favour at thy gracious hand
What is it?
That it would please thee leave these sad designs
To him that hath more cause to be a mourner
Where
At Chertsey monastery this noble king
For divers unknown reasons. I beseech you
With all my heart; and much it joys me too
Tressel and Berkeley
Bid me farewell.
'Tis more than you deserve;
But since you teach me how to flatter you
Exeunt LADY ANNE
Sirs
Towards Chertsey
No
Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER
Was ever woman in this humour woo'd?
Was ever woman in this humour won?
I'll have her; but I will not keep her long.
What! I
Having God
against me
Ha!
Hath she forgot already that brave prince
A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman
And will she yet debase her eyes on me
On me
On me
My dukedom to a beggarly denier
Upon my life
I'll be at charges for a looking-glass
Since I am crept in favour with myself
But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave;
And then return lamenting to my love.
Shine out
Exit
SCENE III. The palace.
Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH
Have patience
Will soon recover his accustom'd health.
In that you brook it in
Therefore
If he were dead
No other harm but loss of such a lord.
The loss of such a lord includes all harm.
The heavens have bless'd you with a goodly son
Oh
Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester
Is it concluded that he shall be protector?
It is determined
But so it must be
Enter BUCKINGHAM and DERBY
Here come the lords of Buckingham and Derby.
Good time of day unto your royal grace!
God make your majesty joyful as you have been!
The Countess Richmond
To your good prayers will scarcely say amen.
Yet
I hate not you for her proud arrogance.
I do beseech you
The envious slanders of her false accusers;
Or
From wayward sickness
Saw you the king to-day
But now the Duke of Buckingham and I
Are come from visiting his majesty.
What likelihood of his amendment
Madam
God grant him health! Did you confer with him?
Madam
Betwixt the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers
And sent to warn them to his royal presence.
Would all were well! but that will never be
I fear our happiness is at the highest.
Enter GLOUCESTER
They do me wrong
Who are they that complain unto the king
By holy Paul
That fill his ears with such dissentious rumours.
Because I cannot flatter and speak fair
Cannot a plain man live and think no harm
By silken
To whom in all this presence speaks your grace?
To thee
When have I injured thee? when done thee wrong?
Or thee? or thee? or any of your faction?
A plague upon you all! His royal person
Whom God preserve better than you would wish!--
Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing-while
Brother of Gloucester
The king
Aiming
Against my kindred
The ground of your ill-will
I cannot tell: the world is grown so bad
Since every Jack became a gentleman
There's many a gentle person made a Jack.
Come
Gloucester;
You envy my advancement and my friends':
God grant we never may have need of you!
Meantime
Your brother is imprison'd by your means
Held in contempt; whilst many fair promotions
Are daily given to ennoble those
That scarce
By Him that raised me to this careful height
From that contented hap which I enjoy'd
Against the Duke of Clarence
An earnest advocate to plead for him.
My lord
You may deny that you were not the cause
Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.
She may
She may
She may do more
She may help you to many fair preferments
What may she not? She may
What
What
I wis your grandam had a worser match.
My Lord of Gloucester
Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs:
By heaven
With those gross taunts I often have endured.
I had rather be a country servant-maid
Than a great queen
Enter QUEEN MARGARET
Small joy have I in being England's queen.
And lessen'd be that small
Thy honour
What! threat you me with telling of the king?
Tell him
I will avouch in presence of the king:
I dare adventure to be sent to the Tower.
'Tis time to speak; my pains are quite forgot.
Out
Thou slewest my husband Henry in the Tower
Ere you were queen
A weeder-out of his proud adversaries
To royalize his blood I spilt mine own.
Yea
In all which time you and your husband Grey
Were factious for the house of Lancaster;
And
In Margaret's battle at Saint Alban's slain?
Let me put in your minds
Withal
A murderous villain
Poor Clarence did forsake his father
Yea
Which God revenge!
To fight on Edward's party for the crown;
And for his meed
I would to God my heart were flint
Or Edward's soft and pitiful
I am too childish-foolish for this world.
Hie thee to hell for shame
My Lord of Gloucester
Which here you urge to prove us enemies
So should we you
If I should be! I had rather be a pedlar:
Far be it from my heart
As little joy
You should enjoy
That I enjoy
A little joy enjoys the queen thereof;
For I am she
I can no longer hold me patient.
Advancing
Hear me
In sharing that which you have pill'd from me!
Which of you trembles not that looks on me?
If not
O gentle villain
Foul wrinkled witch
But repetition of what thou hast marr'd;
That will I make before I let thee go.
Wert thou not banished on pain of death?
I was; but I do find more pain in banishment
Than death can yield me here by my abode.
A husband and a son thou owest to me;
And thou a kingdom; all of you allegiance:
The sorrow that I have
The curse my noble father laid on thee
And with thy scorns drew'st rivers from his eyes
Steep'd in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland--
His curses
Denounced against thee
And God
So just is God
O
Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.
No man but prophesied revenge for it.
Northumberland
What were you snarling all before I came

That Henry's death
Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?
Why
If not by war
Edward thy son
Thyself a queen

Was stabb'd with bloody daggers: God

If heaven have any grievous plague in store
Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee
On thee
The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul!
Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou livest
No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine
Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils!
Thou elvish-mark'd

The slave of nature and the son of hell!

Margaret.
Richard!
Ha!

Why

Fool

False-boding woman
Foul shame upon you! you have all moved mine.
Were you well served
To serve me well
O

Peace

O
What 'twere to lose it
They that stand high have many blasts to shake them;
And if they fall
Good counsel
It toucheth you
Yea
And turns the sun to shade; alas! alas!

Hath in eternal darkness folded up.
Your aery buildeth in our aery's nest.
O God
As it was won with blood
Have done! for shame
Urge neither charity nor shame to me:
Uncharitably with me have you dealt
My charity is outrage
And in that shame still live my sorrow's rage.
Have done
O princely Buckingham I'll kiss thy hand
Now fair befal thee and thy noble house!
Thy garments are not spotted with our blood
Nor no one here; for curses never pass
The lips of those that breathe them in the air.
I'll not believe but they ascend the sky

My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.
And so doth mine: I muse why she's at liberty.
I cannot blame her: by God's holy mother
My part thereof that I have done to her.
I never did her any
But you have all the vantage of her wrong.
I was too hot to do somebody good

A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion

Tush!
Fear not

Your eyes drop millstones
I like you

SCENE IV. London. The Tower.
Enter CLARENCE and BRAKENBURY
Why looks your grace so heavily today?
O
What was your dream? I long to hear you tell it.
Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower
And
Who from my cabin tempted me to walk
Upon the hatches: thence we looked toward England
That had befall'n us. As we paced along
Upon the giddy footing of the hatches
Lord
What dreadful noise of waters in mine ears!
What ugly sights of death within mine eyes!
Methought I saw a thousand fearful wrecks;
Ten thousand men that fishes gnaw'd upon;
Wedges of gold
Some lay in dead men's skulls; and
Where eyes did once inhabit
Had you such leisure in the time of death
To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?
Methought I had; and often did I strive
To yield the ghost: but still the envious flood
Kept in my soul
To seek the empty
But smother'd it within my panting bulk
Awaked you not with this sore agony?
O
O
The first that there did greet my stranger soul
Who cried aloud
Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?'
And so he vanish'd: then came wandering by
A shadow like an angel
Dabbled in blood; and he squeak'd out aloud
Seize on him
With that
Environ'd me about
Such hideous cries
I trembling waked
Could not believe but that I was in hell
No marvel
I promise
O Brakenbury
O God! if my deep prayers cannot appease thee
I pray thee
My soul is heavy
I will
CLARENCE sleeps
Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours
Princes have but their tides for their glories
And
So that

Where is thy conscience now?
In the Duke of Gloucester's purse.
So when he opens his purse to give us our reward
Let it go; there's few or none will entertain it.
How if it come to thee again?
I'll not meddle with it: it is a dangerous thing: it
makes a man a coward: a man cannot steal
accuseth him; he cannot swear
he cannot lie with his neighbour's wife
detects him: 'tis a blushing shamefast spirit that
mutinies in a man's bosom; it fills one full of
obstacles: it made me once restore a purse of gold
that I found; it beggars any man that keeps it: it
is turned out of all towns and cities for a
dangerous thing; and every man that means to live
well endeavours to trust to himself and to live
without it.

not to kill the duke.

No

You shall have wine enough

Ay

I shall be reconciled to him again.
Never

What lawful quest have given their verdict up
Unto the frowning judge? or who pronounced
The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death?
Before I be convict by course of law
I charge you
By Christ's dear blood shed for our grievous sins
The deed you undertake is damnable.
What we will do
And he that hath commanded is the king.
Erroneous vassal! the great King of kings
Hath in the tables of his law commanded
That thou shalt do no murder: and wilt thou
Take heed; for he holds vengeance in his hands
And that same vengeance doth he hurl on thee
Thou didst receive the holy sacrament
And

Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.
How canst thou urge God's dreadful law to us

For Edward

O
