ACT II
SCENE I. London. The palace.
Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV sick
Why
You peers
I every day expect an embassage
From my Redeemer to redeem me hence;
And now in peace my soul shall part to heaven
Rivers and Hastings
Dissemble not your hatred
By heaven
And with my hand I seal my true heart's love.
So thrive I
Take heed you dally not before your king;
Lest he that is the supreme King of kings
Confound your hidden falsehood
Either of you to be the other's end.
So prosper I
And I
Madam
You have been factious one against the other
And what you do
Here
Our former hatred
Dorset
This interchange of love
And so swear I
They embrace
Now
With thy embracements to my wife's allies
Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate
On you or yours
but with all duteous love
Doth cherish you and yours
With hate in those where I expect most love!
When I have most need to employ a friend
Deep
A pleasing cordial
There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here
And
Enter GLOUCESTER
Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen:
And
Happy
Brother
Made peace enmity
A blessed labour
Amongst this princely heap
If I unwittingly
By any in this presence
To reconcile me to his friendly peace:
'Tis death to me to be at enmity;
I hate it
First
Of you
Of you
That without desert have frown'd on me;
Dukes
I do not know that Englishman alive
With whom my soul is any jot at odds
More than the infant that is born to-night
I thank my God for my humility.
A holy day shall this be kept hereafter:
I would to God all strifes were well compounded.
My sovereign liege
To take our brother Clarence to your grace.
Why
To be so bouted in this royal presence?
Who knows not that the noble duke is dead?
They all start
You do him injury to scorn his corse.
Who knows not he is dead! who knows he is?
All seeing heaven
Look I so pale
Ay
But his red colour hath forsook his cheeks.
Is Clarence dead? the order was reversed.
But he
Some tardy cripple bore the countermand
God grant that some
Enter DERBY
A boon
I pray thee
I will not rise
Then speak at once what is it thou demand'st.
The forfeit
Who slew to-day a righteous gentleman
Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolk.
Have a tongue to doom my brother's death
My brother slew no man; his fault was thought
Who sued to me for him? who
Who spake of brotherhood? who spake of love?
Who told me how the poor soul did forsake
The mighty Warwick
Who told me
When Oxford had me down
Who told me
Frozen almost to death
Even in his own garments
All this from my remembrance brutish wrath
Sinfully pluck'd
Had so much grace to put it in my mind.
But when your carters or your waiting-vassals
Have done a drunken slaughter
The precious image of our dear Redeemer
And I unjustly too
But for my brother not a man would speak
For him
Have been beholding to him in his life;
Yet none of you would once plead for his life.
O God
On me
Come
Oh
Exeunt some with KING EDWARD IV and QUEEN MARGARET
This is the fruit of rashness! Mark'd you not
How that the guilty kindred of the queen
Look'd pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?
O
God will revenge it. But come
We wait upon your grace.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The palace.
Enter the DUCHESS OF YORK
Tell me
No
Why do you wring your hands
Why do you look on us
If that our noble father be alive?
My pretty cousins
I do lament the sickness of the king.
As loath to lose him
It were lost sorrow to wail one that's lost.
Then
The king my uncle is to blame for this:
God will revenge it; whom I will importune
With daily prayers all to that effect.
And so will I.
Peace
Incapable and shallow innocents
Grandam
Told me
And when my uncle told me so
Bade me rely on him as on my father
Oh
He is my son; yea
Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.
Think you my uncle did dissemble
Ay
I cannot think it. Hark! what noise is this?
Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH
Oh
I'll join with black despair against my soul
What means this scene of rude impatience?
To make an act of tragic violence:
Edward
Why grow the branches now the root is wither'd?
Why wither not the leaves the sap being gone?
If you will live
Or
To his new kingdom of perpetual rest.
Ah
As I had title in thy noble husband!
I have bewept a worthy husband's death
But now two mirrors of his princely semblance
Are crack'd in pieces by malignant death
Thou art a widow; yet thou art a mother
But death hath snatch'd my husband from mine arms
Good aunt
How can we aid you with our kindred tears?
Our fatherless distress was left unmoan'd;
Your widow-dolour likewise be unwept!
Give me no help in lamentation;
I am not barren to bring forth complaints
All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes
Oh for my husband
Oh for our father
Alas for both
What stay had I but Edward? and he's gone.
What stay had we but Clarence? and he's gone.
What stays had I but they? and they are gone.
Was never widow had so dear a loss!
Were never orphans had so dear a loss!
Was never mother had so dear a loss!
Alas
Their woes are parcell'd
She for an Edward weeps
I for a Clarence weep
These babes for Clarence weep and so do I;
I for an Edward weep
Alas
Comfort
That you take with unthankfulness
In common worldly things
Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;
Much more to be thus opposite with heaven
Madam
Let him be crown'd; in him your comfort lives:
Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward's grave
Enter GLOUCESTER
Madam
To wail the dimming of our shining star;
But none can cure their harms by wailing them.
Madam
I did not see your grace: humbly on my knee
I crave your blessing.
God bless thee; and put meekness in thy mind
[Aside]  Amen; and make me die a good old man!
That is the butt-end of a mother's blessing:
I marvel why her grace did leave it out.
You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers
Though we have spent our harvest of this king
The broken rancour of your high-swoln hearts
Me seemeth good
Hither to London
Why with some little train
Marry
By how much the estate is green and yet ungovern'd:
Where every horse bears his commanding rein
I hope the king made peace with all of us
And the compact is firm and true in me.
And so in me; and so
Yet
To no apparent likelihood of breach
Therefore I say with noble Buckingham
And so say I.
Then be it so; and go we to determine
Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.
Madam
To give your censures in this weighty business?
With all our harts.
Exeunt all but BUCKINGHAM and GLOUCESTER
My lord
For
My other self
Towards Ludlow then
Exeunt
SCENE III. London. A street.
Enter two Citizens meeting
Neighbour
I promise you
Hear you the news abroad?
Ay
Bad news
I fear
Enter another Citizen
Neighbours
Give you good morrow
Doth this news hold of good King Edward's death?
Ay
Then
No
Woe to the land that's govern'd by a child!
In him there is a hope of government
So stood the state when Henry the Sixth
Was crown'd in Paris but at nine months old.
Stood the state so? No
For then this land was famously enrich'd
With politic grave counsel; then the king
Had virtuous uncles to protect his grace.
Why
Better it were they all came by the father
For emulation now
O
And the queen's sons and brothers haught and proud:
And were they to be ruled
Come
When clouds appear
When great leaves fall
When the sun sets
Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.
All may be well; but
Truly
Ye cannot reason almost with a man
That looks not heavily and full of fear.
Before the times of change
By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust
Ensuing dangers; as by proof
The waters swell before a boisterous storm.
But leave it all to God. whither away?
Marry
And so was I: I'll bear you company.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. London. The palace.
Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
Last night
At Stony-Stratford will they be to-night:
To-morrow
I long with all my heart to see the prince:
I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.
But I hear
Hath almost overta'en him in his growth.
Ay
Why
Grandam
More than my brother: 'Ay
Gloucester
And since
Good faith
In him that did object the same to thee;
He was the wretched'st thing when he was young
Why
I hope he is; but yet let mothers doubt.
Now
How
Marry
That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old
'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.
Grandam
I pray thee
Grandam
His nurse! why
If 'twere not she
A parlous boy: go to
Good madam
Pitchers have ears.
Enter a Messenger
Here comes a messenger. What news?
Such news
How fares the prince?
Well
What is thy news then?
Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret
Who hath committed them?
The mighty dukes
Gloucester and Buckingham.
For what offence?
The sum of all I can
Why or for what these nobles were committed
Is all unknown to me
Ay me
The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind;
Insulting tyranny begins to jet
Upon the innocent and aweless throne:
Welcome
I see
Accursed and unquiet wrangling days
My husband lost his life to get the crown;
And often up and down my sons were toss'd
And being seated
Clean over-blown
Make war upon themselves; blood against blood
And frantic outrage
Or let me die
Come
Madam
I'll go along with you.
You have no cause.
My gracious lady
And thither bear your treasure and your goods.
For my part
The seal I keep: and so betide to me
As well I tender you and all of yours!
Come
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. London. A street.
The trumpets sound. Enter the young PRINCE EDWARD
Welcome
Welcome
The weary way hath made you melancholy.
No
Have made it tedious
I want more uncles here to welcome me.
Sweet prince
Hath not yet dived into the world's deceit
Nor more can you distinguish of a man
Than of his outward show; which
Those uncles which you want were dangerous;
Your grace attended to their sugar'd words
God keep you from them
God keep me from false friends! but they were none.
My lord
Enter the Lord Mayor and his train
God bless your grace with health and happy days!
I thank you
I thought my mother
Fie
To tell us whether they will come or no!
Enter HASTINGS
And
Welcome
On what occasion
Would fain have come with me to meet your grace
Fie
Is this of hers! Lord cardinal
Persuade the queen to send the Duke of York
Unto his princely brother presently?
If she deny
My Lord of Buckingham
Can from his mother win the Duke of York
To mild entreaties
We should infringe the holy privilege
Of blessed sanctuary! not for all this land
Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.
You are too senseless--obstinate
Weigh it but with the grossness of this age
The benefit thereof is always granted
To those whose dealings have deserved the place
This prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserved it;
And therefore
Then
Oft have I heard of sanctuary men;
But sanctuary children ne'er till now.
My lord
Come on
I go
Good lords
Exeunt CARDINAL and HASTINGS
Say
Where it seems best unto your royal self.
If I may counsel you
Your highness shall repose you at the Tower:
Then where you please
For your best health and recreation.
I do not like the Tower
Did Julius Caesar build that place
He did
Which
Is it upon record
Successively from age to age
Upon record
But say
[Aside]  So wise so young
live long.
What say you
I say
Aside
Thus
That Julius Caesar was a famous man;
With what his valour did enrich his wit
Death makes no conquest of this conqueror;
For now he lives in fame
I'll tell you what
What
An if I live until I be a man
[Aside]  Short summers lightly have a forward spring.
Enter young YORK
Now
Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?
Well
Ay
Too late he died that might have kept that title
How fares our cousin
I thank you
The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.
He hath
And therefore is he idle?
O
Then is he more beholding to you than I.
He may command me as my sovereign;
But you have power in me as in a kinsman.
I pray you
My dagger
A beggar
Of my kind uncle
And being but a toy
A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.
A greater gift! O
A gentle cousin
O
In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.
It is too heavy for your grace to wear.
I weigh it lightly
What
I would
How?
Little.
My Lord of York will still be cross in talk:
Uncle
You mean
Uncle
Because that I am little
With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!
To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle
So cunning and so young is wonderful.
My lord
Myself and my good cousin Buckingham
Will to your mother
To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.
What
My lord protector needs will have it so.
I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.
Why
Marry
My grandam told me he was murdered there.
I fear no uncles dead.
Nor none that live
An if they live
But come
A Sennet. Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER
Think you
Was not incensed by his subtle mother
To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?
No doubt
Bold
He is all the mother's
Well
Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend
As closely to conceal what we impart:
Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way;
What think'st thou? is it not an easy matter
To make William Lord Hastings of our mind
In the seat royal of this famous isle?
He for his father's sake so loves the prince
What think'st thou
He will do all in all as Hastings doth.
Well
And summon him to-morrow to the Tower
If thou dost find him tractable to us
If he be leaden
For we to-morrow hold divided councils
Commend me to Lord William: tell him
To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;
And bid my friend
Good Catesby
My good lords both
Shall we hear from you
You shall
At Crosby Place
Exit CATESBY
Now
Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?
Chop off his head
And
The earldom of Hereford
Whereof the king my brother stood possess'd.
I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.
And look to have it yielded with all willingness.
Come
We may digest our complots in some form.
Exeunt
SCENE II. Before Lord Hastings' house.
Enter a Messenger
What
[Within]  Who knocks at the door?
A messenger from the Lord Stanley.
Enter HASTINGS
What is't o'clock?
Upon the stroke of four.
Cannot thy master sleep these tedious nights?
So it should seem by that I have to say.
First
And then?
And then he sends you word
He dreamt to-night the boar had razed his helm:
Besides
And that may be determined at the one
which may make you and him to rue at the other.
Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure
Go
Bid him not fear the separated councils
His honour and myself are at the one
Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us
Whereof I shall not have intelligence.
Tell him his fears are shallow
And for his dreams
To trust the mockery of unquiet slumbers
To fly the boar before the boar pursues
And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.
Go
And we will both together to the Tower
My gracious lord
Exit
Enter CATESBY
Many good morrows to my noble lord!
Good morrow
What news
It is a reeling world
And I believe twill never stand upright
Tim Richard wear the garland of the realm.
How! wear the garland! dost thou mean the crown?
Ay
I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders
Ere I will see the crown so foul misplaced.
But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?
Ay
Upon his party for the gain thereof:
And thereupon he sends you this good news
Indeed
But
God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!
But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence
I live to look upon their tragedy.
I tell thee
What
Ere a fortnight make me elder
'Tis a vile thing to die
O monstrous
With Rivers
With some men else
As thou and I; who
To princely Richard and to Buckingham.
The princes both make high account of you;
Aside
For they account his head upon the bridge.
I know they do; and I have well deserved it.
Enter STANLEY
Come on
Fear you the boar
My lord
You may jest on
My lord
And never in my life
Think you
The lords at Pomfret
But yet
This sudden stag of rancour I misdoubt:
Pray God
What
Come
To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.
They
Than some that have accused them wear their hats.
But come
Enter a Pursuivant
Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow.
Exeunt STANLEY and CATESBY
How now
The better that your lordship please to ask.
I tell thee
Than when I met thee last where now we meet:
Then was I going prisoner to the Tower
But now
This day those enemies are put to death
God hold it
Gramercy
Throws him his purse
God save your lordship!
Exit
Enter a Priest
Well met
I thank thee
I am in your debt for your last exercise;
Come the next Sabbath
He whispers in his ear
Enter BUCKINGHAM
What
Your friends at Pomfret
Your honour hath no shriving work in hand.
Good faith
What
I do
I shall return before your lordship thence.
'Tis like enough
[Aside]  And supper too
Come
I'll wait upon your lordship.
Exeunt
SCENE III. Pomfret Castle.
Enter RATCLIFF
Come
Sir Richard Ratcliff
To-day shalt thou behold a subject die
For truth
God keep the prince from all the pack of you!
A knot you are of damned blood-suckers!
You live that shall cry woe for this after.
Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out.
O Pomfret
Within the guilty closure of thy walls
Richard the second here was hack'd to death;
And
Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads
Then cursed she Hastings
To hear her prayers for them
And for my sister and her princely sons
Make haste; the hour of death is expiate.
Come
And take our leave
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The Tower of London.
Enter BUCKINGHAM
My lords
Is
In God's name
Are all things fitting for that royal time?
It is
To-morrow
Who knows the lord protector's mind herein?
Who is most inward with the royal duke?
Your grace
Who
Nor I no more of his
Lord Hastings
I thank his grace
But
I have not sounded him
His gracious pleasure any way therein:
But you
And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice
Enter GLOUCESTER
Now in good time
My noble lords and cousins all
I have been long a sleeper; but
Had not you come upon your cue
William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part
I mean
Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder;
His lordship knows me well
I thank your grace.
My lord of Ely!
My lord?
When I was last in Holborn
I do beseech you send for some of them.
Marry
Exit
Cousin of Buckingham
Drawing him aside
Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business
His master's son
Withdraw you hence
Exit GLOUCESTER
We have not yet set down this day of triumph.
To-morrow
For I myself am not so well provided
As else I would be
Re-enter BISHOP OF ELY
Where is my lord protector? I have sent for these
strawberries.
His grace looks cheerfully and smooth to-day;
There's some conceit or other likes him well
I think there's never a man in Christendom
That can less hide his love or hate than he;
For by his face straight shall you know his heart.
What of his heart perceive you in his face
By any likelihood he show'd to-day?
Marry
For
I pray God he be not
Re-enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM
I pray you all
That do conspire my death with devilish plots
Of damned witchcraft
Upon my body with their hellish charms?
The tender love I bear your grace
To doom the offenders
I say
Then be your eyes the witness of this ill:
See how I am bewitch'd; behold mine arm
Is
And this is Edward's wife
If they have done this thing
If I thou protector of this damned strumpet--
Tellest thou me of 'ifs'?  Thou art a traitor:
Off with his head! Now
Lovel and Ratcliff
The rest
Exeunt all but HASTINGS
Woe
For I
Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm;
But I disdain'd it
Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble
O
I now repent I told the pursuivant
As 'twere triumphing at mine enemies
O Margaret
Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head!
Dispatch
Make a short shrift; he longs to see your head.
O momentary grace of mortal men
Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks
Into the fatal bowels of the deep.
Come
O bloody Richard! miserable England!
I prophesy the fearful'st time to thee
That ever wretched age hath look'd upon.
Come
They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.
Exeunt
SCENE V. The Tower-walls.
Enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM
Come
Tut
Speak and look back
Are at my service
And both are ready in their offices
But what
He is; and
Enter the Lord Mayor and CATESBY
Lord mayor
Look to the drawbridge there!
Hark! a drum.
Catesby
Lord mayor
Look back
God and our innocency defend and guard us!
Be patient
Enter LOVEL and RATCLIFF
Here is the head of that ignoble traitor
So dear I loved the man
I took him for the plainest harmless creature
That breathed upon this earth a Christian;
Made him my book wherein my soul recorded
The history of all her secret thoughts:
So smooth he daub'd his vice with show of virtue
Well
That ever lived.
Would you imagine
This day had plotted
To murder me and my good Lord of Gloucester?
What
What
Or that we would
Now
And you my good lords
I never look'd for better at his hands
Yet had not we determined he should die
Which now the loving haste of these our friends
Because
The traitor speak
The manner and the purpose of his treason;
That you might well have signified the same
Unto the citizens
Misconstrue us in him and wail his death.
But
And doubt you not
With all your just proceedings in this cause.
And to that end we wish'd your lord-ship here
But since you come too late of our intents
And so
Exit Lord Mayor
Go
The mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post:
There
Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen
Heir to the crown; meaning indeed his house
Moreover
And bestial appetite in change of lust;
Which stretched to their servants
Nay
Tell them
Of that unsatiate Edward
My princely father then had wars in France
And
Which well appeared in his lineaments
But touch this sparingly
Fear not
As if the golden fee for which I plead
Were for myself: and so
If you thrive well
Where you shall find me well accompanied
With reverend fathers and well-learned bishops.
I go: and towards three or four o'clock
Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.
Exit BUCKINGHAM
Go
To CATESBY
Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them both
Meet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle.
Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER
Now will I in
And to give notice
At any time have recourse unto the princes.
Exit
SCENE VI. The same.
Enter a Scrivener
This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings;
Which in a set hand fairly is engross'd
And mark how well the sequel hangs together:
Eleven hours I spent to write it over
The precedent was full as long a-doing:
And yet within these five hours lived Lord Hastings
Here's a good world the while! Why who's so gross
Yet who's so blind
Bad is the world; and all will come to nought
Exit
SCENE VII. Baynard's Castle.
Enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM
How now
Now
Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?
I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy
The insatiate greediness of his desires
His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy
Withal I did infer your lineaments
Laid open all your victories in Scotland
Indeed
Untouch'd
And when mine oratory grew to an end
I bid them that did love their country's good
Cry 'God save Richard
Ah! and did they so?
No
But
Which when I saw
And ask'd the mayor what meant this wilful silence:
His answer was
To be spoke to but by the recorder.
Then he was urged to tell my tale again
But nothing spake in warrant from himself.
When he had done
And thus I took the vantage of those few
'This general applause and loving shout
Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard:'
And even here brake off
What tongueless blocks were they! would not they speak?
No
Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?
The mayor is here at hand: intend some fear;
Be not you spoke with
And look you get a prayer-book in your hand
For on that ground I'll build a holy descant:
And be not easily won to our request:
Play the maid's part
I go; and if you plead as well for them
As I can say nay to thee for myself
Go
Exit GLOUCESTER
Enter the Lord Mayor and Citizens
Welcome my lord; I dance attendance here;
I think the duke will not be spoke withal.
Enter CATESBY
Here comes his servant: how now
My lord: he doth entreat your grace;
To visit him to-morrow or next day:
He is within
And no worldly suit would he be moved
Return
Tell him
I'll tell him what you say
Exit
Ah
He is not lolling on a lewd day-bed
Not dallying with a brace of courtezans
Not sleeping
Happy were England
Take on himself the sovereignty thereof:
But
Marry
I fear he will.
Re-enter CATESBY
How now
My lord
Such troops of citizens to speak with him
My lord
Sorry I am my noble cousin should
Suspect me
By heaven
And so once more return and tell his grace.
Exit CATESBY
When holy and devout religious men
Are at their beads
Enter GLOUCESTER aloft
See
Two props of virtue for a Christian prince
And
Famous Plantagenet
And pardon us the interruption
Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.
My lord
I rather do beseech you pardon me
But
Even that
I do suspect I have done some offence
That seems disgracious in the city's eyes
You have
Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?
Then know
The supreme seat
Whilst
Her face defaced with scars of infamy
Of blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion.
Which to recure
Your gracious self to take on you the charge
And kingly government of this your land
But as successively from blood to blood
For this
I know not whether to depart in silence
Best fitteth my degree or your condition
If not to answer
Tongue-tied ambition
To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty
If to reprove you for this suit of yours
Then
Therefore
Your love deserves my thanks; but my desert
Unmeritable shuns your high request.
First if all obstacles were cut away
Yet so much is my poverty of spirit
But
The royal tree hath left us royal fruit
On him I lay what you would lay on me
Which God defend that I should wring from him!
My lord
But the respects thereof are nice and trivial
You say that Edward is your brother's son:
So say we too
For first he was contract to Lady Lucy--
Your mother lives a witness to that vow--
And afterward by substitute betroth'd
To Bona
These both put by a poor petitioner
To base declension and loathed bigamy
By her
This Edward
More bitterly could I expostulate
Then
This proffer'd benefit of dignity;
If non to bless us and the land withal
From the corruption of abusing times
Do
Refuse not
O
Alas
I am unfit for state and majesty;
I do beseech you
I cannot nor I will not yield to you.
If you refuse it
As well we know your tenderness of heart
And gentle
Yet whether you accept our suit or no
But we will plant some other in the throne
And in this resolution here we leave you.--
Come
O
Exit BUCKINGHAM with the Citizens
Call them again
Do
Would you enforce me to a world of care?
Well
Re-enter BUCKINGHAM and the rest
Cousin of Buckingham
But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach
Attend the sequel of your imposition
From all the impure blots and stains thereof;
For God he knows
God bless your grace! we see it
In saying so
Then I salute you with this kingly title:
Long live Richard
Amen.
To-morrow will it please you to be crown'd?
Even when you please
To-morrow
And so most joyfully we take our leave.
Come
Farewell
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Before the Tower.
Enter
Who m eets us here?  my niece Plantagenet
Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?
Now
Daughter
God give your graces both
A happy and a joyful time of day!
As much to you
No farther than the Tower; and
Kind sister
Enter BRAKENBURY
And
Master lieutenant
Right well
The king hath straitly charged the contrary.
The king! why
I cry you mercy: I mean the lord protector.
The Lord protect him from that kingly title!
Hath he set bounds betwixt their love and me?
I am their mother; who should keep me from them?
I am their fathers mother; I will see them.
Their aunt I am in law
Then bring me to their sights; I'll bear thy blame
And take thy office from thee
No
I am bound by oath
Exit
Enter LORD STANLEY
Let me but meet you
To LADY ANNE
Come
O
May have some scope to beat
With this dead-killing news!
Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!
Be of good cheer: mother
O Dorset
Death and destruction dog thee at the heels;
Thy mother's name is ominous to children.
If thou wilt outstrip death
Go
And make me die the thrall of Margaret's curse
Full of wise care is this your counsel
Take all the swift advantage of the hours;
You shall have letters from me to my son
To meet you on the way
Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.
O ill-dispersing wind of misery!
O my accursed womb
A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world
Come
And I in all unwillingness will go.
I would to God that the inclusive verge
Of golden metal that must round my brow
Were red-hot steel
Anointed let me be with deadly venom
Go
To feed my humour
No! why?  When he that is my husband now
Came to me
Which issued from my other angel husband
And that dead saint which then I weeping follow'd;
O
And
And be thy wife--if any be so mad--
As miserable by the life of thee
As thou hast made me by my dear lord's death!
Lo
Grossly grew captive to his honey words
And proved the subject of my own soul's curse
For never yet one hour in his bed
Have I enjoy'd the golden dew of sleep
Besides
And will
Poor heart
No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.
Farewell
Adieu
[To DORSET]
Go thou to Richmond
To LADY ANNE
Go thou to Richard
To QUEEN ELIZABETH
Go thou to sanctuary
I to my grave
Eighty odd years of sorrow have I seen
Stay
Pity
Whom envy hath immured within your walls!
Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!
Rude ragged nurse
For tender princes
So foolish sorrow bids your stones farewell.
Exeunt
SCENE II. London. The palace.
Sennet. Enter KING RICHARD III
Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!
My gracious sovereign?
Give me thy hand.
Here he ascendeth his throne
Thus high
And thy assistance
But shall we wear these honours for a day?
Or shall they last
Still live they and for ever may they last!
O Buckingham
Young Edward lives: think now what I would say.
Say on
Why
Ha! am I king? 'tis so: but Edward lives.
TRUE
O bitter consequence
Cousin
Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead;
And I would have it suddenly perform'd.
What sayest thou? speak suddenly; be brief.
Your grace may do your pleasure.
Tut
Say
Give me some breath
Before I positively herein:
I will resolve your grace immediately.
Exit
[Aside to a stander by]
The king is angry: see
I will converse with iron-witted fools
And unrespective boys: none are for me
That look into me with considerate eyes:
High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.
Boy!
My lord?
Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold
Would tempt unto a close exploit of death?
My lord
Gold were as good as twenty orators
What is his name?
His name
I partly know the man: go
Exit Page
The deep-revolving witty Buckingham
No more shall be the neighbour to my counsel:
Hath he so long held out with me untired
Enter STANLEY
How now! what news with you?
My lord
To Richmond
Where he abides.
Stands apart
Catesby!
My lord?
Rumour it abroad
That Anne
I will take order for her keeping close.
Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman
The boy is foolish
Look
That Anne my wife is sick and like to die:
About it; for it stands me much upon
Exit CATESBY
I must be married to my brother's daughter
Murder her brothers
Uncertain way of gain! But I am in
So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin:
Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.
Re-enter Page
Is thy name Tyrrel?
James Tyrrel
Art thou
Prove me
Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?
Ay
But I had rather kill two enemies.
Why
Are they that I would have thee deal upon:
Tyrrel
Let me have open means to come to them
Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark
Go
Whispers
There is no more but so: say it is done
'Tis done
Shall we hear from thee
Ye shall
Exit
Re-enter BUCKINGHAM
My Lord
The late demand that you did sound me in.
Well
I hear that news
Stanley
My lord
The earldom of Hereford and the moveables
The which you promised I should possess.
Stanley
Letters to Richmond
What says your highness to my just demand?
As I remember
Did prophesy that Richmond should be king
A king
My lord!
How chance the prophet could not at that time
Have told me
My lord
Richmond! When last I was at Exeter
I should not live long after I saw Richmond.
My Lord!
Ay
I am thus bold to put your grace in mind
Of what you promised me.
Well
Upon the stroke of ten.
Well
Why let it strike?
Because that
Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.
I am not in the giving vein to-day.
Why
Tut
Exeunt all but BUCKINGHAM
Is it even so? rewards he my true service
With such deep contempt made I him king for this?
O
To Brecknock
Exit
SCENE III. The same.
Enter TYRREL
The tyrannous and bloody deed is done.
The most arch of piteous massacre
That ever yet this land was guilty of.
Dighton and Forrest
To do this ruthless piece of butchery
Wept like two children in their deaths' sad stories.
'Lo
'Thus
Within their innocent alabaster arms:
Their lips were four red roses on a stalk
A book of prayers on their pillow lay;
Which once
But O! the devil'--there the villain stopp'd
Whilst Dighton thus told on: 'We smothered
The most replenished sweet work of nature
Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse;
They could not speak; and so I left them both
And here he comes.
Enter KING RICHARD III
All hail
Kind Tyrrel
If to have done the thing you gave in charge
Beget your happiness
But didst thou see them dead?
I did
And buried
The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them;
But how or in what place I do not know.
Come to me
Meantime
Farewell till soon.
Exit TYRREL
The son of Clarence have I pent up close;
His daughter meanly have I match'd in marriage;
The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom
Now
At young Elizabeth
Enter CATESBY
My lord!
Good news or bad
Bad news
And Buckingham
Ely with Richmond troubles me more near
Than Buckingham and his rash-levied army.
Come
Is leaden servitor to dull delay;
Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary
Then fiery expedition be my wing
Come
We must be brief when traitors brave the field.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Before the palace.
Enter QUEEN MARGARET
So
And drop into the rotten mouth of death.
Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd
A dire induction am I witness to
Will prove as bitter
Withdraw thee
Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH and the DUCHESS OF YORK
Ah
My unblown flowers
If yet your gentle souls fly in the air
And be not fix'd in doom perpetual
And hear your mother's lamentation!
Hover about her; say
Hath dimm'd your infant morn to aged night.
So many miseries have crazed my voice
Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet.
Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.
Wilt thou
When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?
When holy Harry died
Blind sight
Unlawfully made drunk with innocents' blood!
O
As thou canst yield a melancholy seat!
Then would I hide my bones
O
Sitting down by her
If ancient sorrow be most reverend
If sorrow can admit society
Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine:
I had an Edward
I had a Harry
Thou hadst an Edward
Thou hadst a Richard
I had a Richard too
I had a Rutland too
Thou hadst a Clarence too
From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept
A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death:
That dog
O upright
Preys on the issue of his mother's body
O Harry's wife
God witness with me
Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge
Thy Edward he is dead
Thy other Edward dead
Young York he is but boot
Match not the high perfection of my loss:
Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward;
And the beholders of this tragic play
Richard yet lives
And send them thither: but at hand
Earth gapes
To have him suddenly convey'd away.
Cancel his bond of life
O
That I should wish for thee to help me curse
That bottled spider
I call'd thee then vain flourish of my fortune;
I call'd thee then poor shadow
The presentation of but what I was;
The flattering index of a direful pageant;
One heaved a-high
A mother only mock'd with two sweet babes;
A dream of what thou wert
Where is thy husband now? where be thy brothers?
Where are thy children? wherein dost thou
Who sues to thee and cries 'God save the queen'?
Where be the bending peers that flatter'd thee?
Where be the thronging troops that follow'd thee?
Decline all this
For happy wife
For joyful mother
For queen
For one being sued to
For one that scorn'd at me
For one being fear'd of all
For one commanding all
Thus hath the course of justice wheel'd about
Having no more but thought of what thou wert
Thou didst usurp my place
Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?
Now thy proud neck bears half my burthen'd yoke;
From which even here I slip my weary neck
Farewell
These English woes will make me smile in France.
O thou well skill'd in curses
Forbear to sleep the nights
Compare dead happiness with living woe;
Think that thy babes were fairer than they were
Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse:
Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.
My words are dull; O
Thy woes will make them sharp
Exit
Why should calamity be full of words?
Windy attorneys to their client woes
Let them have scope: though what they do impart
Help not all
If so
And in the breath of bitter words let's smother
My damned son
I hear his drum: be copious in exclaims.
Enter KING RICHARD III
Who intercepts my expedition?
O
From all the slaughters
Hidest thou that forehead with a golden crown
Tell me
Thou toad
And little Ned Plantagenet
Where is kind Hastings
A flourish
Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale women
Rail on the Lord's enointed: strike
Flourish. Alarums
Either be patient
Thus will I drown your exclamations.
Art thou my son?
Ay
Then patiently hear my impatience.
Madam
O
Do then: but I'll not hear.
I will be mild and gentle in my speech.
And brief
Art thou so hasty? I have stay'd for thee
And came I not at last to comfort you?
No
A grievous burthen was thy birth to me;
Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;
Thy school-days frightful
What comfortable hour canst thou name
Faith
your grace
To breakfast once forth of my company.
If I be so disgracious in your sight
Strike the drum.
I prithee
You speak too bitterly.
Hear me a word;
For I shall never speak to thee again.
So.
Either thou wilt die
And never look upon thy face again.
Therefore take with thee my most heavy curse;
Which
Than all the complete armour that thou wear'st!
My prayers on the adverse party fight;
And there the little souls of Edward's children
Whisper the spirits of thine enemies
And promise them success and victory.
Bloody thou art
Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.
Exit
Though far more cause
Abides in me; I say amen to all.
Stay
I have no more sons of the royal blood
For thee to murder: for my daughters
And therefore level not to hit their lives.
You have a daughter call'd Elizabeth
And must she die for this? O
Slander myself as false to Edward's bed;
Throw over her the veil of infamy:
So she may live unscarr'd of bleeding slaughter
Wrong not her birth
To save her life
Her life is only safest in her birth.
And only in that safety died her brothers.
Lo
No
All unavoided is the doom of destiny.
TRUE
My babes were destined to a fairer death
You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.
Cousins
Of comfort
Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts
No doubt the murderous knife was dull and blunt
Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart
But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame
Till that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes;
And I
Madam
And dangerous success of bloody wars
What good is cover'd with the face of heaven
The advancement of your children
Up to some scaffold
No
The high imperial type of this earth's glory.
Flatter my sorrows with report of it;
Tell me what state
Even all I have; yea
So in the Lethe of thy angry soul
Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs
Which thou supposest I have done to thee.
Be brief
Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.
Then know
My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.
What do you think?
That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul:
So from thy soul's love didst thou love her brothers;
And from my heart's love I do thank thee for it.
Be not so hasty to confound my meaning:
I mean
Say then
Even he that makes her queen who should be else?
What
I
How canst thou woo her?
That would I learn of you
And wilt thou learn of me?
Madam
Send to her
Edward and York; then haply she will weep:
Therefore present to her--as sometime Margaret
Did to thy father
A handkerchief; which
The purple sap from her sweet brother's body
And bid her dry her weeping eyes therewith.
If this inducement force her not to love
Tell her thou madest away her uncle Clarence
Come
To win our daughter.
There is no other way
Unless thou couldst put on some other shape
Say that I did all this for love of her.
Nay
Look
Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes
If I did take the kingdom from your sons
If I have kill'd the issue of your womb
Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter
A grandam's name is little less in love
Than is the doting title of a mother;
They are as children but one step below
Of an one pain
Endured of her
Your children were vexation to your youth
The loss you have is but a son being king
I cannot make you what amends I would
Dorset your son
Leads discontented steps in foreign soil
To high promotions and great dignity:
The king
Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother;
Again shall you be mother to a king
Repair'd with double riches of content.
What! we have many goodly days to see:
The liquid drops of tears that you have shed
Shall come again
Of ten times double gain of happiness.
Go
Make bold her bashful years with your experience;
Prepare her ears to hear a wooer's tale
Put in her tender heart the aspiring flame
Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the princess
With the sweet silent hours of marriage joys
And when this arm of mine hath chastised
The petty rebel
And lead thy daughter to a conqueror's bed;
To whom I will retail my conquest won
What were I best to say? her father's brother
Would be her lord? or shall I say
Or
Under what title shall I woo for thee
Infer fair England's peace by this alliance.
Which she shall purchase with still lasting war.
Say that the king
That at her hands which the king's King forbids.
Say
To wail the tide
Say
But how long shall that title 'ever' last?
Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end.
But how long fairly shall her sweet lie last?
So long as heaven and nature lengthens it.
So long as hell and Richard likes of it.
Say
But she
Be eloquent in my behalf to her.
An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.
Then in plain terms tell her my loving tale.
Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.
Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.
O no
Too deep and dead
Harp not on that string
Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.
Now
Profaned
I swear--
By nothing; for this is no oath:
The George
The garter
The crown
if something thou wilt swear to be believed
Now
'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.
My father's death--
Thy life hath that dishonour'd.
Then
Thyself thyself misusest.
Why then
God's wrong is most of all.
If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him
Had not been broken
If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him
What canst thou swear by now?
The time to come.
That thou hast wronged in the time o'erpast;
For I myself have many tears to wash
Hereafter time
The children live
slaughter'd
The parents live
Swear not by time to come; for that thou hast
Misused ere used
As I intend to prosper and repent
Of hostile arms! myself myself confound!
Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours!
Day
Be opposite all planets of good luck
To my proceedings
In her consists my happiness and thine;
Without her
It cannot be avoided but by this;
It will not be avoided but by this.
Therefore
Be the attorney of my love to her:
Plead what I will be
Not my deserts
Urge the necessity and state of times
Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?
Ay
Shall I forget myself to be myself?
Ay
But thou didst kill my children.
But in your daughter's womb I bury them:
Where in that nest of spicery they shall breed
Selves of themselves
Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?
And be a happy mother by the deed.
I go. Write to me very shortly.
And you shall understand from me her mind.
Bear her my true love's kiss; and so
Exit QUEEN ELIZABETH
Relenting fool
Enter RATCLIFF; CATESBY following
How now! what news?
My gracious sovereign
Rideth a puissant navy; to the shore
Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends
'Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral;
And there they hull
Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.
Some light-foot friend post to the Duke of Norfolk:
Ratcliff
Here
Fly to the duke:
To RATCLIFF
Post thou to Salisbury
When thou comest thither--
To CATESBY
Dull
First
O
The greatest strength and power he can make
I go.
Exit
What is't your highness' pleasure I shall do at
Salisbury?
Why
Your highness told me I should post before.
My mind is changed
Enter STANLEY
How now
None good
Nor none so bad
Hoyday
Why dost thou run so many mile about
Once more
Richmond is on the seas.
There let him sink
White-liver'd runagate
I know not
Well
Stirr'd up by Dorset
Is the chair empty? is the sword unsway'd?
Is the king dead? the empire unpossess'd?
What heir of York is there alive but we?
And who is England's king but great York's heir?
Then
Unless for that
Unless for that he comes to be your liege
Thou wilt revolt
No
Where is thy power
Where are thy tenants and thy followers?
Are they not now upon the western shore.
Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships!
No
Cold friends to Richard: what do they in the north
They have not been commanded
Please it your majesty to give me leave
Where and what time your majesty shall please.
Ay
I will not trust you
Most mighty sovereign
I never was nor never will be false.
Well
Your son
Or else his head's assurance is but frail.
So deal with him as I prove true to you.
Exit
Enter a Messenger
My gracious sovereign
Bishop of Exeter
Enter another Messenger
My liege
And every hour more competitors
Flock to their aid
Enter another Messenger
My lord
Out on you
He striketh him
Take that
The news I have to tell your majesty
Is
And he himself wander'd away alone
I cry thee mercy:
There is my purse to cure that blow of thine.
Hath any well-advised friend proclaim'd
Reward to him that brings the traitor in?
Such proclamation hath been made
Enter another Messenger
Sir Thomas Lovel and Lord Marquis Dorset
Yet this good comfort bring I to your grace
Richmond
Unto the shore
If they were his assistants
Who answer'd him
Upon his party: he
March on
If not to fight with foreign enemies
Re-enter CATESBY
My liege
That is the best news: that the Earl of Richmond
Is with a mighty power landed at Milford
Away towards Salisbury! while we reason here
Some one take order Buckingham be brought
To Salisbury; the rest march on with me.
Flourish. Exeunt
SCENE V. Lord Derby's house.
Enter DERBY and SIR CHRISTOPHER URSWICK
Sir Christopher
That in the sty of this most bloody boar
My son George Stanley is frank'd up in hold:
If I revolt
The fear of that withholds my present aid.
But
At Pembroke
What men of name resort to him?
Sir Walter Herbert
Sir Gilbert Talbot
Oxford
And many more of noble fame and worth:
And towards London they do bend their course
Return unto thy lord; commend me to him:
Tell him the queen hath heartily consented
He shall espouse Elizabeth her daughter.
These letters will resolve him of my mind. Farewell.
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. Salisbury. An open place.
Enter the Sheriff
Will not King Richard let me speak with him?
No
Hastings
By underhand corrupted foul injustice
Do through the clouds behold this present hour
This is All-Souls' day
It is
Why
This is the day that
False to his children or his wife's allies
This is the day wherein I wish'd to fall
By the false faith of him I trusted most;
This
Is the determined respite of my wrongs:
That high All-Seer that I dallied with
Hath turn'd my feigned prayer on my head
And given in earnest what I begg'd in jest.
Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men
To turn their own points on their masters' bosoms:
Now Margaret's curse is fallen upon my head;
'When he
Come
Wrong hath but wrong
Exeunt
SCENE II. The camp near Tamworth.
Enter RICHMOND
Fellows in arms
Have we march'd on without impediment;
And here receive we from our father Stanley
Lines of fair comfort and encouragement.
The wretched
In your embowell'd bosoms
Lies now even in the centre of this isle
From Tamworth thither is but one day's march.
In God's name
By this one bloody trial of sharp war.
Every man's conscience is a thousand swords
I doubt not but his friends will fly to us.
He hath no friends but who are friends for fear.
Which in his greatest need will shrink from him.
All for our vantage. Then
True hope is swift
Kings it makes gods
Exeunt
SCENE III. Bosworth Field.
Enter KING RICHARD III in arms
Here pitch our tents
My Lord of Surrey
My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.
My Lord of Norfolk
Here
Norfolk
We must both give and take
Up with my tent there! here will I lie tonight;
But where to-morrow?  Well
Who hath descried the number of the foe?
Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.
Why
Besides
Up with my tent there! Valiant gentlemen
Call for some men of sound direction
Let's want no discipline
Exeunt
Enter
The weary sun hath made a golden set
Sir William Brandon
Give me some ink and paper in my tent
I'll draw the form and model of our battle
My Lord of Oxford
The Earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment:
Good Captain Blunt
And by the second hour in the morning
Desire the earl to see me in my tent:
Yet one thing more
Unless I have mista'en his colours much
South from the mighty power of the king.
If without peril it be possible
Upon my life
And so
Good night
In to our tent; the air is raw and cold.
They withdraw into the tent
Enter
What is't o'clock?
It's supper-time
It's nine o'clock.
I will not sup to-night.
Give me some ink and paper.
What
And all my armour laid into my tent?
If is
Good Norfolk
Use careful watch
I go
Stir with the lark to-morrow
I warrant you
Exit
Catesby!
My lord?
Send out a pursuivant at arms
To Stanley's regiment; bid him bring his power
Before sunrising
Into the blind cave of eternal night.
Exit CATESBY
Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch.
Saddle white Surrey for the field to-morrow.
Look that my staves be sound
Ratcliff!
My lord?
Saw'st thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?
Thomas the Earl of Surrey
Went through the army
So
I have not that alacrity of spirit
Set it down. Is ink and paper ready?
It is
Bid my guard watch; leave me.
Ratcliff
And help to arm me. Leave me
Exeunt RATCLIFF and the other Attendants
Enter DERBY to RICHMOND in his tent
Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!
All comfort that the dark night can afford
Be to thy person
Tell me
I
Who prays continually for Richmond's good:
So much for that. The silent hours steal on
In brief
Prepare thy battle early in the morning
Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.
I
With best advantage will deceive the time
But on thy side I may not be too forward
Lest
Farewell: the leisure and the fearful time
Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love
And ample interchange of sweet discourse
God give us leisure for these rites of love!
Once more
Good lords
I'll strive
Once more
Exeunt all but RICHMOND
O Thou
Put in their hands thy bruising irons of wrath
The usurping helmets of our adversaries!
Make us thy ministers of chastisement
To thee I do commend my watchful soul
Sleeping and waking
Sleeps
Enter the Ghost of Prince Edward
Ghost
[To KING RICHARD III]
Let me sit heavy on thy soul to-morrow!
Think
At Tewksbury: despair
To RICHMOND
Be cheerful
Of butcher'd princes fight in thy behalf
King Henry's issue
Enter the Ghost of King Henry VI
Ghost
[To KING RICHARD III]
When I was mortal
By thee was punched full of deadly holes
Think on the Tower and me: despair
Harry the Sixth bids thee despair
To RICHMOND
Virtuous and holy
Harry
Enter the Ghost of CLARENCE
[To KING RICHARD III]
Let me sit heavy on thy soul to-morrow!
I
To-morrow in the battle think on me
To RICHMOND
Thou offspring of the house of Lancaster
The wronged heirs of York do pray for thee
Good angels guard thy battle! live
Enter the Ghosts of RIVERS
[To KING RICHARD III]
Let me sit heavy on thy soul to-morrow
[To KING RICHARD III]
Think upon Grey
[To KING RICHARD III]
Think upon Vaughan
[To RICHMOND]
Awake
Will conquer him! awake
Enter the Ghost of HASTINGS
[To KING RICHARD III]
Bloody and guilty
Think on Lord Hastings: despair
To RICHMOND
Quiet untroubled soul
Arm
Enter the Ghosts of the two young Princes
Ghosts
[To KING RICHARD III]
Dream on thy cousins smother'd in the Tower:
Let us be led within thy bosom
Thy nephews' souls bid thee despair and die!
To RICHMOND
Sleep
Good angels guard thee from the boar's annoy!
Live
Edward's unhappy sons do bid thee flourish.
Enter the Ghost of LADY ANNE
[To KING RICHARD III]
Richard
To-morrow in the battle think on me
To RICHMOND
Thou quiet soul
Dream of success and happy victory!
Thy adversary's wife doth pray for thee.
Enter the Ghost of BUCKINGHAM
Ghost
[To KING RICHARD III]
The last was I that helped thee to the crown;
The last was I that felt thy tyranny:
O
Dream on
Fainting
To RICHMOND
I died for hope ere I could lend thee aid:
But cheer thy heart
God and good angel fight on Richmond's side;
And Richard falls in height of all his pride.
The Ghosts vanish
KING RICHARD III starts out of his dream
Give me another horse: bind up my wounds.
Have mercy
O coward conscience
The lights burn blue. It is now dead midnight.
Cold fearful drops stand on my trembling flesh.
What do I fear?  myself?  there's none else by:
Richard loves Richard; that is
Is there a murderer here?  No. Yes
Then fly. What
Lest I revenge. What
Alack. I love myself. Wherefore?  for any good
That I myself have done unto myself?
O
For hateful deeds committed by myself!
I am a villain: yet I lie. I am not.
Fool
My conscience hath a thousand several tongues
Perjury
Murder
All several sins
I shall despair. There is no creature loves me;
And if I die
Nay
Find in myself no pity to myself?
Methought the souls of all that I had murder'd
Came to my tent; and every one did threat
To-morrow's vengeance on the head of Richard.
Enter RATCLIFF
My lord!
'Zounds! who is there?
Ratcliff
Hath twice done salutation to the morn;
Your friends are up
O Ratcliff
What thinkest thou
No doubt
O Ratcliff
Nay
By the apostle Paul
Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard
Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers
Armed in proof
It is not yet near day. Come
Under our tents I'll play the eaves-dropper
Exeunt
Enter the Lords to RICHMOND
Good morrow
Cry mercy
How have you slept
The sweetest sleep
That ever enter'd in a drowsy head
Methought their souls
I promise you
In the remembrance of so fair a dream.
How far into the morning is it
Upon the stroke of four.
Why
His oration to his soldiers
More than I have said
Forbids to dwell upon: yet remember this
The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls
Richard except
Had rather have us win than him they follow:
For what is he they follow?  truly
One raised in blood
One that made means to come by what he hath
Abase foul stone
Of England's chair
One that hath ever been God's enemy:
Then
If you do sweat to put a tyrant down
If you do fight against your country's foes
If you do fight in safeguard of your wives
If you do free your children from the sword
Then
For me
Shall be this cold corpse on the earth's cold face;
But if I thrive
The least of you shall share his part thereof.
Sound drums and trumpets boldly and cheerfully;
God and Saint George! Richmond and victory!
Exeunt
Re-enter KING RICHARD
What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?
That he was never trained up in arms.
He said the truth: and what said Surrey then?
He smiled and said 'The better for our purpose.'
He was in the right; and so indeed it is.
Clock striketh
Ten the clock there. Give me a calendar.
Who saw the sun to-day?
Not I
Then he disdains to shine; for by the book
He should have braved the east an hour ago
A black day will it be to somebody. Ratcliff!
My lord?
The sun will not be seen to-day;
The sky doth frown and lour upon our army.
I would these dewy tears were from the ground.
Not shine to-day! Why
More than to Richmond?  for the selfsame heaven
That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.
Enter NORFOLK
Arm
Come
Call up Lord Stanley
I will lead forth my soldiers to the plain
My foreward shall be drawn out all in length
Our archers shall be placed in the midst
John Duke of Norfolk
They thus directed
In the main battle
Shall be well winged with our chiefest horse.
This
A good direction
This found I on my tent this morning.
He sheweth him a paper
[Reads]
'Jockey of Norfolk
A thing devised by the enemy.
Go
Let not our babbling dreams affright our souls:
Conscience is but a word that cowards use
Our strong arms be our conscience
March on
If not to heaven
His oration to his Army
What shall I say more than I have inferr'd?
Remember whom you are to cope withal;
A sort of vagabonds
To desperate ventures and assured destruction.
You sleeping safe
You having lands
And who doth lead them but a paltry fellow
A milk-sop
Felt so much cold as over shoes in snow?
Let's whip these stragglers o'er the seas again;
Lash hence these overweening rags of France
Who
If we be conquer'd
Have in their own land beaten
Shall these enjoy our lands?  lie with our wives?
Ravish our daughters?
Drum afar off
Hark! I hear their drum.
Fight
Draw
Spur your proud horses hard
Amaze the welkin with your broken staves!
Enter a Messenger
What says Lord Stanley? will he bring his power?
My lord
Off with his son George's head!
My lord
After the battle let George Stanley die.
A thousand hearts are great within my bosom:
Advance our standards
Our ancient word of courage
Upon them! victory sits on our helms.
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Another part of the field.
Alarum: excursions. Enter NORFOLK and forces fighting; to him CATESBY
Rescue
The king enacts more wonders than a man
His horse is slain
Rescue
Alarums. Enter KING RICHARD III
A horse! a horse! my kingdom for a horse!
Withdraw
Slave
I think there be six Richmonds in the field;
Five have I slain to-day instead of him.
A horse! a horse! my kingdom for a horse!
Exeunt
SCENE V. Another part of the field.
Alarum. Enter KING RICHARD III and RICHMOND; they  fight. KING RICHARD III is slain. Retreat and  flourish. Re-enter RICHMOND
God and your arms be praised
Courageous Richmond
Lo
From the dead temples of this bloody wretch
Have I pluck'd off
Wear it
Great God of heaven
But
He is
Whither
What men of name are slain on either side?
John Duke of Norfolk
Inter their bodies as becomes their births:
Proclaim a pardon to the soldiers fled
That in submission will return to us:
And then
Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction
What traitor hears me
England hath long been mad
The brother blindly shed the brother's blood
All this divided York and Lancaster
And let their heirs
Enrich the time to come with smooth-faced peace
Abate the edge of traitors
Let them not live to taste this land's increase
That would with treason wound this fair land's peace!
Now civil wounds are stopp'd
That she may long live here
Exeunt
ACT I
PROLOGUE
Two households
From forth the fatal loins of these two foes
A pair of star-cross'd lovers take their life;
Whose misadventured piteous overthrows
Do with their death bury their parents' strife.
The fearful passage of their death-mark'd love
The which if you with patient ears attend
SCENE I. Verona. A public place.
Enter SAMPSON and GREGORY
Gregory
No
I mean
Ay
I strike quickly
But thou art not quickly moved to strike.
A dog of the house of Montague moves me.
To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand:
therefore
A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will
take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.
That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes
to the wall.
True; and therefore women
Montague's men from the wall
to the wall.
The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.
'Tis all one
have fought with the men
maids
The heads of the maids?
Ay
take it in what sense thou wilt.
They must take it in sense that feel it.
Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and
'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.
'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst
hadst been poor John. Draw thy tool! here comes
two of the house of the Montagues.
My naked weapon is out: quarrel
How! turn thy back and run?
Fear me not.
No
Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.
I will frown as I pass by
they list.
Nay
which is a disgrace to them
Enter ABRAHAM and BALTHASAR
Do you bite your thumb at us
I do bite my thumb
Do you bite your thumb at us
[Aside to GREGORY]  Is the law of our side
ay?
No.
No
bite my thumb
Do you quarrel
Quarrel sir! no
If you do
No better.
Well
Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.
Yes
You lie.
Draw
They fight
Enter BENVOLIO
Part
Put up your swords; you know not what you do.
Beats down their swords
Enter TYBALT
What
Turn thee
I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword
What
Have at thee
They fight
Enter
Clubs
Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!
Enter CAPULET in his gown
What noise is this? Give me my long sword
A crutch
My sword
Enter MONTAGUE and LADY MONTAGUE
Thou villain Capulet
Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.
Enter PRINCE
Rebellious subjects
Will they not hear? What
With purple fountains issuing from your veins
Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground
Three civil brawls
Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments
If ever you disturb our streets again
For this time
You Capulet; shall go along with me:
And
Once more
Exeunt all but MONTAGUE
Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?
Speak
Here were the servants of your adversary
I drew to part them: in the instant came
The fiery Tybalt
While we were interchanging thrusts and blows
O
Right glad I am he was not at this fray.
Madam
Peer'd forth the golden window of the east
Where
That westward rooteth from the city's side
Towards him I made
And stole into the covert of the wood:
I
Many a morning hath he there been seen
Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;
But all so soon as the all-cheering sun
Should in the furthest east begin to draw
The shady curtains from Aurora's bed
And makes himself an artificial night:
Black and portentous must this humour prove
My noble uncle
I neither know it nor can learn of him.
Have you importuned him by any means?
Both by myself and many other friends:
But he
But to himself so secret and so close
Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.
We would as willingly give cure as know.
Enter ROMEO
See
I'll know his grievance
I would thou wert so happy by thy stay
Exeunt MONTAGUE and LADY MONTAGUE
Good-morrow
Is the day so young?
But new struck nine.
Ay me! sad hours seem long.
Was that my father that went hence so fast?
It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?
Not having that
In love?
Out--
Of love?
Out of her favour
Alas
Alas
Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?
Yet tell me not
Here's much to do with hate
Why
O any thing
O heavy lightness! serious vanity!
Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!
Feather of lead
Still-waking sleep
This love feel I
Dost thou not laugh?
No
Good heart
At thy good heart's oppression.
Why
Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast
With more of thine: this love that thou hast shown
Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.
Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs;
Being purged
Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears:
What is it else? a madness most discreet
Farewell
Soft! I will go along;
An if you leave me so
Tut
This is not Romeo
Tell me in sadness
What
Groan! why
But sadly tell me who.
Bid a sick man in sadness make his will:
Ah
In sadness
I aim'd so near
A right good mark-man! And she's fair I love.
A right fair mark
Well
With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit;
And
She will not stay the siege of loving terms
O
Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?
She hath
Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
She is too fair
She hath forsworn to love
Do I live dead that live to tell it now.
Be ruled by me
O
By giving liberty unto thine eyes;
Examine other beauties.
'Tis the way
To call hers exquisite
These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows
Being black put us in mind they hide the fair;
He that is strucken blind cannot forget
The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:
Show me a mistress that is passing fair
Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair?
Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.
I'll pay that doctrine
Exeunt
SCENE II. A street.
Enter CAPULET
But Montague is bound as well as I
Of honourable reckoning are you both;
And pity 'tis you lived at odds so long.
But now
But saying o'er what I have said before:
My child is yet a stranger in the world;
She hath not seen the change of fourteen years
Younger than she are happy mothers made.
And too soon marr'd are those so early made.
The earth hath swallow'd all my hopes but she
But woo her
An she agree
Lies my consent and fair according voice.
This night I hold an old accustom'd feast
At my poor house look to behold this night
Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light:
Such comfort as do lusty young men feel
When well-apparell'd April on the heel
Of limping winter treads
Among fresh female buds shall you this night
Inherit at my house; hear all
Which on more view
May stand in number
To Servant
Go
Through fair Verona; find those persons out
Whose names are written there
Exeunt CAPULET and PARIS
Find them out whose names are written here! It is
written
yard
his pencil
sent to find those persons whose names are here
writ
person hath here writ. I must to the learned.--In good time.
Enter BENVOLIO and ROMEO
Tut
Turn giddy
One desperate grief cures with another's languish:
Take thou some new infection to thy eye
Your plaintain-leaf is excellent for that.
For what
For your broken shin.
Why
Not mad
Shut up in prison
God gi' god-den. I pray
Ay
Perhaps you have learned it without book: but
pray
Ay
Ye say honestly: rest you merry!
Stay
Reads
'Signior Martino and his wife and daughters;
County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; the lady
widow of Vitravio; Signior Placentio and his lovely
nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; mine
uncle Capulet
Rosaline; Livia; Signior Valentio and his cousin
Tybalt
assembly: whither should they come?
Up.
Whither?
To supper; to our house.
Whose house?
My master's.
Indeed
Now I'll tell you without asking: my master is the
great rich Capulet; and if you be not of the house
of Montagues
Rest you merry!
Exit
At this same ancient feast of Capulet's
Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lovest
Go thither; and
When the devout religion of mine eye
Maintains such falsehood
And these
One fairer than my love! the all-seeing sun
Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.
Tut
But in that crystal scales let there be weigh'd
Your lady's love against some other maid
That I will show you shining at this feast
I'll go along
Exeunt
SCENE III. A room in Capulet's house.
Enter LADY CAPULET and Nurse
Nurse
Now
God forbid! Where's this girl? What
Enter JULIET
How now! who calls?
Your mother.
Madam
What is your will?
This is the matter:--Nurse
I have remember'd me
Thou know'st my daughter's of a pretty age.
Faith
She's not fourteen.
I'll lay fourteen of my teeth
And yet
She is not fourteen. How long is it now
To Lammas-tide?
A fortnight and odd days.
Even or odd
Susan and she--God rest all Christian souls!--
Were of an age: well
She was too good for me: but
That shall she
'Tis since the earthquake now eleven years;
And she was wean'd
Of all the days of the year
For I had then laid wormwood to my dug
My lord and you were then at Mantua:--
Nay
Of my dug and felt it bitter
Shake quoth the dove-house: 'twas no need
And since that time it is eleven years;
For then she could stand alone; nay
For even the day before
And then my husband--God be with his soul!
A' was a merry man--took up the child:
'Yea
Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit;
Wilt thou not
To see
I warrant
And
Enough of this; I pray thee
Yes
And yet
A bump as big as a young cockerel's stone;
A parlous knock; and it cried bitterly:
'Yea
Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age;
Wilt thou not
And stint thou too
Peace
Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed:
An I might live to see thee married once
Marry
I came to talk of. Tell me
It is an honour that I dream not of.
An honour! were not I thine only nurse
Well
That you are now a maid. Thus then in brief:
The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.
A man
As all the world--why
Verona's summer hath not such a flower.
Nay
What say you? can you love the gentleman?
This night you shall behold him at our feast;
Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face
Examine every married lineament
And what obscured in this fair volume lies
Find written in the margent of his eyes.
This precious book of love
The fish lives in the sea
For fair without the fair within to hide:
That book in many's eyes doth share the glory
So shall you share all that he doth possess
No less! nay
Speak briefly
I'll look to like
But no more deep will I endart mine eye
Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.
Enter a Servant
Madam
called
the pantry
hence to wait; I beseech you
We follow thee.
Exit Servant
Juliet
Go
Exeunt
SCENE IV. A street.
Enter ROMEO
What
Or shall we on without a apology?
The date is out of such prolixity:
We'll have no Cupid hoodwink'd with a scarf
Nor no without-book prologue
After the prompter
But let them measure us by what they will;
We'll measure them a measure
Give me a torch: I am not for this ambling;
Being but heavy
Nay
Not I
With nimble soles: I have a soul of lead
So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.
You are a lover; borrow Cupid's wings
I am too sore enpierced with his shaft
To soar with his light feathers
Under love's heavy burden do I sink.
And
Too great oppression for a tender thing.
Is love a tender thing? it is too rough
If love be rough with you
Prick love for pricking
Give me a case to put my visage in:
A visor for a visor! what care I
What curious eye doth quote deformities?
Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.
Come
A torch for me: let wantons light of heart
Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels
I'll be a candle-holder
The game was ne'er so fair
Tut
If thou art dun
Of this sir-reverence love
Up to the ears. Come
Nay
I mean
We waste our lights in vain
Take our good meaning
Five times in that ere once in our five wits.
And we mean well in going to this mask;
But 'tis no wit to go.
Why
I dream'd a dream to-night.
And so did I.
Well
That dreamers often lie.
In bed asleep
O
She is the fairies' midwife
In shape no bigger than an agate-stone
On the fore-finger of an alderman
Athwart men's noses as they lie asleep;
Her wagon-spokes made of long spiders' legs
Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid;
Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut
Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub
And in this state she gallops night by night
Through lovers' brains
O'er courtiers' knees
Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose
And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail
Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep
Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck
Drums in his ear
And sleeps again. This is that very Mab
That plats the manes of horses in the night
This is the hag
This is she--
Peace
Thou talk'st of nothing.
TRUE
And more inconstant than the wind
Even now the frozen bosom of the north
This wind
Supper is done
I fear
Some consequence yet hanging in the stars
Shall bitterly begin his fearful date
With this night's revels and expire the term
Of a despised life closed in my breast
By some vile forfeit of untimely death.
But He
Strike
Exeunt

Welcome
That I have worn a visor and could tell

You are welcome

Ah
Nay
For you and I are past our dancing days:
How long is't now since last yourself and I
Were in a mask?
By'r lady

'Tis more
His son is thirty.
Will you tell me that?
His son was but a ward two years ago.
[To a Servingman]  What lady is that
enrich the hand
Of yonder knight?
I know not
O
It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night
Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope's ear;
Beauty too rich for use
So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows
The measure done
Did my heart love till now? forswear it
For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.
This
Fetch me my rapier
Come hither
Now
Why
Uncle
Young Romeo is it?
'Tis he
Content thee
He bears him like a portly gentleman;
And
To be a virtuous and well-govern'd youth:
I would not for the wealth of all the town
Here in my house do him disparagement:
Therefore be patient
It is my will
It fits
I'll not endure him.
He shall be endured:
What
Am I the master here
You'll not endure him! God shall mend my soul!
You'll make a mutiny among my guests!
You will set cock-a-hoop! you'll be the man!
Why
Go to
You are a saucy boy: is't so
This trick may chance to scathe you
You must contrary me! marry
Well said
Be quiet
I'll make you quiet. What
Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting
Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.
I will withdraw: but this intrusion shall
Now seeming sweet convert to bitter gall.
Exit
[To JULIET]  If I profane with my unworthiest hand
This holy shrine
My lips
To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.
Good pilgrim
For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch
Have not saints lips
Ay
O
They pray
Saints do not move
Then move not
Thus from my lips
Then have my lips the sin that they have took.
Sin from thy lips? O trespass sweetly urged!
Give me my sin again.
You kiss by the book.
Madam

Marry
I nursed her daughter
I tell you
Shall have the chinks.
Is she a Capulet?
O dear account! my life is my foe's debt.
Away
Ay
Nay
We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.
Is it e'en so? why
I thank you
More torches here! Come on then
Ah

Exeunt all but JULIET and Nurse
Come hither
The son and heir of old Tiberio.
What's he that now is going out of door?
Marry
What's he that follows there
I know not.
Go ask his name: if he be married.
My grave is like to be my wedding bed.
His name is Romeo
The only son of your great enemy.
My only love sprung from my only hate!
Too early seen unknown
Prodigious birth of love it is to me
What's this? what's this?
A rhyme I learn'd even now
Of one I danced withal.
One calls within 'Juliet.'
Anon
Come
