ACT II
PROLOGUE
Enter Chorus
Now old desire doth in his death-bed lie
That fair for which love groan'd for and would die
Now Romeo is beloved and loves again
Being held a foe
To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear;
And she as much in love
To meet her new-beloved any where:
But passion lends them power
Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.
Exit
SCENE I. A lane by the wall of Capulet's orchard.
Enter ROMEO
Can I go forward when my heart is here?
Turn back
He climbs the wall
Enter BENVOLIO and MERCUTIO
Romeo! my cousin Romeo!
He is wise;
And
He ran this way
Call
Nay
Romeo! humours! madman! passion! lover!
Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh:
Speak but one rhyme
Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but 'love' and 'dove;'
Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word
He heareth not
The ape is dead
I conjure thee by Rosaline's bright eyes
And the demesnes that there adjacent lie
And if he hear thee
This cannot anger him: 'twould anger him
To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle
Of some strange nature
Till she had laid it and conjured it down;
That were some spite: my invocation
Is fair and honest
I conjure only but to raise up him.
Come
Blind is his love and best befits the dark.
If love be blind
Now will he sit under a medlar tree
As maids call medlars
Romeo
An open et caetera
Romeo
This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep:
Come
Go
To seek him here that means not to be found.
Exeunt
SCENE II. Capulet's orchard.
Enter ROMEO
He jests at scars that never felt a wound.
JULIET appears above at a window
But
It is the east
Arise
Be not her maid
Her vestal livery is but sick and green
And none but fools do wear it; cast it off.
It is my lady
O
She speaks yet she says nothing: what of that?
Her eye discourses; I will answer it.
I am too bold
Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven
To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
What if her eyes were there
The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars
Would through the airy region stream so bright
That birds would sing and think it were not night.
See
O
Ay me!
She speaks:
O
As glorious to this night
As is a winged messenger of heaven
Unto the white-upturned wondering eyes
Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him
When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds
And sails upon the bosom of the air.
O Romeo
Deny thy father and refuse thy name;
Or
[Aside]  Shall I hear more
'Tis but thy name that is my enemy;
Thou art thyself
What's Montague? it is nor hand
Belonging to a man. O
What's in a name? that which we call a rose
By any other name would smell as sweet;
So Romeo would
Without that title. Romeo
Take all myself.
I take thee at thy word:
Call me but love
Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night
So stumblest on my counsel?
By a name
I know not how to tell thee who I am:
My name
Had I it written
My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words
Of that tongue's utterance
Art thou not Romeo and a Montague?
Neither
How camest thou hither
The orchard walls are high and hard to climb
With love's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls;
For stony limits cannot hold love out
Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me.
If they do see thee
Alack
Than twenty of their swords: look thou but sweet
I would not for the world they saw thee here.
I have night's cloak to hide me from their sight;
And but thou love me
My life were better ended by their hate
By whose direction found'st thou out this place?
By love
He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes.
I am no pilot; yet
As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea
Thou know'st the mask of night is on my face
For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night
Fain would I dwell on form
What I have spoke: but farewell compliment!
Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say 'Ay
And I will take thy word: yet if thou swear'st
Then say
Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won
In truth
But trust me
Than those that have more cunning to be strange.
I should have been more strange
Lady
That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--
O
What shall I swear by?
Do not swear at all;
Or
If my heart's dear love--
Well
It is too rash
Too like the lightning
Ere one can say 'It lightens.' Sweet
This bud of love
Good night
Come to thy heart as that within my breast!
O
What satisfaction canst thou have to-night?
The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.
I gave thee mine before thou didst request it:
And yet I would it were to give again.
Wouldst thou withdraw it? for what purpose
But to be frank
And yet I wish but for the thing I have:
My bounty is as boundless as the sea
Nurse calls within
I hear some noise within; dear love
Anon
Stay but a little
Exit
O blessed
Being in night
Re-enter JULIET
Three words
If that thy bent of love be honourable
And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay
And follow thee my lord throughout the world.
[Within]  Madam!
I come
[Within]  Madam!
By and by
To cease thy suit
To-morrow will I send.
So thrive my soul--
A thousand times good night!
Exit
A thousand times the worse
Love goes toward love
their books
Retiring
Re-enter JULIET
Hist! Romeo
Bondage is hoarse
Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies
It is my soul that calls upon my name:
How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night
Romeo!
My dear?
At what o'clock to-morrow
Shall I send to thee?
At the hour of nine.
I will not fail: 'tis twenty years till then.
I have forgot why I did call thee back.
Let me stand here till thou remember it.
I shall forget
And I'll still stay
'Tis almost morning; I would have thee gone:
And yet no further than a wanton's bird;
Who lets it hop a little from her hand
I would I were thy bird.
Sweet
Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
Good night
sweet sorrow
Exit above
Sleep dwell upon thine eyes
Would I were sleep and peace
Hence will I to my ghostly father's cell
Exit
SCENE III. Friar Laurence's cell.
Enter FRIAR LAURENCE
The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night
From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels:
Now
With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.
The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;
What is her burying grave that is her womb
We sucking on her natural bosom find
O
In herbs
For nought so vile that on the earth doth live
But to the earth some special good doth give
Revolts from true birth
Virtue itself turns vice
And vice sometimes by action dignified.
Within the infant rind of this small flower
Poison hath residence and medicine power:
For this
Being tasted
Two such opposed kings encamp them still
In man as well as herbs
And where the worser is predominant
Enter ROMEO
Good morrow
Benedicite!
What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
Young son
So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed:
Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye
But where unbruised youth with unstuff'd brain
Doth couch his limbs
Therefore thy earliness doth me assure
Thou art up-roused by some distemperature;
Or if not so
That last is true; the sweeter rest was mine.
God pardon sin! wast thou with Rosaline?
With Rosaline
I have forgot that name
That's my good son: but where hast thou been
I'll tell thee
I have been feasting with mine enemy
Within thy help and holy physic lies:
I bear no hatred
Be plain
Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.
Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set
On the fair daughter of rich Capulet:
As mine on hers
And all combined
By holy marriage: when and where and how
We met
Holy Saint Francis
Is Rosaline
Not truly in their hearts
Jesu Maria
Hath wash'd thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline!
How much salt water thrown away in waste
The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears
Lo
Of an old tear that is not wash'd off yet:
If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine
And art thou changed? pronounce this sentence then
Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline.
For doting
And bad'st me bury love.
Not in a grave
I pray thee
Doth grace for grace and love for love allow;
The other did not so.
O
Thy love did read by rote and could not spell.
But come
For this alliance may so happy prove
O
Wisely and slow; they stumble that run fast.
Exeunt

Where the devil should this Romeo be?

Not to his father's; I spoke with his man.
Ah
Torments him so
Tybalt
A challenge

Any man that can write may answer a letter.

dares

Why

And there she shall at Friar Laurence' cell
Be shrived and married. Here is for thy pains.
No truly sir; not a penny.
Go to; I say you shall.
This afternoon
And stay
Within this hour my man shall be with thee
And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair;
Which to the high top-gallant of my joy
Must be my convoy in the secret night.
Farewell; be trusty
Farewell; commend me to thy mistress.
Now God in heaven bless thee! Hark you
What say'st thou
Is your man secret? Did you ne'er hear say
I warrant thee
Well
is a nobleman in town
lay knife aboard; but she
see a toad
sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer
man; but
as pale as any clout in the versal world. Doth not
rosemary and Romeo begin both with a letter?
Ay
Ah. mocker! that's the dog's name; R is for
the--No; I know it begins with some other
letter:--and she hath the prettiest sententious of
it
to hear it.
Commend me to thy lady.
Ay

Peter!
Anon!
Peter

SCENE V. Capulet's orchard.
Enter JULIET
The clock struck nine when I did send the nurse;
In half an hour she promised to return.
Perchance she cannot meet him: that's not so.
O
Therefore do nimble-pinion'd doves draw love
Now is the sun upon the highmost hill
Of this day's journey
Is three long hours
Had she affections and warm youthful blood
My words would bandy her to my sweet love
But old folks
Unwieldy
O God
Enter Nurse and PETER
O honey nurse
Hast thou met with him? Send thy man away.
Peter
Exit PETER
Now
Though news be sad
If good
By playing it to me with so sour a face.
I am a-weary
Fie
I would thou hadst my bones
Nay
Jesu
Do you not see that I am out of breath?
How art thou out of breath
To say to me that thou art out of breath?
The excuse that thou dost make in this delay
Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.
Is thy news good
Say either
Let me be satisfied
Well
how to choose a man: Romeo! no
face be better than any man's
all men's; and for a hand
past compare: he is not the flower of courtesy
ways
No
What says he of our marriage? what of that?
Lord
It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces.
My back o' t' other side
Beshrew your heart for sending me about
I' faith
Sweet
Your love says
courteous
warrant
Where is my mother! why
Where should she be? How oddly thou repliest!
'Your love says
O God's lady dear!
Are you so hot? marry
Is this the poultice for my aching bones?
Henceforward do your messages yourself.
Here's such a coil! come
Have you got leave to go to shrift to-day?
I have.
Then hie you hence to Friar Laurence' cell;
There stays a husband to make you a wife:
Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks
Hie you to church; I must another way
Must climb a bird's nest soon when it is dark:
I am the drudge and toil in your delight
Go; I'll to dinner: hie you to the cell.
Hie to high fortune! Honest nurse
Exeunt
SCENE VI. Friar Laurence's cell.
Enter FRIAR LAURENCE and ROMEO
So smile the heavens upon this holy act
Amen
That one short minute gives me in her sight:
Do thou but close our hands with holy words
It is enough I may but call her mine.
These violent delights have violent ends
And in their triumph die
Is loathsome in his own deliciousness
And in the taste confounds the appetite:
Therefore love moderately; long love doth so;
Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.
Enter JULIET
Here comes the lady: O
Will ne'er wear out the everlasting flint:
A lover may bestride the gossamer
That idles in the wanton summer air
Good even to my ghostly confessor.
Romeo shall thank thee
As much to him
Ah
Be heap'd like mine and that thy skill be more
To blazon it
This neighbour air
Unfold the imagined happiness that both
Receive in either by this dear encounter.
Conceit
They are but beggars that can count their worth;
But my true love is grown to such excess
I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.
Come
For
Till holy church incorporate two in one.
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. A public place.
Enter MERCUTIO
I pray thee
The day is hot
For now
Thou art like one of those fellows that when he
enters the confines of a tavern claps me his sword
upon the table and says 'God send me no need of
thee!' and by the operation of the second cup draws
it on the drawer
Am I like such a fellow?
Come
any in Italy
soon moody to be moved.
And what to?
Nay
shortly
wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts
other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes: what
eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?
Thy head is as fun of quarrels as an egg is full of
meat
an egg for quarrelling: thou hast quarrelled with a
man for coughing in the street
wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun:
didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing
his new doublet before Easter? with another
tying his new shoes with old riband? and yet thou
wilt tutor me from quarrelling!
An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art
should buy the fee-simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.
The fee-simple! O simple!
By my head
By my heel
Enter TYBALT and others
Follow me close
Gentlemen
And but one word with one of us? couple it with
something; make it a word and a blow.
You shall find me apt enough to that
will give me occasion.
Could you not take some occasion without giving?
Mercutio
Consort! what
thou make minstrels of us
discords: here's my fiddlestick; here's that shall
make you dance. 'Zounds
We talk here in the public haunt of men:
Either withdraw unto some private place
Men's eyes were made to look
I will not budge for no man's pleasure
Enter ROMEO
Well
But I'll be hanged
Marry
Your worship in that sense may call him 'man.'
Romeo
No better term than this
Tybalt
Doth much excuse the appertaining rage
To such a greeting: villain am I none;
Therefore farewell; I see thou know'st me not.
Boy
That thou hast done me; therefore turn and draw.
I do protest
And so
As dearly as my own
O calm
Alla stoccata carries it away.
Draws
Tybalt
What wouldst thou have with me?
Good king of cats
lives; that I mean to make bold withal
shall use me hereafter
eight. Will you pluck your sword out of his pitcher
by the ears? make haste
ears ere it be out.
I am for you.
Drawing
Gentle Mercutio
Come
They fight
Draw
Gentlemen

Forbidden bandying in Verona streets:
Hold
TYBALT under ROMEO's arm stabs MERCUTIO
I am hurt.

Ay

Help me into some house
They have made worms' meat of me: I have it

This gentleman
In my behalf; my reputation stain'd
With Tybalt's slander
Hath been my kinsman! O sweet Juliet
And in my temper soften'd valour's steel!
Re-enter BENVOLIO
O Romeo
That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds
This day's black fate on more days doth depend;
This but begins the woe
Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.
Alive
Away to heaven
Re-enter TYBALT
Now
Is but a little way above our heads
Either thou
Thou
This shall determine that.
They fight; TYBALT falls
Romeo
The citizens are up
Stand not amazed: the prince will doom thee death
O
Why dost thou stay?
Exit ROMEO
Enter Citizens
Which way ran he that kill'd Mercutio?
Tybalt
There lies that Tybalt.
Up
I charge thee in the princes name
Enter Prince
Where are the vile beginners of this fray?
O noble prince
The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl:
There lies the man
Tybalt
O prince! O cousin! husband! O
O my dear kinsman! Prince
O cousin
Benvolio
Tybalt
Romeo that spoke him fair
How nice the quarrel was
Your high displeasure: all this uttered
With gentle breath
Of Tybalt deaf to peace
With piercing steel at bold Mercutio's breast
Cold death aside
It back to Tybalt
his tongue
An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life
Of stout Mercutio
But by and by comes back to Romeo
Could draw to part them
And
This is the truth
He is a kinsman to the Montague;
Affection makes him false; he speaks not true:
Some twenty of them fought in this black strife
I beg for justice
Romeo slew Tybalt
Romeo slew him
Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?
Not Romeo
His fault concludes but what the law should end
And for that offence
Immediately we do exile him hence:
I have an interest in your hate's proceeding
But I'll amerce you with so strong a fine
That you shall all repent the loss of mine:
I will be deaf to pleading and excuses;
Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses:
Therefore use none: let Romeo hence in haste
Bear hence this body and attend our will:
Mercy but murders
Exeunt
SCENE II. Capulet's orchard.
Enter JULIET
Gallop apace
As Phaethon would whip you to the west
Spread thy close curtain
Leap to these arms
Lovers can see to do their amorous rites
By their own beauties; or
Hood my unmann'd blood
Come
For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night
Whiter than new snow on a raven's back.
Come
That all the world will be in love with night
And pay no worship to the garish sun.
O
As is the night before some festival
To an impatient child that hath new robes
And may not wear them. O
But Romeo's name speaks heavenly eloquence.
Enter Nurse
Now
That Romeo bid thee fetch?
Ay
Throws them down
Ay me! what news? why dost thou wring thy hands?
Ah
We are undone
Alack the day! he's gone
Can heaven be so envious?
Romeo can
Who ever would have thought it? Romeo!
What devil art thou
This torture should be roar'd in dismal hell.
Hath Romeo slain himself? say thou but 'I
And that bare vowel 'I' shall poison more
Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice:
I am not I
Or those eyes shut
If he be slain
Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.
I saw the wound
God save the mark!--here on his manly breast:
A piteous corse
Pale
O
To prison
Vile earth
And thou and Romeo press one heavy bier!
O Tybalt
O courteous Tybalt! honest gentleman!
That ever I should live to see thee dead!
What storm is this that blows so contrary?
Is Romeo slaughter'd
My dear-loved cousin
Then
For who is living
Tybalt is gone
Romeo that kill'd him
O God! did Romeo's hand shed Tybalt's blood?
It did
O serpent heart
Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave?
Beautiful tyrant! fiend angelical!
Dove-feather'd raven! wolvish-ravening lamb!
Despised substance of divinest show!
Just opposite to what thou justly seem'st
O nature
In moral paradise of such sweet flesh?
Was ever book containing such vile matter
So fairly bound? O that deceit should dwell
In such a gorgeous palace!
There's no trust
Ah
These griefs
Shame come to Romeo!
Blister'd be thy tongue
For such a wish! he was not born to shame:
Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit;
For 'tis a throne where honour may be crown'd
Sole monarch of the universal earth.
O
Will you speak well of him that kill'd your cousin?
Shall I speak ill of him that is my husband?
Ah
But
That villain cousin would have kill'd my husband:
Back
Your tributary drops belong to woe
My husband lives
And Tybalt's dead
All this is comfort; wherefore weep I then?
Some word there was
But
'Tybalt is dead
That 'banished
Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts. Tybalt's death
Was woe enough
Or
And needly will be rank'd with other griefs
Thy father
But with a rear-ward following Tybalt's death
There is no end
Where is my father
Weeping and wailing over Tybalt's corse:
Will you go to them? I will bring you thither.
Wash they his wounds with tears: mine shall be spent
Take up those cords: poor ropes
He made you for a highway to my bed;
But I
Come
And death
Hie to your chamber: I'll find Romeo
To comfort you: I wot well where he is.
Hark ye
I'll to him; he is hid at Laurence' cell.
O
Exeunt
SCENE III. Friar Laurence's cell.
Enter FRIAR LAURENCE
Romeo
Affliction is enamour'd of thy parts
Enter ROMEO
Father
What sorrow craves acquaintance at my hand
Too familiar
Is my dear son with such sour company:
I bring thee tidings of the prince's doom.
What less than dooms-day is the prince's doom?
A gentler judgment vanish'd from his lips
Ha
For exile hath more terror in his look
Hence from Verona art thou banished:
Be patient
There is no world without Verona walls
Hence-banished is banish'd from the world
O deadly sin! O rude unthankfulness!
Thy fault our law calls death; but the kind prince
This is dear mercy
'Tis torture
And little mouse
But Romeo may not: more validity
In carrion-flies than Romeo: they my seize
On the white wonder of dear Juliet's hand
And steal immortal blessing from her lips
But Romeo may not; he is banished:
Flies may do this
They are free men
And say'st thou yet that exile is not death?
Hadst thou no poison mix'd
O friar
Howlings attend it: how hast thou the heart
Thou fond mad man
O
I'll give thee armour to keep off that word:
Adversity's sweet milk
Yet 'banished'? Hang up philosophy!
Unless philosophy can make a Juliet
O
How should they
Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.
Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel:
Wert thou as young as I
Knocking within
Arise; one knocks; good Romeo
Not I; unless the breath of heartsick groans
Knocking
Hark
Thou wilt be taken. Stay awhile! Stand up;
Knocking
Run to my study. By and by! God's will
Knocking
Who knocks so hard? whence come you? what's your will?
[Within]  Let me come in
my errand;
I come from Lady Juliet.
Welcome
Enter Nurse
O holy friar
There on the ground
O
Piteous predicament! Even so lies she
Stand up
For Juliet's sake
Why should you fall into so deep an O?
Nurse!
Ah sir! ah sir! Well
Spakest thou of Juliet? how is it with her?
Doth she not think me an old murderer
With blood removed but little from her own?
Where is she? and how doth she? and what says
My conceal'd lady to our cancell'd love?
O
And now falls on her bed; and then starts up
As if that name
Murder'd her kinsman. O
Doth my name lodge? tell me
The hateful mansion.
Drawing his sword
Hold thy desperate hand:
Art thou a man? thy form cries out thou art:
Thy tears are womanish; thy wild acts denote
The unreasonable fury of a beast:
Unseemly woman in a seeming man!
Or ill-beseeming beast in seeming both!
Thou hast amazed me: by my holy order
Hast thou slain Tybalt? wilt thou slay thyself?
And stay thy lady too that lives in thee
Why rail'st thou on thy birth
Since birth
In thee at once; which thou at once wouldst lose.
Fie
Which
Which should bedeck thy shape
Thy noble shape is but a form of wax
Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury
Thy wit
What
There art thou happy: Tybalt would kill thee
The law that threaten'd death becomes thy friend
And turns it to exile; there art thou happy:
A pack of blessings lights up upon thy back;
Happiness courts thee in her best array;
But
Take heed
Go
But look thou stay not till the watch be set
Where thou shalt live
To blaze your marriage
With twenty hundred thousand times more joy
Than thou went'st forth in lamentation.
Go before
And bid her hasten all the house to bed
Romeo is coming.
O Lord
To hear good counsel: O
My lord
Do so
Here
Hie you
Exit
How well my comfort is revived by this!
Go hence; good night; and here stands all your state:
Either be gone before the watch be set
Sojourn in Mantua; I'll find out your man
Every good hap to you that chances here:
Give me thy hand; 'tis late: farewell; good night.
But that a joy past joy calls out on me
Exeunt
SCENE IV. A room in Capulet's house.
Enter CAPULET
Things have fall'n out
Look you
'Tis very late
I promise you
These times of woe afford no time to woo.
Madam
I will
To-night she is mew'd up to her heaviness.
Sir Paris
Of my child's love: I think she will be ruled
In all respects by me; nay
Wife
Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love;
And bid her
But
Monday
Will you be ready? do you like this haste?
We'll keep no great ado
For
Therefore we'll have some half a dozen friends
My lord
Well get you gone: o' Thursday be it
Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed
Farewell
Afore me! it is so very very late
Good night.
Exeunt
SCENE V. Capulet's orchard.
Enter ROMEO and JULIET above
Wilt thou be gone? it is not yet near day:
It was the nightingale
Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate-tree:
Believe me
It was the lark
Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east:
Night's candles are burnt out
Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops.
I must be gone and live
Yon light is not day-light
It is some meteor that the sun exhales
Therefore stay yet; thou need'st not to be gone.
Let me be ta'en
I am content
I'll say yon grey is not the morning's eye
Nor that is not the lark
The vaulty heaven so high above our heads:
I have more care to stay than will to go:
Come
How is't
It is
It is the lark that sings so out of tune
Some say the lark makes sweet division;
This doth not so
Some say the lark and loathed toad change eyes
Since arm from arm that voice doth us affray
More light and light; more dark and dark our woes!
Enter Nurse
Madam!
Nurse?
Your lady mother is coming to your chamber:
The day is broke; be wary
Exit
Then
Farewell
He goeth down
Art thou gone so? love
I must hear from thee every day in the hour
O
Ere I again behold my Romeo!
Farewell!
I will omit no opportunity
That may convey my greetings
O think'st thou we shall ever meet again?
I doubt it not; and all these woes shall serve
For sweet discourses in our time to come.
O God
Methinks I see thee
Either my eyesight fails
And trust me
Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu
Exit
O fortune
If thou art fickle
That is renown'd for faith? Be fickle
For then
[Within]         Ho
Who is't that calls? is it my lady mother?
Is she not down so late
What unaccustom'd cause procures her hither?
Enter LADY CAPULET
Why
Madam
Evermore weeping for your cousin's death?
What
An if thou couldst
Therefore
But much of grief shows still some want of wit.
Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.
So shall you feel the loss
Which you weep for.
Feeling so the loss
Well
What villain madam?
That same villain
[Aside]  Villain and he be many miles asunder.--
God Pardon him! I do
And yet no man like he doth grieve my heart.
That is
Ay
Would none but I might venge my cousin's death!
We will have vengeance for it
Then weep no more. I'll send to one in Mantua
And then
Indeed
With Romeo
Is my poor heart for a kinsman vex'd.
Madam
To bear a poison
That Romeo should
To hear him named
To wreak the love I bore my cousin
Upon his body that slaughter'd him!
Find thou the means
But now I'll tell thee joyful tidings
And joy comes well in such a needy time:
What are they
Well
One who
Madam
Marry
Now
I wonder at this haste; that I must wed
Ere he
I pray you
Here comes your father; tell him so yourself
Enter CAPULET and Nurse
When the sun sets
But for the sunset of my brother's son
It rains downright.
How now! a conduit
Evermore showering? In one little body
Thou counterfeit'st a bark
For still thy eyes
Who
Thy tempest-tossed body. How now
Have you deliver'd to her our decree?
Ay
I would the fool were married to her grave!
Soft! take me with you
How! will she none? doth she not give us thanks?
Is she not proud? doth she not count her blest
So worthy a gentleman to be her bridegroom?
Not proud
Proud can I never be of what I hate;
But thankful even for hate
How now
'Proud
And yet 'not proud
Out
You tallow-face!
Fie
Good father
Hang thee
I tell thee what: get thee to church o' Thursday
Speak not
My fingers itch. Wife
That God had lent us but this only child;
But now I see this one is one too much
Out on her
God in heaven bless her!
You are to blame
And why
I speak no treason.
O
May not one speak?
Peace
Utter your gravity o'er a gossip's bowl;
For here we need it not.
You are too hot.
God's bread! it makes me mad:
Day
To have her match'd: and having now provided
A gentleman of noble parentage
And then to have a wretched puling fool
But
Graze where you will you shall not house with me:
Look to't
Thursday is near; lay hand on heart
An you be mine
And you be not
the streets
Trust to't
Exit
Is there no pity sitting in the clouds
O
Delay this marriage for a month
Or
In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.
Talk not to me
Do as thou wilt
Exit
O God!--O nurse
My husband is on earth
How shall that faith return again to earth
By leaving earth? comfort me
Alack
Upon so soft a subject as myself!
What say'st thou? hast thou not a word of joy?
Some comfort
Faith
Romeo is banish'd; and all the world to nothing
Or
Then
O
Romeo's a dishclout to him: an eagle
As Paris hath. Beshrew my very heart
Speakest thou from thy heart?
And from my soul too;
Or else beshrew them both.
Amen!
What?
Well
Go in: and tell my lady I am gone
Marry
Exit
Ancient damnation! O most wicked fiend!
Is it more sin to wish me thus forsworn
Which she hath praised him with above compare
So many thousand times? Go
Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain.
I'll to the friar
If all else fail
Exit
ACT IV
SCENE I. Friar Laurence's cell.
Enter FRIAR LAURENCE and PARIS
On Thursday
My father Capulet will have it so;
And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.
You say you do not know the lady's mind:
Uneven is the course
Immoderately she weeps for Tybalt's death
For Venus smiles not in a house of tears.
Now
That she doth give her sorrow so much sway
Which
Now do you know the reason of this haste.
[Aside]  I would I knew not why it should be slow'd.
Look
Enter JULIET
Happily met
That may be
That may be must be
What must be shall be.
That's a certain text.
Come you to make confession to this father?
To answer that
Do not deny to him that you love me.
I will confess to you that I love him.
So will ye
If I do so
Poor soul
The tears have got small victory by that;
For it was bad enough before their spite.
Thou wrong'st it
That is no slander
And what I spake
Thy face is mine
It may be so
Are you at leisure
Or shall I come to you at evening mass?
My leisure serves me
My lord
God shield I should disturb devotion!
Juliet
Till then
Exit
O shut the door! and when thou hast done so
Ah
It strains me past the compass of my wits:
I hear thou must
Tell me not
If
God join'd my heart and Romeo's
And ere this hand
Turn to another
Therefore
Shall play the umpire
Which the commission of thy years and art
Could to no issue of true honour bring.
Be not so long to speak; I long to die
Hold
As that is desperate which we would prevent.
If
A thing like death to chide away this shame
And
O
Or walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk
Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears;
Or shut me nightly in a charnel-house
Or bid me go into a new-made grave
And hide me with a dead man in his shroud;
Things that
And I will do it without fear or doubt
Hold
To marry Paris: Wednesday is to-morrow:
To-morrow night look that thou lie alone;
Let not thy nurse lie with thee in thy chamber:
Take thou this vial
When presently through all thy veins shall run
A cold and drowsy humour
Shall keep his native progress
No warmth
The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade
To paly ashes
Each part
And in this borrow'd likeness of shrunk death
Thou shalt continue two and forty hours
Now
To rouse thee from thy bed
Then
Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault
Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.
In the mean time
Will watch thy waking
Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua.
And this shall free thee from this present shame;
If no inconstant toy
Give me
Hold; get you gone
In this resolve: I'll send a friar with speed
To Mantua
Love give me strength! and strength shall help afford.
Farewell
Exeunt
SCENE II. Hall in Capulet's house.
Enter CAPULET
So many guests invite as here are writ.
Exit First Servant
Sirrah
You shall have none ill
can lick their fingers.
How canst thou try them so?
Marry
own fingers: therefore he that cannot lick his
fingers goes not with me.
Go
Exit Second Servant
We shall be much unfurnished for this time.
What
Ay
Well
A peevish self-will'd harlotry it is.
See where she comes from shrift with merry look.
Enter JULIET
How now
Where I have learn'd me to repent the sin
Of disobedient opposition
To you and your behests
By holy Laurence to fall prostrate here
Henceforward I am ever ruled by you.
Send for the county; go tell him of this:
I'll have this knot knit up to-morrow morning.
I met the youthful lord at Laurence' cell;
And gave him what becomed love I might
Why
This is as't should be. Let me see the county;
Ay
Now
Nurse
As you think fit to furnish me to-morrow?
No
Go
Exeunt JULIET and Nurse
We shall be short in our provision:
'Tis now near night.
Tush
Go thou to Juliet
I'll not to bed to-night; let me alone;
I'll play the housewife for this once. What
They are all forth. Well
To County Paris
Against to-morrow: my heart is wondrous light
Exeunt
SCENE III. Juliet's chamber.
Enter JULIET and Nurse
Ay
To move the heavens to smile upon my state
Enter LADY CAPULET
What
No
As are behoveful for our state to-morrow:
So please you
For
Good night:
Get thee to bed
Exeunt LADY CAPULET and Nurse
Farewell! God knows when we shall meet again.
I have a faint cold fear thrills through my veins
I'll call them back again to comfort me:
Nurse! What should she do here?
My dismal scene I needs must act alone.
Come
What if this mixture do not work at all?
Shall I be married then to-morrow morning?
No
Laying down her dagger
What if it be a poison
Subtly hath minister'd to have me dead
I fear it is: and yet
How if
Come to redeem me? there's a fearful point!
Shall I not
Or
As in a vault
Of all my buried ancestors are packed:
Where bloody Tybalt
Alack
O
And madly play with my forefather's joints?
And pluck the mangled Tybalt from his shroud?
And
O
Seeking out Romeo
Upon a rapier's point: stay
Romeo
She falls upon her bed
SCENE IV. Hall in Capulet's house.
Enter LADY CAPULET and Nurse
Hold
They call for dates and quinces in the pastry.
Enter CAPULET
Come
Look to the baked meats
Spare not for the cost.
Go
For this night's watching.
No
All night for lesser cause
Ay
But I will watch you from such watching now.
Exeunt LADY CAPULET and Nurse
A jealous hood
Enter three or four Servingmen
Now
Things for the cook
Make haste
Exit First Servant
Sirrah
Call Peter
I have a head

Mass
Thou shalt be logger-head. Good faith
The county will be here with music straight
Music within
Nurse! Wife! What

I'll go and chat with Paris: hie

SCENE V. Juliet's chamber.
Enter Nurse
Mistress! what
Why
Why
What
Sleep for a week; for the next night
I must needs wake her. Madam
Ay
He'll fright you up
Undraws the curtains
What
I must needs wake you; Lady! lady! lady!
Alas
O
Some aqua vitae
Enter LADY CAPULET
What noise is here?
O lamentable day!
What is the matter?
Look
O me
Help
Enter CAPULET
For shame
She's dead
Alack the day
Ha! let me see her: out
Her blood is settled
Life and these lips have long been separated:
Death lies on her like an untimely frost
Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.
O lamentable day!
O woful time!
Death
Enter FRIAR LAURENCE and PARIS
Come
Ready to go
O son! the night before thy wedding-day
Hath Death lain with thy wife. There she lies
Death is my son-in-law
My daughter he hath wedded: I will die
Have I thought long to see this morning's face
Accursed
Most miserable hour that e'er time saw
In lasting labour of his pilgrimage!
But one
O woe! O woful
Most lamentable day
O day! O day! O day! O hateful day!
Never was seen so black a day as this:
O woful day
Beguiled
Most detestable death
O love! O life! not life
Despised
Uncomfortable time
To murder
O child! O child! my soul
Dead art thou! Alack! my child is dead;
And with my child my joys are buried.
Peace
In these confusions. Heaven and yourself
Had part in this fair maid; now heaven hath all
Your part in her you could not keep from death
The most you sought was her promotion;
For 'twas your heaven she should be advanced:
And weep ye now
Above the clouds
O
She's not well married that lives married long;
But she's best married that dies married young.
Dry up your tears
On this fair corse; and
For though fond nature bids us an lament
All things that we ordained festival
Our instruments to melancholy bells
Sir
And go
To follow this fair corse unto her grave:
The heavens do lour upon you for some ill;
Move them no more by crossing their high will.
Exeunt CAPULET
Faith
Honest goodfellows
For
Exit
Ay
Enter PETER
Musicians
ease:' O

O
heart is full of woe:' O
Not a dump we; 'tis no time to play now.
You will not
No.
I will then give it you soundly.
What will you give us?
No money
I will give you the minstrel.

your pate. I will carry no crotchets: I'll re you
An you re us and fa us

with an iron wit
me like men:

Marry

Faith
O
for you. It is 'music with her silver sound

With speedy help doth lend redress.'

What a pestilent knave is this same!

mourners

ACT V
SCENE I. Mantua. A street.
Enter ROMEO
If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep
My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne;
And all this day an unaccustom'd spirit
Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thoughts.
I dreamt my lady came and found me dead--
Strange dream
to think!--
And breathed such life with kisses in my lips
Ah me! how sweet is love itself possess'd
Enter BALTHASAR
News from Verona!--How now
Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?
How doth my lady? Is my father well?
How fares my Juliet? that I ask again;
For nothing can be ill
Then she is well
Her body sleeps in Capel's monument
I saw her laid low in her kindred's vault
O
Is it even so? then I defy you
Thou know'st my lodging: get me ink and paper
I do beseech you
Your looks are pale and wild
Some misadventure.
Tush
Leave me
Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?
No
No matter: get thee gone
Exit BALTHASAR
Well
Let's see for means: O mischief
To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!
I do remember an apothecary
And hereabouts he dwells
In tatter'd weeds
And in his needy shop a tortoise hung
Of ill-shaped fishes; and about his shelves
A beggarly account of empty boxes
Noting this penury
'An if a man did need a poison now
O
And this same needy man must sell it me.
As I remember
Being holiday
What
Enter Apothecary
Who calls so loud?
Come hither
Hold
A dram of poison
As will disperse itself through all the veins
That the life-weary taker may fall dead
And that the trunk may be discharged of breath
As violently as hasty powder fired
Doth hurry from the fatal cannon's womb.
Such mortal drugs I have; but Mantua's law
Is death to any he that utters them.
Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness
The world is not thy friend nor the world's law;
The world affords no law to make thee rich;
Then be not poor
My poverty
I pay thy poverty
Put this in any liquid thing you will
Of twenty men
There is thy gold
I sell thee poison; thou hast sold me none.
Farewell: buy food
Come
To Juliet's grave; for there must I use thee.
Exeunt
SCENE II. Friar Laurence's cell.
Enter FRIAR JOHN
Holy Franciscan friar! brother
Enter FRIAR LAURENCE
This same should be the voice of Friar John.
Welcome from Mantua: what says Romeo?
Or
Going to find a bare-foot brother out
One of our order
Where the infectious pestilence did reign
So that my speed to Mantua there was stay'd.
Who bare my letter
I could not send it
Nor get a messenger to bring it thee
Unhappy fortune! by my brotherhood
Of dear import
May do much danger. Friar John
Get me an iron crow
Unto my cell.
Brother
Exit
Now must I to the monument alone;
Within three hours will fair Juliet wake:
She will beshrew me much that Romeo
Hath had no notice of these accidents;
But I will write again to Mantua
Poor living corse
Exit
SCENE III. A churchyard; in it a tomb belonging to the Capulets.
Enter PARIS
Give me thy torch
Yet put it out
Under yond yew-trees lay thee all along
So shall no foot upon the churchyard tread
Give me those flowers. Do as I bid thee
[Aside]  I am almost afraid to stand alone
Here in the churchyard; yet I will adventure.
Retires
Sweet flower
O woe! thy canopy is dust and stones;--
Which with sweet water nightly I will dew
The obsequies that I for thee will keep
Nightly shall be to strew thy grave and weep.
The Page whistles
The boy gives warning something doth approach.
What cursed foot wanders this way to-night
What with a torch! muffle me
Retires
Enter ROMEO and BALTHASAR
Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.
Hold
See thou deliver it to my lord and father.
Give me the light: upon thy life
Why I descend into this bed of death
But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger
A precious ring
In dear employment: therefore hence
But if thou
In what I further shall intend to do
And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs:
The time and my intents are savage-wild
Than empty tigers or the roaring sea.
I will be gone
So shalt thou show me friendship. Take thou that:
Live
[Aside]  For all this same
His looks I fear
Retires
Thou detestable maw
Opens the tomb
This is that banish'd haughty Montague
And here is come to do some villanous shame
To the dead bodies: I will apprehend him.
Comes forward
Stop thy unhallow'd toil
Can vengeance be pursued further than death?
Condemned villain
Obey
I must indeed; and therefore came I hither.
Good gentle youth
Fly hence
Let them affright thee. I beseech thee
By heaven
For I come hither arm'd against myself:
Stay not
I do defy thy conjurations
Wilt thou provoke me? then have at thee
They fight
O Lord
Exit
O
Falls
If thou be merciful
Dies
In faith
Mercutio's kinsman
What said my man
Did not attend him as we rode? I think
He told me Paris should have married Juliet:
Said he not so? or did I dream it so?
Or am I mad
I'll bury thee in a triumphant grave;
A grave? O no! a lantern
This vault a feasting presence full of light.
Death
Laying PARIS in the tomb
How oft when men are at the point of death
Have they been merry! which their keepers call
A lightning before death: O
Call this a lightning? O my love! my wife!
Death
Thou art not conquer'd; beauty's ensign yet
Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks
Tybalt
O
To sunder his that was thine enemy?
Forgive me
That unsubstantial death is amorous
Thee here in dark to be his paramour?
For fear of that
And never from this palace of dim night
Depart again: here
With worms that are thy chamber-maids; O
Will I set up my everlasting rest
From this world-wearied flesh. Eyes
Arms
The doors of breath
A dateless bargain to engrossing death!
Come
Thou desperate pilot
The dashing rocks thy sea-sick weary bark!
Here's to my love!
Drinks
O true apothecary!
Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.
Dies
Enter
Saint Francis be my speed! how oft to-night
Have my old feet stumbled at graves! Who's there?
Here's one
Bliss be upon you! Tell me
To grubs and eyeless skulls? as I discern
It doth so
Who is it?
Romeo.
How long hath he been there?
Full half an hour.
Go with me to the vault.
I dare not
My master knows not but I am gone hence;
And fearfully did menace me with death
Stay
O
As I did sleep under this yew-tree here
Romeo!
Advances
Alack
The stony entrance of this sepulchre?
What mean these masterless and gory swords
To lie discolour'd by this place of peace?
Enters the tomb
Romeo! O
And steep'd in blood? Ah
Is guilty of this lamentable chance!
The lady stirs.
JULIET wakes
O comfortable friar! where is my lord?
I do remember well where I should be
Noise within
I hear some noise. Lady
Of death
A greater power than we can contradict
Hath thwarted our intents. Come
Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead;
And Paris too. Come
Among a sisterhood of holy nuns:
Stay not to question
Come
I dare no longer stay.
Go
Exit FRIAR LAURENCE
What's here? a cup
Poison
O churl! drunk all
To help me after? I will kiss thy lips;
Haply some poison yet doth hang on them
Kisses him
Thy lips are warm.
[Within]  Lead
Yea
Snatching ROMEO's dagger
This is thy sheath;
Stabs herself
there rust
Falls on ROMEO's body
Enter Watch
This is the place; there
The ground is bloody; search about the churchyard:
Go
Pitiful sight! here lies the county slain
Go
Raise up the Montagues: some others search:
We see the ground whereon these woes do lie;
But the true ground of all these piteous woes
We cannot without circumstance descry.
Re-enter some of the Watch
Here's Romeo's man; we found him in the churchyard.
Hold him in safety
Re-enter others of the Watch
Here is a friar
We took this mattock and this spade from him
A great suspicion: stay the friar too.
Enter the PRINCE and Attendants
What misadventure is so early up
Enter CAPULET
What should it be
The people in the street cry Romeo
What fear is this which startles in our ears?
Sovereign
And Romeo dead; and Juliet
Search
Here is a friar
With instruments upon them
These dead men's tombs.
O heavens! O wife
This dagger hath mista'en--for
Is empty on the back of Montague
And it mis-sheathed in my daughter's bosom!
O me! this sight of death is as a bell
Enter MONTAGUE and others
Come
Alas
Grief of my son's exile hath stopp'd her breath:
What further woe conspires against mine age?
Look
O thou untaught! what manners is in this?
To press before thy father to a grave?
Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while
true descent;
And then will I be general of your woes
Bring forth the parties of suspicion.
I am the greatest
Doth make against me of this direful murder;
And here I stand
Myself condemned and myself excused.
Then say at once what thou dost know in this.
I will be brief
Is not so long as is a tedious tale.
Romeo
And she
I married them; and their stol'n marriage-day
Was Tybalt's dooms-day
Banish'd the new-made bridegroom from the city
You
To County Paris: then comes she to me
To rid her from this second marriage
Then gave I her
As I intended
The form of death: meantime I writ to Romeo
But he which bore my letter
Return'd my letter back. Then all alone
At the prefixed hour of her waking
Meaning to keep her closely at my cell
But when I came
Of her awaking
The noble Paris and true Romeo dead.
She wakes; and I entreated her come forth
But then a noise did scare me from the tomb;
And she
All this I know; and to the marriage
Her nurse is privy: and
Miscarried by my fault
Be sacrificed
We still have known thee for a holy man.
Where's Romeo's man? what can he say in this?
I brought my master news of Juliet's death;
And then in post he came from Mantua
To this same place
This letter he early bid me give his father
Give me the letter; I will look on it.
Where is the county's page
Sirrah
He came with flowers to strew his lady's grave;
And bid me stand aloof
Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb;
And by and by my master drew on him;
And then I ran away to call the watch.
This letter doth make good the friar's words
And here he writes that he did buy a poison
Of a poor 'pothecary
Came to this vault to die
Where be these enemies? Capulet! Montague!
See
And I for winking at your discords too
Have lost a brace of kinsmen: all are punish'd.
O brother Montague
This is my daughter's jointure
Can I demand.
But I can give thee more:
For I will raise her statue in pure gold;
That while Verona by that name is known
As that of true and faithful Juliet.
As rich shall Romeo's by his lady's lie;
Poor sacrifices of our enmity!
A glooming peace this morning with it brings;
The sun
Go hence
Some shall be pardon'd
For never was a story of more woe
Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.
Exeunt
SCENE I. Before an alehouse on a heath.
Enter Hostess and SLY
I'll pheeze you
A pair of stocks
Ye are a baggage: the Slys are no rogues; look in
the chronicles; we came in with Richard Conqueror.
Therefore paucas pallabris; let the world slide: sessa!
You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?
No
bed
I know my remedy; I must go fetch the
third--borough.
Exit
Third
by law: I'll not budge an inch
Falls asleep
Horns winded. Enter a Lord from hunting
Huntsman
Brach Merriman
And couple Clowder with the deep--mouth'd brach.
Saw'st thou not
At the hedge-corner
I would not lose the dog for twenty pound.
Why
He cried upon it at the merest loss
And twice to-day pick'd out the dullest scent:
Trust me
Thou art a fool: if Echo were as fleet
But sup them well and look unto them all:
To-morrow I intend to hunt again.
I will
What's here? one dead
He breathes
O monstrous beast! how like a swine he lies!
Grim death
Sirs
What think you
Believe me
It would seem strange unto him when he waked.
Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy.
Then take him up and manage well the jest:
Carry him gently to my fairest chamber
And hang it round with all my wanton pictures:
Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters
And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet:
Procure me music ready when he wakes
And if he chance to speak
And with a low submissive reverence
Say 'What is it your honour will command?'
Let one attend him with a silver basin
Full of rose-water and bestrew'd with flowers
Some one be ready with a costly suit
And ask him what apparel he will wear;
Another tell him of his hounds and horse
Persuade him that he hath been lunatic;
And when he says he is
This do and do it kindly
It will be pastime passing excellent
My lord
He is no less than what we say he is.
Take him up gently and to bed with him;
And each one to his office when he wakes.
Some bear out SLY. A trumpet sounds
Sirrah
Exit Servingman
Belike
Re-enter Servingman
How now! who is it?
An't please your honour
That offer service to your lordship.
Bid them come near.
Enter Players
Now
We thank your honour.
Do you intend to stay with me tonight?
So please your lordship to accept our duty.
With all my heart. This fellow I remember
'Twas where you woo'd the gentlewoman so well:
I have forgot your name; but
Was aptly fitted and naturally perform'd.
I think 'twas Soto that your honour means.
'Tis very true: thou didst it excellent.
Well
The rather for I have some sport in hand
Wherein your cunning can assist me much.
There is a lord will hear you play to-night:
But I am doubtful of your modesties;
Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior
For yet his honour never heard a play--
You break into some merry passion
And so offend him; for I tell you
Fear not
Go
Let them want nothing that my house affords.
Exit one with the Players
Sirrah
That done
And call him 'madam
Tell him from me
Unto their lords
Such duty to the drunkard let him do
With soft low tongue and lowly courtesy
May show her duty and make known her love?'
And then with kind embracements
To see her noble lord restored to health
No better than a poor and loathsome beggar:
And if the boy have not a woman's gift
To rain a shower of commanded tears
Shall in despite enforce a watery eye.
See this dispatch'd with all the haste thou canst:
Anon I'll give thee more instructions.
Exit a Servingman
I know the boy will well usurp the grace
I long to hear him call the drunkard husband
When they do homage to this simple peasant.
I'll in to counsel them; haply my presence
May well abate the over-merry spleen
Which otherwise would grow into extremes.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A bedchamber in the Lord's house.
Enter aloft SLY
For God's sake
Will't please your lordship drink a cup of sack?
Will't please your honour taste of these conserves?
What raiment will your honour wear to-day?
I am Christophero Sly; call not me 'honour' nor
'lordship:' I ne'er drank sack in my life; and if
you give me any conserves
beef: ne'er ask me what raiment I'll wear; for I
have no more doublets than backs
than legs
toes look through the over-leather.
Heaven cease this idle humour in your honour!
O
What
Sly
pedlar
bear-herd
Ask Marian Hacket
she know me not: if she say I am not fourteen pence
on the score for sheer ale
lyingest knave in Christendom. What! I am not
bestraught: here's--
O
O
Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house
O noble lord
And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.
Look how thy servants do attend on thee
Wilt thou have music? hark! Apollo plays
And twenty caged nightingales do sing:
Or wilt thou sleep? we'll have thee to a couch
Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed
On purpose trimm'd up for Semiramis.
Say thou wilt walk; we will bestrew the ground:
Or wilt thou ride? thy horses shall be trapp'd
Dost thou love hawking? thou hast hawks will soar
Above the morning lark or wilt thou hunt?
Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them
And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.
Say thou wilt course; thy greyhounds are as swift
As breathed stags
Dost thou love pictures? we will fetch thee straight
Adonis painted by a running brook
We'll show thee Io as she was a maid
Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood
Thou art a lord
Thou hast a lady far more beautiful
Than any woman in this waning age.
And till the tears that she hath shed for thee
Like envious floods o'er-run her lovely face
And yet she is inferior to none.
Am I a lord? and have I such a lady?
Or do I dream? or have I dream'd till now?
I do not sleep: I see
I smell sweet savours and I feel soft things:
Upon my life
And not a tinker nor Christophero Sly.
Well
And once again
Will't please your mightiness to wash your hands?
O
O
These fifteen years you have been in a dream;
Or when you waked
These fifteen years! by my fay
But did I never speak of all that time?
O
For though you lay here in this goodly chamber
And rail upon the hostess of the house;
And say you would present her at the leet
Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.
Ay
Why
And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell
And twenty more such names and men as these
Which never were nor no man ever saw.
Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!
Amen.
I thank thee: thou shalt not lose by it.
Enter the Page as a lady
How fares my noble lord?
Marry
Where is my wife?
Here
Are you my wife and will not call me husband?
My men should call me 'lord:' I am your goodman.
My husband and my lord
I am your wife in all obedience.
I know it well. What must I call her?
Madam.
Al'ce madam
'Madam
call ladies.
Madam wife
And slept above some fifteen year or more.
Ay
'Tis much. Servants
Madam
Thrice noble lord
To pardon me yet for a night or two
For your physicians have expressly charged
I hope this reason stands for my excuse.
Ay
tarry so long. But I would be loath to fall into
my dreams again: I will therefore tarry in
despite of the flesh and the blood.
Enter a Messenger
Your honour's players
For so your doctors hold it very meet
Therefore they thought it good you hear a play
And frame your mind to mirth and merriment
Marry
comondy a Christmas gambold or a tumbling-trick?
No
What
It is a kind of history.
Well
and let the world slip: we shall ne'er be younger.
Flourish
ACT I
SCENE I. Padua. A public place.
Enter LUCENTIO and his man TRANIO
Tranio
To see fair Padua
And by my father's love and leave am arm'd
With his good will and thy good company
A course of learning and ingenious studies.
Pisa renown'd for grave citizens
Gave me my being and my father first
Vincetino's son brought up in Florence
It shall become to serve all hopes conceived
And therefore
Will I apply that treats of happiness
By virtue specially to be achieved.
Tell me thy mind; for I have Pisa left
And am to Padua come
A shallow plash to plunge him in the deep
And with satiety seeks to quench his thirst.
Mi perdonato
Glad that you thus continue your resolve
To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.
Only
This virtue and this moral discipline
Or so devote to Aristotle's cheques
As Ovid be an outcast quite abjured:
Balk logic with acquaintance that you have
And practise rhetoric in your common talk;
Music and poesy use to quicken you;
The mathematics and the metaphysics
No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en:
In brief
Gramercies
If
Such friends as time in Padua shall beget.
But stay a while: what company is this?
Master
Enter BAPTISTA
Gentlemen
That is
Before I have a husband for the elder:
If either of you both love Katharina
[Aside]  To cart her rather: she's too rough for me.
There
I pray you
To make a stale of me amongst these mates?
Mates
I'faith
I wis it is not half way to her heart;
But if it were
To comb your noddle with a three-legg'd stool
And paint your face and use you like a fool.
From all such devils
And me too
Hush
That wench is stark mad or wonderful froward.
But in the other's silence do I see
Maid's mild behavior and sobriety.
Peace
Well said
Gentlemen
What I have said
And let it not displease thee
A pretty peat! it is best
Put finger in the eye
Sister
Sir
My books and instruments shall be my company
Hark
Signior Baptista
Sorry am I that our good will effects
Bianca's grief.
Why will you mew her up
Gentlemen
Go in
Exit BIANCA
And for I know she taketh most delight
In music
I will be very kind
To mine own children in good bringing up:
And so farewell. Katharina
For I have more to commune with Bianca.
Exit
Why
knew not what to take and what to leave
Exit
You may go to the devil's dam: your gifts are so
good
so great
together
both sides. Farewell: yet for the love I bear my
sweet Bianca
man to teach her that wherein she delights
wish him to her father.
So will I
Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brooked
parle
mistress and be happy rivals in Bianco's love
labour and effect one thing specially.

Sir

Sir

ACT II
SCENE I. Padua. A room in BAPTISTA'S house.

Which I could fancy more than any other.
Minion

What

I will attend her here

She sings as sweetly as a nightingale:

Go

Content you
'Tis deeds must win the prize; and he of both
That can assure my daughter greatest dower
Shall have my Bianca's love.
Say
First
Is richly furnished with plate and gold;
Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands;
My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry;
In ivory coffers I have stuff'd my crowns;
In cypress chests my arras counterpoints
To house or housekeeping: then
I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail
Myself am struck in years
And if I die to-morrow
That 'only' came well in. Sir
I am my father's heir and only son:
If I may have your daughter to my wife
Old Signior Gremio has in Padua;
Besides two thousand ducats by the year
Of fruitful land
What
Two thousand ducats by the year of land!
My land amounts not to so much in all:
That she shall have; besides an argosy
That now is lying in Marseilles' road.
What
Gremio
Than three great argosies; besides two galliases
Nay

If you like me
Why
I must confess your offer is the best;
And
That's but a cavil: he is old
And may not young men die
Well
My daughter Katharina is to be married:
Now
Be bride to you
If not
And so
Adieu
Exit BAPTISTA
Now I fear thee not:
Sirrah young gamester
To give thee all
Set foot under thy table: tut
An old Italian fox is not so kind
Exit
A vengeance on your crafty wither'd hide!
Yet I have faced it with a card of ten.
'Tis in my head to do my master good:
I see no reason but supposed Lucentio
Must get a father
And that's a wonder: fathers commonly
Do get their children; but in this case of wooing
Exit
ACT III
SCENE I. Padua. BAPTISTA'S house.
Enter LUCENTIO
Fiddler
Have you so soon forgot the entertainment
Her sister Katharina welcomed you withal?
But
The patroness of heavenly harmony:
Then give me leave to have prerogative;
And when in music we have spent an hour
Preposterous ass
To know the cause why music was ordain'd!
Was it not to refresh the mind of man
After his studies or his usual pain?
Then give me leave to read philosophy
Sirrah
Why
I am no breeching scholar in the schools;
I'll not be tied to hours nor 'pointed times
And
Take you your instrument
His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.
You'll leave his lecture when I am in tune?
That will be never: tune your instrument.
Where left we last?
Here
'Hic ibat Simois; hic est Sigeia tellus;
Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.'
Construe them.
'Hic ibat
Lucentio

Spit in the hole

Simois

he hear us not

Madam
All but the base.

Now
Pedascule

Was Ajax

SCENE II. Padua. Before BAPTISTA'S house.

[To TRANIO]  Signior Lucentio
'pointed day.
That Katharina and Petruchio should be married
What will be said? what mockery will it be
To speak the ceremonial rites of marriage!
What says Lucentio to this shame of ours?
No shame but mine: I must
To give my hand opposed against my heart
Unto a mad-brain rudesby full of spleen;
Who woo'd in haste and means to wed at leisure.
I told you
And
Yet never means to wed where he hath woo'd.
Now must the world point at poor Katharina

Upon my life
Though he be blunt
Though he be merry

Go
For such an injury would vex a very saint

Master
you never heard of!

Why

He is coming.

jerkin

O
like the horse; with a linen stock on one leg and a

footboy or a gentleman's lackey.

I am glad he's come
Why

And tells us

As you shall well be satisfied withal.

But to her love concerneth us to add
Her father's liking: which to bring to pass
And he shall be Vincentio of Pisa;
And make assurance here in Padua
Of greater sums than I have promised.
So shall you quietly enjoy your hope
Were it not that my fellow-school-master
Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly
Which once perform'd
That by degrees we mean to look into
We'll over-reach the greybeard
All for my master's sake
Re-enter GREMIO
Signior Gremio
As willingly as e'er I came from school.
And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?
A bridegroom say you? 'tis a groom indeed
Curster than she? why
Why he's a devil
Why
Tut
I'll tell you
Should ask
And
That down fell priest and book and book and priest:
'Now take them up
What said the wench when he rose again?
Trembled and shook; for why
But after many ceremonies done
He had been aboard
After a storm; quaff'd off the muscadel
And threw the sops all in the sexton's face;
Having no other reason
But that his beard grew thin and hungerly
And seem'd to ask him sops as he was drinking.
This done
And kiss'd her lips with such a clamorous smack
That at the parting all the church did echo:
And I seeing this came thence for very shame;
And after me
Such a mad marriage never was before:
Hark
Music
Re-enter PETRUCHIO
Gentlemen and friends
I know you think to dine with me to-day
But so it is
Is't possible you will away to-night?
I must away to-day
Make it no wonder; if you knew my business
And
To this most patient
Dine with my father
For I must hence; and farewell to you all.
Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.
It may not be.
Let me entreat you.
It cannot be.
Let me entreat you.
I am content.
Are you content to stay?
I am content you shall entreat me stay;
But yet not stay
Now
Grumio
Ay
Nay

The door is open

For me

Father
Ay

Re-enter PETRUCHIO
Thus have I politicly begun my reign
My falcon now is sharp and passing empty;
And till she stoop she must not be full-gorged
Another way I have to man my haggard
That bate and beat and will not be obedient.
She eat no meat to-day
Last night she slept not
As with the meat
I'll find about the making of the bed;
And here I'll fling the pillow
Ay
That all is done in reverend care of her;
And in conclusion she shall watch all night:
And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl
And with the clamour keep her still awake.
This is a way to kill a wife with kindness;
And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour.
He that knows better how to tame a shrew
Exit

If this be courtesy

The patron of my life and liberty.

This
my father is here look'd for every day
'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here:
In all these circumstances I'll instruct you:
Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.

The worst is this

Off with that bauble
Lord
Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?

The wisdom of your duty
The more fool you
Katharina
What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.
Come
Come on
She shall not.
I say she shall: and first begin with her.
Fie
It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads
A woman moved is like a fountain troubled
And while it is so
Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy lord
To painful labour both by sea and land
And craves no other tribute at thy hands
But love
Too little payment for so great a debt.
Such duty as the subject owes the prince
Even such a woman oweth to her husband;
And when she is froward
And graceless traitor to her loving lord?
I am ashamed that women are so simple
To offer war where they should kneel for peace;
Or seek for rule
Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth
Should well agree with our external parts?
Come
My mind hath been as big as one of yours
But now I see our lances are but straws
Then vail your stomachs
In token of which duty
Why
Well
'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.
But a harsh hearing when women are froward.
Come
We three are married
To LUCENTIO
'Twas I won the wager
And

Now
'Tis a wonder

ACT I
SCENE I. On a ship at sea: a tempestuous noise
of thunder and lightning heard.
Enter a Master and a Boatswain
Boatswain!
Here
Good
Exit
Enter Mariners
Heigh
yare
master's whistle. Blow
Enter ALONSO
Good boatswain
Play the men.
I pray now
Where is the master
Do you not hear him? You mar our labour: keep your
cabins: you do assist the storm.
Nay
When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers
for the name of king? To cabin: silence! trouble us not.
Good
None that I more love than myself. You are a
counsellor; if you can command these elements to
silence
not hand a rope more; use your authority: if you
cannot
yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of
the hour
of our way
Exit
I have great comfort from this fellow: methinks he
hath no drowning mark upon him; his complexion is
perfect gallows. Stand fast
hanging: make the rope of his destiny our cable
born to be hanged
Exeunt
Re-enter Boatswain
Down with the topmast! yare! lower
her to try with main-course.
A cry within
A plague upon this howling! they are louder than
the weather or our office.
Re-enter SEBASTIAN
Yet again! what do you here? Shall we give o'er
and drown? Have you a mind to sink?
A pox o' your throat
Work you then.
Hang
We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.
I'll warrant him for drowning; though the ship were
no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an
unstanched wench.
Lay her a-hold
sea again; lay her off.
Enter Mariners wet
All lost! to prayers
What
The king and prince at prayers! let's assist them
I'm out of patience.
We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards:
This wide-chapp'd rascal--would thou mightst lie drowning
The washing of ten tides!
He'll be hang'd yet
And gape at widest to glut him.
A confused noise within:   'Mercy on us!'--  'We split
Let's all sink with the king.
Let's take leave of him.
Exeunt ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN
Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an
acre of barren ground
thing. The wills above be done! but I would fain
die a dry death.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The island. Before PROSPERO'S cell.
Enter PROSPERO and MIRANDA
If by your art
Put the wild waters in this roar
The sky
With those that I saw suffer: a brave vessel
Against my very heart. Poor souls
Had I been any god of power
Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere
It should the good ship so have swallow'd and
The fraughting souls within her.
Be collected:
No more amazement: tell your piteous heart
There's no harm done.
O
No harm.
I have done nothing but in care of thee
Art ignorant of what thou art
Of whence I am
Than Prospero
More to know
Did never meddle with my thoughts.
'Tis time
I should inform thee farther. Lend thy hand
Lays down his mantle
Lie there
The direful spectacle of the wreck
The very virtue of compassion in thee
So safely ordered that there is no soul--
No
Betid to any creature in the vessel
Which thou heard'st cry
For thou must now know farther.
You have often
Begun to tell me what I am
And left me to a bootless inquisition
The hour's now come;
The very minute bids thee ope thine ear;
Obey and be attentive. Canst thou remember
A time before we came unto this cell?
I do not think thou canst
Out three years old.
Certainly
By what? by any other house or person?
Of any thing the image tell me that
Hath kept with thy remembrance.
'Tis far off
And rather like a dream than an assurance
That my remembrance warrants. Had I not
Four or five women once that tended me?
Thou hadst
That this lives in thy mind? What seest thou else
In the dark backward and abysm of time?
If thou remember'st aught ere thou camest here
But that I do not.
Twelve year since
A prince of power.
Sir
Thy mother was a piece of virtue
She said thou wast my daughter; and thy father
Was Duke of Milan; and thou his only heir
And princess no worse issued.
O the heavens!
What foul play had we
Or blessed was't we did?
Both
By foul play
O
To think o' the teen that I have turn'd you to
My brother and thy uncle
I pray thee
Be so perfidious!--he whom next thyself
Of all the world I loved and to him put
The manage of my state; as at that time
Through all the signories it was the first
And Prospero the prime duke
In dignity
Without a parallel; those being all my study
And to my state grew stranger
And rapt in secret studies. Thy false uncle--
Dost thou attend me?
Sir
Being once perfected how to grant suits
To trash for over-topping
The creatures that were mine
Of officer and office
To what tune pleased his ear; that now he was
The ivy which had hid my princely trunk
O
I pray thee
I
To closeness and the bettering of my mind
With that which
Awaked an evil nature; and my trust
A falsehood in its contrary as great
As my trust was; which had indeed no limit
Who having into truth
He was indeed the duke; out o' the substitution
And executing the outward face of royalty
Dost thou hear?
Your tale
To have no screen between this part he play'd
And him he play'd it for
Absolute Milan. Me
Was dukedom large enough: of temporal royalties
He thinks me now incapable; confederates--
So dry he was for sway--wi' the King of Naples
To give him annual tribute
The dukedom yet unbow'd--alas
To most ignoble stooping.
O the heavens!
Mark his condition and the event; then tell me
If this might be a brother.
I should sin
To think but nobly of my grandmother:
Good wombs have borne bad sons.
Now the condition.
The King of Naples
To me inveterate
Which was
Of homage and I know not how much tribute
Out of the dukedom and confer fair Milan
With all the honours on my brother: whereon
Fated to the purpose did Antonio open
The gates of Milan
Me and thy crying self.
Alack
I
That wrings mine eyes to't.
Hear a little further
And then I'll bring thee to the present business
Which now's upon's; without the which this story
Were most impertinent.
Wherefore did they not
That hour destroy us?
Well demanded
My tale provokes that question. Dear
A mark so bloody on the business
With colours fairer painted their foul ends.
In few
A rotten carcass of a boat
Instinctively had quit it: there they hoist us
To the winds whose pity
Alack
Was I then to you!
O
Thou wast that did preserve me. Thou didst smile.
Infused with a fortitude from heaven
An undergoing stomach
Against what should ensue.
How came we ashore?
By Providence divine.
Some food we had and some fresh water that
A noble Neapolitan
Master of this design
Rich garments
From mine own library with volumes that
I prize above my dukedom.
Would I might
But ever see that man!
Now I arise:
Resumes his mantle
Sit still
Here in this island we arrived; and here
Have I
Than other princesses can that have more time
For vainer hours and tutors not so careful.
Heavens thank you for't! And now
For raising this sea-storm?
Know thus far forth.
By accident most strange
Brought to this shore; and by my prescience
I find my zenith doth depend upon
A most auspicious star
If now I court not but omit
Will ever after droop. Here cease more questions:
Thou art inclined to sleep; 'tis a good dulness
MIRANDA sleeps
Come away
Approach
Enter ARIEL
All hail
To answer thy best pleasure; be't to fly
On the curl'd clouds
Ariel and all his quality.
Hast thou
To every article.
I boarded the king's ship; now on the beak
O' the dreadful thunder-claps
And sight-outrunning were not; the fire and cracks
Of sulphurous roaring the most mighty Neptune
Seem to besiege and make his bold waves tremble
My brave spirit!
Who was so firm
Would not infect his reason?
Not a soul
But felt a fever of the mad and play'd
Some tricks of desperation. All but mariners
Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel
Was the first man that leap'd; cried
And all the devils are here.'
Why that's my spirit!
But was not this nigh shore?
Close by
But are they
Not a hair perish'd;
On their sustaining garments not a blemish
The king's son have I landed by himself;
Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs
In an odd angle of the isle and sitting
Of the king's ship
The mariners say how thou hast disposed
And all the rest o' the fleet.
Safely in harbour
Is the king's ship; in the deep nook
Thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dew
From the still-vex'd Bermoothes
The mariners all under hatches stow'd;
Who
Which I dispersed
And are upon the Mediterranean flote
And his great person perish.
Ariel
Exactly is perform'd: but there's more work.
What is the time o' the day?
Past the mid season.
At least two glasses. The time 'twixt six and now
Must by us both be spent most preciously.
Is there more toil? Since thou dost give me pains
How now? moody?
What is't thou canst demand?
My liberty.
Before the time be out? no more!
I prithee
Told thee no lies
Without or grudge or grumblings: thou didst promise
To bate me a full year.
Dost thou forget
From what a torment I did free thee?
No.
Thou dost
Of the salt deep
When it is baked with frost.
I do not
Thou liest
The foul witch Sycorax
Was grown into a hoop? hast thou forgot her?
No
Thou hast. Where was she born? speak; tell me.
Sir
O
Once in a month recount what thou hast been
To enter human hearing
They would not take her life. Is not this true?
Ay
This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child
And here was left by the sailors. Thou
And
To act her earthy and abhorr'd commands
And in her most unmitigable rage
Imprison'd thou didst painfully remain
A dozen years; within which space she died
And left thee there; where thou didst vent thy groans
As fast as mill-wheels strike. Then was this island--
Save for the son that she did litter here
A human shape.
Yes
Dull thing
Whom now I keep in service. Thou best know'st
What torment I did find thee in; thy groans
Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts
Of ever angry bears: it was a torment
To lay upon the damn'd
Could not again undo: it was mine art
The pine and let thee out.
I thank thee
If thou more murmur'st
And peg thee in his knotty entrails till
Thou hast howl'd away twelve winters.
Pardon
I will be correspondent to command
And do my spiriting gently.
Do so
I will discharge thee.
That's my noble master!
What shall I do? say what; what shall I do?
Go make thyself like a nymph o' the sea: be subject
To no sight but thine and mine
To every eyeball else. Go take this shape
And hither come in't: go
Exit ARIEL
Awake
The strangeness of your story put
Heaviness in me.
Shake it off. Come on;
We'll visit Caliban my slave
Yields us kind answer.
'Tis a villain
But
That profit us. What
Thou earth
[Within]  There's wood enough within.
Come forth
Come
Re-enter ARIEL like a water-nymph
Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel
My lord it shall be done.
Exit
Thou poisonous slave
Upon thy wicked dam
Enter CALIBAN
As wicked dew as e'er my mother brush'd
With raven's feather from unwholesome fen
Drop on you both! a south-west blow on ye
And blister you all o'er!
For this
Shall
As thick as honeycomb
Than bees that made 'em.
I must eat my dinner.
This island's mine
Water with berries in't
To name the bigger light
And show'd thee all the qualities o' the isle
Cursed be I that did so! All the charms
Of Sycorax
For I am all the subjects that you have
In this hard rock
The rest o' the island.
Thou most lying slave
In mine own cell
The honour of my child.
O ho
Thou didst prevent me; I had peopled else
This isle with Calibans.
Abhorred slave
One thing or other: when thou didst not
A thing most brutish
With words that made them known. But thy vile race
good natures
Could not abide to be with; therefore wast thou
Deservedly confined into this rock
You taught me language; and my profit on't
Is
For learning me your language!
Hag-seed
Fetch us in fuel; and be quick
If thou neglect'st or dost unwillingly
What I command
That beasts shall tremble at thy din.
No
Aside
I must obey: his art is of such power
So
