Re-enter ARIEL
ARIEL'S song.
Come unto these yellow sands
Courtsied when you have and kiss'd
The wild waves whist
And
Hark
Burthen [dispersedly
The watch-dogs bark!
Burthen Bow-wow
Hark
The strain of strutting chanticleer
Cry
Where should this music be? i' the air or the earth?
It sounds no more: and sure
Some god o' the island. Sitting on a bank
With its sweet air: thence I have follow'd it
No
ARIEL sings
Full fathom five thy father lies;
Of his bones are coral made;
Those are pearls that were his eyes:
Nothing of him that doth fade
But doth suffer a sea-change
Into something rich and strange.
Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell
Burthen Ding-dong
Hark! now I hear them
The ditty does remember my drown'd father.
This is no mortal business
That the earth owes. I hear it now above me.
The fringed curtains of thine eye advance
And say what thou seest yond.
What is't? a spirit?
Lord
No
As we have
Was in the wreck; and
With grief that's beauty's canker
A goodly person: he hath lost his fellows
And strays about to find 'em.
I might call him
A thing divine
I ever saw so noble.
[Aside] It goes on
Within two days for this.
Most sure
On whom these airs attend! Vouchsafe my prayer
May know if you remain upon this island;
And that you will some good instruction give
How I may bear me here: my prime request
If you be maid or no?
No wonder
But certainly a maid.
My language! heavens!
I am the best of them that speak this speech
How? the best?
What wert thou
A single thing
To hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me;
And that he does I weep: myself am Naples
The king my father wreck'd.
Alack
Yes
And his brave son being twain.
"[Aside]	The Duke of Milan"
And his more braver daughter could control thee
They have changed eyes. Delicate Ariel
To FERDINAND
A word
I fear you have done yourself some wrong: a word.
Why speaks my father so ungently? This
Is the third man that e'er I saw
That e'er I sigh'd for: pity move my father
To be inclined my way!
O
The queen of Naples.
Soft
Aside
They are both in either's powers; but this swift business
I must uneasy make
Make the prize light.
To FERDINAND
One word more; I charge thee
That thou attend me: thou dost here usurp
The name thou owest not; and hast put thyself
Upon this island as a spy
From me
No
There's nothing ill can dwell in such a temple:
If the ill spirit have so fair a house
Follow me.
Speak not you for him; he's a traitor. Come;
I'll manacle thy neck and feet together:
Sea-water shalt thou drink; thy food shall be
The fresh-brook muscles
Wherein the acorn cradled. Follow.
No;
I will resist such entertainment till
Mine enemy has more power.
Draws
O dear father
He's gentle and not fearful.
What? I say
Who makest a show but darest not strike
Is so possess'd with guilt: come from thy ward
And make thy weapon drop.
Beseech you
Hence! hang not on my garments.
Sir
I'll be his surety.
Silence! one word more
Shall make me chide thee
An advocate for an imposter! hush!
Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he
To the most of men this is a Caliban
And they to him are angels.
My affections
Are then most humble; I have no ambition
To see a goodlier man.
Come on; obey:
Thy nerves are in their infancy again
And have no vigour in them.
So they are;
My spirits
My father's loss
Behold this maid: all corners else o' the earth
Let liberty make use of; space enough
Have I in such a prison.
[Aside]                It works.
To FERDINAND
Come on.
Thou hast done well
To FERDINAND
Follow me.
To ARIEL
Hark what thou else shalt do me.
Be of comfort;
My father's of a better nature
Which now came from him.
Thou shalt be free
As mountain winds: but then exactly do
All points of my command.
To the syllable.
Come
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Another part of the island.
Enter ALONSO
Beseech you
Is much beyond our loss. Our hint of woe
Is common; every day some sailor's wife
Have just our theme of woe; but for the miracle
Can speak like us: then wisely
Our sorrow with our comfort.
Prithee
He receives comfort like cold porridge.
The visitor will not give him o'er so.
Look he's winding up the watch of his wit;
by and by it will strike.
Sir
One: tell.
When every grief is entertain'd that's offer'd
A dollar.
Dolour comes to him
have spoken truer than you purposed.
You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.
Therefore
Fie
I prithee
Well
He will be talking.
Which
wager
The old cock.
The cockerel.
Done. The wager?
A laughter.
A match!
Though this island seem to be desert
Ha
Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible
Yet
Yet
He could not miss't.
It must needs be of subtle
temperance.
Temperance was a delicate wench.
Ay
The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
As if it had lungs and rotten ones.
Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.
Here is everything advantageous to life.
True; save means to live.
Of that there's none
How lush and lusty the grass looks! how green!
The ground indeed is tawny.
With an eye of green in't.
He misses not much.
No; he doth but mistake the truth totally.
But the rarity of it is
beyond credit
As many vouched rarities are.
That our garments
the sea
glosses
salt water.
If but one of his pockets could speak
say he lies?
Ay
Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we
put them on first in Afric
the king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
'Twas a sweet marriage
Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to
their queen.
Not since widow Dido's time.
Widow! a pox o' that! How came that widow in?
widow Dido!
What if he had said 'widower AEneas' too? Good Lord
'Widow Dido' said you? you make me study of that:
she was of Carthage
This Tunis
Carthage?
I assure you
His word is more than the miraculous harp; he hath
raised the wall and houses too.
What impossible matter will he make easy next?
I think he will carry this island home in his pocket
and give it his son for an apple.
And
forth more islands.
Ay.
Why
Sir
as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage
of your daughter
And the rarest that e'er came there.
Bate
O
Is not
wore it? I mean
That sort was well fished for.
When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?
You cram these words into mine ears against
The stomach of my sense. Would I had never
Married my daughter there! for
I ne'er again shall see her. O thou mine heir
Of Naples and of Milan
Hath made his meal on thee?
Sir
I saw him beat the surges under him
The surge most swoln that met him; his bold head
'Bove the contentious waves he kept
Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke
To the shore
He came alive to land.
No
Sir
Where she at least is banish'd from your eye
Prithee
You were kneel'd to and importuned otherwise
By all of us
Weigh'd between loathness and obedience
Which end o' the beam should bow. We have lost your
son
More widows in them of this business' making
Than we bring men to comfort them:
The fault's your own.
So is the dear'st o' the loss.
My lord Sebastian
And time to speak it in: you rub the sore
Very well.
And most chirurgeonly.
It is foul weather in us all
Foul weather?
Very foul.
Had I plantation of this isle
He'ld sow't with nettle-seed.
Or docks
And were the king on't
'Scape being drunk for want of wine.
I' the commonwealth I would by contraries
Execute all things; for no kind of traffic
Would I admit; no name of magistrate;
Letters should not be known; riches
No use of metal
No occupation; all men idle
And women too
No sovereignty;--
Yet he would be king on't.
The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the
beginning.
All things in common nature should produce
Without sweat or endeavour: treason
No marrying 'mong his subjects?
None
I would with such perfection govern
God save his majesty!
Long live Gonzalo!
And
Prithee
I do well believe your highness; and
did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen
they always use to laugh at nothing.
'Twas you we laughed at.
Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing
to you: so you may continue and laugh at
nothing still.
What a blow was there given!
An it had not fallen flat-long.
You are gentlemen of brave metal; you would lift
the moon out of her sphere
in it five weeks without changing.
Enter ARIEL
We would so
Nay
No
my discretion so weakly. Will you laugh
me asleep
Go sleep
All sleep except ALONSO
What
Would
They are inclined to do so.
Please you
It seldom visits sorrow; when it doth
We two
Thank you. Wondrous heavy.
ALONSO sleeps. Exit ARIEL
What a strange drowsiness possesses them!
It is the quality o' the climate.
Why
Doth it not then our eyelids sink? I find not
Myself disposed to sleep.
Nor I; my spirits are nimble.
They fell together all
They dropp'd
And yet me thinks I see it in thy face
My strong imagination sees a crown
Dropping upon thy head.
What
Do you not hear me speak?
I do; and surely
It is a sleepy language and thou speak'st
Out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say?
This is a strange repose
With eyes wide open; standing
Noble Sebastian
Whiles thou art waking.
Thou dost snore distinctly;
There's meaning in thy snores.
I am more serious than my custom: you
Must be so too
Trebles thee o'er.
Well
I'll teach you how to flow.
Do so: to ebb
Hereditary sloth instructs me.
O
Whiles thus you mock it! how
By their own fear or sloth.
Prithee
The setting of thine eye and cheek proclaim
A matter from thee
Which throes thee much to yield.
Thus
Although this lord of weak remembrance
When he is earth'd
For he's a spirit of persuasion
Professes to persuade
And he that sleeps here swims.
I have no hope
That he's undrown'd.
O
What great hope have you! no hope that way is
Another way so high a hope that even
Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond
That Ferdinand is drown'd?
He's gone.
Then
Claribel.
She that is queen of Tunis; she that dwells
Ten leagues beyond man's life; she that from Naples
Can have no note
The man i' the moon's too slow--till new-born chins
Be rough and razorable; she that--from whom?
We all were sea-swallow'd
Whereof what's past is prologue
In yours and my discharge.
What stuff is this! how say you?
'Tis true
So is she heir of Naples; 'twixt which regions
There is some space.
A space whose every cubit
Seems to cry out
Measure us back to Naples? Keep in Tunis
That now hath seized them; why
Than now they are. There be that can rule Naples
As well as he that sleeps; lords that can prate
As amply and unnecessarily
As this Gonzalo; I myself could make
A chough of as deep chat. O
The mind that I do! what a sleep were this
For your advancement! Do you understand me?
Methinks I do.
And how does your content
Tender your own good fortune?
I remember
You did supplant your brother Prospero.
True:
And look how well my garments sit upon me;
Much feater than before: my brother's servants
Were then my fellows; now they are my men.
But
Ay
This deity in my bosom: twenty consciences
And melt ere they molest! Here lies your brother
Whom I
This ancient morsel
Should not upbraid our course. For all the rest
They'll tell the clock to any business that
We say befits the hour.
Thy case
Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest;
And I the king shall love thee.
Draw together;
And when I rear my hand
O
They talk apart
Re-enter ARIEL
My master through his art foresees the danger
That you
For else his project dies--to keep them living.
Sings in GONZALO's ear
While you here do snoring lie
His time doth take.
If of life you keep a care
Awake
Then let us both be sudden.
Now
Preserve the king.
They wake
Why
Wherefore this ghastly looking?
What's the matter?
Whiles we stood here securing your repose
Like bulls
It struck mine ear most terribly.
I heard nothing.
O
Of a whole herd of lions.
Heard you this
Upon mine honour
I shaked you
Lead off this ground; and let's make further search
For my poor son.
Heavens keep him from these beasts!
For he is
Lead away.
Prospero my lord shall know what I have done:
So
Exeunt
SCENE II. Another part of the island.
Enter CALIBAN with a burden of wood. A noise of thunder heard
All the infections that the sun sucks up
From bogs
By inch-meal a disease! His spirits hear me
And yet I needs must curse. But they'll nor pinch
Out of my way
For every trifle are they set upon me;
Sometime like apes that mow and chatter at me
And after bite me
Lie tumbling in my barefoot way and mount
Their pricks at my footfall; sometime am I
All wound with adders who with cloven tongues
Do hiss me into madness.
Enter TRINCULO
Lo
Here comes a spirit of his
For bringing wood in slowly. I'll fall flat;
Perchance he will not mind me.
Here's neither bush nor shrub
any weather at all
I hear it sing i' the wind: yond same black
cloud
bombard that would shed his liquor. If it
should thunder as it did before
where to hide my head: yond same cloud cannot
choose but fall by pailfuls. What have we
here? a man or a fish? dead or alive? A fish:
he smells like a fish; a very ancient and fish-
like smell; a kind of not of the newest Poor-
John. A strange fish! Were I in England now
of silver: there would this monster make a
man; any strange beast there makes a man:
when they will not give a doit to relieve a lame
beggar
Indian. Legged like a man and his fins like
arms! Warm o' my troth! I do now let loose
my opinion; hold it no longer: this is no fish
thunderbolt.
Thunder
Alas
creep under his gaberdine; there is no other
shelter hereabouts: misery acquaints a man with
strange bed-fellows. I will here shroud till the
dregs of the storm be past.
Enter STEPHANO
I shall no more to sea
This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man's
funeral: well
Drinks
Sings
The master
Loved Mall
For she had a tongue with a tang
She loved not the savour of tar nor of pitch
Then to sea
This is a scurvy tune too: but here's my comfort.
Drinks
Do not torment me: Oh!
What's the matter? Have we devils here? Do you put
tricks upon's with savages and men of Ind
have not scaped drowning to be afeard now of your
four legs; for it hath been said
ever went on four legs cannot make him give ground;
and it shall be said so again while Stephano
breathes at's nostrils.
The spirit torments me; Oh!
This is some monster of the isle with four legs
hath got
should he learn our language? I will give him some
relief
and keep him tame and get to Naples with him
present for any emperor that ever trod on neat's leather.
Do not torment me
He's in his fit now and does not talk after the
wisest. He shall taste of my bottle: if he have
never drunk wine afore will go near to remove his
fit. If I can recover him and keep him tame
not take too much for him; he shall pay for him that
hath him
Thou dost me yet but little hurt; thou wilt anon
know it by thy trembling: now Prosper works upon thee.
Come on your ways; open your mouth; here is that
which will give language to you
mouth; this will shake your shaking
open your chaps again.
I should know that voice: it should be--but he is
drowned; and these are devils: O defend me!
Four legs and two voices: a most delicate monster!
His forward voice now is to speak well of his
friend; his backward voice is to utter foul speeches
and to detract. If all the wine in my bottle will
recover him
will pour some in thy other mouth.
Stephano!
Doth thy other mouth call me? Mercy
a devil
long spoon.

not drowned. Is the storm overblown? I hid me

That's a brave god and bears celestial liquor.

Come
But that the poor monster's in drink: an abominable monster!
I'll show thee the best springs; I'll pluck thee berries;
I'll fish for thee and get thee wood enough.
A plague upon the tyrant that I serve!
I'll bear him no more sticks
A most ridiculous monster
Poor drunkard!
I prithee
And I with my long nails will dig thee pignuts;
Show thee a jay's nest and instruct thee how
To snare the nimble marmoset; I'll bring thee
To clustering filberts and sometimes I'll get thee
Young scamels from the rock. Wilt thou go with me?
I prithee now
talking. Trinculo

A howling monster: a drunken monster!
No more dams I'll make for fish
Nor fetch in firing
At requiring;
Nor scrape trencher
'Ban
Has a new master: get a new man.
Freedom
O brave monster! Lead the way.

ACT III
SCENE I. Before PROSPERO'S Cell.
Enter FERDINAND
There be some sports are painful
Delight in them sets off: some kinds of baseness
Are nobly undergone and most poor matters
Point to rich ends. This my mean task
Would be as heavy to me as odious
The mistress which I serve quickens what's dead
And makes my labours pleasures: O
Ten times more gentle than her father's crabbed
Some thousands of these logs and pile them up
Weeps when she sees me work
Had never like executor. I forget:
But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labours
Enter MIRANDA; and PROSPERO at a distance
Alas
Burnt up those logs that you are enjoin'd to pile!
Pray
Is hard at study; pray now
He's safe for these three hours.
O most dear mistress
What I must strive to do.
If you'll sit down
I'll carry it to the pile.
No
I had rather crack my sinews
It would become me
As well as it does you: and I should do it
With much more ease; for my good will is to it
Poor worm
This visitation shows it.
You look wearily.
No
When you are by at night. I do beseech you--
Chiefly that I might set it in my prayers--
What is your name?
Miranda.--O my father
Admired Miranda!
Indeed the top of admiration! worth
What's dearest to the world! Full many a lady
I have eyed with best regard and many a time
The harmony of their tongues hath into bondage
Brought my too diligent ear: for several virtues
Have I liked several women; never any
With so fun soul
Did quarrel with the noblest grace she owed
And put it to the foil: but you
Of every creature's best!
I do not know
One of my sex; no woman's face remember
More that I may call men than you
Any companion in the world but you
Something too wildly and my father's precepts
I therein do forget.
I am in my condition
A prince
I would
This wooden slavery than to suffer
The flesh-fly blow my mouth. Hear my soul speak:
The very instant that I saw you
My heart fly to your service; there resides
Am I this patient log--man.
Do you love me?
O heaven
And crown what I profess with kind event
If I speak true! if hollowly
What best is boded me to mischief! I
Beyond all limit of what else i' the world
Do love
I am a fool
To weep at what I am glad of.
Fair encounter
Of two most rare affections! Heavens rain grace
On that which breeds between 'em!
Wherefore weep you?
At mine unworthiness that dare not offer
What I desire to give
What I shall die to want. But this is trifling;
And all the more it seeks to hide itself
And prompt me
I am your wife
If not
You may deny me; but I'll be your servant
My mistress
And I thus humble ever.
My husband
Ay
As bondage e'er of freedom: here's my hand.
And mine
Till half an hour hence.
A thousand thousand!
Exeunt FERDINAND and MIRANDA severally
So glad of this as they I cannot be
At nothing can be more. I'll to my book
Much business appertaining.
Exit

One spirit to command: they all do hate him

He has brave utensils
Which when he has a house
And that most deeply to consider is
The beauty of his daughter; he himself
Calls her a nonpareil: I never saw a woman
But she as far surpasseth Sycorax
As great'st does least.
Is it so brave a lass?
Ay
And bring thee forth brave brood.
Monster

Excellent.

SCENE III. Another part of the island.
Enter ALONSO
By'r lakin
My old bones ache: here's a maze trod indeed
Through forth-rights and meanders! By your patience
Old lord
Even here I will put off my hope and keep it
No longer for my flatterer: he is drown'd
Whom thus we stray to find
Our frustrate search on land. Well
[Aside to SEBASTIAN]  I am right glad that he's so
out of hope.
Do not
That you resolved to effect.
[Aside to ANTONIO]  The next advantage
Will we take throughly.
[Aside to SEBASTIAN]  Let it be to-night;
For

As when they are fresh.
[Aside to ANTONIO]  I say
Solemn and strange music

Marvellous sweet music!
Enter PROSPERO above
Give us kind keepers
A living drollery. Now I will believe
That there are unicorns
There is one tree
At this hour reigning there.
I'll believe both;
And what does else want credit
lie
If in Naples
I should report this now
If I should say
For
Who
Our human generation you shall find
Many
[Aside]              Honest lord
Are worse than devils.
I cannot too much muse
Such shapes
Of excellent dumb discourse.
"[Aside]	Praise in departing."
They vanish'd strangely.
No matter
They have left their viands behind; for we have stomachs.
Will't please you taste of what is here?
Not I.
Faith
Dew-lapp'd like bulls
Wallets of flesh? or that there were such men
Whose heads stood in their breasts? which now we find
Each putter-out of five for one will bring us
Good warrant of.
I will stand to and feed
The best is past. Brother
Thunder and lightning. Enter ARIEL
You are three men of sin
And what is in't
Hath caused to belch up you; and on this island
Where man doth not inhabit; you 'mongst men
Being most unfit to live. I have made you mad;
And even with such-like valour men hang and drown
Their proper selves.
ALONSO
You fools! I and my fellows
Are ministers of Fate: the elements
Wound the loud winds
Kill the still-closing waters
One dowle that's in my plume: my fellow-ministers
Are like invulnerable. If you could hurt
And will not be uplifted. But remember--
For that's my business to you--that you three
From Milan did supplant good Prospero;
Exposed unto the sea
The powers
Incensed the seas and shores
Lingering perdition
Can be at once
You and your ways; whose wraths to guard you from--
Which here
Upon your heads--is nothing but heart-sorrow
And a clear life ensuing.
He vanishes in thunder; then
Bravely the figure of this harpy hast thou
Perform'd
Of my instruction hast thou nothing bated
In what thou hadst to say: so
And observation strange
Their several kinds have done. My high charms work
And these mine enemies are all knit up
In their distractions; they now are in my power;
And in these fits I leave them
Young Ferdinand
Exit above
I' the name of something holy
In this strange stare?
O
Methought the billows spoke and told me of it;
The winds did sing it to me
The name of Prosper: it did bass my trespass.
Therefore my son i' the ooze is bedded
I'll seek him deeper than e'er plummet sounded
And with him there lie mudded.
Exit
But one fiend at a time
I'll be thy second.
Exeunt SEBASTIAN
All three of them are desperate: their great guilt
That are of suppler joints
And hinder them from what this ecstasy
May now provoke them to.
Follow
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Before PROSPERO'S cell.
Enter PROSPERO
If I have too austerely punish'd you
Have given you here a third of mine own life
I tender to thy hand: all thy vexations
Were but my trials of thy love and thou
Hast strangely stood the test here
And make it halt behind her.
I do believe it
Against an oracle.
Then
Worthily purchased take my daughter: but
If thou dost break her virgin-knot before
All sanctimonious ceremonies may
With full and holy rite be minister'd
To make this contract grow: but barren hate
The union of your bed with weeds so loathly
That you shall hate it both: therefore take heed
As I hope
For quiet days
Our worser genius can
Mine honour into lust
The edge of that day's celebration
When I shall think: or Phoebus' steeds are founder'd
Fairly spoke.
Sit then and talk with her; she is thine own.
What
Enter ARIEL
What would my potent master? here I am.
Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service
Did worthily perform; and I must use you
In such another trick. Go bring the rabble
Incite them to quick motion; for I must
Bestow upon the eyes of this young couple
Some vanity of mine art: it is my promise
Presently?
Ay
Before you can say 'come' and 'go
And breathe twice and cry 'so
Each one
Do you love me
Dearly my delicate Ariel. Do not approach
Till thou dost hear me call.
Well
Exit
Look thou be true; do not give dalliance
Too much the rein: the strongest oaths are straw
To the fire i' the blood: be more abstemious
I warrant you sir;
The white cold virgin snow upon my heart
Abates the ardour of my liver.
Well.
Now come
No tongue! all eyes! be silent.
Soft music
Enter IRIS
Ceres
Of wheat
Thy turfy mountains
Thy banks with pioned and twilled brims
And thy sea-marge
Approach
Enter CERES
Hail
Dost disobey the wife of Jupiter;
Who with thy saffron wings upon my flowers
Diffusest honey-drops
My bosky acres and my unshrubb'd down
Summon'd me hither
A contract of true love to celebrate;
And some donation freely to estate
On the blest lovers.
Tell me
The means that dusky Dis my daughter got
I have forsworn.
Of her society
Be not afraid: I met her deity
Cutting the clouds towards Paphos and her son
Dove-drawn with her. Here thought they to have done
Some wanton charm upon this man and maid
Till Hymen's torch be lighted: but vain;
Mars's hot minion is returned again;
Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows
And be a boy right out.
High'st queen of state
Enter JUNO
How does my bounteous sister? Go with me
To bless this twain
And honour'd in their issue.
They sing:
Honour
Juno sings her blessings upon you.
Earth's increase
Spring come to you at the farthest
In the very end of harvest!
Scarcity and want shall shun you;
Ceres' blessing so is on you.
This is a most majestic vision
Harmoniously charmingly. May I be bold
To think these spirits?
Spirits
I have from their confines call'd to enact
My present fancies.
Let me live here ever;
So rare a wonder'd father and a wife
Makes this place Paradise.
Juno and Ceres whisper
Sweet
Juno and Ceres whisper seriously;
There's something else to do: hush
You nymphs
Answer your summons; Juno does command:
Come
A contract of true love; be not too late.
Enter certain Nymphs
You sunburnt sicklemen
Make holiday; your rye-straw hats put on
And these fresh nymphs encounter every one
In country footing.
Enter certain Reapers
[Aside]  I had forgot that foul conspiracy
Of the beast Caliban and his confederates
Against my life: the minute of their plot
Is almost come.
To the Spirits
Well done! avoid; no more!
This is strange: your father's in some passion
That works him strongly.
Never till this day
Saw I him touch'd with anger so distemper'd.
You do look
Our revels now are ended. These our actors
Are melted into air
And
And
As dreams are made on
Is rounded with a sleep. Sir
Bear with my weakness; my
Be not disturb'd with my infirmity:
If you be pleased
And there repose: a turn or two I'll walk
We wish your peace.
Exeunt
Come with a thought I thank thee
Enter ARIEL
Thy thoughts I cleave to. What's thy pleasure?
Spirit
Ay
Lest I might anger thee.
Say again
I told you
So fun of valour that they smote the air
For breathing in their faces; beat the ground
For kissing of their feet; yet always bending
Towards their project. Then I beat my tabour;
At which
their ears
As they smelt music: so I charm'd their ears
That calf-like they my lowing follow'd through
Tooth'd briers
I' the filthy-mantled pool beyond your cell
O'erstunk their feet.
This was well done
Thy shape invisible retain thou still:
The trumpery in my house
I go
Exit
A devil
Nurture can never stick; on whom my pains
And as with age his body uglier grows
Re-enter ARIEL
Come
PROSPERO and ARIEL remain invisible. Enter CALIBAN
Pray you
Hear a foot fall: we now are near his cell.
Monster
a harmless fairy
played the Jack with us.
Monster
which my nose is in great indignation.
So is mine. Do you hear
a displeasure against you
Thou wert but a lost monster.
Good my lord
Be patient
Shall hoodwink this mischance: therefore speak softly.
All's hush'd as midnight yet.
Ay
There is not only disgrace and dishonour in that
That's more to me than my wetting: yet this is your
harmless fairy
I will fetch off my bottle
for my labour.
Prithee
Do that good mischief which may make this island
Thine own for ever
Give me thy hand. I do begin to have bloody thoughts.
O king Stephano! O peer! O worthy Stephano! look
what a wardrobe here is for thee!
Let it alone
O
O king Stephano!
Put off that gown
that gown.
Thy grace shall have it.
The dropsy drown this fool I what do you mean
To dote thus on such luggage? Let's alone
And do the murder first: if he awake
Be you quiet
the line: now
hair and prove a bald jerkin.
Do
I thank thee for that jest; here's a garment for't:

country. 'Steal by line and level' is an excellent
pass of pate; there's another garment for't.
Monster
away with the rest.
I will have none on't: we shall lose our time
With foreheads villanous low.
Monster
away where my hogshead of wine is
out of my kingdom: go to

Ay
A noise of hunters heard. Enter divers Spirits
Hey
Silver I there it goes
Fury
CALIBAN
Go charge my goblins that they grind their joints
With dry convulsions
With aged cramps
Than pard or cat o' mountain.
Hark
Let them be hunted soundly. At this hour
Lie at my mercy all mine enemies:
Shortly shall all my labours end
Shalt have the air at freedom: for a little
Follow
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. Before PROSPERO'S cell.
Enter PROSPERO in his magic robes
Now does my project gather to a head:
My charms crack not; my spirits obey; and time
Goes upright with his carriage. How's the day?
On the sixth hour; at which time
I did say so
Confined together
In the same fashion as you gave in charge
They cannot budge till your release. The king
And the remainder mourning over them
Him that you term'd
His tears run down his beard
From eaves of reeds. Your charm so strongly works 'em
That if you now beheld them
Would become tender.
Dost thou think so
Mine would
And mine shall.
Hast thou
Of their afflictions
Though with their high wrongs I am struck to the quick
Do I take part: the rarer action is
In virtue than in vengeance: they being penitent
Not a frown further. Go release them
My charms I'll break
I'll fetch them
Exit
Ye elves of hills
Do chase the ebbing Neptune and do fly him
When he comes back; you demi-puppets that
By moonshine do the green sour ringlets make
Is to make midnight mushrooms
To hear the solemn curfew; by whose aid
The noontide sun
Set roaring war: to the dread rattling thunder
Have I given fire and rifted Jove's stout oak
With his own bolt; the strong-based promontory
Have I made shake and by the spurs pluck'd up
The pine and cedar: graves at my command
Have waked their sleepers
By my so potent art. But this rough magic
I here abjure
Some heavenly music
This airy charm is for
I'll drown my book.
Solemn music
Re-enter ARIEL before: then ALONSO
A solemn air and the best comforter
To an unsettled fancy cure thy brains
Holy Gonzalo
Begin to chase the ignorant fumes that mantle
Their clearer reason. O good Gonzalo
To him you follow'st! I will pay thy graces
Home both in word and deed. Most cruelly
Didst thou
Thy brother was a furtherer in the act.
Thou art pinch'd fort now
Begins to swell
Will shortly fill the reasonable shore
That now lies foul and muddy. Not one of them
That yet looks on me
I will discase me
As I was sometime Milan: quickly
Thou shalt ere long be free.
ARIEL sings and helps to attire him
Where the bee sucks. there suck I:
In a cowslip's bell I lie;
There I couch when owls do cry.
On the bat's back I do fly
After summer merrily.
Merrily
Under the blossom that hangs on the bough.
Why
But yet thou shalt have freedom: so
To the king's ship
There shalt thou find the mariners asleep
Under the hatches; the master and the boatswain
Being awake
I drink the air before me
Or ere your pulse twice beat.
Exit
All torment
Inhabits here: some heavenly power guide us
Out of this fearful country!
Behold
For more assurance that a living prince
Does now speak to thee
And to thee and thy company I bid
A hearty welcome.
Whether thou best he or no
Beats as of flesh and blood; and
Thy dukedom I resign and do entreat
Thou pardon me my wrongs. But how should Prospero
Be living and be here?
First
Be measured or confined.
Whether this be
Or be not
You do yet taste
Some subtilties o' the isle
Believe things certain. Welcome
Aside to SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO
But you
And justify you traitors: at this time
I will tell no tales.
[Aside]  The devil speaks in him.
No.
For you
Would even infect my mouth
Thy rankest fault; all of them; and require
My dukedom of thee
If thou be'st Prospero
How thou hast met us here
Were wreck'd upon this shore; where I have lost--
How sharp the point of this remembrance is!--
My dear son Ferdinand.
I am woe for't
Irreparable is the loss
Says it is past her cure.
I rather think
You have not sought her help
For the like loss I have her sovereign aid
And rest myself content.
You the like loss!
As great to me as late; and
To make the dear loss
Than you may call to comfort you
Have lost my daughter.
A daughter?
O heavens
Myself were mudded in that oozy bed
Where my son lies. When did you lose your daughter?
In this last tempest. I perceive these lords
At this encounter do so much admire
That they devour their reason and scarce think
Their eyes do offices of truth
Are natural breath: but
Been justled from your senses
That I am Prospero and that very duke
Which was thrust forth of Milan
Upon this shore
For 'tis a chronicle of day by day
Befitting this first meeting. Welcome
This cell's my court: here have I few attendants
And subjects none abroad: pray you
My dukedom since you have given me again
At least bring forth a wonder
As much as me my dukedom.
Here PROSPERO discovers FERDINAND and MIRANDA playing at chess
Sweet lord
No
Yes
If this prove
A vision of the Island
Shall I twice lose.
A most high miracle!
Though the seas threaten
I have cursed them without cause.
Kneels
Now all the blessings
Of a glad father compass thee about!
Arise
O
How many goodly creatures are there here!
How beauteous mankind is! O brave new world
'Tis new to thee.
What is this maid with whom thou wast at play?
Your eld'st acquaintance cannot be three hours:
Is she the goddess that hath sever'd us
Sir
But by immortal Providence she's mine:
I chose her when I could not ask my father
For his advice
Is daughter to this famous Duke of Milan
Received a second life; and second father
This lady makes him to me.
I am hers:
But
Must ask my child forgiveness!
There
Let us not burthen our remembrance with
A heaviness that's gone.
I have inly wept
For it is you that have chalk'd forth the way
Which brought us hither.
I say
Was Milan thrust from Milan
Should become kings of Naples? O
Beyond a common joy
With gold on lasting pillars: In one voyage
Did Claribel her husband find at Tunis
Where he himself was lost
In a poor isle and all of us ourselves
When no man was his own.
[To FERDINAND and MIRANDA]  Give me your hands:
Let grief and sorrow still embrace his heart
That doth not wish you joy!
Be it so! Amen!
Re-enter ARIEL
O
I prophesied
Hast thou no mouth by land? What is the news?
The best news is
Our king and company; the next
Which
Is tight and yare and bravely rigg'd as when
We first put out to sea.
[Aside to PROSPERO]  Sir
Have I done since I went.
[Aside to ARIEL]  My tricksy spirit!
These are not natural events; they strengthen
From strange to stranger. Say
If I did think
Where but even now with strange and several noises
Of roaring
Where we
Our royal
Capering to eye her: on a trice
And were brought moping hither.
[Aside to PROSPERO]          Was't well done?
[Aside to ARIEL]  Bravely
This is as strange a maze as e'er men trod
And there is in this business more than nature
Was ever conduct of: some oracle
Must rectify our knowledge.
Sir
The strangeness of this business; at pick'd leisure
Which shall be shortly
These happen'd accidents; till when
And think of each thing well.
Aside to ARIEL
Come hither
Set Caliban and his companions free;
Untie the spell.
Exit ARIEL
How fares my gracious sir?
There are yet missing of your company
Some few odd lads that you remember not.
Re-enter ARIEL
Every man shift for all the rest
let no man take care for himself; for all is
but fortune. Coragio
If these be true spies which I wear in my head
O Setebos
How fine my master is! I am afraid
He will chastise me.
Ha
What things are these
Will money buy 'em?
Very like; one of them
Is a plain fish
Mark but the badges of these men
That could control the moon
These three have robb'd me; and this demi-devil--
For he's a bastard one--had plotted with them
To take my life. Two of these fellows you
Must know and own; this thing of darkness!
Acknowledge mine.
I shall be pinch'd to death.
Is not this Stephano
He is drunk now: where had he wine?
And Trinculo is reeling ripe: where should they
Find this grand liquor that hath gilded 'em?
How camest thou in this pickle?
I have been in such a pickle since I
saw you last that
my bones: I shall not fear fly-blowing.
Why
O
You'ld be king o' the isle
I should have been a sore one then.
This is a strange thing as e'er I look'd on.
Pointing to Caliban
He is as disproportion'd in his manners
As in his shape. Go
Take with you your companions; as you look
To have my pardon
Ay
And seek for grace. What a thrice-double ass
Was I
And worship this dull fool!
Go to; away!
Hence
Or stole it
Exeunt CALIBAN
Sir
To my poor cell
For this one night; which
With such discourse as
Go quick away; the story of my life
And the particular accidents gone by
Since I came to this isle: and in the morn
I'll bring you to your ship and so to Naples
Of these our dear-beloved solemnized;
And thence retire me to my Milan
Every third thought shall be my grave.
I long
To hear the story of your life
Take the ear strangely.
I'll deliver all;
And promise you calm seas
And sail so expeditious that shall catch
Your royal fleet far off.
Aside to ARIEL
My Ariel
Be free
Exeunt
EPILOGUE
SPOKEN BY PROSPERO
Now my charms are all o'erthrown
And pardon'd the deceiver
In this bare island by your spell;
But release me from my bands
With the help of your good hands:
Gentle breath of yours my sails
Must fill
Spirits to enforce
Mercy itself and frees all faults.
As you from crimes would pardon'd be
ACT I
SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
Enter Poet
Good day
I am glad you're well.
I have not seen you long: how goes the world?
It wears
Ay
But what particular rarity? what strange
Hath conjured to attend. I know the merchant.
I know them both; th' other's a jeweller.
O
Nay
A most incomparable man
He passes.
"Jeweller:	I have a jewel here--"
O
"Jeweller:	If he will touch the estimate: but"
[Reciting to himself]  'When we for recompense have
praised the vile
Which aptly sings the good.'
'Tis a good form.
Looking at the jewel
And rich: here is a water
You are rapt
To the great lord.
A thing slipp'd idly from me.
Our poesy is as a gum
From whence 'tis nourish'd: the fire i' the flint
Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame
Provokes itself and like the current flies
Each bound it chafes. What have you there?
A picture
Upon the heels of my presentment
Let's see your piece.
'Tis a good piece.
So 'tis: this comes off well and excellent.
Indifferent.
Admirable: how this grace
Speaks his own standing! what a mental power
This eye shoots forth! how big imagination
Moves in this lip! to the dumbness of the gesture
One might interpret.
It is a pretty mocking of the life.
Here is a touch; is't good?
I will say of it
Lives in these touches
Enter certain Senators
How this lord is follow'd!
The senators of Athens: happy man!
Look
You see this confluence
of visitors.
I have
With amplest entertainment: my free drift
Halts not particularly
In a wide sea of wax: no levell'd malice
Infects one comma in the course I hold;
But flies an eagle flight
How shall I understand you?
I will unbolt to you.
You see how all conditions
Of grave and austere quality
Their services to Lord Timon: his large fortune
Upon his good and gracious nature hanging
Subdues and properties to his love and tendance
All sorts of hearts; yea
To Apemantus
Than to abhor himself: even he drops down
The knee before him
Most rich in Timon's nod.
I saw them speak together.
Sir
Feign'd Fortune to be throned: the base o' the mount
Is rank'd with all deserts
To propagate their states: amongst them all
Whose present grace to present slaves and servants
Translates his rivals.
'Tis conceived to scope.
This throne
To climb his happiness
In our condition.
Nay
All those which were his fellows but of late
Follow his strides
Drink the free air.
Ay
When Fortune in her shift and change of mood
Spurns down her late beloved
Which labour'd after him to the mountain's top
Even on their knees and hands
'Tis common:
A thousand moral paintings I can show
That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's
More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well
To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen
The foot above the head.
Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON
Imprison'd is he
Ay
Your honourable letter he desires
To those have shut him up; which failing
Noble Ventidius! Well;
I am not of that feather to shake off
My friend when he must need me. I do know him
A gentleman that well deserves a help:
Which he shall have: I'll pay the debt
Your lordship ever binds him.
Commend me to him: I will send his ransom;
And being enfranchised
'Tis not enough to help the feeble up
All happiness to your honour!
Exit
Enter an old Athenian
Lord Timon
Freely
Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.
I have so: what of him?
Most noble Timon
Attends he here
Here
This fellow here
That from my first have been inclined to thrift;
And my estate deserves an heir more raised
Than one which holds a trencher.
Well; what further?
One only daughter have I
The maid is fair
In qualities of the best. This man of thine
Attempts her love: I prithee
Myself have spoke in vain.
The man is honest.
Therefore he will be
His honesty rewards him in itself;
It must not bear my daughter.
Does she love him?
She is young and apt:
Our own precedent passions do instruct us
What levity's in youth.
[To LUCILIUS]           Love you the maid?
Ay
If in her marriage my consent be missing
Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world
How shall she be endow'd
Three talents on the present; in future
This gentleman of mine hath served me long:
To build his fortune I will strain a little
What you bestow
Most noble lord
My hand to thee; mine honour on my promise.
Humbly I thank your lordship: never may
The state or fortune fall into my keeping
Exeunt LUCILIUS and Old Athenian
Vouchsafe my labour
I thank you; you shall hear from me anon:
Go not away. What have you there
A piece of painting
Your lordship to accept.
Painting is welcome.
The painting is almost the natural man;
or since dishonour traffics with man's nature
Even such as they give out. I like your work;
And you shall find I like it: wait attendance
Till you hear further from me.
The gods preserve ye!
Well fare you
We must needs dine together. Sir
Hath suffer'd under praise.
What
A more satiety of commendations.
If I should pay you for't as 'tis extoll'd
My lord
As those which sell would give: but you well know
Are prized by their masters: believe't
Well mock'd.
No
Look
Enter APEMANTUS
Jeweller: We'll bear
He'll spare none.
Good morrow to thee
Till I be gentle
When thou art Timon's dog
Why dost thou call them knaves? thou know'st them not.
Are they not Athenians?
Yes.
Then I repent not.
Jeweller: You know me
Thou know'st I do: I call'd thee by thy name.
Thou art proud
Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.
Whither art going?
To knock out an honest Athenian's brains.
That's a deed thou'lt die for.
Right
How likest thou this picture
The best
Wrought he not well that painted it?
He wrought better that made the painter; and yet
he's but a filthy piece of work.
You're a dog.
Thy mother's of my generation: what's she
Wilt dine with me
No; I eat not lords.
An thou shouldst
O
That's a lascivious apprehension.
So thou apprehendest it: take it for thy labour.
How dost thou like this jewel
Not so well as plain-dealing
man a doit.
What dost thou think 'tis worth?
Not worth my thinking. How now
How now
Thou liest.
Art not one?
Yes.
Then I lie not.
Art not a poet?
Yes.
Then thou liest: look in thy last work
hast feigned him a worthy fellow.
That's not feigned; he is so.
Yes
labour: he that loves to be flattered is worthy o'
the flatterer. Heavens
What wouldst do then
E'en as Apemantus does now; hate a lord with my heart.
What
Ay.
Wherefore?
That I had no angry wit to be a lord.
Art not thou a merchant?
Ay
Traffic confound thee
If traffic do it
Traffic's thy god; and thy god confound thee!
Trumpet sounds. Enter a Messenger
What trumpet's that?
'Tis Alcibiades
Pray
Exeunt some Attendants
You must needs dine with me: go not you hence
Till I have thank'd you: when dinner's done
Enter ALCIBIADES
Most welcome
So
Aches contract and starve your supple joints!
That there should be small love 'mongst these
sweet knaves
Into baboon and monkey.
Sir
Most hungerly on your sight.
Right welcome
Ere we depart
In different pleasures. Pray you
Exeunt all except APEMANTUS

What time o' day is't
Time to be honest.
That time serves still.
The more accursed thou
Thou art going to Lord Timon's feast?
Ay
Fare thee well
Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.
Why
Shouldst have kept one to thyself
give thee none.
Hang thyself!
No
requests to thy friend.
Away

Exit
He's opposite to humanity. Come
The very heart of kindness.
He pours it out; Plutus
Sevenfold above itself; no gift to him
All use of quittance.
The noblest mind he carries
That ever govern'd man.
Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in?
I'll keep you company.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet  served in; FLAVIUS and others attending; then enter  TIMON
Most honour'd Timon
He is gone happy
Then
To your free heart
I derived liberty.
O
I gave it freely ever; and there's none
Can truly say he gives
If our betters play at that game
To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.
A noble spirit!
Nay
Ceremony was but devised at first
To set a gloss on faint deeds
But where there is true friendship
Pray
Than my fortunes to me.
They sit
My lord
Ho
O

Fie

They say
man is ever angry. Go

he fit for't

men eat Timon

and all the madness is
I wonder men dare trust themselves with men:
Methinks they should invite them without knives;
Good for their meat

breath of him in a divided draught

Great men should drink with harness on their throats.
My lord
Let it flow this way
Flow this way! A brave fellow! he keeps his tides
well. Those healths will make thee and thy state
look ill
be a sinner
This and my food are equals; there's no odds:
Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods.
Apemantus' grace.
Immortal gods
I pray for no man but myself:
Grant I may never prove so fond
Or a harlot
Or a dog
Or a keeper with my freedom;
Or my friends
Amen. So fall to't:
Rich men sin
Eats and drinks
Much good dich thy good heart
Captain Alcibiades
My heart is ever at your service
You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than a

So the were bleeding-new
like 'em: I could wish my best friend at such a feast.

Might we but have that happiness

for ever perfect.
O
themselves have provided that I shall have much help

friends

Hail to thee
That of his bounties taste! The five best senses

To gratulate thy plenteous bosom: th' ear
They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

Music

You see
Music. Re-enter Cupid with a mask of Ladies  as Amazons
Hoy-day
They dance! they are mad women.
Like madness is the glory of this life.
As this pomp shows to a little oil and root.
We make ourselves fools
And spend our flatteries
Upon whose age we void it up again
Who lives that's not depraved or depraves?
Who dies
Of their friends' gift?
I should fear those that dance before me now
Would one day stamp upon me: 't has been done;
Men shut their doors against a setting sun.
The Lords rise from table
You have done our pleasures much grace
You have added worth unto 't and lustre
I am to thank you for 't.
My lord

taking

gentleman

[Aside]                What will this come to?
He commands us to provide
Nor will he know his purse
His promises fly so beyond his state
That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes
For every word: he is so kind that he now
Pays interest for 't; his land's put to their books.
Well
Before I were forced out!
Happier is he that has no friend to feed
Than such that do e'en enemies exceed.
I bleed inwardly for my lord.
Exit
You do yourselves
Much wrong
Here
With more than common thanks I will receive it.
O
And now I remember
Good words the other day of a bay courser
I rode on: it is yours
O
You may take my word
Can justly praise but what he does affect:
I weigh my friend's affection with mine own;
I'll tell you true. I'll call to you.
O
I take all and your several visitations
So kind to heart
Methinks
It comes in charity to thee: for all thy living
Is 'mongst the dead
Lie in a pitch'd field.
Ay
We are so virtuously bound--
And so
Am I to you.
So infinitely endear'd--
All to you. Lights
The best of happiness
Ready for his friends.

What a coil's here!
Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums!
I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums
That are given for 'em. Friendship's full of dregs:
Methinks
Now
good to thee.
No
thou wouldst sin the faster. Thou givest so long
paper shortly: what need these feasts

Nay
sworn not to give regard to you. Farewell; and come
with better music.

So:
Thou wilt not hear me now; thou shalt not then:
I'll lock thy heaven from thee.
O
To counsel deaf

ACT II
SCENE I. A Senator's house.
Enter Senator
And late
He owes nine thousand; besides my former sum
Of raging waste? It cannot hold; it will not.
If I want gold
If I would sell my horse
Better than he
All that pass by. It cannot hold: no reason
Can found his state in safety. Caphis
Caphis
Enter CAPHIS
Here
Get on your cloak
Importune him for my moneys; be not ceased
With slight denial
'Commend me to your master'--and the cap
Plays in the right hand
Out of mine own; his days and times are past
And my reliances on his fracted dates
Have smit my credit: I love and honour him
Immediate are my needs
Must not be toss'd and turn'd to me in words
Put on a most importunate aspect
I go
'I go
I will
Go.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.
Enter FLAVIUS
No care
How things go from him
Of what is to continue: never mind
Was to be so unwise
What shall be done? he will not hear
I must be round with him
Fie
Enter CAPHIS
Good even
"Varro's Servant	Is't not your business too?"
It is: and yours too
"Isidore's Servant	It is so."
Would we were all discharged!
"Varro's Servant	I fear it."
Here comes the lord.
Enter TIMON
So soon as dinner's done
My lord
Dues! Whence are you?
Of Athens here
Go to my steward.
Please it your lordship
To the succession of new days this month:
My master is awaked by great occasion
To call upon his own
That with your other noble parts you'll suit
In giving him his right.
Mine honest friend
Nay
Contain thyself
"Varro's Servant	One Varro's servant"

If you did know
"Varro's Servant	'Twas due on forfeiture"

I do beseech you
I'll wait upon you instantly.

Good! gramercy.

Ay

and a knave; which not-withstanding
no less esteemed.

A fool in good clothes
'Tis a spirit: sometime't appears like a lord;
sometime like a lawyer; sometime like a philosopher
very often like a knight; and
shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore
to thirteen

Nor thou altogether a wise man: as much foolery as
I have
That answer might have become Apemantus.

You make me marvel: wherefore ere this time
Had you not fully laid my state before me
You would not hear me
Go to:

And that unaptness made your minister
O my good lord
When
Return so much
Yea
To hold your hand more close: I did endure
Not seldom
Prompted you in the ebb of your estate
And your great flow of debts. My loved lord
The greatest of your having lacks a half
To pay your present debts.
Let all my land be sold.
'Tis all engaged
And what remains will hardly stop the mouth
Of present dues: the future comes apace:
What shall defend the interim? and at length
How goes our reckoning?
To Lacedaemon did my land extend.
O my good lord
Were it all yours to give it in a breath
You tell me true.
If you suspect my husbandry or falsehood
And set me on the proof. So the gods bless me
With riotous feeders
With drunken spilth of wine
Hath blazed with lights and bray'd with minstrelsy
Prithee
Heavens
How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants
This night englutted! Who is not Timon's?
What heart
Lord Timon's?
Great Timon
Ah
Feast-won
Come
No villanous bounty yet hath pass'd my heart;
Unwisely
Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack
If I would broach the vessels of my love
As I can bid thee speak.
Assurance bless your thoughts!
And
Shall I try friends: you shall perceive how you
Mistake my fortunes; I am wealthy in my friends.
Within there! Flaminius! Servilius!

My lord? my lord?

to-day: you
loves

As you have said
[Aside]  Lord Lucius and Lucullus? hum!
Go you
Of whom
Deserved this hearing--bid 'em send o' the instant
A thousand talents to me.
I have been bold--
For that I knew it the most general way--
To them to use your signet and your name;
But they do shake their heads
No richer in return.
Is't true? can't be?
They answer
Do what they would; are sorry--you are honourable
But yet they could have wish'd--they know not--
Something hath been amiss--a noble nature
May catch a wrench--would all were well--'tis pity;--
And so
They froze me into silence.
You gods
Prithee
Have their ingratitude in them hereditary:
Their blood is caked
'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind;
And nature
To a Servant

To FLAVIUS
Prithee
No blame belongs to thee.
To Servant
Ventidius lately
Buried his father; by whose death he's stepp'd
Into a great estate: when he was poor
Bid him suppose some good necessity
Touches his friend
With those five talents.

To FLAVIUS
That had
To whom 'tis instant due. Ne'er speak
I would I could not think it: that thought is
bounty's foe;
Being free itself

ACT III

Flaminius
Your lordship speaks your pleasure.
I have observed thee always for a towardly prompt
spirit--give thee thy due--and one that knows what
belongs to reason; and canst use the time well
the time use thee well: good parts in thee.
To Servant
Get you gone

bountiful gentleman: but thou art wise; and thou

thou sawest me not. Fare thee well.
Is't possible the world should so much differ
Throwing the money back
Ha! now I see thou art a fool

Let moulten coin be thy damnation
Has friendship such a faint and milky heart
Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment

Which my lord paid for

Who
an honourable gentleman.

To LUCIUS

commend me to thy honourable virtuous lord

May it please your honour
Ha! what has he sent? I am so much endeared to

Has only sent his present occasion now

I know his lordship is but merry with me;

If his occasion were not virtuous

Ay

same piece
Is every flatterer's spirit. Who can call him
His friend that dips in the same dish? for
My knowing
Has paid his men their wages: he ne'er drinks
And yet--O
When he looks out in an ungrateful shape!--
He does deny him
Religion groans at it.
For mine own part
And honourable carriage
For policy sits above conscience.

SCENE III. A room in Sempronius' house.
Enter SEMPRONIUS
Must he needs trouble me in 't
all others?
He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus;
And now Ventidius is wealthy too
Owe their estates unto him.
My lord
They have au denied him.
How! have they denied him?
Has Ventidius and Lucullus denied him?
And does he send to me? Three? hum!
It shows but little love or judgment in him:
Must I be his last refuge! His friends
physicians
Has much disgraced me in't; I'm angry at him
For
That e'er received gift from him:
And does he think so backwardly of me now
So it may prove an argument of laughter
To the rest
I'ld rather than the worth of thrice the sum
I'd such a courage to do him good. But now return
Who bates mine honour shall not know my coin.
Exit
Excellent! Your lordship's a goodly villain. The
devil knew not what he did when he made man
politic; he crossed himself by 't: and I cannot
think but
set him clear. How fairly this lord strives to
appear foul! takes virtuous copies to be wicked
whole realms on fire: Of such a nature is his
politic love.
This was my lord's best hope; now all are fled
Many a bounteous year must be employ'd
Now to guard sure their master.
And this is all a liberal course allows;
Who cannot keep his wealth must keep his house.
Exit

Well met; good morrow

Lucius!
What
"Lucilius' Servant	Ay"
One business does command us all; for mine Is money.
So is theirs and ours.

"Lucilius' Servant	And Sir Philotus too!"
Good day at once.
"Lucilius' Servant	                  Welcome"
What do you think the hour?
Labouring for nine.
"Lucilius' Servant	So much?"
Is not my lord seen yet?
"Lucilius' Servant	Not yet."
I wonder on't; he was wont to shine at seven.
"Lucilius' Servant	Ay"
You must consider that a prodigal course
Is like the sun's; but not
I fear 'tis deepest winter in Lord Timon's purse;
That is one may reach deep enough
Find little.
I am of your fear for that.
I'll show you how to observe a strange event.
Your lord sends now for money.
Most true
And he wears jewels now of Timon's gift
It is against my heart.
"Lucilius' Servant	Mark"
And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels
I'm weary of this charge

SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.
My lord
Bloody; 'tis necessary he should die:
Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.
Most true; the law shall bruise him.
Enter ALCIBIADES
Honour
Now
I am an humble suitor to your virtues;
For pity is the virtue of the law
It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy
Upon a friend of mine
To those that
He is a man
Nor did he soil the fact with cowardice--
An honour in him which buys out his fault--
But with a noble fury and fair spirit
And with such sober and unnoted passion
He did behave his anger
You undergo too strict a paradox
Your words have took such pains as if they labour'd
To bring manslaughter into form and set quarrelling
Upon the head of valour; which indeed
Is valour misbegot and came into the world
When sects and factions were newly born:
He's truly valiant that can wisely suffer
The worst that man can breathe
His outsides
If wrongs be evils and enforce us kill
My lord
You cannot make gross sins look clear:
To revenge is no valour
My lords
Why do fond men expose themselves to battle
Such valour in the bearing
Abroad? why then
That stay at home
Loaden with irons wiser than the judge
Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood?
To kill
But
To be in anger is impiety;
But who is man that is not angry?
Weigh but the crime with this.
You breathe in vain.
In vain! his service done
At Lacedaemon and Byzantium
Were a sufficient briber for his life.
What's that?
I say
How full of valour did he bear himself
In the last conflict
He has made too much plenty with 'em;
He's a sworn rioter: he has a sin that often
Drowns him
If there were no foes
To overcome him: in that beastly fury
He has been known to commit outrages
He dies.
Hard fate! he might have died in war.
My lords
Though his right arm might purchase his own time
And be in debt to none--yet
And
Security
My honours to you
If by this crime he owes the law his life
For law is strict
We are for law: he dies; urge it no more
Must it be so? it must not be. My lords
How!
Call me to your remembrances.
What!
I cannot think but your age has forgot me;
It could not else be
My wounds ache at you.
Do you dare our anger?
'Tis in few words
We banish thee for ever.
Banish me!
Banish your dotage; banish usury
If
our spirit
Exeunt Senators
Now the gods keep you old enough; that you may live
Only in bone
I'm worse than mad: I have kept back their foes
Their coin upon large interest
Rich only in large hurts. All those for this?
Is this the balsam that the usuring senate
Pours into captains' wounds? Banishment!
It comes not ill; I hate not to be banish'd;
It is a cause worthy my spleen and fury
My discontented troops
'Tis honour with most lands to be at odds;
Soldiers should brook as little wrongs as gods.
Exit
SCENE VI. The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
Music. Tables set out: Servants attending.  Enter divers Lords
The good time of day to you
I also wish it to you. I think this honourable lord
did but try us this other day.
Upon that were my thoughts tiring
encountered: I hope it is not so low with him as
he made it seem in the trial of his several friends.
It should not be
I should think so: he hath sent me an earnest
inviting
to put off; but he hath conjured me beyond them
I must needs appear.
In like manner was I in debt to my importunate
business

provision was out.
I am sick of that grief too
things go.
Every man here's so. What would he have borrowed of
you?
A thousand pieces.
A thousand pieces!
What of you?
He sent to me
Enter TIMON and Attendants
With all my heart
Ever at the best
The swallow follows not summer more willing than we
your lordship.
[Aside]  Nor more willingly leaves winter; such
summer-birds are men. Gentlemen
recompense this long stay: feast your ears with the
music awhile
trumpet's sound; we shall to 't presently.
I hope it remains not unkindly with your lordship
that I returned you an empty messenger.
O
My noble lord
Ah
My most honourable lord
Think not on 't
If you had sent but two hours before

The banquet brought in

Royal cheer

it.

Alcibiades banished!
'Tis so
How! how!
I pray you
My worthy friends
I'll tell you more anon. Here's a noble feast toward.
This is the old man still.
Will 't hold? will 't hold?
It does: but time will--and so--
I do conceive.
Each man to his stool
the lip of his mistress: your diet shall be in all

The dishes are uncovered and seen to be full of warm water
What does his lordship mean?
I know not.
May you a better feast never behold
Is your perfection. This is Timon's last;
Who
Your reeking villany.
Throwing the water in their faces
Live loathed and long
Of man and beast the infinite malady

Soft! take thy physic first--thou too--and thou;--

Throws the dishes at them

Of Timon man and all humanity!

How now
Know you the quality of Lord Timon's fury?
Push! did you see my cap?
I have lost my gown.
He's but a mad lord
