Did you see my cap?
Here 'tis.
Here lies my gown.
Let's make no stay.
Lord Timon's mad.
I feel 't upon my bones.
One day he gives us diamonds
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Without the walls of Athens.
Enter TIMON
Let me look back upon thee. O thou wall
Obedience fail in children! slaves and fools
Convert o' the instant
Rather than render back
Large-handed robbers your grave masters are
Thy mistress is o' the brothel! Son of sixteen
On Athens
As lamely as their manners. Lust and liberty
Creep in the minds and marrows of our youth
Be general leprosy! Breath infect breath
merely poison! Nothing I'll bear from thee
Take thou that too
Timon will to the woods; where he shall find
The unkindest beast more kinder than mankind.
The gods confound--hear me
The Athenians both within and out that wall!
And grant
To the whole race of mankind
Exit
SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.
Enter FLAVIUS
Hear you
Are we undone? cast off? nothing remaining?
Alack
Let me be recorded by the righteous gods
Such a house broke!
So noble a master fall'n! All gone! and not
One friend to take his fortune by the arm
As we do turn our backs
From our companion thrown into his grave
Slink all away
Enter other Servants
All broken implements of a ruin'd house.
Yet do our hearts wear Timon's livery;
That see I by our faces; we are fellows still
Into this sea of air.
Good fellows all
Wherever we shall meet
Nay
Thus part we rich in sorrow
Servants embrace
O
Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt
Who would be so mock'd with glory? or to live
But in a dream of friendship?
To have his pomp and all what state compounds
But only painted
Poor honest lord
Who
For bounty
My dearest lord
Are made thy chief afflictions. Alas
He's flung in rage from this ingrateful seat
Of monstrous friends
Supply his life
I'll follow and inquire him out:
I'll ever serve his mind with my best will;
Whilst I have gold
Exit
SCENE III. Woods and cave
Enter TIMON
O blessed breeding sun
Rotten humidity; below thy sister's orb
Infect the air! Twinn'd brothers of one womb
The greater scorns the lesser: not nature
Raise me this beggar
The senator shall bear contempt hereditary
It is the pasture lards the rother's sides
Is smooth'd by that below: the learned pate
Ducks to the golden fool: all is oblique;
There's nothing level in our cursed natures
All feasts
His semblable
Destruction fang mankind! Earth
Digging
Who seeks for better of thee
With thy most operant poison! What is here?
Gold? yellow
Thus much of this will make black white
Ha
Will lug your priests and servants from your sides
This yellow slave
Will knit and break religions
And give them title
With senators on the bench: this is it
That makes the wappen'd widow wed again;
She
Would cast the gorge at
To the April day again. Come
Among the route of nations
Do thy right nature.
March afar off
Ha! a drum ? Thou'rt quick
Nay
Keeping some gold
Enter ALCIBIADES
What art thou there? speak.
A beast
What is thy name? Is man so hateful to thee
I am Misanthropos
For thy part
I know thee well;
But in thy fortunes am unlearn'd and strange.
I know thee too; and more than that I know thee
With man's blood paint the ground
Religious canons
Then what should war be? This fell whore of thine
Hath in her more destruction than thy sword
Thy lips rot off!
I will not kiss thee; then the rot returns
To thine own lips again.
How came the noble Timon to this change?
As the moon does
But then renew I could not
There were no suns to borrow of.
Noble Timon
None
Maintain my opinion.
What is it
Promise me friendship
wilt not promise
a man! if thou dost perform
thou art a man!
I have heard in some sort of thy miseries.
Thou saw'st them
I see them now; then was a blessed time.
As thine is now
Is this the Athenian minion
Voiced so regardfully?
Art thou Timandra?
Yes.
Be a whore still: they love thee not that use thee;
Give them diseases
Make use of thy salt hours: season the slaves
For tubs and baths; bring down rose-cheeked youth
To the tub-fast and the diet.
Hang thee
Pardon him
Are drown'd and lost in his calamities.
I have but little gold of late
In my penurious band: I have heard
I prithee
I am thy friend
How dost thou pity him whom thou dost trouble?
I had rather be alone.
Why
Here is some gold for thee.
Keep it
When I have laid proud Athens on a heap
Warr'st thou 'gainst Athens?
Ay
The gods confound them all in thy conquest;
And thee after
Why me
That
Put up thy gold: go on
Be as a planetary plague
Will o'er some high-viced city hang his poison
In the sick air: let not thy sword skip one:
Pity not honour'd age for his white beard;
He is an usurer: strike me the counterfeit matron;
It is her habit only that is honest
Make soft thy trenchant sword; for those milk-paps
Think it a bastard
Hath doubtfully pronounced thy throat shall cut
Put armour on thine ears and on thine eyes;
Whose proof
Make large confusion; and
Hast thou gold yet? I'll take the gold thou
givest me
Dost thou
upon thee!
Give us some gold
Enough to make a whore forswear her trade
Into strong shudders and to heavenly agues
The immortal gods that hear you
And he whose pious breath seeks to convert you
Let your close fire predominate his smoke
With burthens of the dead;--some that were hang'd
Paint till a horse may mire upon your face
Well
Believe't
Consumptions sow
In hollow bones of man; strike their sharp shins
Of him that
ruffians bald;
And let the unscarr'd braggarts of the war
Derive some pain from you: plague all;
That your activity may defeat and quell
The source of all erection. There's more gold:
Do you damn others
More counsel with more money
More whore
Strike up the drum towards Athens! Farewell
If I thrive well
If I hope well
I never did thee harm.
Yes
Call'st thou that harm?
Men daily find it. Get thee away
Thy beagles with thee.
We but offend him. Strike!
Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES
That nature
Whose womb unmeasurable
Whereon Hyperion's quickening fire doth shine;
Yield him
Ensear thy fertile and conceptious womb
Go great with tigers
Teem with new monsters
Hath to the marbled mansion all above
Never presented!--O
Dry up thy marrows
Whereof ungrateful man
And morsels unctuous
Enter APEMANTUS
More man? plague
I was directed hither: men report
Thou dost affect my manners
'Tis
This is in thee a nature but infected;
A poor unmanly melancholy sprung
From change of fortune. Why this spade? this place?
This slave-like habit? and these looks of care?
Thy flatterers yet wear silk
Hug their diseased perfumes
That ever Timon was. Shame not these woods
Be thou a flatterer now
By that which has undone thee: hinge thy knee
Thou gavest thine ears like tapsters that bid welcome
To knaves and all approachers: 'tis most just
That thou turn rascal; hadst thou wealth again
Were I like thee
Thou hast cast away thyself
A madman so long
That the bleak air
cold brook
Whose naked natures live in an the spite
Of wreakful heaven
O
A fool of thee: depart.
I love thee better now than e'er I did.
I hate thee worse.
Why?
Thou flatter'st misery.
I flatter not; but say thou art a caitiff.
Why dost thou seek me out?
To vex thee.
Always a villain's office or a fool's.
Dost please thyself in't?
Ay.
What! a knave too?
If thou didst put this sour-cold habit on
To castigate thy pride
Dost it enforcedly; thou'ldst courtier be again
Outlives encertain pomp
The one is filling still
The other
Thou shouldst desire to die
Not by his breath that is more miserable.
Thou art a slave
With favour never clasp'd; but bred a dog.
Hadst thou
The sweet degrees that this brief world affords
To such as may the passive drugs of it
Freely command
In general riot; melted down thy youth
In different beds of lust; and never learn'd
The icy precepts of respect
The sugar'd game before thee. But myself
At duty
Do on the oak
Fell from their boughs and left me open
For every storm that blows: I
Thy nature did commence in sufferance
Hath made thee hard in't. Why shouldst thou hate men?
They never flatter'd thee: what hast thou given?
If thou wilt curse
To some she beggar and compounded thee
Poor rogue hereditary. Hence
If thou hadst not been born the worst of men
Art thou proud yet?
Ay
I
No prodigal.
I
Were all the wealth I have shut up in thee
That the whole life of Athens were in this!
Thus would I eat it.
Eating a root
Here; I will mend thy feast.
Offering him a root
First mend my company
So I shall mend mine own
'Tis not well mended so
if not
What wouldst thou have to Athens?
Thee thither in a whirlwind. If thou wilt
Here is no use for gold.
The best and truest;
For here it sleeps
Where liest o' nights
Under that's above me.
Where feed'st thou o' days
Where my stomach finds meat; or
it.
Would poison were obedient and knew my mind!
Where wouldst thou send it?
To sauce thy dishes.
The middle of humanity thou never knewest
extremity of both ends: when thou wast in thy gilt
and thy perfume
curiosity; in thy rags thou knowest none
despised for the contrary. There's a medlar for
thee
On what I hate I feed not.
Dost hate a medlar?
Ay
An thou hadst hated meddlers sooner
have loved thyself better now. What man didst thou
ever know unthrift that was beloved after his means?
Who
ever know beloved?
Myself.
I understand thee; thou hadst some means to keep a
dog.
What things in the world canst thou nearest compare
to thy flatterers?
Women nearest; but men
themselves. What wouldst thou do with the world
Give it the beasts
Wouldst thou have thyself fall in the confusion of
men
Ay
A beastly ambition
attain to! If thou wert the lion
beguile thee; if thou wert the lamb
eat three: if thou wert the fox
suspect thee
the ass: if thou wert the ass
torment thee
breakfast to the wolf: if thou wert the wolf
greediness would afflict thee
hazard thy life for thy dinner: wert thou the
unicorn
make thine own self the conquest of thy fury: wert
thou a bear
wert thou a horse
leopard: wert thou a leopard
the lion and the spots of thy kindred were jurors on
thy life: all thy safety were remotion and thy
defence absence. What beast couldst thou be
were not subject to a beast? and what a beast art
thou already
transformation!
If thou couldst please me with speaking to me
mightst have hit upon it here: the commonwealth of
Athens is become a forest of beasts.
How has the ass broke the wall
Yonder comes a poet and a painter: the plague of
company light upon thee! I will fear to catch it
and give way: when I know not what else to do
see thee again.
When there is nothing living but thee
welcome. I had rather be a beggar's dog than Apemantus.
Thou art the cap of all the fools alive.
Would thou wert clean enough to spit upon!
A plague on thee! thou art too bad to curse.
All villains that do stand by thee are pure.
There is no leprosy but what thou speak'st.
If I name thee.
I'll beat thee
I would my tongue could rot them off!
Away
Choler does kill me that thou art alive;
I swound to see thee.
Would thou wouldst burst!
Away
A stone by thee.
Throws a stone at him
Beast!
Slave!
Toad!
Rogue
I am sick of this false world
But even the mere necessities upon 't.
Then
Lie where the light foam the sea may beat
Thy grave-stone daily: make thine epitaph
To the gold
O thou sweet king-killer
'Twixt natural son and sire! thou bright defiler
Of Hymen's purest bed! thou valiant Mars!
Thou ever young
That lies on Dian's lap! thou visible god
every tongue
Think
Set them into confounding odds
May have the world in empire!
Would 'twere so!
But not till I am dead. I'll say thou'st gold:
Thou wilt be throng'd to shortly.
Throng'd to!
Ay.
Thy back
Live
Long live so
Exit APEMANTUS
I am quit.
Moe things like men! Eat
Enter Banditti
Where should he have this gold? It is some poor
fragment
mere want of gold
friends
It is noised he hath a mass of treasure.
Let us make the assay upon him: if he care not
for't
reserve it
True; for he bears it not about him
Is not this he?
Where?
'Tis his description.
He; I know him.
Save thee
Now
Soldiers
Both too; and women's sons.
We are not thieves
Your greatest want is
Why should you want? Behold
Within this mile break forth a hundred springs;
The oaks bear mast
The bounteous housewife
Lays her full mess before you. Want! why want?
We cannot live on grass
Nor on the beasts themselves
You must eat men. Yet thanks I must you con
That you are thieves profess'd
In holier shapes: for there is boundless theft
In limited professions. Rascal thieves
His antidotes are poison
Moe than you rob: take wealth and lives together;
Do villany
The sun's a thief
Robs the vast sea: the moon's an arrant thief
The sea's a thief
The moon into salt tears: the earth's a thief
From general excrement: each thing's a thief:
The laws
Have uncheque'd theft. Love not yourselves: away
All that you meet are thieves: to Athens go
I give you; and gold confound you howsoe'er! Amen.
Has almost charmed me from my profession
persuading me to it.
'Tis in the malice of mankind that he thus advises
us; not to have us thrive in our mystery.
I'll believe him as an enemy
Let us first see peace in Athens: there is no time
so miserable but a man may be true.
Exeunt Banditti
Enter FLAVIUS
O you gods!
Is yond despised and ruinous man my lord?
Full of decay and failing? O monument
And wonder of good deeds evilly bestow'd!
What an alteration of honour
Has desperate want made!
What viler thing upon the earth than friends
Who can bring noblest minds to basest ends!
How rarely does it meet with this time's guise
Grant I may ever love
Those that would mischief me than those that do!
Has caught me in his eye: I will present
My honest grief unto him; and
Away! what art thou?
Have you forgot me
Why dost ask that? I have forgot all men;
Then
An honest poor servant of yours.
Then I know thee not:
I never had honest man about me
I kept were knaves
The gods are witness
For his undone lord than mine eyes for you.
What
love thee
Flinty mankind; whose eyes do never give
But thorough lust and laughter. Pity's sleeping:
Strange times
I beg of you to know me
To entertain me as your steward still.
Had I a steward
So true
It almost turns my dangerous nature mild.
Let me behold thy face. Surely
Was born of woman.
Forgive my general and exceptless rashness
One honest man--mistake me not--but one;
No more
How fain would I have hated all mankind!
And thou redeem'st thyself: but all
Methinks thou art more honest now than wise;
For
For many so arrive at second masters
For I must ever doubt
Is not thy kindness subtle
No
Doubt and suspect
You should have fear'd false times when you did feast:
Suspect still comes where an estate is least.
That which I show
For this one wish
To requite me
Look thee
Have sent thee treasure. Go
But thus condition'd: thou shalt build from men;
Hate all
What thou deny'st to men; let prisons swallow 'em
blasted woods
And so farewell and thrive.
O
If thou hatest curses
Ne'er see thou man
Exit FLAVIUS. TIMON retires to his cave
ACT V
SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.
Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave
As I took note of the place
he abides.
What's to be thought of him? does the rumour hold
for true
Certain: Alcibiades reports it; Phrynia and
Timandra had gold of him: he likewise enriched poor
straggling soldiers with great quantity: 'tis said
he gave unto his steward a mighty sum.
Then this breaking of his has been but a try for his friends.
Nothing else: you shall see him a palm in Athens
again
'tis not amiss we tender our loves to him
supposed distress of his: it will show honestly in
us; and is very likely to load our purposes with
what they travail for
that goes of his having.
What have you now to present unto him?
Nothing at this time but my visitation: only I will
promise him an excellent piece.
I must serve him so too
that's coming toward him.
Good as the best. Promising is the very air o' the
time: it opens the eyes of expectation:
performance is ever the duller for his act; and
deed of saying is quite out of use. To promise is
most courtly and fashionable: performance is a kind
of will or testament which argues a great sickness
in his judgment that makes it.
TIMON comes from his cave
[Aside]  Excellent workman! thou canst not paint a
man so bad as is thyself.
I am thinking what I shall say I have provided for
him: it must be a personating of himself; a satire
against the softness of prosperity
of the infinite flatteries that follow youth and opulency.
[Aside]  Must thou needs stand for a villain in
thine own work? wilt thou whip thine own faults in
other men? Do so
Nay
Then do we sin against our own estate
True;
When the day serves
[Aside]  I'll meet you at the turn. What a
god's gold
Than where swine feed!
'Tis thou that rigg'st the bark and plough'st the foam
To thee be worship! and thy saints for aye
Be crown'd with plagues that thee alone obey!
Fit I meet them.
Coming forward
Hail
Our late noble master!
Have I once lived to see two honest men?
Sir
Not all the whips of heaven are large enough:
What! to you
To their whole being! I am rapt and cannot cover
The monstrous bulk of this ingratitude
With any size of words.
Let it go naked
You that are honest
He and myself
Have travail'd in the great shower of your gifts
Ay
We are hither come to offer you our service.
Most honest men! Why
Can you eat roots
What we can do
Ye're honest men: ye've heard that I have gold;
I am sure you have: speak truth; ye're honest men.
So it is said
Came not my friend nor I.
Good honest men! Thou draw'st a counterfeit
Best in all Athens: thou'rt
Thou counterfeit'st most lively.
So
E'en so
That thou art even natural in thine art.
But
Marry
You take much pains to mend.
Beseech your honour
To make it known to us.
You'll take it ill.
Most thankfully
Will you
Doubt it not
There's never a one of you but trusts a knave
Do we
Ay
That he's a made-up villain.
I know none such
Nor I.
Look you
Hang them or stab them
Name them
You that way and you this
Each man apart
If where thou art two villains shall not be
But where one villain is
Hence
To Painter
You have work'd for me; there's payment for you: hence!
To Poet
You are an alchemist; make gold of that.
Out
Beats them out
Enter FLAVIUS and two Senators
It is in vain that you would speak with Timon;
For he is set so only to himself
That nothing but himself which looks like man
Is friendly with him.
Bring us to his cave:
It is our part and promise to the Athenians
To speak with Timon.
At all times alike
Men are not still the same: 'twas time and griefs
That framed him thus: time
Here is his cave.
Peace and content be here! Lord Timon! Timon!
Look out
Speak to them
TIMON comes from his cave
Thou sun
be hang'd:
For each true word
Be as cauterizing to the root o' the tongue
Worthy Timon
Of none but such as you
The senators of Athens greet thee
I thank them; and would send them back the plague
O
What we are sorry for ourselves in thee.
The senators with one consent of love
Entreat thee back to Athens; who have thought
On special dignities
For thy best use and wearing.
They confess
Toward thee forgetfulness too general
Which now the public body
Play the recanter
A lack of Timon's aid
Of its own fail
And send forth us
Than their offence can weigh down by the dram;
Ay
As shall to thee blot out what wrongs were theirs
And write in thee the figures of their love
You witch me in it;
Surprise me to the very brink of tears:
Lend me a fool's heart and a woman's eyes
Therefore
And of our Athens
The captainship
Live with authority: so soon we shall drive back
Of Alcibiades the approaches wild
His country's peace.
And shakes his threatening sword
Against the walls of Athens.
Therefore
Well
If Alcibiades kill my countrymen
Of contumelious
But I do prize it at my love before
The reverend'st throat in Athens. So I leave you
To the protection of the prosperous gods
Stay not
Why
it will be seen to-morrow: my long sickness
Of health and living now begins to mend
Be Alcibiades your plague
We speak in vain.
But yet I love my country
One that rejoices in the common wreck
That's well spoke.
Commend me to my loving countrymen
These words become your lips as they pass
thorough them.
And enter in our ears like great triumphers
In their applauding gates.
Commend me to them
That nature's fragile vessel doth sustain
In life's uncertain voyage
I'll teach them to prevent wild Alcibiades' wrath.
I like this well; he will return again.
I have a tree
From high to low throughout
To stop affliction
Trouble him no further; thus you still shall find him.
Come not to me again: but say to Athens
Upon the beached verge of the salt flood;
Who once a day with his embossed froth
The turbulent surge shall cover: thither come
Lips
What is amiss plague and infection mend!
Graves only be men's works and death their gain!
Sun
Retires to his cave
His discontents are unremoveably
Coupled to nature.
Our hope in him is dead: let us return
In our dear peril.
It requires swift foot.
Exeunt
SCENE II. Before the walls of Athens.
Enter two Senators and a Messenger
Thou hast painfully discover'd: are his files
As full as thy report?
have spoke the least:
Besides
Present approach.
We stand much hazard
I met a courier
Whom
From Alcibiades to Timon's cave
His fellowship i' the cause against your city
Here come our brothers.
Enter the Senators from TIMON
No talk of Timon
The enemies' drum is heard
Doth choke the air with dust: in
Ours is the fall
Exeunt
SCENE III. The woods. Timon's cave
Enter a Soldier
By all description this should be the place.
Who's here? speak
Timon is dead
Some beast rear'd this; there does not live a man.
Dead
I cannot read; the character I'll take with wax:
Our captain hath in every figure skill
Before proud Athens he's set down by this
Exit
SCENE IV. Before the walls of Athens.
Trumpets sound. Enter ALCIBIADES with his powers
Sound to this coward and lascivious town
Our terrible approach.
A parley sounded
Enter Senators on the walls
Till now you have gone on and fill'd the time
With all licentious measure
The scope of justice; till now myself and such
As slept within the shadow of your power
Hav e wander'd with our traversed arms and breathed
Our sufferance vainly: now the time is flush
Cries of itself 'No more:' now breathless wrong
Shall sit and pant in your great chairs of ease
With fear and horrid flight.
Noble and young
Above their quantity.
So did we woo
Transformed Timon to our city's love
By humble message and by promised means:
We were not all unkind
The common stroke of war.
These walls of ours
Were not erected by their hands from whom
You have received your griefs; nor are they such
That these great towers
should fall
For private faults in them.
Nor are they living
Who were the motives that you first went out;
Shame that they wanted cunning
Hath broke their hearts. March
By decimation
If thy revenges hunger for that food
Which nature loathes--take thou the destined tenth
Let die the spotted.
All have not offended;
For those that were
On those that are
Spare thy Athenian cradle and those kin
Which in the bluster of thy wrath must fall
With those that have offended: like a shepherd
What thou wilt
Than hew to't with thy sword.
Set but thy foot
Against our rampired gates
So thou wilt send thy gentle heart before
Throw thy glove
And not as our confusion
Shall make their harbour in our town
Have seal'd thy full desire.
Then there's my glove;
Descend
Those enemies of Timon's and mine own
Whom you yourselves shall set out for reproof
Fall and no more: and
With my more noble meaning
Shall pass his quarter
Of regular justice in your city's bounds
At heaviest answer.
'Tis most nobly spoken.
Descend
The Senators descend
Enter Soldier
My noble general
Entomb'd upon the very hem o' the sea;
And on his grave-stone this insculpture
With wax I brought away
Interprets for my poor ignorance.
[Reads the epitaph]  'Here lies a
wretched corse
Seek not my name: a plague consume you wicked
caitiffs left!
Here lie I
Pass by and curse thy fill
not here thy gait.'
These well express in thee thy latter spirits:
Though thou abhorr'dst in us our human griefs
droplets which
From niggard nature fall
Taught thee to make vast Neptune weep for aye
On thy low grave
Is noble Timon: of whose memory
Hereafter more. Bring me into your city
Prescribe to other as each other's leech.
Let our drums strike.
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. Rome. Before the Capitol.
The Tomb of the ANDRONICI appearing; the Tribunes  and Senators aloft. Enter
Noble patricians
I am his first-born son
That wore the imperial diadem of Rome;
Then let my father's honours live in me
Romans
And suffer not dishonour to approach
The imperial seat
But let desert in pure election shine
Enter MARCUS ANDRONICUS
Princes
Ambitiously for rule and empery
A special party
For many good and great deserts to Rome:
A nobler man
He by the senate is accit'd home
From weary wars against the barbarous Goths;
That
Ten years are spent since first he undertook
This cause of Rome and chastised with arms
Our enemies' pride: five times he hath return'd
Bleeding to Rome
In coffins from the field;
And now at last
Let us entreat
And in the Capitol and senate's right
Dismiss your followers and
How fair the tribune speaks to calm my thoughts!
Marcus Andronicus
In thy uprightness and integrity
Commit my cause in balance to be weigh'd.
Exeunt the followers of BASSIANUS
Friends
Commit myself
Exeunt the followers of SATURNINUS
Rome
As I am confident and kind to thee.
Open the gates
Tribunes
Flourish. SATURNINUS and BASSIANUS go up into the Capitol
Enter a Captain
Romans
Patron of virtue
From where he circumscribed with his sword
Drums and trumpets sounded. Enter MARTIUS and  MUTIUS; After them
Hail
Lo
From whence at first she weigh'd her anchorage
Thou great defender of this Capitol
Romans
These that survive let Rome reward with love;
These that I bring unto their latest home
Here Goths have given me leave to sheathe my sword.
Titus
Make way to lay them by their brethren.
The tomb is opened
There greet in silence
O sacred receptacle of my joys
Give us the proudest prisoner of the Goths
Ad manes fratrum sacrifice his flesh
That so the shadows be not unappeased
I give him you
Stay
And if thy sons were ever dear to thee
Sufficeth not that we are brought to Rome
O
Were piety in thine
Andronicus
Wilt thou draw near the nature of the gods?
Draw near them then in being merciful:
Sweet mercy is nobility's true badge:
Thrice noble Titus
Patient yourself
These are their brethren
Alive and dead
Religiously they ask a sacrifice:
To this your son is mark'd
Away with him! and make a fire straight;
And with our swords
Exeunt LUCIUS
O cruel
Was ever Scythia half so barbarous?
Oppose not Scythia to ambitious Rome.
Alarbus goes to rest; and we survive
To tremble under Titus' threatening looks.
Then
The self-same gods that arm'd the Queen of Troy
With opportunity of sharp revenge
Upon the Thracian tyrant in his tent
When Goths were Goths and Tamora was queen--
To quit the bloody wrongs upon her foes.
Re-enter LUCIUS
See
Our Roman rites: Alarbus' limbs are lopp'd
Remaineth nought
Let it be so; and let Andronicus
Make this his latest farewell to their souls.
Trumpets sounded
In peace and honour rest you here
Rome's readiest champions
Here lurks no treason
In peace and honour rest you here
Enter LAVINIA
In peace and honour live Lord Titus long;
My noble lord and father
Lo
I render
And at thy feet I kneel
O
Kind Rome
The cordial of mine age to glad my heart!
Lavinia
Enter
Long live Lord Titus
Thanks
And welcome
Fair lords
But safer triumph is this funeral pomp
And triumphs over chance in honour's bed.
Titus Andronicus
And name thee in election for the empire
Be candidatus then
A better head her glorious body fits
Than his that shakes for age and feebleness:
What should I don this robe
Be chosen with proclamations to-day
Rome
Give me a staff of honour for mine age
Upright he held it
Titus
Proud and ambitious tribune
Patience
Romans
Patricians
Till Saturninus be Rome's emperor.
Andronicus
Proud Saturnine
That noble-minded Titus means to thee!
Content thee
The people's hearts
Andronicus
My faction if thou strengthen with thy friends
Of noble minds is honourable meed.
People of Rome
Will you bestow them friendly on Andronicus?
To gratify the good Andronicus
Tribunes
Then
With voices and applause of every sort
Lord Saturninus Rome's great emperor
A long flourish till they come down
Titus Andronicus
To us in our election this day
And
Thy name and honourable family
Tell me
It doth
I hold me highly honour'd of your grace:
And here in sight of Rome to Saturnine
My sword
Presents well worthy Rome's imperial lord:
Receive them then
Thanks
How proud I am of thee and of thy gifts
Rome shall record
The least of these unspeakable deserts
[To TAMORA]  Now
an emperor;
To him that
A goodly lady
That I would choose
Clear up
Though chance of war hath wrought this change of cheer
Princely shall be thy usage every way.
Rest on my word
Daunt all your hopes: madam
Can make you greater than the Queen of Goths.
Lavinia
Not I
Warrants these words in princely courtesy.
Thanks
Ransomless here we set our prisoners free:
Proclaim our honours
Flourish. SATURNINUS courts TAMORA in dumb show
Lord Titus
Seizing LAVINIA
How
Ay
To do myself this reason and this right.
'Suum cuique' is our Roman justice:
This prince in justice seizeth but his own.
And that he will
Traitors
Treason
Surprised! by whom?
By him that justly may
Bear his betroth'd from all the world away.
Exeunt BASSIANUS and MARCUS with LAVINIA
Brothers
Exeunt LUCIUS
Follow
My lord
What
Barr'st me my way in Rome?
Stabbing MUTIUS
Help
Dies
During the fray
Re-enter LUCIUS
My lord
Nor thou
My sons would never so dishonour me:
Traitor
Dead
Exit
No
I'll trust
Thee never
Was there none else in Rome to make a stale
O monstrous! what reproachful words are these?
But go thy ways; go
To him that flourish'd for her with his sword
A valiant son-in-law thou shalt enjoy;
One fit to bandy with thy lawless sons
These words are razors to my wounded heart.
And therefore
Dost overshine the gallant'st dames of Rome
And here I swear by all the Roman gods
And tapers burn so bright and every thing
In readiness for Hymenaeus stand
I lead espoused my bride along with me.
And here
Ascend
Your noble emperor and his lovely bride
There shall we consummate our spousal rites.
Exeunt all but TITUS
I am not bid to wait upon this bride.
Titus
Re-enter MARCUS
O Titus
In a bad quarrel slain a virtuous son.
No
That hath dishonour'd all our family;
Unworthy brother
But let us give him burial
Give Mutius burial with our brethren.
Traitors
This monument five hundred years hath stood
Here none but soldiers and Rome's servitors
Repose in fame; none basely slain in brawls:
Bury him where you can; he comes not here.
My lord
My nephew Mutius' deeds do plead for him
He must be buried with his brethren.
And shall
'And shall!' what villain was it that spake
that word?
He that would vouch it in any place but here.
What
No
To pardon Mutius and to bury him.
Marcus
My foes I do repute you every one;
So
He is not with himself; let us withdraw.
Not I
MARCUS and the Sons of TITUS kneel
Brother
Father
Speak thou no more
Renowned Titus
Dear father
Suffer thy brother Marcus to inter
His noble nephew here in virtue's nest
Thou art a Roman; be not barbarous:
The Greeks upon advice did bury Ajax
That slew himself; and wise Laertes' son
Did graciously plead for his funerals:
Let not young Mutius
Be barr'd his entrance here.
Rise
The dismall'st day is this that e'er I saw
Well
MUTIUS is put into the tomb
There lie thy bones
[Kneeling]  No man shed tears for noble Mutius;
He lives in fame that died in virtue's cause.
My lord
Is of a sudden thus advanced in Rome?
I know not
Is she not then beholding to the man
That brought her for this high good turn so far?
Yes
Flourish. Re-enter
So
God give you joy
And you of yours
Traitor
Rape
But let the laws of Rome determine all;
Meanwhile I am possess'd of that is mine.
'Tis good
But
My lord
Only thus much I give your grace to know:
By all the duties that I owe to Rome
That in the rescue of Lavinia
With his own hand did slay his youngest son
To be controll'd in that he frankly gave:
Receive him
A father and a friend to thee and Rome.
Prince Bassianus
'Tis thou and those that have dishonour'd me.
Rome and the righteous heavens be my judge
My worthy lord
Were gracious in those princely eyes of thine
And at my suit
What
Not so
I should be author to dishonour you!
But on mine honour dare I undertake
For good Lord Titus' innocence in all;
Whose fury not dissembled speaks his griefs:
Then
Lose not so noble a friend on vain suppose
Aside to SATURNINUS
be won at last;
Dissemble all your griefs and discontents:
You are but newly planted in your throne;
Lest
I'll find a day to massacre them all
And raze their faction and their family
Kneel in the streets and beg for grace in vain.
Aloud
Come
Take up this good old man
That dies in tempest of thy angry frown.
Rise
I thank your majesty
These words
Titus
This day all quarrels die
And let it be mine honour
For you
My word and promise to the emperor
And fear not lords
By my advice
We do
That
Away
Nay
The tribune and his nephews kneel for grace;
I will not be denied: sweet heart
Marcus
Lavinia
I would not part a bachelor from the priest.
Come
This day shall be a love-day
To-morrow
To hunt the panther and the hart with me
Be it so
Flourish. Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Rome. Before the Palace.
Enter AARON
Now climbeth Tamora Olympus' top
Advanced above pale envy's threatening reach.
As when the golden sun salutes the morn
So Tamora:
Upon her wit doth earthly honour wait
Then
Hast prisoner held
And faster bound to Aaron's charming eyes
Than is Prometheus tied to Caucasus.
Away with slavish weeds and servile thoughts!
I will be bright
To wait
Holloa! what storm is this?
Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON
Chiron
And may
Demetrius
And so in this
'Tis not the difference of a year or two
Makes me less gracious or thee more fortunate:
I am as able and as fit as thou
To serve
And that my sword upon thee shall approve
[Aside]  Clubs
the peace.
Why
Go to; have your lath glued within your sheath
Till you know better how to handle it.
Meanwhile
Ay
They draw
[Coming forward]  Why
So near the emperor's palace dare you draw
Full well I wot the ground of all this grudge:
I would not for a million of gold
The cause were known to them it most concerns;
Nor would your noble mother for much more
Be so dishonour'd in the court of Rome.
For shame
Not I
My rapier in his bosom and withal
Thrust these reproachful speeches down his throat
That he hath breathed in my dishonour here.
For that I am prepared and full resolved.
Foul-spoken coward
Away
Now
Why
It is to jet upon a prince's right?
What
Without controlment
Young lords
This discord's ground
I care not
I love Lavinia more than all the world.
Youngling
Lavinia is thine elder brother's hope.
Why
How furious and impatient they be
I tell you
By this device.
Aaron
Would I propose to achieve her whom I love.
To achieve her! how?
Why makest thou it so strange?
She is a woman
She is a woman
She is Lavinia
What
Than wots the miller of; and easy it is
Of a cut loaf to steal a shive
Though Bassianus be the emperor's brother.
Better than he have worn Vulcan's badge.
[Aside]  Ay
Then why should he despair that knows to court it
With words
What
Why
Would serve your turns.
Ay
Aaron
Would you had hit it too!
Then should not we be tired with this ado.
Why
To square for this? would it offend you
That both should speed?
Faith
Nor me
For shame
'Tis policy and stratagem must do
That you affect; and so must you resolve
Take this of me: Lucrece was not more chaste
Than this Lavinia
A speedier course than lingering languishment
Must we pursue
My lords
There will the lovely Roman ladies troop:
The forest walks are wide and spacious;
And many unfrequented plots there are
Fitted by kind for rape and villany:
Single you thither then this dainty doe
This way
Come
To villany and vengeance consecrate
And she shall file our engines with advice
The emperor's court is like the house of Fame
The woods are ruthless
There speak
your turns;
There serve your lusts
Thy counsel
To cool this heat
Per Styga
Exeunt
SCENE II. A forest near Rome. Horns and cry of hounds heard.
Enter TITUS ANDRONICUS
The hunt is up
Uncouple here and let us make a bay
And wake the emperor and his lovely bride
And rouse the prince and ring a hunter's peal
Sons
I have been troubled in my sleep this night
A cry of hounds and horns
Many good morrows to your majesty;
Madam
I promised your grace a hunter's peal.
And you have rung it lustily
Somewhat too early for new-married ladies.
Lavinia
I say
I have been broad awake two hours and more.
Come on
To TAMORA
Madam
Our Roman hunting.
I have dogs
And I have horse will follow where the game
Makes way
Chiron
Exeunt
SCENE III. A lonely part of the forest.
Enter AARON
He that had wit would think that I had none
Let him that thinks of me so abjectly
Know that this gold must coin a stratagem
A very excellent piece of villany:
And so repose
Hides the gold
That have their alms out of the empress' chest.
Enter TAMORA
My lovely Aaron
The birds chant melody on every bush
And make a chequer'd shadow on the ground:
Under their sweet shade
And
The wandering prince and Dido once enjoy'd
And curtain'd with a counsel-keeping cave
Whiles hounds and horns and sweet melodious birds
Be unto us as is a nurse's song
Of lullaby to bring her babe asleep.
Madam
What signifies my deadly-standing eye
Even as an adder when she doth unroll
To do some fatal execution?
No
Vengeance is in my heart
Hark Tamora
His Philomel must lose her tongue to-day
And wash their hands in Bassianus' blood.
Seest thou this letter? take it up
Now question me no more; we are espied;
Here comes a parcel of our hopeful booty
Ah
No more
Be cross with him; and I'll go fetch thy sons
To back thy quarrels
Exit
Enter BASSIANUS and LAVINIA
Who have we here? Rome's royal empress
Or is it Dian
To see the general hunting in this forest?
Saucy controller of our private steps!
Had I the power that some say Dian had
With horns
Should drive upon thy new-transformed limbs
Under your patience
And to be doubted that your Moor and you
Are singled forth to try experiments:
Jove shield your husband from his hounds to-day!
'Tis pity they should take him for a stag.
Believe me
Doth make your honour of his body's hue
Why are you sequester'd from all your train
And wander'd hither to an obscure plot
And
For sauciness. I pray you
This valley fits the purpose passing well.
The king my brother shall have note of this.
Ay
Good king
Why have I patience to endure all this?
Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON
How now
Why doth your highness look so pale and wan?
Have I not reason
These two have 'ticed me hither to this place:
A barren detested vale
The trees
Here never shines the sun; here nothing breeds
And when they show'd me this abhorred pit
As any mortal body hearing it
Should straight fall mad
No sooner had they told this hellish tale
Unto the body of a dismal yew
And then they call'd me foul adulteress
That ever ear did hear to such effect:
And
Revenge it
This is a witness that I am thy son.
Stabs BASSIANUS
And this for me
Also stabs BASSIANUS
Ay
Give me thy poniard; you shall know
Your mother's hand shall right your mother's wrong.
Stay
First thrash the corn
This minion stood upon her chastity
And shall she carry this unto her grave?
An if she do
Drag hence her husband to some secret hole
But when ye have the honey ye desire
I warrant you
Come
That nice-preserved honesty of yours.
O Tamora! thou bear'st a woman's face
I will not hear her speak; away with her!
Sweet lords
Listen
To see her tears; but be your heart to them
As unrelenting flint to drops of rain.
When did the tiger's young ones teach the dam?
O
The milk thou suck'dst from her did turn to marble;
Even at thy teat thou hadst thy tyranny.
Yet every mother breeds not sons alike:
To CHIRON
Do thou entreat her show a woman pity.
What
'Tis true; the raven doth not hatch a lark:
Yet have I heard
The lion moved with pity did endure
To have his princely paws pared all away:
Some say that ravens foster forlorn children
O
I know not what it means; away with her!
O
slain thee
Hadst thou in person ne'er offended me
Remember
But fierce Andronicus would not relent;
Therefore
O Tamora
For 'tis not life that I have begg'd so long;
Poor I was slain when Bassianus died.
What begg'st thou
'Tis present death I beg; and one thing more
That womanhood denies my tongue to tell:
O
Do this
So should I rob my sweet sons of their fee:
No
Away! for thou hast stay'd us here too long.
No grace? no womanhood? Ah
The blot and enemy to our general name!
Confusion fall--
Nay
This is the hole where Aaron bid us hide him.
DEMETRIUS throws the body of BASSIANUS into the  pit; then exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON
Farewell
Ne'er let my heart know merry cheer indeed
Now will I hence to seek my lovely Moor
Exit
Re-enter AARON
Come on
Straight will I bring you to the loathsome pit
Where I espied the panther fast asleep.
My sight is very dull
And mine
Falls into the pit
What art thou fall'n? What subtle hole is this
As fresh as morning dew distill'd on flowers?
A very fatal place it seems to me.
Speak
O brother
That ever eye with sight made heart lament!
[Aside]  Now will I fetch the king to find them here
How these were they that made away his brother.
Exit
Why dost not comfort me
From this unhallowed and blood-stained hole?
I am surprised with an uncouth fear;
A chilling sweat o'er-runs my trembling joints:
My heart suspects more than mine eye can see.
To prove thou hast a true-divining heart
Aaron is gone; and my compassionate heart
Will not permit mine eyes once to behold
The thing whereat it trembles by surmise;
O
Was I a child to fear I know not what.
Lord Bassianus lies embrewed here
If it be dark
Upon his bloody finger he doth wear
A precious ring
So pale did shine the moon on Pyramus
When he by night lay bathed in maiden blood.
O brother
If fear hath made thee faint
Out of this fell devouring receptacle
Reach me thy hand
Or
Of this deep pit
I have no strength to pluck thee to the brink.
Nor I no strength to climb without thy help.
Thy hand once more; I will not loose again
Thou canst not come to me: I come to thee.
Falls in
Enter SATURNINUS with AARON
Along with me: I'll see what hole is here
Say who art thou that lately didst descend
Into this gaping hollow of the earth?
The unhappy son of old Andronicus:
Brought hither in a most unlucky hour
My brother dead! I know thou dost but jest:
He and his lady both are at the lodge
Upon the north side of this pleasant chase;
'Tis not an hour since I left him there.
We know not where you left him all alive;
But
Re-enter TAMORA
Where is my lord the king?
Here
Where is thy brother Bassianus?
Now to the bottom dost thou search my wound:
Poor Bassianus here lies murdered.
Then all too late I bring this fatal writ
And wonder greatly that man's face can fold
In pleasing smiles such murderous tyranny.
She giveth SATURNINUS a letter
[Reads]  'An if we miss to meet him handsomely--
Sweet huntsman
Do thou so much as dig the grave for him:
Thou know'st our meaning. Look for thy reward
Among the nettles at the elder-tree
Which overshades the mouth of that same pit
Where we decreed to bury Bassianus.
Do this
O Tamora! was ever heard the like?
This is the pit
Look
That should have murdered Bassianus here.
My gracious lord
[To TITUS]  Two of thy whelps
bloody kind
Sirs
There let them bide until we have devised
Some never-heard-of torturing pain for them.
What
How easily murder is discovered!
High emperor
I beg this boon
If it be proved! you see it is apparent.
Who found this letter? Tamora
Andronicus himself did take it up.
I did
For
They shall be ready at your highness' will
To answer their suspicion with their lives.
Thou shalt not bail them: see thou follow me.
Some bring the murder'd body
Let them not speak a word; the guilt is plain;
For
Andronicus
Fear not thy sons; they shall do well enough.
Come
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON with LAVINIA
So
Write down thy mind
See
Go home
She hath no tongue to call
And so let's leave her to her silent walks.
An 'twere my case
If thou hadst hands to help thee knit the cord.
Exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON
Enter MARCUS
Who is this? my niece
Cousin
If I do dream
If I do wake
Speak
Have lopp'd and hew'd and made thy body bare
Of her two branches
As have thy love? Why dost not speak to me?
Alas
But
Ah
And
Blushing to be encountered with a cloud.
Shall I speak for thee? shall I say 'tis so?
O
Sorrow concealed
Fair Philomela
But
A craftier Tereus
O
Tremble
Or
Which that sweet tongue hath made
As Cerberus at the Thracian poet's feet.
Come
For such a sight will blind a father's eye:
One hour's storm will drown the fragrant meads;
What will whole months of tears thy father's eyes?
Do not draw back
O
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. Rome. A street.
Enter Judges
Hear me
For pity of mine age
In dangerous wars
For all my blood in Rome's great quarrel shed;
For all the frosty nights that I have watch'd;
And for these bitter tears
Filling the aged wrinkles in my cheeks;
Be pitiful to my condemned sons
For two and twenty sons I never wept
Lieth down; the Judges
For these
My heart's deep languor and my soul's sad tears:
Let my tears stanch the earth's dry appetite;
My sons' sweet blood will make it shame and blush.
O earth
In summer's drought I'll drop upon thee still;
In winter with warm tears I'll melt the snow
And keep eternal spring-time on thy face
Enter LUCIUS
O reverend tribunes! O gentle
Unbind my sons
And let me say
O noble father
The tribunes hear you not; no man is by;
And you recount your sorrows to a stone.
Ah
Grave tribunes
My gracious lord
Why
Therefore I tell my sorrows to the stones;
Who
When I do weep
Receive my tears and seem to weep with me;
And
A stone is soft as wax
A stone is silent
Rises
But wherefore stand'st thou with thy weapon drawn?
To rescue my two brothers from their death:
For which attempt the judges have pronounced
My everlasting doom of banishment.
O happy man! they have befriended thee.
Why
That Rome is but a wilderness of tigers?
Tigers must prey
But me and mine: how happy art thou
But who comes with our brother Marcus here?
Enter MARCUS and LAVINIA
Titus
Or
I bring consuming sorrow to thine age.
Will it consume me? let me see it
This was thy daughter.
Why
Ay me
Faint-hearted boy
Speak
Hath made thee handless in thy father's sight?
What fool hath added water to the sea
My grief was at the height before thou camest
Give me a sword
For they have fought for Rome
And they have nursed this woe
In bootless prayer have they been held up
Now all the service I require of them
Is that the one will help to cut the other.
'Tis well
For hands
Speak
O
That blabb'd them with such pleasing eloquence
Sweet varied notes
O
O
That hath received some unrecuring wound.
It was my deer; and he that wounded her
Hath hurt me more than had he killed me dead:
For now I stand as one upon a rock
Environed with a wilderness of sea
Will in his brinish bowels swallow him.
This way to death my wretched sons are gone;
Here stands my other son
But that which gives my soul the greatest spurn
Had I but seen thy picture in this plight
Now I behold thy lively body so?
Thou hast no hands
Nor tongue
Thy husband he is dead: and for his death
Thy brothers are condemn'd
Look
When I did name her brothers
Stood on her cheeks
Upon a gather'd lily almost wither'd.
Perchance she weeps because they kill'd her husband;
Perchance because she knows them innocent.
If they did kill thy husband
Because the law hath ta'en revenge on them.
No
Witness the sorrow that their sister makes.
Gentle Lavinia
Or make some sign how I may do thee ease:
Shall thy good uncle
How they are stain'd
And in the fountain shall we gaze so long
Till the fresh taste be taken from that clearness
Or shall we cut away our hands
Or shall we bite our tongues
Pass the remainder of our hateful days?
What shall we do? let us
Sweet father
Patience
Ah
Thy napkin cannot drink a tear of mine
Ah
Mark
Had she a tongue to speak
That to her brother which I said to thee:
His napkin
O
Enter AARON
Titus Andronicus
Sends thee this word
Will send thee hither both thy sons alive;
And that shall be the ransom for their fault.
O gracious emperor! O gentle Aaron!
Did ever raven sing so like a lark
With all my heart
Good Aaron
Stay
My youth can better spare my blood than you;
And therefore mine shall save my brothers' lives.
Which of your hands hath not defended Rome
O
My hand hath been but idle; let it serve
To ransom my two nephews from their death;
Then have I kept it to a worthy end.
Nay
My hand shall go.
By heaven
Sirs
Are meet for plucking up
Sweet father
And
Agree between you; I will spare my hand.
Then I'll go fetch an axe.
But I will use the axe.
Exeunt LUCIUS and MARCUS
Come hither
Lend me thy hand
[Aside]  If that be call'd deceit
But I'll deceive you in another sort
Cuts off TITUS's hand
Re-enter LUCIUS and MARCUS
Now stay your strife: what shall be is dispatch'd.
Good Aaron
Tell him it was a hand that warded him
From thousand dangers; bid him bury it
More hath it merited; that let it have.
As for my sons
As jewels purchased at an easy price;
And yet dear too
I go
Look by and by to have thy sons with thee.
Aside
Their heads
Doth fat me with the very thoughts of it!
Let fools do good
Aaron will have his soul black like his face.
Exit
O
If any power pities wretched tears
To LAVINIA
What
Do
Or with our sighs we'll breathe the welkin dim
When they do hug him in their melting bosoms.
O brother
Is not my sorrow deep
Then be my passions bottomless with them.
But yet let reason govern thy lament.
If there were reason for these miseries
When heaven doth weep
If the winds rage
And wilt thou have a reason for this coil?
I am the sea; hark
She is the weeping welkin
Then must my sea be moved with her sighs;
Then must my earth with her continual tears
Become a deluge
For why my bowels cannot hide her woes
Then give me leave
To ease their stomachs with their bitter tongues.
Enter a Messenger
Worthy Andronicus
For that good hand thou sent'st the emperor.
Here are the heads of thy two noble sons;
And here's thy hand
Thy griefs their sports
That woe is me to think upon thy woes
More than remembrance of my father's death.
Exit
Now let hot AEtna cool in Sicily
These miseries are more than may be borne.
To weep with them that weep doth ease some deal;
But sorrow flouted at is double death.
Ah
That ever death should let life bear his name
LAVINIA kisses TITUS
Alas
As frozen water to a starved snake.
When will this fearful slumber have an end?
Now
Thou dost not slumber: see
Thy other banish'd son
Struck pale and bloodless; and thy brother
Ah
Rend off thy silver hair
Gnawing with thy teeth; and be this dismal sight
The closing up of our most wretched eyes;
Now is a time to storm; why art thou still?
Ha
Why dost thou laugh? it fits not with this hour.
Why
Besides
And make them blind with tributary tears:
Then which way shall I find Revenge's cave?
For these two heads do seem to speak to me
Till all these mischiefs be return'd again
Even in their throats that have committed them.
Come
You heavy people
The vow is made. Come
And in this hand the other I will bear.
Lavinia
Bear thou my hand
As for thee
Thou art an exile
Hie to the Goths
And
Exeunt TITUS
Farewell Andronicus
Farewell
Farewell
O
But now nor Lucius nor Lavinia lives
But in oblivion and hateful griefs.
If Lucius live
And make proud Saturnine and his empress
Beg at the gates
Now will I to the Goths
Exit
SCENE II. A room in Titus's house. A banquet set out.
Enter TITUS
So
Than will preserve just so much strength in us
As will revenge these bitter woes of ours.
Marcus
Thy niece and I
With folded arms. This poor right hand of mine
Is left to tyrannize upon my breast;
Who
To LAVINIA
Thou map of woe
When thy poor heart beats with outrageous beating
Wound it with sighing
Or get some little knife between thy teeth
That all the tears that thy poor eyes let fall
May run into that sink
Drown the lamenting fool in sea-salt tears.
Fie
Such violent hands upon her tender life.
How now! has sorrow made thee dote already?
Why
What violent hands can she lay on her life?
Ah
To bid AEneas tell the tale twice o'er
O
Fie
Come
Here is no drink! Hark
I can interpret all her martyr'd signs;
She says she drinks no other drink but tears
Speechless complainer
In thy dumb action will I be as perfect
As begging hermits in their holy prayers:
Thou shalt not sigh
And by still practise learn to know thy meaning.
Good grandsire
Make my aunt merry with some pleasing tale.
Alas
Peace
MARCUS strikes the dish with a knife
What dost thou strike at
At that that I have kill'd
Out on thee
Mine eyes are cloy'd with view of tyranny:
A deed of death done on the innocent
Becomes not Titus' brother: get thee gone:
I see thou art not for my company.
Alas
But how
How would he hang his slender gilded wings
Poor harmless fly
kill'd him.
Pardon me
O
Give me thy knife
Flattering myself
Come hither purposely to poison me.--
There's for thyself
Ah
Yet
That comes in likeness of a coal-black Moor.
Alas
Come
I'll to thy closet; and go read with thee
Sad stories chanced in the times of old.
Come
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. Rome. Titus's garden.
Enter young LUCIUS
Help
Follows me every where
Good uncle Marcus
Alas
Stand by me
She loves thee
Ay
What means my niece Lavinia by these signs?
Fear her not
See
Somewhither would she have thee go with her.
Ah
Read to her sons than she hath read to thee
Sweet poetry and Tully's Orator.
Canst thou not guess wherefore she plies thee thus?
My lord
For I have heard my grandsire say full oft
And I have read that Hecuba of Troy
Ran mad through sorrow: that made me to fear;
Although
Loves me as dear as e'er my mother did
Which made me down to throw my books
Causeless
And
Lucius
LAVINIA turns over with her stumps the books which LUCIUS has let fall
How now
Some book there is that she desires to see.
Which is it
But thou art deeper read
Come
Reveal the damn'd contriver of this deed.
Why lifts she up her arms in sequence thus?
I think she means that there was more than one
Confederate in the fact: ay
Or else to heaven she heaves them for revenge.
Lucius
Grandsire
My mother gave it me.
For love of her that's gone
Soft! see how busily she turns the leaves!
Helping her
What would she find? Lavinia
This is the tragic tale of Philomel
And rape
See
Lavinia
Ay
O
Pattern'd by that the poet here describes
O
Give signs
but friends
Or slunk not Saturnine
Sit down
Apollo
My lord
This sandy plot is plain; guide
This after me
Without the help of any hand at all.
He writes his name with his staff
Cursed be that heart that forced us to this shift!
Write thou good niece; and here display
Heaven guide thy pen to print thy sorrows plain
She takes the staff in her mouth
O
'Stuprum. Chiron. Demetrius.'
What
Performers of this heinous
Magni Dominator poli
O
There is enough written upon this earth
To stir a mutiny in the mildest thoughts
And arm the minds of infants to exclaims.
My lord
And kneel
And swear with me
And father of that chaste dishonour'd dame
Mortal revenge upon these traitorous Goths
'Tis sure enough
But if you hunt these bear-whelps
The dam will wake; and
You are a young huntsman
And
Will blow these sands
I say
For these bad bondmen to the yoke of Rome.
Ay
For his ungrateful country done the like.
And
Come
Lucius
Presents that I intend to send them both:
Come
Ay
No
Lavinia
Lucius and I'll go brave it at the court:
Ay
Exeunt TITUS
O heavens
Marcus
Than foemen's marks upon his batter'd shield;
But yet so just that he will not revenge.
Revenge
Exit
SCENE II. The same. A room in the palace.
Enter
Demetrius
He hath some message to deliver us.
Ay
My lords
Aside
And pray the Roman gods confound you both!
Gramercy
[Aside]  That you are both decipher'd
The goodliest weapons of his armoury
To gratify your honourable youth
And so I do
Your lordships
And so I leave you both:
Aside
like bloody villains.
Exeunt Young LUCIUS
What's here? A scroll; and written round about?
Let's see;
Reads
'Integer vitae
O
I read it in the grammar long ago.
Ay
Aside
Now
Here's no sound jest! the old man hath found their guilt;
And sends them weapons wrapped about with lines
But were our witty empress well afoot
But let her rest in her unrest awhile.
And now
Led us to Rome
It did me good
To brave the tribune in his brother's hearing.
But me more good
Basely insinuate and send us gifts.
Had he not reason
Did you not use his daughter very friendly?
I would we had a thousand Roman dames
At such a bay
A charitable wish and full of love.
Here lacks but your mother for to say amen.
And that would she for twenty thousand more.
Come
For our beloved mother in her pains.
[Aside]  Pray to the devils; the gods have given us over.
Trumpets sound within
Why do the emperor's trumpets flourish thus?
Belike
Soft! who comes here?
Enter a Nurse
Good morr ow
O
Well
O gentle Aaron
Now help
Why
What dost thou wrap and fumble in thine arms?
O
She is deliver'd
To whom?
I mean
Well
A devil.
Why
A joyless
Here is the babe
Amongst the fairest breeders of our clime:
The empress sends it thee
'Zounds
Sweet blowse
Villain
That which thou canst not undo.
Thou hast undone our mother.
Villain
And therein
Woe to her chance
Accursed the offspring of so foul a fiend!
It shall not live.
It shall not die.
Aaron
What
Do execution on my flesh and blood.
I'll broach the tadpole on my rapier's point:
Nurse
Sooner this sword shall plough thy bowels up.
Takes the Child from the Nurse
Stay
Now
That touches this my first-born son and heir!
I tell you
What
Ye white-limed walls! ye alehouse painted signs!
Coal-black is better than another hue
For all the water in the ocean
Can never turn the swan's black legs to white
Tell the empress from me
To keep mine own
Wilt thou betray thy noble mistress thus?
My mistress is my mistress; this myself
This before all the world do I prefer;
This maugre all the world will I keep safe
By this our mother is forever shamed.
Rome will despise her for this foul escape.
The emperor
I blush to think upon this ignomy.
Why
Fie
The close enacts and counsels of the heart!
Here's a young lad framed of another leer:
Look
He is your brother
Of that self-blood that first gave life to you
He is enfranchised and come to light:
Nay
Aaron
Advise thee
Save thou the child
Then sit we down
My son and I will have the wind of you:
Keep there: now talk at pleasure of your safety.
They sit
How many women saw this child of his?
Why
But say
Cornelia the midwife and myself;
And no one else but the deliver'd empress.
The empress
Two may keep counsel when the third's away:
Go to the empress
He kills the nurse
Weke
What mean'st thou
O Lord
Shall she live to betray this guilt of ours
And now be it known to you my full intent.
Not far
His wife but yesternight was brought to bed;
His child is like to her
Go pack with him
And how by this their child shall be advanced
And let the emperor dandle him for his own.
Hark ye
And you must needs bestow her funeral;
The fields are near
This done
The midwife and the nurse well made away
Aaron
With secrets.
For this care of Tamora
Exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON bearing off the Nurse's body
Now to the Goths
There to dispose this treasure in mine arms
Come on
For it is you that puts us to our shifts:
I'll make you feed on berries and on roots
To be a warrior
Exit
SCENE III. The same. A public place.
Enter TITUS
Come
Sir boy
Look ye draw home enough
Terras Astraea reliquit:
Be you remember'd
Sirs
Go sound the ocean
Happily you may catch her in the sea;
Yet there's as little justice as at land:
No; Publius and Sempronius
'Tis you must dig with mattock and with spade
Then
Tell him
Ah
What time I threw the people's suffrages
On him that thus doth tyrannize o'er me.
Go
This wicked emperor may have shipp'd her hence;
And
O Publius
Therefore
By day and night to attend him carefully
Kinsmen
Join with the Goths; and with revengeful war
Take wreak on Rome for this ingratitude
Publius
What
No
Marry
He doth me wrong to feed me with delays.
I'll dive into the burning lake below
Marcus
No big-boned men framed of the Cyclops' size;
But metal
And
To send down Justice for to wreak our wrongs.
Come
He gives them the arrows
'Ad Jovem
'Ad Martem
Here
To Saturn
You were as good to shoot against the wind.
To it
Of my word
There's not a god left unsolicited.
Kinsmen
We will afflict the emperor in his pride.
Now
They shoot
O
Good boy
My lord
Your letter is with Jupiter by this.
Ha
Publius
See
This was the sport
That down fell both the Ram's horns in the court;
And who should find them but the empress' villain?
She laugh'd
But give them to his master for a present.
Why
Enter a Clown
News
Sirrah
Shall I have justice? what says Jupiter?
O
them down again
the next week.
But what says Jupiter
Alas
in all my life.
Why
Ay
Why
From heaven! alas
forbid I should be so bold to press to heaven in my
young days. Why
tribunal plebs
betwixt my uncle and one of the emperial's men.
Why
your oration; and let him deliver the pigeons to
the emperor from you.
Tell me
with a grace?
Nay
Sirrah
By me thou shalt have justice at his hands.
Hold
Give me pen and ink. Sirrah
deliver a supplication?
Ay
Then here is a supplication for you. And when you
come to him
then look for your reward. I'll be at hand
you do it bravely.
I warrant you
Sirrah
Here
For thou hast made it like an humble suppliant.
And when thou hast given it the emperor
God be with you
Come
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The same. Before the palace.
Enter SATURNINUS
Why
An emperor in Rome thus overborne
Of egal justice
My lords
Buz in the people's ears
Of old Andronicus. And what an if
His sorrows have so overwhelm'd his wits
And now he writes to heaven for his redress:
See
This to Apollo; this to the god of war;
Sweet scrolls to fly about the streets of Rome!
What's this but libelling against the senate
A goodly humour
As who would say
But if I live
Shall be no shelter to these outrages:
But he and his shall know that justice lives
In Saturninus' health
Cut off the proud'st conspirator that lives.
My gracious lord
And rather comfort his distressed plight
Than prosecute the meanest or the best
For these contempts.
Aside
Why
High-witted Tamora to gloze with all:
But
Enter Clown
How now
Yea
Empress I am
'Tis he. God and Saint Stephen give you good den:
I have brought you a letter and a couple of pigeons here.
SATURNINUS reads the letter
Go
How much money must I have?
Come
Hanged! by'r lady
a fair end.
Exit
Despiteful and intolerable wrongs!
Shall I endure this monstrous villany?
I know from whence this same device proceeds:
May this be borne?--as if his traitorous sons
Go
Nor age nor honour shall shape privilege:
For this proud mock I'll be thy slaughterman;
Sly frantic wretch
Enter AEMILIUS
What news with thee
Arm
The Goths have gather'd head; and with a power
high-resolved men
Of Lucius
Who threats
As much as ever Coriolanus did.
Is warlike Lucius general of the Goths?
These tidings nip me
As flowers with frost or grass beat down with storms:
Ay
'Tis he the common people love so much;
Myself hath often over-heard them say
Why should you fear? is not your city strong?
Ay
King
Is the sun dimm'd
The eagle suffers little birds to sing
He can at pleasure stint their melody:
Even so mayst thou the giddy men of Rome.
Then cheer thy spirit : for know
With words more sweet
But he will not entreat his son for us.
If Tamora entreat him
For I can smooth and fill his aged ear
With golden promises; that
Almost impregnable
To AEmilius
Go thou before
Say that the emperor requests a parley
Of warlike Lucius
Even at his father's house
AEmilius
And if he stand on hostage for his safety
Your bidding shall I do effectually.
Exit
Now will I to that old Andronicus;
And temper him with all the art I have
And now
Then go successantly
Exeunt
ACT V
SCENE I. Plains near Rome.
Enter LUCIUS with an army of Goths
Approved warriors
And how desirous of our sight they are.
Therefore
Brave slip
Whose high exploits and honourable deeds
Ingrateful Rome requites with foul contempt
Led by their master to the flowered fields
And as he saith
I humbly thank him
But who comes here
Enter a Goth
Renowned Lucius
To gaze upon a ruinous monastery;
And
Upon the wasted building
I heard a child cry underneath a wall.
I made unto the noise; when soon I heard
The crying babe controll'd with this discourse:
'Peace
Did not thy hue bewray whose brat thou art
But where the bull and cow are both milk-white
Peace
the babe
'For I must bear thee to a trusty Goth;
Who
With this
O worthy Goth
That robb'd Andronicus of his good hand;
This is the pearl that pleased your empress' eye
Say
This growing image of thy fiend-like face?
Why dost not speak? what
A halter
And by his side his fruit of bastardy.
Touch not the boy; he is of royal blood.
Too like the sire for ever being good.
First hang the child
A sight to vex the father's soul withal.
Get me a ladder.
A ladder brought
Lucius
If thou do this
If thou wilt not
Say on: an if it please me which thou speak'st
Thy child shall live
An if it please thee! why
For I must talk of murders
Ruthful to hear
And this shall all be buried by my death
Tell on thy mind; I say thy child shall live.
Swear that he shall
Who should I swear by? thou believest no god:
That granted
What if I do not? as
Yet
And hast a thing within thee called conscience
An idiot holds his bauble for a god
And keeps the oath which by that god he swears
By that same god
Or else I will discover nought to thee.
Even by my god I swear to thee I will.
First know thou
O most insatiate and luxurious woman!
Tut
To that which thou shalt hear of me anon.
'Twas her two sons that murder'd Bassianus;
They cut thy sister's tongue and ravish'd her
And cut her hands and trimm'd her as thou saw'st.
O detestable villain! call'st thou that trimming?
Why
Trim sport for them that had the doing of it.
O barbarous
Indeed
That codding spirit had they from their mother
That bloody mind
Well
I train'd thy brethren to that guileful hole
Where the dead corpse of Bassianus lay:
I wrote the letter that thy father found
And hid the gold within the letter mention'd
And what not done
I play'd the cheater for thy father's hand
And almost broke my heart with extreme laughter:
I pry'd me through the crevice of a wall
When
Beheld his tears
And when I told the empress of this sport
What
Ay
Art thou not sorry for these heinous deeds?
Ay
Even now I curse the day--and yet
Wherein I did not some notorious ill
Set fire on barns and hay-stacks in the night
Oft have I digg'd up dead men from their graves
And on their skins
Tut
As willingly as one would kill a fly
But that I cannot do ten thousand more.
Bring down the devil; for he must not die
So sweet a death as hanging presently.
If there be devils
Sirs
Enter a Goth
My lord
Desires to be admitted to your presence.
Let him come near.
Enter AEMILIUS
Welcome
Lord Lucius
And
What says our general?
AEmilius
Unto my father and my uncle Marcus
Exeunt
SCENE II. Rome. Before TITUS's house.
Enter TAMORA
Thus
To join with him and right his heinous wrongs.
Knock at his study
Tell him Revenge is come to join with him
They knock
Enter TITUS
Who doth molest my contemplation?
Is it your trick to make me ope the door
You are deceived: for what I mean to do
See here in bloody lines I have set down;
And what is written shall be executed.
Titus
No
Thou hast the odds of me; therefore no more.
If thou didst know me
I am not mad; I know thee well enough:
Witness this wretched stump
Witness these trenches made by grief and care
Witness all sorrow
For our proud empress
Is not thy coming for my other hand?
Know
She is thy enemy
I am Revenge: sent from the infernal kingdom
Come down
Confer with me of murder and of death:
There's not a hollow cave or lurking-place
Can couch for fear
And in their ears tell them my dreadful name
Art thou Revenge? and art thou sent to me
I am; therefore come down
Do me some service
Lo
Now give me some surance that thou art Revenge
And then I'll come and be thy waggoner
Provide thee two proper palfreys
And when thy car is loaden with their heads
Trot
Until his very downfall in the sea:
And day by day I'll do this heavy task
These are my ministers
Are these thy ministers? what are they call'd?
Rapine and Murder; therefore called so
Good Lord
And you
Have miserable
O sweet Revenge
And
Exit above
This closing with him fits his lunacy
Whate'er I forge to feed his brain-sick fits
And
And
See
Enter TITUS below
Long have I been forlorn
Welcome
Rapine and Murder
How like the empress and her sons you are!
Well are you fitted
Could not all hell afford you such a devil?
For well I wot the empress never wags
But in her company there is a Moor;
And
But welcome
What wouldst thou have us do
Show me a murderer
Show me a villain that hath done a rape
Show me a thousand that have done thee wrong
Look round about the wicked streets of Rome;
And when thou find'st a man that's like thyself.
Good Murder
Go thou with him; and when it is thy hap
To find another that is like to thee
Go thou with them; and in the emperor's court
There is a queen
Well mayst thou know her by thy own proportion
I pray thee
They have been violent to me and mine.
Well hast thou lesson'd us; this shall we do.
But would it please thee
When he is here
And at thy mercy shalt they stoop and kneel
What says Andronicus to this device?
Marcus

Go

Bid him repair to me
Some of the chiefest princes of the Goths;

Tell him the emperor and the empress too
Feast at my house
This do thou for my love; and so let him
This will I do

Now will I hence about thy business
Nay

Sirs

You kill'd her husband
Two of her brothers were condemn'd to death
Both her sweet hands
Than hands or tongue
What would you say
Villains
Hark
This one hand yet is left to cut your throats
The basin that receives your guilty blood.
You know your mother means to feast with me
Hark
And with your blood and it I'll make a paste
And make two pasties of your shameful heads
This is the feast that I have bid her to
For worse than Philomel you used my daughter
And now prepare your throats. Lavinia
Receive the blood: and when that they are dead
And with this hateful liquor temper it;
And in that paste let their vile heads be baked.
Come
To make this banquet; which I wish may prove
More stern and bloody than the Centaurs' feast.
So
Exeunt
SCENE III. Court of TITUS's house. A banquet set out.
Enter LUCIUS
Uncle Marcus
That I repair to Rome
And ours with thine
Good uncle
Let him receive no sustenance
Till he be brought unto the empress' face
And see the ambush of our friends be strong;
I fear the emperor means no good to us.
Some devil whisper curses in mine ear
The venomous malice of my swelling heart!
Away
Sirs
Exeunt Goths
The trumpets show the emperor is at hand.

What
What boots it thee to call thyself a sun?
Rome's emperor
These quarrels must be quietly debated.
The feast is ready
Hath ordain'd to an honourable end
Please you
Marcus
Hautboys sound. The Company sit down at table

Welcome
Welcome
And welcome

Because I would be sure to have all well

Your reason

There's meed for meed
Kills SATURNINUS. A great tumult. LUCIUS
You sad-faced men
Scatter'd by winds and high tempestuous gusts
This scatter'd corn  into one mutual sheaf
Lest Rome herself be bane unto herself
But if my frosty signs and chaps of age
Speak
To love-sick Dido's sad attending ear
The story of that baleful burning night
When subtle Greeks surprised King Priam's Troy
That gives our Troy
My heart is not compact of flint nor steel;
Nor can I utter all our bitter grief
When it should move you to attend me most
Here is a captain
Your hearts will throb and weep to hear him speak.
Then
Were they that murdered our emperor's brother;
And they it were that ravished our sister:
For their fell faults our brothers were beheaded;
Our father's tears despised
Of that true hand that fought Rome's quarrel out
Lastly
Who drown'd their enmity in my true tears.
And oped their arms to embrace me as a friend.
I am the turned forth
And from her bosom took the enemy's point
Alas
My scars can witness
But
For when no friends are by

Pointing to the Child in the arms of an Attendant

The issue of an irreligious Moor
The villain is alive in Titus' house

These wrongs

Will

Lucius

But

O
These sorrowful drops upon thy blood-stain'd face
Tear for tear
O were the sum of these that I should pay
Countless and infinite
Come hither
To melt in showers: thy grandsire loved thee well:
Many a time he danced thee on his knee
Many a matter hath he told to thee
In that respect
Friends should associate friends in grief and woe:
Bid him farewell; commit him to the grave;
Do him that kindness
O grandsire
Would I were dead
O Lord
My tears will choke me
Re-enter Attendants with AARON
You sad Andronici
Give sentence on this execrable wretch
Set him breast-deep in earth
There let him stand
If any one relieves or pities him
Some stay to see him fasten'd in the earth.
O
I am no baby
I should repent the evils I have done:
Ten thousand worse than ever yet I did
Would I perform
If one good deed in all my life I did
Some loving friends convey the emperor hence
My father and Lavinia shall forthwith
Be closed in our household's monument.
As for that heinous tiger
But throw her forth to beasts and birds of prey:
Her life was beast-like
And
See justice done on Aaron
Then
Exeunt
ACT I
PROLOGUE
In Troy
The princes orgulous
Of cruel war: sixty and nine
Their crownets regal
Put forth toward Phrygia; and their vow is made
To ransack Troy
The ravish'd Helen
To Tenedos they come;
And the deep-drawing barks do there disgorge
Their warlike fraughtage: now on Dardan plains
The fresh and yet unbruised Greeks do pitch
Their brave pavilions: Priam's six-gated city
And corresponsive and fulfilling bolts
Now expectation
A prologue arm'd
Of author's pen or actor's voice
In like conditions as our argument
Leaps o'er the vaunt and firstlings of those broils
To what may be digested in a play.
Like or find fault; do as your pleasures are:
Now good or bad
SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
Enter TROILUS armed
Call here my varlet; I'll unarm again:
Why should I war without the walls of Troy
Each Trojan that is master of his heart
Will this gear ne'er be mended?
The Greeks are strong and skilful to their strength
But I am weaker than a woman's tear
And skilless as unpractised infancy.
Well
have a cake out of the wheat must needs tarry the grinding.
Have I not tarried?
Ay
the bolting.
Have I not tarried?
Ay
Still have I tarried.
Ay
'hereafter' the kneading
heating of the oven and the baking; nay
stay the cooling too

her look

well

Pour'st in the open ulcer of my heart
Her eyes

Hard as the palm of ploughman: this thou tell'st me

between

Because she's kin to me

Say I she is not fair?

But Pandarus

As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit.
Tell me
Her bed is India; there she lies
Between our Ilium and where she resides
Our doubtful hope

That Paris is returned home and hurt.

Better at home

Come
