Exit PANDARUS
Words
But more in Troilus thousand fold I see
Than in the glass of Pandar's praise may be;
Yet hold I off. Women are angels
Things won are done; joy's soul lies in the doing.
That she beloved knows nought that knows not this:
Men prize the thing ungain'd more than it is:
That she was never yet that ever knew
Love got so sweet as when desire did sue.
Therefore this maxim out of love I teach:
Achievement is command; ungain'd
Then though my heart's content firm love doth bear
Exeunt
SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON
Princes
The ample proposition that hope makes
In all designs begun on earth below
Fails in the promised largeness: cheques and disasters
Grow in the veins of actions highest rear'd
Tortive and errant from his course of growth.
Nor
That we come short of our suppose so far
That after seven years' siege yet Troy walls stand;
Sith every action that hath gone before
Bias and thwart
That gave't surmised shape. Why then
But the protractive trials of great Jove
To find persistive constancy in men:
The fineness of which metal is not found
In fortune's love; for then the bold and coward
But
And what hath mass or matter
Lies rich in virtue and unmingled.
With due observance of thy godlike seat
Thy latest words. In the reproof of chance
Lies the true proof of men: the sea being smooth
Upon her patient breast
With those of nobler bulk!
But let the ruffian Boreas once enrage
The gentle Thetis
The strong-ribb'd bark through liquid mountains cut
Whose weak untimber'd sides but even now
Co-rivall'd greatness? Either to harbour fled
Doth valour's show and valour's worth divide
In storms of fortune; for in her ray and brightness
The herd hath more annoyance by the breeze
Than by the tiger; but when the splitting wind
Makes flexible the knees of knotted oaks
As roused with rage with rage doth sympathize
Retorts to chiding fortune.
Agamemnon
In whom the tempers and the minds of all
Should be shut up
Besides the applause and approbation To which
most mighty for thy place and sway
And thou most reverend for thy stretch'd-out life
I give to both your speeches
As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece
Should hold up high in brass
As venerable Nestor
On which heaven rides
To his experienced tongue
Speak
That matter needless
Troy
The specialty of rule hath been neglected:
And
Hollow upon this plain
When that the general is not like the hive
To whom the foragers shall all repair
The heavens themselves
Observe degree
And therefore is the glorious planet Sol
In noble eminence enthroned and sphered
Amidst the other; whose medicinable eye
Corrects the ill aspects of planets evil
In evil mixture to disorder wander
What raging of the sea! shaking of earth!
Commotion in the winds! frights
The unity and married calm of states
Quite from their fixure! O
Take but degree away
In mere oppugnancy: the bounded waters
Should lift their bosoms higher than the shores
And make a sop of all this solid globe:
Strength should be lord of imbecility
Force should be right; or rather
Then every thing includes itself in power
And appetite
And this neglection of degree it is
That by a pace goes backward
It hath to climb. The general's disdain'd
By him one step below
Of his superior
Of pale and bloodless emulation:
And 'tis this fever that keeps Troy on foot
Most wisely hath Ulysses here discover'd
The fever whereof all our power is sick.
The nature of the sickness found
The great Achilles
The sinew and the forehand of our host
Lies mocking our designs: with him Patroclus
Upon a lazy bed the livelong day
Breaks scurril jests;
And with ridiculous and awkward action
Lies in his hamstring
To hear the wooden dialogue and sound
'Twixt his stretch'd footing and the scaffoldage
Such to-be-pitied and o'er-wrested seeming
He acts thy greatness in: and when he speaks
Would seem hyperboles. At this fusty stuff
The large Achilles
Cries 'Excellent! 'tis Agamemnon just.
Now play me Nestor; hem
That's done
Of parallels
Yet god Achilles still cries 'Excellent!
'Tis Nestor right. Now play him me
And then
Must be the scene of mirth; to cough and spit
Sir Valour dies; cries 'O
Or give me ribs of steel! I shall split all
In pleasure of my spleen.' And in this fashion
As stuff for these two to make paradoxes.
And in the imitation of these twain--
Who
With an imperial voice--many are infect.
Ajax is grown self-will'd
In such a rein
As broad Achilles; keeps his tent like him;
Makes factious feasts; rails on our state of war
They tax our policy
But that of hand: the still and mental parts
Of their observant toil the enemies' weight
Why
They call this bed-work
So that the ram that batters down the wall
By reason guide his execution.
Let this be granted
Makes many Thetis' sons.
A tucket
What trumpet? look
From Troy.
Enter AENEAS
What would you 'fore our tent?
Is this great Agamemnon's tent
Even this.
May one
With surety stronger than Achilles' arm
'Fore all the Greekish heads
Call Agamemnon head and general.
Fair leave and large security. How may
A stranger to those most imperial looks
Know them from eyes of other mortals?
How!
Ay;
I ask
Modest as morning when she coldly eyes
The youthful Phoebus:
Which is that god in office
Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon?
This Trojan scorns us; or the men of Troy
Are ceremonious courtiers.
Courtiers as free
But when they would seem soldiers
The worthiness of praise distains his worth
But what the repining enemy commends
Sir
Ay
What's your affair I pray you?
Sir
He hears naught privately that comes from Troy.
Nor I from Troy come not to whisper him:
I bring a trumpet to awake his ear
Speak frankly as the wind;
It is not Agamemnon's sleeping hour:
That thou shalt know. Trojan
Trumpet
And every Greek of mettle
Trumpet sounds
We have
A prince call'd Hector
Who in this dull and long-continued truce
Is rusty grown: he bade me take a trumpet
If there be one among the fair'st of Greece
That holds his honour higher than his ease
In other arms than hers
Hector
Midway between your tents and walls of Troy
If any come
If none
The splinter of a lance. Even so much.
This shall be told our lovers
If none of them have soul in such a kind
And may that soldier a mere recreant prove
If then one is
Tell him of Nestor
When Hector's grandsire suck'd: he is old now;
But if there be not in our Grecian host
One noble man that hath one spark of fire
I'll hide my silver beard in a gold beaver
And in my vantbrace put this wither'd brawn
Was fairer than his grandam and as chaste
As may be in the world: his youth in flood
Now heavens forbid such scarcity of youth!
Amen.
Fair Lord AEneas
To our pavilion shall I lead you
Achilles shall have word of this intent;
So shall each lord of Greece
Yourself shall feast with us before you go
And find the welcome of a noble foe.
Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
Nestor!
What says Ulysses?
I have a young conception in my brain;
Be you my time to bring it to some shape.
What is't?
This 'tis:
Blunt wedges rive hard knots: the seeded pride
That hath to this maturity blown up
In rank Achilles must or now be cropp'd
Well
This challenge that the gallant Hector sends
The purpose is perspicuous even as substance
And
As banks of Libya
Pointing on him.
And wake him to the answer
Yes
For here the Trojans taste our dear'st repute
With their finest palate: and trust to me
In this wild action; for the success
Of good or bad unto the general;
And in such indexes
To their subsequent volumes
The baby figure of the giant mass
Of things to come at large. It is supposed
He that meets Hector issues from our choice
And choice
Out of our virtues; who miscarrying
Which entertain'd
Directive by the limbs.
Give pardon to my speech:
Therefore 'tis meet Achilles meet not Hector.
Let us
That ever Hector and Achilles meet;
For both our honour and our shame in this
Are dogg'd with two strange followers.
I see them not with my old eyes: what are they?
What glory our Achilles shares from Hector
But he already is too insolent;
A nd we were better parch in Afric sun
Than in the pride and salt scorn of his eyes
In taint of our best man. No
And
The sort to fight with Hector: among ourselves
Give him allowance for the better man;
For that will physic the great Myrmidon
Who broils in loud applause
His crest that prouder than blue Iris bends.
If the dull brainless Ajax come safe off
That we have better men. But
Ajax employ'd plucks down Achilles' plumes.
Ulysses
And I will give a taste of it forthwith
To Agamemnon: go we to him straight.
Two curs shall tame each other: pride alone
Must tarre the mastiffs on
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
Enter AJAX and THERSITES
Thersites!
Agamemnon
Thersites!
And those boils did run? say so: did not the
general run then? were not that a botchy core?
Dog!
Then would come some matter from him; I see none now.
Thou bitch-wolf's son
Beating him
Feel
The plague of Greece upon thee
beef-witted lord!
Speak then
beat thee into handsomeness.
I shall sooner rail thee into wit and holiness: but
thou learn a prayer without book. Thou canst strike
Toadstool
Dost thou think I have no sense
The proclamation!
Thou art proclaimed a fool
Do not
I would thou didst itch from head to foot and I had
the scratching of thee; I would make thee the
loathsomest scab in Greece. When thou art forth in
the incursions
I say
Thou grumblest and railest every hour on Achilles
Cerberus is at Proserpine's beauty
barkest at him.
Mistress Thersites!
Thou shouldest strike him.
Cobloaf!
He would pun thee into shivers with his fist
sailor breaks a biscuit.
[Beating him]  You whoreson cur!
Do
Thou stool for a witch!
Ay
more brain than I have in mine elbows; an assinego
may tutor thee: thou scurvy-valiant ass! thou art
here but to thrash Trojans; and thou art bought and
sold among those of any wit
If thou use to beat me
tell what thou art by inches
bowels
You dog!
You scurvy lord!
[Beating him]  You cur!
Mars his idiot! do
Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS
Why
You see him there
Ay; what's the matter?
Nay
So I do: what's the matter?
Nay
'Well!' why
But yet you look not well upon him; for whosoever you
take him to be
I know that
Ay
Therefore I beat thee.
Lo
evasions have ears thus long. I have bobbed his
brain more than he has beat my bones: I will buy

worth the nineth part of a sparrow. This lord
his guts in his head
him.
What?
I say
Ajax offers to beat him
Nay
Has not so much wit--
Nay

comes to fight.
Peace
I would have peace and quietness
not: he there: that he: look you there.
O thou damned cur! I shall--
Will you set your wit to a fool's?
No
Good words
What's the quarrel?
I bade the vile owl go learn me the tenor of the
proclamation

Well
I serve here voluntarily.
Your last service was sufferance
voluntary: no man is beaten voluntary: Ajax was
here the voluntary

Yes

No more words
I will hold my peace when Achilles' brach bids me
There's for you
I will see you hanged
any more to your tents: I will keep where there is
wit stirring and leave the faction of fools.
Exit
A good riddance.
Marry
That Hector
To-morrow morning call some knight to arms
That hath a stomach; and such a one that dare
Maintain--I know not what: 'tis trash. Farewell.
Farewell. Who shall answer him?
I know not: 'tis put to lottery; otherwise
He knew his man.
O
Exeunt
SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
Enter PRIAM
After so many hours
'Deliver Helen
As honour
In hot digestion of this cormorant war--
Shall be struck off.' Hector
Though no man lesser fears the Greeks than I
As far as toucheth my particular
Than Hector is: the wound of peace is surety
The beacon of the wise
To the bottom of the worst. Let Helen go:
Since the first sword was drawn about this question
If we have lost so many tenths of ours
The yielding of her up?
Fie
Weigh you the worth and honour of a king
So great as our dread father in a scale
Of common ounces? will you with counters sum
The past proportion of his infinite?
And buckle in a waist most fathomless
With spans and inches so diminutive
As fears and reasons? fie
No marvel
Bear the great sway of his affairs with reasons
You are for dreams and slumbers
You fur your gloves with reason. Here are
your reasons:
You know an enemy intends you harm;
You know a sword employ'd is perilous
Who marvels then
A Grecian and his sword
The very wings of reason to his heels
And fly like chidden Mercury from Jove
Should have hare-hearts
their thoughts
With this cramm'd reason: reason and respect
Make livers pale and lustihood deject.
Brother
The holding.
What is aught
But value dwells not in particular will;
It holds his estimate and dignity
As well wherein 'tis precious of itself
As in the prizer: 'tis mad idolatry
To make the service greater than the god
And the will dotes that is attributive
To what infectiously itself affects
I take to-day a wife
Is led on in the conduct of my will;
My will enkindled by mine eyes and ears
Of will and judgment: how may I avoid
To blench from this and to stand firm by honour:
We turn not back the silks upon the merchant
We do not throw in unrespective sieve
Paris should do some vengeance on the Greeks:
Your breath of full consent bellied his sails;
The seas and winds
And did him service: he touch'd the ports desired
Wrinkles Apollo's
Why keep we her? the Grecians keep our aunt:
Is she worth keeping? why
If you'll avouch 'twas wisdom Paris went--
As you must needs
If you'll confess he brought home noble prize--
As you must needs
And cried 'Inestimable!'--why do you now
The issue of your proper wisdoms rate
Richer than sea and land? O
But
[Within]  Cry
What noise? what shriek is this?
'Tis our mad sister
[Within]  Cry
It is Cassandra.
Enter CASSANDRA
Cry
Peace
Virgins and boys
A moiety of that mass of moan to come.
Cry
Troy must not be
Our firebrand brother
Cry
Cry
Exit
Now
Of divination in our sister work
Some touches of remorse? or is your blood
So madly hot that no discourse of reason
Why
Such and no other than event doth form it
Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel
Which hath our several honours all engaged
To make it gracious. For my private part
And Jove forbid there should be done amongst us
Such things as might offend the weakest spleen
To fight for and maintain!
Else might the world convince of levity
As well my undertakings as your counsels:
But I attest the gods
Gave wings to my propension and cut off
All fears attending on so dire a project.
For what
What Propugnation is in one man's valour
This quarrel would excite? Yet
And had as ample power as I have will
Paris
Like one besotted on your sweet delights:
You have the honey still
So to be valiant is no praise at all.
Sir
The pleasures such a beauty brings with it;
But I would have the soil of her fair rape
Wiped off
What treason were it to the ransack'd queen
On terms of base compulsion! Can it be
That so degenerate a strain as this
Should once set footing in your generous bosoms?
There's not the meanest spirit on our party
Without a heart to dare or sword to draw
When Helen is defended
Whose life were ill bestow'd or death unfamed
Where Helen is the subject; then
Paris and Troilus
Have glozed
Unlike young men
Unfit to hear moral philosophy:
The reasons you allege do more conduce
To the hot passion of distemper'd blood
Than to make up a free determination
'Twixt right and wrong
Have ears more deaf than adders to the voice
Of any true decision. Nature craves
All dues be render'd to their owners: now
Than wife is to the husband? If this law
Of nature be corrupted through affection
To their benumbed wills
To curb those raging appetites that are
Most disobedient and refractory.
If Helen then be wife to Sparta's king
Of nature and of nations speak aloud
To have her back return'd: thus to persist
In doing wrong extenuates not wrong
Is this in way of truth; yet ne'ertheless
In resolution to keep Helen still
Upon our joint and several dignities.
Why
Were it not glory that we more affected
Than the performance of our heaving spleens
Spent more in her defence. But
For
So rich advantage of a promised glory
As smiles upon the forehead of this action
For the wide world's revenue.
I am yours
I have a roisting challenge sent amongst
The dun and factious nobles of the Greeks
Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits:
I was advertised their great general slept
This
Exeunt

How now
thy fury! Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He
beats me
would it were otherwise; that I could beat him
conjure and raise devils

scarce

Who's there? Thersites! Good Thersites
If I could have remembered a gilt counterfeit

curse of mankind

out says thou art a fair corse
sworn upon't she never shrouded any but lazars.

What

Patroclus is a fool positive.
Why am I a fool?

Here is such patchery

and bleed to death upon. Now
the subject! and war and lechery confound all!

Where is Achilles?
Within his tent; but ill disposed

He shent our messengers; and we lay by
Our appertainments

argument
All the better; their fraction is more our wish than

No Achilles with him.
The elephant hath joints
his legs are legs for necessity
Achilles bids me say
Did move your greatness and this noble state
To call upon him; he hopes it is no other
But for your health and your digestion sake
Hear you
We are too well acquainted with these answers:
But his evasion
Much attribute he hath
Why we ascribe it to him; yet all his virtues
And under-honest
Than in the note of judgment; and worthier
than himself
Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on
His humorous predominance; yea
His pettish lunes
The passage and whole carriage of this action
Rode on his tide. Go tell him this
Not portable
'Bring action hither
A stirring dwarf we do allowance give
Before a sleeping giant.' Tell him so.
I shall; and bring his answer presently.
Exit
In second voice we'll not be satisfied;
We come to speak with him. Ulysses
Exit ULYSSES
What is he more than another?
No more than what he thinks he is.
Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a
better man than I am?
No question.
Will you subscribe his thought
No
wise
more tractable.
Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I
know not what pride is.
Your mind is the clearer
fairer. He that is proud eats up himself: pride is
his own glass
and whatever praises itself but in the deed
the deed in the praise.
I do hate a proud man
Yet he loves himself: is't not strange?
Aside
Re-enter ULYSSES
Achilles will not to the field to-morrow.
What's his excuse?
He doth rely on none
Without observance or respect of any
Why will he not upon our fair request
Untent his person and share the air with us?
Things small as nothing
That quarrels at self-breath: imagined worth
Holds in his blood such swoln and hot discourse
That 'twixt his mental and his active parts
Kingdom'd Achilles in commotion rages
And batters down himself: what should I say?
He is so plaguy proud that the death-tokens of it
Cry 'No recovery.'
Let Ajax go to him.
Dear lord
'Tis said he holds you well
At your request a little from himself.
O Agamemnon
We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes
When they go from Achilles: shall the proud lord
That bastes his arrogance with his own seam
And never suffers matter of the world
Enter his thoughts
And ruminate himself
Of that we hold an idol more than he?
No
Must not so stale his palm
Nor
That were to enlard his fat already pride

With entertaining great Hyperion.
This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid

A paltry
How he describes himself!

The raven chides blackness.

He will be the physician that should be the patient.
An all men were o' my mind
Wit would be out of fashion.

Our noble general

Ay

Put pardon

Ay

There is no tarrying here; the hart Achilles
Keeps thicket. Please it our great general
To call together all his state of war;
Fresh kings are come to Troy: to-morrow
We must with all our main of power stand fast:
And here's a lord
Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep:
Light boats sail swift

I am giddy; expectation whirls me round.
The imaginary relish is so sweet
That it enchants my sense: what will it be
Love's thrice repured nectar? death
I fear it much; and I do fear besides
As doth a battle
The enemy flying.

She's making her ready
must be witty now. She does so blush
her wind so short
sprite: I'll fetch her. It is the prettiest
villain: she fetches her breath as short as a

Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom:
My heart beats thicker than a feverous pulse;
And all my powers do their bestowing lose
The eye of majesty.

Come

More dregs than water
Fears make devils of cherubims; they never see truly.
Blind fear
footing than blind reason stumbling without fear: to
fear the worst oft cures the worse.
O
pageant there is presented no monster.
Nor nothing monstrous neither?
Nothing
seas
it harder for our mistress to devise imposition
enough than for us to undergo any difficulty imposed.
This is the monstruosity in love
is infinite and the execution confined
desire is boundless and the act a slave to limit.
They say all lovers swear more performance than they
are able and yet reserve an ability that they never
perform
discharging less than the tenth part of one. They
that have the voice of lions and the act of hares
Are there such? such are not we: praise us as we
are tasted
bare till merit crown it: no perfection in reversion
shall have a praise in present: we will not name
desert before his birth
shall be humble. Few words to fair faith: Troilus
shall be such to Cressid as what envy can say worst
shall be a mock for his truth
speak truest not truer than Troilus.
Will you walk in
Re-enter PANDARUS
What
Well
I thank you for that: if my lord get a boy of you
flinch
You know now your hostages; your uncle's word and my

Nay
constant being won: they are burs
they'll stick where they are thrown.
Boldness comes to me now
Prince Troilus
For many weary months.
Why was my Cressid then so hard to win?
Hard to seem won: but I was won
If I confess much
I love you now; but not
But I might master it: in faith
My thoughts were like unbridled children
Too headstrong for their mother. See
Why have I blabb'd? who shall be true to us
But
And yet
Of speaking first. Sweet
The thing I shall repent. See
My very soul of counsel! stop my mouth.
And shall
Pretty
My lord
'Twas not my purpose
I am ashamed. O heavens! what have I done?
For this time will I take my leave
Your leave
Leave! an you take leave till to-morrow morning
Pray you
What offends you
Sir
You cannot shun Yourself.
Let me go and try:
I have a kind of self resides with you;
But an unkind self
Where is my wit? I know not what I speak.
Well know they what they speak that speak so wisely.
Perchance
And fell so roundly to a large confession
Exceeds man's might; that dwells with gods above.
O that I thought it could be in a woman--
As
To feed for aye her ramp and flames of love;
To keep her constancy in plight and youth
That doth renew swifter than blood decays!
Or that persuasion could but thus convince me
Might be affronted with the match and weight
Of such a winnow'd purity in love;
How were I then uplifted! but
I am as true as truth's simplicity
And simpler than the infancy of truth.
In that I'll war with you.
O virtuous fight
True swains in love shall in the world to come
Approve their truths by Troilus: when their rhymes
Prophet may you be!
If I be false
To dusty nothing
As air
'Yea
Go to
witness. Here I hold your hand
If ever you prove false one to another
taken such pains to bring you together
pitiful goers-between be called to the world's end
after my name; call them all Pandars; let all
constant men be Troiluses
Amen.
Amen.
Amen. Whereupon I will show you a chamber with a
bed; which bed
pretty encounters
And Cupid grant all tongue-tied maidens here

SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
Enter AGAMEMNON
Now
To call for recompense. Appear it to your mind
That
That time
Made tame and most familiar to my nature
As new into the world
I do beseech you
What wouldst thou of us
You have a Trojan prisoner
Oft have you--often have you thanks therefore--
Desired my Cressid in right great exchange
That their negotiations all must slack
Give us a prince of blood
Shall quite strike off all service I have done
Let Diomedes bear him
What he requests of us. Good Diomed
Withal bring word if Hector will to-morrow
Be answer'd in his challenge: Ajax is ready.
This shall I undertake; and 'tis a burden
Which I am proud to bear.
Exeunt DIOMEDES and CALCHAS
Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS
Achilles stands i' the entrance of his tent:
Please it our general to pass strangely by him
I will come last. 'Tis like he'll question me
Why such unplausive eyes are bent on him:
If so
It may be good: pride hath no other glass
To show itself but pride
Feed arrogance and are the proud man's fees.
We'll execute your purpose
A form of strangeness as we pass along:
So do each lord
Than if not look'd on. I will lead the way.
What
You know my mind
What says Achilles? would he aught with us?
Would you
No.
Nothing
The better.
Exeunt AGAMEMNON and NESTOR
Good day
How do you? how do you?
Exit
What
How now
Good morrow
Ha?
Good morrow.
Ay
Exit
What mean these fellows? Know they not Achilles?
They pass by strangely: they were used to bend
To send their smiles before them to Achilles;
To come as humbly as they used to creep
To holy altars.
What
'Tis certain
He shall as soon read in the eyes of others
As feel in his own fall; for men
That are without him
Which when they fall
Die in the fall. But 'tis not so with me:
Fortune and I are friends: I do enjoy
At ample point all that I did possess
Something not worth in me such rich beholding
As they have often given. Here is Ulysses;
I'll interrupt his reading.
How now Ulysses!
Now
What are you reading?
A strange fellow here
Writes me: 'That man
As when his virtues shining upon others
Heat them and they retort that heat again
To the first giver.'
This is not strange
The beauty that is borne here in the face
The bearer knows not
To others' eyes; nor doth the eye itself
Salutes each other with each other's form;
For speculation turns not to itself
Where it may see itself. This is not strange at all.
I do not strain at the position
It is familiar
Who
That no man is the lord of any thing
Nor doth he of himself know them for aught
Till he behold them form'd in the applause
Where they're extended; who
The voice again
Fronting the sun
His figure and his heat.  I was much wrapt in this;
And apprehended here immediately
The unknown Ajax.
Heavens
Most abject in regard and dear in use!
What things again most dear in the esteem
And poor in worth! Now shall we see to-morrow--
An act that very chance doth throw upon him--
Ajax renown'd. O heavens
How some men creep in skittish fortune's hall
How one man eats into another's pride
To see these Grecian lords!--why
They clap the lubber Ajax on the shoulder
And great Troy shrieking.
I do believe it; for they pass'd by me
As misers do by beggars
Good word nor look: what
Time hath
Those scraps are good deeds past; which are devour'd
As fast as they are made
As done: perseverance
Quite out of fashion
In monumental mockery. Take the instant way;
For honour travels in a strait so narrow
For emulation hath a thousand sons
That one by one pursue: if you give way
And leave you hindmost;
Or like a gallant horse fall'n in first rank
For time is like a fashionable host
That slightly shakes his parting guest by the hand
virtue seek
Remuneration for the thing it was;
For beauty
To envious and calumniating time.
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin
More laud than gilt o'er-dusted.
The present eye praises the present object.
Then marvel not
Since things in motion sooner catch the eye
Than what not stirs. The cry went once on thee
And case thy reputation in thy tent;
Whose glorious deeds
And drave great Mars to faction.
Of this my privacy
I have strong reasons.
But 'gainst your privacy
The reasons are more potent and heroical:
'Tis known
With one of Priam's daughters.
Ha! known!
Is that a wonder?
The providence that's in a watchful state
Knows almost every grain of Plutus' gold
There is a mystery--with whom relation
Durst never meddle--in the soul of state;
Which hath an operation more divine
Than breath or pen can give expressure to:
All the commerce that you have had with Troy
As perfectly is ours as yours
And better would it fit Achilles much
To throw down Hector than Polyxena:
But it must grieve young Pyrrhus now at home
Farewell
The fool slides o'er the ice that you should break.
Exit
To this effect
A woman impudent and mannish grown
Is not more loathed than an effeminate man
In time of action. I stand condemn'd for this;
They think my little stomach to the war
And your great love to me restrains you thus:
Sweet
Shall from your neck unloose his amorous fold
Shall Ajax fight with Hector?
Ay
I see my reputation is at stake
My fame is shrewdly gored.
O
Those wounds heal ill that men do give themselves:
Omission to do what is necessary
Seals a commission to a blank of danger;
And danger
Even then when we sit idly in the sun.
Go call Thersites hither
I'll send the fool to Ajax and desire him
To invite the Trojan lords after the combat
To see us here unarm'd: I have a woman's longing
Enter THERSITES
A labour saved!
A wonder!
What?
Ajax goes up and down the field
How so?
He must fight singly to-morrow with Hector
prophetically proud of an heroical cudgelling that he
raves in saying nothing.
How can that be?
Why
and a stand: ruminates like an hostess that hath no

Would the fountain of your mind were clear again

ACT IV
SCENE I. Troy. A street.
Enter
See
It is the Lord AEneas.
Is the prince there in person?
Had I so good occasion to lie long
As you
Should rob my bed-mate of my company.
That's my mind too. Good morrow
A valiant Greek
Witness the process of your speech
You told how Diomed
Health to you
But when I meet you arm'd
As heart can think or courage execute.
The one and other Diomed embraces.
Our bloods are now in calm; and
But when contention and occasion meet
With all my force
And thou shalt hunt a lion
With his face backward. In humane gentleness
The thing he means to kill more excellently.
We sympathize: Jove
But
We know each other well.
We do; and long to know each other worse.
This is the most despiteful gentle greeting
What business
I was sent for to the king; but why
His purpose meets you: 'twas to bring this Greek
To Calchas' house
Let's have your company
Or rather
My brother Troilus lodges there to-night:
Rouse him and give him note of our approach.
With the whole quality wherefore: I fear
We shall be much unwelcome.
That I assure you:
Troilus had rather Troy were borne to Greece
Than Cressid borne from Troy.
There is no help;
The bitter disposition of the time
Will have it so. On
Good morrow
Exit with Servant
And tell me
Both alike:
He merits well to have her
He
The lees and dregs of a flat tamed piece;
You
Are pleased to breed out your inheritors:
Both merits poised
But he as he
You are too bitter to your countrywoman.
She's bitter to her country: hear me
For every false drop in her bawdy veins
A Grecian's life hath sunk; for every scruple
Of her contaminated carrion weight
As for her Greeks and Trojans suffer'd death.
Fair Diomed
But we in silence hold this virtue well
Here lies our way.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
Enter TROILUS and CRESSIDA
Dear
Then
He shall unbolt the gates.
Trouble him not;
To bed
As infants' empty of all thought!
Good morrow
I prithee now
Are you a-weary of me?
O Cressida! but that the busy day
Night hath been too brief.
Beshrew the witch! with venomous wights she stays
As tediously as hell
With wings more momentary-swift than thought.
You will catch cold
Prithee
You men will never tarry.
O foolish Cressid! I might have still held off
there's one up.

It is your uncle.
A pestilence on him! now will he be mocking:

How now
maid! where's my cousin Cressid?
Go hang yourself

Good morrow

Here! what should he do here?
Come

My lord
Paris your brother
Deliver'd to us; and for him forthwith
The Lady Cressida.
Is it so concluded?
By Priam and the general state of Troy:
They are at hand and ready to effect it.
How my achievements mock me!
I will go meet them: and
Good
Have not more gift in taciturnity.

Is't possible? no sooner got but lost? The devil

How now! what's the matter? who was here?
Ah
Why sigh you so profoundly? where's my lord? gone!
Tell me
Would I were as deep under the earth as I am above!
O the gods! what's the matter?
Prithee
born! I knew thou wouldst be his death. O

Good uncle
Thou must be gone
art changed for Antenor: thou must to thy father

O you immortal gods! I will not go.
Thou must.
I will not
I know no touch of consanguinity;
No kin no love
As the sweet Troilus. O you gods divine!
Make Cressid's name the very crown of falsehood
But the strong base and building of my love
Is as the very centre of the earth
Do
Tear my bright hair and scratch my praised cheeks
With sounding Troilus. I will not go from Troy.
Exeunt
SCENE III. The same. Street before Pandarus' house.
Enter PARIS
It is great morning
Of her delivery to this valiant Greek
Comes fast upon. Good my brother Troilus
Walk into her house;
I'll bring her to the Grecian presently:
And to his hand when I deliver her
A priest there offering to it his own heart.
Exit
I know what 'tis to love;
And would
Please you walk in
Exeunt
SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
Enter PANDARUS and CRESSIDA
Be moderate
Why tell you me of moderation?
The grief is fine
As that which causeth it: how can I moderate it?
If I could temporize with my affection
My love admits no qualifying dross;
No more my grief
Here
Enter TROILUS
Ah
O Troilus! Troilus!
Embracing him
What a pair of spectacles is here!
Let me embrace too. 'O heart
where he answers again
By friendship nor by speaking.'
There was never a truer rhyme. Let us cast away
nothing
verse: we see it
Cressid
Cold lips blow to their deities
Have the gods envy?
Ay
And is it true that I must go from Troy?
A hateful truth.
What
From Troy and Troilus.
Is it possible?
And suddenly; where injury of chance
Puts back leave-taking
All time of pause
Of all rejoindure
Our lock'd embrasures
Even in the birth of our own labouring breath:
We two
Did buy each other
With the rude brevity and discharge of one.
Injurious time now with a robber's haste
Crams his rich thievery up
As many farewells as be stars in heaven
[Within]  My lord
Hark! you are call'd: some say the Genius so
Cries 'come' to him that instantly must die.
Bid them have patience; she shall come anon.
Where are my tears? rain
my heart will be blown up by the root.
Exit
I must then to the Grecians?
No remedy.
A woful Cressid 'mongst the merry Greeks!
When shall we see again?
Hear me
I true! how now! what wicked deem is this?
Nay
I speak not 'be thou true
But 'be thou true
My sequent protestation; be thou true
O
As infinite as imminent! but I'll be true.
And I'll grow friend with danger. Wear this sleeve.
And you this glove. When shall I see you?
I will corrupt the Grecian sentinels
But yet be true.
O heavens! 'be true' again!
Hear while I speak it
The Grecian youths are full of quality;
They're loving
How novelty may move
Which
Makes me afeard.
O heavens! you love me not.
Die I a villain
In this I do not call your faith in question
So mainly as my merit: I cannot sing
But I can tell that in each grace of these
There lurks a still and dumb-discoursive devil
That tempts most cunningly: but be not tempted.
Do you think I will?
No.
But something may be done that we will not:
And sometimes we are devils to ourselves
[Within]  Nay
Come
[Within]  Brother Troilus!
Good brother
And bring AEneas and the Grecian with you.
My lord
Who
Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion
Whilst some with cunning gild their copper crowns
Fear not my truth: the moral of my wit
Is 'plain and true;' there's all the reach of it.
Enter AENEAS
Welcome
Which for Antenor we deliver you:
At the port
Entreat her fair; and
As Priam is in Ilion.
Fair Lady Cressid
The lustre in your eye
You shall be mistress
Grecian
In praising her: I tell thee
As thou unworthy to be call'd her servant.
I charge thee use her well
For
O
Let me be privileged by my place and message
I'll answer to my lust: and know you
She shall be prized; but that you say 'be't so
I'll speak it in my spirit and honour
Come
Lady
Exeunt TROILUS
Trumpet within
Hark! Hector's trumpet.
How have we spent this morning!
The prince must think me tardy and remiss
'Tis Troilus' fault: come
Let us make ready straight.
Yea
The glory of our Troy doth this day lie
On his fair worth and single chivalry.
Exeunt
SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
Enter AJAX
Here art thou in appointment fresh and fair
Give with thy trumpet a loud note to Troy
May pierce the head of the great combatant
And hale him hither.
Thou
Now crack thy lungs
Blow
Outswell the colic of puff'd Aquilon:
Come
Thou blow'st for Hector.
Trumpet sounds
No trumpet answers.
'Tis but early days.
Is not yond Diomed
'Tis he
He rises on the toe: that spirit of his
In aspiration lifts him from the earth.
Enter DIOMEDES
Is this the Lady Cressid?
Even she.
Most dearly welcome to the Greeks
Our general doth salute you with a kiss.
Yet is the kindness but particular;
'Twere better she were kiss'd in general.
And very courtly counsel: I'll begin.
So much for Nestor.
I'll take what winter from your lips
Achilles bids you welcome.
I had good argument for kissing once.
But that's no argument for kissing now;
For this popp'd Paris in his hardiment
O deadly gall
For which we lose our heads to gild his horns.
The first was Menelaus' kiss; this
Patroclus kisses you.
O
Paris and I kiss evermore for him.
I'll have my kiss
In kissing
Both take and give.
I'll make my match to live
Therefore no kiss.
I'll give you boot
You're an odd man; give even or give none.
An odd man
No
You fillip me o' the head.
No
It were no match
May I
You may.
I do desire it.
Why
Why then for Venus' sake
I am your debtor
Never's my day
Lady
Exit with CRESSIDA
A woman of quick sense.
Fie
There's language in her eye
At every joint and motive of her body.
O
To every ticklish reader! set them down
For sluttish spoils of opportunity
And daughters of the game.
Trumpet within
The Trojans' trumpet.
Yonder comes the troop.
Enter HECTOR
Hail
To him that victory commands? or do you purpose
A victor shall be known? will you the knights
Shall to the edge of all extremity
Pursue each other
By any voice or order of the field?
Hector bade ask.
Which way would Hector have it?
He cares not; he'll obey conditions.
'Tis done like Hector; but securely done
The knight opposed.
If not Achilles
If not Achilles
Therefore Achilles: but
In the extremity of great and little
The one almost as infinite as all
This Ajax is half made of Hector's blood:
In love whereof
Half heart
This blended knight
A maiden battle
Re-enter DIOMEDES
Here is Sir Diomed. Go
Consent upon the order of their fight
Half stints their strife before their strokes begin.
AJAX and HECTOR enter the lists
They are opposed already.
What Trojan is that same that looks so heavy?
The youngest son of Priam
Not soon provoked nor being provoked soon calm'd:
His heart and hand both open and both free;
For what he has he gives
Yet gives he not till judgment guide his bounty
Manly as Hector
For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes
To tender objects
Is more vindicative than jealous love:
They call him Troilus
A second hope
Thus says AEneas; one that knows the youth
Even to his inches
Did in great Ilion thus translate him to me.
Alarum. Hector and Ajax fight
They are in action.
Now
Hector
Awake thee!
His blows are well disposed: there
You must no more.
Trumpets cease
Princes
I am not warm yet; let us fight again.
As Hector pleases.
Why
Thou art
The obligation of our blood forbids
A gory emulation 'twixt us twain:
Were thy commixtion Greek and Trojan so
That thou couldst say 'This hand is Grecian all
All Greek
Runs on the dexter cheek
Bounds in my father's;' by Jove multipotent
Wherein my sword had not impressure made
Of our rank feud: but the just gods gainsay
That any drop thou borrow'dst from thy mother
Be drain'd! Let me embrace thee
By him that thunders
Hector would have them fall upon him thus:
Cousin
I thank thee
Thou art too gentle and too free a man:
I came to kill thee
A great addition earned in thy death.
Not Neoptolemus so mirable
Cries 'This is he
A thought of added honour torn from Hector.
There is expectance here from both the sides
We'll answer it;
The issue is embracement: Ajax
If I might in entreaties find success--
As seld I have the chance--I would desire
My famous cousin to our Grecian tents.
'Tis Agamemnon's wish
Doth long to see unarm'd the valiant Hector.
AEneas
To the expecters of our Trojan part;
Desire them home. Give me thy hand
I will go eat with thee and see your knights.
Great Agamemnon comes to meet us here.
The worthiest of them tell me name by name;
But for Achilles
Shall find him by his large and portly size.
Worthy of arms! as welcome as to one
That would be rid of such an enemy;
But that's no welcome: understand more clear
And formless ruin of oblivion;
But in this extant moment
I thank thee
[To TROILUS]  My well-famed lord of Troy
less to you.
Let me confirm my princely brother's greeting:
You brace of warlike brothers
Who must we answer?
The noble Menelaus.
O
Mock not
Your quondam wife swears still by Venus' glove:
She's well
Name her not now
O
I have
Labouring for destiny make cruel way
Through ranks of Greekish youth
'Lo
And I have seen thee pause and take thy breath
But this thy countenance
But
And
'Tis the old Nestor.
Let me embrace thee
Most reverend Nestor
I would my arms could match thee in contention
I would they could.
Ha!
By this white beard
Well
I wonder now how yonder city stands
When we have here her base and pillar by us.
I know your favour
Ah
In Ilion
Sir
My prophecy is but half his journey yet;
For yonder walls
I must not believe you:
There they stand yet
A drop of Grecian blood: the end crowns all
So to him we leave it.
Most gentle and most valiant Hector
After the general
To feast with me and see me at my tent.
I shall forestall thee
Now
I have with exact view perused thee
Is this Achilles?
I am Achilles.
Stand fair
Behold thy fill.
Nay
Thou art too brief: I will the second time
O
But there's more in me than thou understand'st.
Why dost thou so oppress me with thine eye?
Tell me
Shall I destroy him? whether there
That I may give the local wound a name
And make distinct the very breach whereout
Hector's great spirit flew: answer me
It would discredit the blest gods
Think'st thou to catch my life so pleasantly
As to prenominate in nice conjecture
Where thou wilt hit me dead?
I tell thee
Wert thou an oracle to tell me so
For I'll not kill thee there
But
You wisest Grecians
His insolence draws folly from my lips;
But I'll endeavour deeds to match these words
Do not chafe thee
And you
You may have every day enough of Hector
If you have stomach; the general state
I pray you
We have had pelting wars
The Grecians' cause.
Dost thou entreat me
To-morrow do I meet thee
To-night all friends.
Thy hand upon that match.
First

Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives
Hector is dead; there is no more to say.
Stay yet. You vile abominable tents
I'll haunt thee like a wicked conscience still
Strike a free march to Troy! with comfort go:
Hope of revenge shall hide our inward woe.

A goodly medicine for my aching bones! O world!

O traitors and bawds
a-work

ACT I
SCENE I. DUKE ORSINO's palace.
Enter DUKE ORSINO
If music be the food of love
Give me excess of it
That strain again! it had a dying fall:
O
'Tis not so sweet now as it was before.
O spirit of love! how quick and fresh art thou
Receiveth as the sea
That it alone is high fantastical.
Will you go hunt
What
The hart.
Why
O
That instant was I turn'd into a hart;
And my desires
Enter VALENTINE
How now! what news from her?
So please my lord
But from her handmaid do return this answer:
The element itself
But
And water once a day her chamber round
With eye-offending brine: all this to season
A brother's dead love
And lasting in her sad remembrance.
O
To pay this debt of love but to a brother
Hath kill'd the flock of all affections else
That live in her; when liver
Her sweet perfections with one self king!
Away before me to sweet beds of flowers:
Love-thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.
Exeunt
SCENE II. The sea-coast.
Enter VIOLA
What country
This is Illyria
And what should I do in Illyria?
My brother he is in Elysium.
Perchance he is not drown'd: what think you
It is perchance that you yourself were saved.
O my poor brother! and so perchance may he be.
TRUE
Hung on our driving boat
Where
So long as I could see.
For saying so
Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope
Ay
Not three hours' travel from this very place.
Who governs here?
A noble duke
What is the name?
Orsino.
Orsino! I have heard my father name him:
He was a bachelor then.
And so is now
For but a month ago I went from hence
That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.
What's she?
A virtuous maid
That died some twelvemonth since
In the protection of his son
And sight of men.
O that I served that lady
And might not be delivered to the world
That were hard to compass;
Because she will admit no kind of suit
There is a fair behavior in thee
And though that nature with a beauteous wall
Doth oft close in pollution
I will believe thou hast a mind that suits
With this thy fair and outward character.
I prithee
For such disguise as haply shall become
The form of my intent. I'll serve this duke:
Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him:
It may be worth thy pains; for I can sing
And speak to him in many sorts of music
That will allow me very worth his service.
What else may hap to time I will commit;
Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.
Be you his eunuch
When my tongue blabs
I thank thee: lead me on.
Exeunt

limits of order.

SCENE V. OLIVIA'S house.

Let her hang me: he that is well hanged in this
world needs to fear no colours.
Make that good.
He shall see none to fear.
A good lenten answer: I can tell thee where that
saying was born
Where
In the wars; and that may you be bold to say in your foolery.
Well
that are fools

Two faults
will amend: for give the dry fool drink

himself; if he mend
he cannot
that's mended is but patched: virtue that
transgresses is but patched with sin; and sin that

SCENE III. A street.

I would not by my will have troubled you;

As might have drawn one to a longer voyage

With the memorials and the things of fame
That do renown this city.
Would you'ld pardon me;
I do not without danger walk these streets:
Once
I did some service; of such note indeed
Belike you slew great number of his people.
The offence is not of such a bloody nature;
Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel
Might well have given us bloody argument.
It might have since been answer'd in repaying
What we took from them; which
For which
Do not then walk too open.
It doth not fit me. Hold
In the south suburbs
With viewing of the town: there shall you have me.
Why I your purse?
Haply your eye shall light upon some toy
You have desire to purchase; and your store
I'll be your purse-bearer and leave you
For an hour.
To the Elephant.
I do remember.

I think nobly of the soul

SCENE III. OLIVIA's garden.

This is the air; that is the glorious sun;
This pearl she gave me
And though 'tis wonder that enwraps me thus
I could not find him at the Elephant:
Yet there he was; and there I found this credit
His counsel now might do me golden service;
For though my soul disputes well with my sense
So far exceed all instance
And wrangle with my reason that persuades me
To any other trust but that I am mad
Or else the lady's mad; yet
With such a smooth
As I perceive she does: there's something in't
That is deceiveable. But here the lady comes.

According to my birth. What do you say?

Enter ANTONIO and Officers
That face of his I do remember well;
Yet
As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war:
A bawbling vessel was he captain of
With which such scathful grapple did he make
With the most noble bottom of our fleet
Cried fame and honour on him. What's the matter?
Orsino
That took the Phoenix and her fraught from Candy;
And this is he that did the Tiger board
Here in the streets
He did me kindness
But in conclusion put strange speech upon me:
I know not what 'twas but distraction.
Notable pirate! thou salt-water thief!
What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies
Orsino
Antonio never yet was thief or pirate
That most ingrateful boy there by your side
Did I redeem; a wreck past hope he was:
His life I gave him and did thereto add
My love
Did I expose myself
Drew to defend him when he was beset:
Where being apprehended
While one would wink; denied me mine own purse
Not half an hour before.
How can this be?
When came he to this town?
To-day
Enter OLIVIA and Attendants
Here comes the countess: now heaven walks on earth.
But for thee

But more of that anon. Take him aside.
What would my lord
Cesario
Madam!
Gracious Olivia
What do you say
My lord would speak; my duty hushes me.
If it be aught to the old tune
As howling after music.
Still so cruel?

What

Even what it please my lord

That screws me from my true place in your favour
But this your minion

One face
Antonio
How have the hours rack'd and tortured me
Sebastian are you?
Fear'st thou that
How have you made division of yourself?
An apple
Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?
Most wonderful!
Do I stand there? I never had a brother;
Nor can there be that deity in my nature
Of charity
What countryman? what name? what parentage?
Of Messaline: Sebastian was my father;
Such a Sebastian was my brother too
If spirits can assume both form and suit
You come to fright us.
A spirit I am indeed;
But am in that dimension grossly clad
Which from the womb I did participate.
Were you a woman
My father had a mole upon his brow.
And so had mine.
And died that day when Viola from her birth
Had number'd thirteen years.
O
He finished indeed his mortal act
That day that made my sister thirteen years.
If nothing lets to make us happy both
But this my masculine usurp'd attire
Of place
That I am Viola: which to confirm
I was preserved to serve this noble count.
All the occurrence of my fortune since
Hath been between this lady and this lord.
[To OLIVIA]  So comes it
But nature to her bias drew in that.
You would have been contracted to a maid;
Nor are you therein
Be not amazed; right noble is his blood.
If this be so
To VIOLA
Boy
Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.
And all those sayings will I overswear;
And those swearings keep as true in soul
As doth that orbed continent the fire
That severs day from night.
Give me thy hand;
And let me see thee in thy woman's weeds.
The captain that did bring me first on shore
Hath my maid's garments: he upon some action
Is now in durance
He shall enlarge him: fetch Malvolio hither:
And yet
Re-enter Clown with a letter
A most extracting frenzy of mine own
From my remembrance clearly banish'd his.
How does he
Truly
well as a man in his case may do: has here writ a
letter to you; I should have given't you to-day
morning
Open't
Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers
the madman.
Reads
'By the Lord
How now! art thou mad?
No
will have it as it ought to be
Prithee
So I do
read thus: therefore perpend
Read it you
To FABIAN
[Reads]  'By the Lord
world shall know it: though you have put me into
darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over
me
your ladyship. I have your own letter that induced
me to the semblance I put on; with the which I doubt
not but to do myself much right
Think of me as you please. I leave my duty a little
unthought of and speak out of my injury.
THE MADLY-USED MALVOLIO.'
Did he write this?
Ay
This savours not much of distraction.
See him deliver'd
Exit FABIAN
My lord so please you
thought on
Madam
To VIOLA
Your master quits you; and for your service done him
Your master's mistress.
A sister! you are she.
Re-enter FABIAN
Is this the madman?
Ay
How now
Madam
Have I
Lady
You must not now deny it is your hand:
Write from it
Or say 'tis not your seal
You can say none of this: well
And tell me
Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people;
And
That e'er invention play'd on? tell me why.
Alas
But out of question 'tis Maria's hand.
And now I do bethink me
First told me thou wast mad; then camest in smiling
Upon thee in the letter. Prithee
This practise hath most shrewdly pass'd upon thee;
But when we know the grounds and authors of it
Of thine own cause.
Good madam
Taint the condition of this present hour
Set this device against Malvolio here
We had conceived against him: Maria writ
The letter at Sir Toby's great importance;
In recompense whereof he hath married her.
How with a sportful malice it was follow'd
If that the injuries be justly weigh'd
That have on both sides pass'd.
Alas
Why
one
that's all one. 'By the Lord
But do you remember? 'Madam
a barren rascal? an you smile not
and thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.
I'll be revenged on the whole pack of you.
Exit
He hath been most notoriously abused.
Pursue him and entreat him to a peace:
He hath not told us of the captain yet:
When that is known and golden time convents
Of our dear souls. Meantime
For so you shall be
But when in other habits you are seen
Exeunt all
[Sings]
When that I was and a little tiny boy
But when I came to man's estate
'Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate
But when I came
By swaggering could I never thrive
But when I came unto my beds
With toss-pots still had drunken heads
A great while ago the world begun
But that's all one
Exit
ACT I
SCENE I. Verona. An open place.
Enter VALENTINE and PROTEUS
Cease to persuade
Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.
Were't not affection chains thy tender days
To the sweet glances of thy honour'd love
To see the wonders of the world abroad
But since thou lovest
Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine
Think on thy Proteus
Some rare note-worthy object in thy travel:
Wish me partaker in thy happiness
When thou dost meet good hap; and in thy danger
And on a love-book pray for my success?
Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.
That's on some shallow story of deep love:
How young Leander cross'd the Hellespont.
That's a deep story of a deeper love:
For he was more than over shoes in love.
'Tis true; for you are over boots in love
Over the boots? nay
No
What?
To be in love
Coy looks with heart-sore sighs; one fading moment's mirth
With twenty watchful
If haply won
If lost
However
So
So
'Tis love you cavil at: I am not Love.
Love is your master
And he that is so yoked by a fool
Yet writers say
The eating canker dwells
Inhabits in the finest wits of all.
And writers say
Is eaten by the canker ere it blow
Is turn'd to folly
And all the fair effects of future hopes.
But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee
Once more adieu! my father at the road
Expects my coming
And thither will I bring thee
Sweet Proteus
To Milan let me hear from thee by letters
Of thy success in love
Betideth here in absence of thy friend;
And likewise will visit thee with mine.
All happiness bechance to thee in Milan!
As much to you at home! and so
Exit
He after honour hunts
He leaves his friends to dignify them more
Thou
Made wit with musing weak
Enter SPEED
Sir Proteus
But now he parted hence
Twenty to one then he is shipp'd already
Indeed
You conclude that my master is a shepherd
I do.
Why then
A silly answer and fitting well a sheep.
This proves me still a sheep.
True; and thy master a shepherd.
Nay
It shall go hard but I'll prove it by another.
The shepherd seeks the sheep
shepherd; but I seek my master
not me: therefore I am no sheep.
The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd; the
shepherd for food follows not the sheep: thou for
wages followest thy master; thy master for wages
follows not thee: therefore thou art a sheep.
Such another proof will make me cry 'baa.'
But
Ay sir: I
lost mutton
Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.
If the ground be overcharged
Nay: in that you are astray
Nay
carrying your letter.
You mistake; I mean the pound
From a pound to a pin? fold it over and over
your lover.
But what said she?
[First nodding]  Ay.
Nod--Ay--why
You mistook
me if she did nod; and I say
And that set together is noddy.
Now you have taken the pains to set it together
No
Well
Why sir
Marry
but the word 'noddy' for my pains.
Beshrew me
And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.
Come come
Open your purse
be both at once delivered.
Well
Truly
Why
Sir
and being so hard to me that brought your mind
fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling your
mind. Give her no token but stones; for she's as
hard as steel.
What said she? nothing?
No
testify your bounty
me; in requital whereof
letters yourself: and so
Go
Exit SPEED
I must go send some better messenger:
I fear my Julia would not deign my lines
Exit
SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.
Enter JULlA and LUCETTA
But say
Ay
Of all the fair resort of gentlemen
That every day with parle encounter me
Please you repeat their names
According to my shallow simple skill.
What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?
As of a knight well-spoken
But
What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?
Well of his wealth; but of himself
What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?
Lord
How now! what means this passion at his name?
Pardon
That I
Why not on Proteus
Then thus: of many good I think him best.
Your reason?
I have no other
I think him so because I think him so.
And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?
Ay
Why he
Yet he
His little speaking shows his love but small.
Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.
They do not love that do not show their love.
O
I would I knew his mind.
Peruse this paper
'To Julia.' Say
That the contents will show.
Say
Valentine's page; and sent
He would have given it you; but I
fault I pray.
Now
Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?
To whisper and conspire against my youth?
Now
And you an officer fit for the place.
Or else return no more into my sight.
To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.
Will ye be gone?
That you may ruminate.
Exit
And yet I would I had o'erlooked the letter:
It were a shame to call her back again
And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.
What a fool is she
Since maids
Which they would have the profferer construe 'ay.'
Fie
That
And presently all humbled kiss the rod!
How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence
How angerly I taught my brow to frown
My penance is to call Lucetta back
And ask remission for my folly past.
What ho! Lucetta!
Re-enter LUCETTA
What would your ladyship?
Is't near dinner-time?
I would it were
And not upon your maid.
What is't that you took up so gingerly?
Nothing.
Why didst thou stoop
To take a paper up that I let fall.
And is that paper nothing?
Nothing concerning me.
Then let it lie for those that it concerns.
Madam
Unless it have a false interpeter.
Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme.
That I might sing it
Give me a note: your ladyship can set.
As little by such toys as may be possible.
Best sing it to the tune of 'Light o' love.'
It is too heavy for so light a tune.
Heavy! belike it hath some burden then?
Ay
And why not you?
I cannot reach so high.
Let's see your song. How now
Keep tune there still
And yet methinks I do not like this tune.
You do not?
No
You
Nay
And mar the concord with too harsh a descant:
There wanteth but a mean to fill your song.
The mean is drown'd with your unruly bass.
Indeed
This babble shall not henceforth trouble me.
Here is a coil with protestation!
Tears the letter
Go get you gone
You would be fingering them
She makes it strange; but she would be best pleased
To be so anger'd with another letter.
Exit
Nay
O hateful hands
Injurious wasps
And kill the bees that yield it with your stings!
I'll kiss each several paper for amends.
Look
As in revenge of thy ingratitude
And here is writ 'love-wounded Proteus.'
Poor wounded name! my bosom as a bed
Shall lodge thee till thy wound be thoroughly heal'd;
And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss.
But twice or thrice was 'Proteus' written down.
Be calm
Till I have found each letter in the letter
Unto a ragged fearful-hanging rock
And throw it thence into the raging sea!
Lo
And yet I will not
He couples it to his complaining names.
Thus will I fold them one on another:
Now kiss
Re-enter LUCETTA
Madam
Well
What
If you respect them
Nay
Yet here they shall not lie
I see you have a month's mind to them.
Ay
I see things too
Come
Exeunt
SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.
Enter ANTONIO and PANTHINO
Tell me
Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?
'Twas of his nephew Proteus
Why
He wonder'd that your lordship
Would suffer him to spend his youth at home
Some to the wars
Some to discover islands far away;
Some to the studious universities.
For any or for all these exercises
To let him spend his time no more at home
Nor need'st thou much importune me to that
Whereon this month I have been hammering.
I have consider'd well his loss of time
And how he cannot be a perfect man
Experience is by industry achieved
And perfected by the swift course of time.
Then tell me
I think your lordship is not ignorant
How his companion
I know it well.
'Twere good
There shall he practise tilts and tournaments
And be in eye of every exercise
Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.
I like thy counsel; well hast thou advised:
And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it
Even with the speediest expedition
I will dispatch him to the emperor's court.
To-morrow
And to commend their service to his will.
Good company; with them shall Proteus go:
And
Enter PROTEUS
Sweet love! sweet lines! sweet life!
Here is her hand
Here is her oath for love
O
O heavenly Julia!
How now! what letter are you reading there?
May't please your lordship
Of commendations sent from Valentine
Lend me the letter; let me see what news.
There is no news
How happily he lives
And daily graced by the emperor;
Wishing me with him
And how stand you affected to his wish?
As one relying on your lordship's will
And not depending on his friendly wish.
My will is something sorted with his wish.
Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed;
For what I will
I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time
With Valentinus in the emperor's court:
What maintenance he from his friends receives
To-morrow be in readiness to go:
Excuse it not
My lord
Please you
Look
No more of stay! to-morrow thou must go.
Come on
To hasten on his expedition.
Exeunt ANTONIO and PANTHINO
Thus have I shunn'd the fire for fear of burning
I fear'd to show my father Julia's letter
And with the vantage of mine own excuse
Hath he excepted most against my love.
O
The uncertain glory of an April day
Re-enter PANTHINO
Sir Proteus
He is in haste; therefore
Why
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
Enter VALENTINE and SPEED
Sir
Not mine; my gloves are on.
Why
Ha! let me see: ay
Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine!
Ah

How now
She is not within hearing
Why
Your worship
Well
And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.
Go to
She that your worship loves?
Why

Is she not hard-favoured
Not so fair
Sir
What dost thou know?
That she is not so fair as
I mean that her beauty is exquisite
That's because the one is painted and the other out

How painted? and how out of count?
Marry
man counts of her beauty.
How esteemest thou me? I account of her beauty.
You never saw her since she was deformed.
How long hath she been deformed?
Ever since you loved her.
I have loved her ever since I saw her; and still I
see her beautiful.
If you love her
Why?
Because Love is blind. O

No
Please you command

SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.
Enter PROTEUS and JULIA
Have patience
I must
When possibly I can
If you turn not
Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.
Giving a ring
Why then
And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.
Here is my hand for my true constancy;
And when that hour o'erslips me in the day
Wherein I sigh not
Torment me for my love's forgetfulness!
My father stays my coming; answer not;
The tide is now: nay
That tide will stay me longer than I should.
Julia

What
Ay
For truth hath better deeds than words to grace it.

SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

Servant!
Mistress?
Master
Ay
Not of you.
Of my mistress

Exit
Servant
Indeed
Seem you that you are not?
Haply I do.
So do counterfeits.
So do you.
What seem I that I am not?
Wise.
What instance of the contrary?
Your folly.
And how quote you my folly?
I quote it in your jerkin.
My jerkin is a doublet.
Well
How?
What
Give him leave
That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live
in your air.
You have said
Ay
I know it well
A fine volley of words

Yourself

Sir

I know it well

Enter DUKE
Now
Sir Valentine
What say you to a letter from your friends
Of much good news?
My lord
To any happy messenger from thence.
Know ye Don Antonio
Ay
To be of worth and worthy estimation
And not without desert so well reputed.
Hath he not a son?
Ay
The honour and regard of such a father.
You know him well?
I know him as myself; for from our infancy
We have conversed and spent our hours together:
And though myself have been an idle truant
To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection
His years but young
His head unmellow'd
And
Comes all the praises that I now bestow
With all good grace to grace a gentleman.
Beshrew me
As meet to be an emperor's counsellor.
Well
And here he means to spend his time awhile:
I think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.
Should I have wish'd a thing
Welcome him then according to his worth.
Silvia
For Valentine
I will send him hither to you presently.
Exit
This is the gentleman I told your ladyship
Had come along with me
Did hold his eyes lock'd in her crystal looks.
Belike that now she hath enfranchised them
Upon some other pawn for fealty.
Nay
Nay
How could he see his way to seek out you?
Why
They say that Love hath not an eye at all.
To see such lovers
Upon a homely object Love can wink.
Have done
Exit THURIO
Enter PROTEUS
Welcome
His worth is warrant for his welcome hither
Mistress
To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.
Too low a mistress for so high a servant.
Not so
To have a look of such a worthy mistress.
Leave off discourse of disability:
Sweet lady
My duty will I boast of; nothing else.
And duty never yet did want his meed:
Servant
I'll die on him that says so but yourself.
That you are welcome?
That you are worthless.
Re-enter THURIO
Madam
I wait upon his pleasure. Come
I'll leave you to confer of home affairs;
When you have done
We'll both attend upon your ladyship.
Exeunt SILVIA and THURIO
Now
Your friends are well and have them much commended.
And how do yours?
I left them all in health.
How does your lady? and how thrives your love?
My tales of love were wont to weary you;
I know you joy not in a love discourse.
Ay
I have done penance for contemning Love
With bitter fasts
For in revenge of my contempt of love
And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.
O gentle Proteus
Now no discourse
Now can I break my fast
Enough; I read your fortune in your eye.
Was this the idol that you worship so?
Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?
No; but she is an earthly paragon.
Call her divine.
I will not flatter her.
O
When I was sick
Then speak the truth by her; if not divine
Except my mistress.
Sweet
Except thou wilt except against my love.
Have I not reason to prefer mine own?
And I will help thee to prefer her too:
She shall be dignified with this high honour--
To bear my lady's train
Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss
And
And make rough winter everlastingly.
Why
Pardon me
To her whose worth makes other worthies nothing;
She is alone.
Then let her alone.
Not for the world: why
As twenty seas
Forgive me that I do not dream on thee
My foolish rival
Only for his possessions are so huge
But she loves you?
Ay
Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.
Good Proteus
Go on before; I shall inquire you forth:
I must unto the road
Some necessaries that I needs must use
Will you make haste?
I will.
Exit VALENTINE
Even as one heat another heat expels
Is by a newer object quite forgotten.
Is it mine
She is fair; and so is Julia that I love--
That I did love
Which
Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold
O
How shall I dote on her with more advice
'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld
But when I look on her perfections
If I can cheque my erring love
If not
Exit
