SCENE VI. The same. The DUKE'S palace.
Enter PROTEUS
To leave my Julia
To love fair Silvia
To wrong my friend
And even that power which gave me first my oath
Provokes me to this threefold perjury;
Love bade me swear and Love bids me forswear.
O sweet-suggesting Love
At first I did adore a twinkling star
Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken
To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better.
Fie
With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.
I cannot leave to love
But there I leave to love where I should love.
Julia I lose and Valentine I lose:
If I keep them
If I lose them
For Valentine myself
I to myself am dearer than a friend
And Silvia--witness Heaven
Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.
I will forget that Julia is alive
And Valentine I'll hold an enemy
I cannot now prove constant to myself
This night he meaneth with a corded ladder
To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window
Now presently I'll give her father notice
Of their disguising and pretended flight;
Who
For Thurio
But
By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.
Love
Exit
SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.
Enter JULIA and LUCETTA
Counsel
And even in kind love I do conjure thee
Are visibly character'd and engraved
How
A journey to my loving Proteus.
Alas
A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary
To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps;
Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly
Better forbear till Proteus make return.
O
Pity the dearth that I have pined in
Didst thou but know the inly touch of love
As seek to quench the fire of love with words.
I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire
The more thou damm'st it up
The current that with gentle murmur glides
But when his fair course is not hindered
He overtaketh in his pilgrimage
With willing sport to the wild ocean.
Then let me go and hinder not my course
I'll be as patient as a gentle stream
And make a pastime of each weary step
And there I'll rest
A blessed soul doth in Elysium.
But in what habit will you go along?
Not like a woman; for I would prevent
The loose encounters of lascivious men:
Gentle Lucetta
As may beseem some well-reputed page.
Why
No
With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots.
To be fantastic may become a youth
Of greater time than I shall show to be.
What fashion
That fits as well as 'Tell me
Why even what fashion thou best likest
You must needs have them with a codpiece
Out
A round hose
Lucetta
What thou thinkest meet and is most mannerly.
But tell me
For undertaking so unstaid a journey?
I fear me
If you think so
Nay
Then never dream on infamy
If Proteus like your journey when you come
I fear me
That is the least
A thousand oaths
And instances of infinite of love
Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.
All these are servants to deceitful men.
Base men
But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth
His words are bonds
Pray heaven he prove so
Now
To bear a hard opinion of his truth:
Only deserve my love by loving him;
And presently go with me to my chamber
All that is mine I leave at thy dispose
Only
Come
I am impatient of my tarriance.
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.
Enter DUKE
Sir Thurio
We have some secrets to confer about.
Exit THURIO
Now
My gracious lord
The law of friendship bids me to conceal;
But when I call to mind your gracious favours
Done to me
Which else no worldly good should draw from me.
Know
Myself am one made privy to the plot.
I know you have determined to bestow her
On Thurio
And should she thus be stol'n away from you
Thus
To cross my friend in his intended drift
Than
A pack of sorrows which would press you down
Proteus
Which to requite
This love of theirs myself have often seen
Sir Valentine her company and my court:
But fearing lest my jealous aim might err
And so unworthily disgrace the man
That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.
And
And thence she cannot be convey'd away.
Know
How he her chamber-window will ascend
And with a corded ladder fetch her down;
For which the youthful lover now is gone
And this way comes he with it presently;
Where
But
That my discovery be not aimed at;
For love of you
Upon mine honour
That I had any light from thee of this.
Adieu
Exit
Enter VALENTINE
Sir Valentine
Please it your grace
That stays to bear my letters to my friends
Be they of much import?
The tenor of them doth but signify
My health and happy being at your court.
Nay then
I am to break with thee of some affairs
That touch me near
'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought
To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.
I know it well
Were rich and honourable; besides
Is full of virtue
Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter:
Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?
No
Nor fearing me as if I were her father;
And
And
Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty
And turn her out to who will take her in:
Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower;
For me and my possessions she esteems not.
What would your Grace have me to do in this?
There is a lady in Verona here
Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy
And nought esteems my aged eloquence:
Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor--
For long agone I have forgot to court;
Besides
How and which way I may bestow myself
To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.
Win her with gifts
Dumb jewels often in their silent kind
More than quick words do move a woman's mind.
But she did scorn a present that I sent her.
A woman sometimes scorns what best contents her.
Send her another; never give her o'er;
For scorn at first makes after-love the more.
If she do frown
If she do chide
For why
Take no repulse
For 'get you gone
Flatter and praise
Though ne'er so black
That man that hath a tongue
But she I mean is promised by her friends
Unto a youthful gentleman of worth
Why
Ay
What lets but one may enter at her window?
Her chamber is aloft
Without apparent hazard of his life.
Why then
Now
When would you use it? pray
This very night; for Love is like a child
By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.
But
How shall I best convey the ladder thither?
It will be light
Under a cloak that is of any length.
A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?
Ay
Then let me see thy cloak:
I'll get me one of such another length.
Why
How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?
I pray thee
What letter is this same? What's here? 'To Silvia'!
And here an engine fit for my proceeding.
I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.
Reads
'My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly
O
My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them:
While I
I curse myself
What's here?
'Silvia
'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose.
Why
Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car
And with thy daring folly burn the world?
Wilt thou reach stars
Go
Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates
Thank me for this more than for all the favours
Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee.
But if thou linger in my territories
Longer than swiftest expedition
Will give thee time to leave our royal court
I ever bore my daughter or thyself.
Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse;
But
Exit
And why not death rather than living torment?
To die is to be banish'd from myself;
And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her
Is self from self: a deadly banishment!
What light is light
What joy is joy
Unless it be to think that she is by
And feed upon the shadow of perfection
Except I be by Silvia in the night
Unless I look on Silvia in the day
She is my essence
Foster'd
I fly not death
Tarry I here
But
Enter PROTEUS and LAUNCE
Run
Soho
What seest thou?
Him we go to find: there's not a hair on's head
but 'tis a Valentine.
Valentine?
No.
Who then? his spirit?
Neither.
What then?
Nothing.
Can nothing speak? Master
Who wouldst thou strike?
Nothing.
Villain
Why
Sirrah
My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news
Then in dumb silence will I bury mine
Is Silvia dead?
No
No Valentine
Hath she forsworn me?
No
No Valentine
What is your news?
Sir
That thou art banished--O
From hence
O
Doth Silvia know that I am banished?
Ay
Which
A sea of melting pearl
Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd;
With them
Wringing her hands
As if but now they waxed pale for woe:
But neither bended knees
But Valentine
Besides
No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st
Have some malignant power upon my life:
If so
Cease to lament for that thou canst not help
Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.
Here if thou stay
Besides
Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that
And manage it against despairing thoughts.
Thy letters may be here
Which
Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.
The time now serves not to expostulate:
Come
And
Of all that may concern thy love-affairs.
As thou lovest Silvia
I pray thee
Go
O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!
Exeunt VALENTINE and PROTEUS
I am but a fool
think my master is a kind of a knave: but that's
all one
that knows me to be in love; yet I am in love; but a
team of horse shall not pluck that from me; nor who
'tis I love; and yet 'tis a woman; but what woman
will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milkmaid; yet
'tis not a maid
a maid
wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel;
which is much in a bare Christian.
Pulling out a paper
Here is the cate-log of her condition.
'Imprimis: She can fetch and carry.' Why
can do no more: nay
carry; therefore is she better than a jade. 'Item:
She can milk;' look you
with clean hands.
Enter SPEED
How now
mastership?
With my master's ship? why
Well
news
The blackest news that ever thou heardest.
Why
Why
Let me read them.
Fie on thee
Thou liest; I can.
I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee?
Marry
O illiterate loiterer! it was the son of thy
grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.
Come
There; and St. Nicholas be thy speed!
[Reads]  'Imprimis: She can milk.'
Ay
'Item: She brews good ale.'
And thereof comes the proverb: 'Blessing of your
heart
'Item: She can sew.'
That's as much as to say
'Item: She can knit.'
What need a man care for a stock with a wench
she can knit him a stock?
'Item: She can wash and scour.'
A special virtue: for then she need not be washed
and scoured.
'Item: She can spin.'
Then may I set the world on wheels
spin for her living.
'Item: She hath many nameless virtues.'
That's as much as to say
'Here follow her vices.'
Close at the heels of her virtues.
'Item: She is not to be kissed fasting in respect
of her breath.'
Well
'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.'
That makes amends for her sour breath.
'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.'
It's no matter for that
'Item: She is slow in words.'
O villain
be slow in words is a woman's only virtue: I pray
thee
'Item: She is proud.'
Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy
be ta'en from her.
'Item: She hath no teeth.'
I care not for that neither
'Item: She is curst.'
Well
'Item: She will often praise her liquor.'
If her liquor be good
will; for good things should be praised.
'Item: She is too liberal.'
Of her tongue she cannot
is slow of; of her purse she shall not
I'll keep shut: now
that cannot I help. Well
'Item: She hath more hair than wit
than hairs
Stop there; I'll have her: she was mine
mine
Rehearse that once more.
'Item: She hath more hair than wit
More hair than wit? It may be; I'll prove it. The
cover of the salt hides the salt
is more than the salt; the hair that covers the wit
is more than the wit
less. What's next?
'And more faults than hairs
That's monstrous: O
'And more wealth than faults.'
Why
impossible
What then?
Why
for thee at the North-gate.
For me?
For thee! ay
better man than thee.
And must I go to him?
Thou must run to him
that going will scarce serve the turn.
Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love letters!
Exit
Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; an
unmannerly slave
secrets! I'll after
Exit
SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
Enter DUKE and THURIO
Sir Thurio
Since his exile she hath despised me most
This weak impress of love is as a figure
Trenched in ice
Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts
And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.
Enter PROTEUS
How now
According to our proclamation gone?
Gone
My daughter takes his going grievously.
A little time
So I believe; but Thurio thinks not so.
Proteus
For thou hast shown some sign of good desert--
Makes me the better to confer with thee.
Longer than I prove loyal to your grace
Let me not live to look upon your grace.
Thou know'st how willingly I would effect
The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.
I do
And also
How she opposes her against my will
She did
Ay
What might we do to make the girl forget
The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio?
The best way is to slander Valentine
With falsehood
Ay
Ay
Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken
By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.
Then you must undertake to slander him.
And that
'Tis an ill office for a gentleman
Where your good word cannot advantage him
Therefore the office is indifferent
You have prevail'd
By ought that I can speak in his dispraise
But say this weed her love from Valentine
Therefore
Which must be done by praising me as much
As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.
And
And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.
Upon this warrant shall you have access
Where you with Silvia may confer at large;
For she is lumpish
Where you may temper her by your persuasion
To hate young Valentine and love my friend.
As much as I can do
But you
You must lay lime to tangle her desires
By wailful sonnets
Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.
Ay
Say that upon the altar of her beauty
You sacrifice your tears
Write till your ink be dry
Moist it again
That may discover such integrity:
For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews
Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.
After your dire-lamenting elegies
With some sweet concert; to their instruments
Tune a deploring dump: the night's dead silence
Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.
This
This discipline shows thou hast been in love.
And thy advice this night I'll put in practise.
Therefore
To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music.
I have a sonnet that will serve the turn
To give the onset to thy good advice.
About it
We'll wait upon your grace till after supper
Even now about it! I will pardon you.
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.
Enter certain Outlaws
Fellows
If there be ten
Enter VALENTINE and SPEED
Stand
If not: we'll make you sit and rifle you.
Sir
That all the travellers do fear so much.
My friends
That's not so
Peace! we'll hear him.
Ay
Then know that I have little wealth to lose:
A man I am cross'd with adversity;
My riches are these poor habiliments
Whither travel you?
To Verona.
Whence came you?
From Milan.
Have you long sojourned there?
Some sixteen months
What
I was.
For what offence?
For that which now torments me to rehearse:
I kill'd a man
Bu t yet I slew him manfully in fight
Why
But were you banish'd for so small a fault?
I was
Have you the tongues?
My youthful travel therein made me happy
By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar
We'll have him. Sirs
Master
Peace
Tell us this: have you any thing to take to?
Nothing but my fortune.
Know
Thrust from the company of awful men:
Myself was from Verona banished
For practising to steal away a lady
And I from Mantua
And I for such like petty crimes as these
And partly
With goodly shape and by your own report
A linguist and a man of such perfection
As we do in our quality much want--
Indeed
Are you content to be our general?
To make a virtue of necessity
And live
What say'st thou? wilt thou be of our consort?
Say ay
We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee
But if thou scorn our courtesy
Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer'd.
I take your offer and will live with you
On silly women or poor passengers.
No
Come
Exeunt
SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace
Enter PROTEUS
Already have I been false to Valentine
And now I must be as unjust to Thurio.
Under the colour of commending him
But Silvia is too fair
When I protest true loyalty to her
When to her beauty I commend my vows
In breaking faith with Julia whom I loved:
And notwithstanding all her sudden quips
But here comes Thurio: now must we to her window
Enter THURIO and Musicians
How now
Ay
Will creep in service where it cannot go.
Ay
Sir
Who? Silvia?
Ay
I thank you for your own. Now
Enter
Now
pray you
Marry
Come
you shall hear music and see the gentleman that you asked for.
But shall I hear him speak?
Ay
That will be music.
Music plays
Hark
Is he among these?
Ay: but
SONG.
Who is Silvia? what is she
Holy
The heaven such grace did lend her
Is she kind as she is fair?
For beauty lives with kindness.
Love doth to her eyes repair
Then to Silvia let us sing
She excels each mortal thing
Upon the dull earth dwelling:
To her let us garlands bring.
How now! are you sadder than you were before? How
do you
You mistake; the musician likes me not.
Why
He plays false
How? out of tune on the strings?
Not so; but yet so false that he grieves my very
heart-strings.
You have a quick ear.
Ay
I perceive you delight not in music.
Not a whit
Hark
Ay
You would have them always play but one thing?
I would always have one play but one thing.
But
Often resort unto this gentlewoman?
I tell you what Launce
her out of all nick.
Where is Launce?
Gone to seek his dog; which tomorrow
master's command
Peace! stand aside: the company parts.
Sir Thurio
That you shall say my cunning drift excels.
Where meet we?
At Saint Gregory's well.
Farewell.
Exeunt THURIO and Musicians
Enter SILVIA above
Madam
I thank you for your music
Who is that that spake?
One
Sir Proteus
Sir Proteus
What's your will?
That I may compass yours.
You have your wish; my will is even this:
That presently you hie you home to bed.
Thou subtle
Think'st thou I am so shallow
Return
For me
That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit
Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.
I grant
But she is dead.
[Aside]        'Twere false
For I am sure she is not buried.
Say that she be; yet Valentine thy friend
Survives; to whom
To wrong him with thy importunacy?
I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.
And so suppose am I; for in his grave
Assure thyself my love is buried.
Sweet lady
Go to thy lady's grave and call hers thence
[Aside]  He heard not that.
Madam
To that I'll speak
For since the substance of your perfect self
Is else devoted
And to your shadow will I make true love.
[Aside]  If 'twere a substance
I am very loath to be your idol
But since your falsehood shall become you well
To worship shadows and adore false shapes
And so
As wretches have o'ernight
That wait for execution in the morn.
Exeunt PROTEUS and SILVIA severally
Host
By my halidom
Pray you
Marry
day.
Not so; but it hath been the longest night
That e'er I watch'd and the most heaviest.

SCENE III. The same.
Enter EGLAMOUR
This is the hour that Madam Silvia
Entreated me to call and know her mind:
There's some great matter she'ld employ me in.
Madam

Who calls?
Your servant and your friend;
One that attends your ladyship's command.
Sir Eglamour
As many

It is your pleasure to command me in.
O Eglamour
Think not I flatter
Valiant
Thou art not ignorant what dear good will
I bear unto the banish'd Valentine
Vain Thurio
Thyself hast loved; and I have heard thee say
No grief did ever come so near thy heart
As when thy lady and thy true love died
Sir Eglamour
And
Urge not my father's anger
I do desire thee
As full of sorrows as the sea of sands
If not
Madam
Which since I know they virtuously are placed
As much I wish all good befortune you.
When will you go?
This evening coming.
Where shall I meet you?
At Friar Patrick's cell
I will not fail your ladyship. Good morrow
Good morrow
Exeunt severally
SCENE IV. The same.
Enter LAUNCE
When a man's servant shall play the cur with him
puppy; one that I saved from drowning
four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it.
I have taught him
him as a present to Mistress Silvia from my master;
and I came no sooner into the dining-chamber but he
steps me to her trencher and steals her capon's leg:
O
in all companies! I would have
more wit than he
live
thrusts me himself into the company of three or four
gentlemanlike dogs under the duke's table: he had
not been there--bless the mark!--a pissing while
all the chamber smelt him. 'Out with the dog!' says
one: 'What cur is that?' says another: 'Whip him
out' says the third: 'Hang him up' says the duke.
I
whips the dogs: 'Friend
the dog?' 'Ay
the more wrong
wot of.' He makes me no more ado
of the chamber. How many masters would do this for
his servant? Nay
stocks for puddings he hath stolen
been executed; I have stood on the pillory for geese
he hath killed
Thou thinkest not of this now. Nay
trick you served me when I took my leave of Madam
Silvia: did not I bid thee still mark me and do as I
do? when didst thou see me heave up my leg and make
water against a gentlewoman's farthingale? didst
thou ever see me do such a trick?
Enter PROTEUS and JULIA
Sebastian is thy name? I like thee well
And will employ thee in some service presently.
In what you please: I'll do what I can.
I hope thou wilt.
To LAUNCE
How now

currish thanks is good enough for such a present.

A slave
Sebastian
That can with some discretion do my business
Therefore know thou
Go presently and take this ring with thee
She loved me well deliver'd it to me.
It seems you loved not her
She is dead
Not so; I think she lives.
Alas!
Why dost thou cry 'alas'?
I cannot choose
But pity her.
Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?
Because methinks that she loved you as well
As you do love your lady Silvia:
She dreams of him that has forgot her love;
You dote on her that cares not for your love.
'Tis pity love should be so contrary;
And thinking of it makes me cry 'alas!'
Well
This letter. That's her chamber. Tell my lady
I claim the promise for her heavenly picture.
Your message done
Exit
How many women would do such a message?
Alas
A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs.
Alas
That with his very heart despiseth me?
Because he loves her
Because I love him I must pity him.
This ring I gave him when he parted from me
And now am I
I am my master's true-confirmed love;
But cannot be true servant to my master
Yet will I woo for him
As
Enter SILVIA
Gentlewoman
To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.
What would you with her
If you be she
To hear me speak the message I am sent on.
From whom?
From my master
O
Ay
Ursula
Go give your master this: tell him from me
Madam
Pardon me
Deliver'd you a paper that I should not:
This is the letter to your ladyship.
I pray thee
It may not be; good madam
There
I will not look upon your master's lines:
I know they are stuff'd with protestations
And full of new-found oaths; which he will break
As easily as I do tear his paper.
Madam
The more shame for him that he sends it me;
For I have heard him say a thousand times
His Julia gave it him at his departure.
Though his false finger have profaned the ring
She thanks you.
What say'st thou?
I thank you
Poor gentlewoman! my master wrongs her much.
Dost thou know her?
Almost as well as I do know myself:
To think upon her woes I do protest
That I have wept a hundred several times.
Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her.
I think she doth; and that's her cause of sorrow.
Is she not passing fair?
She hath been fairer
When she did think my master loved her well
But since she did neglect her looking-glass
And threw her sun-expelling mask away
And pinch'd the lily-tincture of her face
How tall was she?
About my stature; for at Pentecost
Therefore I know she is about my height.
And at that time I made her weep agood
Madam
For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight;
Which I so lively acted with my tears
That my poor mistress
If I in thought felt not her very sorrow!
She is beholding to thee
Alas
I weep myself to think upon thy words.
Here
For thy sweet mistress' sake
Farewell.
Exit SILVIA
And she shall thank you for't
A virtuous gentlewoman
I hope my master's suit will be but cold
Alas
Here is her picture: let me see; I think
Were full as lovely as is this of hers:
And yet the painter flatter'd her a little
Her hair is auburn
If that be all the difference in his love
Her eyes are grey as glass
Ay
What should it be that he respects in her
But I can make respective in myself
Come
And
I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake
To make my master out of love with thee!
Exit
ACT V
SCENE I. Milan. An abbey.
Enter EGLAMOUR
The sun begins to gild the western sky;
And now it is about the very hour
That Silvia
She will not fail
So much they spur their expedition.
See where she comes.
Enter SILVIA
Lady
Amen
I fear I am attended by some spies.
Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;
If we recover that
Exeunt
SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.
Enter THURIO
Sir Proteus
O
And yet she takes exceptions at your person.
What
No; that it is too little.
I'll wear a boot
[Aside]  But love will not be spurr'd to what
it loathes.
What says she to my face?
She says it is a fair one.
Nay then
But pearls are fair; and the old saying is
[Aside]  'Tis true; such pearls as put out
ladies' eyes;
For I had rather wink than look on them.
How likes she my discourse?
Ill
But well
[Aside]  But better
What says she to my valour?
O
[Aside]  She needs not
What says she to my birth?
That you are well derived.
[Aside]  True; from a gentleman to a fool.
Considers she my possessions?
O
Wherefore?
[Aside]  That such an ass should owe them.
That they are out by lease.
Here comes the duke.
Enter DUKE
How now
Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?
Not I.
Nor I.
Saw you my daughter?
Neither.
Why then
And Eglamour is in her company.
'Tis true; for Friar Laurence met them both
Him he knew well
Besides
At Patrick's cell this even; and there she was not;
These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence.
Therefore
Upon the rising of the mountain-foot
That leads towards Mantua
Dispatch
Exit
Why
I'll after
Than for the love of reckless Silvia.
Exit
And I will follow
Than hate of Eglamour that goes with her.
Exit
And I will follow
Than hate for Silvia that is gone for love.
Exit
SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.
Enter Outlaws with SILVIA
Come
A thousand more mischances than this one
Have learn'd me how to brook this patiently.
Come
Where is the gentleman that was with her?
Being nimble-footed
Go thou with her to the west end of the wood;
There is our captain: we'll follow him that's fled;
The thicket is beset; he cannot 'scape.
Come
Fear not; he bears an honourable mind
O Valentine
Exeunt
SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.
Enter VALENTINE
How use doth breed a habit in a man!
This shadowy desert
Here can I sit alone
Tune my distresses and record my woes.
O thou that dost inhabit in my breast
And leave no memory of what it was!
Repair me with thy presence
Thou gentle nymph
What halloing and what stir is this to-day?
These are my mates
They love me well; yet I have much to do
To keep them from uncivil outrages.
Withdraw thee
Enter PROTEUS
Madam
That would have forced your honour and your love;
Vouchsafe me
A smaller boon than this I cannot beg
And less than this
[Aside]  How like a dream is this I see and hear!
Love
O miserable
Unhappy were you
But by my coming I have made you happy.
By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.
[Aside]  And me
Had I been seized by a hungry lion
O
And full as much
Therefore be gone; solicit me no more.
What dangerous action
O
When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved.
Read over Julia's heart
Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths
Descended into perjury
Thou hast no faith left now
And that's far worse than none; better have none
Than plural faith which is too much by one:
Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!
In love
Who respects friend?
All men but Proteus.
Nay
Can no way change you to a milder form
O heaven!
I'll force thee yield to my desire.
Ruffian
Valentine!
Thou common friend
Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye
Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say
I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me.
Who should be trusted
Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus
The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst
My shame and guilt confounds me.
Forgive me
Be a sufficient ransom for offence
As e'er I did commit.
Then I am paid;
And once again I do receive thee honest.
Who by repentance is not satisfied
Is nor of heaven nor earth
By penitence the Eternal's wrath's appeased:
And
O me unhappy!
Swoons
Look to the boy.
Why
Look up; speak.
O good sir
to Madam Silvia
Where is that ring
Here 'tis; this is it.
How! let me see:
Why
O
This is the ring you sent to Silvia.
But how camest thou by this ring? At my depart
I gave this unto Julia.
And Julia herself did give it me;
And Julia herself hath brought it hither.
How! Julia!
Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths
How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root!
O Proteus
Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me
Such an immodest raiment
In a disguise of love:
It is the lesser blot
Than men their minds! 'tis true.
O heaven! were man
But constant
Fills him with faults; makes him run through all the sins:
Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.
What is in Silvia's face
More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?
Come
Let me be blest to make this happy close;
'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.
Bear witness
And I mine.
Enter Outlaws
A prize
Forbear
Your grace is welcome to a man disgraced
Sir Valentine!
Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia's mine.
Thurio
Come not within the measure of my wrath;
Do not name Silvia thine; if once again
Take but possession of her with a touch:
I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.
Sir Valentine
I hold him but a fool that will endanger
His body for a girl that loves him not:
I claim her not
The more degenerate and base art thou
And leave her on such slight conditions.
Now
Know then
Take thou thy Silvia
I thank your grace; the gift hath made me happy.
I now beseech you
I grant it
These banish'd men that I have kept withal
Are men endued with worthy qualities:
Forgive them what they have committed here
And let them be recall'd from their exile:
They are reformed
And fit for great employment
Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them and thee:
Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.
Come
With triumphs
And
With our discourse to make your grace to smile.
What think you of this page
I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.
I warrant you
What mean you by that saying?
Please you
Come
The story of your loves discovered:
That done
One feast
Exeunt
ACT I
SCENE I. Antechamber in LEONTES' palace.
Enter CAMILLO and ARCHIDAMUS
If you shall chance
the like occasion whereon my services are now on
foot
difference betwixt our Bohemia and your Sicilia.
I think
means to pay Bohemia the visitation which he justly owes him.
Wherein our entertainment shall shame us we will be
justified in our loves; for indeed--
Beseech you
Verily
we cannot with such magnificence--in so rare--I know
not what to say. We will give you sleepy drinks
us.
You pay a great deal too dear for what's given freely.
Believe me
and as mine honesty puts it to utterance.
Sicilia cannot show himself over-kind to Bohemia.
They were trained together in their childhoods; and
there rooted betwixt them then such an affection
more mature dignities and royal necessities made
separation of their society
with interchange of gifts
embassies; that they have seemed to be together
embraced
winds. The heavens continue their loves!
I think there is not in the world either malice or
matter to alter it. You have an unspeakable
comfort of your young prince Mamillius: it is a
gentleman of the greatest promise that ever came
into my note.
I very well agree with you in the hopes of him: it
is a gallant child; one that indeed physics the
subject
crutches ere he was born desire yet their life to
see him a man.
Would they else be content to die?
Yes; if there were no other excuse why they should
desire to live.
If the king had no son
on crutches till he had one.
Exeunt
SCENE II. A room of state in the same.
Enter LEONTES
Nine changes of the watery star hath been
The shepherd's note since we have left our throne
Without a burthen: time as long again
Would be find up
And yet we should
With one 'We thank you' many thousands moe
That go before it.
Stay your thanks a while;
And pay them when you part.
Sir
I am question'd by my fears
Or breed upon our absence; that may blow
No sneaping winds at home
'This is put forth too truly:' besides
To tire your royalty.
We are tougher
No longer stay.
One seven-night longer.
Very sooth
We'll part the time between's then; and in that
I'll no gainsaying.
Press me not
There is no tongue that moves
'Twere needful I denied it. My affairs
Do even drag me homeward: which to hinder
Were in your love a whip to me; my stay
To you a charge and trouble: to save both
Tongue-tied
speak you.
I had thought
You have drawn oaths from him not to stay. You
All in Bohemia's well; this satisfaction
The by-gone day proclaim'd: say this to him
Well said
To tell
But let him say so then
But let him swear so
Yet of your royal presence I'll adventure
The borrow of a week. When at Bohemia
You take my lord
To let him there a month behind the gest
Prefix'd for's parting: yet
What lady-she her lord. You'll stay?
No
Nay
I may not
Verily!
You put me off with limber vows; but I
stars with oaths
As potent as a lord's. Will you go yet?
Force me to keep you as a prisoner
When you depart
My prisoner? or my guest? by your dread 'Verily
One of them you shall be.
Your guest
To be your prisoner should import offending;
Which is for me less easy to commit
Than you to punish.
Not your gaoler
Of my lord's tricks and yours when you were boys:
You were pretty lordings then?
We were
But such a day to-morrow as to-day
Was not my lord
The verier wag o' the two?
We were as twinn'd lambs that did frisk i' the sun
Was innocence for innocence; we knew not
The doctrine of ill-doing
That any did. Had we pursued that life
With stronger blood
Boldly 'not guilty;' the imposition clear'd
Hereditary ours.
By this we gather
You have tripp'd since.
O my most sacred lady!
Temptations have since then been born to's; for
In those unfledged days was my wife a girl;
Your precious self had then not cross'd the eyes
Of my young play-fellow.
Grace to boot!
Of this make no conclusion
Your queen and I are devils: yet go on;
The offences we have made you do we'll answer
You did continue fault and that you slipp'd not
With any but with us.
Is he won yet?
He'll stay my lord.
At my request he would not.
Hermione
To better purpose.
Never?
Never
What! have I twice said well? when was't before?
I prithee tell me; cram's with praise
As fat as tame things: one good deed dying tongueless
Slaughters a thousand waiting upon that.
Our praises are our wages: you may ride's
With one soft kiss a thousand furlongs ere
With spur we beat an acre. But to the goal:
My last good deed was to entreat his stay:
What was my first? it has an elder sister
But once before I spoke to the purpose: when?
Nay
Why
Three crabbed months had sour'd themselves to death
And clap thyself my love: then didst thou utter
'I am yours for ever.'
'Tis grace indeed.
Why
The one for ever earn'd a royal husband;
The other for some while a friend.
"[Aside]	Too hot"
To mingle friendship far is mingling bloods.
I have tremor cordis on me: my heart dances;
But not for joy; not joy. This entertainment
May a free face put on
From heartiness
But to be paddling palms and pinching fingers
The mort o' the deer; O
My bosom likes not
Ay
I' fecks!
Why
smutch'd thy nose?
They say it is a copy out of mine. Come
And yet the steer
Are all call'd neat.--Still virginalling
Upon his palm!--How now
Art thou my calf?
Yes
Thou want'st a rough pash and the shoots that I have
Almost as like as eggs; women say so
As o'er-dyed blacks
As dice are to be wish'd by one that fixes
No bourn 'twixt his and mine
To say this boy were like me. Come
Most dear'st! my collop! Can thy dam?--may't be?--
Affection! thy intention stabs the centre:
Thou dost make possible things not so held
With what's unreal thou coactive art
Thou mayst co-join with something; and thou dost
And hardening of my brows.
What means Sicilia?
He something seems unsettled.
How
What cheer? how is't with you
You look as if you held a brow of much distraction
Are you moved
No
How sometimes nature will betray its folly
To harder bosoms! Looking on the lines
Of my boy's face
Twenty-three years
How like
No
You will! why
Do seem to be of ours?
If at home
He makes a July's day short as December
Thoughts that would thick my blood.
So stands this squire
Officed with me: we two will walk
Let what is dear in Sicily be cheap:
Next to thyself and my young rover
Apparent to my heart.
If you would seek us
To your own bents dispose you: you'll be found
Aside
I am angling now
Go to
How she holds up the neb
And arms her with the boldness of a wife
To her allowing husband!
Exeunt POLIXENES
Gone already!
Inch-thick
ears a fork'd one!
Go
Play too
Will hiss me to my grave: contempt and clamour
Will be my knell. Go
There have been
And many a man there is
And his pond fish'd by his next neighbour
Sir Smile
Whiles other men have gates and those gates open'd
That have revolted wives
Would hang themselves. Physic for't there is none;
It is a bawdy planet
Where 'tis predominant; and 'tis powerful
It will let in and out the enemy
With bag and baggage: many thousand on's
Have the disease
I am like you
Why that's some comfort. What
Ay
Go play
Exit MAMILLIUS
Camillo
You had much ado to make his anchor hold:
When you cast out
Didst note it?
He would not stay at your petitions: made
His business more material.
Didst perceive it?
Aside
They're here with me already
'Sicilia is a so-forth:' 'tis far gone
At the good queen's entreaty.
At the queen's be't: 'good' should be pertinent
But
By any understanding pate but thine?
For thy conceit is soaking
More than the common blocks: not noted
Of head-piece extraordinary? lower messes
Perchance are to this business purblind? say.
Business
Bohemia stays here longer.
Ha!
Stays here longer.
Ay
To satisfy your highness and the entreaties
Of our most gracious mistress.
Satisfy!
The entreaties of your mistress! satisfy!
Let that suffice. I have trusted thee
My chamber-councils
Hast cleansed my bosom
Thy penitent reform'd: but we have been
Deceived in thy integrity
In that which seems so.
Be it forbid
To bide upon't
From course required; or else thou must be counted
A servant grafted in my serious trust
And therein negligent; or else a fool
That seest a game play'd home
My gracious lord
In every one of these no man is free
I play'd the fool
To do a thing
Against the non-performance
Which oft infects the wisest: these
Is never free of. But
By its own visage: if I then deny it
Ha' not you seen
But that's past doubt
Is thicker than a cuckold's horn
For to a vision so apparent rumour
Cannot be mute
Resides not in that man that does not think
My wife is slippery? If thou wilt confess
My wife's a hobby-horse
As rank as any flax-wench that puts to
Before her troth-plight: say't and justify't.
I would not be a stander-by to hear
My sovereign mistress clouded so
My present vengeance taken: 'shrew my heart
Than this; which to reiterate were sin
As deep as that
Is whispering nothing?
Is leaning cheek to cheek? is meeting noses?
Kissing with inside lip? stopping the career
Of laughing with a sigh?--a note infallible
Of breaking honesty--horsing foot on foot?
Skulking in corners? wishing clocks more swift?
Hours
Blind with the pin and web but theirs
Why
The covering sky is nothing; Bohemia nothing;
My wife is nothing; nor nothing have these nothings
Good my lord
Of this diseased opinion
For 'tis most dangerous.
Say it be
No
It is; you lie
I say thou liest
Canst with thine eyes at once see good and evil
Infected as her life
The running of one glass.
Who does infect her?
Why
About his neck
Had servants true about me
To see alike mine honour as their profits
Which should undo more doing: ay
Have benched and reared to worship
Plainly as heaven sees earth and earth sees heaven
Which draught to me were cordial.
Sir
Maliciously like poison: but I cannot
Believe this crack to be in my dread mistress
I have loved thee
Make that thy question
Dost think I am so muddy
The purity and whiteness of my sheets
Is goads
Could man so blench?
I must believe you
I do; and will fetch off Bohemia for't;
Provided that
Will take again your queen as yours at first
The injury of tongues in courts and kingdoms
Known and allied to yours.
Thou dost advise me
Even so as I mine own course have set down:
I'll give no blemish to her honour
My lord
As friendship wears at feasts
And with your queen. I am his cupbearer:
If from me he have wholesome beverage
This is all:
Do't and thou hast the one half of my heart;
Do't not
I'll do't
I will seem friendly
Exit
O miserable lady! But
Of good Polixenes; and my ground to do't
Is the obedience to a master
Who in rebellion with himself will have
All that are his so too. To do this deed
Of thousands that had struck anointed kings
And flourish'd after
Nor brass nor stone nor parchment bears not one
Forsake the court: to do't
To me a break-neck. Happy star
Here comes Bohemia.
Re-enter POLIXENES
This is strange: methinks
My favour here begins to warp. Not speak?
Good day
Hail
What is the news i' the court?
None rare
The king hath on him such a countenance
As he had lost some province and a region
Loved as he loves himself: even now I met him
With customary compliment; when he
A lip of much contempt
So leaves me to consider what is breeding
That changeth thus his manners.
I dare not know
How! dare not! do not. Do you know
Be intelligent to me: 'tis thereabouts;
For
And cannot say
Which shows me mine changed too; for I must be
A party in this alteration
Myself thus alter'd with 't.
There is a sickness
Which puts some of us in distemper
I cannot name the disease; and it is caught
Of you that yet are well.
How! caught of me!
Make me not sighted like the basilisk:
I have look'd on thousands
By my regard
As you are certainly a gentleman
Clerk-like experienced
Our gentry than our parents' noble names
Thereof to be inform'd
In ignorant concealment.
I may not answer.
A sickness caught of me
I must be answer'd. Dost thou hear
Which honour does acknowledge
Is not this suit of mine
What incidency thou dost guess of harm
Is creeping toward me; how far off
Which way to be prevented
If not
Sir
Since I am charged in honour and by him
That I think honourable: therefore mark my counsel
I mean to utter it
Cry lost
On
I am appointed him to murder you.
By whom
By the king.
For what?
He thinks
To vice you to't
Forbiddenly.
O
To an infected jelly and my name
Be yoked with his that did betray the Best!
Turn then my freshest reputation to
A savour that may strike the dullest nostril
Where I arrive
That e'er was heard or read!
Swear his thought over
By each particular star in heaven and
By all their influences
Forbid the sea for to obey the moon
As or by oath remove or counsel shake
The fabric of his folly
Is piled upon his faith and will continue
The standing of his body.
How should this grow?
I know not: but I am sure 'tis safer to
Avoid what's grown than question how 'tis born.
If therefore you dare trust my honesty
Shall bear along impawn'd
Your followers I will whisper to the business
Clear them o' the city. For myself
My fortunes to your service
By this discovery lost. Be not uncertain;
For
Have utter'd truth: which if you seek to prove
Than one condemn'd by the king's own mouth
His execution sworn.
I do believe thee:
I saw his heart in 's face. Give me thy hand:
Be pilot to me and thy places shall
Still neighbour mine. My ships are ready and
My people did expect my hence departure
Two days ago. This jealousy
Is for a precious creature: as she's rare
He is dishonour'd by a man which ever
Profess'd to him
In that be made more bitter. Fear o'ershades me:
Good expedition be my friend
The gracious queen
Of his ill-ta'en suspicion! Come
I will respect thee as a father if
Thou bear'st my life off hence: let us avoid.
It is in mine authority to command
The keys of all the posterns: please your highness
To take the urgent hour. Come
Exeunt
ACT II
SCENE I. A room in LEONTES' palace.
Enter HERMIONE
Take the boy to you: he so troubles me
Come
No
Why
You'll kiss me hard and speak to me as if
I were a baby still. I love you better.
And why so
Not for because
Your brows are blacker; yet black brows
Too much hair there
Or a half-moon made with a pen.
Who taught you this?
I learnt it out of women's faces. Pray now
What colour are your eyebrows?
Blue
Nay
That has been blue
Hark ye;
The queen your mother rounds apace: we shall
Present our services to a fine new prince
One of these days; and then you'ld wanton with us
She is spread of late
Into a goodly bulk: good time encounter her!
What wisdom stirs amongst you? Come
I am for you again: pray you
Merry or sad shall't be?
As merry as you will.
A sad tale's best for winter: I have one
Of sprites and goblins.
Let's have that
Come on
To fright me with your sprites; you're powerful at it.
There was a man--
Nay
Dwelt by a churchyard: I will tell it softly;
Yond crickets shall not hear it.
Come on
Enter LEONTES
Was he met there? his train? Camillo with him?
Behind the tuft of pines I met them; never
Saw I men scour so on their way: I eyed them
Even to their ships.
How blest am I
In my just censure
Alack
In being so blest! There may be in the cup
A spider steep'd
Is not infected: but if one present
The abhorr'd ingredient to his eye
How he hath drunk
Camillo was his help in this
There is a plot against my life
All's true that is mistrusted: that false villain
Whom I employ'd was pre-employ'd by him:
He has discover'd my design
Remain a pinch'd thing; yea
For them to play at will. How came the posterns
So easily open?
By his great authority;
Which often hath no less prevail'd than so
On your command.
I know't too well.
Give me the boy: I am glad you did not nurse him:
Though he does bear some signs of me
Have too much blood in him.
What is this? sport?
Bear the boy hence; he shall not come about her;
Away with him! and let her sport herself
With that she's big with; for 'tis Polixenes
Has made thee swell thus.
But I'ld say he had not
You
To say 'she is a goodly lady
The justice of your bearts will thereto add
'Tis pity she's not honest
Praise her but for this her without-door form
The shrug
That calumny doth use--O
That mercy does
Virtue itself: these shrugs
Ere you can say 'she's honest:' but be 't known
Should a villain say so
You have mistook
Which I'll not call a creature of thy place
And mannerly distinguishment leave out
Betwixt the prince and beggar: I have said
She's an adulteress; I have said with whom:
More
A federary with her
What she should shame to know herself
But with her most vile principal
A bed-swerver
That vulgars give bold'st titles
To this their late escape.
No
Privy to none of this. How will this grieve you
You thus have publish'd me! Gentle my lord
You did mistake.
No; if I mistake
In those foundations which I build upon
A school-boy's top. Away with her! to prison!
He who shall speak for her is afar off guilty
But that he speaks.
There's some ill planet reigns:
I must be patient till the heavens look
With an aspect more favourable. Good my lords
Commonly are; the want of which vain dew
Perchance shall dry your pities: but I have
That honourable grief lodged here which burns
Worse than tears drown: beseech you all
Shall best instruct you
The king's will be perform'd!
Shall I be heard?
Who is't that goes with me? Beseech your highness
My plight requires it. Do not weep
There is no cause: when you shall know your mistress
Has deserved prison
As I come out: this action I now go on
Is for my better grace. Adieu
I never wish'd to see you sorry; now
I trust I shall. My women
Go
Exit HERMIONE
Beseech your highness
Be certain what you do
Prove violence; in the which three great ones suffer
For her
I' the eyes of heaven and to you; I mean
If it prove
She's otherwise
I lodge my wife; I'll go in couples with her;
Than when I feel and see her no farther trust her;
For every inch of woman in the world
Hold your peaces.
Good my lord
It is for you we speak
You are abused and by some putter-on
That will be damn'd for't; would I knew the villain
The second and the third
If this prove true
by mine honour
And I had rather glib myself than they
Should not produce fair issue.
Cease; no more.
You smell this business with a sense as cold
As is a dead man's nose: but I do see't and feel't
As you feel doing thus; and see withal
The instruments that feel.
If it be so
There's not a grain of it the face to sweeten
Of the whole dungy earth.
What! lack I credit?
I had rather you did lack than I
To have her honour true than your suspicion
Why
Commune with you of this
Our forceful instigation? Our prerogative
Calls not your counsels
Imparts this; which if you
Or seeming so in skill
Relish a truth like us
We need no more of your advice: the matter
Properly ours.
And I wish
How could that be?
Either thou art most ignorant by age
But only seeing
Made up to the deed
Yet
Most piteous to be wild
To sacred Delphos
Of stuff'd sufficiency: now from the oracle
They will bring all; whose spiritual counsel had
Well done
Though I am satisfied and need no more
Than what I know
Give rest to the minds of others
Whose ignorant credulity will not
Come up to the truth. So have we thought it good
From our free person she should be confined
Be left her to perform. Come
We are to speak in public; for this business
Will raise us all.
[Aside]
To laughter
Exeunt
SCENE II. A prison.
Enter PAULINA
The keeper of the prison
let him have knowledge who I am.
Exit Gentleman
Good lady
What dost thou then in prison?
Re-enter Gentleman
Now
For a worthy lady
And one whom much I honour.
Pray you then
I may not
To the contrary I have express commandment.
Here's ado
The access of gentle visitors!
Is't lawful
So please you
Shall bring Emilia forth.
I pray now
Withdraw yourselves.
Exeunt Gentleman and Attendants
And
Well
Exit Gaoler
Here's such ado to make no stain a stain
As passes colouring.
Re-enter Gaoler
Dear gentlewoman
As well as one so great and so forlorn
May hold together: on her frights and griefs
A boy?
A daughter
Much comfort in't; says 'My poor prisoner
I dare be sworn
These dangerous unsafe lunes i' the king
He must be told on't
Becomes a woman best; I'll take't upon me:
If I prove honey-mouth'd let my tongue blister
And never to my red-look'd anger be
The trumpet any more. Pray you
If she dares trust me with her little babe
Her advocate to the loud'st. We do not know
How he may soften at the sight o' the child:
The silence often of pure innocence
Persuades when speaking fails.
Most worthy madam
That your free undertaking cannot miss
A thriving issue: there is no lady living
So meet for this great errand. Please your ladyship
To visit the next room
Acquaint the queen of your most noble offer;
Who  but to-day hammer'd of this design
Tell her
I'll use that tongue I have: if wit flow from't
As boldness from my bosom
I shall do good.
Now be you blest for it!
I'll to the queen: please you
Madam
You need not fear it
This child was prisoner to the womb and is
By law and process of great nature thence
Freed and enfranchised
The anger of the king nor guilty of
I do believe it.
Do not you fear: upon mine honour
Exeunt
SCENE III. A room in LEONTES' palace.
Enter LEONTES
Nor night nor day no rest: it is but weakness
To bear the matter thus; mere weakness. If
The cause were not in being
Is quite beyond mine arm
And level of my brain
I can hook to me: say that she were gone
Might come to me again. Who's there?
My lord?
How does the boy?
He took good rest to-night;
'Tis hoped his sickness is discharged.
To see his nobleness!
Conceiving the dishonour of his mother
Exit Servant
Fie
The thought of my revenges that way
Recoil upon me: in himself too mighty
Until a time may serve: for present vengeance
Laugh at me
They should not laugh if I could reach them
Shall she within my power.
Enter PAULINA
You must not enter.
Nay
Fear you his tyrannous passion more
That's enough.
Madam
None should come at him.
Not so hot
I come to bring him sleep. 'Tis such as you
At each his needless heavings
Nourish the cause of his awaking: I
Do come with words as medicinal as true
That presses him from sleep.
What noise there
No noise
About some gossips for your highness.
How!
Away with that audacious lady! Antigonus
I knew she would.
I told her so
What
From all dishonesty he can: in this
La you now
When she will take the rein I let her run;
But she'll not stumble.
Good my liege
And
Myself your loyal servant
Less appear so in comforting your evils
From your good queen.
Good queen!
Good queen
And would by combat make her good
A man
Force her hence.
Let him that makes but trifles of his eyes
First hand me: on mine own accord I'll off;
But first I'll do my errand. The good queen
Here 'tis; commends it to your blessing.
Laying down the child
Out!
A mankind witch! Hence with her
A most intelligencing bawd!
Not so:
I am as ignorant in that as you
In so entitling me
Than you are mad; which is enough
Traitors!
Will you not push her out? Give her the bastard.
Thou dotard! thou art woman-tired
By thy dame Partlet here. Take up the bastard;
Take't up
For ever
Unvenerable be thy hands
Takest up the princess by that forced baseness
Which he has put upon't!
He dreads his wife.
So I would you did; then 'twere past all doubt
You'ld call your children yours.
A nest of traitors!
I am none
Nor I
But one that's here
The sacred honour of himself
and will not--
For
He cannot be compell'd to't--once remove
The root of his opinion
As ever oak or stone was sound.
A callat
Of boundless tongue
And now baits me! This brat is none of mine;
It is the issue of Polixenes:
Hence with it
Commit them to the fire!
It is yours;
And
And copy of the father
And thou
So like to him that got it
The ordering of the mind too
No yellow in't
A gross hag
And
Hang all the husbands
That cannot do that feat
Hardly one subject.
Once more
A most unworthy and unnatural lord
Can do no more.
I'll ha' thee burnt.
I care not:
It is an heretic that makes the fire
But this most cruel usage of your queen
Than your own weak-hinged fancy
Of tyranny and will ignoble make you
On your allegiance
I pray you
Look to your babe
Jove send her
A better guiding spirit! What needs these hands?
You
So
Exit
Thou
My child? away with't! Even thou
A heart so tender o'er it
And see it instantly consumed with fire;
Even thou and none but thou. Take it up straight:
Within this hour bring me word 'tis done
And wilt encounter with my wrath
The bastard brains with these my proper hands
Shall I dash out. Go
For thou set'st on thy wife.
I did not
These lords
We can: my royal liege
You're liars all.
Beseech your highness
We have always truly served you
So to esteem of us
Past and to come
Lead on to some foul issue: we all kneel.
I am a feather for each wind that blows:
Shall I live on to see this bastard kneel
And call me father? better burn it now
Than curse it then. But be it; let it live.
It shall not neither. You
You that have been so tenderly officious
With Lady Margery
To save this brat's life?
Any thing
And nobleness impose: at least thus much:
I'll pawn the little blood which I have left
To save the innocent: any thing possible.
It shall be possible. Swear by this sword
Thou wilt perform my bidding.
I will
Mark and perform it
Of any point in't shall not only be
Death to thyself but to thy lewd-tongued wife
This female bastard hence and that thou bear it
To some remote and desert place quite out
Of our dominions
And favour of the climate. As by strange fortune
It came to us
Where chance may nurse or end it. Take it up.
I swear to do this
Had been more merciful. Come on
Some powerful spirit instruct the kites and ravens
To be thy nurses! Wolves and bears
Casting their savageness aside have done
Like offices of pity. Sir
In more than this deed does require! And blessing
Against this cruelty fight on thy side
Exit with the child
No
Another's issue.
Enter a Servant
Please your highness
From those you sent to the oracle are come
An hour since: Cleomenes and Dion
So please you
Hath been beyond account.
Twenty-three days
They have been absent: 'tis good speed; foretells
The great Apollo suddenly will have
The truth of this appear. Prepare you
Summon a session
Our most disloyal lady
Been publicly accused
A just and open trial. While she lives
My heart will be a burthen to me. Leave me
Exeunt
ACT III
SCENE I. A sea-port in Sicilia.
Enter CLEOMENES and DION
The climate's delicate
The common praise it bears.
I shall report
Of the grave wearers. O
How ceremonious
It was i' the offering!
But of all
And the ear-deafening voice o' the oracle
That I was nothing.
If the event o' the journey
Prove as successful to the queen
As it hath been to us rare
Great Apollo
Turn all to the best! These proclamations
The violent carriage of it
Will clear or end the business: when the oracle
Even then will rush to knowledge. Go: fresh horses!
And gracious be the issue!
Exeunt
SCENE II. A court of Justice.
Enter LEONTES
This sessions
The daughter of a king
Of us too much beloved. Let us be clear'd
Of being tyrannous
Proceed in justice
Produce the prisoner.
It is his highness' pleasure that the queen
Appear in person here in court. Silence!
Enter HERMIONE guarded; PAULINA and Ladies attending
Read the indictment.
[Reads]            Hermione
Leontes
arraigned of high treason
with Polixenes
with Camillo to take away the life of our sovereign
lord the king
whereof being by circumstances partly laid open
of a true subject
their better safety
Since what I am to say must be but that
Which contradicts my accusation and
The testimony on my part no other
But what comes from myself
To say 'not guilty:' mine integrity
Being counted falsehood
Behold our human actions
False accusation blush and tyranny
Tremble at patience. You
Hath been as continent
Than history can pattern
And play'd to take spectators. For behold me
A fellow of the royal bed
A moiety of the throne a great king's daughter
To prate and talk for life and honour 'fore
Who please to come and hear. For life
As I weigh grief
To your own conscience
Came to your court
Have strain'd to appear thus: if one jot beyond
The bound of honour
That way inclining
Of all that hear me
Cry fie upon my grave!
I ne'er heard yet
That any of these bolder vices wanted
Less impudence to gainsay what they did
Than to perform it first.
That's true enough;
Through 'tis a saying
You will not own it.
More than mistress of
Which comes to me in name of fault
At all acknowledge. For Polixenes
I loved him as in honour he required
A lady like me
Which not to have done I think had been in me
Both disobedience and ingratitude
To you and toward your friend
That it was yours. Now
For me to try how: all I know of it
Is that Camillo was an honest man;
And why he left your court
You knew of his departure
What you have underta'en to do in's absence.
Sir
My life stands in the level of your dreams
Your actions are my dreams;
You had a bastard by Polixenes
Those of your fact are so--so past all truth:
Which to deny concerns more than avails; for as
Thy brat hath been cast out
Shalt feel our justice
Look for no less than death.
Sir
The bug which you would fright me with I seek.
To me can life be no commodity:
The crown and comfort of my life
And first-fruits of my body
I am barr'd
Starr'd most unluckily
Proclaimed a strumpet: with immodest hatred
The child-bed privilege denied
To women of all fashion; lastly
Here to this place
I have got strength of limit. Now
But yet hear this: mistake me not; no life
Upon surmises
But what your jealousies awake
'Tis rigor and not law. Your honours all
Apollo be my judge!
This your request
Is altogether just: therefore bring forth
Exeunt certain Officers
The Emperor of Russia was my father:
O that he were alive
His daughter's trial! that he did but see
The flatness of my misery
Of pity
Re-enter Officers
You here shall swear upon this sword of justice
Been both at Delphos
The seal'd-up oracle
Of great Apollo's priest; and that
Nor read the secrets in't.
All this we swear.
Break up the seals and read.
"[Reads]	Hermione is chaste;"
Polixenes blameless; Camillo a true subject; Leontes
a jealous tyrant; his innocent babe truly begotten;
and the king shall live without an heir
which is lost be not found.
Now blessed be the great Apollo!
Praised!
Hast thou read truth?
Ay
As it is here set down.
There is no truth at all i' the oracle:
The sessions shall proceed: this is mere falsehood.
Enter Servant
My lord the king
What is the business?
O sir
The prince your son
Of the queen's speed
How! gone!
Is dead.
Apollo's angry; and the heavens themselves
Do strike at my injustice.
HERMIONE swoons
How now there!
This news is mortal to the queen: look down
And see what death is doing.
Take her hence:
Her heart is but o'ercharged; she will recover:
I have too much believed mine own suspicion:
Beseech you
Some remedies for life.
Exeunt PAULINA and Ladies
Apollo
My great profaneness 'gainst thine oracle!
I'll reconcile me to Polixenes
For
To bloody thoughts and to revenge
Camillo for the minister to poison
My friend Polixenes: which had been done
My swift command
Reward did threaten and encourage him
And fill'd with honour
Unclasp'd my practise
Of all encertainties himself commended
Thorough my rust! and how his pity
Does my deeds make the blacker!
Re-enter PAULINA
Woe the while!
O
What fit is this
What studied torments
What wheels? racks? fires? what flaying? boiling?
In leads or oils? what old or newer torture
Must I receive
To taste of thy most worst? Thy tyranny
Together working with thy jealousies
For girls of nine
And then run mad indeed
Thy by-gone fooleries were but spices of it.
That thou betray'dst Polixenes
That did but show thee
And damnable ingrateful: nor was't much
The casting forth to crows thy baby-daughter
To be or none or little; though a devil
Would have shed water out of fire ere done't:
Nor is't directly laid to thee
Of the young prince
That could conceive a gross and foolish sire
Blemish'd his gracious dam: this is not
Not dropp'd down yet.
The higher powers forbid!
I say she's dead; I'll swear't. If word nor oath
Prevail not
Tincture or lustre in her lip
As I would do the gods. But
Do not repent these things
Than all thy woes can stir; therefore betake thee
To nothing but despair. A thousand knees
Ten thousand years together
In storm perpetual
To look that way thou wert.
Go on
Thou canst not speak too much; I have deserved
All tongues to talk their bitterest.
Say no more:
Howe'er the business goes
I' the boldness of your speech.
I am sorry for't:
All faults I make
The rashness of a woman: he is touch'd
To the noble heart. What's gone and what's past help
Should be past grief: do not receive affliction
At my petition; I beseech you
Let me be punish'd
Of what you should forget. Now
Sir
The love I bore your queen--lo
I'll speak of her no more
I'll not remember you of my own lord
Thou didst speak but well
When most the truth; which I receive much better
Than to be pitied of thee. Prithee
To the dead bodies of my queen and son:
One grave shall be for both: upon them shall
The causes of their death appear
Our shame perpetual. Once a day I'll visit
The chapel where they lie
Shall be my recreation: so long as nature
Will bear up with this exercise
I daily vow to use it. Come and lead me
Unto these sorrows.
Exeunt
SCENE III. Bohemia. A desert country near the sea.
Enter ANTIGONUS with a Child
Thou art perfect then
The deserts of Bohemia?
Ay
We have landed in ill time: the skies look grimly
And threaten present blusters. In my conscience
And frown upon 's.
Their sacred wills be done! Go
Look to thy bark: I'll not be long before
I call upon thee.
Make your best haste
Too far i' the land: 'tis like to be loud weather;
Besides
Of prey that keep upon't.
Go thou away:
I'll follow instantly.
I am glad at heart
To be so rid o' the business.
Exit
Come
I have heard
May walk again: if such thing be
Appear'd to me last night
So like a waking. To me comes a creature
I never saw a vessel of like sorrow
My cabin where I lay; thrice bow'd before me
Became two spouts: the fury spent
Did this break-from her: 'Good Antigonus
Of my poor babe
Is counted lost for ever
Put on thee by my lord
Thy wife Paulina more.' And so
She melted into air. Affrighted much
This was so and no slumber. Dreams are toys:
Yet for this once
Hermione hath suffer'd death
Apollo would
Of King Polixenes
Of its right father. Blossom
There lie
Which may
To loss and what may follow! Weep I cannot
To be by oath enjoin'd to this. Farewell!
The day frowns more and more: thou'rt like to have
A lullaby too rough: I never saw
The heavens so dim by day. A savage clamour!
Well may I get aboard! This is the chase:
I am gone for ever.
Exit
Enter a Shepherd
I would there were no age between sixteen and
three-and-twenty
rest; for there is nothing in the between but
getting wenches with child
these boiled brains of nineteen and two-and-twenty
hunt this weather? They have scared away two of my
best sheep
than the master: if any where I have them
the seaside
will what have we here! Mercy on 's
pretty barne! A boy or a child
pretty one; a very pretty one: sure
though I am not bookish
waiting-gentlewoman in the 'scape. This has been
some stair-work
behind-door-work: they were warmer that got this
than the poor thing is here. I'll take it up for
pity: yet I'll tarry till my son come; he hallooed
but even now. Whoa
Enter Clown
Hilloa
What
on when thou art dead and rotten
ailest thou
I have seen two such sights
but I am not to say it is a sea
sky: betwixt the firmament and it you cannot thrust
a bodkin's point.
Why
I would you did but see how it chafes
point. O
sometimes to see 'em
ship boring the moon with her main-mast
swallowed with yest and froth
cork into a hogshead. And then for the
land-service
shoulder-bone; how he cried to me for help and said
his name was Antigonus
end of the ship
it: but
sea mocked them; and how the poor gentleman roared
and the bear mocked him
the sea or weather.
Name of mercy
Now
sights: the men are not yet cold under water
the bear half dined on the gentleman: he's at it
now.
Would I had been by
I would you had been by the ship side
helped her: there your charity would have lacked footing.
Heavy matters! heavy matters! but look thee here
dying
thee; look thee
child! look thee here; take up
open't. So
rich by the fairies. This is some changeling:
open't. What's within
You're a made old man: if the sins of your youth
are forgiven you
This is fairy gold
with't
We are lucky
nothing but secrecy. Let my sheep go: come
boy
Go you the next way with your findings. I'll go see
if the bear be gone from the gentleman and how much
he hath eaten: they are never curst but when they
are hungry: if there be any of him left
it.
That's a good deed. If thou mayest discern by that
which is left of him what he is
sight of him.
Marry
'Tis a lucky day
Exeunt
ACT IV
SCENE I:
Enter Time
I
Of good and bad
To me or my swift passage
O'er sixteen years and leave the growth untried
Of that wide gap
To o'erthrow law and in one self-born hour
To plant and o'erwhelm custom. Let me pass
The same I am
Or what is now received: I witness to
The times that brought them in; so shall I do
To the freshest things now reigning and make stale
The glistering of this present
Now seems to it. Your patience this allowing
As you had slept between: Leontes leaving
That he shuts up himself
In fair Bohemia
I now name to you; and with speed so pace
To speak of Perdita
Equal with wondering: what of her ensues
I list not prophecy; but let Time's news
Be known when 'tis brought forth.
A shepherd's daughter
If never
He wishes earnestly you never may.
Exit
SCENE II. Bohemia. The palace of POLIXENES.
Enter POLIXENES and CAMILLO
I pray thee
'tis a sickness denying thee any thing; a death to
grant this.
It is fifteen years since I saw my country: though
I have for the most part been aired abroad
desire to lay my bones there. Besides
king
sorrows I might be some allay
think so
As thou lovest me
thy services by leaving me now: the need I have of
thee thine own goodness hath made; better not to
have had thee than thus to want thee: thou
made me businesses which none without thee can
sufficiently manage
them thyself or take away with thee the very
services thou hast done; which if I have not enough
considered
thankful to thee shall be my study
therein the heaping friendships. Of that fatal
country
naming punishes me with the remembrance of that
penitent
and children are even now to be afresh lamented.
Say to me
son? Kings are no less unhappy
being gracious
they have approved their virtues.
Sir
his happier affairs may be
have missingly noted
from court and is less frequent to his princely
exercises than formerly he hath appeared.
I have considered so much
care; so far that I have eyes under my service which
look upon his removedness; from whom I have this
intelligence
most homely shepherd; a man
very nothing
neighbours
I have heard
daughter of most rare note: the report of her is
extended more than can be thought to begin from such a cottage.
That's likewise part of my intelligence; but
fear
shalt accompany us to the place; where we will
appearing what we are
shepherd; from whose simplicity I think it not
uneasy to get the cause of my son's resort thither.
Prithee
lay aside the thoughts of Sicilia.
I willingly obey your command.
My best Camillo! We must disguise ourselves.
Exeunt
SCENE III. A road near the Shepherd's cottage.
Enter AUTOLYCUS
When daffodils begin to peer
For the red blood reigns in the winter's pale.
The white sheet bleaching on the hedge
Doth set my pugging tooth on edge;
For a quart of ale is a dish for a king.
The lark
I have served Prince Florizel and in my time
wore three-pile; but now I am out of service:
But shall I go mourn for that
The pale moon shines by night:
And when I wander here and there
If tinkers may have leave to live
My traffic is sheets; when the kite builds
lesser linen. My father named me Autolycus; who
being
a snapper-up of unconsidered trifles. With die and
drab I purchased this caparison
the silly cheat. Gallows and knock are too powerful
on the highway: beating and hanging are terrors to
me: for the life to come
of it. A prize! a prize!
Enter Clown
Let me see: every 'leven wether tods; every tod
yields pound and odd shilling; fifteen hundred
shorn. what comes the wool to?
[Aside]
If the springe hold
I cannot do't without counters. Let me see; what am
I to buy for our sheep-shearing feast? Three pound
of sugar
this sister of mine do with rice? But my father
hath made her mistress of the feast
on. She hath made me four and twenty nose-gays for
the shearers
ones; but they are most of them means and bases; but
one puritan amongst them
horn-pipes. I must have saffron to colour the warden
pies; mace; dates?--none
nutmegs
may beg; four pound of prunes
raisins o' the sun.
O that ever I was born!
Grovelling on the ground
I' the name of me--
O
then
Alack
on thee
O sir
than the stripes I have received
ones and millions.
Alas
great matter.
I am robbed
ta'en from me
me.
What
A footman
Indeed
has left with thee: if this be a horseman's coat
O
Alas
O
shoulder-blade is out.
How now! canst stand?
[Picking his pocket]
Softly
a charitable office.
Dost lack any money? I have a little money for thee.
No
a kinsman not past three quarters of a mile hence
any thing I want: offer me no money
that kills my heart.
What manner of fellow was he that robbed you?
A fellow
troll-my-dames; I knew him once a servant of the
prince: I cannot tell
virtues it was
His vices
out of the court: they cherish it to make it stay
there; and yet it will no more but abide.
Vices
hath been since an ape-bearer; then a
process-server
motion of the Prodigal Son
wife within a mile where my land and living lies;
and
settled only in rogue: some call him Autolycus.
Out upon him! prig
wakes
Very true
put me into this apparel.
Not a more cowardly rogue in all Bohemia: if you had
but looked big and spit at him
I must confess to you
false of heart that way; and that he knew
him.
How do you now?
Sweet sir
walk: I will even take my leave of you
softly towards my kinsman's.
Shall I bring thee on the way?
No
Then fare thee well: I must go buy spices for our
sheep-shearing.
Prosper you
Exit Clown
Your purse is not hot enough to purchase your spice.
I'll be with you at your sheep-shearing too: if I
make not this cheat bring out another and the
shearers prove sheep
put in the book of virtue!
Sings
Jog on
A merry heart goes all the day
Exit
SCENE IV. The Shepherd's cottage.
Enter FLORIZEL and PERDITA
These your unusual weeds to each part of you
Do give a life: no shepherdess
Peering in April's front. This your sheep-shearing
Is as a meeting of the petty gods
Sir
O
With a swain's wearing
In every mess have folly and the feeders
Digest it with a custom
To see you so attired
I bless the time
When my good falcon made her flight across
Thy father's ground.
Now Jove afford you cause!
To me the difference forges dread; your greatness
Hath not been used to fear. Even now I tremble
To think your father
How would he look
Vilely bound up? What would he say? Or how
Should I
The sternness of his presence?
Apprehend
Nothing but jollity. The gods themselves
The shapes of beasts upon them: Jupiter
Became a bull
A ram
Were never for a piece of beauty rarer
Run not before mine honour
Burn hotter than my faith.
O
Opposed
One of these two must be necessities
change this purpose
Thou dearest Perdita
The mirth o' the feast. Or I'll be thine
Mine own
I be not thine. To this I am most constant
Strangle such thoughts as these with any thing
That you behold the while. Your guests are coming:
Lift up your countenance
Of celebration of that nuptial which
We two have sworn shall come.
O lady Fortune
See
Address yourself to entertain them sprightly
Enter Shepherd
Fie
This day she was both pantler
Would sing her song and dance her turn; now here
On his shoulder
With labour and the thing she took to quench it
The hostess of the meeting: pray you
These unknown friends to's welcome; for it is
A way to make us better friends
Come
That which you are
[To POLIXENES]                  Sir
It is my father's will I should take on me
The hostess-ship o' the day.
To CAMILLO
You're welcome
Give me those flowers there
Seeming and savour all the winter long:
Grace and remembrance be to you both
Shepherdess
With flowers of winter.
Sir
Of trembling winter
flowers o' the season
Are our carnations and streak'd gillyvors
Our rustic garden's barren; and I care not
To get slips of them.
Wherefore
For I have heard it said
There is an art which in their piedness shares
With great creating nature.
Say there be;
Yet nature is made better by no mean
But nature makes that mean: so
Which you say adds to nature
That nature makes. You see
A gentler scion to the wildest stock
By bud of nobler race: this is an art
Which does mend nature
The art itself is nature.
So it is.
Then make your garden rich in gillyvors
I'll not put
The dibble in earth to set one slip of them;
No more than were I painted I would wish
This youth should say 'twere well and only therefore
Desire to breed by me. Here's flowers for you;
Hot lavender
The marigold
And with him rises weeping: these are flowers
Of middle summer
To men of middle age. You're very welcome.
I should leave grazing
Out
You'd be so lean
Would blow you through and through.
Now
Become your time of day; and yours
Your maidenheads growing: O Proserpina
From Dis's waggon! daffodils
The winds of March with beauty; violets dim
Or Cytherea's breath; pale primroses
That die unmarried
Bight Phoebus in his strength--a malady
Most incident to maids; bold oxlips and
The crown imperial; lilies of all kinds
What
No
Not like a corse; or if
Methinks I play as I have seen them do
In Whitsun pastorals: sure this robe of mine
Does change my disposition.
What you do
Still betters what is done. When you speak
I'ld have you do it ever: when you sing
A wave o' the sea
Nothing but that; move still
O Doricles
I think you have
As little skill to fear as I have purpose
To put you to't. But come; our dance
Your hand
I'll swear for 'em.
This is the prettiest low-born lass that ever
Ran on the green-sward: nothing she does or seems
But smacks of something greater than herself
He tells her something
That makes her blood look out: good sooth
The queen of curds and cream.
Come on
Mopsa must be your mistress: marry
Now
Not a word
Come
Music. Here a dance of Shepherds and Shepherdesses
Pray
Which dances with your daughter?
They call him Doricles; and boasts himself
To have a worthy feeding: but I have it
Upon his own report and I believe it;
He looks like sooth. He says he loves my daughter:
I think so too; for never gazed the moon
Upon the water as he'll stand and read
As 'twere my daughter's eyes: and
I think there is not half a kiss to choose
Who loves another best.
She dances featly.
So she does any thing; though I report it
Do light upon her
Which he not dreams of.
Enter Servant
O master
door
pipe; no
several tunes faster than you'll tell money; he
utters them as he had eaten ballads and all men's
ears grew to his tunes.
He could never come better; he shall come in. I
love a ballad but even too well
matter merrily set down
indeed and sung lamentably.
He hath songs for man or woman
milliner can so fit his customers with gloves: he
has the prettiest love-songs for maids; so without
bawdry
burthens of dildos and fadings

To FLORIZEL
How now
Your heart is full of something that does take
Your mind from feasting. Sooth
And handed love as you do
To load my she with knacks: I would have ransack'd

To her acceptance; you have let him go
And nothing marted with him. If your lass
Interpretation should abuse and call this
Your lack of love or bounty

Knows he of this?
He neither does nor shall.
Methinks a father
Is at the nuptial of his son a guest
That best becomes the table. Pray you once more
Of reasonable affairs? is he not stupid
With age and altering rheums? can he speak? hear?
Know man from man? dispute his own estate?
Lies he not bed-rid? and again does nothing
But what he did being childish?
No
He has his health and ampler strength indeed
Than most have of his age.

'Twixt his unkindness and his kindness; the one
He chides to hell and bids the other grow
Faster than thought or time.

Hold up before him?
Sent by the king your father
