ACT V
SCENE I. A room in LEONTES' palace.
Enter LEONTES
Sir
A saint-like sorrow: no fault could you make
More penitence than done trespass: at the last
With them forgive yourself.
Whilst I remember
Her and her virtues
My blemishes in them
The wrong I did myself; which was so much
Destroy'd the sweet'st companion that e'er man
Bred his hopes out of.
TRUE
If
Would be unparallel'd.
I think so. Kill'd!
She I kill'd! I did so: but thou strikest me
Sorely
Upon thy tongue as in my thought: now
Not at all
You might have spoken a thousand things that would
Have done the time more benefit and graced
Your kindness better.
You are one of those
Would have him wed again.
If you would not so
Of his most sovereign name; consider little
What dangers
Incertain lookers on. What were more holy
Than to rejoice the former queen is well?
What holier than
With a sweet fellow to't?
There is none worthy
Will have fulfill'd their secret purposes;
For has not the divine Apollo said
Till his lost child be found? which that it shall
As my Antigonus to break his grave
And come again to me; who
My lord should to the heavens be contrary
To LEONTES
Care not for issue;
The crown will find an heir: great Alexander
Left his to the worthiest; so his successor
Was like to be the best.
Good Paulina
Had squared me to thy counsel! then
And left them
More rich for what they yielded.
Thou speak'st truth.
No more such wives; therefore
Again possess her corpse
Had she such power
She had; and would incense me
To murder her I married.
I should so.
Were I the ghost that walk'd
Her eye
You chose her; then I'ld shriek
Should rift to hear me; and the words that follow'd
Should be 'Remember mine.'
Stars
I'll have no wife
Will you swear
Never to marry but by my free leave?
Never
Then
You tempt him over-much.
Unless another
Good madam
I have done.
Yet
To choose you a queen: she shall not be so young
As was your former; but she shall be such
As
To see her in your arms.
My true Paulina
That
Shall be when your first queen's again in breath;
Never till then.
Enter a Gentleman
One that gives out himself Prince Florizel
The fairest I have yet beheld
To your high presence.
What with him? he comes not
Like to his father's greatness: his approach
'Tis not a visitation framed
By need and accident. What train?
But few
His princess
Ay
O Hermione
Above a better gone
Give way to what's seen now! Sir
Have said and writ so
Is colder than that theme
Flow'd with her beauty once: 'tis shrewdly ebb'd
Pardon
The one I have almost forgot
The other
Of all professors else
Of who she but bid follow.
How! not women?
Women will love her
More worth than any man; men
The rarest of all women.
Go
Yourself
Exeunt CLEOMENES and others
He thus should steal upon us.
Had our prince
Well with this lord: there was not full a month
Between their births.
Prithee
He dies to me again when talk'd of: sure
Will bring me to consider that which may
Unfurnish me of reason. They are come.
Re-enter CLEOMENES and others
Your mother was most true to wedlock
For she did print your royal father off
By us perform'd before. Most dearly welcome!
And your fair princess
I lost a couple
Might thus have stood begetting wonder as
You
All mine own folly--the society
Once more to look on him.
By his command
Have I here touch'd Sicilia and from him
Give you all greetings that a king
Which waits upon worn times hath something seized
His wish'd ability
The lands and waters 'twixt your throne and his
Measured to look upon you; whom he loves--
He bade me say so--more than all the sceptres
And those that bear them living.
O my brother
Afresh within me
Of my behind-hand slackness. Welcome hither
Exposed this paragon to the fearful usage
The adventure of her person?
Good my lord
Where the warlike Smalus
Most royal sir
His tears proclaim'd his
For visiting your highness: my best train
I have from your Sicilian shores dismiss'd;
Who for Bohemia bend
Not only my success in Libya
Here where we are.
The blessed gods
Purge all infection from our air whilst you
Do climate here! You have a holy father
For which the heavens
Worthy his goodness. What might I have been
Enter a Lord
Most noble sir
Desires you to attach his son
His dignity and duty both cast off--
Fled from his father
A shepherd's daughter.
Where's Bohemia? speak.
Here in your city; I now came from him:
I speak amazedly; and it becomes
My marvel and my message. To your court
Whiles he was hastening
The father of this seeming lady and
Her brother
With this young prince.
Camillo has betray'd me;
Whose honour and whose honesty till now
Endured all weathers.
Lay't so to his charge:
He's with the king your father.
Who? Camillo?
Camillo
Has these poor men in question. Never saw I
Wretches so quake: they kneel
Forswear themselves as often as they speak:
Bohemia stops his ears
With divers deaths in death.
O my poor father!
The heaven sets spies upon us
Our contract celebrated.
You are married?
We are not
The stars
The odds for high and low's alike.
My lord
She is
That 'once' I see by your good father's speed
Will come on very slowly. I am sorry
Where you were tied in duty
Your choice is not so rich in worth as beauty
Dear
Though Fortune
Hath she to change our loves. Beseech you
Than I do now: with thought of such affections
My father will grant precious things as trifles.
Would he do so
Sir
'Fore your queen died
Than what you look on now.
I thought of her
To FLORIZEL
But your petition
Is yet unanswer'd. I will to your father:
Your honour not o'erthrown by your desires
I now go toward him; therefore follow me
And mark what way I make: come
Exeunt
SCENE II. Before LEONTES' palace.
Enter AUTOLYCUS and a Gentleman
Beseech you
I was by at the opening of the fardel
shepherd deliver the manner how he found it:
whereupon
commanded out of the chamber; only this methought I
heard the shepherd say
I would most gladly know the issue of it.
I make a broken delivery of the business; but the
changes I perceived in the king and Camillo were
very notes of admiration: they seemed almost
staring on one another
eyes; there was speech in their dumbness
in their very gesture; they looked as they had heard
of a world ransomed
passion of wonder appeared in them; but the wisest
beholder
say if the importance were joy or sorrow; but in the
extremity of the one
Enter another Gentleman
Here comes a gentleman that haply knows more.
The news
Nothing but bonfires: the oracle is fulfilled; the
king's daughter is found: such a deal of wonder is
broken out within this hour that ballad-makers
cannot be able to express it.
Enter a third Gentleman
Here comes the Lady Paulina's steward: he can
deliver you more. How goes it now
which is called true is so like an old tale
the verity of it is in strong suspicion: has the king
found his heir?
Most true
circumstance: that which you hear you'll swear you
see
of Queen Hermione's
know to be his character
creature in resemblance of the mother
of nobleness which nature shows above her breeding
certainty to be the king's daughter. Did you see
the meeting of the two kings?
No.
Then have you lost a sight
joy crown another
seemed sorrow wept to take leave of them
joy waded in tears. There was casting up of eyes
distraction that they were to be known by garment
himself for joy of his found daughter
joy were now become a loss
embraces his son-in-law; then again worries he his
daughter with clipping her; now he thanks the old
shepherd
conduit of many kings' reigns. I never heard of such
another encounter
and undoes description to do it.
What
hence the child?
Like an old tale still
rehearse
open. He was torn to pieces with a bear: this
avouches the shepherd's son; who has not only his
innocence
handkerchief and rings of his that Paulina knows.
What became of his bark and his followers?
Wrecked the same instant of their master's death and
in the view of the shepherd: so that all the
instruments which aided to expose the child were
even then lost when it was found. But O
combat that 'twixt joy and sorrow was fought in
Paulina! She had one eye declined for the loss of
her husband
fulfilled: she lifted the princess from the earth
her to her heart that she might no more be in danger
of losing.
The dignity of this act was worth the audience of
kings and princes; for by such was it acted.
One of the prettiest touches of all and that which
angled for mine eyes
the fish
death
confessed and lamented by the king
attentiveness wounded his daughter; till
sign of dolour to another
I would fain say
heart wept blood. Who was most marble there changed
colour; some swooned
could have seen 't
Are they returned to the court?
No: the princess hearing of her mother's statue
years in doing and now newly performed by that rare
Italian master
eternity and could put breath into his work
beguile Nature of her custom
ape: he so near to Hermione hath done Hermione that
they say one would speak to her and stand in hope of
answer: thither with all greediness of affection
are they gone
I thought she had some great matter there in hand;
for she hath privately twice or thrice a day
since the death of Hermione
house. Shall we thither and with our company piece
the rejoicing?
Who would be thence that has the benefit of access?
every wink of an eye some new grace will be born:
our absence makes us unthrifty to our knowledge.
Let's along.
Exeunt Gentlemen
Now
man and his son aboard the prince: told him I heard
them talk of a fardel and I know not what: but he
at that time
sea-sick
weather continuing
undiscovered. But 'tis all one to me; for had I
been the finder out of this secret
have relished among my other discredits.
Enter Shepherd and Clown
Here come those I have done good to against my will
Come
daughters will be all gentlemen born.
You are well met
this other day
See you these clothes? say you see them not and
think me still no gentleman born: you were best say
these robes are not gentlemen born: give me the
lie
I know you are now
Ay
And so have I
So you have: but I was a gentleman born before my
father; for the king's son took me by the hand
called me brother; and then the two kings called my
father brother; and then the prince my brother and
the princess my sister called my father father; and
so we wept
tears that ever we shed.
We may live
Ay; or else 'twere hard luck
preposterous estate as we are.
I humbly beseech you
faults I have committed to your worship and to give
me your good report to the prince my master.
Prithee
gentlemen.
Thou wilt amend thy life?
Ay
Give me thy hand: I will swear to the prince thou
art as honest a true fellow as any is in Bohemia.
You may say it
Not swear it
franklins say it
How if it be false
If it be ne'er so false
it in the behalf of his friend: and I'll swear to
the prince thou art a tall fellow of thy hands and
that thou wilt not be drunk; but I know thou art no
tall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt be
drunk: but I'll swear it
be a tall fellow of thy hands.
I will prove so
Ay
wonder how thou darest venture to be drunk
being a tall fellow
and the princes
queen's picture. Come
good masters.
Exeunt
SCENE III. A chapel in PAULINA'S house.
Enter LEONTES
O grave and good Paulina
That I have had of thee!
What
You have paid home: but that you have vouchsafed
Heirs of your kingdoms
My life may last to answer.
O Paulina
To see the statue of our queen: your gallery
Have we pass'd through
In many singularities; but we saw not
That which my daughter came to look upon
As she lived peerless
Or hand of man hath done; therefore I keep it
Lonely
To see the life as lively mock'd as ever
Still sleep mock'd death: behold
PAULINA draws a curtain
I like your silence
Your wonder: but yet speak; first
Her natural posture!
Chide me
Thou art Hermione; or rather
In thy not chiding
As infancy and grace. But yet
So aged as this seems.
O
So much the more our carver's excellence;
Which lets go by some sixteen years and makes her
As she lived now.
As now she might have done
Now piercing to my soul. O
I am ashamed: does not the stone rebuke me
For being more stone than it? O royal piece
My evils conjured to remembrance and
From thy admiring daughter took the spirits
And give me leave
I kneel and then implore her blessing. Lady
O
The statue is but newly fix'd
My lord
Did ever so long live; no sorrow
But kill'd itself much sooner.
Dear my brother
To take off so much grief from you as he
Will piece up in himself.
Indeed
Would thus have wrought you
I'ld not have show'd it.
Do not draw the curtain.
No longer shall you gaze on't
May think anon it moves.
Let be
Would I were dead
What was he that did make it? See
Did verily bear blood?
Masterly done:
The very life seems warm upon her lip.
The fixture of her eye has motion in't
I'll draw the curtain:
My lord's almost so far transported that
He'll think anon it lives.
O sweet Paulina
No settled senses of the world can match
The pleasure of that madness. Let 't alone.
I am sorry
I could afflict you farther.
Do
For this affliction has a taste as sweet
As any cordial comfort. Still
Could ever yet cut breath? Let no man mock me
Good my lord
The ruddiness upon her lip is wet;
You'll mar it if you kiss it
With oily painting. Shall I draw the curtain?
No
So long could I
Stand by
Either forbear
For more amazement. If you can behold it
And take you by the hand; but then you'll think--
Which I protest against--I am assisted
By wicked powers.
What you can make her do
To make her speak as move.
It is required
You do awake your faith. Then all stand still;
On: those that think it is unlawful business
I am about
Proceed:
No foot shall stir.
Music
Music
'Tis time; descend; be stone no more; approach;
Strike all that look upon with marvel. Come
Dear life redeems you. You perceive she stirs:
HERMIONE comes down
Start not; her actions shall be holy as
You hear my spell is lawful: do not shun her
Until you see her die again; for then
You kill her double. Nay
When she was young you woo'd her; now in age
Is she become the suitor?
O
If this be magic
Lawful as eating.
She embraces him.
She hangs about his neck:
If she pertain to life let her speak too.
Ay
That she is living
Like an old tale: but it appears she lives
Please you to interpose
And pray your mother's blessing. Turn
Our Perdita is found.
You gods
And from your sacred vials pour your graces
Upon my daughter's head! Tell me
Where hast thou been preserved? where lived? how found
Thy father's court? for thou shalt hear that I
Gave hope thou wast in being
Myself to see the issue.
There's time enough for that;
Lest they desire upon this push to trouble
Your joys with like relation. Go together
Partake to every one. I
My mate
O
Thou shouldst a husband take by my consent
But how
A prayer upon her grave. I'll not seek far--
For him
An honourable husband. Come
Is richly noted and here justified
By us
What! look upon my brother: both your pardons
My ill suspicion. This is your son-in-law
Each one demand an answer to his part
Perform'd in this wide gap of time since first
We were dissever'd: hastily lead away.
Exeunt
